
402 
FXUS64 KLZK 312049
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
245 PM CST FRI DEC 31 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
COLD FRONT TO THE NORTH IN NORTHERN MISSOURI. THE FRONT WILL NOT 
MOVE SOUTH MUCH DUE TO UPPER FLOW...SO WARM TEMPERATURES WILL 
CONTINUE THROUGH THE SHORT TERM.

SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT CONTINUES BRINGING WEAK UPPER WAVES INTO THE 
REGION. ISOLATED SHOWERS/SPRINKLES ACROSS THE WEST TODAY...BUT ONLY 
TRACE AMOUNTS. WITH SOUTH WINDS...PORTIONS OF THE WEST WARMED ABOVE 
70 DEGREES.

WEAK SHORTWAVES WILL INTERACT WITH FRONT THE WILL PRETTY MUCH STALL 
TO THE NORTH OF THE STATE. SLIGHT CHANCES OF RAIN TONIGHT...BEFORE A 
STRONGER WAVE MOVES IN NEW YEARS DAY WITH A CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS.

RAINFALL POTENTIAL INCREASES SUNDAY INTO MONDAY. ARKANSAS REMAINS IN 
WARM AIR AS THE STALLED FRONT MOVES NORTH AS A WARM FRONT. INCREASED 
RAIN CHANCES FOR THIS TIME FRAME...BUT WILL WAIT UNTIL MODELS COME 
TO A BETTER SOLUTION BEFORE MENTIONING HEAVY RAIN.
&&

.LONG TERM....TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
MODELS ON GENERALLY GOOD AGREEMENT IN THE SYNOPTIC SCALE WITH THE 
USUAL DIFFERENCES IN TIMING AND INTENSITY THAT ALWAYS SHOW UP IN THE 
MEDIUM RANGE. WILL BASICALLY FOLLOW THE LEAD OF THE GFS SOLUTION 
THIS AFTERNOON WHICH IS SHOWING BETTER RUN TO RUN CONSISTENCY BUT 
ALL MODELS PICKING UP ON A COOLING TREND LATER IN THE PERIOD.

SPLIT FLOW REGIME CONTINUES EARLY IN THE PERIOD WITH NORTHERN BRANCH 
KEEPING ALL THE VERY COLD AIR BOTTLED UP TO THE NORTH. SOUTHERN 
STREAM WILL REMAIN ACTIVE WITH SEVERAL SYSTEMS TO DEAL WITH. MODELS 
REMAIN CONSISTENT WITH UPPER RIDGING IN THE EASTERN GULF AND STRONG 
SHORT WAVE ENERGY SLIDING DOWN THE WEST COAST WHICH IN TIME CARVES 
OUT A SIGNIFICANT LOOKING UPPER LOW. RESULTANT UPPER FLOW WILL BE 
FROM THE SOUTHWEST KEEPING TEMPERATURES WELL ABOVE NORMAL TUESDAY. 
WILL CONTINUE HIGH SCATTERED POPS HERE AS WARM AIR ADVECTION PATTERN 
CONTINUES.

SOUTHEAST CONUS RIDGE MOVES TO THE EAST ALLOWING A COLD FRONT TO 
MOVE THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT AND EARLY WEDNESDAY. WILL CARRY POPS 
UNTIL THE FRONT PASSAGES EARLY WEDNESDAY. WHILE TEMPERATURES WILL BE 
COOLER...AIR MASS BEHIND THE FRONT NOT OVERLY COLD. FLOW ALSO 
REMAINS ZONAL SO NO EXTREME COOL DOWNS EXPECTED. NUMERICAL GUIDANCE 
SHOWING QUITE THE COOL DOWN LATE IN THE PERIOD BUT I AM NOT SOLD 
YET. AFOREMENTIONED UPPER LOW DIGS INTO THE SOUTHWEST CONUS WITH A 
RETURN TO SOUTHWEST FLOW LATE IN THE PERIOD. HIGH PRESSURE WILL KEEP 
CONDITIONS DRY AFTER FROPA. REMNANTS OF LOW ARRIVE JUST BEYOND THE 
DAY SEVEN PERIOD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    59  66  57  65 /  20  40  40  40 
HARRISON AR       55  63  54  62 /  20  40  40  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    59  67  58  65 /  20  40  40  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     60  67  58  66 /  20  40  40  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  55  63  54  62 /  20  40  40  40 
MONTICELLO AR     60  68  59  67 /  20  40  40  40 
SEARCY AR         58  65  56  64 /  20  40  40  40 
MOUNT IDA AR      59  67  58  64 /  20  40  40  40 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   58  65  56  63 /  20  40  40  40 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

SHOWING QUITE THE COOL DOWN LATE IN THE PERIOD BUT I AM NOT SOLD 
YET. AFOREMENTIONED UPPER LOW DIGS INTO THE SOUTHWEST CONUS WITH A 
RETURN TO SOUTHWEST FLOW LATE IN THE PERIOD. HIGH PRESSURE WILL KEEP

DAY SEVEN PERIOD.

58/56





687 
FXUS64 KLZK 311613
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1015 AM CST FRI DEC 31 2004

.DISCUSSION...
QUICK UPDATE TO TWEAK SKY COVER AND HOURLY TEMP GRIDS. LOW CLOUDS 
WILL HANG IN TODAY...ALTHOUGH A FEW BREAKS WILL BE POSSIBLE. 
SOUTHERLY WINDS WILL CONTINUE...BUT TEMPERATURES WILL ONLY BE A 
COUPLE OF DEGREES WARMER THAN THURSDAY...EVEN AFTER THE WARM START 
THIS MORNING. ALL IN ALL...FORECAST IN GOOD SHAPE WITH ONLY MINOR 
CHANGES MADE FOR THIS AFTERNOON.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 315 AM CST FRI DEC 31 2004

MUCH ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES WILL BE THE RULE IN THE SHORT TERM. 
SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL CONTINUE TO BRING A SERIES OF WEAK H5 
SHORT WAVES ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA INTO EARLY NEXT WEEK. GFS IS 
MUCH MORE GUNG-HO WITH MOISTURE THAN EITHER THE NGM OR ETA...AND 
LOOKS TO BE A LITTLE OVERDONE. WILL USE A COMPROMISE OF THE MODELS. 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THE FORECAST FOR TODAY...THEN INCREASE POPS TO 
30-40 PERCENT OVER THE WEEKEND. MOISTURE WILL SHOW SOME INCREASES BY 
MONDAY...SO WENT WITH GENERALLY 50 PERCENT POPS OVER THE FORECAST 
AREA ON MONDAY.

EXTENDED LOOKS TO BE FAIRLY ACTIVE...CHARACTERIZED BY 
STALLING/WOBBLING SURFACE BOUNDARIES AND SEVERAL UPPER LEVEL SYSTEMS 
MOVING ACROSS. SURFACE AND UPPER FLOW WILL REMAIN LARGELY OUT OF THE 
SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST RESPECTIVELY...ALLOWING FOR GULF AND PACIFIC 
MOISTURE TO STREAM UP OVER THE MID SOUTH. WITH STRONG H5 RIDGE IN 
PLACE OVER THE SERN PTN OF THE CONUS...ANY SURFACE SYSTEMS TRYING TO 
MOVE THROUGH WILL BE HELD BACK...WOBBLING AROUND THE MID 
SOUTH/SOUTHERN PLAINS FOR SEVERAL DAYS. 

WITH WARM ADVECTION PATTERN REMAINING STRONG OVER THE AREA...
TEMPERATURES WILL BE ABOVE NORMAL FOR EARLY JANUARY. THE OVER 
ABUNDANCE OF CLOUD COVER COULD WREAK HAVOC ON TEMPERATURE 
FORECASTS...SO CONFIDENCE IN THE NUMBERS ISN/T EXACTLY SKY HIGH. 
WITH THIS PATTERN...ONE THING THAT CONCERNS ME IS RAINFALL 
POTENTIAL. DEPENDING ON POSITION OF UPPER RIDGE OVR SERN CONUS AND 
SPEED OF SFC SYSTEMS MOVING INTO THE MIDSOUTH...RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 
1 TO 2 INCHES ARE A DISTINCT POSSIBILITY IN THE MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH 
TUESDAY NIGHT TIME FRAME. TIMING THIS FAR OUT IS ALWAYS A 
HEADACHE...BUT IT IS SOMETHING THAT WILL NEED TO BE WATCHED. 

WET PATTERN LOOKS TO FINALLY COME TO AN END ON WEDNESDAY...AS SERN 
RIDGING BREAKS DOWN AND ALLOWS COLD FRONT TO COME ON THROUGH THE 
STATE. STRONG DRY INTRUSION OF CONTINENTAL AIR SHOULD ACT TO CLEAR 
THINGS OUT. HOWEVER...WITH UPPER FLOW STILL REMAINING LARGELY 
ZONAL...DON/T LOOK FOR A SIGNIFICANT COOLDOWN ANY TIME SOON.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

ISSUED AT 315 AM CST FRI DEC 31 2004

MUCH ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES WILL BE THE RULE IN THE SHORT TERM. 
SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL CONTINUE TO BRING A SERIES OF WEAK H5

SOUTH/SOUTHERN PLAINS FOR SEVERAL DAYS.

TEMPERATURES WILL BE ABOVE NORMAL FOR EARLY JANUARY. THE OVER 
ABUNDANCE OF CLOUD COVER COULD WREAK HAVOC ON TEMPERATURE 
FORECASTS...SO CONFIDENCE IN THE NUMBERS ISN/T EXACTLY SKY HIGH.

POTENTIAL. DEPENDING ON POSITION OF UPPER RIDGE OVR SERN CONUS AND 
SPEED OF SFC SYSTEMS MOVING INTO THE MIDSOUTH...RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 
1 TO 2 INCHES ARE A DISTINCT POSSIBILITY IN THE MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH 
TUESDAY NIGHT TIME FRAME. TIMING THIS FAR OUT IS ALWAYS A 
HEADACHE...BUT IT IS SOMETHING THAT WILL NEED TO BE WATCHED. 

WET PATTERN LOOKS TO FINALLY COME TO AN END ON WEDNESDAY...AS SERN 
RIDGING BREAKS DOWN AND ALLOWS COLD FRONT TO COME ON THROUGH THE 
STATE. STRONG DRY INTRUSION OF CONTINENTAL AIR SHOULD ACT TO CLEAR 
THINGS OUT. HOWEVER...WITH UPPER FLOW STILL REMAINING LARGELY 
ZONAL...DON/T LOOK FOR A SIGNIFICANT COOLDOWN ANY TIME SOON.

EXTENDED LOOKS TO BE FAIRLY ACTIVE...CHARACTERIZED BY 
STALLING/WOBBLING SURFACE BOUNDARIES AND SEVERAL UPPER LEVEL SYSTEMS 
MOVING ACROSS. SURFACE AND UPPER FLOW WILL REMAIN LARGELY OUT OF THE

RIDGING BREAKS DOWN AND ALLOWS COLD FRONT TO COME ON THROUGH THE 
STATE. STRONG DRY INTRUSION OF CONTINENTAL AIR SHOULD ACT TO CLEAR 
THINGS OUT. HOWEVER...WITH UPPER FLOW STILL REMAINING LARGELY 
ZONAL...DON/T LOOK FOR A SIGNIFICANT COOLDOWN ANY TIME SOON. 

THANKS TO WFO MEMPHIS FOR COLLABORATION THIS MORNING. 
&&

22/57


989 
FXUS64 KLZK 302031
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 PM CST THU DEC 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
GUIDANCE HAS BEEN CONSISTENT IN SHOWING ARCTIC AIR BOTTLED UP WELL
TO THE NORTH OF ARKANSAS. REGION LEFT WITH WARM/MOIST SUBTROPICAL
FLOW FROM THE SOUTHWEST...AND WELL ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES.

TONIGHT/FRIDAY...MOISTURE RATHER SHALLOW...SO CHANCES FOR
PRECIPITATION LOW AT THIS TIME.

PRECIPITATION CHANCES WILL GO UP OVER THE WEEKEND AS SYSTEMS
ALOFT IN SOUTHWEST FLOW INTERACT WITH STALLED FRONT NEAR
ARKANSAS/MISSOURI BORDER. WITH DEEPER MOISTURE...COULD HAVE
THUNDER INSTEAD OF SPRINKLES/LIGHT SHOWERS AS NOTED DURING THE
FIRST 24 HOURS OF THE FORECAST.

AS SHORT TERM CLOSES...APPEARS THAT ARCTIC AIR FINALLY MAKING
ITS WAY THROUGH THE PLAINS. ARCTIC HIGH THAT HAS BEEN SITTING
IN CANADA WILL BEGIN SURGING TO THE SOUTH. THIS AIR WILL ARRIVE
IN ARKANSAS DURING THE LONG TERM.(46)
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL CONTINUE BRINGING SHORTWAVES THROUGH THE REGION
AND THE CONTINUED CHANCE OF RAIN. HOWEVER...COLD FRONT LOOKS TO MOVE
THROUGH THE STATE WEDNESDAY...WITH STRONG HIGH PRESSURE BEHIND IT.
THIS WILL USHER IN COOLER AIR...AND RETURN TEMPS TO NEAR NORMAL.
HELD OFF ON GOING AS COLD AS GUIDANCE...BUT TRENDED TEMPERATURES
COOLER.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    56  68  56  65 /  20  20  30  40
HARRISON AR       52  67  52  62 /  20  20  30  40
HOT SPRINGS AR    57  69  57  66 /  20  20  30  40
PINE BLUFF AR     57  69  57  66 /  20  20  30  40
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  51  66  52  62 /  20  20  30  40
MONTICELLO AR     58  70  58  67 /  20  20  30  40
SEARCY AR         55  68  55  64 /  20  20  30  40
MOUNT IDA AR      58  69  56  66 /  20  20  30  40
RUSSELLVILLE AR   56  68  55  64 /  20  20  30  40
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46/58





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 302031
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 PM CST THU DEC 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
GUIDANCE HAS BEEN CONSISTENT IN SHOWING ARCTIC AIR BOTTLED UP WELL
TO THE NORTH OF ARKANSAS. REGION LEFT WITH WARM/MOIST SUBTROPICAL
FLOW FROM THE SOUTHWEST...AND WELL ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES.

TONIGHT/FRIDAY...MOISTURE RATHER SHALLOW...SO CHANCES FOR
PRECIPITATION LOW AT THIS TIME.

PRECIPITATION CHANCES WILL GO UP OVER THE WEEKEND AS SYSTEMS
ALOFT IN SOUTHWEST FLOW INTERACT WITH STALLED FRONT NEAR
ARKANSAS/MISSOURI BORDER. WITH DEEPER MOISTURE...COULD HAVE
THUNDER INSTEAD OF SPRINKLES/LIGHT SHOWERS AS NOTED DURING THE
FIRST 24 HOURS OF THE FORECAST.

AS SHORT TERM CLOSES...APPEARS THAT ARCTIC AIR FINALLY MAKING
ITS WAY THROUGH THE PLAINS. ARCTIC HIGH THAT HAS BEEN SITTING
IN CANADA WILL BEGIN SURGING TO THE SOUTH. THIS AIR WILL ARRIVE
IN ARKANSAS DURING THE LONG TERM.(46)
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL CONTINUE BRINGING SHORTWAVES THROUGH THE REGION
AND THE CONTINUED CHANCE OF RAIN. HOWEVER...COLD FRONT LOOKS TO MOVE
THROUGH THE STATE WEDNESDAY...WITH STRONG HIGH PRESSURE BEHIND IT.
THIS WILL USHER IN COOLER AIR...AND RETURN TEMPS TO NEAR NORMAL.
HELD OFF ON GOING AS COLD AS GUIDANCE...BUT TRENDED TEMPERATURES
COOLER.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    56  68  56  65 /  20  20  30  40
HARRISON AR       52  67  52  62 /  20  20  30  40
HOT SPRINGS AR    57  69  57  66 /  20  20  30  40
PINE BLUFF AR     57  69  57  66 /  20  20  30  40

299 
FXUS64 KLZK 301001
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CST THU DEC 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY
WARM AIR HAS ESTABLISHED ITSELF ACROSS THE AREA AS SOUTHERLY WINDS CONTINUE
AROUND A HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM IN THE SOUTHEAST AND WEAK UPPER 
RIDGING IS OVER THE AREA. A SHORT WAVE MOVING INTO THE NORTHERN 
PLAINS WILL CONTINUE TO DO SO TODAY. THE MAIN EFFECTS WILL BE FAR 
ENOUGH AWAY TO NOT HAVE A SIGNIFICANT EFFECT ON THE WEATHER. AREAS
OF FOG DEVELOPED OVERNIGHT BUT HAVE NOT SUSTAINED THEMSELVES. WILL
MENTION AREAS OF FOG EARLY THIS MORNING. ALSO INCREASED MOISTURE
MAY BE ENOUGH TO SQEEZE OUT SOME DRIZZLE DURING THE MORNING. WITH
THE WEAK SHORT WAVE MOVING IN LATER...PUT IN A SLIGHT CHANCE OF 
SHOWERS FOR THIS AFTERNOON. WILL CONTINUE WITH BASICALLY A SLIGHT 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS THROUGH FRIDAY WITH THE BEST CHANCE OF RAIN
SHIFTING TO THE SOUTH ON FRIDAY. ANOTHER SHORT WAVE APPROACHES
FRIDAY NIGHT AND SATURDAY AND MOISTURE MOVES BACKL OVER THE ENTIRE
AREA. CONTINUED CHANCE POPS FROM FRIDAY NIGHT ON AND MENTIONED 
THUNDER AS THE AIR MAY BECOME MORE UNSTABLE ALTHOUGH OVERALL
INSTABILITY WILL NOT BE REAL GREAT. STRONG SURFACE LOW IN THE 
NORTHERN PLAINS TODAY WILL RESULT IN RATHER STRONG WINDS ESPECIALLY
IN THE NORTH. WILL GO WITH A LAKE WIND ADVISORY IN THE NORTH FROM
MID MORNING THROUGH THE AFTERNOON. THE GRADIENT SLACKENS TONIGHT AS
THE LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM MOVES AWAY FROM THE AREA. TEMPS WILL BE 
ABOVE NORMAL WITH MINS MOSTLY IN THE 50S AND MAXES IN THE 60S
AND A FEW PLACES POSSIBLY REACHING NEAR 70.   
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL CONTINUE INTO NEXT WEEK WITH SEVERAL SHORT
WAVES MOVING THROUGH IN THEM. WILL NEED TO KEEP CHANCES OF SHOWERS
AND THUNDERSTORMS GOING THROUGH MOST OF THE EXTENDED. MODELS 
CONTINUE TO DANCE AROUND INCONSISTENTLY WITH AN ARCTIC OUTBREAK TO
THE NORTH. THE UPPER AIR PATTERN REMAINS GENERALLY UNFAVORABLE FOR 
THE ARCTIC AIR TO REACH THIS FAR SOUTH. IT DOES LOOK LIKE A 
SIGNIFICANT UPPER TROF DOES MOVE PAST THE AREA ABOUT WEDNESDAY AND
THIS WOULD BUCKLE THE FLOW ENOUGH TO ALLOW THE ARCTIC AIR TO MOVE
DOWN INTO THE AREA. DID TREND TOWARD COOLER AND DRIER WEATHER TOWARD
THE END OF THE PERIOD BUT UNCERTAINTY REMAINS HIGH AND THIS WILL
LIKELY CHANGE SOME MORE BEFORE IT GETS HERE.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    67  54  66  53 /  20  30  10  30 
HARRISON AR       65  48  66  49 /  20  20  10  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    67  55  67  53 /  20  20  10  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     68  56  68  54 /  20  30  20  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  64  49  66  49 /  20  20  10  30 
MONTICELLO AR     70  57  69  56 /  20  30  20  30 
SEARCY AR         66  53  66  51 /  20  30  10  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      67  54  67  53 /  20  20  10  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   66  53  66  51 /  20  20  10  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...LAKE WIND ADVISORY FROM 900 AM 
CST THURSDAY UNTIL 500 PM CST THURSDAY FOR ZONES 
ARZ003>007...ARZ012>015.

815 
FXUS64 KLZK 292045
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
240 PM CST WED DEC 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...
GUIDANCE HAS NOT CHANGED MUCH THE PAST FEW DAYS...WITH DOMINANT 
SUBTROPICAL JET AND ARCTIC AIR BOTTLED UP WELL TO THE NORTH...AT
LEAST IN THE SHORT TERM. MOST ENERGY IN THIS PACKAGE LOOKS LIKE
IT WILL GO WELL TO THE NORTH...WITH COLD FRONTS LEFT TO HANG IN/NEAR
ARKANSAS.

ONE SUCH FRONT WILL PUSH TOWARD THE REGION FROM THE PLAINS THURSDAY
AFTERNOON/NIGHT. SOUTHERLY FLOW AHEAD OF FRONT BRINGING INCREASING
MOISTURE...WITH ISOLATED TO SCATTERED SHOWERS MENTIONED IN THE 
FORECAST. PRECIPITATION AMOUNTS PRETTY MUCH NEGLIGIBLE DURING 
THIS PERIOD. WINDY CONDITIONS THURSDAY AFTERNOON MAY WARRANT A LAKE 
WIND ADVISORY IN THE NORTHERN/WESTERN COUNTIES.

THE FRONT MAY PUSH INTO THE STATE...BUT IS EXPECTED TO STALL AS MAIN 
STORM SYSTEM TRAVELS THROUGH GREAT LAKES REGION. SLIGHTLY COOLER AIR
WILL BUILD INTO NORTHERN ARKANSAS BEHIND THE FRONT BY FRIDAY 
MORNING...WITH WELL ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES ELSEWHERE.

FRONT WILL LINGER NEAR MISSOURI BORDER FRIDAY BEFORE HEADING SLOWLY 
BACK TO THE NORTH. SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL REMAIN 
IN THE FORECAST TO END THE SHORT TERM WITH HIGH TEMPERATURES IN THE 
60S/NEAR 70 AND LOWS IN THE 40S/50S. 

IN GENERAL...IT DOES NOT FEEL MUCH LIKE LATE DECEMBER. (46)          
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL CONTINUE DUE TO UPPER TROUGH OVER THE 
WEST. NUMEROUS SHORTWAVES WILL MOVE THROUGH IN THE SOUTHWEST 
FLOW...WITH RAIN CHANCES CONTINUING IN THE FORECAST. MODELS SHOWING 
A COOLER AIRMASS TO NORTH...BUT HELD TEMPS IN CHECK AS MODELS CAN 
HAVE A HARD TIME WITH SHALLOW ARCTIC AIR. 
&& 

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    52  67  54  66 /  20  20  30  20 
HARRISON AR       52  65  48  63 /  20  20  20  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    53  67  55  66 /  20  20  20  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     52  68  56  67 /  20  20  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  50  64  49  63 /  20  20  20  10 
MONTICELLO AR     53  70  57  68 /  20  20  30  20 
SEARCY AR         51  66  53  65 /  20  20  30  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      53  67  54  66 /  20  20  20  10

46/58






591 
FXUS64 KLZK 290945
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CST WED DEC 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY
WARMER AIR HAS ARRIVED AND SHOULD STAY IN PLACE FOR THE REST OF THE
YEAR AND BEYOND. SURFACE HIGH TO THE SOUTHEAST WILL PROVIDE SOUTH
TO SOUTHWEST WINDS TO THE AREA OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS WHILE RIDGING
ALOFT OVER THE AREA WILL HELP DRIVE SHORT WAVES FROM THE WEST TO THE
NORTHEAST AND AWAY FROM THIS AREA. MOISTURE WILL BE INCREASING AND
THIS WILL RESULT IN PARTLY TO MOSTLY CLOUDY SKIES WITH MUCH LOW
CLOUDINESS...ESPECIALLY LATE AT NIGHT AND IN THE MORNING. THE FIRST
SHORT WAVE COMING OUT OF THE SOUTHWEST NOW LOOKS LIKE IT WILL MOVE 
FARTHER TO THE NORTH THAN THOUGHT EARLIER AND WILL HAVE LESS EFFECT 
ON THIS AREA. LOWERED POPS TO 20 PERCENT FOR THURSDAY AND THURSDAY 
NIGHT DUE TO THIS. A COLD FRONT MOVES NEAR THE AREA THURSDAY NIGHT 
BUT STILL WEAKENS AND WASHES OUT. KEPT A CHANCE OF RAIN IN FOR
FRIDAY IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH BUT DROPPED TO SLIGHT CHANCE IN THE
NORTH WHERE MOISTURE WILL BE LESS. WITH THE UPPER SYSTEM FARTHER
AWAY AND INSTABILITY RATHER LACKING...DROPPED THUNDER FROM THE 
FORECAST THROUGH FRIDAY. WENT WITH MAXES IN THE 60S IN MOST AREAS
THE NEXT FEW DAYS WITH MINS MOSTLY IN THE LOWER 50S. SOME PARTS OF
THE SOUTH MAY REACH 70 ON THURSDAY ESPECIALLY IF CLOUDS ARE A LITTLE 
THINNER THAN EXPECTED. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
BROAD SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL CONTINUE WITH SEVERAL SHORT WAVES
MOVING THROUGH THE AREA. UPPER PATTERN STILL NOT FAVORABLE FOR A
BLAST OF ARCTIC AIR WHICH THE GFS HAS BEEN TRYING TO BRING IN. THE
GFS HAS BACKED OFF SOMEWHAT WITH A WEAKER HIGH CENTER AND THICKNESSES
ARE A LITTLE HIGHER BUT THAT COULD BE ITS CHRONIC COLD BIAS IN 
EXTENDED PERIODS EASING AS THE TIME DRAWS CLOSER. NOT OVERLY
CONFIDENT ABOUT COLD FRONT THAT IS PROGGED TO MOVE INTO THE AREA
LATE SUNDAY INTO MONDAY WHICH LATER RETURNS NORTH AS A WARM FRONT
BY TUESDAY. DID CONTINUE CHANCE POPS THROUGH THE EXTENDED. STAYED
WITH THE LOWER TEMPS FOR EARLY NEXT WEEK BUT STILL NOT SURE IT 
COULD COOL DOWN THAT MUCH...ESPECIALLY IN THE NORTH. DID DROP ALL
MENTION OF WINTER PRECIPITATION AS IT LOOKS LIKE IT WILL BE TOO
WARM EVEN IF A SHALLOW COLD AIR LAYER NEAR THE SURFACE MOVES INTO
NORTHERN ARKANSAS.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    61  52  67  54 /  10  10  20  20 
HARRISON AR       62  52  65  51 /  10  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    63  53  67  55 /  10  10  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     62  53  68  56 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  61  50  64  51 /  10  10  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     64  53  70  56 /  10  10  20  20 
SEARCY AR         59  51  66  54 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      64  53  67  54 /  10  10  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   62  52  66  53 /  10  10  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

29 






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 290945
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CST WED DEC 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY
WARMER AIR HAS ARRIVED AND SHOULD STAY IN PLACE FOR THE REST OF THE
YEAR AND BEYOND. SURFACE HIGH TO THE SOUTHEAST WILL PROVIDE SOUTH
TO SOUTHWEST WINDS TO THE AREA OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS WHILE RIDGING
ALOFT OVER THE AREA WILL HELP DRIVE SHORT WAVES FROM THE WEST TO THE
NORTHEAST AND AWAY FROM THIS AREA. MOISTURE WILL BE INCREASING AND
THIS WILL RESULT IN PARTLY TO MOSTLY CLOUDY SKIES WITH MUCH LOW
CLOUDINESS...ESPECIALLY LATE AT NIGHT AND IN THE MORNING. THE FIRST
SHORT WAVE COMING OUT OF THE SOUTHWEST NOW LOOKS LIKE IT WILL MOVE 
FARTHER TO THE NORTH THAN THOUGHT EARLIER AND WILL HAVE LESS EFFECT 
ON THIS AREA. LOWERED POPS TO 20 PERCENT FOR THURSDAY AND THURSDAY 
NIGHT DUE TO THIS. A COLD FRONT MOVES NEAR THE AREA THURSDAY NIGHT 
BUT STILL WEAKENS AND WASHES OUT. KEPT A CHANCE OF RAIN IN FOR
FRIDAY IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH BUT DROPPED TO SLIGHT CHANCE IN THE
NORTH WHERE MOISTURE WILL BE LESS. WITH THE UPPER SYSTEM FARTHER
AWAY AND INSTABILITY RATHER LACKING...DROPPED THUNDER FROM THE 
FORECAST THROUGH FRIDAY. WENT WITH MAXES IN THE 60S IN MOST AREAS
THE NEXT FEW DAYS WITH MINS MOSTLY IN THE LOWER 50S. SOME PARTS OF
THE SOUTH MAY REACH 70 ON THURSDAY ESPECIALLY IF CLOUDS ARE A LITTLE 
THINNER THAN EXPECTED. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
BROAD SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL CONTINUE WITH SEVERAL SHORT WAVES
MOVING THROUGH THE AREA. UPPER PATTERN STILL NOT FAVORABLE FOR A
BLAST OF ARCTIC AIR WHICH THE GFS HAS BEEN TRYING TO BRING IN. THE
GFS HAS BACKED OFF SOMEWHAT WITH A WEAKER HIGH CENTER AND THICKNESSES
ARE A LITTLE HIGHER BUT THAT COULD BE ITS CHRONIC COLD BIAS IN 
EXTENDED PERIODS EASING AS THE TIME DRAWS CLOSER. NOT OVERLY
CONFIDENT ABOUT COLD FRONT THAT IS PROGGED TO MOVE INTO THE AREA
LATE SUNDAY INTO MONDAY WHICH LATER RETURNS NORTH AS A WARM FRONT
BY TUESDAY. DID CONTINUE CHANCE POPS THROUGH THE EXTENDED. STAYED
WITH THE LOWER TEMPS FOR EARLY NEXT WEEK BUT STILL NOT SURE IT 
COULD COOL DOWN THAT MUCH...ESPECIALLY IN THE NORTH. DID DROP ALL
MENTION OF WINTER PRECIPITATION AS IT LOOKS LIKE IT WILL BE TOO
WARM EVEN IF A SHALLOW COLD AIR LAYER NEAR THE SURFACE MOVES INTO
NORTHERN ARKANSAS.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    61  52  67  54 /  10  10  20  20

29 






570 
FXUS64 KLZK 282031
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 PM CST TUE DEC 28 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT 
LOOKS LIKE SUBTROPICAL JET WILL BE DOMINANT IN THE SHORT TERM...WITH 
TROUGH IN THE ROCKIES FORCING SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT OVER ARKANSAS. 
TROUGH FILLS A BIT WITH TIME...WITH SEVERAL PIECES OF ENERGY SENT 
ACROSS CENTRAL PLAINS/UPPER MIDWEST...OR AT LEAST WELL NORTH OF 
NATURAL STATE.

AT THE SURFACE...STORM SYSTEM WILL DEVELOP IN THE PLAINS 
WEDNESDAY/THURSDAY...WITH SYSTEM DRAGGING COLD FRONT TOWARD THE 
REGION. SOUTHERLY WIND AHEAD OF FRONT WILL HAVE ALREADY BROUGHT 
ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES/AMPLE GULF MOISTURE INTO ARKANSAS. WITH 
SYSTEM WELL TO THE NORTH...APPEARS THAT FRONT WILL HAVE LITTLE 
PUSH...AND WILL LIKELY NOT MAKE IT INTO/THROUGH THE STATE.

SCATTERED SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS IN THE FORECAST ALONG AND AHEAD OF 
THE FRONT THURSDAY/THURSDAY NIGHT. LOTS OF CLOUDS/CONTINUING CHANCES 
OF PRECIPITATION TO END THE SHORT TERM AS MOIST/UNSTABLE AIRMASS NOT 
DISPLACED. (46)       
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
MODELS CONT TO INDC THAT SWLY FLOW ALOFT WL PREVAIL INTO EARLY NEXT 
WEEK AS UPPER TROF RMNS OVR THE WRN STATES. SEVERAL SHORT WAVES ARE 
STILL PROGGED TO PASS ACRS THE MID-SOUTH WHICH WL KEEP RAIN CHCS IN 
THE FCST THRU THE WEEKEND. LOOKS LIKE TO COLDER AIRMASS WL BE SLOWER 
TO WORK SWD EARLY NEXT WEEK AS UPPER PATTERN SHOWS LTL CHANGE. HAVE 
REWORKED GRIDS TO ACCOUNT FOR THESE TRENDS. LATER MODEL RUNS WL NEED 
TO BE WATCHED CLOSELY FOR ANY CHGS SINCE THEY HAVE A HARD TIME WITH 
SHALLOW ARCTIC AIRMASSES. (44) 
&& 

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    42  61  50  67 /  10  10  10  20 
HARRISON AR       44  62  52  65 /  10  10  20  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    43  63  51  67 /  10  10  10  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     43  62  51  67 /  10  10  10  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  41  61  50  64 /  10  10  10  30 
MONTICELLO AR     42  64  51  68 /  10  10  10  20 
SEARCY AR         41  59  49  66 /  10  10  10  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      43  64  51  67 /  10  10  10  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   39  62  49  66 /  10  10  10  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&



488 
FXUS64 KLZK 280938
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CST TUE DEC 28 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY
RETURN FLOW SHOULD INCREASE TODAY AS SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE MOVES
TO THE EAST. UPPER RIDGING OVER THE AREA SHOULD ALLOW FOR WARMER 
WEATHER AND MAXES MOSTLY INTO THE 50S. WENT A LITTLE ABOVE MAV MOS
AGAIN WHICH HAS TENDED TO BE A LITTLE TOO COOL RECENTLY. MOISTURE
WILL BEGIN INCREASING TONIGHT AND OVER THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS. 
THE FLOW ALOFT WILL BECOME FROM THE SOUTHWEST AS SHORT WAVES BEGIN 
ROTATING OUT OF THE WEST AND WEAKENING AS THE LIFT TO THE NORTHEAST 
INTO THE NORTHERN PLAINS AND UPPER MISSISSIPPI VALLEY. THE FIRST 
SUCH SYSTEM WILL BE NEAR ENOUGH TO BRING IN A CHANCE OF RAIN ON 
THURSDAY. A WEAK COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH THE AREA THURSDAY BUT 
IT WASHES OUT AS IT MOVES INTO THE AREA. THE MOISTURE AXIS STILL
SHUNTS TO THE SOUTH ON FRIDAY BEFORE MOVING BACK NORTH OVER THE 
AREA AHEAD OF THE NEXT SHORT WAVE FROM THE SOUTHWEST. KEPT POPS
AS THEY WERE FOR FRIDAY WITH NO MENTION OF RAIN IN MOST AREAS
AND SMALL POPS IN THE SOUTH. INSTABILITY LOOKS MARGINAL FOR 
THUNDER BUT LEFT MENTION OF THUNDER IN FOR THURSDAY AFTERNOON 
THROUGH FRIDAY.

A FEW PLACES REPORTING SOME FOG THIS MORNING WITH TEMPERATURES 
BELOW FREEZING. WILL STICK IN PATCHY FREEZING FOG FOR EARLY THIS
MORNING IN SOME CENTRAL AND EASTERN ZONES.    
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
TROFFING ALOFT REMAINS OVER THE WESTERN U.S. THROUGH THE PERIOD WITH 
OCCASIONAL SHORT WAVES MOVING THROUGH THE AREA. MOISTURE REMAINS
HIGH SO KEPT A CONTINUOUS CHANCE OF RAIN THROUGH THE PERIOD. GFS
STILL BRINGING IN AN ARCTIC OUTBREAK EARLY NEXT WEEK WITH A BETTER
THAN 1050 MB HIGH BUT THE UPPER PATTERN IS UNFAVORABLE FOR THIS 
TO OCCUR. THE GFS PATTERN FOR THE END OF THE PERIOD DOES NOT MAKE
MUCH SENSE AND WILL NOT BE DISCOUNTED FOR NOW. DID GO WITH COOL 
DOWN FOR THE FIRST PART OF NEXT WEEK BUT DID NOT GO TOO DRASTIC 
YET DUE TO THE UNFAVORABLE UPPER PATTERN FOR COLDER WEATHER.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    55  44  63  50 /   0  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       56  44  61  50 /   0  10  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    57  46  64  51 /   0  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     55  44  64  50 /   0  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  55  42  60  50 /   0  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     57  44  65  51 /   0  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         54  43  62  50 /   0  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      58  46  64  51 /   0  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   56  44  63  50 /   0  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

29 








640 
FXUS64 KLZK 280403 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
958 PM CST MON DEC 27 2004

.DISCUSSION...
HAVE JUST SENT OUT AN UPDATE MAINLY TO CLEAN UP TEMPORAL WORDING. 
WEAK RETURN FLOW ALREADY SETTING UP OVER THE WEST. AS A 
RESULT...TEMPS WILL BE KEPT IN CHECK IN THESE AREAS. EASTERN 
ARKANSAS WILL SEE COLDER TEMPERATURES...WITH RETURN FLOW SETTING UP 
AFTER DAWN. 

BOTTOM LINE IS THAT THE FORECAST LARGELY IS IN GOOD SHAPE WITH NO 
OTHER CHANGES ANTICIPATED AT THIS TIME. 
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 230 PM CST MON DEC 27 2004

ARCTIC HIGH PRESSURE SAGGING SOUTHWARD FROM OHIO VALLEY TOWARD 
MID-ATLANTIC REGION OVERNIGHT. CLOCKWISE FLOW AROUND HIGH PRODUCED 
WINDS WITH EASTERLY COMPONENT TODAY...WHICH USUALLY TRANSLATES INTO 
COOL WEATHER THIS TIME OF YEAR. SUCH WAS THE CASE THIS 
AFTERNOON...WITH WINDS/SNOW COVER KEEPING PARTS OF NORTHEAST 
ARKANSAS IN THE 30S.

OVERNIGHT/TUESDAY...AS HIGH MOVES TOWARD SOUTHEAST UNITED 
STATES...WINDS IN ARKANSAS WILL GRADUALLY BECOME MORE SOUTHERLY. 
RESULT WILL BE WARMER TEMPERATURES...WITH READINGS TUESDAY AFTERNOON
MOSTLY IN THE 50S.

DEWPOINT SURGE WILL COME ON WEDNESDAY AS GULF BEGINS TO OPEN UP. AS 
MOISTURE LEVELS INCREASE...MORE CLOUDS WILL BE NOTED AND THIS SHOWN 
IN THE GOING FORECAST.

BY MIDWEEK...TROUGH WILL DIG IN THE ROCKIES...WITH A SOUTHWEST WIND 
FLOW ALOFT OVER ARKANSAS. FLOW PRETTY MUCH SPLIT...WITH DOMINANT 
SUBTROPICAL JET AND NO ARCTIC AIR IN THE OFFING. LOOKS SOMEWHAT 
SPRINGLIKE...WITH STORM SYSTEM INTENSIFYING IN THE PLAINS...AND 
DRAGGING A COLD FRONT TOWARD ARKANSAS. SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS EXPECTED AHEAD OF THE FRONT LATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND 
THURSDAY.

APPEARS THAT FRONT MAY NOT PUSH ENTIRELY THROUGH STATE...WITH 
UNSETTLED WEATHER CONTINUING INTO THE LONG TERM. 

OVERALL CONFIDENCE FOR THIS PERIOD IS LOWER THAN PREVIOUS LONG TERM 
PERIODS. UPPER TROUGH ACROSS THE WESTERN U.S....WITH WEAK RIDGING 
OVER THE SOUTHEAST WILL PROVIDE SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW OVER THE FORECAST 
AREA. THE AMPLITUDE OF THIS PATTERN THAT DEVELOPS IS A MAJOR 
QUESTION YET TO BE ANSWERED. AT THIS TIME...EXPECT SCATTERED RAIN 
DURING THIS PERIOD...WITH A COOLING TREND. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY
OVERALL CONFIDENCE FOR THIS PERIOD IS LOWER THAN PREVIOUS LONG TERM 
PERIODS. UPPER TROUGH ACROSS THE WESTERN U.S....WITH WEAK RIDGING 
OVER THE SOUTHEAST WILL PROVIDE SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW OVER THE FORECAST 
AREA. THE AMPLITUDE OF THIS PATTERN THAT DEVELOPS IS A MAJOR 
QUESTION YET TO BE ANSWERED. AT THIS TIME...EXPECT SCATTERED RAIN 
DURING THIS PERIOD...WITH A COOLING TREND. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    30  55  43  62 /   0   0  10  10 
HARRISON AR       31  56  44  62 /   0   0  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    32  57  45  62 /   0   0  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     30  55  43  62 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  28  55  42  60 /   0   0  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     30  57  44  63 /   0   0  10  10 
SEARCY AR         28  54  40  61 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      30  58  45  63 /   0   0  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   28  56  41  62 /   0   0  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

46/55






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 272034
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 PM CST MON DEC 27 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT
ARCTIC HIGH PRESSURE SAGGING SOUTHWARD FROM OHIO VALLEY TOWARD 
MID-ATLANTIC REGION OVERNIGHT. CLOCKWISE FLOW AROUND HIGH PRODUCED 
WINDS WITH EASTERLY COMPONENT TODAY...WHICH USUALLY TRANSLATES INTO 
COOL WEATHER THIS TIME OF YEAR. SUCH WAS THE CASE THIS 
AFTERNOON...WITH WINDS/SNOW COVER KEEPING PARTS OF NORTHEAST 
ARKANSAS IN THE 30S.

OVERNIGHT/TUESDAY...AS HIGH MOVES TOWARD SOUTHEAST UNITED 
STATES...WINDS IN ARKANSAS WILL GRADUALLY BECOME MORE SOUTHERLY. 
RESULT WILL BE WARMER TEMPERATURES...WITH READINGS TUESDAY AFTERNOON
MOSTLY IN THE 50S.

DEWPOINT SURGE WILL COME ON WEDNESDAY AS GULF BEGINS TO OPEN UP. AS 
MOISTURE LEVELS INCREASE...MORE CLOUDS WILL BE NOTED AND THIS SHOWN 
IN THE GOING FORECAST.

BY MIDWEEK...TROUGH WILL DIG IN THE ROCKIES...WITH A SOUTHWEST WIND 
FLOW ALOFT OVER ARKANSAS. FLOW PRETTY MUCH SPLIT...WITH DOMINANT 
SUBTROPICAL JET AND NO ARCTIC AIR IN THE OFFING. LOOKS SOMEWHAT 
SPRINGLIKE...WITH STORM SYSTEM INTENSIFYING IN THE PLAINS...AND 
DRAGGING A COLD FRONT TOWARD ARKANSAS. SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS EXPECTED AHEAD OF THE FRONT LATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND 
THURSDAY.

APPEARS THAT FRONT MAY NOT PUSH ENTIRELY THROUGH STATE...WITH 
UNSETTLED WEATHER CONTINUING INTO THE LONG TERM. (46) 
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY
OVERALL CONFIDENCE FOR THIS PERIOD IS LOWER THAN PREVIOUS LONG TERM 
PERIODS. UPPER TROUGH ACROSS THE WESTERN U.S....WITH WEAK RIDGING 
OVER THE SOUTHEAST WILL PROVIDE SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW OVER THE FORECAST 
AREA. THE AMPLITUDE OF THIS PATTERN THAT DEVELOPS IS A MAJOR 
QUESTION YET TO BE ANSWERED. AT THIS TIME...EXPECT SCATTERED RAIN 
DURING THIS PERIOD...WITH A COOLING TREND. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    30  55  43  62 /   0   0  10  10 
HARRISON AR       31  56  44  62 /   0   0  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    32  57  45  62 /   0   0  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     30  55  43  62 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  28  55  42  60 /   0   0  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     30  57  44  63 /   0   0  10  10 
SEARCY AR         28  54  40  61 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      30  58  45  63 /   0   0  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   28  56  41  62 /   0   0  10  10

46/55






346 
FXUS64 KLZK 270933
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CST MON DEC 27 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY
SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE TO THE EAST WILL INCREASE SOMEWHAT TODAY  
BRINGING A BRIEF REINFORCEMENT OF COLDER AIR. NORTHEAST WINDS WILL 
BE COMING FROM THE SNOW AND ICE PACK IN THE OHIO VALLEY. THIS WILL
LIKELY HOLD TEMPS DOWN SOME TODAY AND LOWERED MAXES INTO THE 40S
IN MOST AREAS WITH THE COLDEST IN THE NORTHEAST. STILL WENT A 
LITTLE ABOVE MAV MOS WHICH HAS TENDED TO BE TOO COLD THE PAST FEW
DAYS. THE HIGH MOVES EAST TONIGHT AND TUESDAY AND THE SURFACE WINDS 
VEER BACK AROUND TO A SOUTHERLY DIRECTION WHICH SHOULD RESUME THE
WARMING TREND. LOWERED MINS A LITTLE FOR TONIGHT AS WELL BUT BASICALLY
KEPT TEMP FORECAST THE SAME FROM TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY. WEATHER
SHOULD BE DRY THROUGH WEDNESDAY. MOISTURE INCREASES SOME TUESDAY 
NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY AS RETURN FLOW CONTINUES BUT IT LOOKS LIKE IT 
WILL BE TOO SHALLOW AND INSUFFICIENT FOR A MENTIONABLE CHANCE OF 
PRECIPITATION UNTIL THURSDAY. THERE LIKELY WILL BE SOME INCREASE
IN CLOUDS TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
UPPER LOW FROM THE SOUTHWEST MOVES NORTHEAST INTO THE NORTHERN 
PLAINS THURSDAY AND FRIDAY. A COLD FRONT APPROACHES THE AREA BUT 
APPARENTLY WEAKENS AS THE UPPER SUPPORT MOVES AWAY FROM THE AREA. 
AN AXIS OF MOISTURE IS STILL PROGGED TO MOVE ACROSS THE AREA 
THURSDAY NIGHT INTO FRIDAY. MOISTURE THEN HANGS AROUND THROUGH THE
WEEKEND WITH SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT AND PROBABLY A FEW WEAK SHORT WAVES
MOVING THROUGH THE AREA. KEPT 30 PERCENT POPS GOING THROUGH THE 
EXTENDED PERIOD FOR NOW WITH MILDER THAN NORMAL TEMPS...MINS 
MOSTLY IN THE 40S AND MAXES MOSTLY IN THE 60S. A STRONG ARCTIC
HIGH SHOWS UP BY THE FIRST OF NEXT WEEK BUT THE UPPER PATTERN IS 
NOT FAVORABLE FOR THIS TO MOVE RAPIDLY INTO THE AREA. APPEARS AT
THIS TIME LIKE THE GFS HAS A BETTER HANDLE ON IT AND ANY EFFECTS 
OF THE ARCTIC AIR WILL BE BEYOND THE FORECAST PERIOD.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    45  30  55  43 /   0   0   0  10 
HARRISON AR       46  34  57  44 /   0   0   0  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    48  34  57  45 /   0   0   0  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     46  30  56  43 /   0   0   0  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  43  32  55  42 /   0   0   0  10 
MONTICELLO AR     46  30  56  44 /   0   0   0  10 
SEARCY AR         44  30  54  40 /   0   0   0  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      49  34  58  45 /   0   0   0  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   47  30  57  40 /   0   0   0  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$


407 
FXUS64 KLZK 262055
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
255 PM CST SUN DEC 26 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT
VISIBLE PICTURES SHOW THAT SNOW COVER HAS REDUCED CONSIDERABLY WITH 
OUR CWA. ALSO...TODAYS SUNSHINE PUSHED TEMPERATURES HIGHER THAN 
FORECAST ORIGINALLY...SO WILL GO FOR WARMER TEMPS TONIGHT AND WILL 
CONTINUE THAT TREND IN THE SHORT TERM. UPPER PATTERN CONTINUES 
FLATTENING THE UPPER RIDGE THROUGH WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON...THEN 
SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL GET CLOSER TO ARKANSAS AS SHORT WAVE APPROACHES 
THE GREAT PLAINS FOR THURSDAY MORNING.

THE SURFACE RIDGE HOLDS OFF MOISTURE FROM THE GULF UNTIL WEDNESDAY 
MORNING WHEN RETURN FLOW BEGINS TO RESPOND MORE TO THE APPROACHING 
SYSTEM FROM THE PLAINS. FORECAST WILL STAY DRY UNTIL THURSDAY 
MORNING IN THE SHORT TERM.
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY
MODELS ALL IN GOOD AGREEMENT SHOWING THE MAJOR PATTERN SHIFT 
CONTINUING THROUGH THE PERIOD. TROFFING WILL PERSIST ALONG THE WEST 
COAST WITH RIDGING OVER THE SOUTHEAST CONUS. PATTERN IS OCCASIONALLY 
KNOCKED DOWN BY SHORTWAVES MOVING THROUGH THE PERSISTENT SOUTHWEST 
FLOW BUT OVERALL SYNOPTIC SCALE REGIME HOLDS THROUGH THE PERIOD.

GULF OPENS UP ENOUGH DURING THE PERIOD THAT WAVES MOVING THROUGH 
WILL HAVE ENOUGH MOISTURE TO WORK WITH TO PRODUCE SCATTERED SHOWERS. 
INSTABILITY IS MARGINAL AT BEST AND APPEARS TO BE ELEVATED BUT A FEW 
RUMBLES OF THUNDER CAN NOT BE DISMISSED. FORTUNATELY NO REALLY COLD 
AIR IS IN SIGHT AND ANY PRECIPITATION THAT DOES FALL WILL BE WET AS 
OPPOSED TO WHITE. TEMPERATURES EXPECTED TO AVERAGE ABOUT TEN DEGREES 
ABOVE SEASONABLE NORMALS AND THINKING IS SUPPORTED BY THE MEX 
NUMBERS WHICH WILL BE FOLLOWED FAIRLY CLOSELY.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    30  53  37  58 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       30  53  36  57 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    30  53  38  59 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     30  53  38  58 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  30  52  35  57 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     30  54  39  58 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         29  52  36  57 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      31  54  39  59 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   30  53  37  58 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&


660 
FXUS64 KLZK 261928
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
120 PM CST SUN DEC 26 2004

.DISCUSSION
A QUICK UPDATE HAS BEEN SENT ALREADY TO ACCOUNT FOR THE WARMER 
TEMPERATURES. EVEN WITH SOME OF THE ENERGY GOING TO SNOW 
MELT...TEMPS HAVE BOUNCED BACK RATHER WELL. 32
&&

.PREVIOUS DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 400 AM CST SUN DEC 26 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT 
DEPARTING HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM AND ITS ASSOCIATED RETURN SOUTHERLY 
WINDS TODAY WILL CONTINUE THE WARMING TREND...GOING FROM BELOW 
NORMAL TEMPERATURES TO ABOVE WHAT WOULD BE CONSIDERED NORMAL FOR 
THIS TIME OF YEAR. A DRY AIR MASS WILL CONTINUE OVER MY CW AREA AND 
THUS EXPECT NO PRECIPITATION TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT. (38)    
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
UPPER RIDGE WILL DOMINATE THE AREA AT THE START OF THE PERIOD
WITH A SURFACE HIGH TO THE EAST AND SOUTHWEST SURFACE WINDS IN
THE AREA. THIS SHOULD PROMOTE WARMER THAN NORMAL TEMPS WHICH WILL
CONTINUE THROUGH THE EXTENDED PERIOD. THE UPPER RIDGE FLATTENS AND
SHIFTS EAST LATE IN THE WEEK AND SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT DEVELOPS
WITH SEVERAL WEAK SHORT WAVES MOVING THROUGH. THE MAIN TROF WILL
REMAIN WELL TO THE WEST. THE FIRST SHORT WAVE APPROACHES THURSDAY
AND THE GULF LOOKS LIKE IT WILL OPEN UP ENOUGH TO BRING ENOUGH 
MOISTURE IN TO INTRODUCE A CHANCE OF RAIN ON THURSDAY. AFTER THAT
MOISTURE REMAINS IN THE AREA WITH WEAK SHORT WAVES MOVING THROUGH
SO WILL CONTINUE CHANCE POPS THROUGH THE REST OF THE EXTENDED. 
GOING FORECAST HAS SHOWERS BY NIGHT AND SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS
BY DAY AND KEPT THIS GOING. INSTABILITY WILL BE MARGINAL AND SHOULD 
BE THE BEST DURING THE AFTERNOONS. (29) 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    47  30  49  35 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       49  30  47  36 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    48  31  50  36 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     47  30  50  35 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  45  29  46  33 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     48  31  51  36 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         46  29  47  34 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      48  31  51  37 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   47  30  49  35 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT 
DEPARTING HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM AND ITS ASSOCIATED RETURN SOUTHERLY 
WINDS TODAY WILL CONTINUE THE WARMING TREND...GOING FROM BELOW 
NORMAL TEMPERATURES TO ABOVE WHAT WOULD BE CONSIDERED NORMAL FOR 
THIS TIME OF YEAR. A DRY AIR MASS WILL CONTINUE OVER MY CW AREA AND 
THUS EXPECT NO PRECIPITATION TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT. (38)    
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
UPPER RIDGE WILL DOMINATE THE AREA AT THE START OF THE PERIOD
WITH A SURFACE HIGH TO THE EAST AND SOUTHWEST SURFACE WINDS IN
THE AREA. THIS SHOULD PROMOTE WARMER THAN NORMAL TEMPS WHICH WILL
CONTINUE THROUGH THE EXTENDED PERIOD. THE UPPER RIDGE FLATTENS AND
SHIFTS EAST LATE IN THE WEEK AND SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT DEVELOPS
WITH SEVERAL WEAK SHORT WAVES MOVING THROUGH. THE MAIN TROF WILL
REMAIN WELL TO THE WEST. THE FIRST SHORT WAVE APPROACHES THURSDAY
AND THE GULF LOOKS LIKE IT WILL OPEN UP ENOUGH TO BRING ENOUGH 
MOISTURE IN TO INTRODUCE A CHANCE OF RAIN ON THURSDAY. AFTER THAT
MOISTURE REMAINS IN THE AREA WITH WEAK SHORT WAVES MOVING THROUGH
SO WILL CONTINUE CHANCE POPS THROUGH THE REST OF THE EXTENDED. 
GOING FORECAST HAS SHOWERS BY NIGHT AND SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS
BY DAY AND KEPT THIS GOING. INSTABILITY WILL BE MARGINAL AND SHOULD 
BE THE BEST DURING THE AFTERNOONS. (29) 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    47  30  49  35 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       49  30  47  36 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    48  31  50  36 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     47  30  50  35 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  45  29  46  33 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     48  31  51  36 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         46  29  47  34 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      48  31  51  37 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   47  30  49  35 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

003 
FXUS64 KLZK 260313
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
904 PM CST SAT DEC 25 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LIGHT SOUTHERLY WINDS CONTINUE OVER THE REGION THIS HOUR WITH DEW 
POINT TEMPERATURES BEING PULLED INTO THE UPPER TEENS TO LOWER 20S. 
WINDS ARE ON THE BACK SIDE OF THE DEPARTING HIGH AND TEMPERATURES 
WILL ONLY CONTINUE TO WARM OVER THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS...GOING FROM 
BELOW NORMAL TO ABOVE. QUICK PEEK AT THE MODELS...FWC DATA AND 
CURRENT TRENDS INDICATE OUR FORECASTED LOWS MAY BE A TAD TOO LOW. 
FORECAST WILL BE UPDATED TO RAISE OVERNIGHT LOWS AND TWEAK THE GRIDS 
TO REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS. NO MAJOR OVERHAULS EXPECTED.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 200 PM CST SAT DEC 25 2004

SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
UPPER LOW THAT DUMPED SNOWFALL OVER DEEP SOUTH TEXAS WILL BE PUSHING 
EAST INTO THE GULF AS THE TROF MOVES EAST OF ARKANSAS TODAY AND 
TONIGHT. UPPER FLOW WILL BE FROM THE NORTHWEST AS RIDGE OVER THE 
ROCKIES MOVES EAST AND FLATTENS GRADUALLY BY 12Z WEDNESDAY. LOW OVER 
THE SOUTHWEST DELAYS ITS MOTION WHILE THE RIDGE DE-AMPLIFIES...AND 
THIS WILL DELAY THE ONSET OF PRECIPITATION OVER ARKANSAS PAST THE 
SHORT TERM. THE SURFACE PATTERN WILL BE PUNCTUATED BY A RIDGE THAT 
STRENGTHENS THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING...KEEPING THE GULF CLOSED. SOME 
WEAKENING OF THE RIDGE TAKES PLACE FROM 12Z TUESDAY INTO 12Z 
WEDNESDAY. RETURN FLOW STARTS TO INCREASE HUMIDITIES DURING THE LAST 
24 HOURS. TEMPERATURES HAVE GONE ABOVE FREEZING ALREADY AT MOST 
PLACES TODAY. THE WARMING TREND WILL CONTINUE IN THE SHORT TERM.
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
MODELS STILL IN GOOD AGREEMENT THRU THE PD. UPPER RDG AXIS IS 
PROGGED TO TRANSLATE EWD ACRS THE MID-SOUTH WED INTO THU. 
MEANWHILE...SFC HIGH WL BE CENTERED OVER THE SERN PART OF THE NATION 
WITH THE RDG AXIS EXTENDING WWD INTO AR. THE LATTER HALF OF THE PD 
WL SEE AN UPPER TROF ESTABLISHED OVR THE WRN STATES...RESULTING IN 
SWLY FLOW ALOFT DVLPG ACRS THE SRN PLAINS.

MOISTURE LVLS ARE FCST TO INCRS STARTING THU NIGHT IN ADVANCE OF A 
SLOW MOVING CDFNT. SEVERAL WEAK UPPER LVL SYSTEMS ARE ALSO FCST TO 
LIFT NEWD ACRS THE FA...PROVIDING SUPPORT FOR SCTD SHRA/TSRA...YES
THUNDER. MILDER AIR WILL ALSO OVERSPREAD THE AREA DURG THE LONG 
TERM. OVERALL...MADE ONLY SOME MINOR CHGS TO TEMPS/PRECIP TRENDS IN 
GOING FCST.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

909 
FXUS64 KLZK 250937
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
338 AM CST SAT DEC 25 2004

.SHORT TERM...
TODAY THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
OF MAIN CONCERN THIS EARLY CHRISTMAS MORNING ARE HIGH TEMPERATURES 
TODAY AND MINIMUMS TONIGHT. THE LATEST RUC80 MODEL IS THE PREFERRED 
MODEL FOR MY CW AREA TODAY. THE LATEST SATELLITE IMAGERY LOOPS 
REVEAL A FEW HIGH CLOUDS MOVING ACROSS SOUTHERN ARKANSAS AND MOSTLY 
CLEAR SKIES OVER THE REMAINDER OF THE NATURAL STATE AS HIGH PRESSURE 
PREVAILS. THE RESIDUAL SNOW COVER AND PATCHY ICE WILL CONTINUE TO 
PLAY A ROLE IN THE TEMPERATURE TRENDS TODAY AND TONIGHT. THE LATEST 
GFS MOS GUIDANCE IS HOWEVER SHOWING TEMPERATURES ABOUT 4 DEGREES 
HIGHER THAN EARLIER EXPECTED FOR TODAY...TONIGHT AND TOMORROW SO 
WILL RAISE THE ON-GOING FORECAST TO BE MORE IN LINE WITH THE NEW 
THINKING. LITTLE OR NO PRECIPITATION IS EXPECTED TODAY THROUGH 
MONDAY NIGHT.           
(38)    
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE AT THE SURFACE WILL CONTINUE ACROSS THE
AREA WITH A BIG UPPER RIDGE OVER THE AREA WHICH SLOWLY MOVES
TO THE EAST AND SETS UP OVER THE SOUTHEASTERN U.S. BY THE END OF
NEXT WEEK...ALSO THE END OF THE YEAR. UPPER TROF WILL SET UP OFF 
THE WEST COAST WITH A SHORT WAVE OR TWO TRYING TO MOVE INTO THE
CENTRAL PART OF THE COUNTRY BUT GETTING SHUNTED OFF TO THE 
NORTHEAST BY THE UPPER RIDGE IN THE SOUTHEAST. THIS WILL LEAD TO
A PERIOD OF MILDER THAN NORMAL WEATHER WITH ALMOST UNSEASONABLY WARM
MAXES INTO THE UPPER 50S AND 60S BY THE LATTER PART OF THE WEEK WITH
LOWS MOSTLY IN THE 40S. THE HIGH PRESSURE IN THE AREA AT MID WEEK 
SHOULD PRECLUDE ANY CHANCE OF RAIN THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT. THE
FIRST SHORT WAVE FROM THE WEST MAY GET CLOSE ENOUGH BY THURSDAY
TO INDUCE A GOOD ENOUGH MOISTURE RETURN FOR SOME CHANCE OF RAIN
AND WILL GO WITH SMALL POPS FOR THEN. GFS INDICATES A FRONT 
GETTING CLOSE TO THE AREA BY FRIDAY SO WILL GO WITH A CHANCE OF
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FOR THEN. FRONT MAY STALL AND/OR WASH
OUT OVER THE AREA WITH MOISTURE AXIS REMAINING ACROSS THE CWA
FOR A CONTINUED CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS BUT THIS IS
BEYOND THE TIME RANGE OF THIS FORECAST. 
(29)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    37  22  46  26 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       39  25  48  28 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    39  24  48  26 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     38  24  48  27 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  36  25  43  27 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     40  25  50  29 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         35  21  43  25 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      41  23  48  25 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   38  20  44  24 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

354 
FXUS64 KLZK 250324
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
925 PM CST FRI DEC 24 2004

.DISCUSSION...
OVERALL THE FORECAST IS IN GOOD SHAPE BUT WILL STILL NEED TO TWEAK 
TEMPERATURES UPWARDS A FEW DEGREES TONIGHT. ARCTIC HIGH PRESSURE 
CONTINUES OVER THE AREA BUT CENTER OF HIGH IS JUST OFF TO THE EAST. 
WINDS HAVE ALREADY SHIFTED TO LIGHT SOUTH TO SOUTHWEST OVER THE WEST 
AND TEMPERATURES THERE HAVE RISEN SLIGHTLY OR STEADIED OUT. QUICK 
PEAK AT THE MODELS SHOWS A SUBTLE WIND SHIFT LINE REACHING SOUTHERN 
ARKANSAS BY MORNING. LATEST FWC GUIDANCE ALSO COMING IN WARMER 
TONIGHT THAN PREVIOUS RUNS SO WILL GO AHEAD AND BOOST TEMPERATURES A 
FEW DEGREES TONIGHT. DIFFERENCE IN FORECASTED LOWS WILL ONLY BE A 
FEW DEGREES BUT ANY THING POSITIVE AT THIS POINT IS WELCOMED. NEW 
MODELS ALSO HINTING AT A WARMER DAY SATURDAY BUT WILL LET THE 
MIDNIGHT CREW MAKE THE FINAL CALL ONCE ALL DATA COMES IN. UPDATE OUT 
SHORTLY. 
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 225 PM CST FRI DEC 24 2004

SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
MOST OF THE MID AND HIGH LVL CLOUDS HAVE SHIFTED SE OF AR THIS 
AFTN...LEAVING SUNNY SKIES. EVEN WITH THE SUNSHINE...TEMPS HAVE ONLY 
MANAGED TO WARM INTO THE 20S WHERE SNOW COVER STILL PREVAILS. THESE 
TEMPS ARE A BIT MORE TOLERABLE TODAY AS HIGH PRES IS CENTERED OVER 
THE AREA...RESULTING IN LIGHT WINDS.

PRIMARY FORECAST CONCERN THRU THE SHORT TERM RMNS TEMPS. EXPECT THE 
MERCURY TO FALL QUICKLY AFTER SUNSET THIS EVENING ACRS THE FA. 
LOOKING AT SINGLE DIGITS AND TEENS FOR LOWS WITH LIGHT WINDS AND 
MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES. SOME OF THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS OF NWRN AR WL SEE 
A LGT S-SE WIND ON BACKSIDE OF SFC HIGH HOLDING READINGS UP A FEW 
DEGREES.

SFC RDG SHIFTS SLOLY SEWD SAT...ALLOWING WEAK RETURN FLOW TO RETURN 
TO MOST LOCATIONS. TEMPS WL ONCE AGAIN BE HELD DOWN SOMEWHAT OVR NRN 
AND CNTRL AR DUE TO CONTD SNOWMELT. APPEARS THAT THIS MRNG/S 
SNOWCOVER WAS INCLUDED IN THE INITIAL MODEL DATA...THUS MOS TEMPS 
LOOK MORE REASONABLE IN THE NEXT FEW PDS.

SFC HIGH BUILDS BACK INTO THE AREA FROM THE NE ON SUN AND MON... 
KEEPING TEMPS AT BLO NORMAL LVLS. HAVE LOWERED READINS FROM GOING 
FCST FOR THE NERN COUNTIES WHERE SFC WIND WL BE MOVING ACRS RESIDUAL 
SNOWPACK OVR NERN AR/SERN MO/WRN KY.

WITH LOW LVLS STAYING DRY AND NO SIGNS OF SIG UPPER SYSTEMS...THE 
FCST WL RMN DRY ON THE PRECIP DEPT FOR THE SHORT TERM.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
THE CUTOFF LOW OVER THE SOUTHWEST PART OF THE COUNTRY REMAINS 
STATIONARY LONGER THAN IN YESTERDAYS RUN. FINALLY THE WESTERLIES 
PICK UP THE LOW AND SCOOT IT TO THE NORTHEAST 00Z THU...BUT IT OPENS 
RAPIDLY BY THE TIME IT GETS TO WESTERN KANSAS. THE CORRESPONDING 
SURFACE PATTERN WILL REMAIN DRY LONGER FROM TUESDAY MORNING THROUGH 
THURSDAY MORNING. RAIN CHANCES WILL INCREASE FROM WEST TO EAST BY 
FRIDAY MORNING. SINCE THE UPPER SYSTEM WILL WEAKEN AS IT GETS CAUGHT 
UP IN THE NORTHERN STREAM...MOISTURE AND POPS WILL LINGER FOR THE 
STATE BEYOND THE PERIOD COVERED BY THIS FORECAST. TEMPERATURES 
SHOULD BOUNCE BACK UP TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY FROM THE LACK OF 
CLOUDS/RAIN...AND THE INCREASED SOUTHERLY FETCH TO THE WINDS.
&&

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

TEMPERATURES UPWARDS A FEW DEGREES TONIGHT. ARCTIC HIGH PRESSURE 
CONTINUES OVER THE AREA BUT CENTER OF HIGH IS JUST OFF TO THE EAST. 
WINDS HAVE ALREADY SHIFTED TO LIGHT SOUTH TO SOUTHWEST OVER THE WEST 
AND TEMPERATURES THERE HAVE RISEN SLIGHTLY OR STEADIED OUT. QUICK 
PEAK AT THE MODELS SHOWS A SUBTLE WIND SHIFT LINE REACHING SOUTHERN 
ARKANSAS BY MORNING. LATEST FWC GUIDANCE ALSO COMING IN WARMER 
TONIGHT THAN PREVIOUS RUNS SO WILL GO AHEAD AND BOOST TEMPERATURES A 
FEW DEGREES TONIGHT. DIFFERENCE IN FORECASTED LOWS WILL ONLY BE A 
FEW DEGREES BUT ANY THING POSITIVE AT THIS POINT IS WELCOMED. NEW 
MODELS ALSO HINTING AT A WARMER DAY SATURDAY BUT WILL LET THE 
MIDNIGHT CREW MAKE THE FINAL CALL ONCE ALL DATA COMES IN. UPDATE OUT 
SHORTLY. 
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 225 PM CST FRI DEC 24 2004

SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
MOST OF THE MID AND HIGH LVL CLOUDS HAVE SHIFTED SE OF AR THIS 
AFTN...LEAVING SUNNY SKIES. EVEN WITH THE SUNSHINE...TEMPS HAVE ONLY 
MANAGED TO WARM INTO THE 20S WHERE SNOW COVER STILL PREVAILS. THESE 
TEMPS ARE A BIT MORE TOLERABLE TODAY AS HIGH PRES IS CENTERED OVER 
THE AREA...RESULTING IN LIGHT WINDS.

PRIMARY FORECAST CONCERN THRU THE SHORT TERM RMNS TEMPS. EXPECT THE 
MERCURY TO FALL QUICKLY AFTER SUNSET THIS EVENING ACRS THE FA. 
LOOKING AT SINGLE DIGITS AND TEENS FOR LOWS WITH LIGHT WINDS AND 
MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES. SOME OF THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS OF NWRN AR WL SEE 
A LGT S-SE WIND ON BACKSIDE OF SFC HIGH HOLDING READINGS UP A FEW 
DEGREES.

SFC RDG SHIFTS SLOLY SEWD SAT...ALLOWING WEAK RETURN FLOW TO RETURN 
TO MOST LOCATIONS. TEMPS WL ONCE AGAIN BE HELD DOWN SOMEWHAT OVR NRN 
AND CNTRL AR DUE TO CONTD SNOWMELT. APPEARS THAT THIS MRNG/S 
SNOWCOVER WAS INCLUDED IN THE INITIAL MODEL DATA...THUS MOS TEMPS 
LOOK MORE REASONABLE IN THE NEXT FEW PDS.

SFC HIGH BUILDS BACK INTO THE AREA FROM THE NE ON SUN AND MON... 
KEEPING TEMPS AT BLO NORMAL LVLS. HAVE LOWERED READINS FROM GOING 
FCST FOR THE NERN COUNTIES WHERE SFC WIND WL BE MOVING ACRS RESIDUAL 
SNOWPACK OVR NERN AR/SERN MO/WRN KY.

WITH LOW LVLS STAYING DRY AND NO SIGNS OF SIG UPPER SYSTEMS...THE 
FCST WL RMN DRY ON THE PRECIP DEPT FOR THE SHORT TERM.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
THE CUTOFF LOW OVER THE SOUTHWEST PART OF THE COUNTRY REMAINS 
STATIONARY LONGER THAN IN YESTERDAYS RUN. FINALLY THE WESTERLIES 
PICK UP THE LOW AND SCOOT IT TO THE NORTHEAST 00Z THU...BUT IT OPENS 
RAPIDLY BY THE TIME IT GETS TO WESTERN KANSAS. THE CORRESPONDING 
SURFACE PATTERN WILL REMAIN DRY LONGER FROM TUESDAY MORNING THROUGH 
THURSDAY MORNING. RAIN CHANCES WILL INCREASE FROM WEST TO EAST BY 
FRIDAY MORNING. SINCE THE UPPER SYSTEM WILL WEAKEN AS IT GETS CAUGHT 
UP IN THE NORTHERN STREAM...MOISTURE AND POPS WILL LINGER FOR THE 
STATE BEYOND THE PERIOD COVERED BY THIS FORECAST. TEMPERATURES 
SHOULD BOUNCE BACK UP TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY FROM THE LACK OF 
CLOUDS/RAIN...AND THE INCREASED SOUTHERLY FETCH TO THE WINDS.
&&

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56







44/32







033 
FXUS64 KLZK 240959
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
358 AM CST FRI DEC 24 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
OF MAIN CONCERN THIS EARLY MORNING ARE HIGH TEMPERATURES TODAY AND 
MINIMUMS TONIGHT. THE LATEST RUC80 MODEL IS THE PREFERRED MODEL AND 
IT STILL SHOWS A WEAK UPPER SHORT WAVE MOVING ACROSS MY CW AREA 
TODAY. THE LATEST SATELLITE IMAGERY LOOPS REVEAL SCATTERED TO BROKEN 
CIRRUS AND A FEW ALTO-CUMULUS ACROSS MOST OF THE REGION. THE 
COMBINATION OF LOW TEMPERATURES THIS MORNING AND SOME WIND WILL 
YIELD LOW WIND CHILLS SO WILL ALLOW THE ON-GOING WIND CHILL ADVISORY 
TO CONTINUE IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 AM THIS FRIDAY MORNING. A WEAK COLD 
FRONT ASSOCIATED WITH THE UPPER LEVEL SYSTEM WILL BE MOVING ACROSS 
THE AREA TODAY AND EARLY TONIGHT. THIS WILL REINFORCE THE COLD AIR 
NOW IN PLACE. THE RESIDUAL SNOW COVER AND PATCHY ICE WILL CONTINUE 
TO PLAY A ROLE IN THE TEMPERATURE TRENDS TODAY...TONIGHT AND INTO 
CHRISTMAS.      
(38)    
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
RATHER STRONG UPPER RIDGE MOVES INTO THE AREA FOR THE FIRST PART
OF THE WEEK WHILE THE ARCTIC HIGH AFFECTING THIS AREA IN THE
SHORT TERM MOVES TO THE EAST AND WARMER AIR RETURNS TO THE AREA.
NEW GFS KEEPS A SURFACE RIDGE IN THE AREA THROUGH NEXT THURSDAY.
ALSO STRONG UPPER LOW STAYS OFF THE WEST COAST THROUGH MUCH OF
THE PERIOD WITH A SHORT WAVE FINALLY MOVING INTO THE PLAINS ABOUT
THURSDAY. THIS SOULTION APPEARS TO BE SLOWER THAN EARLIER RUNS AND
RESULTED IN SOME SIGNIFICANT CHANGES. SURFACE PATTERN FAVORS MORE
OF A SOUTHEAST WIND TO MOST AREAS WITH SOUTH TO SOUTHWEST WINDS
IN THE NORTHWEST. ALSO SKIES SHOULD BE MOSTLY CLEAR TO PARTLY CLOUDY
INTO THE MIDDLE OF THE WEEK. THE SURFACE RIDGE SHOULD BE SET UP
TO KEEP THE GULF CLOSED AND LESSEN THE CHANCE FOR STRATUS. THIS
MAY BREAK DOWN ON WEDNESDAY AND SHOWED INCREASING CLOUDS THEN. 
REALLY LOOKS LIKE ANY CHANCES FOR RAIN WILL HOLD OFF UNTIL 
THURSDAY BUT LEFT SMALL POPS IN FOR TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
NIGHT. AIR WILL STILL BE RATHER STABLE TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY 
SO ONLY WENT WITH RAIN FOR NOW. AS THE UPPER SHORT WAVE COMES OUT
THURSDAY AND A STRONG SURFACE LOW DEVELOPS IN RESPONSE...INSTABILITY
WILL LIKELY INCREASE...SO PUT IN SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FOR 
THURSDAY AFTERNOON. 
(29)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    30  12  36  24 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       24  14  35  24 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    30  13  38  24 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     30  14  37  24 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  22  13  33  22 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     30  15  38  24 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         26  10  33  21 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      29  10  39  23 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   28   9  37  21 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...WIND CHILL ADVISORY UNTIL 800 AM 
CST TODAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>007... ARZ012>016...ARZ021>024...ARZ031.
&&

$$

OF MAIN CONCERN THIS EARLY MORNING ARE HIGH TEMPERATURES TODAY AND

AREA TODAY AND EARLY TONIGHT. THIS WILL REINFORCE THE COLD AIR NOW 
IN PLACE. THE RESIDUAL SNOW COVER AND PATCHY ICE WILL CONTINUE TO 
PLAY A ROLE IN THE TEMPERATURE TRENDS TODAY...TONIGHT AND INTO 
CHRISTMAS.      
(38)    
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
RATHER STRONG UPPER RIDGE MOVES INTO THE AREA FOR THE FIRST PART
OF THE WEEK WHILE THE ARCTIC HIGH AFFECTING THIS AREA IN THE
SHORT TERM MOVES TO THE EAST AND WARMER AIR RETURNS TO THE AREA.
NEW GFS KEEPS A SURFACE RIDGE IN THE AREA THROUGH NEXT THURSDAY.
ALSO STRONG UPPER LOW STAYS OFF THE WEST COAST THROUGH MUCH OF
THE PERIOD WITH A SHORT WAVE FINALLY MOVING INTO THE PLAINS ABOUT
THURSDAY. THIS SOULTION APPEARS TO BE SLOWER THAN EARLIER RUNS AND
RESULTED IN SOME SIGNIFICANT CHANGES. SURFACE PATTERN FAVORS MORE
OF A SOUTHEAST WIND TO MOST AREAS WITH SOUTH TO SOUTHWEST WINDS
IN THE NORTHWEST. ALSO SKIES SHOULD BE MOSTLY CLEAR TO PARTLY CLOUDY
INTO THE MIDDLE OF THE WEEK. THE SURFACE RIDGE SHOULD BE SET UP
TO KEEP THE GULF CLOSED AND LESSEN THE CHANCE FOR STRATUS. THIS
MAY BREAK DOWN ON WEDNESDAY AND SHOWED INCREASING CLOUDS THEN. 
REALLY LOOKS LIKE ANY CHANCES FOR RAIN WILL HOLD OFF UNTIL 
THURSDAY BUT LEFT SMALL POPS IN FOR TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
NIGHT. AIR WILL STILL BE RATHER STABLE TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY 
SO ONLY WENT WITH RAIN FOR NOW. AS THE UPPER SHORT WAVE COMES OUT
THURSDAY AND A STRONG SURFACE LOW DEVELOPS IN RESPONSE...INSTABILITY
WILL LIKELY INCREASE...SO PUT IN SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FOR 
THURSDAY AFTERNOON. 
(29)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    30  12  36  24 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       24  14  35  24 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    30  13  38  24 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     30  14  37  24 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  22  13  33  22 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     30  15  38  24 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         26  10  33  21 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      29  10  39  23 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   28   9  37  21 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

38/29





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 240951
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
353 AM CST FRI DEC 24 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
OF MAIN CONCERN THIS EARLY MORNING ARE HIGH TEMPERATURES TODAY AND 
MINIMUMS TONIGHT. THE LATEST RUC80 MODEL IS THE PREFERRED MODEL AND 
IT STILL SHOWS A WEAK UPPER SHORT WAVE MOVING ACROSS MY CW AREA 
TODAY. THE LATEST SATELLITE IMAGERY LOOPS REVEAL SCATTERED TO BROKEN 
CIRRUS AND A FEW ALTO-CUMULUS ACROSS MOST OF THE REGION. THE 
COMBINATION OF LOW TEMPERATURES THIS MORNING AND SOME WIND WILL 
YIELD LOW WIND CHILLS SO WILL ALLOW THE ON-GOING WIND CHILL ADVISORY 
TO CONTINUE IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 AM THIS FRIDAY MORNING. A WEAK COLD 
ASSOCIATED WITH THE UPPER LEVEL SYSTEM WILL BE MOVING ACROSS THE 
AREA TODAY AND EARLY TONIGHT. THIS WILL REINFORCE THE COLD AIR NOW 
IN PLACE. THE RESIDUAL SNOW COVER AND PATCHY ICE WILL CONTINUE TO 
PLAY A ROLE IN THE TEMPERATURE TRENDS TODAY...TONIGHT AND INTO 
CHRISTMAS.      
(38)    
&&

38/29





134 
FXUS64 KLZK 240320
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
919 PM CST THU DEC 23 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SATELLITE IMAGERY INDICATES SCATTERED TO BROKEN CIRRUS ACROSS ALL OF 
THE FORECAST AREA. OBSERVATIONAL DATA TRENDS GENERALLY SUPPORT NEAR 
TERM FORECASTS. EXPECTED WIND SPEEDS ARE QUITE MARGINAL FOR WIND 
CHILL ADVISORY...BUT WILL NOT DROP THE ADVISORY...FOR CONTINUITY 
CONCERNS. 
(55)

&&

.PREVIOUS DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 235 PM CST THU DEC 23 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
THE CALM AFTER THE WINTER STORM PREVAILS ACRS AR THIS AFTN. SNOW 
FIELD SHOWING UP QUITE WELL ON VISIBLE PICS OVR MUCH OF NRN AND 
CNTRL AR. AFTN TEMPS HAVE RECOVERED INTO THE 20S AND LOWER 30S.

MAIN FCST CONCERN THRU THE SHORT TERM WL BE TEMPS. MODELS STILL SHOW 
A WEAK UPPER SHRTWV MOVG ACRS THE AREA LATER TNGT AND FRI. ONLY 
LOOKING AT MAINLY MID AND HIGH CLDS WITH THIS FEATURE. EXPECT TEMPS 
TO FALL QUICKLY AFTER SUNSET THIS EVENING...BUT FULL EFFECTS OF 
RADIATIONAL COOLING MAY BE HAMPERED SOME BY THE CLOUDS TNGT. COMBO 
OF SINGLE DIGIT TEMPS AND WINDS ARND 10 MPH WILL PRODUCE WIND CHILLS 
IN THE ZERO TO MINUS 10 DEGREE RANGE OVERNIGHT ACRS N-CNTRL AR. HAVE 
ISSUED A WIND CHILL ADVY FOR THOSE AREAS TNGT AND EARLY FRI MRNG.

WEAK CDFNT ASSOCD WITH UPPER SYSTEM IS FCST TO PASS THRU THE FA FRI 
AND EARLY FRI NIGHT WITH A REINFORCING SHOT OF COLDER AIR/SFC HIGH 
PRES BEHIND IT. RESIDUAL SNOW COVER WL CONT TO PLAY A ROLE IN TEMP 
TRENDS INTO SAT.

BY SAT AFTN...HIGH PRES SHIFTS EWD AND A MODERATING TREND BEGINS. 
MOS TEMPS LOOK REASONABLE THRU THIS TIME PD AND HAVE NOT STRAYED TOO 
FAR FROM MODEL OUTPUT. DRY CONDS WL PREVAIL AS WELL WITH GULF 
MOISTURE STILL CUT OFF DURG THE PD.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
RIDGE TO OUR SOUTH WILL KEEP A ZONAL FLOW ACROSS ARKANSAS THROUGH 
12Z TUESDAY. THEN...THE LOW OVER THE SOUTHWEST WILL OPEN UP AND GET 
CLOSER TO ARKANSAS THROUGH 00Z THURSDAY...AND IT WILL CONTINUE TO BE 
ABSORBED BY THE NORTHERN BRANCH OF THE WESTERLIES. THE SURFACE 
REFLECTION OF THE RIDGE WILL YIELD DRY WEATHER THROUGH WEDNESDAY 
ALONG WITH A WARMING TREND SINCE CLOUDS WILL BE FEW AND WE WILL BE 
ON THE RETURN FLOW OF THE SURFACE HIGH TO OUR EAST. MOISTURE WILL BE 
PUSHING NORTH ACROSS TEXAS INTO THE UPPER MID-WEST BY 00Z WEDNESDAY. 
A SURFACE LOW WILL GATHER STRENGTH ON THE LEE SIDE OF THE ROCKIES 
AND IT WILL TIGHTEN THE GRADIENT EARLY ON WEDNESDAY INTO THURSDAY 
MORNING. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL DEVELOP AHEAD OF THE SURFACE 
FRONT WEDNESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY NIGHT. DRYING WILL COME IN QUICKLY ON 
THURSDAY.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...WIND CHILL ADVISORY FROM 900 PM 
CST THURSDAY UNTIL 800 AM CST FRIDAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>007... 
ARZ012>016...ARZ021>024...ARZ031.
&&

$$









040 
FXUS64 KLZK 231721 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1120 AM CST THU DEC 23 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FCST ON TRACK FOR THIS AFTN. WENT AHEAD AND SENT AN UPDATE 
TO REMOVE HEADLINES FROM THE FCST. WIND CHILL READINGS WL RMN ABOVE 
ZERO THIS AFTN. ADJUSTED HOURLY TEMPS GRIDS THIS AFTN BASED ON 
LATEST TRENDS AND SNOW COVER ACRS THE FA. UPDATED GRIDS AND ZNS 
ALREADY SENT.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 356 AM CST THU DEC 23 2004

SNOW EXIT THE CWA SHORTLY AFTER MIDNIGHT. HIGH PRESSURE IS NOW 
BUILDING INTO THE AREA WITH CLEAR SKIES. LATEST SATELLITE IMAGERY 
SHOWED THE CLEARING LINE ALONG I-30 AND HWY 67. SKIES WILL BECOME 
CLEAR IN THE SOUTHEAST EARLY THIS MORNING. MAIN TOPIC NOW IS THE 
COLD TEMPERATURES. TEMPERATURES WILL BE 20 TO 25 DEGREES BELOW 
NORMAL TODAY AND TONIGHT. WILL KEEP THE WIND CHILL ADVISORY GOING 
ACROSS PARTS OF NORTH ARKANSAS THIS MORNING AND ADD ANOTHER ROW OF 
COUNTIES TO THE SOUTH OF THE PREVIOUS AREA. SOME WIND CHILLS WILL BE 
0 TO 10 BELOW ZERO THIS MORNING IN THE NORTH. HIGHS TODAY ARE 
EXPECTED IN THE 20S NORTH TO THE LOWER 30S SOUTH. 

A MID LEVEL SHORT WAVE MOVES ACROSS THE AREA TONIGHT AND BRING SOME 
CLOUDS TO THE AREA. WILL NOT INCLUDE ANY PRECIPITATION AS GOOD 
SUBSIDENCE SHOULD BE IN PLACE. WILL ONLY NOTE SOME CLOUDS ACROSS 
MAINLY THE NORTH AND CENTRAL SECTIONS. MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT 
WITH THIS AND HAVE SHOWN IT THE LAST COUPLE OF RUNS. HIGH PRESSURE 
MOVES EAST OF THE AREA SATURDAY SO WILL START THE WARM UP ON 
SATURDAY AS SOUTHERLY FLOW RETURNS. WE REMAIN UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF 
THE HIGH THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT SO NO PRECIP IS ANTICIPATED. 

GUIDANCE STILL SUGGESTING A PATTERN CHANGE IN THE LONG TERM...WITH 
ARCTIC AIR SLOWLY ERODING AND A TROUGH DEVELOPING THE WESTERN UNITED 
STATES CREATING A SOUTHWEST WIND FLOW ALOFT. 

A WARMING TREND WILL RESULT...ESPECIALLY HEADING INTO 
TUESDAY/WEDNESDAY. AT THAT TIME...A RATHER POTENT STORM SYSTEM WILL 
BE TRACKING THROUGH THE PLAINS AND WILL DRAG A COLD FRONT TOWARD 
ARKANSAS. 

RECENT SNOW WILL BE A MEMORY...AS WE GO FROM WINTRY PRECIPITATION TO 
THUNDERSTORMS. A LITTLE LEERY OF THE STRENGTH/TRACK OF THE 
SYSTEM...BUT COULD BE LOOKING AT POTENTIAL OF SEVERE WEATHER IF 
GUIDANCE PANS OUT. SOMETHING TO KEEP IN MIND ANYWAY.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

44






BUILDING INTO THE AREA WITH CLEAR SKIES. LATEST SATELLITE IMAGERY 
SHOWED THE CLEARING LINE ALONG I-30 AND HWY 67. SKIES WILL BECOME 
CLEAR IN THE SOUTHEAST EARLY THIS MORNING. MAIN TOPIC NOW IS THE 
COLD TEMPERATURES. TEMPERATURES WILL BE 20 TO 25 DEGREES BELOW 
NORMAL TODAY AND TONIGHT. WILL KEEP THE WIND CHILL ADVISORY GOING 
ACROSS PARTS OF NORTH ARKANSAS THIS MORNING AND ADD ANOTHER ROW OF 
COUNTIES TO THE SOUTH OF THE PREVIOUS AREA. SOME WIND CHILLS WILL BE 
0 TO 10 BELOW ZERO THIS MORNING IN THE NORTH. HIGHS TODAY ARE 
EXPECTED IN THE 20S NORTH TO THE LOWER 30S SOUTH. 

A MID LEVEL SHORT WAVE MOVES ACROSS THE AREA TONIGHT AND BRING SOME 
CLOUDS TO THE AREA. WILL NOT INCLUDE ANY PRECIPITATION AS GOOD 
SUBSIDENCE SHOULD BE IN PLACE. WILL ONLY NOTE SOME CLOUDS ACROSS 
MAINLY THE NORTH AND CENTRAL SECTIONS. MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT 
WITH THIS AND HAVE SHOWN IT THE LAST COUPLE OF RUNS. HIGH PRESSURE 
MOVES EAST OF THE AREA SATURDAY SO WILL START THE WARM UP ON 
SATURDAY AS SOUTHERLY FLOW RETURNS. WE REMAIN UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF 
THE HIGH THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT SO NO PRECIP IS ANTICIPATED.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
GUIDANCE STILL SUGGESTING A PATTERN CHANGE IN THE LONG TERM...WITH 
ARCTIC AIR SLOWLY ERODING AND A TROUGH DEVELOPING THE WESTERN UNITED 
STATES CREATING A SOUTHWEST WIND FLOW ALOFT. 

A WARMING TREND WILL RESULT...ESPECIALLY HEADING INTO 
TUESDAY/WEDNESDAY. AT THAT TIME...A RATHER POTENT STORM SYSTEM WILL 
BE TRACKING THROUGH THE PLAINS AND WILL DRAG A COLD FRONT TOWARD 
ARKANSAS. 

RECENT SNOW WILL BE A MEMORY...AS WE GO FROM WINTRY PRECIPITATION TO 
THUNDERSTORMS. A LITTLE LEERY OF THE STRENGTH/TRACK OF THE 
SYSTEM...BUT COULD BE LOOKING AT POTENTIAL OF SEVERE WEATHER IF 
GUIDANCE PANS OUT. SOMETHING TO KEEP IN MIND ANYWAY. (46)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    28  11  25  11 /  10  10  10   0 
HARRISON AR       20   2  18   5 /  10  10  10   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    27  11  25  12 /  10  10  10   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     30  13  26  13 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  20   0  17   5 /  10  10  10   0 
MONTICELLO AR     31  15  27  15 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         25   9  23  10 /  10  10  10   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      27  11  25  12 /  10  10  10   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   24   8  23  10 /  10  10  10   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...WIND CHILL ADVISORY UNTIL 1000 AM 
CST THURSDAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>007...ARZ012>016...ARZ021>024...ARZ030.
&&

$$

51/46






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 230956
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
356 AM CST THU DEC 23 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
SNOW EXIT THE CWA SHORTLY AFTER MIDNIGHT. HIGH PRESSURE IS NOW 
BUILDING INTO THE AREA WITH CLEAR SKIES. LATEST SATELLITE IMAGERY 
SHOWED THE CLEARING LINE ALONG I-30 AND HWY 67. SKIES WILL BECOME 
CLEAR IN THE SOUTHEAST EARLY THIS MORNING. MAIN TOPIC NOW IS THE 
COLD TEMPERATURES. TEMPERATURES WILL BE 20 TO 25 DEGREES BELOW 
NORMAL TODAY AND TONIGHT. WILL KEEP THE WIND CHILL ADVISORY GOING 
ACROSS PARTS OF NORTH ARKANSAS THIS MORNING AND ADD ANOTHER ROW OF 
COUNTIES TO THE SOUTH OF THE PREVIOUS AREA. SOME WIND CHILLS WILL BE 
0 TO 10 BELOW ZERO THIS MORNING IN THE NORTH. HIGHS TODAY ARE 
EXPECTED IN THE 20S NORTH TO THE LOWER 30S SOUTH. 

A MID LEVEL SHORT WAVE MOVES ACROSS THE AREA TONIGHT AND BRING SOME 
CLOUDS TO THE AREA. WILL NOT INCLUDE ANY PRECIPITATION AS GOOD 
SUBSIDENCE SHOULD BE IN PLACE. WILL ONLY NOTE SOME CLOUDS ACROSS 
MAINLY THE NORTH AND CENTRAL SECTIONS. MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT 
WITH THIS AND HAVE SHOWN IT THE LAST COUPLE OF RUNS. HIGH PRESSURE 
MOVES EAST OF THE AREA SATURDAY SO WILL START THE WARM UP ON 
SATURDAY AS SOUTHERLY FLOW RETURNS. WE REMAIN UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF 
THE HIGH THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT SO NO PRECIP IS ANTICIPATED.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
GUIDANCE STILL SUGGESTING A PATTERN CHANGE IN THE LONG TERM...WITH 
ARCTIC AIR SLOWLY ERODING AND A TROUGH DEVELOPING THE WESTERN UNITED 
STATES CREATING A SOUTHWEST WIND FLOW ALOFT. 

A WARMING TREND WILL RESULT...ESPECIALLY HEADING INTO 
TUESDAY/WEDNESDAY. AT THAT TIME...A RATHER POTENT STORM SYSTEM WILL 
BE TRACKING THROUGH THE PLAINS AND WILL DRAG A COLD FRONT TOWARD 
ARKANSAS. 

RECENT SNOW WILL BE A MEMORY...AS WE GO FROM WINTRY PRECIPITATION TO 
THUNDERSTORMS. A LITTLE LEERY OF THE STRENGTH/TRACK OF THE 
SYSTEM...BUT COULD BE LOOKING AT POTENTIAL OF SEVERE WEATHER IF 
GUIDANCE PANS OUT. SOMETHING TO KEEP IN MIND ANYWAY. (46)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    28  11  25  11 /  10  10  10   0 
HARRISON AR       20   2  18   5 /  10  10  10   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    27  11  25  12 /  10  10  10   0

MOUNTAIN HOME AR  20   0  17   5 /  10  10  10   0 
MONTICELLO AR     31  15  27  15 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         25   9  23  10 /  10  10  10   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      27  11  25  12 /  10  10  10   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   24   8  23  10 /  10  10  10   0

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1200 AM CST THU DEC 23 2004

QUICK UPDATE THIS MORNING TO LET ALL WINTER RELATED HEADLINES 
EXPIRE. SNOW HAS JUST ABOUT ENDED OVER THE AREA ALTHOUGH A FEW 
FLAKES ARE POSSIBLE FOR THE NEXT SEVERAL HOURS. SKIES ALREADY 
CLEARING ACROSS THE NORTHWEST WITH A VERY COLD NIGHT IN STORE. ALL 
UPDATED PRODUCTS WILL BE OUT SHORTLY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
WIND CHILL ADVISORY FROM 1100 PM CST WEDNESDAY UNTIL 1000 AM CST
THURSDAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>007...ARZ012>015.

56





484 
FXUS64 KLZK 230306 RRA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
900 PM CST WED DEC 22 2004

LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES SURFACE CYCLONE ALONG THE MISSISSIPPI 
AND ALABAMA BORDER AND CONTINUING TO MOVE OFF TO THE NORTHEAST. DRY 
SLOT THAT MOVED ACROSS THE AREA EARLIER TONIGHT CONTINUES TO BE 
SQUEEZED OFF TO THE EAST AS UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT APPROACHES. SNOWFALL 
CONTINUES ACROSS MOST OF THE AREA ALTHOUGH IT HAS TAPERED OFF FOR 
THE MOST PART. RADAR CONTINUES TO SHOW MAINLY LIGHT PRECIPITATION 
WITH SEVERAL BANDS ON ENHANCEMENT IN THE PRECIPITATION SHIELD THAT 
EXTEND ALL THE WAY BACK TO THE ARKANSAS BORDER. 

WITH PRECIPITATION WINDING DOWN BUT NOT OVER...WILL CONTINUE ALL 
WARNINGS AND ADVISORIES UNTIL SCHEDULED EXPIRATION TIME AT MIDNIGHT. 
WILL ISSUE NEW PACKAGE AT THAT TIME. PRECIP SHOULD BE CONFINED 
MAINLY TO THE NORTHEAST PART OF THE AREA BUT ADDITIONAL AMOUNTS 
SHOULD BE RELATIVELY MINOR.  SNOWFALL AMOUNTS ARE AVERAGING 2 TO 5 
INCHES ACROSS THE WESTERN AND CENTRAL PARTS OF THE CWA. PLEASE REFER 
TO LITPNSLZK FOR SNOWFALL TOTALS.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...ISSUED AT 345 PM CST WED DEC 22 2004
SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT
WINTER STORM HAS MATERIALIZED PRETTY MUCH ON SCHEDULE TODAY ACRS THE 
AREA. HAVE SEEN COLDER AIR WORK INTO AR AT THE SFC AND ALOFT...
ALLOWING PRECIP TO CHANGE OVR TO A WINTRY MIX ACRS MOST AREAS...WITH 
ALL SNOW ACRS WRN AND NRN AR ATTM. MUCH DRIER AIR AT THE SFC HAS 
BEEN WORKING INTO NRN AR TODAY AND THIS MAY CUT DOWN ON SNOW AMOUNTS 
IN THOSE AREAS INTO TNGT.

MODELS IN DECENT AGREEMENT WITH PRECIP TRENDS. ETA ACTUALLY HAS DONE 
A BETTER JOB WITH PRECIP TRENDS...KEEPING THE BULK OF THE PRECIP 
FURTHER S INTO AR AS COMPARED TO THE GFS. ONE THING THEY AGREE ON IS 
THE PRECIP WL BE ENDING LATER TNGT AND MUCH COLDER AIR WL PERSIST 
INTO LATE THIS WEEK. PLAN TO KEEP HEADLINES IN PLACE INTO TNGT FOR 
THE FA. MAY HAVE TO EXTEND WARNINGS/ADVYS A LITTLE LONGER TNGT...BUT
WL MAKE LAST MINUTE DECISION.

OTHER WINTER WX ITEM TO CONTEND WITH TNGT AND THU MRNG IS WIND CHILL 
READINGS. EXPECT VALUES TO DROP BLO ZERO OVER N-CNTRL AR LATER TNGT 
AND THU MRNG...SO PLAN TO ISSUE AN ADVY WITH THIS FCST PACKAGE.

WITH EXPECTED SNOW COVER AND ARCTIC AIRMASS IN PLACE...HAVE GONE A 
FEW DEGREES BLO MOS TEMPS OVR MOST OF THE FA.
&&

.MID AND LONG TERM...00Z FRIDAY THROUGH 12Z THURSDAY 
MODELS PERSIST ON ABNORMALLY COLD AIR BLASTING INTO THE MID SOUTH 
FOR THE HOLIDAY WEEKEND. WITH SNOWSTORM UNFOLDING A BIT SOUTH THAN 
PREVIOUS THOUGHT...SNOW COVER WILL LIKELY EXIST ACROSS THE NORTHEAST 
HALF OF THE CWA. FOR THAT REASON...WENT AHEAD AND BUMPED TEMPS DOWN 
A BIT FOR FRIDAY MORNING. WITH FORECASTED TEMP AND WIND VALUES... 
WILL REALIZE WIND CHILLS AT OR BELOW ADVISORY CRITERIA...ZERO 
DEGREES. WILL HAVE TO MONITOR FOR POSSIBLE ISSUANCE OF ADVISORY.

HIGHS ON FRIDAY CONTINUED TO LOOK GOOD...JUST SOME SLIGHT TWEAKING 
MADE. H85 TEMPS REMAIN PERSISTENT WITH -12 TO -16 H85 TEMPS OVER AR 
FRIDAY. WITH FULL SUNSHINE...MIX LAYER WOULD BE ROUGHLY 900 
MB...WHICH WOULD GIVE A MAX TEMP NEAR 20. FUTURE SHIFTS WILL HAVE TO 
WATCH CLOSELY...ESPECIALLY OVER AREAS WITH A FRESH SNOWPACK WHERE 
THE SFC ALBEDO WILL BE QUITE HIGH.

MODELS...SPECIFICALLY GFS...COMING IN RATHER COLD FOR CHRISTMAS 
MORNING...3 AT RUSSELLVILLE...7 AT LITTLE ROCK. BELIEVE THAT TO BE A 
BIT COLD AT THIS TIME. MODELS HINTING AT SOME MOISTURE WORKING DOWN 
ON THE BACK SIDE OF THE H5 RIDGE...WHICH MAY GIVE USE A SAFETY 
BLANKET OF CLOUDS EARLY IN THE MORNING. ALSO...TIMING ISSUES MAY 
ARISE WITH HOW FAST THE BULK OF THE COLD AIR WILL BEGIN TO MOVE 
EAST...ALLOWING WAA TO SETUP OVER THE STATE. WENT AHEAD AND LOWERED 
TEMPS JUST A FEW SAT AM...BUT WILL BE TRICKY.

ARCTIC DOME SHIFTS EAST LATE SATURDAY AND SUNDAY...ALLOWING THE 
ATMOSPHERE TO GRADUAL WARM FOR THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS. MODELS SHOWING 
H5 TROUGH DEEPENING OFF THE WEST COAST OF THE US EARLY NEXT WEEK. 
THIS WILL GIVE OUR AREA FAIRLY DEEP SOUTHWEST FLOW. GFS AND DGEX 
INDICATING H85 TEMPS RETURNING TO NEAR +10 EARLY IN THE WEEK.

COLD FRONT PROGGED TO MOVE THROUGH THE STATE WEDNESDAY. ADDED 
THUNDER WEDNESDAY DUE TO RATHER WARM AND MOIST SFC LAYER. THIS FAR 
OUT THOUGH...TIMING WILL DEFINITELY BE AN ISSUE. BUT LOOKS LIKE THE 
COLD AIR OVER THE WEEKEND WILL BE REPLACED WITH ABOVE NORMAL TEMPS 
BY EARLY NEXT WEEK.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...WINTER STORM WARNING UNTIL 1200 
AM CST THURSDAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>007...ARZ012>016...ARZ021>025... 
ARZ030>034...ARZ037>047...ARZ052>054.

WIND CHILL ADVISORY FROM 1100 PM CST WEDNESDAY UNTIL 1000 AM CST
THURSDAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>007...ARZ012>015.

WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY UNTIL 1200 AM CST THURSDAY FOR ZONES
ARZ055>057...ARZ062>069.
&&

56

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
900 PM CST WED DEC 22 2004

LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES SURFACE CYCLONE ALONG THE MISSISSIPPI 
AND ALABAMA BORDER AND CONTINUING TO MOVE OFF TO THE NORTHEAST. DRY 
SLOT THAT MOVED ACROSS THE AREA EARLIER TONIGHT CONTINUES TO BE 
SQUEEZED OFF TO THE EAST AS UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT APPROACHES. SNOWFALL 
CONTINUES ACROSS MOST OF THE AREA ALTHOUGH IT HAS TAPERED OFF FOR 
THE MOST PART. RADAR CONTINUES TO SHOW MAINLY LIGHT PRECIPITATION 
WITH SEVERAL BANDS ON ENHANCEMENT IN THE PRECIPITATION SHIELD THAT 
EXTEND ALL THE WAY BACK TO THE ARKANSAS BORDER. 

WITH PRECIPITATION WINDING DOWN BUT NOT OVER...WILL CONTINUE ALL 
WARNINGS AND ADVISORIES UNTIL SCHEDULED EXPIRATION TIME AT MIDNIGHT. 
WILL ISSUE NEW PACKAGE AT THAT TIME. PRECIP SHOULD BE CONFINED 
MAINLY TO THE NORTHEAST PART OF THE AREA BUT ADDITIONAL AMOUNTS 
SHOULD BE RELATIVELY MINOR.  SNOWFALL AMOUNTS ARE AVERAGING 2 TO 5 
INCHES ACROSS THE WESTERN AND CENTRAL PARTS OF THE CWA. PLEASE REFER 
TO LITPNSLZK FOR SNOWFALL TOTALS.

.PREV DISCUSSION...ISSUED AT 345 PM CST WED DEC 22 2004
SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT
WINTER STORM HAS MATERIALIZED PRETTY MUCH ON SCHEDULE TODAY ACRS THE 
AREA. HAVE SEEN COLDER AIR WORK INTO AR AT THE SFC AND ALOFT...
ALLOWING PRECIP TO CHANGE OVR TO A WINTRY MIX ACRS MOST AREAS...WITH 
ALL SNOW ACRS WRN AND NRN AR ATTM. MUCH DRIER AIR AT THE SFC HAS 
BEEN WORKING INTO NRN AR TODAY AND THIS MAY CUT DOWN ON SNOW AMOUNTS 
IN THOSE AREAS INTO TNGT.

MODELS IN DECENT AGREEMENT WITH PRECIP TRENDS. ETA ACTUALLY HAS DONE 
A BETTER JOB WITH PRECIP TRENDS...KEEPING THE BULK OF THE PRECIP 
FURTHER S INTO AR AS COMPARED TO THE GFS. ONE THING THEY AGREE ON IS 
THE PRECIP WL BE ENDING LATER TNGT AND MUCH COLDER AIR WL PERSIST 
INTO LATE THIS WEEK. PLAN TO KEEP HEADLINES IN PLACE INTO TNGT FOR 
THE FA. MAY HAVE TO EXTEND WARNINGS/ADVYS A LITTLE LONGER TNGT...BUT
WL MAKE LAST MINUTE DECISION.

OTHER WINTER WX ITEM TO CONTEND WITH TNGT AND THU MRNG IS WIND CHILL 
READINGS. EXPECT VALUES TO DROP BLO ZERO OVER N-CNTRL AR LATER TNGT 
AND THU MRNG...SO PLAN TO ISSUE AN ADVY WITH THIS FCST PACKAGE.

WITH EXPECTED SNOW COVER AND ARCTIC AIRMASS IN PLACE...HAVE GONE A 
FEW DEGREES BLO MOS TEMPS OVR MOST OF THE FA.
&&

.MID AND LONG TERM...00Z FRIDAY THROUGH 12Z THURSDAY 
MODELS PERSIST ON ABNORMALLY COLD AIR BLASTING INTO THE MID SOUTH 
FOR THE HOLIDAY WEEKEND. WITH SNOWSTORM UNFOLDING A BIT SOUTH THAN 
PREVIOUS THOUGHT...SNOW COVER WILL LIKELY EXIST ACROSS THE NORTHEAST 
HALF OF THE CWA. FOR THAT REASON...WENT AHEAD AND BUMPED TEMPS DOWN 
A BIT FOR FRIDAY MORNING. WITH FORECASTED TEMP AND WIND VALUES... 
WILL REALIZE WIND CHILLS AT OR BELOW ADVISORY CRITERIA...ZERO 
DEGREES. WILL HAVE TO MONITOR FOR POSSIBLE ISSUANCE OF ADVISORY.

HIGHS ON FRIDAY CONTINUED TO LOOK GOOD...JUST SOME SLIGHT TWEAKING 
MADE. H85 TEMPS REMAIN PERSISTENT WITH -12 TO -16 H85 TEMPS OVER AR 
FRIDAY. WITH FULL SUNSHINE...MIX LAYER WOULD BE ROUGHLY 900 
MB...WHICH WOULD GIVE A MAX TEMP NEAR 20. FUTURE SHIFTS WILL HAVE TO 
WATCH CLOSELY...ESPECIALLY OVER AREAS WITH A FRESH SNOWPACK WHERE 
THE SFC ALBEDO WILL BE QUITE HIGH.

MODELS...SPECIFICALLY GFS...COMING IN RATHER COLD FOR CHRISTMAS 
MORNING...3 AT RUSSELLVILLE...7 AT LITTLE ROCK. BELIEVE THAT TO BE A 
BIT COLD AT THIS TIME. MODELS HINTING AT SOME MOISTURE WORKING DOWN 
ON THE BACK SIDE OF THE H5 RIDGE...WHICH MAY GIVE USE A SAFETY 
BLANKET OF CLOUDS EARLY IN THE MORNING. ALSO...TIMING ISSUES MAY 
ARISE WITH HOW FAST THE BULK OF THE COLD AIR WILL BEGIN TO MOVE 
EAST...ALLOWING WAA TO SETUP OVER THE STATE. WENT AHEAD AND LOWERED 
TEMPS JUST A FEW SAT AM...BUT WILL BE TRICKY.

ARCTIC DOME SHIFTS EAST LATE SATURDAY AND SUNDAY...ALLOWING THE 
ATMOSPHERE TO GRADUAL WARM FOR THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS. MODELS SHOWING 
H5 TROUGH DEEPENING OFF THE WEST COAST OF THE US EARLY NEXT WEEK. 
THIS WILL GIVE OUR AREA FAIRLY DEEP SOUTHWEST FLOW. GFS AND DGEX 
INDICATING H85 TEMPS RETURNING TO NEAR +10 EARLY IN THE WEEK.

COLD FRONT PROGGED TO MOVE THROUGH THE STATE WEDNESDAY. ADDED 
THUNDER WEDNESDAY DUE TO RATHER WARM AND MOIST SFC LAYER. THIS FAR 
OUT THOUGH...TIMING WILL DEFINITELY BE AN ISSUE. BUT LOOKS LIKE THE 
COLD AIR OVER THE WEEKEND WILL BE REPLACED WITH ABOVE NORMAL TEMPS 
BY EARLY NEXT WEEK.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...WINTER STORM WARNING UNTIL 1200 
AM CST THURSDAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>007...ARZ012>016...ARZ021>025... 
ARZ030>034...ARZ037>047...ARZ052>054.

WIND CHILL ADVISORY FROM 1100 PM CST WEDNESDAY UNTIL 1000 AM CST
THURSDAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>007...ARZ012>015.

WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY UNTIL 1200 AM CST THURSDAY FOR ZONES
ARZ055>057...ARZ062>069.
&&

44/220
