
238 
FXUS64 KLZK 090953
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
353 AM CST THU DEC 9 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
SHOWERS HAVE MOVED OUT OF THE SOUTHEAST COUNTIES AT THIS TIME. 
THEREFORE WILL NOT INCLUDE ANY POPS THIS MORNING. SATELLITE IMAGES 
SHOW CLEARING LINE ENTERING WEST ARKANSAS. SKIES WILL BECOME PARTLY 
CLOUDY THIS MORNING AND HIGHS THIS AFTERNOON WILL BE IN THE 60S.  

THE NEXT ISSUE IS THE CLIPPER SYSTEM HEADED OUR WAY TONIGHT FROM 
CANADA. WITH THIS STRONG UPPER LOW...SEVERAL SHORT WAVES WILL BE 
ROTATING AROUND IT. APPEARS TO BE MORE MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS 
SYSTEM THAN PREVIOUS MODEL RUNS. ETA IS MUCH DRIER THAN THE GFS THIS 
MORNING SO WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF GFS AND ETA WITH MORE WEIGHT 
TOWARD THE GFS. WILL INCLUDE SLIGHT CHANCE OF LIGHT RAIN SHOWERS 
TONIGHT AND INTO FRIDAY MORNING. LOOKS TO BE A BREAK DURING THE DAY 
FRIDAY...THEN ANOTHER SLIGHT CHANCE FRIDAY EVENING. MOST OF THIS 
PRECIPITATION SHOULD BE CONCENTRATED IN THE NORTHEAST AND EAST. 
AMOUNTS WILL BE LIGHT WITH GOOD COLD AIR ADVECTION SETTLING IN. THE 
TIGHT GRADIENT AROUND THE LOW WILL PRODUCE STRONG NORTHWEST WINDS 
LATE THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY. LAKE WIND ADVISORY MAY BE NEEDED 
THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY. 

HIGH PRESSURE MOVES IN FOR SATURDAY AND SATURDAY NIGHT. COLDER 
TEMPERATURES ARE EXPECTED FRIDAY NIGHT AS THE COLDER AIR FILTERS IN 
FROM THE NORTH. LOWS FRIDAY NIGHT WILL BE FROM AROUND 30 DEGREES 
NORTH TO THE MID 30S SOUTH. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
EXPECT SOME MODERATION IN TEMPS ON SUN AHEAD OF NEXT CDFNT. BNDRY 
SWEEPS THRU THE AREA LATE SUN AFTN AND EVENING...WITH MUCH COOLER 
AND DRIER AIR TO FOLLOW. SFC HIGH WL SETTLE OVER THE NATURAL STATE 
BY THE END OF THE PD. CURRENT TEMP FCST THRU THE PD LOOKS GOOD AND 
NO SIG CHGS MADE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    68  43  55  34 /  10  10  10  20 
HARRISON AR       63  38  46  29 /  10  20  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    68  43  55  35 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     69  44  56  35 /  10  10  10  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  63  38  46  29 /  10  20  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     69  46  57  36 /  10  10  10  20 
SEARCY AR         67  42  53  33 /  10  20  10  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      68  43  55  35 /  10  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   66  41  52  33 /  10  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

51/44


836 
FXUS64 KLZK 090426 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1020 PM CST WED DEC 8 2004

.DISCUSSION...
GOING FORECAST PRETTY MUCH ON TRACK. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
WIDESPREAD ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST...WITH ISOLATED/SCATTERED SHOWERS 
ELSEWHERE. 

IN THE SOUTHEAST...RAINFALL AMOUNTS TO THIS POINT HAVE 
NOT BEEN APPRECIABLE...AND OPTED NOT TO ISSUED FLASH FLOOD WATCH. 
HOWEVER...AMOUNTS OF HALF AN INCH TO AN INCH WILL BE COMMON 
OVERNIGHT IN PORTIONS OF BRADLEY...DREW...LINCOLN...DESHA AND 
ARKANSAS COUNTIES.

OTHERWISE...BOOSTED TEMPERATURES A BIT TONIGHT...ESPECIALLY IN THE 
SOUTHEAST HALF OF THE STATE. DEWPOINTS CLIMBING READILY IN THESE 
AREAS...AND TEMPERATURES WILL STAY IN THE 50S. (46)
&&       

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 300 PM CST WED DEC 8 2004

IN SHORT TERM...SHORT WAVE MOVING OUT OF THE ROCKIES SHOULD APPROACH 
THE AREA TONIGHT. MOISTURE WILL INCREASE WITH A SOUTHERLY GRADIENT 
SETTING UP AHEAD OF A SURFACE LOW IN THE PLAINS. THE MAIN MOISTURE 
INFLOW WILL BE IN THE SOUTHEAST AND WILL HAVE LIKELY POPS IN THAT 
AREA WITH POPS DECREASING TO THE NORTHWEST. WILL KEEP MENTION OF 
RAIN OUT OF THE NORTHERN ZONES. INSTABILITY WILL BE MARGINAL WITH 
THE MOST IN THE SOUTHEAST. MENTIONED ISOLATED THUNDER IN THE 
SOUTHEAST FOR A FEW HOURS DURING THE NIGHT. APPEARS THE MOISTURE 
WILL BE OUT OF THE CWA BY 12Z THURSDAY SO DROPPED ALL MENTION OF 
RAIN FOR THURSDAY. THE SHORT WAVE SHOULD PROGRESS OUT OF THE AREA 
DURING THE MORNING ALLOWING FOR CLEARING. A RATHER MODERATE WEST 
WIND SHOULD SET UP WHICH SHOULD RESULT IN GOOD WARMING SIMILAR TO 
YESTERDAY. WENT WITH MOS ON MAXES WITH MOST AREAS REACHING THE UPPER 
60S. A STRONG UPPER TROF DIGS INTO THE OHIO VALLEY THURSDAY NIGHT 
AND FRIDAY WITH VERY STRONG NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT DEVELOPING OVER THE 
AREA. THIS WILL SEND A RATHER STRONG COLD FRONT THROUGH THE AREA 
THURSDAY NIGHT WITH STRONG NORTHWEST WINDS AND COLD ADVECTION IN THE 
AREA FOR FRIDAY. OVERALL MOISTURE LOOKS INSUFFICIENT TO MENTION A 
CHANCE OF PRECIPITATION AT THIS TIME. DEEPER MOISTURE WILL BE NEAR 
THE NORTHEAST CORNER ON FRIDAY AND COULD SEE SOME SPRINKLES OR 
FLURRIES IN THAT AREA BUT WILL LEAVE IT OUT FOR NOW. CANNOT SEE MOS 
MAXES BEING REACHED ON FRIDAY IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH WITH CLOUDS AND 
COLD ADVECTION. WENT ABOUT FIVE DEGREES BELOW MOS AND STILL MAY NOT 
BE COOL ENOUGH. SKIES SHOULD CLEAR OUT FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY AS 
THE UPPER TROF MOVES TO THE EAST. FRIDAY NIGHT SHOULD BE THE COLDEST 
NIGHT AND WENT BELOW MOS ON MINS. TEMPS SHOULD MODERATE SOME SATURDAY
AND SATURDAY NIGHT.

IN LONG TERM...LOOKS DRY AND UNEVENTFUL. UPPER FLOW THROUGHOUT 
HAS A SLIGHT NORTHWEST TILT TO IT. A STRONG SHORT WAVE MOVES ACROSS 
THE OHIO RIVER VALLEY IN THE STRONGER NORTHERN BRANCH OF THE 
WESTERLIES TO OUR NORTHEAST MONDAY NIGHT INTO TUESDAY MORNING. A 
COUPLE OF SHORT WAVES MOVE ACROSS THE NORTHERN TIER OF STATES 
WITHOUT AFFECTING US. THE SURFACE PATTERN HAS A DRY FRONT CROSS 
ARKANSAS SUNDAY AFTERNOON. THEN A LARGE HIGH ON THE LEE SIDE OF THE 
ROCKIES SLIDES SOUTH FROM CANADA. ITS CLOCKWISE FLOW DAMS MOISTURE 
AGAINST THE ROCKIES WITH THE USUAL UPSLOPE EFFECT ON THE FRONT 
RANGES. THE HIGH CROSSES THE STATE TUESDAY NIGHT AND IT ENDS OVER 
THE APPALACHIANS WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46

ISSUED AT 300 PM CST WED DEC 8 2004

IN SHORT TERM...SHORT WAVE MOVING OUT OF THE ROCKIES SHOULD APPROACH 
THE AREA TONIGHT. MOISTURE WILL INCREASE WITH A SOUTHERLY GRADIENT 
SETTING UP AHEAD OF A SURFACE LOW IN THE PLAINS. THE MAIN MOISTURE 
INFLOW WILL BE IN THE SOUTHEAST AND WILL HAVE LIKELY POPS IN THAT 
AREA WITH POPS DECREASING TO THE NORTHWEST. WILL KEEP MENTION OF 
RAIN OUT OF THE NORTHERN ZONES. INSTABILITY WILL BE MARGINAL WITH 
THE MOST IN THE SOUTHEAST. MENTIONED ISOLATED THUNDER IN THE 
SOUTHEAST FOR A FEW HOURS DURING THE NIGHT. APPEARS THE MOISTURE 
WILL BE OUT OF THE CWA BY 12Z THURSDAY SO DROPPED ALL MENTION OF 
RAIN FOR THURSDAY. THE SHORT WAVE SHOULD PROGRESS OUT OF THE AREA 
DURING THE MORNING ALLOWING FOR CLEARING. A RATHER MODERATE WEST 
WIND SHOULD SET UP WHICH SHOULD RESULT IN GOOD WARMING SIMILAR TO 
YESTERDAY. WENT WITH MOS ON MAXES WITH MOST AREAS REACHING THE UPPER 
60S. A STRONG UPPER TROF DIGS INTO THE OHIO VALLEY THURSDAY NIGHT 
AND FRIDAY WITH VERY STRONG NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT DEVELOPING OVER THE 
AREA. THIS WILL SEND A RATHER STRONG COLD FRONT THROUGH THE AREA 
THURSDAY NIGHT WITH STRONG NORTHWEST WINDS AND COLD ADVECTION IN THE 
AREA FOR FRIDAY. OVERALL MOISTURE LOOKS INSUFFICIENT TO MENTION A 
CHANCE OF PRECIPITATION AT THIS TIME. DEEPER MOISTURE WILL BE NEAR 
THE NORTHEAST CORNER ON FRIDAY AND COULD SEE SOME SPRINKLES OR 
FLURRIES IN THAT AREA BUT WILL LEAVE IT OUT FOR NOW. CANNOT SEE MOS 
MAXES BEING REACHED ON FRIDAY IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH WITH CLOUDS AND 
COLD ADVECTION. WENT ABOUT FIVE DEGREES BELOW MOS AND STILL MAY NOT 
BE COOL ENOUGH. SKIES SHOULD CLEAR OUT FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY AS 
THE UPPER TROF MOVES TO THE EAST. FRIDAY NIGHT SHOULD BE THE COLDEST 
NIGHT AND WENT BELOW MOS ON MINS. TEMPS SHOULD MODERATE SOME SATURDAY
AND SATURDAY NIGHT.

IN LONG TERM...LOOKS DRY AND UNEVENTFUL. UPPER FLOW THROUGHOUT 
HAS A SLIGHT NORTHWEST TILT TO IT. A STRONG SHORT WAVE MOVES ACROSS 
THE OHIO RIVER VALLEY IN THE STRONGER NORTHERN BRANCH OF THE 
WESTERLIES TO OUR NORTHEAST MONDAY NIGHT INTO TUESDAY MORNING. A 
COUPLE OF SHORT WAVES MOVE ACROSS THE NORTHERN TIER OF STATES 
WITHOUT AFFECTING US. THE SURFACE PATTERN HAS A DRY FRONT CROSS 
ARKANSAS SUNDAY AFTERNOON. THEN A LARGE HIGH ON THE LEE SIDE OF THE 
ROCKIES SLIDES SOUTH FROM CANADA. ITS CLOCKWISE FLOW DAMS MOISTURE 
AGAINST THE ROCKIES WITH THE USUAL UPSLOPE EFFECT ON THE FRONT 
RANGES. THE HIGH CROSSES THE STATE TUESDAY NIGHT AND IT ENDS OVER 
THE APPALACHIANS WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46








AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CST WED DEC 8 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
SHORT WAVE MOVING OUT OF THE ROCKIES SHOULD APPROACH THE AREA 
TONIGHT. MOISTURE WILL INCREASE WITH A SOUTHERLY GRADIENT SETTING
UP AHEAD OF A SURFACE LOW IN THE PLAINS. THE MAIN MOISTURE INFLOW
WILL BE IN THE SOUTHEAST AND WILL HAVE LIKELY POPS IN THAT AREA
WITH POPS DECREASING TO THE NORTHWEST. WILL KEEP MENTION OF RAIN OUT 
OF THE NORTHERN ZONES. INSTABILITY WILL BE MARGINAL WITH THE MOST IN 
THE SOUTHEAST. MENTIONED ISOLATED THUNDER IN THE SOUTHEAST FOR A FEW 
HOURS DURING THE NIGHT. APPEARS THE MOISTURE WILL BE OUT OF THE CWA 
BY 12Z THURSDAY SO DROPPED ALL MENTION OF RAIN FOR THURSDAY. THE 
SHORT WAVE SHOULD PROGRESS OUT OF THE AREA DURING THE MORNING 
ALLOWING FOR CLEARING. A RATHER MODERATE WEST WIND SHOULD SET UP
WHICH SHOULD RESULT IN GOOD WARMING SIMILAR TO YESTERDAY. WENT 
WITH MOS ON MAXES WITH MOST AREAS REACHING THE UPPER 60S. A STRONG
UPPER TROF DIGS INTO THE OHIO VALLEY THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY
WITH VERY STRONG NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT DEVLOPING OVER THE AREA.
THIS WILL SEND A RATHER STRONG COLD FRONT THROUGH THE AREA THURSDAY
NIGHT WITH STRONG NORTHWEST WINDS AND COLD ADVECTION IN THE AREA
FOR FRIDAY. OVERALL MOISTURE LOOKS INSUFFICIENT TO MENTION A CHANCE
OF PRECIPITATION AT THIS TIME. DEEPER MOISTURE WILL BE NEAR THE 
NORTHEAST CORNER ON FRIDAY AND COULD SEE SOME SPRINKLES OR FLURRIES
IN THAT AREA BUT WILL LEAVE IT OUT FOR NOW. CANNOT SEE MOS MAXES
BEING REACHED ON FRIDAY IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH WITH CLOUDS AND COLD
ADVECTION. WENT ABOUT FIVE DEGREES BELOW MOS AND STILL MAY NOT BE
COOL ENOUGH. SKIES SHOULD CLEAR OUT FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY AS THE
UPPER TROF MOES TO THE EAST. FRIDAY NIGHT SHOULD BE THE COLDEST 
NIGHT AND WENT BELOW MOS ON MINS. TEMPS SHOULD MODERATE SOME SATURDAY
AND SATURDAY NIGHT.   
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
THIS PERIOD LOOKS DRY AND UNEVENTFUL. UPPER FLOW THROUGHOUT HAS A 
SLIGHT NORTHWEST TILT TO IT. A STRONG SHORT WAVE MOVES ACROSS THE 
OHIO RIVER VALLEY IN THE STRONGER NORTHERN BRANCH OF THE WESTERLIES 
TO OUR NORTHEAST MONDAY NIGHT INTO TUESDAY MORNING. A COUPLE OF 
SHORT WAVES MOVE ACROSS THE NORTHERN TIER OF STATES WITHOUT 
AFFECTING US. THE SURFACE PATTERN HAS A DRY FRONT CROSS ARKANSAS 
SUNDAY AFTERNOON. THEN A LARGE HIGH ON THE LEE SIDE OF THE ROCKIES 
SLIDES SOUTH FROM CANADA. ITS CLOCKWISE FLOW DAMS MOISTURE AGAINST 
THE ROCKIES WITH THE USUAL UPSLOPE EFFECT ON THE FRONT RANGES. THE 
HIGH CROSSES THE STATE TUESDAY NIGHT AND IT ENDS OVER THE 
APPALACHIANS WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    45  67  43  55 /  50  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       41  62  38  48 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    45  67  43  55 /  50  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     47  68  44  56 /  60  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  41  62  38  48 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     50  68  46  57 /  70  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         43  66  42  53 /  40  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      45  67  43  55 /  30  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   43  65  41  52 /  30  10  10  10

29/32






434 
FXUS64 KLZK 081739
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1140 AM CST WED DEC 8 2004

.DISCUSSION...
RATHER TIGHT PRESSURE GRADIENT HAS DEVELOPED IN EASTERN OKLAHOMA 
INTO NORTHWESTERN ARKANSAS AHEAD OF THE APPROACHING LOW PRESSURE
SYSTEM. WINDS HAVE INCREASED DUE TO THIS SO INCREASED WIND FORECASTS
FOR THIS AFTERNOON...ESPECIALLY IN THE NORTH. CONSIDERABLE CIRRUS
COVERS THE AREA TODAY WHICH SHOULD CONTINUE. LOWER CLOUDS SHOULD
INCREASE FROM THE SOUTH LATER THIS AFTERNOON INTO TONIGHT. DUE
TO THE THINNESS OF THE PRESENT CLOUD COVER...WENT WITH 50 PERCENT
COVERAGE AND PARTLY CLOUDY WORDING FOR THIS AFTERNOON...BECOMING
MOSTLY CLOUDY AS THE OPAQUE LOWER CLOUDS MOVE IN. TEMP FORECASTS
STILL LOOK ON TRACK IN MOST AREAS ALTHOUGH THEY COULD BE A LITTLE
HIGH IN THE NORTHWEST.  
&&
29

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 354 AM CST WED DEC 8 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT
SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE IS NOW MOVING OFF TO THE EAST AND IS CURRENTLY 
CENTERED IN SOUTHERN ILLINOIS. HIGH CLOUDS ASSOCIATED WITH A SHORT 
WAVE ARE SEEN ON INFRARED SATELLITE IMAGES MOVING THROUGH TEXAS AND 
OKLAHOMA. SOME OF THESE HIGH CLOUDS WILL MOVE ACROSS ARKANSAS THIS 
MORNING ESPECIALLY THE NORTH SECTIONS. CLOUDS WERE ALSO NOTED ALONG 
THE FRONT IN THE GULF OF MEXICO. 

GFS IS MORE CONSISTENT THAN THE ETA THIS MORNING WITH THE 
DEVELOPMENT OF LOW PRESSURE ALONG THE FRONT IN THE GULF AND ITS 
MOVEMENT. THE AFOREMENTIONED SHORT WAVE WILL INTERACT WITH A LOW 
THAT WILL DRAG THE WARM FRONT CLOSE TO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS TO HELP 
INDUCE SHOWERS. SHOWERS ARE EXPECTED MAINLY ACROSS SOUTH AND CENTRAL 
SECTIONS TONIGHT AND WILL KEEP THE NORTH DRY. CLOUDS SHOULD 
INCREASE THIS AFTERNOON AND RAIN CHANCES WILL BE GREATEST IN THE 
SOUTH AND WORK NORTH. SHOULD BE A QUICK EVENT AS THE SYSTEM MOVES 
EAST OF THE AREA BY 12Z THURSDAY. WILL KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS 
IN FOR EARLY THURSDAY MORNING SOUTHEAST AS THE SYSTEM DEPARTS. 

CANADIAN LOW PRESSURE DIVES SOUTHWARD THROUGH THE PLAINS THURSDAY 
AFTERNOON BRINING A COLD FRONT THROUGH ARKANSAS THURSDAY NIGHT. WITH 
1000-500MB THICKNESS VALUES LESS THAN 540 WILL EXPECT COLD AIR TO 
MOVE IN. INCREASING WINDS MAY KEEP THE ATMOSPHERE MIXED ENOUGH TO 
KEEP SURFACE TEMPERATURES FROM FALLING THAT MUCH. NO RAIN EXPECTED 
AS MOISTURE IS RATHER LIMITED. STILL...DECREASED LOWS A FEW DEGREES 
THURSDAY NIGHT. 

HIGH PRESSURE WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA FROM THE WEST FRIDAY NIGHT. 
FRIDAY AND FRIDAY NIGHT WILL BE DRY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
NWLY FLOW ALOFT WL CONT TO PREVAIL THRU THE PD. EXPECT MODERATING 
TEMPS SAT AND SUN AS ONE FRONT DEPARTS THE AREA AND ANOTHER APCHS 
FROM THE NW. DECIDED TO RAISE MAX TEMPS SEVERAL DEGREES SUN IN 
ADVANCE OF THE BNDRY. EXPECT FROPA SUN AFTN AND EVENING WITH MUCH 
COOLER AND DRIER AIR TO FOLLOW. LACK OF SIG MOISTURE WILL KEEP RAIN 
CHCS AOB 10 PERCENT TO CLOSE OUT THE WEEKEND. EXPECT READINGS NEAR 
OR JUST BLO NORMAL LVLS EARLY NEXT WEEK.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    61  45  64  41 /  10  50  10  10 
HARRISON AR       59  41  61  36 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    62  45  64  40 /  10  50  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     62  46  64  42 /  10  60  20  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  59  41  61  38 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     63  47  65  43 /  10  70  20  10 
SEARCY AR         60  43  63  41 /  10  40  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      62  45  64  39 /  10  30  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   59  42  63  38 /  10  30  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

FRIDAY AND FRIDAY NIGHT WILL BE DRY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
NWLY FLOW ALOFT WL CONT TO PREVAIL THRU THE PD. EXPECT MODERATING 
TEMPS SAT AND SUN AS ONE FRONT DEPARTS THE AREA AND ANOTHER APCHS 
FROM THE NW. DECIDED TO RAISE MAX TEMPS SEVERAL DEGREES SUN IN 
ADVANCE OF THE BNDRY. EXPECT FROPA SUN AFTN AND EVENING WITH MUCH 
COOLER AND DRIER AIR TO FOLLOW. LACK OF SIG MOISTURE WILL KEEP RAIN 
CHCS AOB 10 PERCENT TO CLOSE OUT THE WEEKEND. EXPECT READINGS NEAR 
OR JUST BLO NORMAL LVLS EARLY NEXT WEEK.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    61  45  64  41 /  10  50  10  10 
HARRISON AR       59  41  61  36 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    62  45  64  40 /  10  50  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     62  46  64  42 /  10  60  20  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  59  41  61  38 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     63  47  65  43 /  10  70  20  10 
SEARCY AR         60  43  63  41 /  10  40  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      62  45  64  39 /  10  30  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   59  42  63  38 /  10  30  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

51/44






598 
FXUS64 KLZK 080328
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
915 PM CST TUE DEC  7 2004

.DISCUSSION...
FORECAST RIGHT ON TARGET AND NO CHANGES NEEDED. WEAK AREA OF HIGH 
PRESSURE WILL CONTINUE TO BE IN CONTROL AND MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES ARE 
EXPECTED. BAND OF CIRRUS MOVING ACROSS THE CENTRAL PART OF THE STATE 
WILL THIN OUT WITH TIME AND WILL NOT HAVE MUCH OF AN IMPACTED ON 
FORECASTED LOWS.

WARM FRONT STILL PROGGED TO LIFT TO THE NORTH LATE WEDNESDAY WITH 
ANOTHER CHANCE OF RAIN DURING THE NIGHT. NEW MESO-ETA AND ETA12 NOW 
SHOW PRECIP FURTHER NORTH THAN PREVIOUS RUNS. POPS MAY NEED TO BE 
ADJUSTED UPWARDS WEDNESDAY NIGHT BUT WILL HOLD OFF ON ANY CHANGES 
FOR NOW UNTIL ALL SHORT TERM MODELS COME IN FOR THE MIDNIGHT CREW.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 300 PM CST TUE DEC  7 2004 

WEAK SURFACE HIGH WILL PASS OVER THE AREA TONIGHT WITH QUITE DRY AIR
IN PLACE. THIS SHOULD ALLOW FOR GOOD COOLING WITH MINS INTO THE 30S 
IN MOST PLACES. THE SURFACE HIGH MOVES EAST EARLY WEDNESDAY AND
RETURN FLOW BEGINS. SHOULD SEE SLOW INCREASE IN MOISTURE DURING THE 
DAY WITH CLOUDS INCREASING LATE. MOISTURE SHOULD BE INSUFFICIENT
FOR A CHANCE OF RAIN BY THE END OF WEDNESDAY. CHANCES OF RAIN 
INCREASE MOSTLY IN THE SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST WEDNESDAY NIGHT AS
AN UPPER TROF MOVES IN FROM THE WEST AND THE OLD FRONTAL SYSTEM
LIFTS BACK NORTH TOWARD THE AREA AS A WARM FRONT. WILL KEEP 
MENTION OF RAIN OUT OF THE NORTHERN ZONES AND HAVE MOSTLY CHANCE
POPS ELSEWHERE WITH THE HIGHEST IN THE SOUTHEAST. WILL CONTINUE WITH 
SMALL POPS IN THE SOUTHEAST EARLY THURSDAY WHILE THE UPPER TROF 
CLEARS OUT TO THE EAST. A RATHER STRONG UPPER LOW THEN DIGS INTO 
THE OHIO VALLEY WITH INCREASING NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT OVER THIS 
AREA. THE MAIN EFFECTS OF THIS UPPER LOW WILL STAY TO THE NORTHEAST
OF THE AREA. DRY WEATHER SHOULD PREVAIL ACROSS ARKANSAS THROUGH 
FRIDAY. WENT CLOSE TO GUIDANCE ON TEMP FORECASTS WITH COOLER AIR 
MOVING IN FRIDAY. 

THIS PERIOD BEGINS WITH NORTHWESTERLY FLOW IN THE WAKE OF FRIDAYS 
LONG WAVE TROF AND IT TRANSFORMS PRIMARILY INTO ZONAL FLOW FOR 
SUNDAY. THE NEXT SHORT WAVE RIDES THE WESTERLIES INTO THE NORTHERN 
AND CENTRAL ROCKIES FOR TUESDAY. IT SHOWS THAT THE NEXT SYSTEM 
BEYOND THIS FORECAST PERIOD WILL NOT DIP AS FAR SOUTH AS THE 
PREVIOUS ONES HAVE DONE. AT THE SURFACE...SATURDAY WILL BEGIN WITH 
NORTHWEST WINDS THAT WILL BACK QUICKLY DURING THE DAY AND INTO 
SUNDAY MORNING. HIGHS SATURDAY SHOULD REBOUND RATHER WELL...AND SO 
WILL THE LOWS FOR SUNDAY MORNING. A WEAK SHOT OF ENERGY WILL BE 
ROTATING AROUND THE UPPER LOW OVER THE GREAT LAKES AREA. THIS WILL 
BRING A CORRESPONDINGLY WEAK SURFACE FRONT TO THE MID SOUTH ON 
SUNDAY. THIS FRONT WILL BE LACKING MOISTURE SINCE THE GULF NEVER 
OPENS UP. WITH LIMITED MOISTURE...FORECAST WILL INCLUDE MINIMAL POPS 
WITH THE FRONTAL PASSAGE. NORTHERLY WINDS WILL BE BREEZY SUNDAY 
NIGHT AND MONDAY MORNING. COOL AND DRY AIR WILL REESTABLISH ITSELF 
OVER ARKANSAS FOR TUESDAY. 

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29/32










371 
FXUS64 KLZK 071654
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1050 AM CST TUE DEC 7 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CLOUDS HAVE MOSTLY CLEARED OUT OF THE CWA AS UPPER TROF AND COLD
FRONT MOVE RAPIDLY EAST AWAY FROM THE AREA. SOME STRATOCU HAS
DEVELOPED AT THE WFO AND PROBABLY WILL SEE SOME STRATOCU THROUGH 
THE AFTERNOON AT MANY AREAS ESPECIALLY NORTH AND CENTRAL. THIS
SHOULD CLEAR OUT BY SUNSET AND TONIGHT SHOULD BE CLEAR WITH VERY DRY
AIR IN PLACE. SENT OUT UPDATE TO REMOVE MORNING WORDING AND GO WITH
PARTLY CLOUDY THIS AFTERNOON AND CLEAR TONIGHT. TEMP FORECASTS LOOK
PRETTY GOOD AND ONLY MADE MINOR TWEAKS TO GRIDS TO RELFECT OBSERVED
DATA. FAIRLY BREEZY IN NORTH LATE THIS MORNING BUT WINDS SHOULD
DIMINISH THROUGH THE AFTERNOON AND ADJUSTED GRIDS FOR THIS.  
&&

29

.PREV DISCUSSION
ISSUED AT 350 AM CST TUE DEC 7 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT
COLD FRONT HAS MOVED THROUGH AND WINDS ARE BECOMING WEST ACROSS THE 
AREA. LOW PRESSURE CURRENTLY LOCATED OVER EAST CENTRAL MISSOURI. 
SATELLITE IMAGES SHOW SOME LOW CLOUDS MOVING INTO WESTERN SECTIONS. 
ALL AREAS SHOULD SEE THE CLOUDS WELL DISSIPATED BY NOON AS HIGH 
PRESSURE CONTINUES TO BUILD IN BEHIND THE DEPARTING LOW. VERY DRY 
AIR MOVES IN FOR TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY. 

THE NEXT CHANCE OF RAIN WILL BE WEDNESDAY NIGHT INTO THURSDAY 
MORNING. THE COLD FRONT THAT MOVED THROUGH THIS MORNING WILL STALL 
IN THE GULF OF MEXICO AND BY LATE WEDNESDAY WILL BE MOVING BACK TO 
THE NORTH. AN APPROACHING SHORT WAVE WILL INTERACT WITH THE FRONT 
AND WILL BRING THE BEST CHANCES OF SHOWERS TO THE SOUTH AND 
SOUTHEAST SECTIONS. AN UPPER TROUGH WILL MOVE EAST OF THE AREA 
THURSDAY NIGHT AND THIS WILL ALLOW DRIER AIR TO MOVE INTO THE REGION 
THURSDAY AFTERNOON AND THURSDAY NIGHT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH MONDAY
NWLY FLOW ALOFT IS FCST TO PREVAIL ACRS THE MID-SOUTH. SFC HIGH WL 
BE SETTLING INTO AR EARLY IN THE PD...PROVIDING COOLER AND DRIER 
AIRMASS. A REINFORCING SHOT OF COOLER AIR WILL ARRIVE ON MON BEHIND 
ANOTHER CDFNT. WITH GULF MOISTURE CUTOFF...ONLY LOOKING AT A WIND 
SHIFT ALONG WITH A FEW MID AND HIGH LVL CLOUDS WITH FROPA. LTL 
CHANGE TO GOING FCST TEMPS...WITH HIGHS IN THE 50S AND LOWS IN THE 
30S THRU THE PD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    65  38  60  45 /  10   0   0  30 
HARRISON AR       58  34  57  41 /  10   0  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    64  38  61  45 /  10   0  10  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     66  40  61  46 /  10   0  10  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  58  34  57  41 /  10   0   0  10 
MONTICELLO AR     68  41  62  47 /  10   0  10  40 
SEARCY AR         62  37  59  43 /  10   0   0  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      63  37  61  45 /  10   0  10  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   60  35  58  42 /  10   0   0  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

HOT SPRINGS AR    64  38  61  45 /  10   0  10  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     66  40  61  46 /  10   0  10  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  58  34  57  41 /  10   0   0  10 
MONTICELLO AR     68  41  62  47 /  10   0  10  40 
SEARCY AR         62  37  59  43 /  10   0   0  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      63  37  61  45 /  10   0  10  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   60  35  58  42 /  10   0   0  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

51/44






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 070951
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
350 AM CST TUE DEC 7 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT
COLD FRONT HAS MOVED THROUGH AND WINDS ARE BECOMING WEST ACROSS THE 
AREA. LOW PRESSURE CURRENTLY LOCATED OVER EAST CENTRAL MISSOURI. 
SATELLITE IMAGES SHOW SOME LOW CLOUDS MOVING INTO WESTERN SECTIONS. 
ALL AREAS SHOULD SEE THE CLOUDS WELL DISSIPATED BY NOON AS HIGH 
PRESSURE CONTINUES TO BUILD IN BEHIND THE DEPARTING LOW. VERY DRY 
AIR MOVES IN FOR TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY. 

THE NEXT CHANCE OF RAIN WILL BE WEDNESDAY NIGHT INTO THURSDAY 
MORNING. THE COLD FRONT THAT MOVED THROUGH THIS MORNING WILL STALL 
IN THE GULF OF MEXICO AND BY LATE WEDNESDAY WILL BE MOVING BACK TO 
THE NORTH. AN APPROACHING SHORT WAVE WILL INTERACT WITH THE FRONT 
AND WILL BRING THE BEST CHANCES OF SHOWERS TO THE SOUTH AND 
SOUTHEAST SECTIONS. AN UPPER TROUGH WILL MOVE EAST OF THE AREA 
THURSDAY NIGHT AND THIS WILL ALLOW DRIER AIR TO MOVE INTO THE REGION 
THURSDAY AFTERNOON AND THURSDAY NIGHT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH MONDAY
NWLY FLOW ALOFT IS FCST TO PREVAIL ACRS THE MID-SOUTH. SFC HIGH WL 
BE SETTLING INTO AR EARLY IN THE PD...PROVIDING COOLER AND DRIER 
AIRMASS. A REINFORCING SHOT OF COOLER AIR WILL ARRIVE ON MON BEHIND 
ANOTHER CDFNT. WITH GULF MOISTURE CUTOFF...ONLY LOOKING AT A WIND 
SHIFT ALONG WITH A FEW MID AND HIGH LVL CLOUDS WITH FROPA. LTL 
CHANGE TO GOING FCST TEMPS...WITH HIGHS IN THE 50S AND LOWS IN THE 
30S THRU THE PD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    65  38  60  45 /  10   0   0  30 
HARRISON AR       58  34  57  41 /  10   0  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    64  38  61  45 /  10   0  10  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     66  40  61  46 /  10   0  10  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  58  34  57  41 /  10   0   0  10 
MONTICELLO AR     68  41  62  47 /  10   0  10  40 
SEARCY AR         62  37  59  43 /  10   0   0  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      63  37  61  45 /  10   0  10  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   60  35  58  42 /  10   0   0  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

51/44






517 
FXUS64 KLZK 070312
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
904 PM CST MON DEC  6 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LOTS GOING ON TONIGHT AND DISCUSSION WILL BE BRIEF. NUMEROUS WATCHES 
REMAIN IN EFFECT THIS EVENING FOR SQUALL LINE FORMING ALONG THE 
ADVANCING COLD FRONT. STILL APPEARS THAT SOUTHERN ARKANSAS WILL SEE 
THE BEST CHANCES OF SEEING SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS WITH STRONG WINDS 
BEING THE PRIMARY CONCERN.

VERTICAL PROFILES REMAIN FAVORABLE FOR SEVERE DEVELOPMENT BUT LACK OF
STABILITY WILL PRECLUDE WIDESPREAD ACTIVITY. BOW ECHOS WILL BE THE 
PRIMARY CONCERN THIS EVENING WITH AS LINE RACES EASTWARD. CURRENT 
GRIDS/ZONES ACTUALLY NEED VERY LITTLE WORK AT THIS TIME AND WILL NOT 
ISSUE ANY WHOLESALE CHANGES AT THIS TIME.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 315 PM CST MON DEC  6 2004

STRONG UPPER TROF AND COLD FRONT WILL MOVE ACROSS THE AREA 
OVERNIGHT. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BECOME WIDESPREAD DURING 
THE EVENING...AND THEN BEGIN TO TAPER OFF FROM THE WEST AFTER 
MIDNIGHT. A FEW SHOWERS MAY BE LEFT OVER THE EASTERN SECTIONS 
TUESDAY MORNING...BUT ALL RAINFALL SHOULD BE GONE BY NOONTIME. DRY 
WEATHER THEN ON TAP FOR THE REMAINDER OF TUESDAY AND DURING THE DAY 
ON WEDNESDAY. RETURN FLOW STARTING WEDNESDAY NIGHT BRINGS A RETURN 
OF SHOWERS TO THE AREA WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY MORNING. 
TEMPERATURES WILL COOL OFF TO MORE NORMAL LEVELS ON TUESDAY. 

HIGH PRESSURE WILL THE MAIN STORY...WITH DRY CONDITIONS IN THE 
FORECAST. WEAK FRONT TO MOVE THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT/MONDAY...BUT LACK 
OF MOISTURE WILL PREVENT ANY MORE THAN A WIND SHIFT AND COOLER AIR. 
TEMPERATURES WILL BE NEAR TO SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL...WITH READINGS 
IN THE 50S FOR HIGHS...AND 30S FOR LOWS.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

22/58








855 
FXUS64 KLZK 062029 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
229 PM CST MON DEC  6 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS HAVE NOT BECOME AS WIDESPREAD THIS 
AFTERNOON AS WAS PREVIOUSLY FORECASTED. QUICK UPDATE TO LOWER POPS 
FOR THIS AFTERNOON TO CHANCE CATEGORY...WITH SMALLEST POPS IN THE 
NORTH AND LARGEST POPS IN THE SOUTH. ALL UPDATES OUT. 
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 1048 AM CST MON DEC 6 2004

UPDATED FORECASTS TO CLEAN UP WORDING IN THE TEXT PRODUCTS. THINK 
THAT ANY POSSIBILITY FOR SEVERE THIS AFTERNOON WILL BE LATE. BIGGER 
SHOW LOOKS LIKE IT SHOULD BE TONIGHT.

ISSUED AT 922 AM CST MON DEC 6 2004

QUICK UPDATE TO REMOVE DENSE FOG ADVISORY FROM THE ZONE FORECASTS. 
CONTINUED FOG IN THE FORECASTS UNTIL NOONTIME. REST OF PREVIOUS 
FORECAST OKAY.

ISSUED AT 350 AM CST MON DEC 6 2004

TALE OF TWO SEASONS ACRS THE FA THIS MRNG...WITH SPRINGLIKE TEMPS 
NOTED OVER SERN AR AND READINGS MORE TYPICAL OF THIS TIME OF YEAR 
ELSEWHERE. WE CAN THANK A WARM FRONT THAT WAS SITUATED ROUGHLY ALONG 
A KTXK-KPBF-KMEM LINE ATTM. READINGS S OF THE BNDRY WERE WELL INTO 
THE 60S. MEANWHILE...AREAS OF DENSE FOG WERE NOTED N OF THE BNDRY 
AND ALREADY ISSUED A DENSE FOG ADVY THRU MID-MRNG FOR THOSE AREAS. 
MAY HAVE ADD A FEW COUNTIES WITH BNDRY MEANDERING OVR CNTRL AR.

MODELS RMN IS GOOD AGREEMENT WITH OVERALL FCST TRENDS. UPPER SYS 
THAT BROUGHT THE RAINFALL ON SUN WAS HEADING INTO THE GREAT LAKES 
REGION THIS MRNG. MEANWHILE...THE NEXT UPPER LOW TO BRING ROUND TWO 
OF WET WEATHER TO AR WAS LOCATED OVR NRN BAJA/SWRN AZ. THIS FEATURE 
WILL CONT TO HEAD TOWARD THE SRN PLAINS LATER TODAY AND TRACK ACRS 
THE MID-SOUTH TNGT.

EXPECT WARM FRONT TO EVENTUALLY MOVE FURTHER NWD LATER TODAY AS SFC 
LOW DVLPS OVR THE PLAINS AND SLY FLOW INCRS. HOW FAR N OF THE BNDRY 
WILL GET IS ONE FCST CONCERN. AT THIS POINT...IT APPEARS THAT THE 
MORE HUMID AIR WILL AT LEAST ENCOMPASS LOCATIONS ALONG AND E OF THE 
I-30/HWY 67 CORRIDOR. EXPECT ADDITIONAL SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO 
FORM THIS AFTN IN ADVANCE OF THE UPPER LOW TO OUR SW AND SPREAD NEWD.

THE OTHER FCST CONCERN LATER THIS AFTN AND EVENING IS SVR WX 
POTENTIAL. WE HAVE BEEN HIGHLIGHTING THE POTENTIAL FOR THE LAST FEW 
DAYS. FCST WIND FIELDS RMN FAVORABLE AT THE SFC AND ALOFT FOR 
ROTATING STORMS. HOWEVER...THE AMOUNT OF INSTABILITY IS STILL IN 
QUESTION IF THE CLOUD COVER RMNS IN PLACE. IT/S TOUGHER THIS TIME OF 
YEAR TO BREAK OUT OF THE STRATUS WITH A LOWER SUN ANGLE. AGREE WITH 
THE LATEST DAY ONE OUTLOOK FROM SPC WITH A MOD RISK OF STORMS FOR 
THE SERN HALF OF THE FA. WILL AGAIN HIGHLIGHT THE POTENTIAL IN THE 
HWO.

CDFNT ASSOCD WITH THE UPPER STORM WILL SWEEP THRU THE STATE LATER 
TNGT AND EARLY TUE AND STALL OUT S OF THE AREA. CONVECTION OVERNIGHT 
EXPECTED TO EVOLVE INTO A SQUALL LINE ALONG AND AHEAD OF THE FNT. WL 
CONT WITH HIGHEST POPS THIS EVENING AND DCRS RAIN CHCS FROM THE WEST 
AFTER MIDNIGHT. DID LEAVE SOME LINGERING LOW POPS IN ERN AR TUE MRNG.

HIGH PRES WL BUILD IN BRIEFLY ACRS AR TUE NIGHT AND WED. BY WED 
NIGHT...THE HIGH SHIFTS EWD AND RETURN FLOW SETS UP ONCE AGAIN. FNTL 
BNDRY WILL BEGIN TO RETURN NWD WED NIGHT WITH A CHC OF RAIN BACK IN 
THE FCST.

A WARM FRONT IN THE GULF WILL MOVE ONSHORE THURSDAY AND WILL SET UP 
ANOTHER OVERRUNNING EPISODE. BEST CHANCES OF RAIN WILL BE IN THE 
SOUTHERN HALF OF THE STATE ON THURSDAY. ALSO THERE WILL BE A CHANCE 
OF THUNDERSTORMS IN THE SOUTH. A STRONG COLD FRONT IN THE NORTHERN 
PLAINS WILL SINK SOUTH AND PUSH THE MOISTURE OFF TO THE EAST EARLY 
FRIDAY. AS THE UPPER LOW MOVES EAST OF THE GREAT LAKES...NORTHWEST 
FLOW WILL RETURN TO THE AREA. THIS WILL BRING COOLER TEMPERATURES 
FOR SATURDAY MORNING. HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES FOR SATURDAY AND 
SUNDAY.  

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

THE FCST.

A WARM FRONT IN THE GULF WILL MOVE ONSHORE THURSDAY AND WILL SET UP 
ANOTHER OVERRUNNING EPISODE. BEST CHANCES OF RAIN WILL BE IN THE 
SOUTHERN HALF OF THE STATE ON THURSDAY. ALSO THERE WILL BE A CHANCE

SUNDAY.  

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

FXUS64 KLZK 061647 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1048 AM CST MON DEC 6 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATED FORECASTS TO CLEAN UP WORDING IN THE TEXT PRODUCTS. THINK 
THAT ANY POSSIBILITY FOR SEVERE THIS AFTERNOON WILL BE LATE. BIGGER 
SHOW LOOKS LIKE IT SHOULD BE TONIGHT.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 922 AM CST MON DEC 6 2004

QUICK UPDATE TO REMOVE DENSE FOG ADVISORY FROM THE ZONE FORECASTS. 
CONTINUED FOG IN THE FORECASTS UNTIL NOONTIME. REST OF PREVIOUS 
FORECAST OKAY.

ISSUED AT 350 AM CST MON DEC 6 2004

TALE OF TWO SEASONS ACRS THE FA THIS MRNG...WITH SPRINGLIKE TEMPS 
NOTED OVER SERN AR AND READINGS MORE TYPICAL OF THIS TIME OF YEAR 
ELSEWHERE. WE CAN THANK A WARM FRONT THAT WAS SITUATED ROUGHLY ALONG 
A KTXK-KPBF-KMEM LINE ATTM. READINGS S OF THE BNDRY WERE WELL INTO 
THE 60S. MEANWHILE...AREAS OF DENSE FOG WERE NOTED N OF THE BNDRY 
AND ALREADY ISSUED A DENSE FOG ADVY THRU MID-MRNG FOR THOSE AREAS. 
MAY HAVE ADD A FEW COUNTIES WITH BNDRY MEANDERING OVR CNTRL AR.

MODELS RMN IS GOOD AGREEMENT WITH OVERALL FCST TRENDS. UPPER SYS 
THAT BROUGHT THE RAINFALL ON SUN WAS HEADING INTO THE GREAT LAKES 
REGION THIS MRNG. MEANWHILE...THE NEXT UPPER LOW TO BRING ROUND TWO 
OF WET WEATHER TO AR WAS LOCATED OVR NRN BAJA/SWRN AZ. THIS FEATURE 
WILL CONT TO HEAD TOWARD THE SRN PLAINS LATER TODAY AND TRACK ACRS 
THE MID-SOUTH TNGT.

EXPECT WARM FRONT TO EVENTUALLY MOVE FURTHER NWD LATER TODAY AS SFC 
LOW DVLPS OVR THE PLAINS AND SLY FLOW INCRS. HOW FAR N OF THE BNDRY 
WILL GET IS ONE FCST CONCERN. AT THIS POINT...IT APPEARS THAT THE 
MORE HUMID AIR WILL AT LEAST ENCOMPASS LOCATIONS ALONG AND E OF THE 
I-30/HWY 67 CORRIDOR. EXPECT ADDITIONAL SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO 
FORM THIS AFTN IN ADVANCE OF THE UPPER LOW TO OUR SW AND SPREAD NEWD.

THE OTHER FCST CONCERN LATER THIS AFTN AND EVENING IS SVR WX 
POTENTIAL. WE HAVE BEEN HIGHLIGHTING THE POTENTIAL FOR THE LAST FEW 
DAYS. FCST WIND FIELDS RMN FAVORABLE AT THE SFC AND ALOFT FOR 
ROTATING STORMS. HOWEVER...THE AMOUNT OF INSTABILITY IS STILL IN 
QUESTION IF THE CLOUD COVER RMNS IN PLACE. IT/S TOUGHER THIS TIME OF 
YEAR TO BREAK OUT OF THE STRATUS WITH A LOWER SUN ANGLE. AGREE WITH 
THE LATEST DAY ONE OUTLOOK FROM SPC WITH A MOD RISK OF STORMS FOR 
THE SERN HALF OF THE FA. WILL AGAIN HIGHLIGHT THE POTENTIAL IN THE 
HWO.

CDFNT ASSOCD WITH THE UPPER STORM WILL SWEEP THRU THE STATE LATER 
TNGT AND EARLY TUE AND STALL OUT S OF THE AREA. CONVECTION OVERNIGHT 
EXPECTED TO EVOLVE INTO A SQUALL LINE ALONG AND AHEAD OF THE FNT. WL 
CONT WITH HIGHEST POPS THIS EVENING AND DCRS RAIN CHCS FROM THE WEST 
AFTER MIDNIGHT. DID LEAVE SOME LINGERING LOW POPS IN ERN AR TUE MRNG.

HIGH PRES WL BUILD IN BRIEFLY ACRS AR TUE NIGHT AND WED. BY WED 
NIGHT...THE HIGH SHIFTS EWD AND RETURN FLOW SETS UP ONCE AGAIN. FNTL 
BNDRY WILL BEGIN TO RETURN NWD WED NIGHT WITH A CHC OF RAIN BACK IN 
THE FCST.

A WARM FRONT IN THE GULF WILL MOVE ONSHORE THURSDAY AND WILL SET UP 
ANOTHER OVERRUNNING EPISODE. BEST CHANCES OF RAIN WILL BE IN THE 
SOUTHERN HALF OF THE STATE ON THURSDAY. ALSO THERE WILL BE A CHANCE 
OF THUNDERSTORMS IN THE SOUTH. A STRONG COLD FRONT IN THE NORTHERN 
PLAINS WILL SINK SOUTH AND PUSH THE MOISTURE OFF TO THE EAST EARLY 
FRIDAY. AS THE UPPER LOW MOVES EAST OF THE GREAT LAKES...NORTHWEST 
FLOW WILL RETURN TO THE AREA. THIS WILL BRING COOLER TEMPERATURES 
FOR SATURDAY MORNING. HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES FOR SATURDAY AND 
SUNDAY.  

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

44/51






138 
FXUS64 KLZK 060327
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
857 PM CST SUN DEC  5 2004

.DISCUSSION...
OVERALL FORECAST IN GOOD SHAPE BUT SOME ADJUSTMENTS ARE NEEDED THIS 
EVENING. CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES WARM FRONT OVER SOUTHERN 
ARKANSAS...ROUGHLY ALONG A DEQUEEN TO ARKADELPHIA TO STAR CITY TO 
DUMAS LINE. DEW POINT TEMPERATURES HAVE RISEN INTO THE LOWER 60S 
HERE WITH AMBIENT AIR TEMPERATURE ON THE RISE EVERYWHERE. THE
TEMPERATURE AT THE WFO HAS RISEN AN AVERAGE OF ONE DEGREE PER HOUR 
THIS EVENING.  BELIEVE MOST IF NOT ALL TEMPERATURES HAVE BOTTOMED 
OUT AND SLOWLY RISING OR AT THE VERY LEAST STEADY TEMPS THE REST 
OF THE NIGHT. AS SUCH...GRIDS/ZONES TEMPS AND DEW POINTS ADJUSTED 
UPWARDS. 

WILL KEEP CURRENT POPS ALONE AS SCATTERED SHOWERS EXPECTED TO 
PERSIST IN DEVELOPING WARM AIR ADVECTION PATTERN. PLENTY OF LOW 
CLOUDS AND FOG AROUND THIS EVENING AND DONT EXPECT THIS TO GO 
ANYWHERE TONIGHT. CROSS SECTIONS SHOW DRY AIR ALOFT BUT WITH 
PERSISTENT SOUTHWEST FLOW LOW LEVELS REMAIN SATURATED. WAS TOYING 
WITH THE IDEA OF A DENSE FOG ADVISORY EARLIER BUT MANAGED TO TALK 
MYSELF OUT OF IT. WHILE POCKETS OF DENSE FOG ARE LIKELY...DONT 
BELIEVE IT WILL BE WIDESPREAD ENOUGH TO MEET CRITERIA AS GRADIENT 
SHOULD REMAIN JUST ENOUGH TO MIX THINGS UP.

CURRENT VAPOR IMAGERY SHOWS PLENTY OF TROPICAL MOISTURE BEING PULLED 
INTO THE REGION. STRONG SHORTWAVE ALSO CLEARLY SEEN OVER BAJA. 
MODELS STILL PERSISTENT IN BRINGING THE WAVE ACROSS THE AREA MONDAY 
NIGHT. COLD FRONT EXPECTED TO PLOW INTO THE TROPICAL AIR WITH 
SURFACE LOW PRESSURE MOVING TO NEAR THE ARKLATEX BY MONDAY EVENING. 
PLENTY OF DYNAMICS STILL AVAILABLE AND AREA REMAINS UNDER A SLIGHT 
RISK FOR SEVERE WEATHER WHICH APPEARS REASONABLE. ONE MISSING FACTOR 
REMAINS STABILITY. ANY WIDESPREAD SUNSHINE MONDAY WILL TAKE CARE OF 
THAT IN A HURRY AND SET THE STAGE FOR SOME POSSIBLY SEVERE STORMS.

PWAT VALUES WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE THROUGH THE NIGHT AND LOCALLY 
HEAVY RAIN WILL REMAIN POSSIBLE LATE MONDAY AND MONDAY NIGHT. (56)
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 320 PM CST SUN DEC  5 2004


PRECIP SLOWLY CLEARING OUT OF THE AREA...AS WARM BOUNDARY IN THE 
VICINITY OF CENTRAL/NORTHERN LOUISIANA CONTINUES TO MOVE NORTHWARD. 
AIRMASS MOISTENING UP...AS SIXTY PLUS DEWPOINTS SURGE NORTHWARD FROM 
LOUISIANA. SATURATED AIR...ALONG WITH LIGHT WINDS WILL ALLOW FOR 
AREAS OF FOG TO CONTINUE THROUGH THE OVERNIGHT HOURS. SOME OF THE 
FOG HAS BEEN DENSE AT TIMES...AND THIS DENSE FOG COULD BECOME MORE 
WIDESPREAD OVERNIGHT. IF THAT IS THE CASE...DENSE FOG ADVISORY WOULD 
NEED TO BE CONSIDERED. 

WARM FRONT WILL MOVE NORTHWARD TONIGHT...INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS...
AND GRADUALLY THROUGH CENTRAL AND INTO NORTHERN ARKANSAS BY MORNING. 
MOST LOCATIONS WILL LIKELY SEE THEIR OVERNIGHT LOWS BY 00Z...WITH 
TEMPERATURES STEADY OR SLOWLY RISING THROUGOUT THE NIGHT. MOST 
SIGNIFICANT RISES WILL BE IN SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. THIS AREA IS NOW IN 
THE MID 50S TO UPPER 50S...AND IS LIKELY TO BE IN THE MID 60S BY 
SUNRISE. 

SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BECOME LIKELY BY MONDAY 
AFTERNOON...AS REMAINDER OF THE WARM SECTOR ADVANCES THROUGH 
NORTHERN ARKANSAS...AND STRONG UPPER LEVEL SYSTEM MOVES UP IN THE 
MEAN FLOW.

SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS CONTINUE TO BE A GOOD POSSIBILITY MONDAY 
AFTERNOON AND NIGHT...AS UPPER SYSTEM MOVES INTO WESTERN 
ARKANSAS...POTENT IMPULSES MOVE UP IN THE MEAN FLOW...AND COLD FRONT 
APPROACHES FROM THE WEST. THE POTENTIAL EVENT IS LOOKING TO BE A LOW 
CAPE/HIGH SHEAR TYPE OF EVENT. 

BIG QUESTION MARK CONTINUES TO BE SURFACE BASED HEATING AND 
INSTABILITY. IF ENOUGH SUN CAN BREAK THROUGH...SIGNIFICANT 
DEVELOPMENT IS LIKELY AS EARLY AS THE AFTERNOON. PLENTY OF 
DIRECTIONAL AND SPEED SHEAR AVAILABLE...WITH UPPER JET GREATER THAN 
100 KT. THUS...UPDRAFTS WILL BE MORE THAN CAPABLE OF SUSTAINING 
SUPERCELLS. SO...HAVE MENTIONED DAMAGING WINDS AND ISOLATED 
TORNADOES AS A POSSIBILITY IN THE HAZARDOUS WEATHER OUTLOOK. 

IF THERE IS NOT ENOUGH HEATING...THIS HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BE MORE 
OF A RAINFALL EVENT.

THE SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL MOVE EAST BY TUESDAY MORNING...
WITH COLD FRONT HEADING EAST ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA. THIS WILL BE 
ANOTHER DIFFICULT DAY TO TRY TO PIN DOWN TEMPERATURE TRENDS...WITH 
COLDER AIR MOVING IN BEHIND THE FRONT AS IT HEADS ACROSS THE STATE. 
WESTERN AREAS LIKELY TO SEE THEIR MAX TEMPS LATE IN THE MORNING...
WITH EAST DOING SO IN THE EARLY AFTERNOON...WITH READINGS FALLING 
DURING THE AFTERNOON HOURS. 

BY TUESDAY NIGHT...SURFACE AND 500 MB RIDGING WILL MOVE INTO THE 
MIDSOUTH...WITH COOL AND DRY CONDITIONS NOTED. RETURN FLOW WILL 
BEGIN TO SET UP BY WEDNESDAY...AS THE SURFACE HIGH MOVES 
NORTHEASTWARD. MOISTURE WILL INCREASE ON WEDNESDAY NIGHT...OUT AHEAD 
OF ANOTHER APPROACHING SURFACE AND UPPER SYSTEM.

STORM SYSTEM WILL BE DEPARTING TO THE EAST TO BEGIN THE SHORT TERM. 
WILL BE RAIN/SHOWERS WITH LOTS OF CLOUDS ON THURSDAY...WITH CLEARING 
THURSDAY NIGHT/FRIDAY. SYSTEM ALONG A VERY ACTIVE SUBTROPICAL 
JET...AND AIR BEHIND SYSTEM SLIGHTLY COOLER AT BEST. WITH POLAR JET 
NOT A FACTOR...TEMPERATURES AT/SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL FOR THE MOST 
PART. IF EXTENDED GUIDANCE IS CORRECT...MORE SIGNIFICANT COOLDOWN 
COMING LATE NEXT WEEKEND FOLLOWING STRONG FRONT FROM NORTHWEST. 
GIVEN THAT THIS IS A LONG WAY OFF...CONFIDENCE IS LOW CONCERNING 
TIMING OF FRONT. (46)

RAINFALL AMOUNTS AS MUCH AS ONE TO TWO INCHES OR GREATER ARE 
POSSIBLE THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT...MAINLY EAST OF A LINE FROM ASH FLAT 
TO WALDRON. 

OVER THE LAST TWO MONTHS...MANY PORTIONS OF THE FORECAST AREA HAVE 
HAD AS MUCH AS 10 TO 20 INCHES OF RAINFALL. SEVERAL RIVERS IN 
EASTERN ARKANSAS ARE ALREADY NEAR OR ABOVE FLOOD STAGE...AND AN 
ADDITIONAL ONE TO TWO INCHES OF RAIN WILL ONLY CREATE MORE PROBLEMS. 
(57)
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 060327
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
857 PM CST SUN DEC  5 2004

.DISCUSSION...
OVERALL FORECAST IN GOOD SHAPE BUT SOME ADJUSTMENTS ARE NEEDED THIS 
EVENING. CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES WARM FRONT OVER SOUTHERN 
ARKANSAS...ROUGHLY ALONG A DEQUEEN TO ARKADELPHIA TO STAR CITY TO 
DUMAS LINE. DEW POINT TEMPERATURES HAVE RISEN INTO THE LOWER 60S 
HERE WITH AMBIENT AIR TEMPERATURE ON THE RISE EVERYWHERE. THE
TEMPERATURE AT THE WFO HAS RISEN AN AVERAGE OF ONE DEGREE PER HOUR 
THIS EVENING.  BELIEVE MOST IF NOT ALL TEMPERATURES HAVE BOTTOMED 
OUT AND SLOWLY RISING OR AT THE VERY LEAST STEADY TEMPS THE REST 
OF THE NIGHT. AS SUCH...GRIDS/ZONES TEMPS AND DEW POINTS ADJUSTED 
UPWARDS. 

WILL KEEP CURRENT POPS ALONE AS SCATTERED SHOWERS EXPECTED TO 
PERSIST IN DEVELOPING WARM AIR ADVECTION PATTERN. PLENTY OF LOW 
CLOUDS AND FOG AROUND THIS EVENING AND DONT EXPECT THIS TO GO 
ANYWHERE TONIGHT. CROSS SECTIONS SHOW DRY AIR ALOFT BUT WITH 
PERSISTENT SOUTHWEST FLOW LOW LEVELS REMAIN SATURATED. WAS TOYING 
WITH THE IDEA OF A DENSE FOG ADVISORY EARLIER BUT MANAGED TO TALK 
MYSELF OUT OF IT. WHILE POCKETS OF DENSE FOG ARE LIKELY...DONT 
BELIEVE IT WILL BE WIDESPREAD ENOUGH TO MEET CRITERIA AS GRADIENT 
SHOULD REMAIN JUST ENOUGH TO MIX THINGS UP.

CURRENT VAPOR IMAGERY SHOWS PLENTY OF TROPICAL MOISTURE BEING PULLED 
INTO THE REGION. STRONG SHORTWAVE ALSO CLEARLY SEEN OVER BAJA. 
MODELS STILL PERSISTENT IN BRINGING THE WAVE ACROSS THE AREA MONDAY 
NIGHT. COLD FRONT EXPECTED TO PLOW INTO THE TROPICAL AIR WITH 
SURFACE LOW PRESSURE MOVING TO NEAR THE ARKLATEX BY MONDAY EVENING. 
PLENTY OF DYNAMICS STILL AVAILABLE AND AREA REMAINS UNDER A SLIGHT 
RISK FOR SEVERE WEATHER WHICH APPEARS REASONABLE. ONE MISSING FACTOR 
REMAINS STABILITY. ANY WIDESPREAD SUNSHINE MONDAY WILL TAKE CARE OF 
THAT IN A HURRY AND SET THE STAGE FOR SOME POSSIBLY SEVERE STORMS.

PWAT VALUES WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE THROUGH THE NIGHT AND LOCALLY 
HEAVY RAIN WILL REMAIN POSSIBLE LATE MONDAY AND MONDAY NIGHT. (56)
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 320 PM CST SUN DEC  5 2004


PRECIP SLOWLY CLEARING OUT OF THE AREA...AS WARM BOUNDARY IN THE 
VICINITY OF CENTRAL/NORTHERN LOUISIANA CONTINUES TO MOVE NORTHWARD. 
AIRMASS MOISTENING UP...AS SIXTY PLUS DEWPOINTS SURGE NORTHWARD FROM 
LOUISIANA. SATURATED AIR...ALONG WITH LIGHT WINDS WILL ALLOW FOR 
AREAS OF FOG TO CONTINUE THROUGH THE OVERNIGHT HOURS. SOME OF THE 
FOG HAS BEEN DENSE AT TIMES...AND THIS DENSE FOG COULD BECOME MORE 
WIDESPREAD OVERNIGHT. IF THAT IS THE CASE...DENSE FOG ADVISORY WOULD 
NEED TO BE CONSIDERED. 

WARM FRONT WILL MOVE NORTHWARD TONIGHT...INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS...
AND GRADUALLY THROUGH CENTRAL AND INTO NORTHERN ARKANSAS BY MORNING. 
MOST LOCATIONS WILL LIKELY SEE THEIR OVERNIGHT LOWS BY 00Z...WITH 
TEMPERATURES STEADY OR SLOWLY RISING THROUGOUT THE NIGHT. MOST 
SIGNIFICANT RISES WILL BE IN SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. THIS AREA IS NOW IN 
THE MID 50S TO UPPER 50S...AND IS LIKELY TO BE IN THE MID 60S BY 
SUNRISE. 

SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BECOME LIKELY BY MONDAY 
AFTERNOON...AS REMAINDER OF THE WARM SECTOR ADVANCES THROUGH 
NORTHERN ARKANSAS...AND STRONG UPPER LEVEL SYSTEM MOVES UP IN THE 
MEAN FLOW.

SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS CONTINUE TO BE A GOOD POSSIBILITY MONDAY 
AFTERNOON AND NIGHT...AS UPPER SYSTEM MOVES INTO WESTERN 
ARKANSAS...POTENT IMPULSES MOVE UP IN THE MEAN FLOW...AND COLD FRONT 
APPROACHES FROM THE WEST. THE POTENTIAL EVENT IS LOOKING TO BE A LOW 
CAPE/HIGH SHEAR TYPE OF EVENT. 

BIG QUESTION MARK CONTINUES TO BE SURFACE BASED HEATING AND 
INSTABILITY. IF ENOUGH SUN CAN BREAK THROUGH...SIGNIFICANT 
DEVELOPMENT IS LIKELY AS EARLY AS THE AFTERNOON. PLENTY OF 
DIRECTIONAL AND SPEED SHEAR AVAILABLE...WITH UPPER JET GREATER THAN 
100 KT. THUS...UPDRAFTS WILL BE MORE THAN CAPABLE OF SUSTAINING 
SUPERCELLS. SO...HAVE MENTIONED DAMAGING WINDS AND ISOLATED 
TORNADOES AS A POSSIBILITY IN THE HAZARDOUS WEATHER OUTLOOK. 

IF THERE IS NOT ENOUGH HEATING...THIS HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BE MORE 
OF A RAINFALL EVENT.

THE SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL MOVE EAST BY TUESDAY MORNING...
WITH COLD FRONT HEADING EAST ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA. THIS WILL BE 
ANOTHER DIFFICULT DAY TO TRY TO PIN DOWN TEMPERATURE TRENDS...WITH 
COLDER AIR MOVING IN BEHIND THE FRONT AS IT HEADS ACROSS THE STATE. 
WESTERN AREAS LIKELY TO SEE THEIR MAX TEMPS LATE IN THE MORNING...
WITH EAST DOING SO IN THE EARLY AFTERNOON...WITH READINGS FALLING 
DURING THE AFTERNOON HOURS. 

BY TUESDAY NIGHT...SURFACE AND 500 MB RIDGING WILL MOVE INTO THE 
MIDSOUTH...WITH COOL AND DRY CONDITIONS NOTED. RETURN FLOW WILL 
BEGIN TO SET UP BY WEDNESDAY...AS THE SURFACE HIGH MOVES 
NORTHEASTWARD. MOISTURE WILL INCREASE ON WEDNESDAY NIGHT...OUT AHEAD 
OF ANOTHER APPROACHING SURFACE AND UPPER SYSTEM.

STORM SYSTEM WILL BE DEPARTING TO THE EAST TO BEGIN THE SHORT TERM. 
WILL BE RAIN/SHOWERS WITH LOTS OF CLOUDS ON THURSDAY...WITH CLEARING 
THURSDAY NIGHT/FRIDAY. SYSTEM ALONG A VERY ACTIVE SUBTROPICAL 
JET...AND AIR BEHIND SYSTEM SLIGHTLY COOLER AT BEST. WITH POLAR JET 
NOT A FACTOR...TEMPERATURES AT/SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL FOR THE MOST 
PART. IF EXTENDED GUIDANCE IS CORRECT...MORE SIGNIFICANT COOLDOWN 
COMING LATE NEXT WEEKEND FOLLOWING STRONG FRONT FROM NORTHWEST. 
GIVEN THAT THIS IS A LONG WAY OFF...CONFIDENCE IS LOW CONCERNING 
TIMING OF FRONT. (46)

RAINFALL AMOUNTS AS MUCH AS ONE TO TWO INCHES OR GREATER ARE 
POSSIBLE THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT...MAINLY EAST OF A LINE FROM ASH FLAT 
TO WALDRON. 

OVER THE LAST TWO MONTHS...MANY PORTIONS OF THE FORECAST AREA HAVE 
HAD AS MUCH AS 10 TO 20 INCHES OF RAINFALL. SEVERAL RIVERS IN 
EASTERN ARKANSAS ARE ALREADY NEAR OR ABOVE FLOOD STAGE...AND AN 
ADDITIONAL ONE TO TWO INCHES OF RAIN WILL ONLY CREATE MORE PROBLEMS. 
(57)

882 
FXUS64 KLZK 051747 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1150 AM CST SUN DEC  5 2004

.DISCUSSION...
HAVE JUST SENT OUT AN UPDATE ON THE MORNING PACKAGE. SURFACE DATA 
INDICATES WARM FRONTAL BOUNDARY OVER SOUTHERN LOUISIANA AND SLOWLY 
PROGRESSING NORTHWARD. SECONDARY BOUNDARY...MORE OF AN 
ISODROSOTHERMAL GRADIENT...CURRENTLY OVER WESTERN ARKANSAS...
EXTENDING DOWN TOWARD SOUTHEASTERN ARKANSAS. 

RADAR TRENDS CONTINUE SHOWING A GENERAL DECREASE FROM THE SOUTHWEST. 
HAVE THUS REFLECTED THESE TRENDS IN THE FORECAST FOR THE REMAINDER 
OF THE AFTERNOON. PRECIPITABLE WATERS STILL NOT THAT GREAT LOOKING 
AT 12Z SOUNDING...SO RAINFALL HAS MOSTLY BEEN LIGHT WITHIN MUCH OF 
THE FORECAST AREA. 

TEMPERATURES ARE ANOTHER PAIN TO CONTEND WITH. WITH CONTINUED 
STRATOCU OVER NORTH AND CENTRAL...AND STRATUS ADVANCING NORTHWARD 
FROM SOUTHERN ARKANSAS/NORTHERN LOUISIANA...TEMPERATURE TRENDS WILL 
BE HELD IN CHECK. MOST DAYTIME HIGHS WILL BE LATE THIS AFTERNOON...
AND NIGHTTIME LOWS WILL ALSO BE LATE THIS AFTERNOON/EARLY THIS 
EVENING...WITH TEMPS STEADYING OUT OR RISING DURING MUCH OF THE 
NIGHT. TRIED THE BEST I COULD TO HAMMER OUT TEMPERATURE TRENDS IN 
THE GRIDS.

UPDATED GRIDS...GRAPHICAL AND TEXT FORECASTS HAVE BEEN SENT...AND 
TABULAR FORECASTS HAVE BEEN UPDATED AS WELL. MORE UPDATES ARE A GOOD 
POSSIBILITY...GIVEN THE VARIABILITY OF THIS WEATHER SCENARIO. (57)
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 340 AM CST SUN DEC 5 2004

CLOUDS CONT TO INCRS FM THE SW ACRS AR THIS MRNG. NRN AR HAS SEEN 
MOSTLY CLR SKIES FOR A GOOD BIT OF THE NIGHT...ALLOWING TEMPS TO 
FALL INTO THE 30S. MEANWHILE...WELL-DEFINED UPPER TROF OVER THE SWRN 
STATES ATTM WL CONT LIFTING NEWD TODAY. LEADING EDGE OF RAINFALL 
ASSOCD WITH THIS SYS IS NOTED OVR NERN TX ATTM.

INCRSG LIFT ASSOCD WITH APCHG UPPER TROF AND WAA WL ALLOW RAIN TO 
OVERSPREAD THE AREA TODAY FROM THE SW. HAVE SLOWED DOWN THE ONSET OF 
RAINFALL A FEW HOURS ACRS THE FA TODAY WITH UPPER SYS A LTL SLOWER 
AND DRIER AIR HOLDING OVR CNTRL AND NRN AR. WITH TEMPS STARTING OUT 
COOLER THIS MRNG...HAVE TRIMMED BACK HIGHS THIS AFTN A FEW DEGREES 
AS CLOUDS CONT TO THICKEN AND RAINFALL MOVES IN.

THIS FIRST UPPER SYSTEM SHIFTS NE OF THE AREA THIS EVENING...GIVING 
US A BREAK IN THE RAINFALL. MORE HUMID AIRMASS WL ALSO BE WORKING 
SLOLY NWD TNGT AS SFC WINDS BECOME MORE SLY. LOOKING AT LOWS TNGT 
OCCURRING ARND 00Z...AND THEN RMNG STEADY AND EVEN SLOLY RISING DURG 
THE OVERNIGHT HRS.

NEXT UPPER SYS...CURRENTLY OFF THE CA COAST...IS FCST TO TURN EWD 
AND HEAD TOWARD THE SRN PLAINS LATER MON AND MON NIGHT. THIS WILL 
BRING ANOTHER ROUND OF RAIN AND STORMS TO THE STATE. THE POTENTIAL 
DOES EXIST FOR STRONG OR SVR STORMS FOR THE AREA MON AFTN AND 
EVENING AHEAD OF SFC CDFNT. FCST WIND FIELDS AT THE SFC AND ALOFT 
RMN FAVORABLE FOR SOME ROTATING STORMS. HOWEVER...THE AMOUNT OF 
INSTABILITY IS STILL IN QUESTION MON AFTN IF CLOUDS PERSIST AND 
LIMIT AFTN HEATING. PLAN TO MENTION THIS SCENARIO IN THE HWO.

MODEL SOLUTIONS THIS MRNG HAVE TRENDED SLOWER WITH THE SECOND UPPER 
SYS OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS. THUS...HAVE HAD TO HOLD ONTO RAIN CHCS 
INTO MONDAY NIGHT AND EARLY TUE FOR MUCH OF THE FA. TODAY/S MODEL 
RUNS SHOULD GET A BETTER HANDLE ON THE SECOND UPPER LOW AS IT WORKS 
ONSHORE AND IS SAMPLED BY GROUND BASED SOUNDINGS.

TEMPS ARE CERTAINLY A TOSS UP FOR THE SHORT TERM WITH PRECIP TIMING 
AND CLOUD COVER. LEANED TOWARD THE COOLER GFS MOS FOR TODAY AND 
TNGT. BOTH GFS AND ETA MOS READINGS IN GOOD AGREEMENT FOR MON THRU 
TUE.

HIGH PRESSURE AT THE SURFACE WILL BUILD INTO THE AREA TUESDAY NIGHT 
AND WEDNESDAY. DRY AIR WILL BE IN PLACE AS RIDGING DEVELOPS ACROSS 
THE REGION THROUGH WEDNESDAY. A WARM FRONT IN THE GULF WILL MOVE 
ONSHORE THURSDAY AND WILL SET UP ANOTHER OVERRUNNING EPISODE. 
MOISTURE INCREASES OVER THE AREA ON THURSDAY AND THIS WILL KEEP 
CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION IN THE AREA...AND WILL LEAVE POPS IN THE 
40S AT THIS TIME. SOUTHERN SECTIONS WILL HAVE A CHANCE OF 
THUNDERSTORMS. UPPER TROUGH MOVES THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT AND DRIER 
AIR FOLLOWS. HIGH PRESSURE MOVES IN FRIDAY BRINGING DRY WEATHER ON 
FRIDAY AND SATURDAY. 

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

57





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 051747 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1150 AM CST SUN DEC  5 2004

.DISCUSSION...
HAVE JUST SENT OUT AN UPDATE ON THE MORNING PACKAGE. SURFACE DATA 
INDICATES WARM FRONTAL BOUNDARY OVER SOUTHERN LOUISIANA AND SLOWLY 
PROGRESSING NORTHWARD. SECONDARY BOUNDARY...MORE OF AN 
ISODROSOTHERMAL GRADIENT...CURRENTLY OVER WESTERN ARKANSAS...
EXTENDING DOWN TOWARD SOUTHEASTERN ARKANSAS. 

RADAR TRENDS CONTINUE SHOWING A GENERAL DECREASE FROM THE SOUTHWEST. 
HAVE THUS REFLECTED THESE TRENDS IN THE FORECAST FOR THE REMAINDER 
OF THE AFTERNOON. PRECIPITABLE WATERS STILL NOT THAT GREAT LOOKING 
AT 12Z SOUNDING...SO RAINFALL HAS MOSTLY BEEN LIGHT WITHIN MUCH OF 
THE FORECAST AREA. 

TEMPERATURES ARE ANOTHER PAIN TO CONTEND WITH. WITH CONTINUED 
STRATOCU OVER NORTH AND CENTRAL...AND STRATUS ADVANCING NORTHWARD 
FROM SOUTHERN ARKANSAS/NORTHERN LOUISIANA...TEMPERATURE TRENDS WILL 
BE HELD IN CHECK. MOST DAYTIME HIGHS WILL BE LATE THIS AFTERNOON...
AND NIGHTTIME LOWS WILL ALSO BE LATE THIS AFTERNOON/EARLY THIS 
EVENING...WITH TEMPS STEADYING OUT OR RISING DURING MUCH OF THE 
NIGHT. TRIED THE BEST I COULD TO HAMMER OUT TEMPERATURE TRENDS IN 
THE GRIDS.

UPDATED GRIDS...GRAPHICAL AND TEXT FORECASTS HAVE BEEN SENT...AND 
TABULAR FORECASTS HAVE BEEN UPDATED AS WELL. MORE UPDATES ARE A GOOD 
POSSIBILITY...GIVEN THE VARIABILITY OF THIS WEATHER SCENARIO. (57)
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 340 AM CST SUN DEC 5 2004

CLOUDS CONT TO INCRS FM THE SW ACRS AR THIS MRNG. NRN AR HAS SEEN 
MOSTLY CLR SKIES FOR A GOOD BIT OF THE NIGHT...ALLOWING TEMPS TO 
FALL INTO THE 30S. MEANWHILE...WELL-DEFINED UPPER TROF OVER THE SWRN 
STATES ATTM WL CONT LIFTING NEWD TODAY. LEADING EDGE OF RAINFALL 
ASSOCD WITH THIS SYS IS NOTED OVR NERN TX ATTM.

INCRSG LIFT ASSOCD WITH APCHG UPPER TROF AND WAA WL ALLOW RAIN TO 
OVERSPREAD THE AREA TODAY FROM THE SW. HAVE SLOWED DOWN THE ONSET OF 
RAINFALL A FEW HOURS ACRS THE FA TODAY WITH UPPER SYS A LTL SLOWER 
AND DRIER AIR HOLDING OVR CNTRL AND NRN AR. WITH TEMPS STARTING OUT 
COOLER THIS MRNG...HAVE TRIMMED BACK HIGHS THIS AFTN A FEW DEGREES 
AS CLOUDS CONT TO THICKEN AND RAINFALL MOVES IN.

THIS FIRST UPPER SYSTEM SHIFTS NE OF THE AREA THIS EVENING...GIVING 
US A BREAK IN THE RAINFALL. MORE HUMID AIRMASS WL ALSO BE WORKING 
SLOLY NWD TNGT AS SFC WINDS BECOME MORE SLY. LOOKING AT LOWS TNGT 
OCCURRING ARND 00Z...AND THEN RMNG STEADY AND EVEN SLOLY RISING DURG 
THE OVERNIGHT HRS.

NEXT UPPER SYS...CURRENTLY OFF THE CA COAST...IS FCST TO TURN EWD 
AND HEAD TOWARD THE SRN PLAINS LATER MON AND MON NIGHT. THIS WILL 
BRING ANOTHER ROUND OF RAIN AND STORMS TO THE STATE. THE POTENTIAL 
DOES EXIST FOR STRONG OR SVR STORMS FOR THE AREA MON AFTN AND 
EVENING AHEAD OF SFC CDFNT. FCST WIND FIELDS AT THE SFC AND ALOFT 
RMN FAVORABLE FOR SOME ROTATING STORMS. HOWEVER...THE AMOUNT OF 
INSTABILITY IS STILL IN QUESTION MON AFTN IF CLOUDS PERSIST AND 
LIMIT AFTN HEATING. PLAN TO MENTION THIS SCENARIO IN THE HWO.

MODEL SOLUTIONS THIS MRNG HAVE TRENDED SLOWER WITH THE SECOND UPPER 
SYS OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS. THUS...HAVE HAD TO HOLD ONTO RAIN CHCS 
INTO MONDAY NIGHT AND EARLY TUE FOR MUCH OF THE FA. TODAY/S MODEL 
RUNS SHOULD GET A BETTER HANDLE ON THE SECOND UPPER LOW AS IT WORKS 
ONSHORE AND IS SAMPLED BY GROUND BASED SOUNDINGS.

TEMPS ARE CERTAINLY A TOSS UP FOR THE SHORT TERM WITH PRECIP TIMING 
AND CLOUD COVER. LEANED TOWARD THE COOLER GFS MOS FOR TODAY AND 
TNGT. BOTH GFS AND ETA MOS READINGS IN GOOD AGREEMENT FOR MON THRU 
TUE.

HIGH PRESSURE AT THE SURFACE WILL BUILD INTO THE AREA TUESDAY NIGHT 
AND WEDNESDAY. DRY AIR WILL BE IN PLACE AS RIDGING DEVELOPS ACROSS 
THE REGION THROUGH WEDNESDAY. A WARM FRONT IN THE GULF WILL MOVE 
ONSHORE THURSDAY AND WILL SET UP ANOTHER OVERRUNNING EPISODE. 
MOISTURE INCREASES OVER THE AREA ON THURSDAY AND THIS WILL KEEP 
CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION IN THE AREA...AND WILL LEAVE POPS IN THE 
40S AT THIS TIME. SOUTHERN SECTIONS WILL HAVE A CHANCE OF 
THUNDERSTORMS. UPPER TROUGH MOVES THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT AND DRIER 
AIR FOLLOWS. HIGH PRESSURE MOVES IN FRIDAY BRINGING DRY WEATHER ON 
FRIDAY AND SATURDAY. 

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

57





NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
340 AM CST SUN DEC 5 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY
CLOUDS CONT TO INCRS FM THE SW ACRS AR THIS MRNG. NRN AR HAS SEEN 
MOSTLY CLR SKIES FOR A GOOD BIT OF THE NIGHT...ALLOWING TEMPS TO 
FALL INTO THE 30S. MEANWHILE...WELL-DEFINED UPPER TROF OVER THE SWRN 
STATES ATTM WL CONT LIFTING NEWD TODAY. LEADING EDGE OF RAINFALL 
ASSOCD WITH THIS SYS IS NOTED OVR NERN TX ATTM.

INCRSG LIFT ASSOCD WITH APCHG UPPER TROF AND WAA WL ALLOW RAIN TO 
OVERSPREAD THE AREA TODAY FROM THE SW. HAVE SLOWED DOWN THE ONSET OF 
RAINFALL A FEW HOURS ACRS THE FA TODAY WITH UPPER SYS A LTL SLOWER 
AND DRIER AIR HOLDING OVR CNTRL AND NRN AR. WITH TEMPS STARTING OUT 
COOLER THIS MRNG...HAVE TRIMMED BACK HIGHS THIS AFTN A FEW DEGREES 
AS CLOUDS CONT TO THICKEN AND RAINFALL MOVES IN.

THIS FIRST UPPER SYSTEM SHIFTS NE OF THE AREA THIS EVENING...GIVING 
US A BREAK IN THE RAINFALL. MORE HUMID AIRMASS WL ALSO BE WORKING 
SLOLY NWD TNGT AS SFC WINDS BECOME MORE SLY. LOOKING AT LOWS TNGT 
OCCURRING ARND 00Z...AND THEN RMNG STEADY AND EVEN SLOLY RISING DURG 
THE OVERNIGHT HRS.

NEXT UPPER SYS...CURRENTLY OFF THE CA COAST...IS FCST TO TURN EWD 
AND HEAD TOWARD THE SRN PLAINS LATER MON AND MON NIGHT. THIS WILL 
BRING ANOTHER ROUND OF RAIN AND STORMS TO THE STATE. THE POTENTIAL 
DOES EXIST FOR STRONG OR SVR STORMS FOR THE AREA MON AFTN AND 
EVENING AHEAD OF SFC CDFNT. FCST WIND FIELDS AT THE SFC AND ALOFT 
RMN FAVORABLE FOR SOME ROTATING STORMS. HOWEVER...THE AMOUNT OF 
INSTABILITY IS STILL IN QUESTION MON AFTN IF CLOUDS PERSIST AND 
LIMIT AFTN HEATING. PLAN TO MENTION THIS SCENARIO IN THE HWO.

MODEL SOLUTIONS THIS MRNG HAVE TRENDED SLOWER WITH THE SECOND UPPER 
SYS OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS. THUS...HAVE HAD TO HOLD ONTO RAIN CHCS 
INTO MONDAY NIGHT AND EARLY TUE FOR MUCH OF THE FA. TODAY/S MODEL 
RUNS SHOULD GET A BETTER HANDLE ON THE SECOND UPPER LOW AS IT WORKS 
ONSHORE AND IS SAMPLED BY GROUND BASED SOUNDINGS.

TEMPS ARE CERTAINLY A TOSS UP FOR THE SHORT TERM WITH PRECIP TIMING 
AND CLOUD COVER. LEANED TOWARD THE COOLER GFS MOS FOR TODAY AND 
TNGT. BOTH GFS AND ETA MOS READINGS IN GOOD AGREEMENT FOR MON THRU 
TUE.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
HIGH PRESSURE AT THE SURFACE WILL BUILD INTO THE AREA TUESDAY NIGHT 
AND WEDNESDAY. DRY AIR WILL BE IN PLACE AS RIDGING DEVELOPS ACROSS 
THE REGION THROUGH WEDNESDAY. A WARM FRONT IN THE GULF WILL MOVE 
ONSHORE THURSDAY AND WILL SET UP ANOTHER OVERRUNNING EPISODE. 
MOISTURE INCREASES OVER THE AREA ON THURSDAY AND THIS WILL KEEP 
CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION IN THE AREA...AND WILL LEAVE POPS IN THE 
40S AT THIS TIME. SOUTHERN SECTIONS WILL HAVE A CHANCE OF 
THUNDERSTORMS. UPPER TROUGH MOVES THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT AND DRIER 
AIR FOLLOWS. HIGH PRESSURE MOVES IN FRIDAY BRINGING DRY WEATHER ON 
FRIDAY AND SATURDAY.



288 
FXUS64 KLZK 050247
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
845 PM CST SAT DEC  4 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS TO BE RIGHT ON TARGET AND ONLY SUPERFICIAL 
CHANGES ARE NEEDED. ONLY A FEW MINOR TWEAKS TO THE GRIDS ARE NEEDED 
TO REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS WITH IMPACT ON THE PRODUCTS TRANSPARENT.

WARM FRONTAL BOUNDARY SITTING IN THE GULF WILL BE MOVING NORTHWARD 
THROUGH THE NIGHT WITH OVERRRUNING RAIN DEVELOPING THROUGH THE 
NIGHT. STILL EXPECTING THE MAJORITY OF THE NIGHT TO BE DRY BUT RAIN 
WILL QUICKLY OVERSPREAD THE AREA SUNDAY MORNING. CATEGORICAL POPS 
LOOK GOOD WITH A GENERAL ONE QUARTER TO ONE HALF INCH RAIN EXPECTED.
TEMPERATURES HAVE DROPPED OFF TO ONLY A FEW DEGREES ABOVE FORECASTED 
LOWS BUT EXPECTING THEN TO STEADY OUT THE REST OF THE NIGHT AS 
SOUTHERLY FLOW INCREASES AND MOISTURE LEVELS RISE.

RAINFALL WILL BE FURTHER ENHANCED BY AN UPPER LEVEL DISTURBANCE 
CLEARLY SEEN ON WATER VAPOR IMAGERY SPINNING OVER THE BAJA. WAVE 
WILL LIFT OUT DURING THE NIGHT AND PASS TO THE NORTHWEST OF THE 
STATE SUNDAY. GOOD PUNCH OF DRY AIR LATE IN THE DAY WILL END THE 
PRECIP FOR THE TIME BEING.

WATER VAPOR IMAGERY ALSO SHOWING ANOTHER...MORE IMPRESSIVE WAVE IN 
THE EASTERN PACIFIC...OFF THE CENTRAL CALIF COAST. THIS WAVE WILL 
APPROACH THE CWA LATE MONDAY WITH MORE RAIN LIKELY. DYNAMICS COMING 
TOGETHER QUITE NICELY LATE MONDAY FOR POTENTIAL SEVERE WEATHER 
OUTBREAK. ONLY SAVING GRACE IS ATMOSPHERE IS NOT OVERLY UNSTABLE 
BUT ANY SUNSHINE MONDAY WOULD TAKE CARE OF THAT. WILL NEED TO KEEP A 
CLOSE EYE ON THE EVOLUTION OF THIS SYSTEM FOR LATE MONDAY/MONDAY 
NIGHT TIME FRAME.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 315 PM CST SAT DEC 4 2004

VERY COMPLICATED AND CUMBERSOME WEATHER SITUATION SETTING UP FOR 
MUCH OF THE SHORT TERM PERIODS. WARM BOUNDARY CURRENTLY MOVING UP 
TOWARD THE GULF COAST...WITH STRONG SHORTWAVE APPROACHING FROM THE 
DESERT SOUTHWEST. ASSOCIATED PACIFIC AND GULF MOISTURE WILL GREATLY 
INCREASE TONIGHT AS THE SYSTEM APPROACHES THE FORECAST AREA. EXPECT 
RAIN TO BEGIN DEVELOPING SOME TIME AFTER MIDNIGHT...BECOMING LIKELY 
AREAWIDE BY MID MORNING. CONTINUED CATEGORICAL POPS FOR SUNDAY...AS 
THE WARM BOUNDARY AND UPPER SYSTEM MOVE ACROSS THE AREA. 

RAIN WILL DECREASE BEGINNING LATE SUNDAY AFTERNOON...AS STRONG DRY 
INTRUSION PUNCHES IN FROM THE SOUTHWEST. 

TEMPERATURE TRENDS WILL BE VERY HARD TO PIN DOWN ON SUNDAY 
NIGHT...AS WARM SECTOR ADVANCES NORTHWARD THROUGH CENTRAL AND 
NORTHERN ARKANSAS. NOCTURNAL VARIANCE SOUTH OF THE FRONT WILL BE 
VERY LITTLE TO ALMOST NONE. IN CENTRAL ARKANSAS AND NORTHERN 
ARKANSAS...MANY LOCATIONS WILL LIKELY SEE LOWS IN THE EARLY TO MID 
EVENING...WITH TEMPERATURES NEARLY STEADY OR SLOWLY RISING FROM 
AROUND MIDNIGHT ON.

ROUND TWO BEGINS ON MONDAY. STRONG COLD FRONT AND YET ANOTHER IN 
THIS SERIES OF 500MB TROUGHS WILL ADVANCE TOWARD THE MID AND LOWER 
MISSISSIPPI VALLEY. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL DEVELOP IN THE 
WARM SECTOR DURING THE LATE MORNING...AND INTO THE AFTERNOON AS THE 
UPPER TROUGH MOVES ACROSS...AND SEVERAL STRONG UPPER IMPULSES MOVE 
UP IN THE MEAN FLOW. SHOWERS AND STORMS WILL BE ONGOING ALONG THE 
COLD FRONT AS IT MOVES INTO WESTERN ARKANSAS ON MONDAY NIGHT. 

SEVERE WEATHER IS A GOOD POSSIBILITY ON MONDAY AND MONDAY NIGHT. 
TREMENDOUS AMOUNT OF WIND ENERGY WILL BE PRESENT...WITH 60KT OR 
GREATER MIDLEVEL JET...AND 110KT OR GREATER UPPER LEVEL JET. PLENTY 
OF DIRECTIONAL SHEAR AVAILABLE AS WELL. THUS...POTENTIAL EXISTS FOR 
STRONG...DAMAGING WINDS AND ISOLATED TORNADOES. CAN EXPECT A FEW 
HAILERS AS WELL. THE FRONT WILL MOVE INTO WESTERN ARKANSAS ON MONDAY 
NIGHT...WITH STORMS BECOMING MORE LINEAR.

ONE FLY IN THE OINTMENT IS POTENTIAL CLOUD COVER ON MONDAY. IF 
CLOUDS CAN BREAK UP ENOUGH...AND SUFFICIENT DESTABILIZATION CAN 
OCCUR...THUNDERSTORMS COULD GET GOING FAIRLY EARLY. HOWEVER...IF THE 
CLOUDS CANT BREAK...LACK OF SURFACE BASED HEATING COULD ACT TO 
PRECLUDE SIGNIFICANT DEVELOPMENT. 

WHILE PRECIPITABLE WATERS WILL BE IN THE ONE TO TWO INCH RANGE...
WINDS ALOFT SHOULD BE SUFFICIENT ENOUGH TO KEEP STORMS MOVING. THAT 
BEING SAID HOWEVER...THERE COULD BE AT LEAST ONE TO TWO INCHES OF 
RAINFALL...MOSTLY EAST OF A LINE FROM ASH FLAT TO MENA. WITH AS MUCH 
RAINFALL THAT HAS OCCURRED OVER THE STATE DURING THE LAST TWO 
MONTHS...AND SEVERAL RIVERS NEAR OR ABOVE FLOOD STAGE...THE 
ABUNDANCE OF RAIN COULD CREATE EVEN MORE FLOODING PROBLEMS. 

A FEW CLOUDS MAY LINGER OVER THE NORTH ON TUESDAY...AS WRAPAROUND 
ASSOCIATED WITH UPPER SYSTEM MOVES ACROSS. OTHERWISE...SHORT TERM 
WILL END ON A QUIET NOTE...WITH SURFACE AND UPPER RIDGE MOVING IN 
FROM THE PLAINS. 

LONG TERM STARTS OFF TRANQUIL...BUT ONLY BRIEFLY. HIGH PRESSURE WILL 
SHIFT TO THE EAST...WITH RETURN FLOW BRINGING MOISTURE WEDNESDAY 
NIGHT/THURSDAY. SUBTROPICAL JET CONTINUES TO BE ACTIVE...WITH SYSTEM 
RIDING SOUTHWEST WIND ALOFT TOWARD REGION. SYSTEM WILL TRIGGER 
SCATTERED SHOWERS ON THURSDAY...WITH ATMOSPHERE UNSTABLE ENOUGH FOR 
SOME THUNDER IN SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS. COLD FRONT WILL GO THROUGH BY 
THURSDAY NIGHT...WITH LONG TERM ENDING SLIGHTLY COOLER AIR/DRIER. 

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56

731 
FXUS64 KLZK 042117
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
315 PM CST SAT DEC 4 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT

.TONIGHT AND SUNDAY...
VERY COMPLICATED AND CUMBERSOME WEATHER SITUATION SETTING UP FOR 
MUCH OF THE SHORT TERM PERIODS. WARM BOUNDARY CURRENTLY MOVING UP 
TOWARD THE GULF COAST...WITH STRONG SHORTWAVE APPROACHING FROM THE 
DESERT SOUTHWEST. ASSOCIATED PACIFIC AND GULF MOISTURE WILL GREATLY 
INCREASE TONIGHT AS THE SYSTEM APPROACHES THE FORECAST AREA. EXPECT 
RAIN TO BEGIN DEVELOPING SOME TIME AFTER MIDNIGHT...BECOMING LIKELY 
AREAWIDE BY MID MORNING. CONTINUED CATEGORICAL POPS FOR SUNDAY...AS 
THE WARM BOUNDARY AND UPPER SYSTEM MOVE ACROSS THE AREA. 

RAIN WILL DECREASE BEGINNING LATE SUNDAY AFTERNOON...AS STRONG DRY 
INTRUSION PUNCHES IN FROM THE SOUTHWEST. 

.SUNDAY NIGHT...
TEMPERATURE TRENDS WILL BE VERY HARD TO PIN DOWN ON SUNDAY 
NIGHT...AS WARM SECTOR ADVANCES NORTHWARD THROUGH CENTRAL AND 
NORTHERN ARKANSAS. NOCTURNAL VARIANCE SOUTH OF THE FRONT WILL BE 
VERY LITTLE TO ALMOST NONE. IN CENTRAL ARKANSAS AND NORTHERN 
ARKANSAS...MANY LOCATIONS WILL LIKELY SEE LOWS IN THE EARLY TO MID 
EVENING...WITH TEMPERATURES NEARLY STEADY OR SLOWLY RISING FROM 
AROUND MIDNIGHT ON.

.MONDAY AND MONDAY NIGHT...
ROUND TWO BEGINS ON MONDAY. STRONG COLD FRONT AND YET ANOTHER IN 
THIS SERIES OF 500MB TROUGHS WILL ADVANCE TOWARD THE MID AND LOWER 
MISSISSIPPI VALLEY. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL DEVELOP IN THE 
WARM SECTOR DURING THE LATE MORNING...AND INTO THE AFTERNOON AS THE 
UPPER TROUGH MOVES ACROSS...AND SEVERAL STRONG UPPER IMPULSES MOVE 
UP IN THE MEAN FLOW. SHOWERS AND STORMS WILL BE ONGOING ALONG THE 
COLD FRONT AS IT MOVES INTO WESTERN ARKANSAS ON MONDAY NIGHT. 

.SEVERE WEATHER POTENTIAL...
SEVERE WEATHER IS A GOOD POSSIBILITY ON MONDAY AND MONDAY NIGHT. 
TREMENDOUS AMOUNT OF WIND ENERGY WILL BE PRESENT...WITH 60KT OR 
GREATER MIDLEVEL JET...AND 110KT OR GREATER UPPER LEVEL JET. PLENTY 
OF DIRECTIONAL SHEAR AVAILABLE AS WELL. THUS...POTENTIAL EXISTS FOR 
STRONG...DAMAGING WINDS AND ISOLATED TORNADOES. CAN EXPECT A FEW 
HAILERS AS WELL. THE FRONT WILL MOVE INTO WESTERN ARKANSAS ON MONDAY 
NIGHT...WITH STORMS BECOMING MORE LINEAR.

ONE FLY IN THE OINTMENT IS POTENTIAL CLOUD COVER ON MONDAY. IF 
CLOUDS CAN BREAK UP ENOUGH...AND SUFFICIENT DESTABILIZATION CAN 
OCCUR...THUNDERSTORMS COULD GET GOING FAIRLY EARLY. HOWEVER...IF THE 
CLOUDS CANT BREAK...LACK OF SURFACE BASED HEATING COULD ACT TO 
PRECLUDE SIGNIFICANT DEVELOPMENT. 

.HEAVY RAINFALL POTENTIAL...
WHILE PRECIPITABLE WATERS WILL BE IN THE ONE TO TWO INCH RANGE...
WINDS ALOFT SHOULD BE SUFFICIENT ENOUGH TO KEEP STORMS MOVING. THAT 
BEING SAID HOWEVER...THERE COULD BE AT LEAST ONE TO TWO INCHES OF 
RAINFALL...MOSTLY EAST OF A LINE FROM ASH FLAT TO MENA. WITH AS MUCH 
RAINFALL THAT HAS OCCURRED OVER THE STATE DURING THE LAST TWO 
MONTHS...AND SEVERAL RIVERS NEAR OR ABOVE FLOOD STAGE...THE 
ABUNDANCE OF RAIN COULD CREATE EVEN MORE FLOODING PROBLEMS. 

.TUESDAY AND TUESDAY NIGHT...
A FEW CLOUDS MAY LINGER OVER THE NORTH ON TUESDAY...AS WRAPAROUND 
ASSOCIATED WITH UPPER SYSTEM MOVES ACROSS. OTHERWISE...SHORT TERM 
WILL END ON A QUIET NOTE...WITH SURFACE AND UPPER RIDGE MOVING IN 
FROM THE PLAINS. 
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY TUESDAY SATURDAY
LONG TERM STARTS OFF TRANQUIL...BUT ONLY BRIEFLY. HIGH PRESSURE WILL 
SHIFT TO THE EAST...WITH RETURN FLOW BRINGING MOISTURE WEDNESDAY 
NIGHT/THURSDAY. SUBTROPICAL JET CONTINUES TO BE ACTIVE...WITH SYSTEM 
RIDING SOUTHWEST WIND ALOFT TOWARD REGION. SYSTEM WILL TRIGGER 
SCATTERED SHOWERS ON THURSDAY...WITH ATMOSPHERE UNSTABLE ENOUGH FOR 
SOME THUNDER IN SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS. COLD FRONT WILL GO THROUGH BY 
THURSDAY NIGHT...WITH LONG TERM ENDING SLIGHTLY COOLER AIR/DRIER. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    41  57  53  65 /  50  90  60  70 
HARRISON AR       42  56  53  63 /  40  90  40  70 
HOT SPRINGS AR    42  54  53  67 /  50  90  50  70 
PINE BLUFF AR     44  60  55  68 /  50  90  60  80 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  42  56  53  64 /  30  90  50  70 
MONTICELLO AR     46  61  57  70 /  50  90  60  80 
SEARCY AR         40  56  53  65 /  40  90  60  70 
MOUNT IDA AR      42  53  53  67 /  50  90  40  70 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   39  54  53  65 /  40  90  40  70 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 46





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 042117
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
315 PM CST SAT DEC 4 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT

.TONIGHT AND SUNDAY...
VERY COMPLICATED AND CUMBERSOME WEATHER SITUATION SETTING UP FOR 
MUCH OF THE SHORT TERM PERIODS. WARM BOUNDARY CURRENTLY MOVING UP 
TOWARD THE GULF COAST...WITH STRONG SHORTWAVE APPROACHING FROM THE 
DESERT SOUTHWEST. ASSOCIATED PACIFIC AND GULF MOISTURE WILL GREATLY 
INCREASE TONIGHT AS THE SYSTEM APPROACHES THE FORECAST AREA. EXPECT 
RAIN TO BEGIN DEVELOPING SOME TIME AFTER MIDNIGHT...BECOMING LIKELY 
AREAWIDE BY MID MORNING. CONTINUED CATEGORICAL POPS FOR SUNDAY...AS 
THE WARM BOUNDARY AND UPPER SYSTEM MOVE ACROSS THE AREA. 

RAIN WILL DECREASE BEGINNING LATE SUNDAY AFTERNOON...AS STRONG DRY 
INTRUSION PUNCHES IN FROM THE SOUTHWEST. 

.SUNDAY NIGHT...
TEMPERATURE TRENDS WILL BE VERY HARD TO PIN DOWN ON SUNDAY 
NIGHT...AS WARM SECTOR ADVANCES NORTHWARD THROUGH CENTRAL AND 
NORTHERN ARKANSAS. NOCTURNAL VARIANCE SOUTH OF THE FRONT WILL BE

SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 46





206 
FXUS64 KLZK 040946
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
345 AM CST SAT DEC 4 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
SFC HIGH CENTERED OVR SRN AR THIS MRNG. CLEAR SKIES AND LIGHT WINDS 
HAVE ALLOWED TEMPS TO FALL INTO THE 30S AT MOST LOCATIONS. EXCEPTION 
WAS ACRS THE HIGHER TERRAIN OF NRN AND CNTRL AR WHERE LIGHT W WINDS 
HAVE KEPT READINGS IN THE UPPER 30S TO NEAR 40. MEANWHILE... 
SUB-TROPICAL MOISTURE CONTS TO LURK JUST S OF AR THIS MRNG.

HIGH PRES WILL PROVIDE ONE MORE DRY DAY ACRS THE NATURAL STATE 
BEFORE UNSETTLED WX QUICKLY RETURNS TO THE FA. EXCEPT FOR SOME HIGH 
CLOUDS...EXPECT A GOOD BIT OF SUNSHINE TODAY WITH TEMPS A COUPLE OF 
DEGREES HIGHER THAN FRI.

SFC HIGH HEADS EWD BY TNGT ALLOWING LOW LVL RH TO BEGIN RETURNING 
NWD. MEANWHILE...UPPER LOW CURRENTLY OFF THE SRN CA COAST...WL BEGIN 
HEADING EWD OVR THE NEXT 24 HOURS. THE MODELS HAVE TRENDED A BIT 
SLOWER WITH THE MOVEMENT OF THE UPPER SYS COMPARED TO YESTERDAY. 
THUS...HAVE KEPT FCST DRY INTO THIS EVENING WITH INCRSG RAIN CHCS 
LATER TNGT FROM THE SW. STUCK WITH CAT POPS FOR SUN WITH UPPER 
SUPPORT AND BEST LIFT PROGGED TO AFFECT THE FA. 

UPPER FEATURE SHIFTS NE OF THE AREA BY SUN NIGHT AND WILL SEE A 
BREAK IN THE RAINFALL. WITH BULK OF MOISTURE CONFINED TO THE LOW 
LVLS AND WARM FRONT IN THE VCNTY OF SRN AR...HAVE KEPT CHC POPS 
GOING FOR MOST AREAS SUN NIGHT.

BOTH THE ETA AND GFS ARE IN DECENT AGREEMENT FOR THE NEXT 24 TO 36 
HOURS. HOWEVER...NOTABLE DIFFERENCES OCCUR BY MON WITH THE PLACEMENT 
OF THE WARM FRONT AND NEXT UPPER SYS PROGGED TO AFFECT THE AREA. ETA 
TAKES A MORE NRN TRACK AND BRINGS HIGHER DEWPOINTS /LOW TO MID 60S/ 
INTO MUCH OF AR. WHEREAS THE GFS IS FURTHER S AND KEEPS UNSTABLE 
CONDS CONFINED TO MAINLY SRN AND ERN AR. HAVE DECIDED TO STICK 
CLOSER TO THE GFS SOLUTION ATTM AND SEE HOW LATER MODEL RUNS PAN OUT.

BY MON...CDFNT WL BE WORKING ACRS THE FA. POTENTIAL WL EXIST FOR 
STRONG TO SVR STORMS WITH THE FNT. HOWEVER...THIS HEAVILY DEPENDS ON 
THE EVENTUAL TRACK OF THE SFC LOW AND HOW FAR N THE WARM AND 
UNSTABLE AIR GETS INTO AR. STAY TUNED.

AS FOR TEMPS...MOS IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH CURRENT FCST HIGHS TODAY. 
STAYED CLOSER TO GFS MOS FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE SHORT TERM. EXPECT 
MINS SUNDAY NIGHT TO OCCUR ARND 00Z MOST LOCATIONS...WITH STEADY OR 
SLOWLY RISING READINGS THRU THE OVERNIGHT HOURS. &&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD INTO THE AREA TUESDAY. DRY AIR WILL BE IN 
PLACE AS RIDGING DEVELOPS ACROSS THE REGION THROUGH WEDNESDAY. AN 
UPPER LEVEL TROUGH DEVELOPS IN THE ROCKIES ON WEDNESDAY AND WILL 
SLIDE TO THE EAST ON THURSDAY. THIS WILL BRING US OUR NEXT CHANCE OF 
SHOWERS THURSDAY. THE GFS IS BRINGING IN QUITE A BIT OF MOISTURE AT 
THIS TIME BUT IT COULD BE OVERDONE. WILL INCREASE POPS JUST TO A 
CHANCE FOR THURSDAY. THE BEST CHANCE OF RAIN WILL BE DURING THE DAY 
ON THURSDAY. WILL NEED TO KEEP AN EYE ON THIS ONE...SINCE IT COULD 
BECOME A DECENT RAINMAKER AS THE UPPER LOW PULLS OUT OF TEXAS. 
NORTHWEST FLOW DEVELOPS ACROSS THE AREA FOR FRIDAY.
&&

.COORDINATION...
THANKS TO WFO/S SGF AND PAH FOR PRODUCTIVE COORDINATION EFFORTS THIS 
MORNING.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

44/51









44/51








591 
FXUS64 KLZK 040255
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
855 PM CST FRI DEC  3 2004

.DISCUSSION...
ANOTHER QUIET NIGHT ACROSS THE MID SOUTH AND ANOTHER NIGHT OF NO 
UPDATES TO THE CURRENT PACKAGE. BAND OF MID TO HIGH CLOUDS 
STRADDLING THE ARKANSAS/LOUISIANA BORDER EXPECTED TO MOVE EAST AND 
SHOULD BE A NON FACTOR TONIGHT. ALL OTHER FORECAST PARAMETERS LOOK 
GOOD. 
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AT 250 PM CST FRI DEC  3 2004

HIGH PRESSURE FAIRLY EXPANSIVE AT THE MOMENT...WITH LIGHT 
WINDS...LOW DEWPOINTS AND CLEAR SKY YIELDING ONE MORE COLD NIGHT 
ACROSS ARKANSAS. EVEN SO...READINGS A COUPLE OF DEGREES WARMER 
IN MOST AREAS THAN IN RECENT NIGHTS.

DRY WEATHER WILL CONTINUE ON SATURDAY WITH LOTS OF SUNSHINE. HIGH 
PRESSURE HEADING TO EAST DURING THE AFTERNOON...WITH RETURN FLOW 
BRINGING INCREASING MOISTURE THROUGH TEXAS.

MOISTURE WILL ARRIVE IN ARKANSAS SATURDAY NIGHT/SUNDAY...WITH RAIN 
OVERSPREADING THE REGION. AT THIS POINT...IT APPEARS RAIN WILL NOT 
BE EXCESSIVE...BUT WILL HAVE TO MONITOR CLOSELY GIVEN NEAR RECORD 
PRECIPITATION THE PAST COUPLE OF MONTHS AND A SATURATED 
GROUND/ONGOING RIVER FLOODING IN SOME AREAS.

ROUND ONE OF PRECIPITATION WILL END SUNDAY EVENING. LOOKS LIKE 
SUBTROPICAL JET WILL BRING A SYSTEM ALOFT...WITH ROUND TWO LATE 
SUNDAY NIGHT/MONDAY. SCATTERED SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS EXPECTED IN 
SOUTHEAST HALF OF THE STATE WITH ROUND TWO...WITH SHOWERS MORE 
ISOLATED FARTHER NORTH AND WEST. 

COLD FRONT WILL HEAD THROUGH ARKANSAS ON MONDAY...WITH CLOUDS 
THINNING OUT MONDAY NIGHT AND COOLER/DRIER AIR RETURNING. (46) 

UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD INTO THE MID SOUTH ON TUESDAY. RETURN FLOW 
WILL SET UP LATE WEDNESDAY...OUT AHEAD OF AN APPROACHING FRONTAL 
BOUNDARY. WITH SURFACE FLOW LARGELY OUT OF THE NORTH AND NORTHEAST...
GULF MOISTURE WILL BE SHUNTED TO THE SOUTH. THUS...CONDITIONS WILL 
MOSTLY BE DRY THROUGH MUCH OF THE PERIOD. 500 MB TROUGH WILL MOVE 
THROUGH ON THURSDAY...WITH SEVERAL DISTURBANCES MOVING THROUGH THE 
TROUGH. THUS...WILL LEAVE A SLIGHT CHANCE OF RAIN IN THE FORECAST 
FOR THURSDAY. 

UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD IN AND PUSH THIS WEAK FRONT OUT OF THE AREA 
BY THE WEEKEND...WITH CLOUDS DECREASING AREAWIDE. EXTENDED LARGELY 
IN GOOD SHAPE...SO ONLY A FEW TWEAKS WERE APPLIED. THANKS TO MEMPHIS 
AND JACKSON FOR COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS TODAY. (57)

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56

BOUNDARY. WITH SURFACE FLOW LARGELY OUT OF THE NORTH AND NORTHEAST...
GULF MOISTURE WILL BE SHUNTED TO THE SOUTH. THUS...CONDITIONS WILL 
MOSTLY BE DRY THROUGH MUCH OF THE PERIOD. 500 MB TROUGH WILL MOVE 
THROUGH ON THURSDAY...WITH SEVERAL DISTURBANCES MOVING THROUGH THE 
TROUGH. THUS...WILL LEAVE A SLIGHT CHANCE OF RAIN IN THE FORECAST 
FOR THURSDAY. 

UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD IN AND PUSH THIS WEAK FRONT OUT OF THE AREA 
BY THE WEEKEND...WITH CLOUDS DECREASING AREAWIDE. EXTENDED LARGELY 
IN GOOD SHAPE...SO ONLY A FEW TWEAKS WERE APPLIED. THANKS TO MEMPHIS 
AND JACKSON FOR COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS TODAY. (57)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    34  60  43  55 /   0  10  40  80 
HARRISON AR       32  60  42  54 /   0   0  20  80 
HOT SPRINGS AR    34  61  45  57 /   0  10  40  80 
PINE BLUFF AR     32  60  44  56 /   0  10  50  80 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  31  58  41  53 /   0   0  20  80 
MONTICELLO AR     31  61  46  58 /   0  10  60  80 
SEARCY AR         33  59  42  54 /   0  10  30  80 
MOUNT IDA AR      32  62  43  57 /   0  10  40  80 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   29  60  42  54 /   0  10  30  80 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46/57


000 
FXUS64 KLZK 032056
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
250 PM CST FRI DEC 3 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT 
HIGH PRESSURE FAIRLY EXPANSIVE AT THE MOMENT...WITH LIGHT 
WINDS...LOW DEWPOINTS AND CLEAR SKY YIELDING ONE MORE COLD NIGHT 
ACROSS ARKANSAS. EVEN SO...READINGS A COUPLE OF DEGREES WARMER 
IN MOST AREAS THAN IN RECENT NIGHTS.

DRY WEATHER WILL CONTINUE ON SATURDAY WITH LOTS OF SUNSHINE. HIGH 
PRESSURE HEADING TO EAST DURING THE AFTERNOON...WITH RETURN FLOW 
BRINGING INCREASING MOISTURE THROUGH TEXAS.

MOISTURE WILL ARRIVE IN ARKANSAS SATURDAY NIGHT/SUNDAY...WITH RAIN 
OVERSPREADING THE REGION. AT THIS POINT...IT APPEARS RAIN WILL NOT 
BE EXCESSIVE...BUT WILL HAVE TO MONITOR CLOSELY GIVEN NEAR RECORD 
PRECIPITATION THE PAST COUPLE OF MONTHS AND A SATURATED 
GROUND/ONGOING RIVER FLOODING IN SOME AREAS.

ROUND ONE OF PRECIPITATION WILL END SUNDAY EVENING. LOOKS LIKE 
SUBTROPICAL JET WILL BRING A SYSTEM ALOFT...WITH ROUND TWO LATE 
SUNDAY NIGHT/MONDAY. SCATTERED SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS EXPECTED IN 
SOUTHEAST HALF OF THE STATE WITH ROUND TWO...WITH SHOWERS MORE 
ISOLATED FARTHER NORTH AND WEST. 

COLD FRONT WILL HEAD THROUGH ARKANSAS ON MONDAY...WITH CLOUDS 
THINNING OUT MONDAY NIGHT AND COOLER/DRIER AIR RETURNING. (46) 
&&                

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD INTO THE MID SOUTH ON TUESDAY. RETURN FLOW 
WILL SET UP LATE WEDNESDAY...OUT AHEAD OF AN APPROACHING FRONTAL 
BOUNDARY. WITH SURFACE FLOW LARGELY OUT OF THE NORTH AND NORTHEAST...
GULF MOISTURE WILL BE SHUNTED TO THE SOUTH. THUS...CONDITIONS WILL 
MOSTLY BE DRY THROUGH MUCH OF THE PERIOD. 500 MB TROUGH WILL MOVE 
THROUGH ON THURSDAY...WITH SEVERAL DISTURBANCES MOVING THROUGH THE 
TROUGH. THUS...WILL LEAVE A SLIGHT CHANCE OF RAIN IN THE FORECAST 
FOR THURSDAY. 

UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD IN AND PUSH THIS WEAK FRONT OUT OF THE AREA 
BY THE WEEKEND...WITH CLOUDS DECREASING AREAWIDE. EXTENDED LARGELY 
IN GOOD SHAPE...SO ONLY A FEW TWEAKS WERE APPLIED. THANKS TO MEMPHIS 
AND JACKSON FOR COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS TODAY. (57)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    34  60  43  55 /   0  10  40  80 
HARRISON AR       32  60  42  54 /   0   0  20  80 
HOT SPRINGS AR    34  61  45  57 /   0  10  40  80 
PINE BLUFF AR     32  60  44  56 /   0  10  50  80 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  31  58  41  53 /   0   0  20  80 
MONTICELLO AR     31  61  46  58 /   0  10  60  80 
SEARCY AR         33  59  42  54 /   0  10  30  80 
MOUNT IDA AR      32  62  43  57 /   0  10  40  80 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   29  60  42  54 /   0  10  30  80

46/57


345 
FXUS64 KLZK 030932
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
330 AM CST FRI DEC 3 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY
WEAK SFC TROF JUST E OF THE AREA THIS MRNG...MAINLY NOTED BY LIGHT 
NWLY WIND FLOW. SFC DEWPOINTS IN THE MID 30S AND LIGHT WINDS ACRS 
CNTRL AND SRN AR HAVE KEPT TEMPS FROM BOTTOMING OUT. MEANWHILE...
READINGS OVR NRN AND WRN SECTIONS HAVE DROPPED INTO THE 30S WHERE 
DRIER AIR HAS MANAGED TO FILTER IN.

LTL CHG IN THE OVERALL WX PATTERN EXPECTED THRU SAT. ANOTHER WEAK 
CDFNT IS PROGGED BY THE MODELS TO MOVE THRU AR LATE TNGT AND EARLY 
SAT. DECENT UPPER SHORTWV ASSOCD WITH THE FNT...BUT WITH GULF 
MOISTURE CUT OFF...POPS WL RMN NIL. DO EXPECT SOME MID AND HIGH LVL 
CLOUDS TO ACCOMPANY THE UPPER SYS.

HIGH PRES SETTLES INTO THE FA FOR EARLY SAT AND THEN BEGINS TO SHIFT 
EWD LATER IN THE DAY. THIS WL ALLOW S/SELY WINDS TO RETURN TO THE 
REGION...ALONG WITH GULF MOISTURE. MEANWHILE...UPPER LVL SYS WL APCH 
FROM THE SW SAT NIGHT AND SUN TO BRING ANOTHER ROUND OF RAINFALL TO 
THE STATE. TIMING OF THE UPPER SYS NEEDS TO BE WATCHED ON LATER 
MODEL RUNS. APPEARS HIGHEST RAIN CHCS WL OCCUR ON SUN ACRS MUCH OF 
AR. CANNOT RULE OUT ISOLD THUNDER FOR THE FA...SO HAVE MENTIONED 
THAT IN THE GRIDS/ZNS.

ASSOCD SFC LOW IS PROGGED TO PASS TO THE N OF AR ON MON. DRIER AIR 
PUSHING IN FROM THE SW...RESULTING IN DIMINISHING RAIN CHCS AS THE
DAY PROGRESSES. GOING FCST HAS THIS TREND HANDLED WELL.

TEMPS WL BE A CHALLENGE THROUGHOUT THE SHORT TERM. MOS OUTPUT SEEMS 
FAIRLY CONSISTENT THRU THE PD. DID GO ABOVE MOS A FEW DEGREES SUN 
NIGHT AND MON AS MUCH OF THE FA WL BE RMN IN THE WARM SECTOR.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
UPPER TROUGH WILL MOVE THROUGH THE AREA MONDAY NIGHT AND HIGH 
PRESSURE WILL BUILD INTO THE AREA TUESDAY. VERY DRY AIR WILL REMAIN 
IN THE AREA TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. A COLD FRONT WILL MOVE INTO THE 
AREA FROM THE PLAINS THURSDAY MORNING. THE BEST CHANCE OF RAIN WILL 
BE DURING THE DAY ON THURSDAY. REMOVED MENTION OF SNOW FOR WEDNESDAY 
NIGHT AND THURSDAY MORNING. RAISED LOW TEMPERATURES FOR THURSDAY 
MORNING SINCE COLD FRONT APPEARS TO ARRIVE A LITTLE LATER THAN 
PREVIOUS RUNS OF THE GFS INDICATED. SHOULD ONLY SEE LOWS IN THE MID 
30S FOR THURSDAY MORNING IN THE NORTH. AFTER THE COLD FRONT MOVES 
THROUGH DURING THE DAY ON THURSDAY...HIGH PRESSURE RETURNS.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$
