000 
FXUS64 KLZK 311730 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1125 AM CST SUN OCT 31 2004

.DISCUSSION...
AS EXPECTED...WIDESPREAD RAIN LIFTING TO THE NORTH...WITH 
PRECIPITATION BECOMING MORE SHOWERY. APPEARS THAT SCATTERED SHOWERS 
IN THE OFFING THIS AFTERNOON. 

SATELLITE SHOWING CLEARING IN SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS LATE THIS MORNING. 
WITH SUNSHINE...TEMPERATURES WILL WARM INTO THE 80S/DEWPOINTS IN THE 
UPPER 60S AND LOWER 70S. WEAK SHORTWAVE HEADING THROUGH SOUTHERN 
COUNTIES THIS AFTERNOON...WITH POSSIBILITY OF SCATTERED 
THUNDERSTORMS FLARING UP. 

FARTHER NORTH...CLOUDS WILL PRETTY WELL HOLD...WITH READINGS IN THE 
60S/70S.

KIND OF IN A LULL NOW...WITH THE BIG EVENT COMING TONIGHT/MONDAY. 
STORM SYSTEM MOVING FROM THE ROCKIES INTO THE PLAINS WILL DRAG A 
COLD FRONT INTO THE REGION. LOTS OF MOISTURE WILL BE AVAILABLE...
WITH RAIN/THUNDERSTORMS BECOMING WIDESPREAD.

ALREADY HAVE A FLOOD WATCH IN PARTS OF NORTHERN/WESTERN ARKANSAS 
TONIGHT/EARLY MONDAY. LATEST DATA SHOWING RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 2 TO 3 
INCHES AND LOCALLY MORE GENERALLY NORTH AND WEST OF MOUNT 
IDA...MORRILTON AND BATESVILLE. PARTS OF THIS AREA HAVE ALREADY 
RECEIVED A FOOT OF RAIN THIS MONTH...AND HIGH WATER PROBLEMS APPEAR 
LIKELY. 

RAIN AREA WILL EXPAND EASTWARD ON MONDAY...WITH 1 TO 2 INCH AMOUNTS 
COMMON ACROSS THE REST OF THE REGION AND LOCALLY MORE. RAIN WILL 
COME DOWN AT A PRETTY GOOD CLIP ON NEARLY SATURATED SOIL. GIVEN 
THIS...WILL LIKELY EXPAND THE FLOOD WATCH TO INCLUDE MUCH OF 
ARKANSAS ON MONDAY. (46)
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...FLOOD WATCH FROM 600 PM CST 
SUNDAY UNTIL NOON CST MONDAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>005...ARZ012>013... 
ARZ021>022...ARZ030...ARZ037>038...ARZ040>041.
&&

$$


055 
FXUS64 KLZK 310934
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
330 AM CST SUN OCT 31 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
SHRA/TSRA CONTS TO AFFECT A LARGE PART OF AR THIS MRNG. ACTIVITY 
ASSOCD WITH WAA THAT IS IN FULL SWING OVER THE REGION. BASED ON 
LATEST SFC OBS...FNTL BNDRY LOCATED ACRS SRN AR ATTM.

EXPECT A MAJORITY OF THE RAINFALL TODAY TO BE CONCENTRATED OVR NRN 
AND WRN AR. WARM FRONT WILL LIFT SLOLY NWD TODAY AND EXPECT BNDRY TO 
MOVE INTO CNTRL AND E-CNTRL AR BY LATE IN THE DAY AND INTO NWRN AR 
TNGT. HAVE BASED HIGH TEMPS TODAY ON THIS SCENARIO.

FOCUS TNGT AND MON WITH BE THE POTENTIAL FOR EXCESSIVE RAINFALL. 
UPPER SYS APCHG FROM THE PLAINS...AND PRESENCE OF WARM FRONT...WILL
FOCUS HEAVIEST RAINS OVER WRN AND NRN AR INTO MON. 1 TO 3 INCHES 
APPEAR COMMON...WITH HIGHER AMOUNTS EXPECTED. FOR THIS REASON...WL 
ISSUE A FF WATCH FOR LOCATIONS WEST OF A KBPK-KRUE-KMWT LINE FOR 
TNGT AND MON MRNG. DAY SHIFT CAN ASSESS THINGS FOR POSSIBLE 
EXTENSION OF WATCH FOR LATER MON AND MON NIGHT FOR OTHER AREAS 
FURTHER E.

UPPER SYS IS PROGGED TO CLOSE OFF OVER THE SRN PLAINS MON NIGHT AND 
TUE AND SHIFT SLOWLY EWD. MEANWHILE...CDFNT WILL ONLY MAKE A SLOW 
PROGRESSION EWD DURG THIS TIME AS FLOW ALOFT WL RMN SWLY OVER AR 
AHEAD OF UPPER LOW.

DUE TO THE SLOWER MOVEMENT OF THE CDFNT...TWEAKED TEMPS A FEW 
DEGREES FOR MON NIGHT AND TUE. EXTENDED RAIN CHCS INTO TUE WITH 
UPPER SYS PROGGED TO MOVE ACRS THE AREA. WINDY CONDS AND COOLER 
TEMPS WILL MAKE FOR A RAW DAY ON TUE. 
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
THE EXTENDED FORECAST WILL BE DRY. UPPER LOW MOVES EAST OF THE CWFA 
TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY MORNING. HIGH PRESSURE AND VERY DRY AIR 
WILL MOVE IN FOR WEDNESDAY AND MUCH OF THURSDAY. A COLD FRONT CLIPS 
THE NORTH PART OF THE CWFA THURSDAY NIGHT...BUT MOISTURE IS LIMITED 
WITH THIS SYSTEM. ANOTHER AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE MOVES INTO THE AREA 
ON FRIDAY. COOL TEMPERATURES ARE EXPECTED WITH BELOW NORMAL READINGS.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...FLASH FLOOD WATCH FROM 600 PM CST 
SUNDAY UNTIL NOON CST MONDAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>005...ARZ012>013... 
ARZ021>022...ARZ030...ARZ037>038...ARZ040>041.
&&

402 
FXUS64 KLZK 302006
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT SAT OCT 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
AFTER A RARE TRANQUIL DAY...COMPLEX PATTERN SETTING UP. STORM 
SYSTEM WILL INTENSIFY IN THE ROCKIES/PLAINS...WITH STALLED FRONT TO 
THE SOUTH RESPONDING BY MOVING TO THE NORTH TONIGHT/SUNDAY. NORTH OF 
THE FRONT...CLOUDS WILL INCREASE WITH RAIN BECOMING LIKELY. 

ROUND ONE WILL MOSTLY END SUNDAY AFTERNOON/EVENING AS PRECIPITATION 
SHIELD LIFTS NORTH AND WEST OF THE STATE. SHIELD WILL HEAD BACK INTO 
ARKANSAS SUNDAY NIGHT/MONDAY AS STORM SYSTEM TO THE WEST DRAGS A 
COLD FRONT INTO THE REGION.

RAINFALL SUNDAY NIGHT/MONDAY APPEARS TO BE HEAVY/EXCESSIVE. TWO TO 
THREE INCH AMOUNTS LOOK LIKELY...WITH LOCALLY MORE. BELIEVE THAT
HEAVIEST AMOUNTS WILL BE IN THE NORTHERN/WESTERN COUNTIES.

FOR NOW...OPTED NOT TO ISSUE FLASH FLOOD WATCH SINCE POSSIBLE HEAVY 
RAIN EVENT 36 TO 48 HOURS AWAY. ALSO...DATA WAVERING A BIT ON TIMING 
OF EVENT. EVEN SO...MENTIONED HEAVY RAIN IN THE BODY OF THE 
FORECAST.

FRONT WILL PUSH THROUGH THE REGION MONDAY...WITH SHARPLY COOLER AIR 
TO FOLLOW. ALSO...WINDS WILL SHIFT TO THE NORTHWEST...WITH WINDY 
CONDITIONS MONDAY NIGHT/TUESDAY. FAIR AMOUNT OF WRAPAROUND MOISTURE 
BEHIND FRONT...WITH LEFTOVER LIGHT RAIN INTO EARLY TUESDAY...MAINLY 
IN NORTHERN ARKANSAS.

HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD INTO THE REGION TUESDAY NIGHT...WITH WINDS 
DECREASING/A COOL NIGHT TO FOLLOW. (46)           
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
DRY FORECAST FOR THE EXTENDED. AFTER UPPER TROUGH MOVES 
EAST...SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE TAKES HOLD FOR QUIET WEATHER. WEAK 
FRONT MOVES THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT/FRIDAY...BUT WITH LIMITED 
MOISTURE. TEMPS WILL BE BELOW NORMAL THROUGH THE WEEKEND. (58) 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    57  67  62  70 /  60  80  60  80 
HARRISON AR       47  61  57  63 /  30  80  80  80 
HOT SPRINGS AR    59  68  63  70 /  60  80  80  80 
PINE BLUFF AR     61  70  64  73 /  70  60  40  80 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  47  61  56  63 /  30  80  80  80 
MONTICELLO AR     62  75  66  75 /  70  60  40  80 
SEARCY AR         53  66  60  68 /  50  80  60  80 
MOUNT IDA AR      58  68  63  69 /  60  80  80  80 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   52  65  61  67 /  50  80  80  80 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

STORM SYSTEM IN THE ROCKIES WILL HEAD INTO THE PLAINS. IN RESPONSE 
TO THE APPROACHING SYSTEM...FRONT TO THE SOUTH WILL RETURN TO THE 
NORTH WITH LOTS OF MOISTURE. CLOUDS WILL INCREASE TONIGHT...WITH 
WIDESPREAD RAIN/ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS ON SUNDAY.

ARKANSAS WILL BE THE FAVORED AREAS FOR HEAVY/EXCESSIVE AMOUNTS...AND

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
355 AM CDT SAT OCT 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY
RUNNING A BIT LATE THIS MRNG DUE TO ISOLD SVR STORMS. LINE OF 
CONVECTION IN ADVANCE OF CDFNT BISECTING AR FM NE TO SW EARLY THIS 
MRNG. HAD ONE STORM OF INTEREST THAT TRACKED ACRS CNTRL AR PRODUCING 
SEVERAL REPORTS OF WIND DAMAGE.

CDFNT WILL WORK INTO NWRN AR EARLY THIS MRNG AND SHIFT SEWD DURG THE 
DAY. MODELS CONT TO STALL THE FNT OUT NEAR THE AR/LA BRDR REGION 
TNGT. NEXT UPPER SYSTEM STILL FCST TO APCH FROM THE W LATE SAT NIGHT 
AND SUN...ALLOWING SFC FNT TO LIFT BACK NWD. INCRSG WAA AND MOISTURE 
ADVECTION WILL RESULT IN ANOTHER ROUND OF SHOWERS AND STORMS FOR THE 
STATE TO CLOSE OUT THE WEEKEND.

FNTL BNDRY WILL LIFT INTO CNTRL AR LATER SUN AND EVENTUALLY WORK 
INTO NRN AND WRN AR SUN NIGHT AND MON. DUE TO SLOW PROGRESSION OF 
THE FNT...HEAVY RAINFALL WILL BE A CONCERN SUN INTO MON FOR A GOOD 
PART OF THE FA.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
MODELS CONT TO SLOW DOWN THE PROGRESSION OF THE UPPER SYS FOR THE 
FIRST HALF OF THE PD. HELD ONTO POPS INTO TUE NIGHT FOR MOST AREAS. 
STILL LOOKS LIKE DRIER AND COOLER AIR WILL RETURN FOR LATE IN THE 
WEEK.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

946 
FXUS64 KLZK 300230
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
925 PM CDT FRI OCT 29 2004

.DISCUSSION...
THIN LINE OF CONVECTION EXTENDS FROM SOUTHWEST MISSOURI TO SOUTH 
CENTRAL OKLAHOMA AND SLOWLY PUSHING EAST. LINE PRODUCED SEVERE 
WEATHER EARLIER TONIGHT OVER PARTS OF NORTHEAST OKLAHOMA AND 
SOUTHWEST MISSOURI BUT TREND HAS BEEN DECREASING OVER THE PAST FEW 
HOURS AS LINE RUNS INTO MUCH LESS FAVORABLE ENVIRONMENT. TORNADO 
WATCH NUMBER WATCH 872 FOR THREE COUNTIES IN THE WESTERN CWA RUNS 
THROUGH 11 PM AND WILL LET WATCH EXPIRE ON TIME BASED ON CURRENT 
TRENDS.

LINE OF STORMS ASSOCIATED WITH A COLD FRONT MOVING ACROSS THE 
CENTRAL PLAINS. OTHER LIGHT ACTIVITY CONTINUES OVER PARTS OF THE 
CENTRAL AND EAST. LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES COLD FRONT JUST 
BEHIND THE LINE ON CONVECTION. ALL THE UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT FOR THE 
FRONT WELL TO THE NORTHWEST OF THE AREA AND FRONT SHOULD CONTINUE TO 
WEAKEN THROUGH THE NIGHT WITH MINIMAL CHANCES FOR EASTERN ARKANSAS 
AND LOW CHANCE POPS ELSEWHERE.

CURRENT FORECAST HAS SITUATION WELL IN HAND AND WILL ONLY NEED TO 
TWEAK THE GRIDS TO REFLECT CURRENT CONDITIONS. SATURDAY STILL 
APPEARS TO BE A RATHER QUIET DAY WITH RAIN...POSSIBLY HEAVY...FOR 
SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY. RAIN MAY HOLD THROUGH TUESDAY AND 
POSSIBLY WEDNESDAY DEPENDING ON WHAT MODEL YOU BUY INTO. REGARDLESS 
...FLOODING POTENTIAL DOES EXIST SUNDAY AND MONDAY AND SITUATION 
WILL BE WATCHED CLOSELY.

WILL ISSUE A NEW SET OF ZONES BY 945 PM WITH ANOTHER SET SLATED TO 
GO OUT AT 11 PM WHEN THE WATCH EXPIRES.  
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$


210 
FXUS64 KLZK 292006
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT FRI OCT 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
OTHER THAN A FEW SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS IN THE NORTHWEST...A DRY AND 
WARM AFTERNOON. THIS WILL CHANGE. A COLD FRONT SET TO HEAD INTO 
ARKANSAS FROM THE PLAINS LATER TONIGHT...BRINGING ANOTHER ROUND OF 
SCATTERED PRECIPITATION.

UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT WITH FRONT WELL NORTH OF THE STATE. MODERATE 
RISK OF SEVERE WEATHER IN UPPER MIDWEST...WITH ONLY ISOLATED SEVERE 
STORMS IN ARKANSAS. LOOKS AS THOUGH PRECIPITATION COVERAGE WILL 
DECREASE AS SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS MOVE INTO EASTERN ARKANSAS
OVERNIGHT...WITH NOT MUCH LEFT TOWARD MORNING.

ON SATURDAY...FRONT WILL SAG JUST TO THE SOUTH OF ARKANSAS BEFORE 
STALLING. AT THIS POINT...DRIER/SLIGHTLY COOLER BEHIND FRONT...AND 
NO RAIN IN THE FORECAST.

NEW SYSTEM WILL APPROACH THE REGION FROM THE SOUTHERN PLAINS 
SATURDAY NIGHT/SUNDAY. STALLED FRONT TO THE SOUTH WILL SURGE BACK TO 
THE NORTH...WITH A LOT OF MOISTURE BECOMING AVAILABLE ONCE 
AGAIN. 

SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS WILL BECOME LIKELY SUNDAY INTO MONDAY. IT 
LOOKS LIKE A HEAVY RAIN EVENT IS IN STORE...WITH WIDESPREAD 2 TO 3 
INCH AMOUNTS AND LOCALLY MORE. IT APPEARS THAT THE HEAVIEST RAIN 
WILL FALL IN NORTHERN AND WESTERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE. WILL 
MONITOR THE SITUATION CLOSELY FOR THE POTENTIAL OF FLOODING. (46)  
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
CHANGES MADE TO EXTENDED FORECAST...AS MODELS HAVE SLOWED TIMING OF 
NEXT TROUGH AND ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT. NEW MODEL RUNS ARE DIFFERING 
BETWEEN A CLOSED LOW AND AN OPEN WAVE. DUE TO A MAJOR CHANGE...HAVE 
TRENDED UPWARD WITH POPS...BUT DID NOT GO QUITE AS HIGH AS GUIDANCE. 
IF NEED BE...LATER SHIFTS CAN CONTINUE THE TREND HIGHER. TUESDAY AND 
WEDNESDAY WILL DEPEND ON WHERE THE LOW/WAVE IS LOCATED. THURSDAY AND 
FRIDAY WILL BE DRY WITH HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN. TEMPS WILL DEPEND 
ON CLOUD COVER/PRECIP...SO LOWERED READINGS TO SHOW TREND.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    65  78  53  65 /  40  30  30  50 
HARRISON AR       54  70  45  63 /  50  10  10  50 
HOT SPRINGS AR    64  78  54  65 /  40  20  40  50 
PINE BLUFF AR     66  79  56  66 /  40  30  50  50 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  56  70  45  62 /  50  20  10  50 
MONTICELLO AR     67  81  59  69 /  30  30  50  50 
SEARCY AR         64  77  50  64 /  40  30  30  50 
MOUNT IDA AR      61  76  54  65 /  40  20  30  50 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   59  76  49  63 /  50  20  20  50 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46/58






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 292006
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT FRI OCT 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
OTHER THAN A FEW SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS IN THE NORTHWEST...A DRY AND 
WARM AFTERNOON. THIS WILL CHANGE. A COLD FRONT SET TO HEAD INTO 
ARKANSAS FROM THE PLAINS LATER TONIGHT...BRINGING ANOTHER ROUND OF 
SCATTERED PRECIPITATION.

UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT WITH FRONT WELL NORTH OF THE STATE. MODERATE 
RISK OF SEVERE WEATHER IN UPPER MIDWEST...WITH ONLY ISOLATED SEVERE 
STORMS IN ARKANSAS. LOOKS AS THOUGH PRECIPITATION COVERAGE WILL 
DECREASE AS SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS MOVE INTO EASTERN ARKANSAS
OVERNIGHT...WITH NOT MUCH LEFT TOWARD MORNING.

ON SATURDAY...FRONT WILL SAG JUST TO THE SOUTH OF ARKANSAS BEFORE 
STALLING. AT THIS POINT...DRIER/SLIGHTLY COOLER BEHIND FRONT...AND 
NO RAIN IN THE FORECAST.

NEW SYSTEM WILL APPROACH THE REGION FROM THE SOUTHERN PLAINS 
SATURDAY NIGHT/SUNDAY. STALLED FRONT TO THE SOUTH WILL SURGE BACK TO 
THE NORTH...WITH A LOT OF MOISTURE BECOMING AVAILABLE ONCE 
AGAIN. 

SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS WILL BECOME LIKELY SUNDAY INTO MONDAY. IT 
LOOKS LIKE A HEAVY RAIN EVENT IS IN STORE...WITH WIDESPREAD 2 TO 3 
INCH AMOUNTS AND LOCALLY MORE. IT APPEARS THAT THE HEAVIEST RAIN 
WILL FALL IN NORTHERN AND WESTERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE. WILL 
MONITOR THE SITUATION CLOSELY FOR THE POTENTIAL OF FLOODING. (46)  
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
CHANGES MADE TO EXTENDED FORECAST...AS MODELS HAVE SLOWED TIMING OF 
NEXT TROUGH AND ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT. NEW MODEL RUNS ARE DIFFERING 
BETWEEN A CLOSED LOW AND AN OPEN WAVE. DUE TO A MAJOR CHANGE...HAVE 
TRENDED UPWARD WITH POPS...BUT DID NOT GO QUITE AS HIGH AS GUIDANCE. 
IF NEED BE...LATER SHIFTS CAN CONTINUE THE TREND HIGHER. TUESDAY AND 
WEDNESDAY WILL DEPEND ON WHERE THE LOW/WAVE IS LOCATED. THURSDAY AND 
FRIDAY WILL BE DRY WITH HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN. TEMPS WILL DEPEND 
ON CLOUD COVER/PRECIP...SO LOWERED READINGS TO SHOW TREND.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    65  78  53  65 /  40  30  30  50 
HARRISON AR       54  70  45  63 /  50  10  10  50 
HOT SPRINGS AR    64  78  54  65 /  40  20  40  50 
PINE BLUFF AR     66  79  56  66 /  40  30  50  50 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  56  70  45  62 /  50  20  10  50 
MONTICELLO AR     67  81  59  69 /  30  30  50  50 
SEARCY AR         64  77  50  64 /  40  30  30  50 
MOUNT IDA AR      61  76  54  65 /  40  20  30  50 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   59  76  49  63 /  50  20  20  50 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

46/58






749 
FXUS64 KLZK 291643 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1135 AM CDT FRI OCT 29 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CLOUDS HOLDING ON LONGER THAN EXPECTED IN SOUTHERN/WESTERN ARKANSAS. 
KEPT CLOUDS IN THROUGH EARLY THIS AFTERNOON THESE AREAS...THEN 
THINNED THE CLOUDS OUT A BIT. TEMPERATURES/WINDS STILL LOOK 
REASONABLE...WITH BREEZY SOUTHWEST WINDS PUSHING MERCURY LEVELS WELL 
ABOVE NORMAL.

REST OF FORECAST ON TRACK. COLD FRONT WILL HEAD INTO THE REGION 
TONIGHT FROM THE PLAINS...WITH UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT WELL TO THE 
NORTH. THIS WILL TEND TO KEEP SEVERE WEATHER MORE ISOLATED 
TONIGHT...AND THE FRONT WILL ALSO HAVE LESS PUSH. GOING FORECAST 
STALLS THE FRONT NEAR THE ARKANSAS/LOUISIANA BORDER ON SATURDAY.

LOOKING AHEAD...RATHER OMINOUS AS FAR AS RAIN DURING THE LATTER HALF 
OF THE WEEKEND/EARLY NEXT WEEK. STALLED FRONT WILL LIFT NORTH IN 
RESPONSE TO NEW SYSTEM APPROACHING FROM THE SOUTHERN PLAINS. THERE 
WILL BE LOTS OF MOISTURE IN PLACE...WITH THE POTENTIAL FOR HEAVY TO 
EXCESSIVE RAIN SUNDAY/MONDAY. (46)
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46

46






518 
FXUS64 KLZK 290837
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
335 AM CDT FRI OCT 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY
SPRINGLIKE CONDS PERSIST OVR THE FA THIS MRNG WITH TEMPS IN THE MID 
60S TO LOWER 70S. ALREADY SEEING SOME STRATUS FORM OVER THE HIGHER 
TERRAIN OF WRN AND NRN AR. EXPECT THESE CLOUDS TO CONT FORMING THRU 
SUNRISE OVER MOST AREAS ALONG WITH PTCHY FOG.

MODELS STILL IN DECENT AGREEMENT WITH OVERALL FCST TRENDS EARLY IN 
THE PD. UPPER RDG IN PLACE ACRS THE FA IS FCST TO WEAKEN LATER TODAY 
AS AN UPPER TROF HEAD EWD OUT OF THE NRN ROCKIES OVR THE NEXT 24 TO 
36 HOURS.

EXPECT WARM SLY WINDS TO CONT TODAY...ALLOWING TEMPS TO CLIMB TO ABV 
NORMAL LVLS ONCE AGAIN THIS AFTN AS CLOUDS THIN OUT. SFC CDFNT 
TRAILING SWD FROM THE NRN PLAINS STORM SYS WILL AFFECT THE STATE 
TNGT AND SAT. HAVE KEPT SLIGHT CHC POPS IN PLACE FOR WRN AR THIS 
AFTN...WITH CAP EXPECTED TO HOLD ELSEWHERE. INCRSD POPS STATEWIDE 
TNGT AS FNT WORKS SLOLY SEWD ACRS THE AREA. LATEST M-ETA RUN HAS 
TRENDED EVEN A BIT SLOWER WITH FROPA TNGT AND SAT...SO HAVE MADE 
SOME MINOR ADJUSTMENTS TO POPS. 

BNDRY STILL EXPECTED TO STALL OUT NEAR THE AR/LA BRDR ON SAT AND 
HAVE LEFT SOME LINGERING RAIN CHCS FOR SRN AR THRU SAT. BNDRY BEGINS 
TO LIFT BACK NWD LATE SAT NIGHT AND SUN AS ANOTHER STORM SYS 
ORGANIZES IN THE SRN PLAINS. RAISED POPS FOR SUN AND SUN NIGHT IN 
ADVANCE OF THE SYS. ASSOCD FNT WILL MOVE SLOLY INTO ERN AR ON MON.

HEAVY RAIN POTENTIAL EXISTS FOR THE STATE SUN THRU MON WITH FNTL 
BNDRYS PROVIDING FOCUS FOR CONVECTIVE FORMATION. LATER SHIFTS WILL 
NEED TO CONT TO MONITOR THE SITUATION AND PLAN TO HIGHLIGHT IN THE 
HWO.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
CONFIDENCE IN EXTENDED PERIODS IS SEVERELY LACKING THIS MORNING. 
MODELS ARE IN A BIT OF A DISAGREEMENT AS TO HOW FAST THE FRONTAL 
SYSTEM PUSHES OUT OF THE MID/LWR MS VALLEY LATE MONDAY INTO TUESDAY. 
INCOMING RUN OF THE GFS WAITS TO PUSH FRONTAL BOUNDARY OUT OF 
ARKANSAS UNTIL TUESDAY MORNING...WITH SIGNIFICANT MOISTURE 
ASSOCIATED WITH STRONG UPPER LOW MOVING IN FROM OK/TX BY TUESDAY 
NIGHT. 

GFS SEEMS TO BE THE MOST AGGRESSIVE...INDICATING A CLOSED 500 MB LOW 
MOVING INTO WESTERN ARKANSAS TUESDAY NIGHT. EXTENDED UKMET...
EUROPEAN...AND DGEX SHOW THE SYSTEM TO BE MORE OF AN OPEN WAVE...
THUS A LITTLE WEAKER WITH LESS IMPRESSIVE MOISTURE FIELDS. ALSO...
GFS HAS TENDED TO STRENGTHEN RIDGE OVER THE EAST COAST...WHEREAS 
OTHER MODELS APPEAR TO FLATTEN OUT THE RIDGE.

TRENDED THE FORECAST A LITTLE SLOWER...BUT HAVE CLEARED OUT PRECIP 
CHANCES BY TUESDAY DURING THE DAY. HAVE ALSO TRENDED MINS A DEGREE 
OR TWO WARMER AND MAXES A LITTLE COOLER DUE TO POSSIBLE INCREASED 
CLOUD COVER. OF COURSE IF THIS TREND OF SLOWING THE SYSTEM DOWN 
CONTINUES...ADJUSTMENTS WILL HAVE TO BE MADE FURTHER.

ONCE THIS SYSTEM CLEARS THE AREA...UPPER FLOW APPEARS TO VARY FROM 
NORTHWESTERLY TO ZONAL FOR A FEW DAYS...PRECLUDING A MAJOR WARMUP 
AND KEEPING TEMPERATURES MUCH CLOSER TO NORMAL THAN THEY HAVE BEEN. 
BY THURSDAY...HIGH PRESSURE WILL SCOOT ON BY...WITH WEAK RETURN FLOW 
SETTING UP OUT AHEAD OF AN APPROACHING WEAK COLD FRONT.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

44/57

44/57







248 
FXUS64 KLZK 290233
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
922 PM CDT THU OCT 28 2004

.DISCUSSION...
ONLY SUPERFICIAL CHANGES NEEDED TO THE FORECAST THIS EVENING. WILL 
UPDATE TO REMOVE MENTION OF EVENING WORDING AND REMOVE ALL MENTION 
OF PRECIP. OTHER CHANGES WILL BE NEEDED TO TWEAK CLOUD COVER A BIT 
AND ADJUST THE TEMP GRIDS TO REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS BUT FORECASTED 
LOWS LOOK REASONABLE.

RIDGE CENTERED IN THE GULF STILL FORECAST TO BUILD NORTHWARD THROUGH 
THE NIGHT WITH THE AXIS SLIGHTLY FURTHER EAST THAN LAST FEW RUNS. 
THIS WILL KEEP THE SOUTHWEST FLOW IN PLACE WITH TEMPERATURES AND 
HUMIDITY LEVELS ABOVE WHERE THEY NORMALLY ARE FOR THIS TIME OF THE 
YEAR. CURRENT THINKING OF A WET PERIOD HEADING INTO THE WEEKEND 
LOOKS GOOD BUT LATEST GFS MODEL HOLDS ONTO THE PRECIP FOR TUESDAY 
INSTEAD OF MOVING IT OUT. WILL HAVE TO LET THE MIDNIGHT SHIFT DECIDE 
WHAT DO DO HERE AS ALL THE NEW MODELS JUST STARTING TO TRICKLE IN.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
RIDGING OCCURRING ALOFT AHEAD OF DEEP TROUGH IN THE ROCKIES. THIS 
WILL BRING WARM/MOSTLY DRY WEATHER TO THE REGION THROUGH TONIGHT AND 
MUCH OF FRIDAY.

TROUGH WILL FILL A BIT AS IT HEADS FROM THE ROCKIES INTO THE PLAINS. 
SURFACE FRONT WILL PUSH INTO ARKANSAS FRIDAY NIGHT...WITH BREEZY 
CONDITIONS SURROUNDING THE FRONT. WILL BE SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS AHEAD OF THE FRONT. HOWEVER...WITH UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT 
WELL NORTH OF THE STATE...WOULD THINK THAT ANY SEVERE WEATHER WOULD 
BE ISOLATED.

AS UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT MOVES AWAY...FRONT WILL STALL JUST TO THE 
SOUTH OF THE STATE ON SATURDAY. NEW SYSTEM WILL INTENSIFY IN THE 
SOUTHERN PLAINS...WHICH WILL INDUCE THE STALLED FRONT TO MOVE BACK 
TO THE NORTH SATURDAY NIGHT/SUNDAY.

SYSTEM IN THE PLAINS WILL DRAG NEW FRONT INTO ARKANSAS SUNDAY 
NIGHT/MONDAY. THIS FRONT DOES NOT APPEAR THAT IT WILL STALL...AND 
WILL BE FOLLOWED BY DRIER/COOLER AIR NEXT WEEK. 

BIG CONCERN IN THE SHORT TERM WILL BE HEAVY RAINFALL. LOTS OF 
MOISTURE SURROUNDING STALLED FRONT OVER THE WEEKEND. AS SYSTEM FROM 
THE PLAINS APPROACHES LATE IN THE WEEKEND...COULD HAVE WIDESPREAD 
HEAVY RAIN EVENT. WILL MONITOR THE SITUATION CLOSELY. (46)           

UPPER TROUGH WILL MOVE TO EAST TUESDAY...WITH HIGH PRESSURE AND DRY 
WEATHER TO FOLLOW. TEMPERATURES WILL BE SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL...WITH 
HIGHS IN THE MID TO UPPER 60S...AND LOWS IN THE 40S. (58)

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56

HEAVY RAIN EVENT. WILL MONITOR THE SITUATION CLOSELY. (46)           
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
UPPER TROUGH WILL MOVE TO EAST TUESDAY...WITH HIGH PRESSURE AND DRY 
WEATHER TO FOLLOW. TEMPERATURES WILL BE SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL...WITH 
HIGHS IN THE MID TO UPPER 60S...AND LOWS IN THE 40S. (58)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    67  84  65  76 /  10  20  40  20 
HARRISON AR       66  79  57  69 /  20  30  40  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    67  84  63  76 /  10  20  40  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     66  84  66  78 /  10  20  40  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  65  79  58  69 /  20  30  40  10 
MONTICELLO AR     66  85  67  78 /  10  20  40  30 
SEARCY AR         66  82  64  75 /  10  20  40  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      68  84  62  76 /  10  30  40  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   67  82  60  75 /  10  30  40  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

46/58






152 
FXUS64 KLZK 281616 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1110 AM CDT THU OCT 28 2004

.DISCUSSION...
PRECIPITATION IN NORTHERN ARKANSAS WINDING DOWN LATE THIS MORNING. 
SKY WILL BECOME PARTLY CLOUDY IN MUCH OF THE STATE THIS 
AFTERNOON...WITH ONLY SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS.

PLENTY OF RIDGING TONIGHT...AND NOTHING TO INDICATE REDEVELOPMENT OF 
PRECIPITATION. GIVEN THIS...REMOVED MENTION OF RAIN TONIGHT.

MUCH OF FRIDAY WILL END UP BREEZY AND WARM...WITH PRECIPITATION 
HOLDING OFF UNTIL THE AFTERNOON/EVENING. PRECIPITATION WILL BE AHEAD 
OF A COLD FRONT...WHICH WILL ARRIVE FROM THE WEST FRIDAY NIGHT.

STILL APPEARS THAT FRONT WILL STALL ACROSS SOUTHERN ARKANSAS THIS 
WEEKEND AS UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT HEADS WELL TO THE NORTH. NEW STORM 
SYSTEM WILL APPROACH THE REGION FROM THE PLAINS LATE IN THE 
WEEKEND/EARLY NEXT WEEK...WITH STALLED FRONT LIFTING NORTH IN 
RESPONSE. LOTS OF MOISTURE SET TO HEAD NORTH WITH THE FRONT...AND 
THIS COULD LEAD TO HEAVY RAINFALL EVENT. (46)
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46 






986 
FXUS64 KLZK 280848
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT THU OCT 28 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY
SHORT WAVE MOVING ACROSS NORTHERN ARKANSAS THIS MORNING WITH AN 
ASSOCIATED AREA OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. THIS WILL DRIFT TO
THE EAST TODAY AND UPPER RIDGING SHOULD INCREASE ACROSS THE AREA
WHICH SHOULD LOWER RAIN CHANCES UNTIL THE COLD FRONT APPROACHES 
LATE FRIDAY. WENT WITH LIKELY POPS EARLY THIS MORNING IN THE NORTH
THEN DECREASED POPS THIS AFTERNOON. AFTER THAT HAVE SLIGHT CHANCE
POPS ACROSS THE AREA TONIGHT INTO FRIDAY WITH POPS STARTING TO
INCREASE IN THE WEST LATE IN THE DAY. PUT IN PATCHY FOG FOR 
EARLY THIS MORNING BASED ON OBS BUT WILL NEED TO MONITOR OVER
THE NEXT FEW HOURS FOR DEVELOPMENT OF DENSE FOG. RIDGING SHOULD 
HELP CLOUDS BREAK SOME DURING THE AFTERNOON SO WENT CLOSE TO 
MOS ON MAXES FOR TODAY AND FRIDAY WITH MOST AREAS REACHING THE
LOWER 80S. THE NORTH WILL HAVE MORE CLOUDS TODAY AND BETTER CHANCES
OF RAIN THIS MORNING WHICH MAY HOLD MAXES DOWN A LITTLE THERE. 
UPPER TROF MOVES INTO THE PLAINS LATE FRIDAY INTO SATURDAY AND 
PUSHES A COLD FRONT ACROSS THE AREA. KEPT 40 PERCENT POPS
FOR THE FRONTAL PASSAGE. MODELS SHOW FRONT MOVING TO THE SOUTH OF 
THE AREA BY LATE SATURDAY AND PUSHING THE MOISTURE OUT FOR 
SATURDAY NIGHT AND A WEAK SURFACE HIGH MOVES ACROSS THE AREA.
LOWERED POPS FOR SATURDAY NIGHT CONFINING A SLIGHT CHANCE TO
THE FAR SOUTH. MOISTURE RETURNS RAPIDLY TO THE AREA SUNDAY WHEN 
THE SURFACE HIGH SHIFTS TO THE EAST OF THE AREA. INCREASED POPS 
DURING THE DAY SUNDAY TO ACCOUNT FOR THIS.
   
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
THE NEXT BIG TROF AND COLD FRONT RACH THE AREA MONDAY. GOOD MOISTURE
RETURN SUNDAY AHEAD OF THIS SYSTEM WILL BRING CLOUDS AND A GOOD
CHANCE OF RAIN BY LATE SUNDAY CONTINUING UNTIL THE FRONT PASSES ON 
MONDAY. THE DYNAMICS ARE NOT LOOKING AS STRONG AND THE TROF IS 
PROGGED TO HAVE A POSITIVE TILT AS IT MOVES TOWARD THE AREA. THE
INFLUX OF CLOUDS AND PRECIP AHEAD OF THE SYSTEM MAY LIMIT 
INSTABILITY SO THE RISK OF SEVERE WEATHER FOR MONDAY IS NOT LOOKING 
AS GOOD AS IT DID EARLIER. STILL LOOKS LIKE THE FRONT WILL SWEEP 
OUT OF THE AREA MONDAY NIGHT AND TUESDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY SHOULD
BE DRY WITH CONSIDERABLY COOLER AND DRIER AIR IN PLACE. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    82  67  84  65 /  40  20  20  40 
HARRISON AR       78  66  79  57 /  60  20  30  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    83  67  84  63 /  40  20  20  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  66  84  66 /  30  20  20  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  78  65  79  58 /  60  20  30  40 
MONTICELLO AR     84  66  85  67 /  20  20  20  40 
SEARCY AR         81  66  82  64 /  50  20  20  40 
MOUNT IDA AR      83  68  84  62 /  40  20  30  40 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   81  67  82  60 /  40  20  30  40 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29 






461 
FXUS64 KLZK 280218
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
911 PM CDT WED OCT 27 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS RIGHT ON TARGET AND NO CHANGES ARE NEEDED. 
SHORTWAVE CONTINUES TO LIFT OUT OF TEXAS AND INTO A VERY MOIST 
AIRMASS. SHOWERS CONTINUE OVER THE NORTHWEST AND STILL EXPECTING 
THEM TO SPREAD EAST AS THE WAVE PASSES ACROSS THE NORTHERN TIER OF 
COUNTIES. TEMPERATURES LOOK GOOD AND EVERYTHING WILL BE LEFT IN 
PLACE.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
WEAK SHORTWAVES RIDING SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT MOVED OVER 
MOIST/UNSTABLE AIR AT THE SURFACE THIS MORNING...WITH WIDESPREAD 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN NORTHERN/CENTRAL ARKANSAS. A SIMILAR 
SCENARIO EXPECTED TONIGHT...WITH MORE VIGOROUS SYSTEM ARRIVING FROM 
THE SOUTHERN PLAINS.

SYSTEM IN PLAINS WILL BE INTERACTING WITH STALLED FRONT CLOSE TO THE 
ARKANSAS/MISSOURI BORDER. HENCE...PRECIPITATION THAT DEVELOPS WILL 
BE MOST WIDESPREAD NEAR FRONT...WITH RAIN MORE SCATTERED TOWARD 
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS WHERE RIDGE BEGINNING TO BUILD FROM GULF 
COAST. 

RIDGE MORE PRONOUNCED THURSDAY/FRIDAY IN RESPONSE TO DEEP TROUGH 
IN THE ROCKIES. AFTER MORNING SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS IN NORTHERN 
ARKANSAS ON THURSDAY...PRECIPITATION WILL BECOME MORE ISOLATED WITH 
TEMPERATURES WELL ABOVE NORMAL.

AS TROUGH IN THE ROCKIES HEADS INTO THE PLAINS...IT WILL FILL A BIT 
AS IT MOVES TOWARD THE UPPER MIDWEST. SURFACE FRONT WILL SURGE INTO 
ARKANSAS FRIDAY NIGHT/SATURDAY...WITH SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
AHEAD OF THE FRONT. FRONT WILL STALL AS UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT MOVES 
WELL TO THE NORTH. 

STALLED FRONT WILL REMAIN IN THE STATE THROUGH THE WEEKEND. APPEARS 
THAT PRECIPITATION BE LIKELY NEAR THE FRONT...WITH HEAVY RAINFALL 
AMOUNTS POSSIBLE. AM A LITTLE WORRIED ABOUT FLOODING OVER THE 
WEEKEND...ESPECIALLY IN CENTRAL/SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE. WILL 
MONITOR THE SITUATION CLOSELY. 

PRECIPITATION WILL BE SWEPT TO THE EAST EARLY NEXT WEEK AS NEW 
FRONT ARRIVES FROM THE WEST. (46)         

COLD FRONT AND UPPER TROUGH WILL QUICKLY MOVE EAST AND THROUGH THE 
STATE MONDAY. DYNAMICS WILL BE CLOSER TO THE STATE THAN THE SYSTEM 
DURING THE WEEKEND...SO SEVERE WEATHER IS POSSIBLE. WILL HAVE TO SEE 
HOW THE SITUATION DEVELOPS. DRY CONDITIONS FOR TUESDAY AND 
WEDNESDAY. TEMPS WILL NEAR NORMAL MONDAY...BEFORE FALLING BEHIND THE 
COLD FRONT FOR THE REST OF THE EXTENDED. (58)

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

DURING THE WEEKEND...SO SEVERE WEATHER IS POSSIBLE. WILL HAVE TO SEE 
HOW THE SITUATION DEVELOPS. DRY CONDITIONS FOR TUESDAY AND 
WEDNESDAY. TEMPS WILL NEAR NORMAL MONDAY...BEFORE FALLING BEHIND THE 
COLD FRONT FOR THE REST OF THE EXTENDED. (58)

825 AM CDT WED OCT 27 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SHOWERS/FEW THUNDERSTORMS DEVELOPED IN SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS EARLY THIS 
MORNING...AND WILL SPREAD ACROSS CENTRAL/NORTHERN SECTIONS OF THE 
STATE THROUGH THE EARLY AFTERNOON BEFORE SCATTERING OUT. GIVEN THE 
CURRENT TREND...UPPED CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION NORTH/CENTRAL 
ARKANSAS...WITH LOW RAIN CHANCES CONTINUING IN THE SOUTH. (46)
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



860 
FXUS64 KLZK 270903
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT WED OCT 27 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY
UPPER RIDGING OVER THE AREA WITH UNSEASONABLY WARM AND HUMID AIR
MASS IN PLACE ACROSS THE AREA. THIS PATTERN SHOULD CHANGE LITTLE
THROUGH FRIDAY WITH NO SIGNIFICANT SHORT WAVES OR FRONTS MOVING
THROUGH. MODELS BROUGHT BLOWUP OF PRECIPITATION INTO THE AREA
THIS MORNING CONTINUING THROUGH TODAY BUT THIS HAS NOT HAPPENED
IN REAL TIME. SIMILAR PATTERN OCCURRED MONDAY. THUS WILL NOT GO 
WITH EXCESSIVELY HIGH MOS POPS AND GENERALLY KEEP THE POP PATTERN
IN CHANCE RANGE WITH THE HIGHEST POPS IN THE NORTH WHERE UPPER 
HEIGHTS ARE LOWEST. DID GO WITH 30 PERCENT POPS IN THE SOUTH TODAY 
SINCE AREA OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WERE MOVING INTO SOUTHWESTERN
ARKANSAS FROM TEXAS AND SHOULD TRACK ACROSS THE SOUTH THIS MORNING. 
CLOUDS MAY BE MORE PREVALENT TODAY WITH THE HIGHER MOISTURE LEVELS
PROGGED SO WENT WITH MAXES TODAY ABOUT A CATEGORY LOWER THAN 
YESTERDAY BUT WENT FOR MAXES THURSDAY AND FRIDAY CLOSE TO THOSE
OF YESTERDAY. ON FRIDAY INTO SATURDAY...UPPER TROF MOVES NORTHEAST
ACROSS THE PLAINS AND BRINGS A COLD FRONT INTO THE AREA. WITH THE 
BEST UPPER SUPPORT MOVING AWAY FROM THE AREA...THE COLD FRONT WEAKENS
AND DOES NOT PENETRATE THE CWA. WENT WITH CHANCE POPS ACROSS THE
AREA AND ONLY INDICATED SIGNIFICANT COOLING AND DRYING IN THE 
NORTHWEST.  
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
THE FRONT REMAINS IN THE AREA AND WASHES OUT OVER THE WEEKEND. 
MOISTURE SLIPS TO THE SOUTH LATE SATURDAY THEN COMES BACK OVER
THE CWA SUNDAY. WILL KEEP POPS GOING IN THE SOUTHEAST THROUGH
THE PERIOD AND BRING POPS BACK INTO THE NORTHWEST ON SUNDAY. 
ANOTHER STRONG UPPER TROF ARRIVES MONDAY. THE BETTER DYNAMICS
WILL BE CLOSER TO THE AREA AND THIS SHOULD BRING A SIGNIFICANT 
COLD FRONT THROUGH ON MONDAY. DRIER AND COOLER AIR SHOULD MOVE
IN FOR ELECTION DAY. DID NOT MAKE SIGNIFICANT CHANGES TO THE 
GOING FORECAST FOR THIS TIME PERIOD. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    79  67  83  67 /  30  30  30  20 
HARRISON AR       75  63  79  66 /  40  40  40  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    80  67  83  67 /  30  30  30  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     80  66  83  66 /  30  30  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  75  63  79  65 /  40  40  40  20 
MONTICELLO AR     81  65  84  66 /  30  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         79  66  82  66 /  30  30  30  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      80  67  83  68 /  30  30  30  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   78  67  82  67 /  30  30  30  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

1010 PM CDT TUE OCT 26 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LATEST RUC AND 00Z M-ETA INDCG ADDITIONAL CONVECTION AFFECTING PARTS 
OF WRN AND NRN AR LATER TNGT INTO WED MRNG. DECIDED TO RAISE POPS 
INTO CHC CAT FOR ROUGHLY THE NWRN HALF OF THE FA OVERNIGHT. LOW 
TEMPS LOOK ON TRACK AND ONLY ADJUSTMENTS WERE TO THE HOURLY GRIDS TO 
FIT CURRENT TRENDS. REST OF FCST IN GREAT SHAPE. UPDATES ZNS AND 
GRIDS GONE.



969 
FXUS64 KLZK 261957
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
255 PM CDT TUE OCT 26 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
WARM FRONT LIFTED NORTH OF ARKANSAS THIS AFTERNOON...LEAVING ABOVE 
NORMAL TEMPERATURES AND HUMID AIRMASS. FOR THE MOST PART...AIRMASS 
WILL NOT CHANGE FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE SHORT TERM...WITH SMALL 
CHANCES FOR SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ACROSS THE REGION.

CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION WILL BE MOSTLY DUE TO STORM SYSTEM HEADING 
THROUGH MID-MISSISSIPPI AND OHIO VALLEYS...AND DRAGGING A COLD FRONT 
TOWARD ARKANSAS FROM THE NORTH LATE TONIGHT/WEDNESDAY. FRONT WILL 
INTERACT WITH SYSTEMS RIDING SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT...WITH HIGHEST 
CHANCES FOR RAIN NEAREST FRONT AS IT STALLS NEAR ARKANSAS/MISSOURI 
BORDER. 

VERY LITTLE CHANCE FOR PRECIPITATION THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS ACROSS 
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS AS RIDGE ALOFT STARTS BUILDING FROM GULF COAST 
REGION AND ATMOSPHERE STARTS CAPPING OFF. RIDGE BUILDING IN RESPONSE 
TO DEEPENING TROUGH IN THE ROCKIES.

TOWARD THE END OF THE WEEK...TROUGH TO THE WEST WILL EJECT AND WILL 
START FILLING. LOW PRESSURE IN PLAINS WILL DRAG A COLD FRONT TOWARD 
ARKANSAS. APPEARS THAT FRONT WILL STALL ACROSS THE STATE SATURDAY AS 
MAIN UPPER SUPPORT HEADS WELL TO THE NORTH. SOME COOLING  
BEHIND STALLED FRONT LATE IN THE SHORT TERM...MAINLY IN 
NORTHERN/CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE STATE. (46)        
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
FRONT WILL STALL IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO ARKANSAS. AM NOT CONFIDENT ON 
PLACEMENT AND TIMING...SO HAVE SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR SUNDAY. UPPER 
TROUGH AND COLD FRONT WILL MOVE INTO THE REGION MONDAY. HAVE ADDED 
CHANCE POPS TO THE FORECAST MONDAY...AND COULD SEE THEM GO EVEN 
HIGHER. TEMPS WILL BE NEAR NORMAL UNTIL MONDAY NIGHT...WHEN TEMPS 
FALL. (58)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    68  82  67  83 /  20  30  30  20 
HARRISON AR       63  75  63  79 /  40  40  40  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    68  82  67  83 /  30  30  30  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     68  82  66  83 /  20  30  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  64  75  63  79 /  40  40  40  40 
MONTICELLO AR     68  83  65  84 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         67  81  66  82 /  20  30  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      67  81  67  83 /  30  30  30  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   67  80  67  82 /  30  30  30  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&



522 
FXUS64 KLZK 260847
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT TUE OCT 26 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY
WARM FRONT APPEARS TO BE MOVING TO THE NORTH AS RIDGING ALOFT DEVELOPS
OVER THE AREA. THIS SHOULD PUSH THE MAIN MOISTURE AXIS TO THE NORTH 
AND BRING THE BEST CHANCE OF RAIN TO NORTHERN SECTIONS. STRONG TROPICAL
MOISTURE CONNECTION AIDED BY A TROPICAL DEPRESSION APPEARS TO BE 
SETTING UP FROM OFF THE WEST COAST OF MEXICO THROUGH MEXICO AND THE 
PLAINS BUT IT APPEARS THIS AXIS WILL REMAIN NORTH AND WEST OF THE 
CWA. SEVERAL WEAK SHORT WAVES WILL MOVE THROUGH THE AREA OVER THE 
NEXT FEW DAYS WITH WARM AND UNUSUALLY HUMID AIR FOR THE END OF 
OCTOBER IN PLACE. THE PRESENCE OF THE HEAVY MOISTURE WILL REQUIRE
POPS IN ALL AREAS BUT WILL GENERALLY GO ONLY 20 PERCENT IN THE 
SOUTH WHERE UPPER HEIGHTS ARE THE HIGHEST. THE HIGHEST POPS WILL
BE IN THE NORTH WITH LIKELY POPS FOR TODAY WHICH LOOKS GOOD BASED ON 
RADAR TRENDS. WILL DECREASE POPS INTO CHANCE RANGE TONIGHT INTO 
WEDNESDAY. A STRONG UPPER TROF WILL MOVE ACROSS THE PLAINS FRIDAY 
AND WILL BRING A COLD FRONT TOWARD THE AREA. WILL INCREASE POPS 
SOME ON FRIDAY DUE TO THIS. WINDS SHOULD INCREASE ACROSS THE 
AREA FRIDAY AS WELL. CONSIDERABLE CLOUDS SHOULD BE PRESENT THE NEXT 
THREE DAYS. THIS COULD PLAY HAVOC ON MAXES AND WILL GO ON THE COOL 
SIDE OF MOS ON MAXES TODAY BUT CLOSE TO MOS ON MAXES WEDNESDAY
THROUGH FRIDAY. MAXES SHOULD DEFINITELY BE LOWER IN THE NORTH WITH 
BETTER CHANCES OF RAIN. THE HIGH DEW POINTS SHOULD KEEP MINS WELL 
INTO THE 60S IN MOST AREAS.     
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
COLD FRONT WILL MOVE ACROSS THE AREA FRIDAY NIGHT AND SATURDAY WITH
A MODEST CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. DRIER AIR MOVES IN 
ON SATURDAY BUT WILL BE SHORT LIVED AS ANOTHER STRONG TROF DEVELOPS
TO THE WEST RESULTING IN A QUICK TURNAROUND TO RETURN FLOW. THIS 
MAY BRING THE FRONT BACK AS A WARM FRONT SUNDAY AND MOISTURE COVERS 
THE AREA AGAIN. APPEARS A STRONG COLD FRONT WILL MOVE ACROSS THE
AREA ON MONDAY. STRONG DYNAMICS WILL BE CLOSER TO THE AREA SO 
THE SYSTEM WILL HAVE TO BE WATCHED FOR THE POSSIBILITY OF SIGNIFICANT
SEVERE WEATHER. FOR NOW PUT IN SMALL POPS FOR SUNDAY NIGHT WITH 
POPS INCREASING TO CHANCE RANGE LATE SUNDAY NIGHT INTO MONDAY.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    80  67  82  67 /  30  30  30  30 
HARRISON AR       73  62  75  62 /  60  50  40  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    80  67  82  67 /  30  30  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     80  67  82  67 /  30  30  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  73  61  75  61 /  60  50  40  40 
MONTICELLO AR     81  68  83  68 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         77  66  80  66 /  40  40  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      79  66  81  66 /  30  30  30  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   76  65  79  65 /  40  40  30  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

THREE DAYS. THIS COULD PLAY HAVOC ON MAXES AND WILL GO ON THE COOL 
SIDE OF MOS ON MAXES TODAY BUT CLOSE TO MOS ON MAXES WEDNESDAY
THROUGH FRIDAY. MAXES SHOULD DEFINITELY BE LOWER IN THE NORTH WITH 
BETTER CHANCES OF RAIN. THE HIGH DEW POINTS SHOULD KEEP MINS WELL 
INTO THE 60S IN MOST AREAS.     
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
COLD FRONT WILL MOVE ACROSS THE AREA FRIDAY NIGHT AND SATURDAY WITH
A MODEST CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. DRIER AIR MOVES IN 
ON SATURDAY BUT WILL BE SHORT LIVED AS ANOTHER STRONG TROF DEVELOPS
TO THE WEST RESULTING IN A QUICK TURNAROUND TO RETURN FLOW. THIS 
MAY BRING THE FRONT BACK AS A WARM FRONT SUNDAY AND MOISTURE COVERS 
THE AREA AGAIN. APPEARS A STRONG COLD FRONT WILL MOVE ACROSS THE
AREA ON MONDAY. STRONG DYNAMICS WILL BE CLOSER TO THE AREA SO 
THE SYSTEM WILL HAVE TO BE WATCHED FOR THE POSSIBILITY OF SIGNIFICANT
SEVERE WEATHER. FOR NOW PUT IN SMALL POPS FOR SUNDAY NIGHT WITH 
POPS INCREASING TO CHANCE RANGE LATE SUNDAY NIGHT INTO MONDAY.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    80  67  82  67 /  30  30  30  30 
HARRISON AR       73  62  75  62 /  60  50  40  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    80  67  82  67 /  30  30  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     80  67  82  67 /  30  30  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  73  61  75  61 /  60  50  40  40 
MONTICELLO AR     81  68  83  68 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         77  66  80  66 /  40  40  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      79  66  81  66 /  30  30  30  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   76  65  79  65 /  40  40  30  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

FXUS64 KLZK 252025
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
325 PM CDT MON OCT 25 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
A WARM FRONT CONTINUES TO MOVE NORTH ACROSS ARKANSAS. THE FRONT WAS 
NEAR THE MISSOURI BORDER WITH MOIST AIR SOUTH OF IT AND DRIER AIR 
FURTHER NORTH. SCATTERED SHOWERS CONTINUE ACROSS ALL BUT WESTERN 
ARKANSAS. AN AREA OF UPPER HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUED OVER THE GULF OF 
MEXICO WITH ZONAL FLOW ACROSS ARKANSAS. SEVERAL SHORT WAVES WILL 
MOVE ACROSS THE STATE THIS WEEK AND BRING CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. IT LOOKS TO BE AN UNSETTLED WEATHER PATTERN THIS 
WEEK. THE GFS IS A BIT OVERZEALOUS WITH THE MOISTURE IN THE SHORT 
TERM. THE NGM AND ETA HAVE LOWER POPS AND WILL STAY CLOSE TO THE ETA 
AS FAR AS POPS GO. WILL KEEP LIKELY IN FOR TONIGHT ALL AREAS AND 
KEEP LIKELY IN THE NORTH FOR TUESDAY. CHANCES OF RAIN WILL CONTINUE 
THROUGH THURSDAY. WITH SOUTHERLY WINDS...TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN 
ABOVE NORMAL FOR THIS TIME OF YEAR.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
A STATIONARY FRONT TO OUR WEST THROUGH OKLAHOMA WILL MOVE THROUGH 
ARKANSAS FRIDAY NIGHT AND SATURDAY. THIS WILL BRING ANOTHER CHANCE 
OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. HOWEVER...HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD IN 
BEHIND THE FRONT AND BRING DRY WEATHER TO THE SECOND HALF OF THE 
WEEKEND. TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN ABOVE NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    65  80  64  80 /  60  40  40  40 
HARRISON AR       61  73  61  75 /  60  60  60  40

PINE BLUFF AR     65  80  66  80 /  60  40  30  30

MOUNT IDA AR      65  79  65  79 /  60  40  40  30

.DISCUSSION...

REMAIN IN OKLAHOMA. ABUNDANT CLOUDS ARE OVER MUCH OF THE AREA THIS

UPDATE TO INCREASE CLOUD COVER IN MOST AREAS. ALSO ADJUSTED 
TEMPERATURES FOR CURRENT TRENDS. ISOLATED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
MOVED THROUGH THE AREA THIS MORNING. POPS LOOK GOOD FOR THIS 
AFTERNOON WITH THE HIGHEST CHANCES IN THE SOUTH AND LOWER CHANCES IN 
THE NORTH.

047 
FXUS64 KLZK 250848
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT MON OCT 25 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY
RETURN FLOW STARTING UP AND THE RESULTING WARM ADVECTION AND 
ISENTROPIC LIFT HAVE RESULTED IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF SOME ELEVATED 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. SOME WERE NEAR THE SOUTHERN EDGES OF THE
CWA AROUND MIDNIGHT WHICH DISSIPATED AND SOME NEW ACTIVITY HAS 
DEVELOPED IN EASTERN OKLAHOMA JUST BEFORE ISSUE TIME. FRONTAL BOUNDARY
TO THE SOUTH IS RATHER DIFFUSE BUT IT MAY MOVE A LITTLE NORTH AS
A WARM FRONT TODAY. WOULD EXPECT SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO 
INCREASE DURING THE MORNING AND HAVE POPS INCREASING THROUGH 
CHANCE CATEGORY. THE WARM FRONT MAY MOVE ACROSS THE AREA TONIGHT
WITH A WEAK SHORT WAVE SUPPORTING IT AND WENT WITH LIKELY POPS 
IN MOST AREAS. AS UPPER RIDGING INCREASES TUESDAY INTO LATER IN 
THE WEEK...THE MAIN MOISTURE AXIS SHIFTS INTO NORTHERN SECTIONS. 
HAVE THE HIGHEST POPS IN THE NORTH TAPERING DOWN TO THE SOUTH. 
AXIS OF SUBTROPICAL MOISTURE FROM THE PACIFIC SETS UP ACROSS 
THE SOUTHERN PLAINS AND IT MAY EXTEND INTO NORTHERN ARKANSAS.
THIS AREA WILL NEED TO BE MONITORED FOR HEAVY RAINS TUESDAY INTO
WEDNESDAY. LOWERED POPS SOME MORE FOR THURSDAY AS STRONGER RIDGING
ALOFT MOVES IN AHEAD OF A STRONG TROF TO THE WEST WHICH WILL
BRING A COLD FRONT TOWARD THE AREA. MAX TEMP FORECASTS WILL BE
TRICKY DUE TO CLOUD COVER. GENERALLY WENT CLOSER TO THE COOLER 
MOS MAXES. MINS SHOULD STAY UP MOSTLY IN THE 60S DUE TO THE HUMID
AIR IN PLACE AND TENDED TO GO A LITTLE ABOVE MOS THERE.      
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
UPPER TROF LIFTS OFF TO THE NORTHEAST BUT SHOULD BE ENOUGH TO BRING A
COLD FRONT ACROSS THE AREA FRIDAY INTO SATURDAY. PATTERN LOOKS 
SIMILAR TO THIS PAST FRIDAY AND SATURDAY. HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN
AFTER THAT WITH ANOTHER FRONT APPROACHING LATE SUNDAY. EXTENDED 
FORECAST GENERALLY LOOKS GOOD AND ONLY MINOR CHANGES WERE MADE. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    79  65  79  65 /  40  60  50  40 
HARRISON AR       77  60  73  60 /  30  60  60  60 
HOT SPRINGS AR    80  65  80  65 /  40  60  50  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     80  65  80  65 /  40  60  50  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  76  59  73  60 /  20  60  60  60 
MONTICELLO AR     80  65  81  65 /  50  60  40  20 
SEARCY AR         77  61  77  63 /  30  60  60  50 
MOUNT IDA AR      80  65  79  64 /  40  60  50  40



938 
FXUS64 KLZK 241920
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
220 PM CDT SUN OCT 24 2004

SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT...
ALL MEDIUM RANGES MODELS IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH NO MAJOR 
DIFFERENCES NOTED. ALL MODELS ARE TRENDING STRONGER AND A LITTLE 
FASTER WITH THE NEXT UPPER LEVEL SYSTEM APPROACHING THE WEST COAST 
IN THE MIDDLE OF THE WEEK. AS SUCH WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF FORECAST 
SOLUTIONS THIS AFTERNOON WITH A LEAN TOWARDS THE MORE CONSISTENT 
GFS.

LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES WEAK FRONT SOMEWHERE OVER EXTREME 
SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS AND THROUGH NORTHERN LOUISIANA. THIS BOUNDARY 
WILL BEGIN TO LIFT TOWARDS THE NORTH TONIGHT IN RESPONSE TO 
DEVELOPING WARM AIR ADVECTION PATTERN. SURFACE HIGH RESPONSIBLE FOR 
THE PLEASANT WEATHER ON SUNDAY MOVES TO THE EAST AND RETURN FLOW 
GETS REESTABLISHED. ADVANCING FRONT WILL ACT AS A FOCUSING MECHANISM 
FOR SHOWER AND THUNDERSTORM DEVELOPMENT.

DENSE FOG DEVELOPED OVER THE AREA LAST NIGHT WITH IDEAL RADIATIONAL 
COOLING CONDITIONS. WILL ADD SOME PATCHY FOG TO THE ZONES/GRIDS FOR 
TONIGHT BUT DO NOT BELIEVE IT WILL BE AS WIDESPREAD AND DENSE AS 
THIS MORNING. SHOWERS WILL BE POSSIBLE LATE TONIGHT OVER THE SOUTH 
AS FRONT LIFTS NORTH WITH RAIN CHANCES ADVANCING NORTH DURING THE 
DAY. ONLY CHANCE POPS ARE JUSTIFIED AT THIS POINT. SEVERAL WEAK 
WAVES WILL RIPPLE THROUGH THE SOUTHWEST FLOW. ONE SUCH WAVE COMES 
THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT AND WILL BE AIDED BY AN APPROACHING COLD FRONT. 
CURRENT PACKAGE HAS HIGH POPS IN THE IN THE MONDAY NIGHT TIME FRAME 
AND SEE NO REASON TO ARGUE.

AMPLIFICATION OF THE OVERALL PATTERN LIKELY OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS. 
STRONG UPPER LOW APPROACHES THE WEST COAST ON TUESDAY WITH STRONG 
SHORTWAVE ENERGY UNDER CUTTING IT CARVING OUT A LARGE WESTERN TROF. 
UPPER RIDGE CENTERED IN THE CENTRAL GULF EXPANDS NORTHWARD IN 
RESPONSE WITH RELATIVELY MOIST AND UNSTABLE AIRMASS IN PLACE. 
PLACEMENT OF THE MAJOR FEATURES WILL KEEP THE AREA IN A PERSISTENT 
SOUTHWEST FLOW THROUGH THE PERIOD. MODELS CONTINUE TO MOVE NUMEROUS 
SHORTWAVES THROUGH HE MEAN FLOW. ONE SUCH WAVE MOVES THROUGH ON 
TUESDAY. AS RIDGE BUILDS THE WAVES ARE SHUNTED EVER SO SLIGHTLY TO 
THE NORTHWEST AND IT APPEARS THIS IS WHERE THE BEST CHANCES OF 
PRECIPITATION WILL BE. WAVES ALSO FORECAST TO MOVE THROUGH ON 
WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. BOTTOM LINE IS AN UNSETTLED FORECAST WITH 
POPS LIKELY THROUGHOUT...HIGHER TO THE NORTHWEST.

TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO BE ABOVE SEASONABLE NORMS WITH 
PERSISTENT SOUTHWEST FLOW. TEMPERATURES WILL AVERAGE 5 TO 8 DEGREES 
ABOVE NORMAL THROUGHOUT THE PERIOD IN SPITE OF CLOUD COVER AND 
SCATTERED PRECIPITATION. FWC NUMBERS GENERALLY WARMER THAN ITS MAV 
COUNTERPART BUT MAY BE A LITTLE OVERDONE. WILL SPLIT THE DIFFERENCES 
BETWEEN THE MAV/FWC NUMBERS.
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY...
ONCE MORE WE HAVE AN UPPER LEVEL SYSTEM THAT WEAKENS AS IT MOVES TO 
THE NORTHEAST AWAY FROM THE STATE...LEAVING A WEAKENED SHORT WAVE TO 
PUSH THE SURFACE SYSTEM. THE SURFACE WILL HAVE A SLOW-MOVING SLUG OF 
MOISTURE FROM NORTHWEST TO SOUTHEAST FRIDAY THROUGH SATURDAY. THEN 
DRYING WILL TAKE PLACE OVERNIGHT SATURDAY WITH A QUICK RETURN OF 
MOISTURE FROM THE SOUTHWEST POISED TO MOVE ACROSS THE STATE JUST 
BEYOND THIS FORECAST PERIOD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    56  79  62  78 /  20  40  60  40 
HARRISON AR       51  77  59  75 /  10  30  60  50 
HOT SPRINGS AR    57  80  63  80 /  20  40  60  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     57  80  62  79 /  20  40  60  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  51  76  58  74 /  10  20  60  50 
MONTICELLO AR     58  80  63  80 /  30  40  60  30 
SEARCY AR         54  77  60  75 /  10  30  60  50 
MOUNT IDA AR      57  80  63  80 /  20  40  60  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   54  79  62  77 /  20  40  60  40 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

COOLING CONDITIONS. WILL ADD SOME PATCHY FOG TO THE ZONES/GRIDS FOR 
TONIGHT BUT DO NOT BELIEVE IT WILL BE AS WIDESPREAD AND DENSE AS 
THIS MORNING. SHOWERS WILL BE POSSIBLE LATE TONIGHT OVER THE SOUTH 
AS FRONT LIFTS NORTH WITH RAIN CHANCES ADVANCING NORTH DURING THE 
DAY. ONLY CHANCE POPS ARE JUSTIFIED AT THIS POINT. SEVERAL WEAK 
WAVES WILL RIPPLE THROUGH THE SOUTHWEST FLOW. ONE SUCH WAVE COMES 
THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT AND WILL BE AIDED BY AN APPROACHING COLD FRONT. 
CURRENT PACKAGE HAS HIGH POPS IN THE IN THE MONDAY NIGHT TIME FRAME 
AND SEE NO REASON TO ARGUE.

AMPLIFICATION OF THE OVERALL PATTERN LIKELY OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS. 
STRONG UPPER LOW APPROACHES THE WEST COAST ON TUESDAY WITH STRONG 
SHORTWAVE ENERGY UNDER CUTTING IT CARVING OUT A LARGE WESTERN TROF. 
UPPER RIDGE CENTERED IN THE CENTRAL GULF EXPANDS NORTHWARD IN 
RESPONSE WITH RELATIVELY MOIST AND UNSTABLE AIRMASS IN PLACE. 
PLACEMENT OF THE MAJOR FEATURES WILL KEEP THE AREA IN A PERSISTENT 
SOUTHWEST FLOW THROUGH THE PERIOD. MODELS CONTINUE TO MOVE NUMEROUS 
SHORTWAVES THROUGH HE MEAN FLOW. ONE SUCH WAVE MOVES THROUGH ON 
TUESDAY. AS RIDGE BUILDS THE WAVES ARE SHUNTED EVER SO SLIGHTLY TO 
THE NORTHWEST AND IT APPEARS THIS IS WHERE THE BEST CHANCES OF 
PRECIPITATION WILL BE. WAVES ALSO FORECAST TO MOVE THROUGH ON 
WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. BOTTOM LINE IS AN UNSETTLED FORECAST WITH 
POPS LIKELY THROUGHOUT...HIGHER TO THE NORTHWEST.

TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO BE ABOVE SEASONABLE NORMS WITH 
PERSISTENT SOUTHWEST FLOW. TEMPERATURES WILL AVERAGE 5 TO 8 DEGREES 
ABOVE NORMAL THROUGHOUT THE PERIOD IN SPITE OF CLOUD COVER AND 
SCATTERED PRECIPITATION. FWC NUMBERS GENERALLY WARMER THAN ITS MAV 
COUNTERPART BUT MAY BE A LITTLE OVERDONE. WILL SPLIT THE DIFFERENCES 
BETWEEN THE MAV/FWC NUMBERS.
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY...
ONCE MORE WE HAVE AN UPPER LEVEL SYSTEM THAT WEAKENS AS IT MOVES TO 
THE NORTHEAST AWAY FROM THE STATE...LEAVING A WEAKENED SHORT WAVE TO 
PUSH THE SURFACE SYSTEM. THE SURFACE WILL HAVE A SLOW-MOVING SLUG OF 
MOISTURE FROM NORTHWEST TO SOUTHEAST FRIDAY THROUGH SATURDAY. THEN 
DRYING WILL TAKE PLACE OVERNIGHT SATURDAY WITH A QUICK RETURN OF 
MOISTURE FROM THE SOUTHWEST POISED TO MOVE ACROSS THE STATE JUST 
BEYOND THIS FORECAST PERIOD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    56  79  62  78 /  20  40  60  40 
HARRISON AR       51  77  59  75 /  10  30  60  50 
HOT SPRINGS AR    57  80  63  80 /  20  40  60  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     57  80  62  79 /  20  40  60  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  51  76  58  74 /  10  20  60  50 
MONTICELLO AR     58  80  63  80 /  30  40  60  30 
SEARCY AR         54  77  60  75 /  10  30  60  50 
MOUNT IDA AR      57  80  63  80 /  20  40  60  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   54  79  62  77 /  20  40  60  40 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56/32





589 
FXUS64 KLZK 241457
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
951 AM CDT SUN OCT 24 2004

.DISCUSSION...
JUST A QUICK UPDATE NEEDED THIS MORNING TO LET THE DENSE FOG 
ADVISORY EXPIRE. MOST OF THE FOG HAS BURNED OFF WITH THE EXCEPTION 
OF PARTS OF THE SOUTH. FOG NOT WIDESPREAD OR DENSE ENOUGH TO 
CONTINUE THE ADVISORY AND WILL COVER WHATS LEFT WITH NOWCASTS. WILL 
INCLUDE PATCHY FOG IN THE GRIDS/ZONES THROUGH NOON. OTHERWISE 
FORECAST LOOKS TO BE IN OUTSTANDING SHAPE FOR THE REST OF THE DAY. 
QUICK LOOK AT THE MODELS THIS MORNING SHOWS NEXT SYSTEM MAY BE A 
LITTLE QUICKER THAN PREVIOUS THINKING. WILL ADDRESS THIS CONCERN IN 
AFTERNOON PACKAGE.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
FOG HAS HAS BECOME MORE WIDESPREAD OVER MUCH OF THE FORECAST AREA 
BEFORE DAWN. ISSUED A DENSE FOG ADVISORY UNTIL MID MORNING FOR ALL 
BUT THE EXTREME NORTHERN SECTIONS. ALL UPDATES GONE.

COLD FRONT HAD PRETTY WELL MADE IT THROUGH ARKANSAS EARLY THIS 
MORNING. MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES IN MOST AREAS...BUT SOME FOG HAS 
DEVELOPED OVER CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN ARKANSAS EARLY THIS MORNING. PUT 
MENTION OF PATCHY FOG OVER THE CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN SECTIONS UNTIL 
MID MORNING...OTHERWISE THIS MORNING SHOULD BE MOSTLY SUNNY. 
MOISTURE WILL BEGIN TO SLOWLY RETURN FROM THE SOUTH BY THIS 
AFTERNOON AS FRONT STALLS OUT JUST SOUTH OF ARKANSAS. THUS...WILL 
SEE PARTLY CLOUDY CONDITIONS MOVING NORTHWARD THIS AFTERNOON. FRONT 
WILL BEGIN TO MOVE BACK NORTHWARD AS A WARM FRONT TONIGHT. PUT SMALL 
CHANCES OF RAINFALL OVER THE SOUTH AFTER MIDNIGHT. THEN EXPECT 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ON MONDAY. MONDAY NIGHT SHOULD 
SEE HEAVIEST RAINFALL AS MOISTURE INCREASES AND ANOTHER COLD FRONT 
APPROACHES FROM THE NORTHWEST. WENT WITH LIKELY POPS AREA WIDE 
MONDAY NIGHT...THEN DROPPING BACK TO A CHANCE ON TUESDAY. KEPT SMALL 
POPS IN FOR WEDNESDAY AS AREA REMAINS UNDER SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW ALOFT 
AND CONTINUING SERIES OF H5 SHORT WAVES AFFECT US.  

UNSETTLED PATTERN CONTINUES WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY WITH 
CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS EACH DAY. TEMPERATURES WILL BE 
NEAR OR A LITTLE ABOVE NORMAL.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

22/38






936 
FXUS64 KLZK 231906
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
204 PM CDT SAT OCT 23 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT...
MODELS ARE CONTINUING THEIR RECENT TREND OF SLOWING DOWN THE 
ADVANCING H5 TROF. SHORT TERM MODELS ARE ALL SLIGHTLY FURTHER NORTH 
WITH THE PLACEMENT OF THE TROF VERSUS PREVIOUS RUNS. GFS A LITTLE 
STRONGER VERSUS ITS ETA COUNTER PART FROM THIS TIME YESTERDAY BUT 
ACTUALLY SEEMS TO BE A BETTER FIT. WITH THE GFS BEING THE PREFERRED 
SOLUTION OF LATE...SEE NO REASON TO DIFFER FROM IT. MESO-ETA ALSO 
HANDLING THE SITUATION WELL AND WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF THOSE TWO 
SOLUTIONS.

LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS IS SHOWING THE COLD FRONT HAS MADE VERY 
LITTLE EASTWARD PROGRESSION SINCE THIS MORNING. FRONT EXTENDS 
ROUGHLY FROM SPRINGFIELD TO TULSA AND POINTS SOUTH. WATER VAPOR 
IMAGERY STILL SHOWING THE SUBTROPICAL TAP WITH DRIER AIR TRYING TO 
WORK IN FROM THE WEST. ENTIRE SYSTEM SEEMS TO BE SLOWING UP WITH 
STRONG UPPER LEVEL HIGH SITTING IN THE GULF. FRONT NOT EXPECTED TO 
GET THROUGH THE METRO AREA BEFORE EARLY EVENING AND OUT OF THE 
SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE STATE UNTIL MIDNIGHT OR SO. 

SHOWERS AND A FEW THUNDERSTORMS CONTINUE OVER MAINLY THE SOUTHEAST 
ZONES WHERE DEEPEST MOISTURE LIES. WEAK SHORTWAVE MOVING THROUGH 
THE MEAN FLOW ALSO HELPING THE PRECIP ALONG. WILL CARRY CHANCE POPS 
THROUGH EVENING HERE. MAIN TROF...CURRENTLY IN THE CENTRAL PLAINS... 
WILL MOVE NORTHEAST WITH AXIS PASSING OVERHEAD SOMETIME THIS EVENING 
BUT DRIER AIR SHOULD BE IN PLACE BY THAT TIME. WITH WIDESPREAD RAIN
LAST NIGHT SOME FOG FORMATION A CONCERN BUT ENOUGH GRADIENT WIND 
SHOULD PREVENT WIDESPREAD FORMATION. FRONT SETTLES ACROSS CENTRAL 
LOUISIANA ON SUNDAY WITH WEAK RIDGING AND SURFACE HIGH WELL IN 
CONTROL.

FRONT WILL BEGIN TO MOVE BACK TO THE NORTH SUNDAY NIGHT AS A WARM 
FRONT. SURFACE HIGH SLIPS OFF TO THE EAST AND RETURN FLOW GETS 
REESTABLISHED. AS SOUTHWEST LOW LEVEL JET AND WARM AIR ADVECTION 
PATTERN COMMENCES MONDAY...SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE 
POSSIBLE MAINLY OVER THE SOUTHERN THIRD OF THE AREA. PRECIP CHANCES 
WILL EXPAND NORTHWARD MONDAY NIGHT AND INTO TUESDAY AS SOUTHWEST 
FLOW INCREASES WITH UPPER HIGH IN THE GULF ONCE AGAIN GAINING 
STRENGTH. SEVERAL SHORTWAVES TRAVERSE THE AREA WITH BEST RAIN 
CHANCES APPEARING TO BE OVER THE NORTHWEST HALF OF THE STATE. 

PERSISTENT PATTERN OF WESTERN CONUS TROFFING AND EASTERN CONUS 
RIDGING GETS REESTABLISHED ONCE AGAIN BY THE END OF THE PERIOD. WITH 
CENTER OF THE RIDGE OFF THE GULF COAST...MAJORITY OF THE SHORT WAVE 
ENERGY SHOULD STAY TO THE NORTHWEST OF THE CWA. CHANCE OR SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS STILL WARRANTED ON WEDNESDAY AND WEDNESDAY NIGHT WITH 
INCREASING MOISTURE AND ANOTHER WEAK WARM FRONT MOVING THROUGH THE 
AREA IN ADVANCE OF THE DIGGING WESTERN TROF.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...WITH CONTINUED SOUTHWEST FLOW TEMPERATURES 
WILL BE A FEW DEGREES ABOVE SEASONABLE NORMS IN SPITE OF WIDESPREAD 
CLOUDS AND OCCASIONAL PERIODS OF PRECIPITATION. FWC/MAV NUMBERS ARE 
IN GENERALLY GOOD AGREEMENT AND WILL GO WITH A BLEND.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY...
THE PATTERN CONTINUES ITS TREND TO GO FROM SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW ALOFT 
ON THURSDAY TO ZONAL FLOW FRIDAY NIGHT...AND BACK TO REBUILDING OF 
THE RIDGE OVER ARKANSAS. PRECIPITATION WILL BE MOVING FROM NORTHWEST 
TO SOUTHEAST ACROSS ARKANSAS THURSDAY AND FRIDAY. THEN A RIDGE OF 
PACIFIC ORIGIN WILL MOVE OVER THE STATE...DRYING THE REMAINDER OF 
THE LONG TERM FORECAST. LOWERED TEMPERATURES IN LIGHT OF THE COOL 
AIR MOVING DOWN WITH THE PACIFIC HIGH AND THE LOWER HUMIDITIES. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    51  79  58  77 /  10  10  20  30 
HARRISON AR       44  77  55  77 /  10  10  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    52  79  59  77 /  10  10  20  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     53  79  59  77 /  20  10  20  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  44  77  55  77 /  10  10  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     54  80  60  77 /  30  10  20  40 
SEARCY AR         49  78  57  76 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      52  79  59  78 /  10  10  20  40 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   49  78  57  77 /  10  10  20  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

BUT DRIER AIR SHOULD BE IN PLACE BY THAT TIME. WITH WIDESPREAD RAIN
LAST NIGHT SOME FOG FORMATION A CONCERN BUT ENOUGH GRADIENT WIND 
SHOULD PREVENT WIDESPREAD FORMATION. FRONT SETTLES ACROSS CENTRAL 
LOUISIANA ON SUNDAY WITH WEAK RIDGING AND SURFACE HIGH WELL IN 
CONTROL.

FRONT WILL BEGIN TO MOVE BACK TO THE NORTH SUNDAY NIGHT AS A WARM 
FRONT. SURFACE HIGH SLIPS OFF TO THE EAST AND RETURN FLOW GETS 
REESTABLISHED. AS SOUTHWEST LOW LEVEL JET AND WARM AIR ADVECTION 
PATTERN COMMENCES MONDAY...SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE 
POSSIBLE MAINLY OVER THE SOUTHERN THIRD OF THE AREA. PRECIP CHANCES 
WILL EXPAND NORTHWARD MONDAY NIGHT AND INTO TUESDAY AS SOUTHWEST 
FLOW INCREASES WITH UPPER HIGH IN THE GULF ONCE AGAIN GAINING 
STRENGTH. SEVERAL SHORTWAVES TRAVERSE THE AREA WITH BEST RAIN 
CHANCES APPEARING TO BE OVER THE NORTHWEST HALF OF THE STATE. 

PERSISTENT PATTERN OF WESTERN CONUS TROFFING AND EASTERN CONUS 
RIDGING GETS REESTABLISHED ONCE AGAIN BY THE END OF THE PERIOD. WITH 
CENTER OF THE RIDGE OFF THE GULF COAST...MAJORITY OF THE SHORT WAVE 
ENERGY SHOULD STAY TO THE NORTHWEST OF THE CWA. CHANCE OR SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS STILL WARRANTED ON WEDNESDAY AND WEDNESDAY NIGHT WITH 
INCREASING MOISTURE AND ANOTHER WEAK WARM FRONT MOVING THROUGH THE 
AREA IN ADVANCE OF THE DIGGING WESTERN TROF.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...WITH CONTINUED SOUTHWEST FLOW TEMPERATURES 
WILL BE A FEW DEGREES ABOVE SEASONABLE NORMS IN SPITE OF WIDESPREAD 
CLOUDS AND OCCASIONAL PERIODS OF PRECIPITATION. FWC/MAV NUMBERS ARE 
IN GENERALLY GOOD AGREEMENT AND WILL GO WITH A BLEND.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY...
THE PATTERN CONTINUES ITS TREND TO GO FROM SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW ALOFT 
ON THURSDAY TO ZONAL FLOW FRIDAY NIGHT...AND BACK TO REBUILDING OF 
THE RIDGE OVER ARKANSAS. PRECIPITATION WILL BE MOVING FROM NORTHWEST 
TO SOUTHEAST ACROSS ARKANSAS THURSDAY AND FRIDAY. THEN A RIDGE OF 
PACIFIC ORIGIN WILL MOVE OVER THE STATE...DRYING THE REMAINDER OF 
THE LONG TERM FORECAST. LOWERED TEMPERATURES IN LIGHT OF THE COOL 
AIR MOVING DOWN WITH THE PACIFIC HIGH AND THE LOWER HUMIDITIES. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    51  79  58  77 /  10  10  20  30 
HARRISON AR       44  77  55  77 /  10  10  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    52  79  59  77 /  10  10  20  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     53  79  59  77 /  20  10  20  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  44  77  55  77 /  10  10  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     54  80  60  77 /  30  10  20  40 
SEARCY AR         49  78  57  76 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      52  79  59  78 /  10  10  20  40 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   49  78  57  77 /  10  10  20  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

56/32






829 
FXUS64 KLZK 231459
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1000 AM CDT SAT OCT 23 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATE ON THE WAY THIS MORNING. LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES COLD 
FRONT WELL OFF TO THE NORTHWEST OF THE AREA AND MAKING ONLY SLOW 
PROGRESS AGAINST UPPER LEVEL RIDGING CENTERED IN THE GULF OF MEXICO.
FRONT CURRENTLY EXTENDS FROM NORTHWEST MISSOURI TO SOUTHEAST KANSAS 
TO CENTRAL OKLAHOMA. WATER VAPOR IMAGERY CONTINUES TO SHOW GOOD 
TROPICAL CONNECTION ALL THE WAY TO THE BAJA BUT DRIER AIR IS ALSO 
VERY EVIDENT JUST TO THE WEST OF THE SURFACE BOUNDARY.

VISIBLE SATELLITE SHOWING SKIES ALREADY STARTING TO BREAK UP OVER 
NORTHWEST ARKANSAS. LAST OF THE ORGANIZED PRECIP NOW ENTERING 
NORTHEAST ARKANSAS WITH JUST SCATTERED PRECIP OVER THE REMAINDER OF 
THE AREA. NEW MESO ETA SEEMS TO HAVE A VERY GOOD HANDLE ON THE 
SITUATION THIS MORNING AND ADVANCES THE DRIER AIR SOUTHWARD THROUGH 
THE CWA THIS AFTERNOON. FRONT BARELY CLEARS THE METRO AREA BY THIS 
EVENING AND DOES NOT EXIT THE STATE UNTIL SUNDAY MORNING.

UPDATE WILL REMOVE POPS FROM THE WEST AND NORTHWEST AREAS AND GO 
WITH A DECREASING TREND ELSEWHERE. WILL HOLD ONTO POPS OVER THE 
SOUTHEAST AND EAST CENTRAL ZONES FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE DAY WITH 
SHORTWAVE ENERGY COMING ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST PART OF THE STATE. 
LARGE AREA OF RAIN OVER EASTERN TEXAS AND NORTHERN LOUISIANA 
ASSOCIATED WITH THAT ENERGY ADVANCING TOWARDS SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS. 
CLOUD COVER WILL ALSO NEED TO BE TWEAKED AND TEMPERATURES LOWERED 
ACROSS THE BOARD BASED ON CURRENT TRENDS AND SLOWER THAN EXPECTED 
MOVEMENT OF THE FRONT.

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

007 
FXUS64 KLZK 230933
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
430 AM CDT SAT OCT 23 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY
LINE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS HAS MOVED ACROSS MUCH OF THE 
FORECAST AREA OVERNIGHT. LINE WAS OVER EASTERN ARKANSAS BEFORE DAWN. 
ADDITIONAL AREAS OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL OCCUR OVER THE 
AREA THIS MORNING...THEN TAPER OFF. COLD FRONT SHOULD MOVE ACROSS 
THE AREA TODAY...WITH DRIER AIR MOVING IN BEHIND IT. EXPECT MOSTLY 
CLEAR CONDITIONS OVER THE AREA BY TONIGHT. MOISTURE BEGINS TO RETURN 
NORTHWARD BY SUNDAY AFTERNOON. INCLUDED SMALL CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS SUNDAY NIGHT INTO MONDAY. GFS BLOWING UP LARGE AREA OF 
HEAVY RAINFALL OVER NORTHERN ARKANSAS MONDAY NIGHT/TUESDAY MORNING 
TIMEFRAME. AT THIS TIME...IT LOOKS A LITTLE OVERDONE. DID INCREASE 
POPS OVER THE NORTH MONDAY NIGHT AND TUESDAY...AND WILL SEE HOW 
LATER MODEL RUNS HANDLE IT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY 
BY EARLY TUESDAY NIGHT...AN H5 HIGH WILL BE CENTERED OVER THE GULF 
OF MEXICO...WITH A RIDGE EXTENDING FROM THIS CENTER TOWARDS THE OHIO 
VALLEY. THIS COUPLE WITH A AN UPPER LEVEL TROF OVER THE WESTERN U.S. 
WILL RESULT IN A SOUTHWESTERLY UPPER LEVEL FLOW OVER ARKANSAS...WITH 
A SERIES OF VORT MAXES RIDING ACROSS TEXAS AND INTO ARKANSAS. THIS 
PATTERN WILL BRING ABOUT SMALL CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
TO MUCH OF ARKANSAS TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY.  TEMPERATURES WILL 
GENERALLY CONTINUE ON THE MILD SIDE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    80  52  78  56 /  60  10  10  20 
HARRISON AR       76  45  76  53 /  30  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    80  53  78  57 /  60  10  10  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     80  54  78  57 /  70  10  10  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  75  45  76  53 /  40  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     80  55  79  58 /  70  10  10  20 
SEARCY AR         77  50  77  55 /  70  10  10  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      80  53  78  57 /  50  10  10  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   79  50  77  55 /  50  10  10  20

704 
FXUS64 KLZK 230211 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
910 PM CDT FRI OCT 22 2004

.DISCUSSION...
ISSUED AN UPDATE TO TEXT FORECASTS A LITTLE WHILE AGO. WHILE AN 
ISOLATED STRONG STORM OVER THE AREA IS NOT OUT OF THE QUESTION 
TONIGHT...HAVE SERIOUSLY DOWNPLAYED SEVERE WEATHER THREAT. AREA 
REALLY DIDNT BREAK OUT OF THE CLOUDS MUCH TODAY...WHICH SERIOUSLY 
PUT A LID ON SIGNIFICANT WARMING. 00Z LZK SOUNDING STILL SHOWING A 
CAP BETWEEN 750 AND 800 MB. WILL CONTINUE TO HIGHLIGHT IN THE 
HAZARDOUS WEATHER OUTLOOK.

AXIS OF HEAVIER RAINFALL WILL SHIFT EASTWARD OVERNIGHT...FOCUSING 
MORE ON CENTRAL AND EASTERN ARKANSAS BY SATURDAY MORNING. STRONG 
STORM OR TWO OVER EASTERN ARKANSAS ON SATURDAY WOULDNT BE TOTALLY 
OUT OF THE QUESTION...THOUGH IT WILL LARGELY DEPEND ON THE AMOUNT OF 
HEATING OVER THAT AREA DURING THE DAY. 

AS FAR AS TEMPERATURES GO...FORECASTED MINS LOOK TO BE REASONABLE AT 
THIS TIME. HAVE REALIGNED POPS A BIT...TRENDING HEAVIER POPS A 
LITTLE SLOWER EASTWARD DURING THE NIGHT. HAVE DROPPED SEVERE 
MENTION...AND REALIGNED ZONE GROUPS. HAVE ALSO ADJUSTED OTHER 
PARAMETERS BASED ON CURRENT WEATHER TRENDS. 

UPDATED TEXT FORECASTS HAVE BEEN SENT...GRAPHICS AND GRIDS ARE 
UPDATING RIGHT NOW...AND TABULAR PRODUCTS WILL BE SENT SHORTLY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

57





481 
FXUS64 KLZK 221927
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 PM CDT FRI OCT 22 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
WATER VAPOR LOOP SHOWS THAT THE UPPER PATTERN CONTINUES TO EVOLVE AS 
SHOWN BY PREVIOUS RUNS. RIDGE IS OFFERING RESISTANCE TO THE STRONG 
LOW COMING ACROSS THE ROCKIES INTO THE CENTRAL PLAINS. EVEN WITH THE 
MAIN LOW CUTTING ACROSS THE NORTHERN GREAT LAKES AREAS...THERE WILL 
BE A SIGNIFICANT LOBE OF ENERGY TO PUSH ACROSS AR AND OK FOR THE 
WEEK END. SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL RETURN TO OUR AREA AFTER A BRIEF 
PERIOD OF ZONAL FLOW AND AS THE RIDGE AMPLIFIES ONCE MORE IN ADVANCE 
OF THE NEXT SYSTEM. THE SURFACE PATTERN STILL HAS A DRY RIDGE MOVING 
ACROSS ARKANSAS AFTER SATURDAYS FRONTAL PASSAGE. SURFACE HIGH WILL 
REGAIN ITS STRENGTH AS A REFLECTION OF THE UPPER RIDGE. THIS WILL 
RESULT IN POOL OF MOISTURE MOVING BACK OVER AR FROM THE SOUTHWEST 
FOR MONDAY AND TUESDAY. PRECIPITATION WILL NEVER BE TO FAR FROM OUR 
WESTERN BORDER...SO A WET PATTERN WILL PERSIST BEYOND TUESDAY NIGHT.
TEMPERATURES WILL BE DIFFICULT IN LIGHT OF UPCOMING RAINFALL AND 
FRONT. FORECAST WILL TEND TO HAVE COOLER HIGHS FOR THE FIRST PART OF 
THE WEEK END UNTIL THE DRY AIR GETS HERE FOR SUNDAY WHEN THERE WILL 
BE WIDER DIURNAL FLUCTUATIONS. LOWS WILL BE KEPT WARM TONIGHT BY 
HIGH DEW POINTS...THEN DRIER AIR WILL ALLOW RADIATIONAL COOLING. 
RAIN CHANCES WILL BE CATEGORICAL ACROSS THE NORTH TONIGHT AND TAPER 
TO LIKELY OVER THE CENTRAL SECTIONS AND A GOOD CHANCE SOUTH. THEN 
RAIN CHANCES WILL BE HIGHER OVER THE SOUTH SATURDAY AND DECREASE 
NORTHWARD. SUNDAY WILL HAVE A DRY FORECAST. RAIN TO RETURN OVERNIGHT 
SUNDAY FROM THE SOUTHWEST AND IT WILL LINGER INTO TUESDAY IN 
SCATTERED FASHION. INITIALLY I HAD EXPECTED OVER-RUNNING RAINS ONLY 
FOR MONDAY...BUT THERE MAY BE ENOUGH ELEVATED INSTABILITY TO CREATE 
SOME CONVECTIVE ACTIVITY...SO WILL STICK WITH CONVECTION.
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
MODELS ARE IN MUCH BETTER AGREEMENT THIS AFTERNOON VERSUS THIS TIME 
YESTERDAY. WHILE GFS HAS BEEN HOLDING SERVE AND CHANGING VERY 
LITTLE...THE OTHER MEDIUM RANGE MODELS HAVE BEEN WAFFLING SOMEWHAT. 
IT APPEARS THAT WHILE THE OTHER MODELS ARE NOW ON THE SAME PAGE AS 
THE GFS...THEY HAVE BEEN PLAYING CATCH UP. ALL THAT BEING SAID...THE 
GFS SOLUTION SEEMS TO BE THE BEST WAY TO GO.

OVERALL PATTERN SHOULD BE FAIRLY ACTIVE WITH PERSISTENT WESTERN 
CONUS TROFFING AND RIDGING ALONG THE CENTRAL GULF COAST. PLENTY OF 
GULF MOISTURE COMING UP WHICH IS AIDED BY A SURFACE HIGH OVER THE 
NORTHERN LAKES. MODELS CARRY A WARM FRONT THROUGH THE AREA IN THE 
LATE TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY TIME FRAME SO POPS FROM TUESDAY 
NIGHT WILL BE EXTENDED. ONCE THE FRONT MOVES THROUGH...A FEW WEAK 
SHORTWAVES WILL MOVE THROUGH IN THE RESULTANT SOUTHWEST FLOW FOR A 
CONTINUATION OF SCATTERED POPS. STRONG SHORTWAVE MOVES INTO THE 
DESERT SOUTHWEST THURSDAY. SYSTEM FLATTENS OUT THE RIDGE SOMEWHAT 
BUT A CONTINUATION OF SCATTERED POPS IS WARRANTED. A BROAD WESTERN 
CONUS TROF FOR FRIDAY WILL MAINTAIN THE SOUTHWEST FLOW OVER THE 
AREA. A SURFACE LOW MOVING THROUGH THE WESTERN LAKES WILL DRAG A 
COLD FRONT THROUGH FRIDAY FOR EVEN MORE UNSETTLED WEATHER.

WITH SOUTHERLY FLOW IN PLACE TEMPERATURES WILL BE A FEW DEGREES 
ABOVE SEASONABLE NORMS...DESPITE THE SHOWERY AND CLOUDY CONDITIONS 
EXPECTED. MEX NUMBERS IN GOOD AGREEMENT AND HAVE GENERALLY BEEN 
CONSISTENT SO THEY WILL BE FOLLOWED FAIRLY CLOSELY.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    79  65  80  54 /  20  80  60  10 
HARRISON AR       76  63  76  49 /  60  90  20  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    80  66  81  54 /  30  80  40  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     80  66  80  55 /  20  70  70  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  76  63  76  49 /  50  90  30  10 
MONTICELLO AR     80  67  80  57 /  10  80  70  10 
SEARCY AR         78  64  78  52 /  20  80  60  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      80  67  81  54 /  40  80  30  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   79  65  79  52 /  50  80  30  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

MOUNTAIN HOME AR  76  63  76  49 /  50  90  30  10 
MONTICELLO AR     80  67  80  57 /  10  80  70  10 
SEARCY AR         78  64  78  52 /  20  80  60  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      80  67  81  54 /  40  80  30  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   79  65  79  52 /  50  80  30  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

32/56





710 
FXUS64 KLZK 221617
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1100 AM CDT FRI OCT 22 2004

UPDATE OUT ALREADY. THE FOG IS NOT AS DENSE AS EARLIER...BUT THERE 
IS ENOUGH OF IT STILL TO KEEP A MENTION OF PATCHY FOG THROUGH MID 
AFTERNOON. THE ORIGINAL DISCUSSION FOLLOWS. 32

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY
CONSIDERABLE LOW CLOUDS AND SOME AREAS OF DENSE FOG PREVAIL OVER THE 
FORECAST AREA EARLY THIS MORNING. CLOUDS ARE EXPECTED TO BREAK 
SOMEWHAT OVER THE SOUTH BY THIS AFTERNOON...BUT THE NORTHERN AND 
CENTRAL SECTIONS WILL REMAIN MOSTLY CLOUDY TODAY. SERIES OF H5 SHORT 
WAVES WILL AFFECT THE AREA TODAY AND TONIGHT WITH MAIN H5 TROF 
PASSING NORTH OF THE STATE ON SATURDAY. EXPECT SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS TO INCREASE SOUTHEASTWARD TODAY WITH ONLY THE EXTREME 
SOUTHEAST REMAINING DRY. A FEW OF THE STORMS MAY BECOME SEVERE OVER 
ABOUT THE NORTHWESTERN HALF OF THE AREA. THEN SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS WILL BECOME LIKELY OVER THE AREA AS TONIGHT 
PROGRESSES. A COLD FRONT SHOULD MOVE INTO THE NORTHWEST BY SATURDAY 
MORNING WITH CONTINUING CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. MAY 
THREAT FOR SEVERE SHOULD OVER ABOUT THE SOUTHEASTERN HALF. SUNDAY 
LOOKS DRY...BUT MOISTURE WILL RETURN BY SUNDAY NIGHT AS FRONT SLOWLY 
MAKES ITS WAY BACK NORTHWARD AND THEN SOMEWHAT STALLS OVER THE 
SOUTHERN PARTS OF THE AREA ON MONDAY. HAVE SMALL CHANCES OF SHOWERS 
AND THUNDERSTORMS RETURNING FROM THE SOUTH SUNDAY NIGHT.  
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
THE STALLED OUT FRONT WILL REMAIN WITH US THROUGH MUCH OF THE 
UPCOMING WEEK. ALSO...A SERIES OF WEAK H5 LOWS WILL TRAVERSE THE 
AREA IN SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT. WILL CONTINUE SMALL CHANCES OF SHOWERS 
AND THUNDERSTORMS THROUGH FRIDAY. NEXT SIGNIFICANT FRONT WILL 
APPROACH THE AREA ON FRIDAY. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    79  66  79  54 /  30  60  60  10 
HARRISON AR       76  63  75  49 /  50  70  20  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    80  67  80  55 /  30  60  60  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     80  66  79  56 /  20  60  70  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  76  63  75  49 /  50  70  20  10 
MONTICELLO AR     80  67  79  57 /  10  60  70  10 
SEARCY AR         78  64  77  52 /  20  60  70  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      80  67  80  55 /  50  70  30  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   79  65  78  52 /  50  70  30  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

489 
FXUS64 KLZK 220229 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
930 PM CDT THU OCT 21 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CLOUDS CONTINUE TO HOLD OVER THE ENTIRE FORECAST AREA TONIGHT. WINDS 
HAVE DIED DOWN IN MOST PLACES. DENSE FOG HAS DEVELOPED OVER PORTIONS 
OF WESTERN ARKANSAS...WITH VISBYS DROPPING BELOW ONE MILE AT TIMES. 
DENSE FOG ADVISORY MAY BE REQUIRED LATER TONIGHT IF THESE TRENDS 
BECOME WIDESPREAD. 

WITH ALL THE CLOUDS AROUND...REALLY DONT THINK THAT TEMPS WILL FALL 
ALL THAT MUCH TONIGHT. HAVE UPDATED FORECASTED MINS TO THE LOWER TO 
MID 60S OVER THE WEST AND CENTRAL. HAVE ALSO INCLUDED NEARLY STEADY 
TEMPERATURE WORDING IN THE TEXT FORECASTS.

REMAINING PARAMETERS SEEM TO BE IN GOOD SHAPE...THOUGH HAVE MADE 
SOME MINOR ADJUSTMENTS TO BETTER ACCOUNT FOR ONGOING TRENDS. UPDATED 
TEXT...GRAPHICAL...AND GRIDDED FORECASTS HAVE BEEN SENT. TABULAR 
PRODUCTS WILL BE UPDATED SHORTLY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



227 
FXUS64 KLZK 211947
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
245 PM CDT THU OCT 21 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
THE MAIN FEATURES FROM YESTERDAY ARE STILL IN PLAY. THE RIDGE OVER 
THE EASTERN HALF OF THE COUNTRY CONTINUES TO AMPLIFY AS LONG WAVE 
TROF OVER THE ROCKIES ADVANCES EAST. THE 06Z RUN OF THE GFS DOES NOT 
SHOW AS MUCH VARIATION WITH THE STRENGTH OF THE LOW AS YESTERDAYS 
12Z RUN. STILL...THE BULK OF THE ENERGY WILL CONTINUE SLIDING 
NORTHWARD WITH THE AMPLIFYING OF THE RIDGE. THE TIMING SEEMS TO BE 
ABOUT 6 HOURS SLOWER...WHICH WILL TRANSLATE INTO THE SURFACE FRONT 
CROSSING AR DURING THE DAYLIGHT HOURS. DAY2 AND DAY 3 OUTLOOKS 
REFLECT THIS CHANGE IN TIMING. AFTER SATURDAY...THE RIDGE WILL TAKE 
UP RESIDENCE OVER THE GULF OF MEXICO AND GIVE US ZONAL FLOW. 
PRECIPITATION WILL STILL MOVE INTO THE WESTERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE 
FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY MORNING...HOWEVER THE FRONT WILL ACROSS 
THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE STATE AROUND 18Z AND IT WILL BE ABOUT TO 
CROSS THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BY 00Z SUN. MOISTURE WILL LINGER JUST TO 
THE SOUTH OF THE STATE AND BACK TOWARDS NORTHEAST TEXAS. THE CHANCE 
OF SEVERE WEATHER WILL EXIST FROM FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY MORNING 
WITH THE STRONG SYSTEM...BUT MAINLY IT WILL BE STRONG WINDS AND 
LARGE HAIL ON ACCOUNT OF THE UPPER LOW MOVING AWAY TO THE NORTHEAST. 
SURFACE RIDGE OVER ARKANSAS WILL RETARD THE RETURN OF THIS MOISTURE 
UNTIL MONDAY NIGHT FOR THE SOUTHWEST AND FOR MUCH OF THE STATE FOR 
MONDAY. PRECIPITATION MONDAY WILL BE RAIN RATHER THAN CONVECTIVE 
BECAUSE OF THE OVERRUNNING THAT WILL SET UP. CLOUDS WILL PERSIST 
THROUGHOUT MONDAY NIGHT WHILE PRECIPITATION WILL SLACKEN.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
FRONTAL SYSTEM ACROSS REGION WILL MOVE BACK TO THE NORTH TO START 
THE LONG TERM. MOIST SOUTHERLY FLOW WILL DEVELOP...WITH TEMPERATURES 
GENERALLY ABOVE NORMAL. A FEW WEAK SYSTEMS WILL RIDE SOUTHWEST FLOW 
ALOFT...WITH SLIGHT CHANCES FOR SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
TUESDAY/WEDNESDAY. TROUGH WILL DEEPEN IN THE WEST TOWARD THE END OF 
THE LONG TERM. STORM SYSTEM/FRONT WILL NEAR FROM THE PLAINS ON 
THURSDAY...WITH CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION INCREASING.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    58  79  66  79 /  10  20  50  60 
HARRISON AR       56  76  62  75 /  10  50  60  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    59  80  67  80 /  10  20  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     60  80  66  79 /  10  10  60  70 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  56  76  62  75 /  10  50  60  20 
MONTICELLO AR     62  80  67  79 /  10  10  60  70 
SEARCY AR         57  78  64  78 /  10  20  50  60 
MOUNT IDA AR      59  80  67  80 /  10  40  50  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   57  79  65  79 /  10  50  50  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

32/46





414 
FXUS64 KLZK 211456
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...PRELIMINARY
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
955 AM CDT THU OCT 21 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
THE MAIN FEATURES FROM YESTERDAY ARE STILL IN PLAY. THE RIDGE OVER 
THE EASTERN HALF OF THE COUNTRY CONTINUES TO AMPLIFY AS LONG WAVE 
TROF OVER THE ROCKIES ADVANCES EAST. THE 06Z RUN OF THE GFS DOES NOT 
SHOW AS MUCH VARIATION WITH THE STRENGTH OF THE LOW AS YESTERDAYS 
12Z RUN. STILL...THE BULK OF THE ENERGY WILL CONTINUE SLIDING 
NORTHWARD WITH THE AMPLIFYING OF THE RIDGE. THE TIMING SEEMS TO BE 
ABOUT 6 HOURS SLOWER...WHICH WILL TRANSLATE INTO THE SURFACE FRONT 
CROSSING AR DURING THE DAYLIGHT HOURS. DAY2 AND DAY 3 OUTLOOKS 
REFLECT THIS CHANGE IN TIMING. AFTER SATURDAY...THE RIDGE WILL TAKE 
UP RESIDENCE OVER THE GULF OF MEXICO AND GIVE US ZONAL FLOW. TODAYS 
WEATHER WILL BE SIMILAR TO YESTERDAY. LOW CLOUDS AND FOG WILL BE 
TRAPPED BY THE LOW LEVEL INVERSION. FOG WILL DISSIPATE ENOUGH TO 
EASE UP ON THE FOG ADVISORY...BUT LOW CLOUDS WILL BE PESKY. THIS 
WILL REQUIRED A SIGNIFICANT LOWERING OF TEMPERATURES INTO THE 60S 
MAINLY FOR HIGHS RATHER THAN THE 70S AND A FEW 80S IN THE FORECAST 
FOR THE SOUTH. PRECIPITATION WILL STILL MOVE INTO THE WESTERN 
SECTIONS OF THE STATE FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY MORNING...HOWEVER 
THE FRONT WILL ACROSS THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE STATE AROUND 18Z 
AND IT WILL BE ABOUT TO CROSS THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BY 00Z SUN. 
MOISTURE WILL LINGER JUST TO THE SOUTH OF THE STATE AND BACK TOWARDS 
NORTHEAST TEXAS. SURFACE RIDGE OVER ARKANSAS WILL RETARD THE RETURN 
OF THIS MOISTURE UNTIL MONDAY NIGHT FOR THE SOUTHWEST AND FOR THE 
ENTIRE STATE FOR MONDAY. CLOUDS WILL PERSIST THROUGHOUT MONDAY NIGHT 
WHILE PRECIPITATION WILL SLACKEN.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...DENSE FOG ADVISORY UNTIL 900 AM 
CDT TODAY FOR ZONES ARZ053...ARZ062>069.
&&

$$

32





OF THIS MOISTURE UNTIL MONDAY NIGHT FOR THE SOUTHWEST AND FOR THE 
ENTIRE STATE FOR MONDAY. CLOUDS WILL PERSIST THROUGHOUT MONDAY NIGHT 
WHILE PRECIPITATION WILL SLACKEN.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...DENSE FOG ADVISORY UNTIL 900 AM 
CDT TODAY FOR ZONES ARZ053...ARZ062>069.
&&

$$

32





349 
FXUS64 KLZK 210907
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT THU OCT 21 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY
LOW CLOUDS AND FOG ARE AGAIN ACROSS THE AREA THIS MORNING. MOST 
DENSE FOG IS IN OUR SOUTHERN COUNTIES SO HAVE ISSUED A DENSE FOG 
ADVISORY THERE. STATIONARY FRONT IS ACROSS NORTHERN LOUISIANA AND 
HAS NOT REALLY MOVED OVERNIGHT. SOME DRIZZLE IS ALSO BEING REPORTED. 
DRIZZLE AND FOG SHOULD END THIS MORNING.

UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD OVER THE AREA THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT. THE 
FRONT WILL MOVE ACROSS THE AREA AS A WARM FRONT TONIGHT. THIS WILL 
EVENTUALLY HELP BRING THE FRONT NORTH ON FRIDAY. AS THIS OCCURS A 
COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH FROM THE WEST EARLY FRIDAY. THIS WILL 
SPREAD SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ACROSS THE AREA. INCREASED POPS 
ALONG THE FRONT. HIGH PRESSURE WILL MOVE IN FOR SATURDAY NIGHT AND 
SUNDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
FRONTAL SYSTEM WILL MOVE TO THE NORTH BACK ACROSS THE 
AREA SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY THEN WILL BE NORTH OF THE AREA 
AFTER THAT WITH RATHER STRONG SOUTHWEST FLOW SETTING UP. 
KEPT SMALL POPS IN FOR SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT.
RATHER GOOD MOISTURE REMAINS IN PLACE TUESDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
BUT ENOUGH RIDGING ALOFT MAY SET IN TO CAP THE ATMOSPHERE SO
KEPT MENTION OF RAIN OUT OF THE FORECAST. RAISED TEMP FORECASTS 
A LITTLE FROM MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY TO ACCOUNT FOR 
SOUTHWEST WINDS AND UPPER RIDGING.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    76  60  82  65 /   0  10  20  50 
HARRISON AR       72  58  79  60 /   0  10  40  70 
HOT SPRINGS AR    76  60  83  66 /   0  10  20  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     77  61  83  65 /   0  10  10  60 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  71  58  79  59 /   0  10  40  70 
MONTICELLO AR     82  63  83  66 /   0  10  10  60 
SEARCY AR         74  59  81  63 /   0  10  20  50 
MOUNT IDA AR      76  60  83  66 /   0  10  40  50 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   75  59  81  64 /   0  10  40  60 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...DENSE FOG ADVISORY UNTIL 900 AM 
CDT TODAY FOR ZONES ARZ053...ARZ062>069.

51/29
