
440 
FXUS64 KLZK 210250 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
950 PM CDT WED OCT 20 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LOW CLOUDS CONTINUE TO FILL BACK IN OVER WESTERN ARKANSAS AT THIS 
HOUR. FOG ALSO BEGINNING TO RE-FORM IN AREAS WHERE IT HAD DISPERSED 
EARLIER. HAS BEEN LOCALLY DENSE AT HRO...BUT STILL BETWEEN 2 AND 6 
MILES AT OTHER LOCATIONS. WILL HOLD OFF ON ADVISORY AT THIS 
TIME...BUT IF CURRENT TRENDS CONTINUE...THE MID SHIFT WILL NEED TO 
CONSIDER ISSUING ONE. 

FRONTAL BOUNDARY CURRENTLY STALLED FROM NEAR DEQUEEN...TO NEAR 
MONTICELLO. BOUNDARY NOT LIKELY TO MOVE MUCH OVERNIGHT...WHICH WILL 
KEEP AREAS NORTH OF THE BOUNDARY COOLER. FORECASTED MINS LOOK TO BE 
IN GREAT SHAPE...SO NO CHANGES NEEDED THERE. 

HAVE SENT OUT AN UPDATE...MAINLY TO ADD MENTION OF DRIZZLE. HAVE 
ALSO ADJUSTED OTHER SENSIBLE WEATHER PARAMETERS...TEMP...DEWPOINTS...
WINDS BASED ON ONGOING TRENDS. 

UPDATED GRIDDED...GRAPHICAL...TEXT...AND TABULAR FORECASTS HAVE ALL 
BEEN TRANSMITTED. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

57





036 
FXUS64 KLZK 202001
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT WED OCT 20 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
THE UPPER FLOW WILL CONTINUE AMPLIFYING THE RIDGE OVER THE CENTRAL 
AND EASTERN SECTIONS OF THE COUNTRY DURING THIS PERIOD. IN THE 
MEANTIME THE STRONG LOW OVER SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA MOVES EAST AND 
WEAKENS AS IT GETS CAUGHT IN THE STRONG SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW RESULTING 
FROM THE STRONG RIDGE HOLDING ITS GROUND. THE GFS RE-STRENGTHENS THE 
SHOT OF ENERGY MOVING THROUGH THE CENTRAL SECTION OF THE COUNTRY 
OVER KANSAS BY 00Z SATURDAY BUT THE RIDGE DEFLECTS IT AWAY FROM 
AR...PLACING IT OVER THE UPPER MIDWEST BY SATURDAY MORNING. FROM 12Z 
SAT TO 12Z MON...THE FLOW GETS BACK TO A ZONAL CONFIGURATION. THE 
RESULT OF ALL THIS RIDGING AND DEFLECTING WILL BE TO SLOW DOWN THE 
PROGRESS OF THE SURFACE FRONT TO MORE FAVORABLE HOURS FOR AR TO 
MINIMIZE SEVERE WEATHER SINCE IT WILL CROSS OVERNIGHT FRIDAY INTO 
SATURDAY MORNING. ALSO...THE SOUTHERN END WILL LOSE ITS OOMPH AND 
LEAVE MOISTURE POISED JUST SOUTH OF OUR BORDERS...READY TO RETURN ON 
THE BACK SIDE OF THE NEXT HIGH THAT WILL BE CENTERED OVER THE MO 
BOOTHEEL. I WILL REINTRODUCE SMALL POPS FROM SOUTH TO NORTH ON 
SUNDAY NIGHT. WEATHER-WISE...OUR LOW CLOUDS AND FOG ARE QUITE LIKELY 
TO RETURN SOON TONIGHT WITH PROLONGED EASTERLY WINDS AND UNDER PESKY 
INVERSION. TEMPS WILL TREND TOWARD THE GFS NUMBERS SINCE IT IS 
HANDLING THE SITUATION BETTER.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
GFS SOLUTION HAS DONE A GOOD JOB WITH THE OVERALL PATTERN OF LATE 
AND STILL SEEMS TO BE THE BEST WAY TO GO. ONLY CHANGE OF NOTE IS THE 
MODEL HAS TRENDED JUST A LITTLE FASTER WITH ALL MAJOR FEATURES BUT 
CHANGES TO THE SENSIBLE WEATHER WILL BE SUPERFICIAL AT BEST.

PROGRESSIVE PATTERN WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE EXTENDED WITH A SERIES 
OF SYSTEMS COMING ON SHORE ALONG THE WEST COAST WITH THE NORTHERN 
STREAM APPEARING TO BE MORE ACTIVE THROUGH THE PERIOD. HIGH PRESSURE 
MOVES INTO THE CENTRAL PLAINS EARLY IN THE PERIOD WITH RETURN FLOW 
SETTING UP. REMNANTS OF AN OLD STATIONARY BOUNDARY STILL LURKING 
ACROSS NORTHERN LOUISIANA...WILL NEED TO KEEP SLIGHT CHANCES POPS IN 
FOR MONDAY AND MONDAY NIGHT. 

UPPER LOWS WILL BE LOCATED OVER NEW ENGLAND AND THE WASHINGTON COAST 
BY THE END OF TUESDAY WITH RIDGING PUMPING UP OVER THE NATIONS MID 
SECTION IN RESPONSE. MODELS TRY TO MOVE A WEAK FRONT THROUGH ON 
TUESDAY BUT ITS EFFECT APPEARS MINIMAL. AS WASHINGTON LOWS DIGS DOWN 
THE WEST COAST...RIDGE STRENGTHENS CONSIDERABLY FOR WEDNESDAY AND AS 
SUCH WILL GO WITH DRY CONDITIONS BOTH DAYS SIX AND SEVEN. 
TEMPERATURES CURRENTLY IN THE EXTENDED LOOK REASONABLE AND WILL BE 
LEFT IN PLACE. NUMBERS AGREE FAIRLY WELL WITH MEX GUIDANCE AND ARE 
GENERALLY ACCEPTED.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    55  80  60  82 /  10  10  10  20 
HARRISON AR       51  75  57  79 /  10  10  10  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    55  80  60  83 /  10  10  10  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     57  80  61  83 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  51  74  57  79 /  10  10  10  40 
MONTICELLO AR     60  81  63  83 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         54  78  59  81 /  10  10  10  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      55  80  60  83 /  10  10  10  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   54  78  59  81 /  10  10  10  40 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

32





711 
FXUS64 KLZK 201652
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1110 AM CDT WED OCT 20 2004

SOUNDING SHOWS QUITE STRONG INVERSION THAT WILL TRAP THE LOW LEVEL 
MOISTURE MUCH LONGER THAN EXPECTED EARLIER...SO MADE ADJUSTMENTS TO 
KEEP FOG AND CLOUDS. TO GO ALONG WITH THAT...I HAD TO LOWER 
TEMPERATURES FOR TODAYS HIGHS. PREVIOUS DISCUSSION FOLLOWS (32).

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY
THE COLD FRONT EXTENDS FROM NEAR DEQUEEN TO NORTH OF PINE BLUFF TO 
NEAR MEMPHIS. NORTHEAST WINDS ARE ACROSS THE NORTH AND CENTRAL 
SECTIONS WITH SOUTH WINDS ACROSS MOST SOUTHERN LOCATIONS. COOL DRY 
AIR HAS MADE IT INTO CENTRAL AND PORTIONS OF SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS. 
THIS WILL IMPACT THE MAX TEMPERATURES ACROSS NORTH AND CENTRAL 
ARKANSAS ESPECIALLY. LOWERED MAX TEMPS IN MOST LOCATIONS WITH THE 
BIGGEST DECREASE ACROSS THE NORTH. SHOULD ONLY SEE TEMPS AROUND 70 
DEGREES AT HARRISON. LOW STRATUS CLOUDS HAVE MOVED BACK INTO THIS 
AREA AND WILL KEEP TEMPERATURES COOL IN THIS AREA. LATEST SATELLITE 
IMAGES SHOW LOW STRATUS MOVING INTO CENTRAL ARKANSAS FROM THE 
NORTHEAST AND INTO SOUTH ARKANSAS FROM THE SOUTH...SO WILL ADJUST 
GRIDS ACCORDINGLY.

A FEW SHOWERS MOVED ACROSS NORTHEAST PORTIONS OF ARKANSAS EARLY THIS 
MORNING BUT HAVE DISSIPATED OR MOVED EAST OF THE CWFA. WILL NOT 
MENTION ANY POPS TODAY AS PRECIP WILL BE JUST EAST OF CWFA. 

A SURFACE LOW IS CENTERED IN SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS ALONG THE 
AFOREMENTIONED FRONT. WILL STAY CLOSE TO THE CONSISTENT GFS SOLUTION 
FOR THIS PACKAGE. AN UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD OVER THE AREA TONIGHT 
AND THE COLD FRONT WILL MOVE NORTH BRINGING WARMER MORE HUMID AIR 
NORTHWARD. A DEVELOPING COLD FRONT IN THE ROCKIES WILL HEAD FOR 
ARKANSAS ON THURSDAY. WILL BEGIN A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS ACROSS THE WEST AND NORTHWEST EARLY FRIDAY 
MORNING...AND PROGRESS THEM EASTWARD AS THE FRONT MOVES THROUGH THE 
AREA. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL SPREAD ACROSS THE AREA FRIDAY 
AND FRIDAY NIGHT. THE FRONT SHOULD ENTER THE NORTHWEST CORNER FRIDAY 
AFTERNOON AND BE THROUGH THE STATE BY SATURDAY AFTERNOON. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM WILL BE OVER THE AREA SATURDAY NIGHT
INTO SUNDAY AND THIS SHOULD BRING DRY AND COOL WEATHER. LOWERED 
MIN TEMPS AND DEW POINTS DURING THIS PERIOD. THIS HIGH MOVES TO
THE EAST SUNDAY NIGHT WITH SOME RETURN FLOW COMING AROUND IT BUT
THE NEW GFS NOW INDICATES ANOTHER WEAK COLD FRONT MOVING THROUGH
ON MONDAY. CONTINUED WITH SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR MONDAY AND MONDAY
NIGHT FOR THIS. THIS HIGH SLIDES TO THE EAST TUESDAY WITH RETURN
FLOW BRINGING GOOD MOISTURE INTO THE AREA. UPPER RIDGE AXIS WILL
BE TO THE WEST OF THE AREA HOWEVER WHICH MAY INHIBIT MUCH IN THE 
WAY OF PRECIPITATION. WENT WITH SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR TUESDAY FOR 
NOW.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    82  59  80  62 /   0   0  10  10 
HARRISON AR       70  55  75  60 /   0   0  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    83  59  80  63 /   0   0  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  61  80  64 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  70  55  74  60 /  10   0  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     85  64  81  66 /   0   0  10  10 
SEARCY AR         79  58  78  62 /  10   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      83  59  80  63 /   0   0  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   81  57  78  62 /   0   0  10  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

THE COLD FRONT EXTENDS FROM NEAR DEQUEEN TO NORTH OF PINE BLUFF TO 
NEAR MEMPHIS. NORTHEAST WINDS ARE ACROSS THE NORTH AND CENTRAL 
SECTIONS WITH SOUTH WINDS ACROSS MOST SOUTHERN LOCATIONS. COOL DRY 
AIR HAS MADE IT INTO CENTRAL AND PORTIONS OF SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS. 
THIS WILL IMPACT THE MAX TEMPERATURES ACROSS NORTH AND CENTRAL 
ARKANSAS ESPECIALLY. LOWERED MAX TEMPS IN MOST LOCATIONS WITH THE 
BIGGEST DECREASE ACROSS THE NORTH. SHOULD ONLY SEE TEMPS AROUND 70 
DEGREES AT HARRISON. LOW STRATUS CLOUDS HAVE MOVED BACK INTO THIS 
AREA AND WILL KEEP TEMPERATURES COOL IN THIS AREA. LATEST SATELLITE 
IMAGES SHOW LOW STRATUS MOVING INTO CENTRAL ARKANSAS FROM THE 
NORTHEAST AND INTO SOUTH ARKANSAS FROM THE SOUTH...SO WILL ADJUST 
GRIDS ACCORDINGLY.

A FEW SHOWERS MOVED ACROSS NORTHEAST PORTIONS OF ARKANSAS EARLY THIS 
MORNING BUT HAVE DISSIPATED OR MOVED EAST OF THE CWFA. WILL NOT 
MENTION ANY POPS TODAY AS PRECIP WILL BE JUST EAST OF CWFA. 

A SURFACE LOW IS CENTERED IN SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS ALONG THE 
AFOREMENTIONED FRONT. WILL STAY CLOSE TO THE CONSISTENT GFS SOLUTION 
FOR THIS PACKAGE. AN UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD OVER THE AREA TONIGHT 
AND THE COLD FRONT WILL MOVE NORTH BRINGING WARMER MORE HUMID AIR 
NORTHWARD. A DEVELOPING COLD FRONT IN THE ROCKIES WILL HEAD FOR 
ARKANSAS ON THURSDAY. WILL BEGIN A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS ACROSS THE WEST AND NORTHWEST EARLY FRIDAY 
MORNING...AND PROGRESS THEM EASTWARD AS THE FRONT MOVES THROUGH THE 
AREA. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL SPREAD ACROSS THE AREA FRIDAY 
AND FRIDAY NIGHT. THE FRONT SHOULD ENTER THE NORTHWEST CORNER FRIDAY 
AFTERNOON AND BE THROUGH THE STATE BY SATURDAY AFTERNOON. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM WILL BE OVER THE AREA SATURDAY NIGHT
INTO SUNDAY AND THIS SHOULD BRING DRY AND COOL WEATHER. LOWERED 
MIN TEMPS AND DEW POINTS DURING THIS PERIOD. THIS HIGH MOVES TO
THE EAST SUNDAY NIGHT WITH SOME RETURN FLOW COMING AROUND IT BUT
THE NEW GFS NOW INDICATES ANOTHER WEAK COLD FRONT MOVING THROUGH
ON MONDAY. CONTINUED WITH SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR MONDAY AND MONDAY
NIGHT FOR THIS. THIS HIGH SLIDES TO THE EAST TUESDAY WITH RETURN
FLOW BRINGING GOOD MOISTURE INTO THE AREA. UPPER RIDGE AXIS WILL
BE TO THE WEST OF THE AREA HOWEVER WHICH MAY INHIBIT MUCH IN THE 
WAY OF PRECIPITATION. WENT WITH SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR TUESDAY FOR 
NOW.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    82  59  80  62 /   0   0  10  10 
HARRISON AR       70  55  75  60 /   0   0  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    83  59  80  63 /   0   0  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  61  80  64 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  70  55  74  60 /  10   0  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     85  64  81  66 /   0   0  10  10 
SEARCY AR         79  58  78  62 /  10   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      83  59  80  63 /   0   0  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   81  57  78  62 /   0   0  10  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

51/29

51/29






075 
FXUS64 KLZK 200240 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
940 PM CDT TUE OCT 19 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATED FORECASTS TO REMOVE MENTION OF PRECIPITATION FOR OVERNIGHT. 
ALSO INTRODUCED AREAS OF FOG FOR LATE TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY MORNING. 
LOWERED MINIMUM TEMPERATURES ABOUT ONE CATEGORY IN THE NORTH FOR 
OVERNIGHT. ALL UPDATES GONE.
 
&&



.PREV DISCUSSION...
MODELS IN VERY GOOD AGREEMENT THIS AFTERNOON IN BOTH INTENSITY AND 
TIMING. ALL ARE ADVERTISING A VERY PROGRESSIVE PATTERN WITH A 
TRANSITION FROM NEARLY ZONAL FLOW TO A HIGHLY AMPLIFIED ONE AND THEN 
BACK TO ZONAL. MODELS HAVE SLOWED DOWN THE EVOLUTION OF THE SYSTEM 
BY ABOUT SIX HOURS VERSUS PREVIOUS RUNS. WITH THAT BEING SAID...WILL 
GO WITH A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS THIS AFTERNOON.

CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACE THE SURFACE BOUNDARY ROUGHLY ALONG A 
JONESBORO TO HOT SPRINGS TO DEQUEEN LINE.. TEMPERATURES AND DEW 
POINTS ACROSS THE BOUNDARY DIFFER BY ABOUT 20 DEGREES. FRONT IS 
SHOWING SOME SIGNS OF SINKING SOUTHWARD WITH VERY WARM AND UNSTABLE 
AIRMASS PROCEEDING IT. LOTS OF SUNSHINE SEEN OVER THE REST OF THE 
STATE WITH AIRMASS LIKELY TO DESTABILIZE EVEN MORE ALONG AND 
PROCEEDING THE FRONT. SCATTERED CONVECTION HAS BEEN OCCURRING ALL 
DAY OVER THE SOUTH EAST AND SEE NO REASON WHY IT WILL NOT CONTINUE 
THROUGH EARLY EVENING AS SPEED MAX LIFTS OUT OF TEXAS. SPECIAL 18Z 
RADIOSONDE RELEASE CONTINUES TO SHOW GOOD SPEED SHEER AND A LITTLE 
BETTER DIRECTIONAL SHEER THAN THE UPPER AIR SOUNDING FROM THIS 
MORNING. ACTIVITY SHOULD BEGIN TO DECREASE AFTER LOSS OF DAYTIME 
HEATING.

FRONT MAKES VERY LITTLE PROGRESS OVER THE NEXT DAY OR SO BEFORE 
BECOMING ILL DEFINED OR WASHING OUT COMPLETELY. NEARLY ZONAL PATTERN 
ALOFT WILL BEGIN TO TRANSITION TONIGHT AS UPPER LOW APPROACHES THE 
WEST COAST. AS LOW DIGS OFF THE WEST COAST...RIDGE BEGINS TO PUMP UP 
OVER THE AREA IN RESPONSE. TROF WILL EXTEND FROM BAJA INTO CENTRAL 
CANADA WITH RIDGING FROM THE GULF NORTH TO THE GREAT LAKES STATES BY 
THURSDAY NIGHT.

WITH THE RIDGE OVER HEAD...PRECIP CHANCES WILL BE MINIMAL THROUGH 
MID DAY FRIDAY. MESOETA MOVES A SHORTWAVES TRAPPED UNDER THE RIDGE 
ACROSS SOUTHERN ARKANSAS WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON BUT MOISTURE APPEARS 
MINIMAL SO WILL LEAVE POPS OUT.

TROF LIFTS OUT OF THE DESERT SOUTHWEST ON FRIDAY BUT IS SHUNTED 
NORTHEAST BY STRONG MID LEVEL RIDGING OVER THE NATIONS MID SECTION. 
LOW PRESSURE DEVELOPS ON THE ASSOCIATED FRONT IN THE LEE OF THE 
ROCKIES FRIDAY MORNING AND RACES OFF TO THE NORTHEAST INTO THE 
WESTERN LAKES BY SATURDAY MORNING. COLD FRONT MOVES THROUGH THE AREA 
FRIDAY NIGHT AND EARLY SATURDAY WITH DECENT SURFACE CONVERGENCE AND 
LIFT ALONG THE FRONT ITSELF. BEST DYNAMICS WILL BE OVER THE NORTH 
FRIDAY NIGHT AND HIGHER POPS WILL BE JUSTIFIED HERE STARTING AS 
EARLY AS FRIDAY AFTERNOON OVER THE NORTHWEST. WILL KEEP HIGHER POPS 
ACROSS THE NORTH FRIDAY NIGHT AND OVER THE SOUTH SATURDAY MORNING 
AS FRONT MOVES THROUGH. FRONT CLEARS THE STATE LATE SATURDAY WITH 
HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN BEHIND IT.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...WITH STRONG RIDGING BUILDING IN AND NO 
APPRECIABLE PUSH OF COOLER AIR...WILL GO ABOVE GUIDANCE OVER THE 
NEXT FEW DAYS. MEX NUMBERS APPEAR MORE REASONABLE ON SATURDAY AND 
WILL LEAN IN THAT DIRECTION.

FRONT WILL MOVE SOUTH OF THE STATE SUNDAY...SO REMOVED PRECIP FROM 
THE FORECAST. FRONT WILL MOVE BACK NORTH MONDAY...AND CONTINUED THE 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS. UPPER RIDGE MOVES NORTH TUESDAY FOR A DRY 
FORECAST. TEMPS WILL REMAIN SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL...WITH READINGS IN 
THE 70S.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

22






WESTERN LAKES BY SATURDAY MORNING. COLD FRONT MOVES THROUGH THE AREA

LIFT ALONG THE FRONT ITSELF. BEST DYNAMICS WILL BE OVER THE NORTH 
FRIDAY NIGHT AND HIGHER POPS WILL BE JUSTIFIED HERE STARTING AS 
EARLY AS FRIDAY AFTERNOON OVER THE NORTHWEST. WILL KEEP HIGHER POPS 
ACROSS THE NORTH FRIDAY NIGHT AND OVER THE SOUTH SATURDAY MORNING 
AS FRONT MOVES THROUGH. FRONT CLEARS THE STATE LATE SATURDAY WITH 
HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN BEHIND IT.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...WITH STRONG RIDGING BUILDING IN AND NO 
APPRECIABLE PUSH OF COOLER AIR...WILL GO ABOVE GUIDANCE OVER THE 
NEXT FEW DAYS. MEX NUMBERS APPEAR MORE REASONABLE ON SATURDAY AND 
WILL LEAN IN THAT DIRECTION.

FRONT WILL MOVE SOUTH OF THE STATE SUNDAY...SO REMOVED PRECIP FROM 
THE FORECAST. FRONT WILL MOVE BACK NORTH MONDAY...AND CONTINUED THE 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS. UPPER RIDGE MOVES NORTH TUESDAY FOR A DRY 
FORECAST. TEMPS WILL REMAIN SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL...WITH READINGS IN 
THE 70S.

GO WITH A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS THIS AFTERNOON.

CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACE THE SURFACE BOUNDARY ROUGHLY ALONG A 
JONESBORO TO HOT SPRINGS TO DEQUEEN LINE.. TEMPERATURES AND DEW 
POINTS ACROSS THE BOUNDARY DIFFER BY ABOUT 20 DEGREES. FRONT IS 
SHOWING SOME SIGNS OF SINKING SOUTHWARD WITH VERY WARM AND UNSTABLE 
AIRMASS PROCEEDING IT. LOTS OF SUNSHINE SEEN OVER THE REST OF THE 
STATE WITH AIRMASS LIKELY TO DESTABILIZE EVEN MORE ALONG AND 
PROCEEDING THE FRONT. SCATTERED CONVECTION HAS BEEN OCCURRING ALL 
DAY OVER THE SOUTH EAST AND SEE NO REASON WHY IT WILL NOT CONTINUE 
THROUGH EARLY EVENING AS SPEED MAX LIFTS OUT OF TEXAS. SPECIAL 18Z 
RADIOSONDE RELEASE CONTINUES TO SHOW GOOD SPEED SHEER AND A LITTLE 
BETTER DIRECTIONAL SHEER THAN THE UPPER AIR SOUNDING FROM THIS 
MORNING. ACTIVITY SHOULD BEGIN TO DECREASE AFTER LOSS OF DAYTIME 
HEATING.

FRONT MAKES VERY LITTLE PROGRESS OVER THE NEXT DAY OR SO BEFORE 
BECOMING ILL DEFINED OR WASHING OUT COMPLETELY. NEARLY ZONAL PATTERN 
ALOFT WILL BEGIN TO TRANSITION TONIGHT AS UPPER LOW APPROACHES THE 
WEST COAST. AS LOW DIGS OFF THE WEST COAST...RIDGE BEGINS TO PUMP UP 
OVER THE AREA IN RESPONSE. TROF WILL EXTEND FROM BAJA INTO CENTRAL 
CANADA WITH RIDGING FROM THE GULF NORTH TO THE GREAT LAKES STATES BY 
THURSDAY NIGHT.

WITH THE RIDGE OVER HEAD...PRECIP CHANCES WILL BE MINIMAL THROUGH 
MID DAY FRIDAY. MESOETA MOVES A SHORTWAVES TRAPPED UNDER THE RIDGE 
ACROSS SOUTHERN ARKANSAS WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON BUT MOISTURE APPEARS 
MINIMAL SO WILL LEAVE POPS OUT.

TROF LIFTS OUT OF THE DESERT SOUTHWEST ON FRIDAY BUT IS SHUNTED 
NORTHEAST BY STRONG MID LEVEL RIDGING OVER THE NATIONS MID SECTION. 
LOW PRESSURE DEVELOPS ON THE ASSOCIATED FRONT IN THE LEE OF THE 
ROCKIES FRIDAY MORNING AND RACES OFF TO THE NORTHEAST INTO THE 
WESTERN LAKES BY SATURDAY MORNING. COLD FRONT MOVES THROUGH THE AREA 
FRIDAY NIGHT AND EARLY SATURDAY WITH DECENT SURFACE CONVERGENCE AND 
LIFT ALONG THE FRONT ITSELF. BEST DYNAMICS WILL BE OVER THE NORTH 
FRIDAY NIGHT AND HIGHER POPS WILL BE JUSTIFIED HERE STARTING AS 
EARLY AS FRIDAY AFTERNOON OVER THE NORTHWEST. WILL KEEP HIGHER POPS 
ACROSS THE NORTH FRIDAY NIGHT AND OVER THE SOUTH SATURDAY MORNING 
AS FRONT MOVES THROUGH. FRONT CLEARS THE STATE LATE SATURDAY WITH 
HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN BEHIND IT.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...WITH STRONG RIDGING BUILDING IN AND NO 
APPRECIABLE PUSH OF COOLER AIR...WILL GO ABOVE GUIDANCE OVER THE 
NEXT FEW DAYS. MEX NUMBERS APPEAR MORE REASONABLE ON SATURDAY AND 
WILL LEAN IN THAT DIRECTION.

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY...
FRONT WILL MOVE SOUTH OF THE STATE SUNDAY...SO REMOVED PRECIP FROM 
THE FORECAST. FRONT WILL MOVE BACK NORTH MONDAY...AND CONTINUED THE 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS. UPPER RIDGE MOVES NORTH TUESDAY FOR A DRY 
FORECAST. TEMPS WILL REMAIN SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL...WITH READINGS IN 
THE 70S.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY...
FRONT WILL MOVE SOUTH OF THE STATE SUNDAY...SO REMOVED PRECIP FROM 
THE FORECAST. FRONT WILL MOVE BACK NORTH MONDAY...AND CONTINUED THE 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS. UPPER RIDGE MOVES NORTH TUESDAY FOR A DRY 
FORECAST. TEMPS WILL REMAIN SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL...WITH READINGS IN 
THE 70S.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    62  85  61  85 /  20  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       56  79  57  83 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    63  86  61  86 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     65  86  63  85 /  30  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  56  80  57  82 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     67  87  66  85 /  40  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         60  84  60  84 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      63  85  61  86 /  10  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   60  84  59  84 /  10  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
238 PM CDT TUE OCT 19 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT...
MODELS IN VERY GOOD AGREEMENT THIS AFTERNOON IN BOTH INTENSITY AND 
TIMING. ALL ARE ADVERTISING A VERY PROGRESSIVE PATTERN WITH A 
TRANSITION FROM NEARLY ZONAL FLOW TO A HIGHLY AMPLIFIED ONE AND THEN 
BACK TO ZONAL. MODELS HAVE SLOWED DOWN THE EVOLUTION OF THE SYSTEM 
BY ABOUT SIX HOURS VERSUS PREVIOUS RUNS. WITH THAT BEING SAID...WILL 
GO WITH A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS THIS AFTERNOON.

CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACE THE SURFACE BOUNDARY ROUGHLY ALONG A 
JONESBORO TO HOT SPRINGS TO DEQUEEN LINE.. TEMPERATURES AND DEW 
POINTS ACROSS THE BOUNDARY DIFFER BY ABOUT 20 DEGREES. FRONT IS 
SHOWING SOME SIGNS OF SINKING SOUTHWARD WITH VERY WARM AND UNSTABLE 
AIRMASS PROCEEDING IT. LOTS OF SUNSHINE SEEN OVER THE REST OF THE 
STATE WITH AIRMASS LIKELY TO DESTABILIZE EVEN MORE ALONG AND 
PROCEEDING THE FRONT. SCATTERED CONVECTION HAS BEEN OCCURRING ALL 
DAY OVER THE SOUTH EAST AND SEE NO REASON WHY IT WILL NOT CONTINUE 
THROUGH EARLY EVENING AS SPEED MAX LIFTS OUT OF TEXAS. SPECIAL 18Z 
RADIOSONDE RELEASE CONTINUES TO SHOW GOOD SPEED SHEER AND A LITTLE 
BETTER DIRECTIONAL SHEER THAN THE UPPER AIR SOUNDING FROM THIS 
MORNING. ACTIVITY SHOULD BEGIN TO DECREASE AFTER LOSS OF DAYTIME 
HEATING.

FRONT MAKES VERY LITTLE PROGRESS OVER THE NEXT DAY OR SO BEFORE 
BECOMING ILL DEFINED OR WASHING OUT COMPLETELY. NEARLY ZONAL PATTERN 
ALOFT WILL BEGIN TO TRANSITION TONIGHT AS UPPER LOW APPROACHES THE 
WEST COAST. AS LOW DIGS OFF THE WEST COAST...RIDGE BEGINS TO PUMP UP 
OVER THE AREA IN RESPONSE. TROF WILL EXTEND FROM BAJA INTO CENTRAL 
CANADA WITH RIDGING FROM THE GULF NORTH TO THE GREAT LAKES STATES BY 
THURSDAY NIGHT.

WITH THE RIDGE OVER HEAD...PRECIP CHANCES WILL BE MINIMAL THROUGH 
MID DAY FRIDAY. MESOETA MOVES A SHORTWAVES TRAPPED UNDER THE RIDGE 
ACROSS SOUTHERN ARKANSAS WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON BUT MOISTURE APPEARS 
MINIMAL SO WILL LEAVE POPS OUT.

TROF LIFTS OUT OF THE DESERT SOUTHWEST ON FRIDAY BUT IS SHUNTED 
NORTHEAST BY STRONG MID LEVEL RIDGING OVER THE NATIONS MID SECTION. 
LOW PRESSURE DEVELOPS ON THE ASSOCIATED FRONT IN THE LEE OF THE 
ROCKIES FRIDAY MORNING AND RACES OFF TO THE NORTHEAST INTO THE 
WESTERN LAKES BY SATURDAY MORNING. COLD FRONT MOVES THROUGH THE AREA 
FRIDAY NIGHT AND EARLY SATURDAY WITH DECENT SURFACE CONVERGENCE AND 
LIFT ALONG THE FRONT ITSELF. BEST DYNAMICS WILL BE OVER THE NORTH 
FRIDAY NIGHT AND HIGHER POPS WILL BE JUSTIFIED HERE STARTING AS 
EARLY AS FRIDAY AFTERNOON OVER THE NORTHWEST. WILL KEEP HIGHER POPS 
ACROSS THE NORTH FRIDAY NIGHT AND OVER THE SOUTH SATURDAY MORNING 
AS FRONT MOVES THROUGH. FRONT CLEARS THE STATE LATE SATURDAY WITH 
HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN BEHIND IT.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...WITH STRONG RIDGING BUILDING IN AND NO 
APPRECIABLE PUSH OF COOLER AIR...WILL GO ABOVE GUIDANCE OVER THE 
NEXT FEW DAYS. MEX NUMBERS APPEAR MORE REASONABLE ON SATURDAY AND 
WILL LEAN IN THAT DIRECTION.

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY...
FRONT WILL MOVE SOUTH OF THE STATE SUNDAY...SO REMOVED PRECIP FROM 
THE FORECAST. FRONT WILL MOVE BACK NORTH MONDAY...AND CONTINUED THE 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS. UPPER RIDGE MOVES NORTH TUESDAY FOR A DRY 
FORECAST. TEMPS WILL REMAIN SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL...WITH READINGS IN 
THE 70S.

ARZ003>005-012-013-192300-
BOONE-MARION-BAXTER-NEWTON-SEARCY-
INCLUDING THE CITIES OF...HARRISON...YELLVILLE...MOUNTAIN HOME...
JASPER...MARSHALL
1104 AM CDT TUE OCT 19 2004

UPDATED

.THIS AFTERNOON...MOSTLY CLOUDY. AREAS OF FOG. HIGHS IN THE UPPER 
70S. SOUTHWEST WINDS 5 TO 10 MPH. 
.TONIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY. LOWS IN THE UPPER 50S. SOUTHWEST WINDS 5
MPH IN THE EVENING...SHIFTING TO THE NORTHEAST AFTER MIDNIGHT. 
.WEDNESDAY...PARTLY CLOUDY. HIGHS IN THE UPPER 70S. EAST WINDS 5 MPH
IN THE MORNING...BECOMING SOUTH 5 TO 10 MPH IN THE AFTERNOON. 
.WEDNESDAY NIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY. LOWS IN THE UPPER 50S. SOUTH WINDS
5 TO 10 MPH. 
.THURSDAY...PARTLY CLOUDY. HIGHS IN THE LOWER 80S. SOUTH WINDS 5 TO
10 MPH IN THE MORNING...INCREASING TO 10 TO 15 MPH IN THE AFTERNOON. 
.THURSDAY NIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY. LOWS AROUND 60. 
.FRIDAY...PARTLY CLOUDY. SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS.
HIGHS IN THE LOWER 80S. CHANCE OF RAIN 20 PERCENT. 
.FRIDAY NIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY IN THE EVENING...THEN BECOMING MOSTLY
CLOUDY. CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. LOWS AROUND 60. CHANCE
OF RAIN 50 PERCENT. 
.SATURDAY...PARTLY CLOUDY. CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN
THE MORNING...THEN SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN THE
AFTERNOON. HIGHS IN THE MID 70S. CHANCE OF RAIN 40 PERCENT. 
.SATURDAY NIGHT...MOSTLY CLEAR. LOWS IN THE MID 50S. 
.SUNDAY...MOSTLY SUNNY IN THE MORNING...THEN BECOMING PARTLY CLOUDY.
SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN THE AFTERNOON. HIGHS
IN THE MID 70S. CHANCE OF RAIN 20 PERCENT. 
.SUNDAY NIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY. SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND
THUNDERSTORMS. LOWS IN THE MID 50S. CHANCE OF RAIN 20 PERCENT. 
.MONDAY...PARTLY CLOUDY. SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS
IN THE AFTERNOON. HIGHS IN THE MID 70S. CHANCE OF RAIN 20 PERCENT.

CLOUDY. CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. HIGHS IN THE UPPER 70S.
CHANCE OF RAIN 50 PERCENT. 
.SATURDAY NIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY IN THE EVENING...THEN CLEARING. LOWS
AROUND 60. 
.SUNDAY...MOSTLY SUNNY IN THE MORNING...THEN BECOMING PARTLY CLOUDY.
SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN THE AFTERNOON. HIGHS
IN THE UPPER 70S. CHANCE OF RAIN 20 PERCENT. 
.SUNDAY NIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY. SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND
THUNDERSTORMS. LOWS AROUND 60. CHANCE OF RAIN 20 PERCENT. 
.MONDAY...PARTLY CLOUDY. SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS.
HIGHS IN THE UPPER 70S. CHANCE OF RAIN 20 PERCENT.

JEFFERSON-ARKANSAS-CLEVELAND-LINCOLN-DESHA-BRADLEY-DREW-
INCLUDING THE CITIES OF...PINE BLUFF...STUTTGART...DEWITT...RISON...
STAR CITY...MCGEHEE..DUMAS...ARKANSAS CITY...WARREN...MONTICELLO
1104 AM CDT TUE OCT 19 2004

UPDATED

.THIS AFTERNOON...SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS LIKELY. HIGHS IN THE
UPPER 80S. SOUTHWEST WINDS 5 TO 10 MPH. CHANCE OF RAIN 60 PERCENT.
AVERAGE RAINFALL LESS THAN 1/10 INCH. 
.TONIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY. CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN THE
EVENING...THEN SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS AFTER
MIDNIGHT. LOWS IN THE MID 60S. SOUTH WINDS 5 TO 10 MPH IN THE
EVENING...DECREASING TO 5 MPH AFTER MIDNIGHT. CHANCE OF RAIN 40
PERCENT. AVERAGE RAINFALL LESS THAN 1/10 INCH. 
.WEDNESDAY...PARTLY CLOUDY. HIGHS IN THE MID 80S. SOUTH WINDS 5 TO
10 MPH...WITH GUSTS TO AROUND 25 MPH. 
.WEDNESDAY NIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY. LOWS IN THE MID 60S. SOUTH WINDS 5
TO 10 MPH. 
.THURSDAY...PARTLY CLOUDY. HIGHS IN THE MID 80S. SOUTH WINDS 5 TO 10
MPH. 
.THURSDAY NIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY. LOWS IN THE MID 60S. 
.FRIDAY...PARTLY CLOUDY. SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS.
HIGHS IN THE MID 80S. CHANCE OF RAIN 20 PERCENT. 
.FRIDAY NIGHT...PARTLY CLOUDY IN THE EVENING...THEN BECOMING MOSTLY
CLOUDY. CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. LOWS IN THE LOWER 60S.
CHANCE OF RAIN 40 PERCENT. 
.SATURDAY...MOSTLY CLOUDY IN THE MORNING...THEN BECOMING PARTLY
CLOUDY. CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. HIGHS IN THE UPPER 70S.
CHANCE OF RAIN 50 PERCENT.

SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN THE EVENING. LOWS
AROUND 60. CHANCE OF RAIN 20 PERCENT. 
.SUNDAY...MOSTLY SUNNY IN THE MORNING...THEN BECOMING PARTLY CLOUDY.


382 
FXUS64 KLZK 191700
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1055 AM CDT TUE OCT 19 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATES ON THE WAY THIS MORNING. QUITE THE RANGE OF CONDITIONS 
ACROSS THE CWA THIS MORNING WITH LOW CLOUDS AND FOG TO THE 
NORTH...CLEAR SKIES OVER THE WEST AND VERY HUMID AIR OVER THE SOUTH. 
LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES THE SURFACE FRONT FROM JONESBORO TO 
RUSSELLVILLE TO WALDRON WITH VERY LITTLE MOVEMENT NOTED. TEMPERATURE 
GRADIENT ACROSS THE BOUNDARY 25 DEGREES WITH DEW POINT GRADIENT OF 
20 DEGREES. 

SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS STILL OCCURRING OVER THE SOUTH IN THE WARM 
SECTOR AND EXPECTING THIS ACTIVITY TO CONTINUE. ACTIVITY WILL LIKELY 
INCREASE THROUGH THE AFTERNOON OVER THE SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ALONG 
AND AHEAD OF THE FRONT AS SPEED MAX LIFTS OUT OF TEXAS. 12Z SOUNDING 
FROM LZK SHOWING A VERY UNSTABLE AIRMASS. CURRENT SATELLITE SHOWING 
NUMEROUS BREAKS OVER MOST THE AREA WHICH WILL ONLY DESTABILIZE THE 
WARM SECTOR EVEN MORE. SOUNDING ALSO SHOWING PLENTY OF SPEED SHEER 
BUT NOT MUCH IN THE WAY OF DIRECTIONAL SHEER.

PLENTY OF LOW CLOUDS AND FOG ACROSS THE NORTHERN TIER OF COUNTIES 
WITH A SUBTLE BUT NOTICEABLE DRIFT TO THE SOUTH. HAVE ADDED LOW 
CLOUDS AND FOG HERE AND EXPECT IT TO CONTINUE MOST OF THE AFTERNOON.

HAVE BOOSTED POPS ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST AND ADDED SMALL POPS TO MOST 
OF THE CENTRAL SECTIONS. OTHER CHANGES INCLUDED MODIFYING THE GRIDS 
TO REFLECT CURRENT TEMPERATURE...DEW POINT...HUMIDITY AND CLOUD 
COVER TRENDS. UPDATES OUT SHORTLY.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



678 
FXUS64 KLZK 190855
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT TUE OCT 19 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY
AREA OF THUNDERSTORMS HAS SHIFTED TO THE EAST OF THE CWA AT FORECAST 
TIME. SOME DEVELOPMENT HAS OCCURRED IN EASTERN TEXAS WHICH HAS 
SPREAD INTO EXTREME SOUTHWESTERN ARKANSAS. LOOKS LIKE MAIN AXIS OF
PRECIPITATION WILL BE IN SOUTHEASTERN ARKANSAS TODAY WITH DRIER 
AIR IN PLACE TO THE NORTHWEST. A DRY LINE/WEAK FRONT IS IN 
NORTHWESTERN ARKANSAS. MODELS IN DISAGREEMENT ON THE BEHAVIOR OF
THIS FRONT OVER THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS. UPPER RIDGING WILL 
INCREASE OVER THE AREA WEDNESDAY INTO THURSDAY AND THIS SUGGESTS
THE COOLER AND DRIER AIR WILL STAY TO THE NORTH. THUS WENT MORE WITH
THE WARMER GUIDANCE FOR TEMP FORECASTS OVER THE NEXT THREE DAYS BUT
DID SHADE DOWN A LITTLE IN THE NORTH. WENT WITH 30 PERCENT POPS IN 
THE SOUTHEAST FOR TODAY AND 20 PERCENT IN SOUTH 
CENTRAL...CENTRAL...AND EASTERN SECTIONS FOR TODAY. CHANCES OF RAIN 
SHOULD DECREASE WITH LOSS OF HEATING AND ONLY KEPT SMALL POPS IN THE 
FAR SOUTHEAST FOR TONIGHT. WITH UPPER RIDGING BUILDING IN ON 
WEDNESDAY AND NO SIGNIFICANT FORCING THE ATMOSPHERE SHOULD BECOME 
CAPPED AND DROPPED MENTION OF RAIN THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT. UPPER 
TROF TO THE WEST WILL APPROACH FRIDAY AND A COLD FRONT WILL MOVE 
TOWARD THE AREA. PUT IN SMALL POPS FOR FRIDAY DUE TO THIS WITH THE 
BETTER CHANCES OF RAIN LIKELY COMING AFTER FRIDAY.      
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
THE UPPER RIDGE WILL BE SLIDING EAST OF THE AREA BY FRIDAY NIGHT. 
THIS WILL ALLOW A COLD FRONT TO MOVE THROUGH THE AREA FRIDAY NIGHT 
AND SATURDAY. THE SURFACE AND UPPER LOW WILL REMAIN NORTH OF 
ARKANSAS. WITH WARM TEMPERATURES AND ABUNDANT MOISTURE AVAILABLE 
WITH THE SOUTHWEST FLOW...DECIDED TO INCREASE POPS TO HIGH CHANCE 
ACROSS THE AREA ALONG AND AHEAD OF THE FRONT. GFS IS SHOWING SOME 
STRONG DRYING BEHIND THE FRONT SATURDAY NIGHT. THEREFORE DECIDED TO 
REMOVE POPS SUNDAY MORNING. WILL PROGRESS THE SLIGHT CHANCE POPS 
FROM SOUTH TO NORTH SUNDAY AFTERNOON. THE FRONT MAY STALL IN 
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS BEFORE MOVING BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT. 
SUNDAY NIGHT INTO MONDAY. 

TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL THROUGH THE EXTENDED 
PERIOD WITH HIGHS MAINLY IN THE 70S AND A FEW 80S SOUTH. DEW POINTS 
WILL REMAIN IN THE 50S AND 60S. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    85  62  84  62 /  20  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       81  56  78  58 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    85  63  85  62 /  20  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     86  65  85  64 /  30  20  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  81  56  79  58 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     87  67  86  67 /  30  20  10  10 
SEARCY AR         84  60  83  61 /  20  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      85  63  84  62 /  20  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   84  60  83  60 /  20  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&


259 
FXUS64 KLZK 182019
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
320 PM CDT MON OCT 18 2004

.DISCUSSION...
PLENTY OF ACTIVE WEATHER THIS MORNING...WITH NUMEROUS WARNINGS 
ISSUED. STORM SURVEYS BEING CONDUCTED THIS AFTERNOON FOR DAMAGE SEEN 
IN SALINE COUNTY.

WARM FRONT IN SOUTHERN MISSOURI...WITH A DRY LINE IN EASTERN 
OKLAHOMA. DRY LINE WILL MOVE EAST LATE THIS AFTERNOON/EARLY TONIGHT. 
ANOTHER ROUND OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL DEVELOP THIS 
EVENING...BUT NOT LOOKING AT WIDESPREAD SEVERE WEATHER. COULD SEE 
SOME HEAVY RAINFALL AGAIN...ESPECIALLY IN THE SOUTHWEST...BUT DUE TO 
UNCERTAINTY...HAVE NOT INCLUDED IN ZONES. DID INCREASE QPF AMOUNTS 
THOUGH.

ACTIVITY WILL MOVE TO THE EAST/NORTHEAST TUESDAY AS UPPER TROUGH 
MOVES INTO THE GREAT LAKES REGION. KEPT SOME POPS IN THE 
EAST/SOUTHEAST...DECREASING IN THE AFTERNOON AND EVENING HOURS.

DECREASED POPS WEDNESDAY...AS UPPER RIDGE MOVES OVERHEAD AND 
MOISTURE IS LIMITED.. DID NOT FEEL CONFIDENT PULLING POPS ALL 
TOGETHER...BUT SHOWED A DOWNWARD TREND. KEPT CHANCE POPS GOING FOR 
THURSDAY...BUT THESE MAY NEED TO BE DECREASED AS WELL.

NEXT SYSTEM MOVES INTO THE STATE FRIDAY...WITH COLD FRONT ENTERING 
LATE FRIDAY AFTERNOON. WITH THE LOW PRESSURE CENTER HEADING TO THE 
NORTHEAST...NOT A LOT OF SUPPORT WITH THIS SYSTEM IN REGARDS TO 
SEVERE WEATHER. STILL ENOUGH LIFT FOR CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. FRONT MOVES THROUGH THE STATE SATURDAY...BUT WILL 
MOVE BACK NORTH ON SUNDAY. DRY WEATHER IN THE FORECAST FOR MONDAY AS 
UPPER RIDGE MOVES NORTH.

TEMPS WILL BE TRICKY DEPENDING ON CLOUD COVER...BUT FOR THE MOST 
PART WILL BE ABOVE NORMAL. READINGS WILL BEGIN TO COOL DOWN WITH 
COLD FRONT SATURDAY...BEFORE CLIMBING AGAIN WITH WARM FRONT ON 
SUNDAY.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    65  84  64  84 /  30  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       59  82  57  82 /  30  10  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    65  85  64  85 /  30  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     67  84  65  85 /  40  30  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  59  81  57  81 /  30  10  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     68  84  66  85 /  50  30  20  20 
SEARCY AR         64  83  62  83 /  40  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      65  85  63  85 /  30  20  10  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   63  83  61  84 /  30  20  10  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

928 
FXUS64 KLZK 180844
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT MON OCT 18 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY
WARM FRONT IN SOUTHERN ARKANSAS HAS MOVED NORTH AND MAY BE 
DISSIPATING WITH A NEW WARM FRONT DEVELOPING TO THE NORTH. 
A WARM HUMID AND UNSTABLE AIR MASS WILL DEVELOP ACROSS THE 
AREA TODAY AND WILL CONTINUE THROUGH MOST OF THE WEEK. ONE
SHORT WAVE MOVING THROUGH THE AREA THIS MORNING MAY RESULT
IN THUNDERSTORMS THIS MORNING WHICH MAY WEAKEN/DECREASE DURING 
THE MORNING. NEW THUNDERSTORMS COULD DEVELOP THIS AFTERNOON 
AFTER SOME HEATING AND A WEAK DRY LINE MAY MOVE INTO WESTERN 
SECTIONS. INSTABILITY AND SHEAR PRESENT WILL SUPPORT CHANCE OF 
SEVERE STORMS BUT WILL NOT PUT SEVERE WORDING IN ZONES BUT WILL
PLAY UP IN HWO AND WEATHER SUMMARY. HAVE POPS IN CHANCE CATEGORY
IN EAST AND SLIGHT CHANCE IN WEST BASICALLY TODAY AND TONIGHT.
DECREASED POPS A LITTLE FOR AWHILE AROUND MID MORNING TODAY. 
SURFACE LOW BELOW 1000 MB IN SOUTHEASTERN KANSAS THIS MORNING
SHOULD FILL SOMEWHAT AS IT MOVES NORTHEAST. THE PRESENCE OF THE
LOW THAT STRONG SUGGESTS WINDS COULD REACH LAKE WIND ADVISORY 
LEVELS DURING TODAY. WILL GO WITH ADVISORY FROM MID MORNING
THROUGH LATE AFTERNOON ALTHOUGH CLOUDS MAY BE ENOUGH TO HOLD
WINDS BELOW THREASHOLD. WINDS SHOULD DIMINISH LATE THIS AFTERNOON
AND EVENING AS THE FILLING LOWS PULLS AWAY FROM THE AREA. MAIN
MOISTURE AXIS PUSHES TO THE EAST TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY THEN MAY
DEVELOP A LITTLE BACK TO THE WEST. UPPER RIDGING MAY CAP ATMOSPHERE
AND NO SIGNIFICANT SHORT WAVES SUGGEST CHANCES FOR RAIN WILL
BE LOW...BUT THE UNSTABLE AIR MASS PRESENT STILL PRESENTS A CHANCE
OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WITH SOME SEVERE POSSIBLE. GENERALLY
KEP POPS AS THEY WERE FROM TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY. GFS BRINGS 
BLOB OF MOISTURE ACROSS THE AREA WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY. 
NO REAL SHORT WAVE OR FRONT IS INDICATED WITH IT BUT WE ALREADY HAVE
ENHANCED POPS OUT FOR THAT TIME PERIOD...SO LEFT THEM GOING. TEMPS
SHOULD SETTLE INTO MINS IN THE LOWER TO MID 60S FOR THE MOST PART
WITH MAXES IN THE LOWER TO MID 80S. THERE MAY BE A WEAK COLD FRONT
MOVE THROUGH THE AREA LATE TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY WHICH COULD 
BRING SLIGHTLY COOLER AND DRIER AIR TO PARTS OF THE AREA AND 
MADE A SLIGHT DOWNWARD ADJUSTMENT TO TEMPS AND DEW POINTS FOR THAT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD ACROSS THE AREA THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY. 
HOWEVER...ACTIVE WEATHER WILL BE THE GENERAL RULE THROUGH THE 
EXTENDED PERIOD. SEVERAL SHORT WAVES WILL WORK THEIR WAY THROUGH THE 
REGION BRINGING CHANCES FOR SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. CHANCE FOR 
THUNDERSTORMS INCREASES ON SATURDAY AS A COLD FRONT MOVES IN FROM 
THE NORTHWEST. STRONG SOUTHERLY WINDS WILL BRING ABUNDANT MOISTURE 
AND ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES TO THE AREA. THE UPPER LOW AND SURFACE 
LOW ASSOCIATED WITH THE COLD FRONT WILL TRACK NORTH OF ARKANSAS. 
THIS WILL BE TOO FAR NORTH FOR WIDESPREAD SEVERE STORMS IN 
ARKANSAS...AS IT STANDS NOW. 

THE COLD FRONT STALLS IN SOUTHERN ARKANSAS SATURDAY NIGHT THEN 
BEGINS MOVING BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT. THIS WILL AGAIN 
BRING MORE SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO THE AREA. AS THE FRONT MOVES 
NORTH...THE BEST CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION WILL BE IN NORTH ARKANSAS 
SUNDAY NIGHT. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  64  84  61 /  40  30  20  20 
HARRISON AR       81  58  81  57 /  30  20  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  64  85  62 /  30  30  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     84  66  84  63 /  40  30  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  79  58  80  57 /  40  20  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     83  67  84  65 /  40  30  30  20 
SEARCY AR         81  63  83  60 /  40  30  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      84  64  85  62 /  30  20  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   82  62  83  60 /  30  20  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...LAKE WIND ADVISORY TODAY ENTIRE 
AREA...ARZ003>007...ARZ012>016...ARZ021>025...ARZ030>034...
ARZ037>047...ARZ052>057...ARZ062>069. 
&&

$$

29/51








000 
FXUS64 KLZK 180844
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT MON OCT 18 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY
WARM FRONT IN SOUTHERN ARKANSAS HAS MOVED NORTH AND MAY BE 
DISSIPATING WITH A NEW WARM FRONT DEVELOPING TO THE NORTH. 
A WARM HUMID AND UNSTABLE AIR MASS WILL DEVELOP ACROSS THE 
AREA TODAY AND WILL CONTINUE THROUGH MOST OF THE WEEK. ONE
SHORT WAVE MOVING THROUGH THE AREA THIS MORNING MAY RESULT
IN THUNDERSTORMS THIS MORNING WHICH MAY WEAKEN/DECREASE DURING 
THE MORNING. NEW THUNDERSTORMS COULD DEVELOP THIS AFTERNOON 
AFTER SOME HEATING AND A WEAK DRY LINE MAY MOVE INTO WESTERN 
SECTIONS. INSTABILITY AND SHEAR PRESENT WILL SUPPORT CHANCE OF 
SEVERE STORMS BUT WILL NOT PUT SEVERE WORDING IN ZONES BUT WILL
PLAY UP IN HWO AND WEATHER SUMMARY. HAVE POPS IN CHANCE CATEGORY
IN EAST AND SLIGHT CHANCE IN WEST BASICALLY TODAY AND TONIGHT.
DECREASED POPS A LITTLE FOR AWHILE AROUND MID MORNING TODAY. 
SURFACE LOW BELOW 1000 MB IN SOUTHEASTERN KANSAS THIS MORNING
SHOULD FILL SOMEWHAT AS IT MOVES NORTHEAST. THE PRESENCE OF THE
LOW THAT STRONG SUGGESTS WINDS COULD REACH LAKE WIND ADVISORY 
LEVELS DURING TODAY. WILL GO WITH ADVISORY FROM MID MORNING
THROUGH LATE AFTERNOON ALTHOUGH CLOUDS MAY BE ENOUGH TO HOLD
WINDS BELOW THREASHOLD. WINDS SHOULD DIMINISH LATE THIS AFTERNOON
AND EVENING AS THE FILLING LOWS PULLS AWAY FROM THE AREA. MAIN
MOISTURE AXIS PUSHES TO THE EAST TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY THEN MAY
DEVELOP A LITTLE BACK TO THE WEST. UPPER RIDGING MAY CAP ATMOSPHERE
AND NO SIGNIFICANT SHORT WAVES SUGGEST CHANCES FOR RAIN WILL
BE LOW...BUT THE UNSTABLE AIR MASS PRESENT STILL PRESENTS A CHANCE
OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WITH SOME SEVERE POSSIBLE. GENERALLY
KEP POPS AS THEY WERE FROM TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY. GFS BRINGS 
BLOB OF MOISTURE ACROSS THE AREA WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY. 
NO REAL SHORT WAVE OR FRONT IS INDICATED WITH IT BUT WE ALREADY HAVE
ENHANCED POPS OUT FOR THAT TIME PERIOD...SO LEFT THEM GOING. TEMPS
SHOULD SETTLE INTO MINS IN THE LOWER TO MID 60S FOR THE MOST PART
WITH MAXES IN THE LOWER TO MID 80S. THERE MAY BE A WEAK COLD FRONT
MOVE THROUGH THE AREA LATE TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY WHICH COULD 
BRING SLIGHTLY COOLER AND DRIER AIR TO PARTS OF THE AREA AND 
MADE A SLIGHT DOWNWARD ADJUSTMENT TO TEMPS AND DEW POINTS FOR THAT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD ACROSS THE AREA THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY. 
HOWEVER...ACTIVE WEATHER WILL BE THE GENERAL RULE THROUGH THE 
EXTENDED PERIOD. SEVERAL SHORT WAVES WILL WORK THEIR WAY THROUGH THE 
REGION BRINGING CHANCES FOR SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. CHANCE FOR 
THUNDERSTORMS INCREASES ON SATURDAY AS A COLD FRONT MOVES IN FROM 
THE NORTHWEST. STRONG SOUTHERLY WINDS WILL BRING ABUNDANT MOISTURE 
AND ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES TO THE AREA. THE UPPER LOW AND SURFACE 
LOW ASSOCIATED WITH THE COLD FRONT WILL TRACK NORTH OF ARKANSAS. 
THIS WILL BE TOO FAR NORTH FOR WIDESPREAD SEVERE STORMS IN 
ARKANSAS...AS IT STANDS NOW. 

THE COLD FRONT STALLS IN SOUTHERN ARKANSAS SATURDAY NIGHT THEN 
BEGINS MOVING BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT. THIS WILL AGAIN 
BRING MORE SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO THE AREA. AS THE FRONT MOVES 
NORTH...THE BEST CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION WILL BE IN NORTH ARKANSAS 
SUNDAY NIGHT. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  64  84  61 /  40  30  20  20 
HARRISON AR       81  58  81  57 /  30  20  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  64  85  62 /  30  30  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     84  66  84  63 /  40  30  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  79  58  80  57 /  40  20  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     83  67  84  65 /  40  30  30  20 
SEARCY AR         81  63  83  60 /  40  30  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      84  64  85  62 /  30  20  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   82  62  83  60 /  30  20  10  10

29/51








657 
FXUS64 KLZK 180247
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
948 PM CDT SUN OCT 17 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LATEST SEVERE WEATHER OUTLOOK FROM SPC INCREASES THE SLIGHT RISK 
AREA OVERNIGHT TO INCLUDE PARTS OF SOUTH CENTRAL ARKANSAS ALSO. 
UPDATED FORECASTS TO INCREASE AREA OF SEVERE MENTION. ALSO WARM 
FRONT IS NOT MOVING NORTHWARD QUITE AS FAST AS EARLIER EXPECTED...SO 
LOWERED MINIMUM TEMPERATURES DOWN A CATEGORY OR SO...ESPECIALLY OVER 
CENTRAL AND NORTHERN ARKANSAS. ALL UPDATES GONE. 
&&



.PREV DISCUSSION...
WARM FRONT QUITE EVIDENT OVER SRN AR THIS AFTN...WITH SFC DEWPOINTS 
APCHG 70F ALONG THE AR/LA BRDR. MEANWHILE...DRIER AIR STILL IN PLACE 
OVER NRN AR WHERE DEWPOINTS STILL IN THE 40S. HAVE SEEN A FEW 
SHOWERS FORM N OF THE BNDRY OVER CNTRL AND SRN SECTIONS.

HAVE CONTD TO FOLLOW ALONG WITH THE ETA SOLUTION FOR THE SHORT TERM 
FCST PD. WARM FRONT WL CONT TO TRACK SLOLY NWD TNGT AND EARLY ON 
MON. EXPECT MIN TEMPS TO OCCUR EARLY TNGT N OF THE BNDRY AND HAVE 
INDCD THIS IN THE HOURLY GRID TEMPS. LOOKING AT STEADY TEMPS TNGT 
FOR LOCATIONS S OF THE FNT.

PRIMARY CONCERN FOR TNGT AND MON CONTS TO BE CONVECTIVE TRENDS. 
INCRSG WAA AND LLJ LATER THIS EVENING WILL ALLOW FOR SHRA/TSRA TO 
FORM ALONG AND N OF THE ADVANCING WARM FRONT. HAVE CONTD WITH 
HIGHEST POPS /MAINLY CHC CAT/ OVR THE NRN AND ERN PARTS OF THE FA 
TNGT AND INTO MON. WITH MOST OF THE STORMS EXPECTED TO BE 
ELEVATED...LARGE HAIL APPEARS TO BE THE PRIMARY SVR WX THREAT.

WARM AND UNSTABLE AIRMASS WILL RMN IN PLACE ACRS AR THRU MIDWEEK. 
W-SWLY FLOW ALOFT WL KEEP AND SFC FNTS AWAY FROM THE AREA THRU THE 
PD. HOWEVER...WILL KEEP RAIN CHCS IN THE FCST THE NEXT FEW DAYS AS 
WEAK IMPULSES IN THE UPPER FLOW WILL BE ENOUGH TO TRIGGER A FEW 
SHOWERS OR STORMS.

HAVE USED A BLEND OF THE VARIOUS MODEL TEMP OUTPUT FOR MAX AND MIN 
TEMPS IN THE SHORT TERM.

ACTIVE WEATHER PATTERN STILL APPEARS LIKELY DURING THE LONG TERM 
PERIODS. STRENGTHENING OF 500 MB RIDGE OVER THE SERN STATES/GULF 
COAST WILL ACT AS A BLOCK FOR FORWARD MOVING SURFACE SYSTEMS. STRONG 
SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW ALOFT WILL BRING UPPER LEVEL IMPULSES UP THROUGH 
THE FORECAST AREA FREQUENTLY. 

THE SURFACE AND UPPER SYSTEMS WILL INTERACT...AND WHEN COMBINED WITH 
DAYTIME HEATING THIS WILL INITIATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. CONVECTION LIKELY TO INITIATE DURING LATE 
MORNING/EARLY AFTERNOON THEN DIE OFF OVERNIGHT. SCENARIO APPEARS 
POSSIBLE SEVERAL DAYS AS AREA DEALS WITH SEVERAL MESOSCALE AND 
SYNOPTIC SCALE BOUNDARIES LINGERING AROUND THE LOWER/MID MS VALLEY.

AS WAS MENTIONED YESTERDAY...IT IS ALWAYS DIFFICULT TO TIME 
INDIVIDUAL FEATURES AND BOUNDARIES THIS FAR OUT. HOWEVER...
INSTABILITY PARAMETERS...PRESENCE OF LIFTING MECHANISMS...AND AMPLE 
UPPER SUPPORT SUGGEST THE POTENTIAL FOR STRONG THUNDERSTORMS...
PARTICULARLY DURING THE FRIDAY AFTERNOON/NIGHT TIME FRAME AS COLD 
FRONT MOVES INTO WESTERN ARKANSAS. THAT BEING SAID...ONE THING THAT 
COULD LIMIT THIS POTENTIAL WOULD BE INHIBITION OF DAYTIME HEATING 
DUE TO CLOUD COVER. OF COURSE...THINGS COULD AND MAY CHANGE BETWEEN 
NOW AND THEN...BUT IT IS SOMETHING WE WILL KEEP AN EYE ON. 

APPEARS THAT COLD FRONT WILL STALL SOMEWHERE INVOF CENTRAL/SRN 
ARKANSAS INTO WRN TENNESSEE/NRN MISSISSIPPI. NORTHWESTERN HALF OF 
THE AREA WILL SEE A BREAK IN THE ACTION SATURDAY/EARLY SUNDAY AS 
SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE SCOOTS BY TO THE NORTH. BY SUNDAY...UPPER 
RIDGE APPEARS TO RETROGRADE A BIT...YUP...PUSHING THE FRONT BACK TO 
THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT. 

AND I THOUGHT THIS WAS FALL...

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

ARKANSAS INTO WRN TENNESSEE/NRN MISSISSIPPI. NORTHWESTERN HALF OF 
THE AREA WILL SEE A BREAK IN THE ACTION SATURDAY/EARLY SUNDAY AS 
SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE SCOOTS BY TO THE NORTH. BY SUNDAY...UPPER 
RIDGE APPEARS TO RETROGRADE A BIT...YUP...PUSHING THE FRONT BACK TO 
THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT. 

AND I THOUGHT THIS WAS FALL...
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



971 
FXUS64 KLZK 170817
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT SUN OCT 17 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
FRONTAL SYSTEM JUST SOUTH OF THE BORDER WILL BE POISED TO MOVE BACK
NORTH AS A WARM FRONT LATER TODAY AND TONIGHT AS WEAK SURFACE HIGH 
PRESSURE SHIFTS TO THE EAST AND RETURN FLOW BEGINS OVER THE AREA. 
THE WARM ADVECTION ASSOCIATED WITH THE PATTERN MAY BE ENOUGH TO SET 
OFF SOME SHOWERS TODAY SO WILL PUT IN SMALL POPS MOSTLY IN THE SOUTH
THIS MORNING CLOSER TO THE WARM FRONT THEN SPREAD SMALL POPS OVER ALL
BUT THE NORTH BY LATE AFTERNOON. AS THE AIR DESTABILIZES THIS AFTERNOON
A THUNDERSTORM OR TWO MAY DEVELOP. WENT WITH ISOLATED WORDING IN THE
ZONES FOR TODAY AS COVERAGE SHOULD NOT BE VERY GREAT. A WEAK SHORT 
WAVE MOVES INTO THE AREA LATER TONIGHT AND THE WARM FRONT SHOULD 
BECOME MORE PRONOUNCED AS IT MOVES INTO NORTHERN AREAS AND THEN MOVES
INTO MISSOURI. THIS SHOULD RESULT IN AN INCREASING CHANCE OF RAIN
BUT THIS WILL BE REALIZED MORE IN THE NORTH CLOSER TO THE WARM 
FRONT. WENT UP TO 50 PERCENT IN THE NORTH FOR TONIGHT BUT KEPT POPS
AT 20 PERCENT IN THE SOUTHWEST. AVAILABLE INSTABILITY FROM DEW POINTS
INTO THE 60S AND RATHER STRONG JET DYNAMICS WILL POSE A THREAT FOR
SEVERE STORMS BUT THIS LOOKS LIKE IT WILL BE GREATEST ALONG AND
A LITTLE NORTH OF THE WARM FRONT AND MAY ONLY AFFECT SOME NORTHERN 
COUNTIES IN THE CWA. STORMS MAY STILL BE ELEVATED IN NATURE WHICH 
SHOULD CUT DOWN ON SEVERE COVERAGE SO WILL NOT PLAY UP SEVERE IN
ZONES. ON MONDAY THE WARM FRONT SHOULD BE OUT OF THE CWA WITH 
WARM AND RATHER HUMID AIR FOR THIS LATE IN THE SEASON TAKING OVER. 
A WEAK DRY LINE MAY MOVE INTO THE AREA AND A WEAK SHORT WAVE MAY 
ACT TO SET OFF SOME THUNDERSTORMS. THERE WILL BE ENOUGH INSTABILITY
AND WIND DYNAMICS FOR A THREAT OF SEVERE STORMS BUT THE BEST CHANCE
OF THIS AGAIN APPEARS TO BE TO THE NORTHEAST OF THE AREA. WILL NOT 
MENTION SEVERE IN THE ZONES FOR MONDAY OR MONDAY NIGHT AT THIS 
TIME. RATHER STRONG GUSTY WINDS MAY DEVELOP IN RESPONSE TO A DEEP
SURFACE LOW TO THE NORTHWEST AND LAKE WIND ADVISORIES MAY BE 
REQUIRED. WARM HUMID AND UNSTABLE AIR WILL REMAIN IN PLACE 
THROUGH WEDNESDAY. NO SIGNIFICANT FRONTS OR SHORT WAVES ARE 
INDICATED BUT WILL KEEP SOME MENTION OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
IN THE FORECAST AS ANY WEAK SHORT WAVE COMING OUT OF THE ZONAL TO
SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WOULD BE ENOUGH TO SET OFF SOME ACTIVITY. 
MAX TEMPS FOR TODAY WILL DEPEND A LOT ON THE BEHAVIOR OF THE 
WARM FRONT AND THE WARM ADVECTION CLOUDS IN PACE. THE MOS 
PACKAGES DIVERGE ON MAX FORECASTS FOR TODAY AND WILL GO ABOUT
IN THE MIDDLE OF THE POSSIBILITIES. FROM TONIGHT THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY...CONFIDENCE IS MUCH STRONGER THAT A WARM AND HUMID
AIR MASS WILL BE IN PLACE SO WILL GO WITH MINS MOSTLY IN THE
60S AND MAXES MOSTLY IN THE LOWER TO MID 80S.    
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
LONG WAVE CROSSING THE ROCKIES STARTS OUT VERY IMPRESSIVE AT 00Z 
THURSDAY...THEN BY 00Z FRIDAY THE NORTHERN END TAKES OVER WHILE THE 
SOUTHERN END LAGS BEHIND AND WEAKENS. THERE WILL BE ENOUGH ENERGY 
LEFT TO PUSH A COLD FRONT ACROSS THE STATE AND TO BRING VERY DRY AIR 
BY EARLY NEXT WEEK. THE SURFACE LOW WILL BE MOVING AWAY FROM 
ARKANSAS AS IT GATHERS STRENGTH ON FRIDAY. THIS WILL MAKE THE 
SOUTHERN END OF THE COLD FRONT SLOW TO CLEAR THE STATE...SO MOISTURE 
WILL LINGER OVER EASTERN ARKANSAS THROUGH SATURDAY MORNING. THE 
RIDGE MOVING IN FROM THE WEST WILL BE OF PACIFIC ORIGIN...AND IT 
WILL HAVE MODERATE EFFECTS ON OUR TEMPERATURES. IN FACT...LOWS AND 
HIGHS WILL BE ABOVE NORMAL DURING THE LONG TERM. POPS WILL BE IN THE 
CHANCE CATEGORY FOR NOW ALTHOUGH THERE ARE HINTS THEY MIGHT BE 
LIKELY ON FRIDAY PER THE 24-HOUR MOS. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    75  65  83  65 /  20  30  30  30 
HARRISON AR       72  60  81  61 /  10  50  40  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    76  65  83  65 /  20  20  30  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     76  65  84  66 /  20  20  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  72  60  80  61 /  10  50  40  20 
MONTICELLO AR     78  66  85  67 /  20  20  20  30 
SEARCY AR         73  62  81  64 /  20  30  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      77  65  83  65 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   74  63  82  64 /  20  30  30  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
910 PM CDT SAT OCT 16 2004

.DISCUSSION...

ONLY SUPERFICIAL CHANGES NEEDED TO THE FORECAST THIS EVENING. 
LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES THE SURFACE BOUNDARY OVER EASTERN 
TEXAS THROUGH NORTH CENTRAL LOUISIANA. BOUNDARY HAS BARELY MOVED 
THIS EVENING BUT THAT MAY BE CHANGING SOON. SATELLITE SHOWING LOW 
CLOUDS EXPANDING ACROSS SOUTHERN ARKANSAS TO THE NORTH OF THE 
BOUNDARY BUT STILL BELIEVE ONLY MINIMAL NORTHERN PUSH IS LIKELY 
TONIGHT. 

TEMPERATURES HAVE COOLED OFF TO WITHIN A FEW DEGREES OVER MOST OF 
THE NORTH AND WILL ADJUST DOWNWARD. WITH CLOUD COVER INCREASING 
OVERNIGHT...WILL ONLY TRIM A FEW MORE DEGREES OFF THE EXPECTED LOWS.
ONLY OTHER CHANGES WILL BE TO TWEAK THE CLOUD COVER...DEW POINT AND 
TEMPERATURE GRIDS TO REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS. 
&&

000 
FXUS64 KLZK 161931
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 PM CDT SAT OCT 16 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
N WINDS CONT TO ALLOW DRIER AIRMASS TO SETTLE OVER THE FA THIS AFTN. 
DEWPOINTS IN THE 30S AND LOWER 40S COMMON ATTM. SFC WINDS EXPECTED 
TO DIMINISH AFTER SUNSET...ALLOWING FOR DECENT COOLING OVERNIGHT...
ESPECIALLY IN THE VALLEY AREAS OF NRN AND W-CNTRL AR.

THE COOL AND DRY WX OVER AR WILL BE SHORT-LIVED AS WE TRANSITION TO 
A SPRINGLIKE PATTERN IN THE COMING DAYS. ETA HAS CONTD TO SHOW GOOD 
RUN TO RUN CONSISTENCY IN THE SHORT TERM AND WL FOLLOW CLOSER TO 
IT/S SOLUTION. 

SFC HIGH WILL SHIFT EWD BY SUN...ALLOWING OLD SFC BNDRY TO BEGIN 
WORKING SLOLY NWD AS A WRMFNT. BNDRY EXPECTED INTO SRN AR BY MIDDAY 
SUN AND INTO CNTRL AR SUNDAY EVENING. COULD SEE A FEW SHRA/TSRA FORM 
ON SUN JUST N OF THE BNDRY WHERE WAA AND LIFT WL BE FOCUSED...MAINLY 
OVER SRN AR. HAVE BASED TEMP FCST FOR SUN AND SUN NIGHT ON THIS 
TIMING OF THE BNDRY. LOOKS LIKE SUN NIGHT LOWS MAY OCCUR EARLY IN 
THE EVENING DEPENDING ON LOCATION OF WRMFNT. S OF THE BNDRY...HAVE 
WORKED HOURLY GRIDS TO INDC STEADY TEMPS SUN NIGHT.

WRMFNT PROGGED TO BE OVER NERN AR MON MRNG AND CONT LIFTING SLOLY 
NWD DURG THE AFTN HRS. HAVE KEPT CHC POPS FOCUSED ALONG AND N OF THE 
BNDRY FOR MON...WITH SLGT CHC POPS ELSEWHERE.

FA IS EXPECTED TO BE IN THE WARM AND HUMID AIRMASS BY MON NIGHT. 
EXPECT A GOOD BIT OF LOW CLOUDS...ESP DURG THE OVERNIGHT AND EARLY 
MRNG HRS MON AND TUE. SEVERAL WEAK IMPULSES ALOFT WILL ALSO AFFECT 
THE FA DURG THE LATTER HALF OF THE PD...SO HAVE LEFT SMALL RAIN CHCS 
IN THE FCST FOR MOST LOCATIONS.

HAVE GENERALLY GONE WITH A BLEND OF THE ETA AND GFS MOS TEMPS FOR 
MOST PDS. EXTENDED BREAKS IN THE CLOUDS WL LIKELY PLAY HAVOC WITH 
MAX TEMPS ON TUE.
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
MODEL SOLUTIONS INDICATE ACTIVE WEATHER PATTERN IN THE LONG TERM 
PERIODS. 500 MB RIDGE WILL CONTINUE BUILDING OVER THE EASTERN UNITED 
STATES...WITH TROUGH SETTING UP OVER THE SOUTHWEST. APPROACHING 
SURFACE FRONT WILL COME INTO PLAY BY WEDNESDAY...WITH PROGRESS 
HINDERED AND EVENTUALLY STOPPED BY THE RIDGE. 

WHAT THIS MEANS FOR ARKANSAS IS A SLOW MOVING/STALLED SURFACE 
BOUNDARY INVOF THE CENTRAL PORTION OF THE STATE FOR SEVERAL DAYS. 
MODELS INDICATE AFTERNOON AND EVENING SHOWER AND THUNDERSTORM 
DEVELOPMENT AS UPPER WAVES MOVE UP IN THE MEAN FLOW AND INTERACT 
WITH THE SYSTEM. ACTIVITY WILL LIKELY WANE DURING THE LATE 
NIGHT...AND REDEVELOP THE FOLLOWING AFTERNOON. THIS SCENARIO COULD 
CONTINUE INTO THE NEXT WEEKEND...WHEN POTENT UPPER TROUGH SWINGS 
DOWN IN STRENGTHENING NORTHWESTERLY FLOW AND PUSHES THE SURFACE 
SYSTEM EASTWARD. 

WITH THE AFOREMENTIONED PATTERN SETTING UP...AND CONSIDERING THE 
TIME OF YEAR...IT WOULD NOT SURPRISE ME IF WE SEE A STRONG STORM OR 
TWO DURING THE MIDDLE/END OF THE WORK WEEK. SURFACE BASED 
INSTABILITY WILL BE PRESENT...AND UPPER JET DYNAMICS WILL BE IN 
PLACE AS WELL. OF COURSE...THIS FAR OUT...THINGS ARE ALWAYS HARD TO 
PIN DOWN AS TIMING ISSUES COME INTO PLAY. HOWEVER...IT IS SOMETHING 
WE WILL KEEP AN EYE ON. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

485 
FXUS64 KLZK 161136
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
635 AM CDT SAT OCT 16 2004

.DISCUSSION...
COLD FRONT HAS MOVED THROUGH THE AREA. A SMALL AREA OF LIGHT RAIN
BEHIND THE FRONT HAS PERSISTED ACROSS CENTRAL SECTIONS THROUGH THE 
EARLY MORNING AND HAS SHOWN LITTLE SIGN OF MOVING. UPDATED TO PUT IN 
SLIGHT CHANCE OF LIGHT RAIN FOR THIS MORNING IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH.
ALSO SATELLITE CONTINUES TO SHOW CONSIDERABLE MIDDLE AND HIGH CLOUDS
ACROSS THE AREA SO INCREASED CLOUD COVER FOR THIS MORNING. CLOUDS 
SHOULD THIN OUT LATER TODAY. 

.PREV DISCUSSION...
.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY
COLD FRONT SLOWLY MOVING SOUTH ACROSS THE AREA WITH A WEAKENING BAND
OF LIGHT RAIN BEHIND IT. THIS WILL BRING A REINFORCEMENT OF COOL AND
DRY AIR TO THE AREA FOR TODAY BUT IT SHOULD BE SHORT LIVED AS WEAK 
HIGH PRESSURE SLIPS TO THE EAST BY TONIGHT AND RETURN FLOW WILL SET
UP BY SUNDAY. A WARM FRONT MAY DEVELOP SOMEWHERE IN THE AREA AS THE
RETURN FLOW DEVELOPS ON SUNDAY AND BY MONDAY...THE AREA WILL BE 
IN A WARM HUMID AND UNSTABLE AIR MASS A LITTLE MORE TYPICAL OF 
SUMMER. THIS WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE SHORT TERM. QUITE A BIT OF 
CLOUDINESS IS OVER THE AREA EARLY THIS MORNING BUT THIS SHOULD 
DECREASE SOME TODAY AND PARTLY CLOUDY WORDING SHOULD BE GOOD. 
CHANCES OF RAIN BY 12Z SHOULD DECREASE ENOUGH TO NOT NEED MENTION
OF RAIN IN THE FORECAST. MAXES WILL LIKELY BE A LITTLE COOLER THAN
ON FRIDAY WITH MOST AREAS IN THE 60S. TONIGHT SHOULD BE RATHER
COOL BUT NOT AS COLD AS THURSDAY NIGHT DUE TO THE QUICK TRANSITION
TOWARD RETURN FLOW. MOST AREAS SHOULD DROP INTO THE MID AND UPPER
40S HOWEVER. WARM ADVECTION BEGINS TO DEVLOP SUNDAY BUT IT LOOKS
LIKE IT WILL BE INSUFFICIENT FOR A MENTION OF RAIN DURING THE DAY.
WILL TREND TOWARD THE COOLER MAXES OF MAV AND MET FOR NOW AS THE
WARM HUMID AIR MASS WILL JUST BE STARTING TO DEVELOP AND ANY WARM 
FRONT THAT DEVELOPS MAY WELL BE IN SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF THE CWA
IF NOT FARTHER SOUTH. BETTER WARM ADVECTION SUNDAY NIGHT WILL LEAD
ME TO KEEP CHANCE POPS GOING WITH SLIGHTLY HIGHER POPS TO THE NORTH
WHERE THE WARM ADVECTION AND ISENTROPIC LIFT SHOULD BE STRONGER. 
THIS WILL HOLD MINS UP WITH MOST AREAS STAYING IN THE 60S. MAXES
MONDAY AND TUESDAY COULD BE MOSTLY IN THE LOWER 80S ALTHOUGH MORNING
STRATUS COLD HANG IN AND KEEP TEMPS DOWN A LITTLE.  
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
UNEVENTFUL SOUTHWEST FLOW OVER THE STATE THROUGH 00Z THU. THEN THE 
TROF DIGGING INTO THE SOUTHWEST PART OF THE COUNTRY CROSSES THE 
ROCKIES AND APPROACHES ARKANSAS THURSDAY MORNING. THE LOW WILL 
REPEAT THE BEHAVIOR OF THE PAST COUPLE OF SYSTEMS BY MOVING OFF TO 
THE NORTHEAST RATHER QUICKLY AND WEAKENING AT THE SAME TIME. ANOTHER 
WEAK SHORT WAVE WILL BE POISED TO AFFECT THE STATE JUST PAST THE 
PERIOD COVERED BY THIS FORECAST. TUESDAY NIGHT WILL SEE MOISTURE 
RETURNING FROM THE SOUTH...WITH SMALL POPS LINGERING INTO WEDNESDAY. 
THEN BY THURSDAY MORNING THE SURFACE LOW WILL BE IN THE MKC AREA 
WHILE DRAGGING MOISTURE ACROSS ARKANSAS ALONG WITH A COLD FRONT. IN 
KEEPING WITH THE FAST FLOW ALOFT...THE COLD FRONT WILL CROSS THE 
STATE QUICKLY AS WELL...IT SHOULD BE CROSSING THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER 
BY SUNSET THURSDAY. DRY WEATHER FOR FRIDAY. BOTH THE HIGHS AND LOWS 
WILL BE ON THE WARM SIDE OF NORMAL. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    67  48  76  64 /  10  10  10  30 
HARRISON AR       63  47  73  59 /  10  10  10  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    69  51  77  64 /  10  10  10  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     68  50  78  65 /  10  10  10  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  63  47  73  59 /  10  10  10  30 
MONTICELLO AR     70  52  80  67 /  20  10  10  30 
SEARCY AR         66  47  75  62 /  10  10  10  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      69  51  77  64 /  10  10  10  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   67  49  75  62 /  10  10  10  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

EARLY MORNING AND HAS SHOWN LITTLE SIGN OF MOVING. UPDATED TO PUT IN 
SLIGHT CHANCE OF LIGHT RAIN FOR THIS MORNING IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH.
ALSO SATELLITE CONTINUES TO SHOW CONSIDERABLE MIDDLE AND HIGH CLOUDS
ACROSS THE AREA SO INCREASED CLOUD COVER FOR THIS MORNING. CLOUDS 
SHOULD THIN OUT LATER TODAY. 

.PREV DISCUSSION...
.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY
COLD FRONT SLOWLY MOVING SOUTH ACROSS THE AREA WITH A WEAKENING BAND
OF LIGHT RAIN BEHIND IT. THIS WILL BRING A REINFORCEMENT OF COOL AND
DRY AIR TO THE AREA FOR TODAY BUT IT SHOULD BE SHORT LIVED AS WEAK 
HIGH PRESSURE SLIPS TO THE EAST BY TONIGHT AND RETURN FLOW WILL SET
UP BY SUNDAY. A WARM FRONT MAY DEVELOP SOMEWHERE IN THE AREA AS THE
RETURN FLOW DEVELOPS ON SUNDAY AND BY MONDAY...THE AREA WILL BE 
IN A WARM HUMID AND UNSTABLE AIR MASS A LITTLE MORE TYPICAL OF 
SUMMER. THIS WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE SHORT TERM. QUITE A BIT OF 
CLOUDINESS IS OVER THE AREA EARLY THIS MORNING BUT THIS SHOULD 
DECREASE SOME TODAY AND PARTLY CLOUDY WORDING SHOULD BE GOOD. 
CHANCES OF RAIN BY 12Z SHOULD DECREASE ENOUGH TO NOT NEED MENTION
OF RAIN IN THE FORECAST. MAXES WILL LIKELY BE A LITTLE COOLER THAN
ON FRIDAY WITH MOST AREAS IN THE 60S. TONIGHT SHOULD BE RATHER
COOL BUT NOT AS COLD AS THURSDAY NIGHT DUE TO THE QUICK TRANSITION
TOWARD RETURN FLOW. MOST AREAS SHOULD DROP INTO THE MID AND UPPER
40S HOWEVER. WARM ADVECTION BEGINS TO DEVLOP SUNDAY BUT IT LOOKS
LIKE IT WILL BE INSUFFICIENT FOR A MENTION OF RAIN DURING THE DAY.
WILL TREND TOWARD THE COOLER MAXES OF MAV AND MET FOR NOW AS THE
WARM HUMID AIR MASS WILL JUST BE STARTING TO DEVELOP AND ANY WARM 
FRONT THAT DEVELOPS MAY WELL BE IN SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF THE CWA
IF NOT FARTHER SOUTH. BETTER WARM ADVECTION SUNDAY NIGHT WILL LEAD
ME TO KEEP CHANCE POPS GOING WITH SLIGHTLY HIGHER POPS TO THE NORTH
WHERE THE WARM ADVECTION AND ISENTROPIC LIFT SHOULD BE STRONGER. 
THIS WILL HOLD MINS UP WITH MOST AREAS STAYING IN THE 60S. MAXES
MONDAY AND TUESDAY COULD BE MOSTLY IN THE LOWER 80S ALTHOUGH MORNING
STRATUS COLD HANG IN AND KEEP TEMPS DOWN A LITTLE.  
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
UNEVENTFUL SOUTHWEST FLOW OVER THE STATE THROUGH 00Z THU. THEN THE 
TROF DIGGING INTO THE SOUTHWEST PART OF THE COUNTRY CROSSES THE 
ROCKIES AND APPROACHES ARKANSAS THURSDAY MORNING. THE LOW WILL 
REPEAT THE BEHAVIOR OF THE PAST COUPLE OF SYSTEMS BY MOVING OFF TO 
THE NORTHEAST RATHER QUICKLY AND WEAKENING AT THE SAME TIME. ANOTHER 
WEAK SHORT WAVE WILL BE POISED TO AFFECT THE STATE JUST PAST THE 
PERIOD COVERED BY THIS FORECAST. TUESDAY NIGHT WILL SEE MOISTURE 
RETURNING FROM THE SOUTH...WITH SMALL POPS LINGERING INTO WEDNESDAY. 
THEN BY THURSDAY MORNING THE SURFACE LOW WILL BE IN THE MKC AREA 
WHILE DRAGGING MOISTURE ACROSS ARKANSAS ALONG WITH A COLD FRONT. IN 
KEEPING WITH THE FAST FLOW ALOFT...THE COLD FRONT WILL CROSS THE 
STATE QUICKLY AS WELL...IT SHOULD BE CROSSING THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER 
BY SUNSET THURSDAY. DRY WEATHER FOR FRIDAY. BOTH THE HIGHS AND LOWS 
WILL BE ON THE WARM SIDE OF NORMAL. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    67  48  76  64 /  10  10  10  30 
HARRISON AR       63  47  73  59 /  10  10  10  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    69  51  77  64 /  10  10  10  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     68  50  78  65 /  10  10  10  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  63  47  73  59 /  10  10  10  30 
MONTICELLO AR     70  52  80  67 /  20  10  10  30 
SEARCY AR         66  47  75  62 /  10  10  10  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      69  51  77  64 /  10  10  10  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   67  49  75  62 /  10  10  10  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

FXUS64 KLZK 160250 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
950 PM CDT FRI OCT 15 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CDFNT CONTS TO MAKE PROGRESS SWD INTO CNTRL AR ATTM. LATEST SFC OBS 
PLACE BNDRY ROUGHLY ALONG A KFSM-KSRC-KBYH LINE. HAVE SEEN PATCHY 
LIGHT RAIN AND SHOWERS MAINLY BEHIND THE FNT. EXPECT CDFNT TO CONT 
WORKING SWD OVERNIGHT AND EVENTUALLY STALL JUST TO S OF AR ON SAT.

HAVE KEPT SLGT CHC POPS GOING FOR THE OVERNIGHT HOURS IN THE VCNTY 
OF THE CDFNT. NO SIG CHGS MADE TO GOING MIN TEMPS FOR TNGT. ADJUSTED 
HOURLY GRIDS TO REFLECT CURRENT CONDS. OTHERWISE...GOING FCST IN 
GREAT SHAPE. UPDATED ZNS AND GRIDS ALREADY SENT.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

44





851 
FXUS64 KLZK 151959
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
259 PM CDT FRI OCT 15 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
FAIRLY ACTIVE WEATHER PATTERN SETTING UP FOR THE SHORT TERM. AC 
CURRENTLY STREAMING INTO NORTHWEST ARKANSAS FROM SOUTHEAST KANSAS...
WITH SOME STRATOCU SLOWLY DEVELOPING IN NORTHEAST OKLAHOMA. SURFACE 
ANALYSIS INDICATES COLD FRONT OVER CENTRAL MISSOURI...INTO NORTHERN 
OKLAHOMA AND HEADING SOUTHWARD. FRONT AND ASSOCIATED UPPER LEVEL 
SYSTEM WILL MOVE INTO THE FORECAST AREA TONIGHT. WHILE MOISTURE IS 
NOT VERY IMPRESSIVE WITH THIS SYSTEM...STILL WILL BE A SLIGHT CHANCE 
OF RAIN AS THE SYSTEM MOVES THROUGH. 

FRONT WILL BRING A REINFORCING SHOT OF COOLER AIR. SYSTEM WILL HIT 
500 MB RIDGE OVER THE GULF COAST...AND WILL STALL LATE SATURDAY 
BEFORE HEADING BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT BEGINNING EARLY 
SUNDAY. ELEVATED CONVECTION WILL BE POSSIBLE ALONG AND TO THE NORTH 
OF THE BOUNDARY ON SUNDAY AFTERNOON AND NIGHT.

BY MONDAY...TROUGH DEVELOPING IN THE WEST AND RIDGE DEVELOPING OVER 
THE TENNESEE VALLEY WILL SHIFT UPPER FLOW TO THE SOUTHWEST. RETURN 
FLOW WILL SET UP...WITH SEVERAL WAVES MOVING UP IN THE MEAN FLOW. 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL ONCE AGAIN BE POSSIBLE. FAIRLY STRONG 
COLD FRONT DEVELOPING IN THE PLAINS WILL SLOWLY DRIFT TOWARD THE 
STATE...BUT PROGRESS WILL BE HINDERED BY STRENGTHENING UPPER RIDGE. 
FRONT WILL SLOW DOWN AND EVENTUALLY STALL OUT TO THE WEST OF 
ARKANSAS. 

LOOKING TOWARD THE LONG TERM...FAIRLY POTENT UPPER LOW DEVELOPING 
OVER THE SOUTHWEST WILL KICK OUT...GIVING SURFACE SYSTEM A PUSH 
TOWARD ARKANSAS. 

MOS GUIDANCE IS IN DECENT AGREEMENT FOR THE FIRST TWO OR THREE 
PERIODS...DIVERGING SIGNIFICANTLY BEYOND THAT DUE TO WARM FRONT 
SITUATION SETTING UP. FAVOR WARMER NUMBERS OF THE GFS AT THAT POINT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY       
UNSETTLED WEATHER PATTERN WILL PREVAIL THROUGH MUCH OF THE LONG 
TERM. RAINFALL WILL END FROM THE WEST TUESDAY MORNING...BUT THAT 
WILL BE SHORT-LIVED. MOISTURE WILL BEGIN TO INCREASE FROM THE SOUTH 
AGAIN TUESDAY NIGHT WITH INCREASING CHANCES FOR RAINFALL. SCATTERED 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL INCREASE ACROSS THE AREA ON WEDNESDAY 
AS H5 LOW AND COLD FRONT APPROACH FROM THE WEST. RAINFALL AMOUNTS 
COULD BE SIGNIFICANT WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND EARLY THURSDAY. DRIER AIR 
SHOULD BEGIN TO MOVE IN BY THURSDAY AFTERNOON...AND RAINFALL WILL 
DECREASE FROM THE NORTHWEST ON THURSDAY. DRY AND COOLER CONDITIONS 
EXPECTED ON FRIDAY. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    49  67  48  77 /  20  10  10  20 
HARRISON AR       42  63  47  72 /  20  10  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    50  69  51  78 /  20  10  10  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     51  68  50  79 /  20  10  10  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  42  63  47  72 /  20  10  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     49  70  52  80 /  20  20  10  20 
SEARCY AR         47  66  47  75 /  20  10  10  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      50  69  51  78 /  20  10  10  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   46  67  49  76 /  20  10  10  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 22

MOUNTAIN HOME AR  42  63  47  72 /  20  10  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     49  70  52  80 /  20  20  10  20

SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 22


603 
FXUS64 KLZK 151558 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1058 AM CDT FRI OCT 15 2004

.DISCUSSION...
WARMER AIR WORKING ITS WAY INTO THE AREA THIS MORNING...WITH CLOUDS 
BREAKING UP OVER THE EASTERN HALF OF ARKANSAS. TEMPERATURES HAVE 
BEEN SLOW TO WARM...WITH ONLY MID 50S IN NORTHERN ARKANSAS TO NEAR 
60 IN THE SOUTH. HOWEVER...WITH SURFACE RIDGE PASSING TO THE SOUTH 
THIS AFTERNOON...WESTERLY FLOW WILL STRENGTHEN...AND TEMPERATURES 
SHOULD WARM UP TO FORECASTED HIGHS. 

SATELLITE IMAGERY SHOWS DECK OF AC MOVING DOWN THROUGH SOUTHEASTERN 
KANSAS AS UPPER WAVE AND APPROACHING COLD FRONT RIDE NORTHWESTERLY 
FLOW DOWN TOWARD ARKANSAS. CLOUDS WILL INCREASE ACROSS THE NORTHWEST 
HALF OF THE AREA DURING THE AFTERNOON...WITH CONDITIONS REMAINING 
MOSTLY SUNNY FOR THE SOUTHEAST. 

WILL BE SENDING OUT AN UPDATE SHORTLY...PRIMARILY CLEANING UP SOME 
TEMPORAL WORDING IN THE TEXT FORECASTS. HAVE ALSO UPDATED GRIDS TO 
BETTER ACCOUNT FOR ONGOING SENSIBLE WEATHER TRENDS. 

UPDATED GRAPHICAL AND GRIDDED DATA HAS BEEN SENT. UPDATE TO TEXT AND 
TABULAR FORECASTS WILL BE SENT SHORTLY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

57

NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT FRI OCT 15 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY
UNUSUALLY STRONG UPPER LOW FOR THIS TIME OF YEAR IS PULLING 
NORTHEAST AWAY FROM THE AREA THIS MORNING BUT NOT MUCH HIGH
PRESSURE IS MOVING IN BEHIND IT. CLOUDS HAVE DECREASED BUT A COUPLE 
OF AREAS OF CLOUDS WILL ROTATE THROUGH THE AREA THIS MORNING. 
COULD SEE SOME STRATOCUMULUS THIS AFTERNOON SO WILL GO WITH PARTLY
CLOUDY WORDING. WESTERLY WINDS AND SUNSHINE SHOULD ALLOW FOR GOOD
WARMING TODAY AND MAXES IN THE MID 60S TO LOWER 70S LOOK GOOD.
ANOTHER SHORT WAVE AND COLD FRONT MOVE ACROSS THE AREA TONIGHT.
A GOOD AMOUNT OF MOISTURE ACCOMPNIES THIS SYSTEM AND PUT IN SMALL
POPS FOR LIGHT RAIN ACROSS THE AREA FOR TONIGHT. THIS SHOULD MOVE 
OUT EARLY SATURDAY AND CLOUDS SHOULD DECREASE. WENT A LITTLE LOWER 
WITH MAXES FOR SATURDAY. RETURN FLOW SETS UP AGAIN SUNDAY WITH A
MODEST INCREASE IN MOISTURE. THIS SHOULD INCREASE CLOUDS AND KEPT
SMALL POPS IN FOR SUNDAY AFTERNOON...SPREADING ACROSS THE AREA 
SUNDAY NIGHT. A SHORT WAVE AND COLD FRONT APPROACH THE AREA MONDAY 
AND WENT UP TO CHANCE POPS FOR MONDAY. AIR BECOMES QUITE UNSTABLE
MONDAY WITH RATHER STRONG FLOW ALOFT OVER THE AREA AND LOW SURFACE
PRESSURES. THIS COULD BE SET UP FOR SEVERE WEATHER BUT WILL JUST
GO WITH SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FOR NOW. DID NOT MAKE SIGNIFICANT 
CHANGES TO TEMP FORECAST SUNDAY THROUGH MONDAY.   
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL PREVAIL THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT WHEN THE 
NEXT SHORT WAVE CROSSES THE SOUTHERN ROCKIES. THE LOW WILL BECOME 
WEAKER AS IT PUSHES TO THE NORTHEAST BY THURSDAY MORNING...LEAVING 
THE STATE BACK IN SOUTHWEST FLOW. THE SURFACE PATTERN KEEPS A 
SOMEWHAT MOIST SOUTHERLY FLOW ACROSS ARKANSAS MONDAY NIGHT AND 
TUESDAY. THEN...A LOW TAKES SHAPE UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF THE UPPER 
SYSTEM AND IT OPENS THE GULF SIGNIFICANTLY BY WEDNESDAY MORNING. THE 
COLD FRONT ACCOMPANYING THE LOW WILL BE SLOW TO MOVE EAST OF THE 
STATE IN LIGHT OF THE WEAKENING UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT. I WILL PLACE 
CHANCE POPS IN THE FORECAST STARTING FROM THE SOUTH TUESDAY NIGHT 
INTO WEDNESDAY. MOST OF THE STATE WILL BE DRY BY THURSDAY MORNING. 
THE FRONT WILL BECOME STATIONARY JUST TO THE SOUTH AND EAST OF OUR 
BORDERS...SETTING UP A QUICK RETURN OF CLOUDS AND RAIN BEYOND 
THURSDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL BE BACK ABOVE NORMALS WITH THE SOUTHERLY 
WINDS AHEAD OF THE FRONT.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    70  50  68  51 /   0  20  10  10 
HARRISON AR       66  42  60  46 /   0  20  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    71  50  70  52 /   0  20  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     71  51  69  53 /   0  20  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  65  42  60  46 /   0  20  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     72  52  69  55 /   0  20  20  10 
SEARCY AR         69  48  66  50 /   0  20  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      71  50  70  51 /   0  20  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   69  46  66  50 /   0  20  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29/32

400 AM CDT FRI OCT 15 2004

29/32 






092 
FXUS64 KLZK 150245 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
941 PM CDT THU OCT 14 2004

.DISCUSSION...
TEMPERATURES FALLING A LITTLE FASTER THAN EARLIER EXPECTED OVER THE 
NORTHERN SECTIONS OF THE FORECAST AREA. UPDATED FORECASTS TO LOWER 
NORTHERN SECTIONS INTO THE MID 30S OVERNIGHT. REMOVED RAIN MENTION 
FOR REMAINDER OF TONIGHT. UPDATES ALL OUT.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
UPPER LOW SHOWING UP VERY WELL ON SATELLITE IMAGERY THIS 
AFTERNOON...WITH THE CENTER RIGHT BETWEEN SPRINGFIELD AND BRANSON 
MISSOURI. SYSTEM WILL ENTER NORTHERN ARKANSAS THIS EVENING AND CROSS 
NORTHEAST ARKANSAS INTO TENNESSEE LATE TONIGHT. A MIX OF SOME WINTRY 
PRECIP HAS BEEN REPORTED IN SOME OF THE HIGHER TERRAIN OF SWRN 
AND SCNTRL MISSOURI THIS AFTERNOON...AS COLDER AIR WORKS ITS WAY 
DOWN TOWARD THE SURFACE. AIRMASS OVER OUR FORECAST AREA HAS REMAINED 
WARM ENOUGH TO KEEP PRECIP LIQUID. WOULD NOT BE SUPRISED TO SEE AN 
ISOLATED REPORT OF A SNOWFLAKE OR TWO OVER THE HIGHER TERRAIN OF 
NORTHERN ARKANSAS AS THE COLDER AIR MOVES OVER THE MOUNTAINS 
TONIGHT. WILL NOT MENTION THIS IN THE FORECAST...AS IT WOULD BE VERY 
ISOLATED IN NATURE...AND COULD BE COVERED BY A NOWCAST. 

WINDS HAVE MOSTLY BEEN 10 TO 20 MPH SUSTAINED...WITH SOME GUSTS 
APPROACHING THE 25 TO 30 MPH RANGE. GRADIENT WILL SUBSIDE QUITE A 
BIT TONIGHT...BUT SHOULD BE ENOUGH TO KEEP WINDS AT 5 TO 10 MPH. 
NORTHEASTERN AREAS WILL BE SLOW TO CLEAR OUT TONIGHT...AS WRAPAROUND 
MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH UPPER LOW WILL REMAIN IN PLACE. MOISTURE 
ASSOCIATED WITH H5 WAVE MOVING DOWN IN NORTHWESTERLY FLOW MAY AFFECT 
WESTERN ARKANSAS TOWARD MORNING. MUCH COOLER TEMPERATURES WILL BE 
NOTED TONIGHT...HOWEVER GRADIENT AND PRESENCE OF CLOUD COVER WILL 
ACT TO KEEP READINGS FROM COMPLETELY TANKING.

FRIDAY WILL DEFINITELY FEEL LIKE FALL...WITH A MOSTLY SUNNY/PARTLY 
CLOUDY SKY...AND TEMPERATURES IN THE LOWER 60S TO LOWER 70S. CLOUDS 
WILL INCREASE LATE FRIDAY...AS A WEAKER COLD FRONT MAKES ITS WAY 
INTO ARKANSAS FROM THE PLAINS. SOME MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS 
FRONT...AND LIFT ENOUGH TO PRODUCE ISOLATED SHOWERS FRIDAY NIGHT AND 
EARLY SATURDAY IN THE SOUTH. SYSTEM WILL STALL INVOF NORTHERN 
LOUISIANA OR SOUTHERN ARKANSAS BY SATURDAY AFTERNOON. FRONT LOOKS TO 
BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT ON SUNDAY. ISOLATED ELEVATED 
CONVECTION WILL BE POSSIBLE OUT AHEAD OF THE SYSTEM ON SUNDAY 
AFTERNON AND EVENING AS IT ADVANCES THROUGH CENTRAL AND NORTHERN 
ARKANSAS. 

MOISTURE LVLS WILL ONCE AGAIN BE ON THE INCRS STARTING MON AHEAD OF 
ANOTHER IN A SERIES OF UPPER LVL WAVES APCHG FROM THE SWRN STATES.
ASSOCD SFC CDFNT IS PROGGED TO MOVE ACRS AR MON NIGHT AND TUE...WITH 
A CONTD CHC OF RAINFALL.

FNTL BNDRY WILL STALL JUST TO S OF AR BEFORE RETURNING NWD AHEAD OF 
NEXT UPPER SYS THAT WILL AFFECT THE FA WED INTO THU. HAVE LEFT RAIN 
CHCS IN THE 20-30 PERCENT RANGE FOR NOW AS TIMING ISSUES WILL LIKELY 
COME INTO PLAY LATER IN THE FCST PD. TEMPS OVERALL SHOULD RMN CLOSE 
TO NORMAL FOR THIS TIME OF YEAR.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

22






AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
238 PM CDT THU OCT 14 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
UPPER LOW SHOWING UP VERY WELL ON SATELLITE IMAGERY THIS 
AFTERNOON...WITH THE CENTER RIGHT BETWEEN SPRINGFIELD AND BRANSON 
MISSOURI. SYSTEM WILL ENTER NORTHERN ARKANSAS THIS EVENING AND CROSS 
NORTHEAST ARKANSAS INTO TENNESSEE LATE TONIGHT. A MIX OF SOME WINTRY 
PRECIP HAS BEEN REPORTED IN SOME OF THE HIGHER TERRAIN OF SWRN 
AND SCNTRL MISSOURI THIS AFTERNOON...AS COLDER AIR WORKS ITS WAY 
DOWN TOWARD THE SURFACE. AIRMASS OVER OUR FORECAST AREA HAS REMAINED 
WARM ENOUGH TO KEEP PRECIP LIQUID. WOULD NOT BE SUPRISED TO SEE AN 
ISOLATED REPORT OF A SNOWFLAKE OR TWO OVER THE HIGHER TERRAIN OF 
NORTHERN ARKANSAS AS THE COLDER AIR MOVES OVER THE MOUNTAINS 
TONIGHT. WILL NOT MENTION THIS IN THE FORECAST...AS IT WOULD BE VERY 
ISOLATED IN NATURE...AND COULD BE COVERED BY A NOWCAST. 

WINDS HAVE MOSTLY BEEN 10 TO 20 MPH SUSTAINED...WITH SOME GUSTS 
APPROACHING THE 25 TO 30 MPH RANGE. GRADIENT WILL SUBSIDE QUITE A 
BIT TONIGHT...BUT SHOULD BE ENOUGH TO KEEP WINDS AT 5 TO 10 MPH. 
NORTHEASTERN AREAS WILL BE SLOW TO CLEAR OUT TONIGHT...AS WRAPAROUND 
MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH UPPER LOW WILL REMAIN IN PLACE. MOISTURE 
ASSOCIATED WITH H5 WAVE MOVING DOWN IN NORTHWESTERLY FLOW MAY AFFECT 
WESTERN ARKANSAS TOWARD MORNING. MUCH COOLER TEMPERATURES WILL BE 
NOTED TONIGHT...HOWEVER GRADIENT AND PRESENCE OF CLOUD COVER WILL 
ACT TO KEEP READINGS FROM COMPLETELY TANKING.

FRIDAY WILL DEFINITELY FEEL LIKE FALL...WITH A MOSTLY SUNNY/PARTLY 
CLOUDY SKY...AND TEMPERATURES IN THE LOWER 60S TO LOWER 70S. CLOUDS 
WILL INCREASE LATE FRIDAY...AS A WEAKER COLD FRONT MAKES ITS WAY 
INTO ARKANSAS FROM THE PLAINS. SOME MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS 
FRONT...AND LIFT ENOUGH TO PRODUCE ISOLATED SHOWERS FRIDAY NIGHT AND 
EARLY SATURDAY IN THE SOUTH. SYSTEM WILL STALL INVOF NORTHERN 
LOUISIANA OR SOUTHERN ARKANSAS BY SATURDAY AFTERNOON. FRONT LOOKS TO 
BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT ON SUNDAY. ISOLATED ELEVATED 
CONVECTION WILL BE POSSIBLE OUT AHEAD OF THE SYSTEM ON SUNDAY 
AFTERNON AND EVENING AS IT ADVANCES THROUGH CENTRAL AND NORTHERN 
ARKANSAS. 
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
MOISTURE LVLS WILL ONCE AGAIN BE ON THE INCRS STARTING MON AHEAD OF 
ANOTHER IN A SERIES OF UPPER LVL WAVES APCHG FROM THE SWRN STATES.
ASSOCD SFC CDFNT IS PROGGED TO MOVE ACRS AR MON NIGHT AND TUE...WITH 
A CONTD CHC OF RAINFALL.

FNTL BNDRY WILL STALL JUST TO S OF AR BEFORE RETURNING NWD AHEAD OF 
NEXT UPPER SYS THAT WILL AFFECT THE FA WED INTO THU. HAVE LEFT RAIN 
CHCS IN THE 20-30 PERCENT RANGE FOR NOW AS TIMING ISSUES WILL LIKELY 
COME INTO PLAY LATER IN THE FCST PD. TEMPS OVERALL SHOULD RMN CLOSE 
TO NORMAL FOR THIS TIME OF YEAR.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    42  70  50  68 /  20   0  20   0 
HARRISON AR       40  63  42  60 /  30   0  20   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    42  72  49  70 /  10   0  20   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     44  70  49  69 /  20   0  20   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  39  63  42  60 /  30   0  20   0 
MONTICELLO AR     44  70  47  69 /  20   0  20   0 
SEARCY AR         40  68  49  66 /  30   0  20   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      42  71  49  70 /  10   0  20   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   41  68  48  66 /  20   0  20   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
