SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 44





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 141603 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1100 AM CDT THU OCT 14 2004

.DISCUSSION...
12Z UPA ANALYSIS INDICATES UPPER LOW INVOF SERN KS. SATELLITE 
IMAGERY SHOWS CONTINUAL STREAM OF CLOUDS OVER THE EASTERN TWO THIRDS 
OF THE FORECAST AREA...WHILE CLOUDS ARE SHOWING SOME BREAKS OVER THE 
WEST. 

COLD ADVECTION BEHIND THE SYSTEM HAS BEEN STRONG THIS MORNING...WITH 
READINS IN NORTHWEST ARKANSAS DROPPING AS MUCH AS EIGHT DEGREES IN 
THE LAST FIVE HOURS. THIS WILL LEVEL OFF A BIT BEFORE THE EARLY 
AFTERNOON...AND TEMPS MAY ACTUALLY RISE A DEGREE OR TWO BEFORE 
FALLING AGAIN DURING THE AFTERNOON. READINGS IN THE CENTRAL HAVE 
BEEN NEARLY STEADY FOR THE LAST FEW HOURS...AND THE SOUTHEASTERN 
AREAS HAVE SHOWN ONLY A SLIGHT RISE.

SO...THAT BEING SAID...THIS BRINGS ME TO UPDATES FOR THE CURRENT 
FORECAST. CLOUD COVER AND ADVECTION BEHIND THE SYSTEM HAVE MADE 
TEMPERATURE TRENDS EXTREMELY DIFFICULT TO PIN DOWN. IT APPEARS THAT 
NORTHWEST ARKANSAS WILL SEE VERY LITTLE CHANGE THROUGH THE 
AFTERNOON...WITH READINGS LIKELY FALLING A FEW DEGREES IN NORTHEAST 
ARKANSAS AS COLD FRONT CONTINUES MOVING EASTWARD TOWARD THE 
TENNESSEE VALLEY. CENTRAL ARKANSAS WILL SEE READINGS RISE A LITTLE 
BIT OR HOLD STEADY...BEFORE FALLING DURING THE AFTERNOON. SOUTHEAST 
ARKANSAS SHOULD SEE THE MOST DIURNAL SWING /IF YOU WANT TO CALL IT 
THAT/...WITH READINGS TOPPING OUT NEAR 60. 

NEXT ISSUE IS WINDS. SUSTAINED WINDS SHOULD REMAIN BELOW LAKE WIND 
CRITERIA THIS AFTERNOON. HOWEVER...THEY HAVE CONTINUED TO INCREASE 
BEHIND THE COLD FRONT AND AS THE UPPER LOW APPROACHES. WILL KEEP 
SUSTAINED WINDS AT 10 TO 15...BUT WILL MENTION GUSTS AS HIGH AS 30 
MPH. 

FINALLY...HAVE UPDATED POP TRENDS...WITH THE HIGHEST POPS IN 
NORTHERN ARKANSAS AS UPPER LOW SWINGS THROUGH THIS AFTERNOON. WHILE 
THERE IS A POSSIBILITY OF ADDITIONAL PATCHY LIGHT RAIN DEVELOPING 
THIS AFTERNOON...DECIDED TO TAKE ISOLATED THUNDER OUT OF THE 
FORECAST DUE TO LACK OF INSTABILITY AND A SLIGHT CAP IN THE MID 
LEVELS. 

UPDATED TEXT FORECASTS HAVE BEEN SENT. GRAPHICAL AND GRIDDED DATA 
HAS BEEN POSTED. TABULAR PRODUCT UPDATES ARE FORTHCOMING. AND...DUE 
TO TRICKINESS OF THIS FORECAST...MORE UPDATES MAY FOLLOW LATER 
TODAY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

57





944 
FXUS64 KLZK 140909
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT THU OCT 14 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
UPPER LOW WILL MOVE SOUTHEAST INTO ARKANSAS TODAY...AND DISTURBANCES 
ROTATING AROUND THIS LOW WILL BRING CLOUDY AND RAINY CONDITIONS TO 
THE AREA. LIGHT RAINFALL ALREADY REPORTED IN NORTHWEST ARKANSAS... 
AND WILL MOVE SOUTHEAST THIS MORNING. AMOUNTS WILL BE LIGHT...WITH 
LESS THAN 1/4 INCH EXPECTED. HIGHEST CHANCES WILL BE IN THE NORTH 
...CLOSER TO THE UPPER LOW. THUNDER ALSO POSSIBLE...BUT WILL BE 
ISOLATED AT BEST. GUSTY WINDS ALSO TODAY...DUE TO PRESSURE GRADIENT 
BETWEEN HIGH PRESSURE IN WEST TEXAS AND LOW JUST TO THE EAST OF 
ARKANSAS.

AS THE UPPER LOW QUICKLY MOVES EAST...RAINFALL WILL END FROM 
SOUTHWEST TO NORTHEAST THIS AFTERNOON AND EARLY EVENING. CLOUDS WILL 
HANG ON A LITTLE LONGER...BUT MOST AREAS WILL BE PARTLY CLOUDY BY 
MORNING.

TEMPERATURES WILL STRUGGLE TO CLIMB OUT OF THE 50S TODAY...WITH 
LOCATIONS IN NORTHERN ARKANSAS SEEING HIGH TEMPS AROUND 
NOON...BEFORE SLOWLY FALLING. SOUTHERN ARKANSAS COULD SEE A REBOUND 
IN READINGS THIS AFTERNOON...BUT TEMPS WILL ONLY GET INTO THE LOWER 
60S. OVERNIGHT LOWS TONIGHT WILL DROP TO AROUND 40...WITH THE 
COOLEST READINGS OF THE FALL SO FAR.

COOL AIR WILL BE SHORT LIVED...AS TEMPS WILL WARM FRIDAY. ANOTHER 
SHOT OF COOL AIR WILL MOVE IN FRIDAY NIGHT...BUT TEMPS WILL REBOUND 
NICELY SATURDAY.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
RATHER ACTIVE PERIOD SETTING UP NEXT WEEK. WEEKEND WILL FINISH ON A 
DRY NOTE WITH A WARMING TREND CONTINUING. WARMING/INCREASE IN 
MOISTURE WILL BE IN ADVANCE OF A STORM SYSTEM IN THE SOUTHERN 
PLAINS. 

SYSTEM WILL DRAG COLD FRONT INTO THE REGION MONDAY/TUESDAY WITH A 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS. APPEARS THAT FRONT WILL NOT MAKE IT 
THROUGH STATE...WITH LOTS OF CLOUDS REMAINING. 

AS FRONT STALLS...NEW SYSTEM WILL GET ORGANIZED IN THE 
ROCKIES/PLAINS. SYSTEM WILL ARRIVE BY WEDNESDAY WITH YET ANOTHER 
CHANCE OF PRECIPITATION. 

IN GENERAL...TEMPERATURES WILL AVERAGE CLOSE TO NORMAL TO PERHAPS A 
FEW DEGREES ABOVE NORMAL. NO BIG COOLING FOLLOWING SYSTEMS AS THEY 
RIDE QUASIZONAL FLOW WITH MINOR AMPLIFICATION. (46)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    60  44  68  46 /  50  20  10   0 
HARRISON AR       55  40  66  42 /  60  30  10   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    61  44  69  46 /  50  20  10   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     61  44  69  46 /  40  20  10   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  55  39  65  41 /  50  30  10   0 
MONTICELLO AR     62  45  69  47 /  40  20  10   0 
SEARCY AR         58  42  67  44 /  50  30  10   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      60  44  69  46 /  50  20  10   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   58  43  68  45 /  50  20  10   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56/46





375 
FXUS64 KLZK 140243 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
941 PM CDT WED OCT 13 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATED TEXT PRODUCTS TO REMOVE EVENING WORDING...AND PUSH RAINFALL 
BACK TO LATER TONIGHT. CLOUDS WILL BE INCREASING FROM NORTHWEST TO 
SOUTHEAST OVERNIGHT. ALL UPDATES GONE.  
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
THE NEXT SHORT WAVE IS STILL ON ITS FAST TRACK DIVING TOWARD THE 
STATE IN NORTHWESTERLY FLOW. ITS SPEED WILL PLACE IT JUST EAST OF 
ARKANSAS BY 00Z FRIDAY. THE NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL BECOME ZONAL 
GRADUALLY AS LARGE VORTEX BECOMES CLOSED LOW OVER THE GREAT LAKES 
FOR THE WEEK END. THE SURFACE FEATURES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS SYSTEM 
ARE WELL ON THEIR WAY TO THE STATE. VISIBLE SATELLITE PHOTOGRAPHS 
SHOW EXTENSIVE CLOUD SHIELD APPROACHING FROM THE CENTRAL PLAINS. 
HIGH CHANCE POPS OR EVEN LIKELY ARE SHOWN IN THE MOS NUMBERS 
CONSISTENTLY SO WILL GO ALONG WITH THEM ALTHOUGH SPEED OF SYSTEM MAY 
BE SUCH THAT ONLY CHANCE POPS WOULD SUFFICE. MOS TEMPS SHOW CLOSER 
AGREEMENT THAN YESTERDAY...SO WILL FOLLOW THEM CLOSELY.

SFC HIGH PRES WL SHIFT E OF THE FA EARLY IN THE PD...ALLOWING FOR 
RETURN FLOW AND INCREASING WAA PATTERN. UPPER FLOW IS EXPECTED TO BE 
ZONAL THRU MUCH OF THE FCST PD. AN UPPER LVL IMPULSE IS PROGGED TO  
AFFECT THE AREA LATE MON INTO MON NIGHT. HAVE CONTD WITH 20-30 
PERCENT POPS...MAINLY FOR THE NRN HALF OF THE FA. TIMING STILL AN 
ISSUE WITH THE SYSTEM...SO HAVE NOT MADE TOO MANY CHGS TO GOING 
FCST. TEMPS WILL RETURN TO MORE NORMAL LVLS NEXT WEEK.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

32/44





743 
FXUS64 KLZK 131641
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1100 AM CDT WED OCT 13 2004

MADE MINOR CHANGES TO THE FORECAST. UPDATE IS OUT ALREADY.
THE PREVIOUS DISCUSSION FOLLOWS...

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT
UPPER LOW CURRENTLY OVER SOUTHERN ILLINOIS WILL MOVE EAST TODAY. LOW 
CLOUDS WILL GRADUALLY BREAK UP OVER THE NORTHEAST HALF OF THE AREA 
AS THE LOW CONTINUES TO MOVE EAST...WHILE IN THE SOUTHWEST... 
CLEARING HAS ALREADY OCCURRED. TEMPERATURES TODAY WILL BE 5 TO 10 
DEGREES WARMER THAN TUESDAY ACROSS MOST OF THE AREA...DUE TO LACK OF 
CLOUDS AND PRECIP.

CLOUDS WILL INCREASE TONIGHT FROM THE NORTHWEST...AHEAD OF A STRONG 
COLD FRONT AND ANOTHER UPPER LOW. MODELS CONSISTENT WITH TIMING... 
BUT NOT WITH MOISTURE AND POPS. FOR NOW...CONTINUED THE TREND OF 
HIGH CHANCE/LIKELY POPS...BUT AMOUNTS WILL BE SIGNIFICANTLY LESS 
THAN THE LAST EVENT. MOST AREAS WILL PROBABLY SEE LESS THAN 1/2 INCH.

BREEZY NORTHWEST WINDS WILL ACCOMPANY THE FRONTAL PASSAGE THURSDAY 
AND CONTINUE INTO THURSDAY EVENING. WITH PLENTY OF CLOUDS AROUND AS 
UPPER LOW OVERHEAD THURSDAY...TEMPERATURES WILL BE COOL. READINGS 
WILL STRUGGLE TO REACH MID 50S AND LOWER 60S. NORMALS FOR THIS TIME 
OF YEAR ARE IN THE 70S.

CLOUDS WILL DECREASE THURSDAY NIGHT...ALLOWING TEMPS TO FALL INTO 
THE 40S. SOME LINGERING SHOWERS IN THE EAST THURSDAY EVENING...BUT 
AS UPPER LOW HEADS EAST...PRECIP AND CLOUDS DIMINISH.

PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES AND SOUTHWEST WINDS WILL BRING WARMING TEMPS 
FRIDAY...SO COOL DOWN WILL BE SHORT LIVED.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
PATTERN WILL REMAIN FAIRLY ACTIVE HEADING INTO EARLY NEXT WEEK. 
FRONT WEDNESDAY NIGHT/THURSDAY WILL BE FOLLOWED BY SECONDARY FRONT 
FRIDAY NIGHT/EARLY SATURDAY. NOT MUCH MOISTURE WITH FRONT...SO NO 
PRECIPITATION MENTIONED WITH PASSAGE. THE SECONDARY FRONT WILL CURB 
WARMING TREND HEADING INTO WEEKEND. 

AFOREMENTIONED WARMING TREND WILL REALLY GET GOING SUNDAY/MONDAY AS 
NEXT STORM SYSTEM RIDES SUBTROPICAL JET THROUGH SOUTHERN 
ROCKIES/SOUTHERN PLAINS. AHEAD OF THE SYSTEM...NOT ONLY WILL 
TEMPERATURES GO UP WITH SOUTHERLY WIND...MOISTURE WILL ALSO INCREASE 
AS WELL.

TIMING WITH SYSTEM A LITTLE UNCERTAIN...BUT HAVE IT SCHEDULED TO 
ARRIVE LATE MONDAY/EARLY TUESDAY WITH SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. SYSTEM OUT OF PHASE WITH NORTHERN STREAM...SO WILL BE 
FOLLOWED BY PACIFIC AIR AND ONLY A MINIMAL COOLDOWN. (46)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    70  49  57  44 /  10  40  50  30 
HARRISON AR       67  44  52  41 /  10  50  60  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    72  49  59  45 /  10  40  50  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     71  51  58  45 /  10  40  50  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  65  45  51  41 /  10  50  60  30 
MONTICELLO AR     72  52  60  46 /  10  40  50  20 
SEARCY AR         68  49  54  43 /  10  40  60  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      72  49  59  45 /  10  50  50  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   70  47  56  44 /  10  50  50  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

CLOUDS WILL DECREASE THURSDAY NIGHT...ALLOWING TEMPS TO FALL INTO 
THE 40S. SOME LINGERING SHOWERS IN THE EAST THURSDAY EVENING...BUT 
AS UPPER LOW HEADS EAST...PRECIP AND CLOUDS DIMINISH.

PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES AND SOUTHWEST WINDS WILL BRING WARMING TEMPS 
FRIDAY...SO COOL DOWN WILL BE SHORT LIVED.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
PATTERN WILL REMAIN FAIRLY ACTIVE HEADING INTO EARLY NEXT WEEK. 
FRONT WEDNESDAY NIGHT/THURSDAY WILL BE FOLLOWED BY SECONDARY FRONT 
FRIDAY NIGHT/EARLY SATURDAY. NOT MUCH MOISTURE WITH FRONT...SO NO 
PRECIPITATION MENTIONED WITH PASSAGE. THE SECONDARY FRONT WILL CURB 
WARMING TREND HEADING INTO WEEKEND. 

AFOREMENTIONED WARMING TREND WILL REALLY GET GOING SUNDAY/MONDAY AS 
NEXT STORM SYSTEM RIDES SUBTROPICAL JET THROUGH SOUTHERN 
ROCKIES/SOUTHERN PLAINS. AHEAD OF THE SYSTEM...NOT ONLY WILL 
TEMPERATURES GO UP WITH SOUTHERLY WIND...MOISTURE WILL ALSO INCREASE 
AS WELL.

TIMING WITH SYSTEM A LITTLE UNCERTAIN...BUT HAVE IT SCHEDULED TO 
ARRIVE LATE MONDAY/EARLY TUESDAY WITH SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. SYSTEM OUT OF PHASE WITH NORTHERN STREAM...SO WILL BE 
FOLLOWED BY PACIFIC AIR AND ONLY A MINIMAL COOLDOWN. (46)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    70  49  57  44 /  10  40  50  30 
HARRISON AR       67  44  52  41 /  10  50  60  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    72  49  59  45 /  10  40  50  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     71  51  58  45 /  10  40  50  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  65  45  51  41 /  10  50  60  30 
MONTICELLO AR     72  52  60  46 /  10  40  50  20 
SEARCY AR         68  49  54  43 /  10  40  60  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      72  49  59  45 /  10  50  50  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   70  47  56  44 /  10  50  50  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

58/46





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 130856
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
355 AM CDT WED OCT 13 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT
UPPER LOW CURRENTLY OVER SOUTHERN ILLINOIS WILL MOVE EAST TODAY. LOW 
CLOUDS WILL GRADUALLY BREAK UP OVER THE NORTHEAST HALF OF THE AREA 
AS THE LOW CONTINUES TO MOVE EAST...WHILE IN THE SOUTHWEST... 
CLEARING HAS ALREADY OCCURRED. TEMPERATURES TODAY WILL BE 5 TO 10 
DEGREES WARMER THAN TUESDAY ACROSS MOST OF THE AREA...DUE TO LACK OF 
CLOUDS AND PRECIP.

CLOUDS WILL INCREASE TONIGHT FROM THE NORTHWEST...AHEAD OF A STRONG 
COLD FRONT AND ANOTHER UPPER LOW. MODELS CONSISTENT WITH TIMING... 
BUT NOT WITH MOISTURE AND POPS. FOR NOW...CONTINUED THE TREND OF 
HIGH CHANCE/LIKELY POPS...BUT AMOUNTS WILL BE SIGNIFICANTLY LESS 
THAN THE LAST EVENT. MOST AREAS WILL PROBABLY SEE LESS THAN 1/2 INCH.

BREEZY NORTHWEST WINDS WILL ACCOMPANY THE FRONTAL PASSAGE THURSDAY 
AND CONTINUE INTO THURSDAY EVENING. WITH PLENTY OF CLOUDS AROUND AS 
UPPER LOW OVERHEAD THURSDAY...TEMPERATURES WILL BE COOL. READINGS 
WILL STRUGGLE TO REACH MID 50S AND LOWER 60S. NORMALS FOR THIS TIME 
OF YEAR ARE IN THE 70S.

CLOUDS WILL DECREASE THURSDAY NIGHT...ALLOWING TEMPS TO FALL INTO 
THE 40S. SOME LINGERING SHOWERS IN THE EAST THURSDAY EVENING...BUT 
AS UPPER LOW HEADS EAST...PRECIP AND CLOUDS DIMINISH.

PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES AND SOUTHWEST WINDS WILL BRING WARMING TEMPS 
FRIDAY...SO COOL DOWN WILL BE SHORT LIVED.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
PATTERN WILL REMAIN FAIRLY ACTIVE HEADING INTO EARLY NEXT WEEK. 
FRONT WEDNESDAY NIGHT/THURSDAY WILL BE FOLLOWED BY SECONDARY FRONT 
FRIDAY NIGHT/EARLY SATURDAY. NOT MUCH MOISTURE WITH FRONT...SO NO 
PRECIPITATION MENTIONED WITH PASSAGE. THE SECONDARY FRONT WILL CURB 
WARMING TREND HEADING INTO WEEKEND. 

AFOREMENTIONED WARMING TREND WILL REALLY GET GOING SUNDAY/MONDAY AS 
NEXT STORM SYSTEM RIDES SUBTROPICAL JET THROUGH SOUTHERN 
ROCKIES/SOUTHERN PLAINS. AHEAD OF THE SYSTEM...NOT ONLY WILL 
TEMPERATURES GO UP WITH SOUTHERLY WIND...MOISTURE WILL ALSO INCREASE 
AS WELL.

TIMING WITH SYSTEM A LITTLE UNCERTAIN...BUT HAVE IT SCHEDULED TO 
ARRIVE LATE MONDAY/EARLY TUESDAY WITH SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. SYSTEM OUT OF PHASE WITH NORTHERN STREAM...SO WILL BE 
FOLLOWED BY PACIFIC AIR AND ONLY A MINIMAL COOLDOWN. (46)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    70  49  57  44 /  10  40  50  30 
HARRISON AR       67  44  52  41 /  10  50  60  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    72  49  59  45 /  10  40  50  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     71  51  58  45 /  10  40  50  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  65  45  51  41 /  10  50  60  30 
MONTICELLO AR     72  52  60  46 /  10  40  50  20 
SEARCY AR         68  49  54  43 /  10  40  60  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      72  49  59  45 /  10  50  50  20

58/46





914 
FXUS64 KLZK 130256
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
955 PM CDT TUE OCT 12 2004

.DISCUSSION...
KLZK RADAR IS DRY THIS EVENING. SATELLITE IMAGES SHOW THE BACK EDGE 
OF THE CLOUDS ACROSS SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS. THIS CLEARING LINE WILL 
WORK SLOWLY NORTHEAST. SEVERAL CHANGES WERE NEEDED IN THIS UPDATE. 
ADJUSTED CLOUD GRIDS TO BETTER MATCH CURRENT CONDITIONS. WITH THE 
CLEARING SKIES IN THE SOUTHWEST...LOWERED TEMPERATURES THERE. 
ALSO...WITH NO RAIN AROUND THE AREA...LOWERED POPS TO SLIGHT CHANCE 
IN THE NORTH AND REMOVED THUNDER. CROSS SECTIONS DO NOT REVEAL MUCH 
IN THE WAY OF UPWARD MOTION OVER THE NEXT 24 HOURS...HOWEVER 
THURSDAY MORNING IS A DIFFERENT STORY AS THE NEXT COLD FRONT COMES 
THROUGH.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

51






292 
FXUS64 KLZK 121952
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
246 PM CDT TUE OCT 12 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
PERSISTENT LOW OVER MISSOURI WILL MOVE EAST OUT OF OUR PICTURE 
OVERNIGHT. THIS WILL WORK ON LOW CLOUDS SO WILL KEEP LOW POPS ACROSS 
THE NORTH TONIGHT. THE NEXT SYSTEM WILL BE UPON US RATHER QUICKLY 
DURING THE OVERNIGHT HOURS WEDNESDAY INTO EARLY THURSDAY. MOISTURE 
NEVER QUITE GETS OUT OF OUR AREA...SO STRONG LIFTING WITH THAT 
SYSTEM WILL TRIGGER GOOD CHANCE TO LIKELY POPS WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND 
THURSDAY. SPEED OF THE SYSTEM WILL TAKE IT EAST OF THE STATE FRIDAY 
NIGHT...WARRANTING SMALL POPS FRIDAY NIGHT EARLY. DRY FORECAST 
FRIDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT. THE SURFACE REFLECTION OF 
THESE FAST MOVING SYSTEMS WILL HAVE STRONG WINDS TO GO ALONG WITH 
THEM...IN THE 15 TO 25 MPH RANGE FOR NOW WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND 10 TO 
20 ON THURSDAY. WINDS WILL SHIFT GRADUALLY TO THE WEST ON FRIDAY. 
TEMPERATURES WILL MAKE A NOTICEABLE SHIFT TOWARDS THE COLDER SIDE 
WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND DURING THE DAY THURSDAY. HIGHS THURSDAY WILL 
RISE VERY LITTLE FROM THE MORNING LOWS...AND IT WILL FEEL SOMEWHAT 
RAW WHEN COMBINED WITH THE WINDS.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
THE MEDIUM RANGE MODELS ARE IN GENERALLY GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THE 
USUAL TIMING AND INTENSITY DIFFERENCES ONE WOULD EXPECT. GFS HAS 
BEEN THE MOST CONSISTENT MODEL OF LATE BUT SEEMS TO BE A LITTLE 
FASTER THAN THE REMAINDER OF THE MODELS. WILL SIMPLY SPLIT THE 
DIFFERENCES IN THE DETAILS AND GO WITH A COMPROMISE OF SOLUTIONS 
THIS AFTERNOON.

OVERALL PROGRESSIVE PATTERN WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE PERIOD. 
RIDGING OVER THE PAC NORTHWEST WILL FLATTEN OUT AS MID LEVEL TROF 
KICKS OUT OF THE ROCKIES EARLY IN THE PERIOD. SURFACE HIGH OVER THE 
SOUTHEAST WILL HOLD LONG ENOUGH TO KEEP THE AREA DRY ON SUNDAY BUT 
PUSHES OFF SHORE BY MONDAY MORNING. SURFACE LOW MOVES ACROSS THE 
UPPER MIDWEST SUNDAY NIGHT AND PUSHES A COLD FRONT THROUGH THE AREA 
SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY. CURRENT FORECAST DRY SO POPS WILL NEED TO 
BE INTRODUCED AS MOISTURE MAY BE AVAILABLE. WILL GO WITH JUST MIDDLE 
OF THE ROAD SCATTERED POPS FOR NOW AS SYSTEM DEVELOPS. GFS IS NOW 
HINTING AT SECONDARY LOW FORMATION ON THE FRONT MONDAY MORNING BUT 
WILL TAKE A WAIT AND SEE APPROACH. SYSTEM MOVES THROUGH LATE MONDAY 
WITH WEAK RIDGING RETURNING FOR TUESDAY IN ADVANCE OF THE NEXT 
SYSTEM DIGGING INTO THE PLAINS.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...OVERALL FLOW ALOFT IS WESTERLY THROUGH OUT 
THE PERIOD. TEMPERATURES WILL AVERAGE NEAR MID OCTOBER NORMS THROUGH 
THE PERIOD. MEX NUMBERS LOOK REASONABLE AND ARE GENERALLY ACCEPTED.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    55  70  49  56 /  10  10  50  50 
HARRISON AR       48  65  42  51 /  30  30  60  60 
HOT SPRINGS AR    55  73  49  58 /   0  10  50  60 
PINE BLUFF AR     56  71  51  58 /   0  10  50  50 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  48  63  44  51 /  30  30  50  60 
MONTICELLO AR     55  72  52  60 /   0  10  40  50 
SEARCY AR         54  69  48  54 /  20  20  50  50 
MOUNT IDA AR      55  73  48  58 /   0  10  50  60 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   53  71  47  55 /  20  20  50  60 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

32/56





935 
FXUS64 KLZK 120917
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
405 AM CDT TUE OCT 12 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT
LOW PRESSURE ALOFT WILL HEAD THROUGH SOUTHERN MISSOURI TODAY FROM 
THE SOUTHERN PLAINS. CLOUDS WILL REMAIN OVER NORTHERN AND CENTRAL 
ARKANSAS...WITH CLOUDS BREAKING UP IN THE SOUTH.

AFTER SOME PATCHY DENSE FOG THIS MORNING...WILL HAVE SCATTERED TO 
NUMEROUS SHOWERS IN NORTHERN ARKANSAS...WITH SHOWERS BECOMING MORE 
ISOLATED TOWARD CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE STATE. NO RAIN IN THE 
FORECAST ACROSS THE SOUTH.

WILL KEEP SCATTERED SHOWERS IN NORTHERN ARKANSAS TONIGHT...WITH 
PRECIPITATION HEADING EAST WEDNESDAY MORNING AS LOW PRESSURE 
DEPARTS. STRONG COLD FRONT WILL BE MOVING QUICKLY SOUTHWARD THROUGH 
THE PLAINS DURING THE AFTERNOON HOURS...WITH A FEW SHOWERS 
DEVELOPING AHEAD OF THE FRONT IN WESTERN ARKANSAS.

AS FRONT APPROACHES...CLOUDS SHOULD BREAK UP IN MANY AREAS...WITH 
WARMER TEMPERATURES. AFTER READINGS PEAK IN THE 60S TO LOWER 70S 
TODAY...READINGS WEDNESDAY WILL CLIMB INTO THE MID 60S TO MID 
70S. 

FRONT WILL HEAD THROUGH STATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT...WITH SCATTERED 
SHOWERS SURROUNDING FRONT. ALSO QUITE A BIT OF WIND...WITH BREEZY 
CONDITIONS DEVELOPING.

ON THURSDAY...WINDY AND COOLER WITH WRAPAROUND MOISTURE BEHIND FRONT 
IN NORTHERN/CENTRAL ARKANSAS. THIS WILL BRING CLOUDS AND SMALL 
CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION.

HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD INTO REGION THURSDAY NIGHT...WITH SKY 
CLEARING AND WINDS DECREASING. THIS WILL ALLOW TEMPERATURES TO 
DROP INTO THE UPPER 30S TO MID 40S.                 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH MONDAY
A GRADUAL WARMING TREND OVER THE REGION AS WESTERLY FLOW BECOMES 
ESTABLISHED DURING THE WEEKEND. MOISTURE RETURN WILL LIMITED...SO 
HAVE CONTINUED GOING DRY FORECAST. MODELS ARE HINTING AT SHORTWAVES 
MOVING THROUGH IN THE FLOW...BUT WILL WAIT UNTIL BETTER CONSISTENCY 
BEFORE ADDING POPS TO THE FORECAST.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    68  55  70  48 /  20  20  10  30 
HARRISON AR       59  48  65  41 /  60  40  20  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    67  55  73  48 /  20  10  10  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     70  56  71  50 /  10  10  10  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  59  48  63  43 /  60  40  20  30 
MONTICELLO AR     72  55  72  51 /  10  10  10  20 
SEARCY AR         66  54  69  47 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      66  55  73  47 /  20  10  20  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   64  53  71  46 /  40  20  20  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

BEFORE ADDING POPS TO THE FORECAST.

MADE ADJUSTMENTS TO THE POPS AND TO TEMPERATURES IN THE FIRST PERIOD 
GRIDS. CLOUDS WILL KEEP A WIDE RANGE OF TEMPS ACROSS THE STATE FROM 
NORTH TO SOUTH. UPDATE OUT ALREADY...PREVIOUS DISCUSSION FOLLOWS...

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

46/58








000 
FXUS64 KLZK 121729
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1215 AM CDT TUE OCT 12 2004

MADE ADJUSTMENTS TO THE POPS AND TO TEMPERATURES IN THE FIRST PERIOD 
GRIDS. CLOUDS WILL KEEP A WIDE RANGE OF TEMPS ACROSS THE STATE FROM 
NORTH TO SOUTH. UPDATE OUT ALREADY...PREVIOUS DISCUSSION FOLLOWS...

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT
LOW PRESSURE ALOFT WILL HEAD THROUGH SOUTHERN MISSOURI TODAY FROM 
THE SOUTHERN PLAINS. CLOUDS WILL REMAIN OVER NORTHERN AND CENTRAL 
ARKANSAS...WITH CLOUDS BREAKING UP IN THE SOUTH.

AFTER SOME PATCHY DENSE FOG THIS MORNING...WILL HAVE SCATTERED TO 
NUMEROUS SHOWERS IN NORTHERN ARKANSAS...WITH SHOWERS BECOMING MORE 
ISOLATED TOWARD CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE STATE. NO RAIN IN THE 
FORECAST ACROSS THE SOUTH.

WILL KEEP SCATTERED SHOWERS IN NORTHERN ARKANSAS TONIGHT...WITH 
PRECIPITATION HEADING EAST WEDNESDAY MORNING AS LOW PRESSURE 
DEPARTS. STRONG COLD FRONT WILL BE MOVING QUICKLY SOUTHWARD THROUGH 
THE PLAINS DURING THE AFTERNOON HOURS...WITH A FEW SHOWERS 
DEVELOPING AHEAD OF THE FRONT IN WESTERN ARKANSAS.

AS FRONT APPROACHES...CLOUDS SHOULD BREAK UP IN MANY AREAS...WITH 
WARMER TEMPERATURES. AFTER READINGS PEAK IN THE 60S TO LOWER 70S 
TODAY...READINGS WEDNESDAY WILL CLIMB INTO THE MID 60S TO MID 
70S. 

FRONT WILL HEAD THROUGH STATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT...WITH SCATTERED 
SHOWERS SURROUNDING FRONT. ALSO QUITE A BIT OF WIND...WITH BREEZY 
CONDITIONS DEVELOPING.

ON THURSDAY...WINDY AND COOLER WITH WRAPAROUND MOISTURE BEHIND FRONT 
IN NORTHERN/CENTRAL ARKANSAS. THIS WILL BRING CLOUDS AND SMALL 
CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION.

HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD INTO REGION THURSDAY NIGHT...WITH SKY 
CLEARING AND WINDS DECREASING. THIS WILL ALLOW TEMPERATURES TO 
DROP INTO THE UPPER 30S TO MID 40S.                 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH MONDAY
A GRADUAL WARMING TREND OVER THE REGION AS WESTERLY FLOW BECOMES 
ESTABLISHED DURING THE WEEKEND. MOISTURE RETURN WILL LIMITED...SO 
HAVE CONTINUED GOING DRY FORECAST. MODELS ARE HINTING AT SHORTWAVES 
MOVING THROUGH IN THE FLOW...BUT WILL WAIT UNTIL BETTER CONSISTENCY 
BEFORE ADDING POPS TO THE FORECAST.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    68  55  70  48 /  20  20  10  30 
HARRISON AR       59  48  65  41 /  60  40  20  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    67  55  73  48 /  20  10  10  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     70  56  71  50 /  10  10  10  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  59  48  63  43 /  60  40  20  30 
MONTICELLO AR     72  55  72  51 /  10  10  10  20 
SEARCY AR         66  54  69  47 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      66  55  73  47 /  20  10  20  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   64  53  71  46 /  40  20  20  30

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
941 PM CDT MON OCT 11 2004

.DISCUSSION...
KLZK RADAR CONTINUES TO SHOW PATCHY LIGHT RAIN MAINLY ACROSS THE 
NORTHEAST SECTIONS. SATELLITE IMAGES INDICATE AN ABUNDANCE OF CLOUDS 
ACROSS THE AREA WITH A FEW BREAKS ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST CORNER. LOW 
PRESSURE REMAINS OVER ARKANSAS AT THE SURFACE AND AN UPPER LOW IS 
JUST NORTHWEST OF THE STATE. WITH THE BREAK IN THE CLOUD COVER 
BEFORE SUNSET...TEMPERATURES ROSE NICELY IN THE SOUTHEAST CORNER. 
ALSO...GIVEN THE CLOUD COVER...WILL INCREASE TEMPERATURES ACROSS THE 
SOUTH. POPS LOOK TO BE IN GOOD SHAPE FOR THE NIGHT WITH THE BEST 
CHANCE IN THE NORTH...NEAR THE UPPER LOW.

51






725 
FXUS64 KLZK 111918
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
216 PM CDT MON OCT 11 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT...
DATA STILL COMING IN LATER THAN USUAL DUE TO SOME COMPUTER CONCERNS 
BUT ALL INDICATIONS ARE THAT THE UNSETTLED PATTERN WILL CONTINUE FOR 
THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS. COMPARING THE CURRENT POSITIONING OF THE 
FEATURES BASED OFF THE OLDER RUNS...THE GFS SEEMS TO HAVE A REAL 
GOOD HANDLE ON THE OVERALL SITUATION. GFS MODEL ALSO THE MOST 
CONSISTENT OF LATE WITH ETA SEEMINGLY PLAYING CATCH UP ALL THE TIME. 
THAT BEING SAID...WILL LEAN IN THE DIRECTION OF THE GFS THIS 
AFTERNOON.

CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES THE CENTER OF WHAT WAS ONCE MATTHEW 
ALONG THE STONE COUNTY/CLEBURNE COUNTY BORDER. SYSTEM CONTINUES 
TO FILL AND WEAKEN AS IT DRIFTS OFF TO THE NORTHEAST. WATER VAPOR  
IMAGERY SHOWS AIR MASS DRYING OUT CONSIDERABLY BUT LOW LEVEL 
MOISTURE WILL REMAIN PLENTIFUL. WIDESPREAD PRECIPITATION HAS MOVED 
WELL OFF TO THE NORTHEAST BUT SCATTERED SHOWERS ARE STILL POSSIBLE 
THROUGH THE NIGHT WITH SEVERAL WEAK UPPER LEVEL DISTURBANCES 
RIPPLING THROUGH THE MEAN FLOW. 

NEXT CONCERN WILL BE LOW PRESSURE ALOFT. WATER VAPOR IMAGERY SHOWS 
THIS FEATURE CURRENTLY OVER CENTRAL OKLAHOMA. UPPER LOW PROGGED TO 
SLOWLY CROSS THE STATE LATE TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY. LOW IS PROGGED 
TO STRADDLE THE ARKANSAS/MISSOURI BORDER SO CHANCES FOR ADDITIONAL 
RAIN WILL MAINLY BE ACROSS THE NORTHERN AND CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE 
STATE WHERE BEST DYNAMICS LAY. PRECIPITATION WILL BE MORE SCATTERED 
IN NATURE THAN WHAT HAS OCCURRED OVER THE PAST SEVERAL DAYS WHERE 
SOME ARAES SAW NEARLY 8 INCHES OF RAIN.  LOTS OF CLOUDS IN FORECAST 
AND WITH NORTHEAST WIND AND SOME PRECIPITATION IN THE FORECAST... 
TUESDAY PROMISES TO BE COOL WITH READINGS WELL BELOW NORMAL.

ONCE UPPER LOW PASSES...STRONG COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH FROM THE 
WEST. THERE MAY BE A BRIEF PERIOD OF CLEARING WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON 
BETWEEN SYSTEMS BUT ANY SUNSHINE WILL BE SHORT LIVED. SCATTERED 
SHOWERS WILL ACCOMPANY THE FRONT AS IT MOVES THROUGH VERY QUICKLY 
WEDNESDAY NIGHT. DEEP TROF AXIS WITH AN UPPER LEVEL LOW IN ITS BASE 
SWINGS THROUGH NORTHERN THURSDAY MORNING SO SCATTERED POPS ONCE 
AGAIN ARE SUPPORTED. MODELS INDICATING STRONG RIDGING OFF THE WEST 
COAST AS THE NEARLY FULL LATITUDE TROF MOVES INTO THE EASTERN CONUS 
BY FRIDAY MORNING. GUSTY NORTH TO NORTHWEST WINDS WILL DEVELOP 
BEHIND THE FRONT WITH A CONSIDERABLY COOLER AIR MASS MOVING IN. 
SECONDARY COLD FRONT WILL MOVE ACROSS THE AREA LATE FRIDAY AND 
FRIDAY NIGHT BUT APPEARS TO BE DRY. IT WILL ACT TO REINFORCE THE 
COOL AIR OVER THE REGION. FOR TEMPERATURES...WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF 
MAV/FWC NUMBERS. TEMPERATURES WILL AVERAGE BELOW NORMAL THROUGH OUT 
THE PERIOD.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY
THIS TERM WILL BEGIN WITH NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT AND IT WILL 
TRANSITION TO WESTERLY FLOW BY MONDAY AFTERNOON. NO SIGNIFICANT 
SHORT WAVES WILL INTERACT WITH OUR SURFACE PATTERN AFTER THE LONG 
WAVE TROF MOVES ACROSS THE STATE THURSDAY. A DEEP SURFACE LOW WILL 
BE DROPPING SOUTHEAST ACROSS THE NORTHERN ROCKIES FROM CANADA 
SATURDAY. THEN...ON SUNDAY...THE LOW WILL BRING STRONG FLOW ACROSS 
THE SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL PLAINS AND THE MID SOUTH. A SURFACE HIGH 
OVER THE NORTHERN ROCKIES WILL SLIDE SOUTHEAST PUSHING A SHOT OF 
REINFORCING COOL AND DRY AIR FOR MONDAY. CURRENT GRIDS ON TRACK SO 
CHANGES WERE MINIMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    57  66  50  71 /  30  30  30  20 
HARRISON AR       51  59  46  67 /  60  40  30  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    56  66  51  73 /  30  30  20  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     58  68  52  72 /  30  30  30  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  51  59  45  66 /  50  40  40  20 
MONTICELLO AR     58  70  52  72 /  20  30  30  10 
SEARCY AR         56  65  49  69 /  40  40  40  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      55  66  51  73 /  40  30  20  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   54  65  50  71 /  40  40  30  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED

748 AM CDT MON OCT 11 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATE ON THE WAY THIS MORNING TO ADJUST POPS DOWNWARD MOST 
LOCATIONS. LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES REMNANTS OF MATTHEW IN 
WESTERN OUACHITA COUNTY AND CONTINUING TO WEAKEN. SURGE OF TROPICAL 
MOISTURE HAS MOVED TO THE NORTH WITH STEADY PRECIPITATION NOW 
CONFINED TO THE NORTHERN QUARTER OF THE STATE. UPPER LOW OVER 
SOUTHWEST OKLAHOMA WILL CONTINUE TO WOBBLE AROUND KEEPING ABUNDANT 
LOW LEVEL MOISTURE IN PLACE. COMBINATION OF BOTH SYSTEMS WILL 
WARRANT AT LEAST SCATTERED POPS THROUGH THE DAY ALTHOUGH TAPERING 
OFF FROM SOUTH TO NORTH AS THE DAY PROGRESSES. UPPER LOW AND COLD 
FRONT WILL KEEP CHANCES OF RAIN IN THE FORECAST FOR THE NEXT SEVERAL 
DAYS AS WELL.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

394 
FXUS64 KLZK 110905
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
355 AM CDT MON OCT 11 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT
REMNANTS OF TROPICAL STORM MATTHEW HEADING THROUGH WESTERN 
MISSISSIPPI EARLY THIS MORNING...AND WILL CONTINUE PROGRESSING INTO 
EASTERN ARKANSAS THIS AFTERNOON. AS REMNANTS LIFT TO THE NORTH...SO 
TOO WILL ABUNDANT MOISTURE...WITH ONLY ISOLATED SHOWERS IN THE SOUTH 
AND LIKELY CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION TOWARD THE MISSOURI BORDER.

WIDESPREAD PRECIPITATION WILL EVENTUALLY END STATEWIDE LATER THIS 
AFTERNOON/EVENING...BUT STILL HAVE LOW PRESSURE ALOFT TO DEAL WITH 
IN THE SOUTHERN PLAINS. LOW WILL HEAD OVER REGION TONIGHT/TUESDAY... 
SPREADING MORE CHANCES FOR SHOWERS ACROSS MAINLY NORTHERN/CENTRAL 
ARKANSAS.

WITH REMNANTS OF MATTHEW TODAY/LOW PRESSURE ALOFT TUESDAY...LOTS OF 
CLOUDS IN FORECAST. WITH NORTHEAST WIND AND SOME PRECIPITATION 
CONTINUING...COOL DAYTIME TEMPERATURES EXPECTED...WITH READINGS WELL 
BELOW NORMAL.

LOOKING AHEAD TO WEDNESDAY...LOW PRESSURE ALOFT WILL EXIT TO 
EAST...BUT WILL BE QUICKLY FOLLOWED BY STRONG COLD FRONT FROM THE 
NORTHWEST WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON/NIGHT. ANY BREAKUP OF CLOUDS AHEAD OF 
FRONT WILL BE BRIEF...WITH SCATTERED SHOWERS AS FRONT BLOWS THROUGH. 

SURROUNDING FRONT...WILL BE STRONG/GUSTY NORTH TO NORTHWEST 
WIND...WHICH WILL BE FELT WEDNESDAY NIGHT INTO THURSDAY. COOLER AIR 
WILL ALSO FOLLOW FRONT.         
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SUNDAY
AFTER FRONT MOVES THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT...TEMPS WILL BE THE MAIN 
STORY IN THE EXTENDED. COOLER READINGS THURSDAY...BEFORE A GRADUAL 
WARMUP BEGINS. A WEAK SHORTWAVE WILL MOVE THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT...BUT 
DID NOT INTRODUCE ANY POPS.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    67  58  67  53 /  60  30  40  40

PINE BLUFF AR     68  59  69  55 /  40  20  20  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  59  52  60  48 /  90  50  70  70 
MONTICELLO AR     71  59  71  55 /  30  20  20  30

MOUNT IDA AR      67  56  67  54 /  60  40  40  40


187 
FXUS64 KLZK 110238
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
938 PM CDT SUN OCT 10 2004

.DISCUSSION...
REMAINS OF MATTHEW CURRENTLY MOVING NORTHWARD FROM SOUTHWEST 
MISSISSIPPI AND THE FLORIDA PARISHES OF LOUISIANA. UPPER LOW INVOF 
NORTH TEXAS AND SOUTHERN OKLAHOMA CONTINUES TO PUMP MOISTURE UP FROM 
THE GULF AS WELL. THUS...PERIODS OF RAIN WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE 
OVERNIGHT HOURS.

FORECAST ON THE WHOLE IS IN GREAT SHAPE...WITH ONLY SOME TEMPORAL 
ADJUSTMENTS NEEDED TO THE TEXT PRODUCTS. AS FAR AS THE GRIDS 
GO...HAVE UPPED QPF AMOUNTS OVER THE EASTERN HALF OF THE FORECAST 
AREA...AS MOISTURE CONTINUES LIFTING NORTHWARD AND INTERACTING WITH 
UPPER SUPPORT OVER SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS/NORTHERN MISSISSIPPI. 
BASICALLY...THE AXIS OF MORE ABUNDANT RAINFALL HAS SHIFTED TO 
EASTERN ARKANSAS TONIGHT WITH SOME AREAS LIKELY TO PICK UP AS MUCH 
AS ANOTHER HALF TO THREE QUARTERS OF AN INCH OR GREATER. 

HAVE ALSO BETTER ADJUSTED TEMPS AND DEWPOINTS AS WELL AS WINDS TO 
BETTER ACCOUNT FOR ONGOING TRENDS. IN MUCH OF THE AREA...NOCTURNAL 
RANGE WILL BE LITTLE TO NONE. 

UPDATED TEXT AND GRAPHICAL FORECASTS HAVE BEEN SENT. UPDATE TO 
GRIDDED FORECASTS WILL BE OUT SHORTLY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

57





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 110238
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
938 PM CDT SUN OCT 10 2004

.DISCUSSION...
REMAINS OF MATTHEW CURRENTLY MOVING NORTHWARD FROM SOUTHWEST 
MISSISSIPPI AND THE FLORIDA PARISHES OF LOUISIANA. UPPER LOW INVOF 
NORTH TEXAS AND SOUTHERN OKLAHOMA CONTINUES TO PUMP MOISTURE UP FROM 
THE GULF AS WELL. THUS...PERIODS OF RAIN WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE 
OVERNIGHT HOURS.

FORECAST ON THE WHOLE IS IN GREAT SHAPE...WITH ONLY SOME TEMPORAL 
ADJUSTMENTS NEEDED TO THE TEXT PRODUCTS. AS FAR AS THE GRIDS 
GO...HAVE UPPED QPF AMOUNTS OVER THE EASTERN HALF OF THE FORECAST 
AREA...AS MOISTURE CONTINUES LIFTING NORTHWARD AND INTERACTING WITH 
UPPER SUPPORT OVER SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS/NORTHERN MISSISSIPPI. 
BASICALLY...THE AXIS OF MORE ABUNDANT RAINFALL HAS SHIFTED TO 
EASTERN ARKANSAS TONIGHT WITH SOME AREAS LIKELY TO PICK UP AS MUCH 
AS ANOTHER HALF TO THREE QUARTERS OF AN INCH OR GREATER. 

HAVE ALSO BETTER ADJUSTED TEMPS AND DEWPOINTS AS WELL AS WINDS TO 
BETTER ACCOUNT FOR ONGOING TRENDS. IN MUCH OF THE AREA...NOCTURNAL 
RANGE WILL BE LITTLE TO NONE.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
340 PM CDT SUN OCT 10 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT
WET PATTERN TO CONTINUE OVER THE FORECAST AREA FOR ANOTHER DAY OR 
SO. REMNANTS OF TROPICAL STORM MATTHEW WILL CONTINUE TO PUSH 
MOISTURE INTO ARKANSAS AHEAD OF STRONG H5 TROF. MORE RAIN IS IN THE 
OFFING TONIGHT AND MONDAY WITH HIGH POPS BOTH PERIODS. H5 TROF WILL 
CONTINUE TO AFFECT THE AREA INTO TUESDAY NIGHT. SIGNIFICANT COLD 
FRONT WILL AFFECT THE AREA BY WEDNESDAY NIGHT. MOISTURE VERY LIMITED 
SO ONLY HAVE SMALL POPS IN FOR WEDNESDAY NIGHT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SUNDAY
A FAIRLY GOOD COOL DOWN WILL OCCUR BEHIND THE FRONT. DRY WEATHER 
WILL BE THE RULE IN THE LONG TERM PORTION. A WARMING TREND WILL 
BEGIN BY THE END OF THE WEEKEND.  

&&

22/38








755 
FXUS64 KLZK 101546 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1045 AM CDT SUN OCT 10 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST ON TRACK. UPDATED TEXT PRODUCTS TO REMOVE MORNING 
WORDING. TWEAKED GRIDS SLIGHTLY AFTER REVIEW OF 15Z CONDITIONS. ALL 
UPDATES OUT. 

&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
REMNANTS OF TROPICAL STORM MATTHEW HEADING INLAND THROUGH EASTERN 
LOUISIANA TODAY. PLENTY OF MOISTURE SURROUNDING SYSTEM...WITH 
WIDESPREAD RAIN IN ARKANSAS TODAY/TONIGHT. WHILE 1 TO 2 INCH TOTALS 
LIKELY...AND LOCALLY MORE...RAIN SPREAD OUT OVER LONG PERIOD OF TIME 
WITH WATER PRETTY MUCH SOAKING INTO GROUND. GIVEN THIS...WILL OPT 
NOT TO ISSUE FLASH FLOOD WATCH AT THIS TIME.

AS REMNANTS OF MATTHEW CONTINUE HEADING NORTH ON COLUMBUS 
DAY...MOISTURE WILL MARKEDLY DECREASE FROM THE SOUTH WITH RAIN 
CHANCES ON THE DECLINE. 

TROUGH IN SOUTHERN PLAINS PROGGED TO MOVE OVER ARKANSAS MONDAY 
NIGHT/TUESDAY...KEEPING PLENTY OF CLOUDS IN FORECAST. ALSO...WILL 
KEEP CHANCES OF SHOWERS GOING MAINLY IN NORTHERN/CENTRAL 
COUNTIES. 

AS FAR AS TEMPERATURES...EAST/NORTHEAST WIND IN SHORT TERM TO NORTH 
OF MATTHEW ALONG WITH RAIN WILL KEEP READINGS WELL BELOW NORMAL 
TODAY/MONDAY. WIND WILL BECOME NORTH/NORTHWEST BY TUESDAY AS MATTHEW 
DEPARTS TO THE EAST. WITH CLOUDS STILL IN PLACE/TROUGH 
OVERHEAD...WILL CONTINUE WITH COOL TREND. (46)             

MAIN CONCERN IN THE EXTENDED IS TEMPS. STRONG COLD FRONT WILL MAKE 
ITS WAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT...WITH COOLER TEMPS BEHIND IT. NOT 
MUCH MOISTURE WITH THE FRONT...SO ONLY SLIGHT CHANCE OF RAIN. TEMPS 
WILL BE 5 TO 10 DEGREES BELOW NORMAL THROUGH THE END OF THE WEEK.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

045 
FXUS64 KLZK 100309
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1010 PM CDT SAT OCT 9 2004

.DISCUSSION...
AREA OF RAIN THAT HAS RESIDED IN ABOUT THE SOUTHERN ONE HALF OF
THE CWA THROUGH THE EVENING IS SHOWING SIGNS OF SPREADING SLOWLY
TO THE NORTH. RAIN SHOULD COVER CENTRAL SECTIONS BY MIDNIGHT BUT
ARRIVAL INTO NORTHERN SECTIONS MAY NOT COME UNTIL VERY LATE TONIGHT 
OR SUNDAY MORNING. DUE TO THIS...LOWERED POPS TO CHANCE IN THE 
NORTH FOR THE REST OF THE NIGHT AND LOWERED QPF TO ONLY A FEW
HUNDREDTHS OF AN INCH. OTHERWISE KEPT OTHER POPS ABOUT THE SAME
INDICATING AN INCREASE ACROSS CENTRAL SECTIONS AS THE NIGHT GOES ON. 
WENT WITH 90 PERCENT POPS IN THE SOUTH AND INCREASED QPF A LITTLE 
TO UP TO 1/2 INCH. REST OF FORECAST FOR TONIGHT LOOKS ON TRACK.
TROPICAL STORM MATTHEW MAY BE MOVING A LITTLE FARTHER EAST THAN 
THOUGHT EARLIER. STILL SOME UNCERTAINTY ABOUT HOW MUCH TROPICAL
MOISTURE AND ASSOCIATED HEAVY RAINFALL WILL AFFECT THE CWA BUT 
LEFT FORECAST BEYOND TONIGHT UNCHANGED.     
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

FXUS64 KLZK 092022
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
320 PM CDT SAT OCT  9 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
VERY WET PERIOD FOR THE AREA INTO MONDAY. GULF MOISTURE CONTINUES TO 
STREAM NORTHWARD AHEAD OF TROPICAL STORM MATTHEW. THIS COUPLED WITH 
H5 TROF IN THE VICINITY WILL KEEP WIDESPREAD RAIN IN THE FORECAST 
INTO MONDAY. UNQUALIFIED POPS IN MOST AREAS TONIGHT...SUNDAY...AND 
SUNDAY NIGHT. RAIN CHANCES BEGAN TO SLOWLY DECREASE ON MONDAY AS H5 
SYSTEM MOVES FINALLY MOVES BY. MOISTURE IS SLOW TO MOVE OUT BEHIND 
H5 LOW...SO QUITE A BIT OF CLOUDINESS FORECAST FOR TUESDAY. DRY 
WEATHER EXPECTED ON TUESDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
NEXT COLD FRONT WITH A FAIRLY SIGNIFICANT COOLDOWN WILL MOVE THROUGH 
THE AREA WEDNESDAY NIGHT. WITH ONLY LIMITED MOISTURE AVAILABLE... 
HAVE GONE WITH JUST SMALL POPS WEDNESDAY NIGHT. MUCH COOLER READINGS 
EXPECTED INTO THE END OF THE WEEK. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    62  66  60  68 /  80  90  90  60 
HARRISON AR       59  64  57  66 /  60  80  90  80

PINE BLUFF AR     63  67  62  69 /  90  90  90  60


820 
FXUS64 KLZK 091437 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
935 AM CDT SAT OCT 9 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST PRETTY MUCH ON TRACK. UPDATED TEXT PRODUCTS TO 
REMOVE MORNING WORDING. TWEAKED MAXIMUM TEMPERATURES AND DEWPOINTS
FOR THIS AFTERNOON AFTER REVIEW OF CURRENT CONDITIONS. ALL UPDATES 
OUT SHORTLY. 
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
TROPICAL STORM MATTHEW IN GULF OF MEXICO WILL CONTINUE TO SPREAD 
MOISTURE INTO ARKANSAS FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE WEEKEND. COLD FRONT 
TO NORTHWEST WILL HEAD INTO THE STATE TODAY BEFORE STALLING 
TONIGHT/SUNDAY. AROUND FRONT...COOL NORTHEAST WIND WILL BE NOTED 
WITH OVERCAST SKY/WIDESPREAD RAIN. 

DAYTIME TEMPERATURES WELL BELOW NORMAL THE NEXT COUPLE OF 
DAYS...WITH ONLY A FEW DEGREES SEPARATING DAYTIME AND NIGHTTIME 
READINGS. 

PRECIPITATION TRENDS FOR TODAY WILL SHOW RAIN MAINLY CONFINED TO 
CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. AS MATTHEW HEADS TOWARD THE CENTRAL GULF 
COAST...RAIN WILL SPREAD FARTHER NORTH TONIGHT/SUNDAY WITH AREAS OF 
FOG DEVELOPING.

WIDESPREAD PRECIPITATION WILL BEGIN SHIFTING TO THE NORTH ON 
COLUMBUS DAY...BUT RAIN CHANCES WILL REMAIN HIGH OVER NORTHERN 
HALF OF THE STATE. AGAIN...DAYTIME TEMPERATURES HELD DOWN BY 
CLOUDS/RAIN. 

CLOUDS/PRECIPITATION PRETTY MUCH OVER HEADING INTO MIDWEEK WITH 
WARMER DAYTIME TEMPERATURES. HOWEVER...THIS WILL BE SQUELCHED 
THURSDAY/FRIDAY AS A SIGNIFICANT COLD FRONT ARRIVES FROM THE 
NORTHWEST. LOW CHANCES OF RAIN WITH FRONT...BUT LIKELY THE COOLEST 
AIR OF THE YOUNG FALL SEASON BEHIND THE FRONT. (46) 

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

TONIGHT/SUNDAY. AROUND FRONT...COOL NORTHEAST WIND WILL BE NOTED 
WITH OVERCAST SKY/WIDESPREAD RAIN. 

DAYTIME TEMPERATURES WELL BELOW NORMAL THE NEXT COUPLE OF 
DAYS...WITH ONLY A FEW DEGREES SEPARATING DAYTIME AND NIGHTTIME 
READINGS. 

PRECIPITATION TRENDS FOR TODAY WILL SHOW RAIN MAINLY CONFINED TO 
CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. AS MATTHEW HEADS TOWARD THE CENTRAL GULF 
COAST...RAIN WILL SPREAD FARTHER NORTH TONIGHT/SUNDAY WITH AREAS OF 
FOG DEVELOPING.

WIDESPREAD PRECIPITATION WILL BEGIN SHIFTING TO THE NORTH ON 
COLUMBUS DAY...BUT RAIN CHANCES WILL REMAIN HIGH OVER NORTHERN 
HALF OF THE STATE. AGAIN...DAYTIME TEMPERATURES HELD DOWN BY 
CLOUDS/RAIN. 

CLOUDS/PRECIPITATION PRETTY MUCH OVER HEADING INTO MIDWEEK WITH 
WARMER DAYTIME TEMPERATURES. HOWEVER...THIS WILL BE SQUELCHED 
THURSDAY/FRIDAY AS A SIGNIFICANT COLD FRONT ARRIVES FROM THE 
NORTHWEST. LOW CHANCES OF RAIN WITH FRONT...BUT LIKELY THE COOLEST 
AIR OF THE YOUNG FALL SEASON BEHIND THE FRONT. (46) 

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

046 
FXUS64 KLZK 090304
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1000 PM CDT FRI OCT 8 2004

.DISCUSSION...
MAIN AREA OF RAIN HAS MOVED INTO SOUTHEASTERN PARTS OF THE CWA WITH
PATCHY RAIN ELSEWHERE. UPDATED POPS TO FIT THIS PATTERN WHICH MAY 
NOT CHANGE MUCH THE REST OF THE NIGHT. SOME CHANCE RAIN AREA COULD 
RETURN BACK NORTH A LITTLE WITH UPPER TROF MOVING A LITTLE CLOSER
SO HAVE SLIGHTLY HIGHER POPS IN CENTRAL AND EASTERN ZONES. ADDITIONAL
RAINFALL IN MOST AREAS SHOULD NOT BE MORE THAN .10 INCH BUT WENT
UP TO ONE INCH ADDITIONAL IN FAR SOUTHEAST. MOST AREAS WHERE RAIN 
HAS MOSTLY ENDED HAS HAD 2 TO 5 INCHES OF RAIN WITH HUMIDITIES CLOSE
TO SATURATION SO PUT IN AREAS OF FOG FOR THE REST OF TONIGHT INTO
SATURDAY MORNING.     
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

180 
FXUS64 KLZK 082019
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
320 PM CDT FRI OCT  8 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
HEAVY RAIN OCCURRED OVER MUCH OF THE FORECAST AREA TODAY. 
HOWEVER...GROUND WAS SO DRY THAT IT ABSORBED IT LIKE A SPONGE WITH 
NOT A LOT OF RUNOFF. AREA OF RAINFALL CONTINUED TO DRIFT EASTWARD 
DURING THE AFTERNOON. WILL CONTINUE SMALL CHANCES OF RAIN IN THE 
NORTHWEST AND WEST TONIGHT...WITH HIGHER POPS CONTINUING ELSEWHERE. 
HEAVIEST MOISTURE WILL REMAIN OVER THE SOUTHEAST HALF OF THE AREA 
SATURDAY AND SATURDAY NIGHT. HAVE HIGHEST POPS IN THOSE AREAS FOR 
SATURDAY AND SATURDAY NIGHT...BUT RAINFALL AMOUNTS SHOULD BE LIGHT 
IN MOST AREAS. H5 LOW GETS CLOSER TO THE AREA ON SUNDAY. HAVE 
INCREASED POPS AGAIN FOR SUNDAY. RAINFALL WILL BEGIN TO TAPER OFF ON 
MONDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
DRY WEATHER WILL BE THE RULE TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. NEXT COLD FRONT 
WILL BRING SMALL CHANCES OF RAINFALL WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY. A 
FAIRLY SHARP COOLDOWN WILL OCCUR WITH THE FRONT.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    60  68  60  71 /  70  60  50  60 
HARRISON AR       56  65  55  67 /  30  30  40  60 
HOT SPRINGS AR    60  68  60  71 /  60  60  60  60 
PINE BLUFF AR     61  68  61  73 /  80  70  60  60 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  56  65  55  67 /  40  30  30  60 
MONTICELLO AR     62  69  62  74 /  80  70  60  60 
SEARCY AR         59  68  59  70 /  70  50  50  60 
MOUNT IDA AR      60  68  60  71 /  50  50  60  60 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   59  67  58  69 /  50  40  50  60



793 
FXUS64 KLZK 080903
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
355 AM CDT FRI OCT 8 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LOTS OF MOISTURE PRETTY MUCH STUCK OVER THE SOUTH CENTRAL UNITED
STATES. MOISTURE BETWEEN DEEPENING TROUGH IN THE SOUTHERN PLAINS
AND FAIRLY STRONG HIGH PRESSURE TO THE NORTH AND EAST. SLOW MOVING
STORM SYSTEM IN THE GULF OF MEXICO WITH GOOD CHANCES FOR RAIN
THROUGH THE WEEKEND.

RAIN COULD BE SIGNIFICANT...WITH ALREADY TWO TO THREE INCHES OF
PRECIPITATION OVERNIGHT IN PORTIONS OF WESTERN ARKANSAS. LARGE
PRECIPITATION SHIELD COVERING WESTERN HALF OF STATE EARLY
THIS MORNING...WITH THE RAIN EXPECTED TO PUSH SLOWLY EASTWARD
TODAY.

WITH LOTS OF CLOUDS AND RAIN...LOWERED AFTERNOON TEMPERATURES QUITE
A BIT...ESPECIALLY FROM LITTLE ROCK WESTWARD.

MOISTURE WILL GET SHUNTED TO THE SOUTH A BIT TONIGHT/SATURDAY AS
HIGH PRESSURE STRENGHENS NORTH OF THE REGION. LOWERED CHANCES OF
RAIN NORTH/CENTRAL ARKANSAS...WITH SHOWERS/A FEW THUNDERSTORMS
REMAINING LIKELY IN SOUTHERN ARKANSAS.

HIGH WILL MOVE TO THE EAST A BIT ON SUNDAY...ALLOWING MOISTURE TO
SURGE NORTH ONCE AGAIN. RAIN CHANCES ON THE WAY UP...AND WOULD NOT BE
SURPRISED TO SEE ANOTHER ROUND OF HEAVY PRECIPITATION.

THROUGH THE WEEKEND...KEPT HIGH TEMPERATURES PRETTY MUCH IN THE
UPPER 60S/LOWER 70S. READINGS WILL NOT DROP MUCH AT NIGHT...WITH
MID 50S/LOWER 60S IN THE FORECAST.

LOOKING AHEAD...LOW PRESSURE IN THE GULF WILL LIFT TO THE
NORTHEAST...WITH MOISTURE ON THE DECLINE BY TUESDAY. A BRIEF
WARMUP WILL OCCUR BEFORE A COLD FRONT FOLLOWS FROM CANADA BY
WEDNESDAY/THURSDAY. COOLER CONDITIONS BEHIND FRONT TO END
THE WEEK. (46)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    72  60  68  61 /  90  60  50  50
HARRISON AR       68  54  65  56 /  90  40  30  40
HOT SPRINGS AR    68  60  68  61 /  90  60  50  60
PINE BLUFF AR     72  61  68  62 /  90  60  60  60
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  69  54  65  56 /  90  40  30  30
MONTICELLO AR     73  63  69  63 /  80  60  60  60
SEARCY AR         73  59  68  60 /  80  60  40  50
MOUNT IDA AR      68  60  68  61 /  90  60  50  60
RUSSELLVILLE AR   68  58  67  59 /  90  60  40  50
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



537 
FXUS64 KLZK 080308
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1000 PM CDT THU OCT 7 2004

.DISCUSSION...
RAIN AND THUNDERSTORMS HAVE REMAINED CONFINED TO ABOUT THE WESTERN
HALF OF THE CWA WITH ONLY PATCHY ACTIVITY IN THE EAST. ANALYSIS
INDICATED HIGH PRESSURE HOLDING ON STRONG AT 850 AND 700 MB IN 
EASTERN AREAS LIKELY KEEPING DEEPER MOISTURE OUT OF THOSE AREAS. 
SURFACE SHOWED THE GULF HAS OPENED UP TO MOST OF THE CWA. FIGURE
RAIN PATTERN WILL NOT CHANGE MUCH OVERNIGHT ALTHOUGH THE RAIN MAY
MANAGE TO PUSH MORE INTO EASTERN SECTIONS. SET POPS FOR THE REST 
OF THE NIGHT TO 40 PERCENT IN THE EAST...60 PERCENT IN CENTRAL
AREAS...AND 80 PERCENT IN THE WEST. INCREASED QPF IN THE WEST 
WITH ONE INCH OR MORE POSSIBLE IN THE WEST CENTRAL AREAS THAT
TYPICALLY GET MORE RAINFALL IN GENERAL RAIN SITUATIONS. THIS
MAY BE CONSERVATIVE IN SOME AREAS. DECREASED QPF IN THE EAST 
TO ONLY A FEW HUNDREDTHS OF AN INCH. TWEAKED WIND FORECASTS
UP A LITTLE FOR TONIGHT BASED ON OBS AT FORECAST TIME. TEMP
FORECASTS STILL LOOK CLOSE AND WERE NOT CHANGED. LIGHTNING
HAS DECREASED IN THE WEST WITH LOSS OF HEATING AND DECREASING
INSTABILITY. CHANGED WORDING TO RAIN AND ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS
IN CENTRAL AND WEST FOR REST OF THE NIGHT. KEPT SHOWER/THUNDERSTORM
WORDING IN EAST WHERE INSTABILITY REMAINS HIGHER DUE TO HIGHER 
TEMPS THIS AFTERNOON WHICH HAVE CONTINUED THROUGH THE EVENING.   
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29










000 
FXUS64 KLZK 080308
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1000 PM CDT THU OCT 7 2004

.DISCUSSION...
RAIN AND THUNDERSTORMS HAVE REMAINED CONFINED TO ABOUT THE WESTERN
HALF OF THE CWA WITH ONLY PATCHY ACTIVITY IN THE EAST. ANALYSIS
INDICATED HIGH PRESSURE HOLDING ON STRONG AT 850 AND 700 MB IN 
EASTERN AREAS LIKELY KEEPING DEEPER MOISTURE OUT OF THOSE AREAS. 
SURFACE SHOWED THE GULF HAS OPENED UP TO MOST OF THE CWA. FIGURE
RAIN PATTERN WILL NOT CHANGE MUCH OVERNIGHT ALTHOUGH THE RAIN MAY
MANAGE TO PUSH MORE INTO EASTERN SECTIONS. SET POPS FOR THE REST 
OF THE NIGHT TO 40 PERCENT IN THE EAST...60 PERCENT IN CENTRAL
AREAS...AND 80 PERCENT IN THE WEST. INCREASED QPF IN THE WEST 
WITH ONE INCH OR MORE POSSIBLE IN THE WEST CENTRAL AREAS THAT
TYPICALLY GET MORE RAINFALL IN GENERAL RAIN SITUATIONS. THIS
MAY BE CONSERVATIVE IN SOME AREAS. DECREASED QPF IN THE EAST 
TO ONLY A FEW HUNDREDTHS OF AN INCH. TWEAKED WIND FORECASTS
UP A LITTLE FOR TONIGHT BASED ON OBS AT FORECAST TIME. TEMP
FORECASTS STILL LOOK CLOSE AND WERE NOT CHANGED. LIGHTNING
HAS DECREASED IN THE WEST WITH LOSS OF HEATING AND DECREASING
INSTABILITY. CHANGED WORDING TO RAIN AND ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS
IN CENTRAL AND WEST FOR REST OF THE NIGHT. KEPT SHOWER/THUNDERSTORM
WORDING IN EAST WHERE INSTABILITY REMAINS HIGHER DUE TO HIGHER 
TEMPS THIS AFTERNOON WHICH HAVE CONTINUED THROUGH THE EVENING.   
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
255 PM CDT THU OCT  7 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
LOW PRESSURE BOTH AT THE SURFACE AND ALOFT APPROACHING ARKANSAS FROM 
THE SOUTH AND WEST THIS AFTERNOON. MOISTURE VALUES HAVE SHOWN A 
STEADY INCREASE DURING THE AFTERNOON. HAVE INCREASING POPS ACROSS 
THE AREA OVERNIGHT. LIKELY POPS WILL CONTINUE ON FRIDAY WITH ONLY 
SLIGHT POP DECREASES FOR FRIDAY NIGHT. QUITE A BIT OF CLOUDINESS 
WILL REMAIN ON SATURDAY AND SUNDAY...BUT UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT WILL BE 
LESS. THUS...HAVE GONE WITH MORE CHANCE POPS FOR THE WEEKEND. CHANCE 
POPS CONTINUING THROUGH COLUMBUS DAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
DRY WEATHER EXPECTED FOR TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. NEXT SYSTEM WILL 
BRING CHANCE POPS WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY...AS MOISTURE 
SOMEWHAT LIMITED. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    65  76  57  75 /  70  70  40  30

HOT SPRINGS AR    65  75  57  76 /  80  80  50  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     66  77  58  76 /  60  60  40  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  61  74  56  74 /  70  70  50  30 
MONTICELLO AR     66  77  59  76 /  60  60  40  40 
SEARCY AR         64  76  57  75 /  60  60  40  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      65  75  57  76 /  80  80  60  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   64  75  57  75 /  80  80  50  30

38/22






188 
FXUS64 KLZK 070825
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
325 AM CDT THU OCT  7 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT...
BOTH THE GFS AND ETA SOLUTIONS ARE TENDING STRONGER WITH THE TROF 
LIFTING OUT OF THE FOUR CORNERS OVER THE NEXT DAY OR SO BUT ARE ALSO 
SHUNTING IT OFF FURTHER NORTH THAN PREVIOUS RUNS. OTHER CHANGES DEAL 
WITH THE DEVELOPING LOW IN THE GULF OF MEXICO. ETA SEEMS TO BE OUT 
ON ITS OWN WITH ITS SOLUTION OF BRINGING IT ON SHORE. GFS KEEP THE 
SYSTEM OFF SHORE WITH THE ASSOCIATED SURFACE TROUGH CONSIDERABLY 
FURTHER SOUTH THAN THE ETA. GFS SOLUTION BACKED UP BY OTHER SHORT 
TERM MODELS AND CONTINUES TO BE MORE CONSISTENT OVERALL. I HATE TO 
DISCOUNT THE ETA ENTIRELY AS IT LOOKS LIKE THE GFS DID A DAY OR SO 
AGO. THAT BEING SAID...WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS. 

LATEST ANALYSIS CONTINUES TO SHOW STRONG RIDGING OVER THE SOUTHEAST 
CONUS AND A STRONG SURFACE HIGH CENTERED OVER THE MID ATLANTIC. 
RETURN FLOW HAS RETURNED WITH DEW POINT TEMPERATURES SURGING INTO 
THE LOWER 60S OVER THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE STATE. DRY AIR THAT 
WAS IN PLACE STATE WIDE HAS BEEN PUSHED OFF TO THE NORTHEAST AND 
EXPECT MOISTURE TO INCREASE HERE AS WELL...JUST A LITTLE SLOWER WITH 
THE PROXIMITY OF THE HIGH PRESSURE. 

LOW LEVEL WWA FORECAST TO INCREASE DURING THE DAY TODAY AS TROUGH 
STARTS TO LIFT OUT. FAVORABLE JET DYNAMICS ALSO COME INTO PLAY AND 
EXPECT PRECIPITATION TO STEADILY INCREASE ACROSS THE AREA DURING THE 
LATE AFTERNOON. DYNAMICS REMAIN IN PLACE THROUGH THE OVERNIGHT HOURS 
AS THE TROF CONTINUES TO MOVE EAST/NORTHEAST. WILL NOT GO AS FAST 
WITH THE INITIATION OF PRECIPITATION ADVERTISED BY THE MODELS AS AIR 
MASS WILL STILL NEED SOME TIME TO MOISTEN UP. WILL HAVE HIGH 
SCATTERED TO LIKELY POPS ACROSS THE ENTIRE CWA BY THE END OF THE DAY 
AS PATTERN EVOLVES. WILL CONTINUE HIGH SCATTERED/LIKELY POPS THROUGH 
THE OVERNIGHT HOURS ACROSS THE REGION AS GUIDANCE COMING BACK WITH 
POPS IN THE 80 PERCENT AND ABOVE RANGE AND I REALLY HAVE NO REASON 
TO ARGUE.

ANOTHER FACTOR TO CONSIDER IS THE DEVELOPING SYSTEM IN THE GULF. 
WHILE GFS IS NOT AS AGGRESSIVE WITH THIS FEATURE AS THE ETA...PWAT 
VALUES ARE AT OR ABOVE 1.5 INCHES THROUGH OUT THE DAY. SURFACE WAVE 
WILL BE SITTING IN THE WESTERN GULF FRIDAY MORNING WITH GFS BRINGING 
INVERTED TROF AS FAR NORTH AS THE SOUTHERN BORDER OF THE STATE. ETA 
BRINGS THE INVERTED TROF INTO CENTRAL MISSOURI AND THE LOW MUCH 
FURTHER NORTH. THIS WOULD SUPPORT MUCH HEAVIER PRECIPITATION AMOUNTS 
THAN THE GFS. 

REGARDLESS...HIGH POPS WILL NEED TO BE CONTINUED ON FRIDAY AS DEEP 
MOISTURE WILL REMAIN AND JET DYNAMICS REMAIN FAVORABLE FOR 
OVERRUNNING PRECIP. RAIN WILL BE SLOW TO MOVE OUT FRIDAY AS TROF 
RUNS INTO THE HIGH STRETCHED OUT ALONG THE EASTERN SEABOARD. WILL 
TAPER POPS OFF FRIDAY NIGHT AS ENTIRE SYSTEM LIFTS OUT. SYSTEM OUT 
OF THE AREA BY SATURDAY WITH ANOTHER HIGH MOVING INTO THE UPPER 
MIDWEST AND SOME RIDGING ALOFT. SURFACE FLOW TURNS TO THE NORTHEAST 
ON SATURDAY AND CHANCE POPS SHOULD SUFFICE TO ACCOUNT FOR THE 
RESIDUAL MOISTURE AND THE SLOW MOVING WAVE STILL IN THE GULF. SAME 
SITUATION HOLD FOR SUNDAY AND WILL LOWER POPS TO CHANCE FOR THIS DAY.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...WITH INCREASING MOISTURE...CLOUDS AND POPS 
TEMPERATURES WILL BE TRICKY TODAY. STILL SHOULD BE ABLE TO SQUEEZE 
OUT ONE MORE DAY OF 80 IN THE METRO AND SOUTH BEFORE PRECIP STATES. 
TEMPS WILL BE IN THE 70S THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD. WILL GO WITH A 
BLEND OF FWC/MAV NUMBERS.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY...
CUT OFF LOW OVER THE SOUTHWEST PART OF THE COUNTRY WILL FILL SLOWLY 
AS IT APPROACHES FROM THE WEST. THIS WILL AMPLIFY A WEAK RIDGE OVER 
THE STATE TO BRING A BRIEF BREAK IN THE RAINFALL FOR TUESDAY 
AFTERNOON AND TUESDAY NIGHT. THEN...THE LONG WAVE TROF WILL PHASE IN 
WITH THE LOW AND IT WILL PUNCH TO THE EAST AS THE SYSTEM TRANSLATES 
EAST. THE SURFACE PATTERN WILL CONTINUE WET AS A SLUG OF MOISTURE 
MOVES ACROSS ARKANSAS ON THE BACK SIDE OF THE RETREATING SURFACE 
HIGH. TUESDAY AFTERNOON AND NIGHT WILL TAKE A BREAK FROM THE 
RAIN...THEN THE NEXT COLD FRONT WILL ROLL TO THE EAST UNDER THE 
INFLUENCE OF THE PHASING TROF ALOFT ON WEDNESDAY. HIGH TEMPERATURES 
WILL BE IN THE 70S FOR MONDAY...AND THEY WILL WARM TUESDAY WITH THE 
BREAK IN THE RAIN. IT WILL BE EVEN WARMER FOR WEDNESDAY WITH 
SOUTHERLY FLOW AHEAD OF THE NEXT FRONT.
&&
&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
THOUGH FINE FUELS REMAIN CRITICALLY DRY...MOISTURE HAS BEGUN TO 
INCREASE ACROSS THE AREA AS WINDS CONTINUE TO SHIFT TO MORE OF A 
SOUTHERLY DIRECTION. DEW POINT TEMPERATURES CONTINUE TO STEADILY 
RISE WITH WETTING RAIN LIKELY OVER THE CENTRAL AND NORTHERN 
DISTRICTS OVER THE NEXT THREE DAYS. THIS WILL ALLEVIATE THE DRY 
CONDITIONS IN THE SHORT TERM BUT RAINFALL AMOUNTS WILL LIKELY NOT BE 
ENOUGH TO HAVE A MAJOR IMPACT IN THE BIGGER SCHEME OF THINGS. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    81  63  74  57 /  50  60  60  40 
HARRISON AR       76  59  71  56 /  60  70  70  60 
HOT SPRINGS AR    80  63  74  57 /  60  70  70  50 
PINE BLUFF AR     82  64  75  58 /  50  50  60  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  77  59  71  56 /  60  60  70  50 
MONTICELLO AR     84  64  75  59 /  40  50  50  40 
SEARCY AR         80  62  74  57 /  50  50  60  40 
MOUNT IDA AR      80  63  74  57 /  60  70  70  60 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   78  62  74  57 /  60  70  70  50 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

872 
FXUS64 KLZK 070306
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1005 PM CDT WED OCT 6 2004

.DISCUSSION...
RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES ACROSS THE AREA AT THE SURFACE WITH
STRONG HIGH PRESSURE AT 850 MB CENTERED TO THE EAST OF THE AREA. 
THIS SHOULD MAKE MOISTURE RETURN INTO MUCH OF THE CWA VERY SLOW.
PATCHY SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS CONTINUE THIS EVENING TO THE WEST
OF THE CWA BUT MOVEMENT SUGGESTS IT WILL STAY MOSTLY TO THE WEST. 
SENT OUT UPDATE TO REMOVE TEMPORAL WORDING AND TRIMMED BACK SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS FOR TONIGHT TO JUST THE WESTERNMOST SET OF ZONES. REST
OF THE FORECAST LOOKS PRETTY GOOD BUT WENT A LITTLE LIGHTER ON CLOUD 
COVER IN SKY GRIDS. IT REMAINS TO BE SEEN WHETHER THE ANTICIPATED 
RAINFALL OVER THE NEXT FIVE DAYS WILL ALLEVIATE THE DROUGHT 
CONDITIONS THAT HAVE DEVELOPED.  
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29










137 
FXUS64 KLZK 062050
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
350 PM CDT WED OCT  6 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
HIGH PRESSURE OVER THE EAST COAST IS PULLING AWAY. SATELLITE IMAGES 
SHOW CLOUDS INCREASING FROM THE SOUTHWEST AS EXPECTED THIS 
AFTERNOON. RADAR SHOWS PRECIP ALREADY ACROSS PARTS OF EASTERN 
OKLAHOMA. AN UPPER TROUGH WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA THIS EVENING AND 
TRIGGER ISOLATED TO SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS MAINLY 
ACROSS THE WEST. 

GFS MODEL IS CONSIDERABLY MORE WET THAN PREVIOUS RUNS. THEREFORE 
HAVE INCREASED POPS ACROSS THE AREA THROUGH THE WEEKEND. THE UPPER 
TROUGH AND COLD FRONT WILL BE SLOW TO MOVE THROUGH THE AREA THIS 
WEEKEND AS A LOW PRESSURE AREA OVER THE GULF OF MEXICO MOVES EAST 
ALONG THE COAST. THIS IS A GOOD SET UP TO BRING US SOME WELL NEEDED 
RAIN TO DECREASE FIRE DANGERS. THE FRONT MOVES THROUGH ON SUNDAY AND 
WILL DECREASE POPS THEN. 
&&

.LONG TERM...
MOISTURE WILL SLOWLY DECREASE ON MONDAY WITH DECREASING CHANCES OF 
RAIN. DRY WEATHER WILL RETURN ON TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. TEMPERATURES 
WILL BE NEAR NORMAL. 

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    80  60  80  62 /  10  10  40  50 
HARRISON AR       77  58  75  58 /  10  20  50  60 
HOT SPRINGS AR    80  61  79  62 /  10  20  40  60 
PINE BLUFF AR     81  61  81  63 /  10  10  40  50 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  77  57  76  58 /  10  10  40  60 
MONTICELLO AR     84  62  83  63 /  10  10  40  40 
SEARCY AR         79  58  79  61 /  10  10  40  50 
MOUNT IDA AR      80  61  79  62 /  10  20  50  60 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   79  59  77  61 /  10  20  50  60 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

FXUS64 KLZK 062050
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
350 PM CDT WED OCT  6 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
HIGH PRESSURE OVER THE EAST COAST IS PULLING AWAY. SATELLITE IMAGES 
SHOW CLOUDS INCREASING FROM THE SOUTHWEST AS EXPECTED THIS 
AFTERNOON. RADAR SHOWS PRECIP ALREADY ACROSS PARTS OF EASTERN 
OKLAHOMA. AN UPPER TROUGH WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA THIS EVENING AND 
TRIGGER ISOLATED TO SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS MAINLY 
ACROSS THE WEST. 

GFS MODEL IS CONSIDERABLY MORE WET THAN PREVIOUS RUNS. THEREFORE 
HAVE INCREASED POPS ACROSS THE AREA THROUGH THE WEEKEND. THE UPPER 
TROUGH AND COLD FRONT WILL BE SLOW TO MOVE THROUGH THE AREA THIS 
WEEKEND AS A LOW PRESSURE AREA OVER THE GULF OF MEXICO MOVES EAST 
ALONG THE COAST. THIS IS A GOOD SET UP TO BRING US SOME WELL NEEDED 
RAIN TO DECREASE FIRE DANGERS. THE FRONT MOVES THROUGH ON SUNDAY AND 
WILL DECREASE POPS THEN. 
&&

.LONG TERM...
MOISTURE WILL SLOWLY DECREASE ON MONDAY WITH DECREASING CHANCES OF 
RAIN. DRY WEATHER WILL RETURN ON TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. TEMPERATURES 
WILL BE NEAR NORMAL. 

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

HOT SPRINGS AR    80  61  79  62 /  10  20  40  60 
PINE BLUFF AR     81  61  81  63 /  10  10  40  50 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  77  57  76  58 /  10  10  40  60 
MONTICELLO AR     84  62  83  63 /  10  10  40  40

MOUNT IDA AR      80  61  79  62 /  10  20  50  60

51/22








895 
FXUS64 KLZK 061553
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1053 AM CDT WED OCT  6 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CLEAR SKIES ARE ACROSS THE NORTHERN HALF OF THE STATE THIS MORNING 
WITH INCREASING CLOUDS ACROSS THE SOUTHERN PART OF THE STATE. HIGH 
PRESSURE OVER THE EAST COAST CONTINUES TO INFLUENCE THE ARKANSAS 
WEATHER. ADJUSTED CLOUD GRIDS TO BETTER FIT CURRENT CONDITIONS AND 
WILL EXPECT CLOUDS TO CONTINUE TO SPREAD INTO THE STATE THIS 
AFTERNOON FROM THE SOUTHWEST. ALSO INCREASED HIGH TEMPERATURES IN 
CENTRAL AND SOUTHEAST SECTIONS FOR THIS AFTERNOON. WITH LOW DEW 
POINTS IN PLACE...THE DRY AIR WILL HEAT UP RAPIDLY THIS AFTERNOON. 
AROUND 80 DEGREES AT LIT AND MID 80S AT MONTICELLO SHOULD WORK FINE.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

1053 AM CDT WED OCT  6 2004

.DISCUSSION...

51






244 
FXUS64 KLZK 060759
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
256 AM CDT WED OCT  6 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT...
ETA SHOWING CONSIDERABLE CHANGES THIS MORNING VERSUS PREVIOUS RUNS. 
ETA HAS TRENDED SLIGHTLY FASTER BUT CONSIDERABLY STRONGER WITH THE 
TROF OVER THE FOUR CORNERS REGION. EXCEPT FOR THE SLIGHT TIMING 
DIFFERENCES WITH THE TROF AS IT KICKS INTO THE CENTRAL PLAINS...THE 
MODELS ARE NOW IN GOOD AGREEMENT. THAT BEING SAID...WILL GO WITH A 
BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS THIS MORNING WITH A LEAN TOWARDS THE 
MORE CONSISTENT GFS.

HIGH PRESSURE TO REMAIN IN CONTROL ONE MORE DAY BEFORE OVERALL 
PATTERN EVOLVES INTO A WETTER ONE. STRONG SURFACE HIGH STRETCHES 
FROM NORTHEAST ARKANSAS TO SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND AND ONLY MOVES 
SLIGHTLY EASTWARD DURING THE COURSE OF THE DAY. DEW POINT 
TEMPERATURES RANGE FROM THE LOW 30S TO LOW 40S ACROSS THE STATE AS 
EAST TO NORTHEAST WINDS CONTINUE TO ADVECT IN DRY AIR. DEEPER 
MOISTURE ALREADY POOLING OFF TO WEST ACROSS THE CENTRAL PLAINS. 
LARGE MCS OVER WESTERN TEXAS WILL LIKELY THROW SOME HIGH LEVEL 
CLOUDS OVER US LATER BUT OVERALL BECOMING PARTLY CLOUDY SHOULD 
SUFFICE FOR TODAY.

HIGH BEGINS TO SLIDE OFF TO THE EAST WEDNESDAY NIGHT WITH RETURN 
FLOW SETTING UP. CLOUDS WILL INCREASE ACROSS THE AREA THURSDAY BUT 
PRECIPITATION CHANCES WILL BE HELD OFF EXCEPT OVER THE FAR WEST 
WHERE DEEPEST MOISTURE REMAINS. CONFIDENCE IN PRECIPITATION EVEN 
OVER THE WEST NOT VERY HIGH ON THURSDAY. AIR MASS IS SO DRY 
INITIALLY THAT IT WILL TAKE TIME TO MOISTEN IT UP ENOUGH TO SUPPORT 
PRECIPITATION.

UPPER LEVEL RIDGING OVER THE AREA ON WEDNESDAY WILL BE SHUNTED EAST 
ON THURSDAY AS TROF OVER THE FOUR CORNERS STARTS TO LIFT OUT. 
SEVERAL WEAK UPPER LEVEL DISTURBANCES IN THE SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT 
WILL JUSTIFY AT LEAST CHANCE POPS FOR FRIDAY. BEST SUPPORT FOR 
SIGNIFICANT PRECIPITATION REMAINS OVER OKLAHOMA AND THEN CURVES INTO 
SOUTHWEST MISSOURI SO HIGHER POPS IN THESE AREAS WILL BE NEEDED BUT 
QPF STILL WILL BE ON THE LIGHT SIDE.

WHILE ALL THIS IS GOING ON...THINGS START TO GET INTERESTING IN THE 
WESTERN GULF. MODELS HAVE BEEN CONSISTENT WITH DEVELOPING A WAVE 
JUST OFF OF BROWNSVILLE TEXAS AND CARRYING IT NORTHEAST ALONG THE 
GULF COAST. SYSTEM TAPS INTO TROPICAL MOISTURE WITH PWATS IN EXCESS 
OF 1.5 INCHES OVER MOST OF THE SOUTHEASTERN PART OF THE CWA BY 
SATURDAY MORNING. MODELS ALSO CONSISTENT WITH TWO DISTINCT 
SHORTWAVES MOVING THROUGH THE AREA IN THE SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT AS 
TROF GETS BOGGED DOWN RUNNING INTO THE SURFACE HIGH SITTING OVER THE 
CAROLINAS.

SYSTEM IN THE GULF COMES ON SHORE OVER CENTRAL LOUISIANA LATE 
SATURDAY. LARGE PLUME OF MOISTURE SWINGS THROUGH THE CWA SATURDAY 
AFTERNOON BEFORE MOVING NORTH BY SUNDAY MORNING. SLIVER OF DRY AIR 
OVER THE EASTERN PART OF THE STATE EARLY SATURDAY QUICKLY PUSHED OFF 
TO THE NORTH. LOW SCATTERED POPS EARLY SATURDAY WILL HAVE TO BE 
BOOSTED TO HIGH SCATTERED BY LATE SATURDAY. MEX GUIDANCE COMING IN 
WITH 70 POPS BUT WITH SO MUCH DRY AIR IN PLACE INITIALLY...WONT GO 
ABOVE HIGH SCATTERED AT THIS POINT.  

ANOTHER CONCERN IS THUNDER. UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT ONLY JUSTIFIES 
ISOLATED THUNDER MOST OF THE PERIOD. WILL REWORK THE PRECIP GRIDS TO 
GO WITH ISOLATED THUNDER. EVENT ON SATURDAY ACTUALLY LOOKS TO BE 
MORE STRATIFORM IN NATURE SO WILL GO MORE THAT WAY. AS FAR AS 
TEMPERATURES GO...FWC NUMBERS ARE INITIALLY COOLER AND ACTUALLY FIT 
IN BETTER WITH CURRENT CONDITIONS AS OPPOSED TO THE MAV. WILL LEAN 
MORE TOWARDS THE FWC NUMBERS EARLY BEFORE GOING WITH A BLEND OF 
MAV/FWC NUMBERS LATER IN THE PERIOD.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY...
WEAK SHORT WAVE ALOFT WILL LINGER JUST TO THE NORTHWEST OF ARKANSAS 
DURING THE FIRST TWO DAYS...THEN IT WILL FILL AND GET OUT OF OUR 
PICTURE ON TUESDAY. IN THE MEANTIME...LONG WAVE TROF OVER THE WEST 
IS STILL ON TRACK TO CUT OFF AND PARK OVER THE WEST COAST. AT THE 
SURFACE...THE LOW OVER THE NORTHERN GULF WILL MOVE ONSHORE AND 
APPROACH ARKANSAS SUNDAY...THEN THE RIDGE IN THE VICINITY OF JAMES 
BAY WILL REGAIN ITS HOLD OVER THE MIDWEST AND PUSH THE LOW BACK TO 
THE COAST NEXT TO THE FLORIDA PAN HANDLE BY MONDAY AFTERNOON. DRIER 
AIR AND CLEARING SKIES WILL RETURN ON TUESDAY. PRECIPITATION SUNDAY 
WILL BE PRIMARILY IN THE FORM OF RAIN...BUT THERE WILL BE ENOUGH 
INSTABILITY ALOFT TO SUPPORT ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS. MONDAY WILL 
HAVE THE DRIER AIR UNDER CUTTING THE MOISTURE OVER THE STATE...SO 
THAT STEADY RAIN WILL BE THE PRECIP TYPE FOR MONDAY AND MONDAY 
NIGHT. DRY FORECAST FOR TUESDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL SHOW A GRADUAL 
WARMING TREND FOR THE HIGHS AS THE WEATHER DRIES OUT. LOWS WILL DROP 
A BIT BY DAY 7 AS SKIES CLEAR.
&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
FIRE WEATHER STILL A CONCERN FOR THIS AFTERNOON OVER THE NORTHERN 
AND CENTRAL DISTRICTS WITH 10 HOUR FUELS ONLY IN THE FIVE TO SIX 
PERCENTILE WITH EVEN A FEW LOCATIONS IN THE THREE TO FOUR 
PERCENTILE. WHILE TWENTY FOOT WINDS WILL REMAIN BELOW RED FLAG 
CRITERIA...MINIMUM RELATIVE HUMIDITY IS FORECAST TO DROP INTO THE 
UPPER 20S TO LOWER 30S ONCE AGAIN. MOISTURE LEVELS WILL BEGIN TO 
INCREASE ON THURSDAY AS SOUTHERLY WINDS RETURN TO ADVECT MORE 
MOISTURE INTO THE AREA. THE CHANCES OF WETTING RAIN APPEAR LOW ON 
THURSDAY AND FRIDAY BUT INCREASE OVER THE WEEKEND.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    79  55  82  61 /  10  10  20  20 
HARRISON AR       77  53  77  57 /  10  10  20  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    80  56  81  61 /  10  10  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     80  56  83  62 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  77  52  78  57 /  10  10  20  30 
MONTICELLO AR     81  57  85  62 /  10  10  20  20 
SEARCY AR         79  53  81  60 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      80  56  81  61 /  10  10  30  40 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   79  54  79  60 /  10  10  20  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

724 
FXUS64 KLZK 060125 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
825 PM CDT TUE OCT 5 2004

.DISCUSSION...
HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES TO HOLD STRONG FROM ARKANSAS INTO ILLINOIS. 
DEWPOINTS ALREADY INTO MID 20S OVER NORTHEAST ARKANSAS. 
HOWEVER...CLOUD COVER FROM DISTURBANCE IN WEST TEXAS MOVING EAST. 
PARTLY CLOUDY WILL SUFFICE TONIGHT...BUT THESE CLOUDS WILL HELP HOLD 
TEMPS UP A LITTLE. READINGS TONIGHT WILL BE IN THE UPPER 40S TO 
LOWER 50S. WOULD NOT BE SURPRISED TO SEE A FEW MID 40S IN THE COLDER 
VALLEYS IN THE NORTH.

HIGH PRESSURE WILL DOMINATE THROUGH WEDNESDAY...BEFORE HEADING EAST 
THURSDAY. MOISTURE WILL MOVE INTO WESTERN ARKANSAS IN RETURN FLOW 
THURSDAY...BUT WILL BE LIMITED TO THE WEST. MOISTURE WILL BE AROUND 
THROUGH THE WEEKEND. HOWEVER...PRECIP LOOKS TO BE SCATTERED FOR 
NOW...SO WEEKEND WILL NOT BE A COMPLETE WASHOUT.

FOR TONIGHT...UPDATED GRIDS FOR CURRENT CONDITIONS AND TO TWEAK SKY 
COVER WITH CLOUDS MOVING EAST OUT OF TEXAS. OTHERWISE...FORECAST IS 
ON TRACK.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

58





597 
FXUS64 KLZK 051920
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
238 PM CDT TUE OCT 5 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT
A RATHER BROAD AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES ITS STRONG HOLD OF 
THE ARKANSAS WEATHER. A RIDGE EXTENDS FROM ILLINOIS INTO ARKANSAS. 
WITH DEWPOINTS IN THE 20S ACROSS THE NORTHERN SECTIONS RANGING TO 
THE LOWER 50S OVER THE EXTREME SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF ARKANSAS...EXPECT
MINIMUMS TONIGHT TO TAKE A SIGNIFICANT DIVE. THIS DRY AIRMASS OVER 
THE REGION WILL BE SLOW TO MODIFY...MAXIMUMS TOMORROW WILL THEREFORE 
RECOVER TO NEAR NORMAL LEVELS. THE CURRENT DRY SPELL WILL LIKELY 
CONTINUE UNTIL ABOUT LATE THURSDAY WHEN THE HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM 
SHIFTS EAST ENOUGH TO ALLOW MOISTURE FROM THE GULF OF MEXICO TO MOVE 
ACROSS PARTS OF TEXAS AND OKLAHOMA AND INTO SOUTHERN AND WESTERN 
ARKANSAS. THE CHANCE OF SIGNIFICANT RAIN WILL INCREASE BY FRIDAY 
INTO FRIDAY NIGHT AS THE HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM MOVES FARTHER EAST TO 
ALLOW MORE GULF OF MEXICO MOISTURE INTO ARKANSAS.      
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
SURFACE LOW DEVELOPING IN THE GULF WILL LIKELY MOVE ONTO THE COAST 
DURING SATURDAY...WITH UPPER LOW CLOSING OFF OVER THE PLAINS. LOOKS 
TO BE A RAIN PRODUCER FOR THE AREA...AS ISENTROPIC UPGLIDE LIKELY TO 
OCCUR ALONG THE BACK SIDE OF THE SURFACE LOW. NOT ALL THAT CONFIDENT 
OF THUNDERSTORM CHANCES DUE TO LACK OF LARGE SCALE LIFTING BEHIND 
THE SURFACE SYSTEM...HOWEVER UPPER SUPPORT DOES JUSTIFY PUTTING AT 
LEAST ISOLATED THUNDER IN. 

UPPER FLOW BECOMES MORE ZONAL BY TUESDAY...ALLOWING FOR BOTH SYSTEMS 
TO SLIDE EAST OF THE AREA. SOME DRYING WILL OCCUR AS SURFACE RIDGE 
BUILDS INTO THE AREA. UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD OVER TEXAS BY MID 
WEEK...AND NORTHWESTERLY FLOW REGIME WILL SET UP OVER ARKANSAS. 
&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
LOW HUMIDITY WILL CONTINUE TOMORROW. THE WINDS ARE EXPECTED TO REMAIN
LESS THAN 14 MPH.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    51  75  54  78 /  10  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       47  73  54  74 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    52  76  60  79 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     53  76  59  80 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  47  73  54  75 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     54  77  60  81 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         49  75  54  77 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      52  76  61  78 /  10  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   50  75  56  76 /  10  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

38/57/22





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 051920
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
238 PM CDT TUE OCT 5 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT
A RATHER BROAD AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES ITS STRONG HOLD OF 
THE ARKANSAS WEATHER. A RIDGE EXTENDS FROM ILLINOIS INTO ARKANSAS. 
WITH DEWPOINTS IN THE 20S ACROSS THE NORTHERN SECTIONS RANGING TO 
THE LOWER 50S OVER THE EXTREME SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF ARKANSAS...EXPECT
MINIMUMS TONIGHT TO TAKE A SIGNIFICANT DIVE. THIS DRY AIRMASS OVER 
THE REGION WILL BE SLOW TO MODIFY...MAXIMUMS TOMORROW WILL THEREFORE 
RECOVER TO NEAR NORMAL LEVELS. THE CURRENT DRY SPELL WILL LIKELY 
CONTINUE UNTIL ABOUT LATE THURSDAY WHEN THE HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM 
SHIFTS EAST ENOUGH TO ALLOW MOISTURE FROM THE GULF OF MEXICO TO MOVE 
ACROSS PARTS OF TEXAS AND OKLAHOMA AND INTO SOUTHERN AND WESTERN 
ARKANSAS. THE CHANCE OF SIGNIFICANT RAIN WILL INCREASE BY FRIDAY 
INTO FRIDAY NIGHT AS THE HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM MOVES FARTHER EAST TO 
ALLOW MORE GULF OF MEXICO MOISTURE INTO ARKANSAS.      
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
SURFACE LOW DEVELOPING IN THE GULF WILL LIKELY MOVE ONTO THE COAST 
DURING SATURDAY...WITH UPPER LOW CLOSING OFF OVER THE PLAINS. LOOKS 
TO BE A RAIN PRODUCER FOR THE AREA...AS ISENTROPIC UPGLIDE LIKELY TO 
OCCUR ALONG THE BACK SIDE OF THE SURFACE LOW. NOT ALL THAT CONFIDENT 
OF THUNDERSTORM CHANCES DUE TO LACK OF LARGE SCALE LIFTING BEHIND 
THE SURFACE SYSTEM...HOWEVER UPPER SUPPORT DOES JUSTIFY PUTTING AT 
LEAST ISOLATED THUNDER IN. 

UPPER FLOW BECOMES MORE ZONAL BY TUESDAY...ALLOWING FOR BOTH SYSTEMS 
TO SLIDE EAST OF THE AREA. SOME DRYING WILL OCCUR AS SURFACE RIDGE 
BUILDS INTO THE AREA. UPPER RIDGE WILL BUILD OVER TEXAS BY MID 
WEEK...AND NORTHWESTERLY FLOW REGIME WILL SET UP OVER ARKANSAS. 
&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
LOW HUMIDITY WILL CONTINUE TOMORROW. THE WINDS ARE EXPECTED TO REMAIN
LESS THAN 14 MPH.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    51  75  54  78 /  10  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       47  73  54  74 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    52  76  60  79 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     53  76  59  80 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  47  73  54  75 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     54  77  60  81 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         49  75  54  77 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      52  76  61  78 /  10  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   50  75  56  76 /  10  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

38/57/22





321 
FXUS64 KLZK 051504
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1005 AM CDT TUE OCT 5 2004

.DISCUSSION...
MADE MINOR ADJUSTMENTS TO FRESHEN UP THE WORDING BY MOSTLY REMOVAL 
OF THE MORNING VERBAGE. REST OF FORECAST APPEARS ON TRACK AT THIS 
TIME.
&&

38
&&

PREVIOUS DISCUSSION...
315 AM CDT TUE OCT  5 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT...
MODELS IN PRETTY GOOD AGREEMENT THIS MORNING WITH REGARDS TO TIMING 
OF THE INDIVIDUAL FEATURES. ETA HAS BEEN WAFFLING A BIT WITH ITS 
SOLUTION OF LATE WHILE THE GFS HAS BEEN THE MOST CONSISTENT. IN 
ADDITION...THE ETA IS NOW THE WEAKEST SOLUTION REGARDING THE 
EVOLUTION OF THE MID LEVEL TROF OVER THE FOUR CORNERS REGION. 
STRONGER GFS SOLUTION IS SUPPORTED BY THE OTHER SHORT TERM MODELS 
AND IS THE PREFERRED CHOICE THIS MORNING.

LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES WEAK COLD FRONT ROUGHLY ALONG THE 
LOUISIANA AND ARKANSAS BORDER. TEMPERATURE SPREAD ACROSS THE FRONT 
ONLY ABOUT 5 DEGREES THANKS IN PART TO RATHER EXTENSIVE CLOUD COVER 
COVERING MOST OF THE STATE. MOST NOTICEABLE DIFFERENCE WITH THE 
FRONT ARE DEW POINTS...WHICH RANGE FROM THE MID 30S ACROSS THE NORTH 
TO MID 60S OVER THE SOUTH. CLOUD COVER ARE IN ASSOCIATION WITH 
SEVERAL DISTURBANCES EMBEDDED IN THE ACTIVE SOUTHERN STREAM OF THE 
WESTERLYS.

SURFACE HIGH IN THE UPPER MIDWEST WILL SLIDE OFF TO THE EAST OVER 
THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS. EAST TO NORTHEAST SURFACE FLOW WILL CONTINUE 
THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON ADVECTING DRIER AIR INTO THE REGION AND 
CLOUD COVER WILL BREAK UP ENOUGH FOR PARTLY CLOUDY CONDITIONS. 
COOLER AND DRIER AIR WILL CONTINUE TO COME IN BEHIND THE FRONT WITH 
HIGH TEMPERATURES EXPECTED TO BE FIVE TO EIGHT DEGREES COOLER ON 
TUESDAY VERSUS MONDAY.

MEANWHILE... A SHORTWAVE TROF IN THE FOUR CORNERS WILL START TO MOVE 
SLOWLY EASTWARD. THIS IN TURN BRINGS RIDGING ACROSS THE MID SOUTH. 
ALL THESE FACTORS COMING TOGETHER WILL KEEP PRECIPITATION AT BAY FOR 
BOTH TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. MODELS ARE ALL CONSISTENT HOWEVER WITH 
BRINGING SIGNIFICANT MOISTURE TO THE WEST OF THE FORECAST AREA BY 
THURSDAY MORNING. INCREASE IN MOISTURE SEEMS TO BE NOTHING MORE THAN 
RETURN FLOW ON THE BACKSIDE OF THE RETREATING SURFACE HIGH. MOISTURE 
RETURN AIDED BY UPPER RIDGE AXIS SLIDING OFF TO THE EAST ALLOWING 
FOR SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT. EVEN THOUGH MOISTURE BEGINS TO INCREASE 
OVER THE WEST THURSDAY...I AM HAVING A DIFFICULT TIME FINDING ANY 
SIGNIFICANT SHORTWAVES OR ANYTHING ELSE THAT WOULD INITIATE PRECIP. 
AIR MASS WILL LIKELY TAKE TIME TO MOISTEN UP SO WILL GO CAUTIOUSLY 
WITH A DRY FORECAST FOR THURSDAY.

FORECAST GETS A BIT MORE INTERESTING ON THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY AS 
MODELS HAVE BEEN CONSISTENT WITH DEVELOPING A WAVE IN THE WESTERN 
GULF BY FRIDAY MORNING. FEATURE SLOWLY STRENGTHENS AS IT DRIFTS 
ALONG THE TEXAS COAST TAKING POSITION OFF GALVESTON BAY BY SATURDAY 
MORNING. MODELS KEEP HIGH QPF SOUTH OF THE STATE THROUGH FRIDAY 
NIGHT AS A SLIVER OF DRY AIR REMAINS OVER THE AREA. WITH SOME 
UNCERTAINTY HERE...WILL NEED TO CONTINUE THE SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN 
THE THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT TIME FRAME. BASED ON CURRENT 
TRENDS WILL BOOST THE POPS FRIDAY NIGHT OVER THE SOUTH.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...MAV AND FWC GUIDANCE IN GOOD AGREEMENT 
THIS MORNING AND WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF NUMBERS. WILL BOOST 
TEMPERATURES A LITTLE ON THURSDAY WITH DEEPEST MOISTURE OFF TO THE 
WEST BUT WILL DROP THEM ONCE AGAIN ON FRIDAY WITH INCREASED CLOUD 
COVER AND POSSIBILITY OF SHOWER ACTIVITY. OVERNIGHT LOWS WILL BE 
BELOW NORMAL TUESDAY NIGHT BUT AVERAGE CLOSE TO SEASONABLE THE 
REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY...
BROAD TROF WILL MOVE CLOSER TO ARKANSAS FROM THE TEXAS-OKLAHOMA PAN 
HANDLES TO START THE LONG TERM. SHORT WAVE WILL WEAKEN OVER 
NORTHEAST TEXAS AS RIDGE AMPLIFIES OVER THE UPPER MID WEST IN 
RESPONSE TO LONG WAVE TROF INTENSIFYING OVER THE WESTERN UNITED 
STATES. THIS NEW SYSTEM WILL DIVE TO THE SOUTHWEST PART OF THE 
COUNTRY AND BECOME CUT OFF FROM THE FLOW BEYOND DAY 7. IN THE 
MEANTIME...THE SURFACE PATTERN WILL HAVE A LOW OFF THE UPPER GULF 
COAST REINFORCING THE EASTERLY FLOW ACROSS ARKANSAS ON SATURDAY. 
RAIN CHANCES FROM THIS SYSTEM WILL BE LIMITED TO THE SOUTHERN 
COUNTIES IN LIGHT OF DRIER AIR MOVING IN FROM THE EAST AROUND 
SURFACE HIGH IN THE SOUTHEAST. AT THE SAME TIME...A SQUEEZE PLAY 
WILL TAKE PLACE FROM THE NORTH AS THE NEXT CANADIAN HIGH BRINGS 
SMALL RAIN CHANCES SOUTH FROM MISSOURI SATURDAY. THEN THE HIGH MOVES 
FROM SOUTH CENTRAL CANADA TO THE GREAT LAKES BY MONDAY. RAIN CHANCES 
WILL END FROM SOUTHWEST TO NORTHEAST MONDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL KEEP 
CLOSE TO NORMAL..WITH HIGHS IN THE 70S AND LOWS IN THE 50S AND 60S.
&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
FIRE WEATHER STILL A CONCERN THROUGH WEDNESDAY OVER THE NORTHERN AND 
CENTRAL DISTRICTS WITH 10 HOUR FUELS ONLY IN THE SEVEN TO EIGHT 
PERCENTILE. WHILE TWENTY FOOT WINDS WILL REMAIN BELOW RED FLAG 
CRITERIA...DRIER AIR COMING IN BEHIND THE AFOREMENTIONED FRONT WILL 
PRODUCE MINIMUM RELATIVE HUMIDITY IN THE UPPER 20S TO LOWER 30S 
THROUGH WEDNESDAY. SOME AREAS ACROSS THE NORTH MAY DROP INTO THE 
UPPER 20S TUESDAY AFTERNOON. HUMIDITY RECOVERY AT NIGHT WILL 
CONTINUE TO BE EXCELLENT. THE CHANCES OF WETTING RAIN ACROSS THE 
NORTH AND CENTRAL DISTRICTS STILL LOOKS MINIMAL THROUGH THE 
REMAINDER OF THE WEEK.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    75  51  75  54 /  10  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       69  47  73  54 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    76  52  76  60 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     76  53  76  59 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  69  47  73  54 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     76  54  77  60 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         74  49  75  54 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      75  52  76  61 /  10  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   73  50  75  56 /  10  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$
