LOUISIANA AND ARKANSAS BORDER. TEMPERATURE SPREAD ACROSS THE FRONT 
ONLY ABOUT 5 DEGREES THANKS IN PART TO RATHER EXTENSIVE CLOUD COVER 
COVERING MOST OF THE STATE. MOST NOTICEABLE DIFFERENCE WITH THE 
FRONT ARE DEW POINTS...WHICH RANGE FROM THE MID 30S ACROSS THE NORTH 
TO MID 60S OVER THE SOUTH. CLOUD COVER ARE IN ASSOCIATION WITH 
SEVERAL DISTURBANCES EMBEDDED IN THE ACTIVE SOUTHERN STREAM OF THE 
WESTERLYS.

SURFACE HIGH IN THE UPPER MIDWEST WILL SLIDE OFF TO THE EAST OVER 
THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS. EAST TO NORTHEAST SURFACE FLOW WILL CONTINUE 
THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON ADVECTING DRIER AIR INTO THE REGION AND 
CLOUD COVER WILL BREAK UP ENOUGH FOR PARTLY CLOUDY CONDITIONS. 
COOLER AND DRIER AIR WILL CONTINUE TO COME IN BEHIND THE FRONT WITH 
HIGH TEMPERATURES EXPECTED TO BE FIVE TO EIGHT DEGREES COOLER ON 
TUESDAY VERSUS MONDAY.

MEANWHILE... A SHORTWAVE TROF IN THE FOUR CORNERS WILL START TO MOVE 
SLOWLY EASTWARD. THIS IN TURN BRINGS RIDGING ACROSS THE MID SOUTH. 
ALL THESE FACTORS COMING TOGETHER WILL KEEP PRECIPITATION AT BAY FOR 
BOTH TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. MODELS ARE ALL CONSISTENT HOWEVER WITH 
BRINGING SIGNIFICANT MOISTURE TO THE WEST OF THE FORECAST AREA BY 
THURSDAY MORNING. INCREASE IN MOISTURE SEEMS TO BE NOTHING MORE THAN 
RETURN FLOW ON THE BACKSIDE OF THE RETREATING SURFACE HIGH. MOISTURE 
RETURN AIDED BY UPPER RIDGE AXIS SLIDING OFF TO THE EAST ALLOWING 
FOR SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT. EVEN THOUGH MOISTURE BEGINS TO INCREASE 
OVER THE WEST THURSDAY...I AM HAVING A DIFFICULT TIME FINDING ANY 
SIGNIFICANT SHORTWAVES OR ANYTHING ELSE THAT WOULD INITIATE PRECIP. 
AIR MASS WILL LIKELY TAKE TIME TO MOISTEN UP SO WILL GO CAUTIOUSLY 
WITH A DRY FORECAST FOR THURSDAY.

FORECAST GETS A BIT MORE INTERESTING ON THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY AS 
MODELS HAVE BEEN CONSISTENT WITH DEVELOPING A WAVE IN THE WESTERN 
GULF BY FRIDAY MORNING. FEATURE SLOWLY STRENGTHENS AS IT DRIFTS 
ALONG THE TEXAS COAST TAKING POSITION OFF GALVESTON BAY BY SATURDAY 
MORNING. MODELS KEEP HIGH QPF SOUTH OF THE STATE THROUGH FRIDAY 
NIGHT AS A SLIVER OF DRY AIR REMAINS OVER THE AREA. WITH SOME 
UNCERTAINTY HERE...WILL NEED TO CONTINUE THE SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN 
THE THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT TIME FRAME. BASED ON CURRENT 
TRENDS WILL BOOST THE POPS FRIDAY NIGHT OVER THE SOUTH.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...MAV AND FWC GUIDANCE IN GOOD AGREEMENT 
THIS MORNING AND WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF NUMBERS. WILL BOOST 
TEMPERATURES A LITTLE ON THURSDAY WITH DEEPEST MOISTURE OFF TO THE 
WEST BUT WILL DROP THEM ONCE AGAIN ON FRIDAY WITH INCREASED CLOUD 
COVER AND POSSIBILITY OF SHOWER ACTIVITY. OVERNIGHT LOWS WILL BE 
BELOW NORMAL TUESDAY NIGHT BUT AVERAGE CLOSE TO SEASONABLE THE 
REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY...
BROAD TROF WILL MOVE CLOSER TO ARKANSAS FROM THE TEXAS-OKLAHOMA PAN 
HANDLES TO START THE LONG TERM. SHORT WAVE WILL WEAKEN OVER 
NORTHEAST TEXAS AS RIDGE AMPLIFIES OVER THE UPPER MID WEST IN 
RESPONSE TO LONG WAVE TROF INTENSIFYING OVER THE WESTERN UNITED 
STATES. THIS NEW SYSTEM WILL DIVE TO THE SOUTHWEST PART OF THE 
COUNTRY AND BECOME CUT OFF FROM THE FLOW BEYOND DAY 7. IN THE 
MEANTIME...THE SURFACE PATTERN WILL HAVE A LOW OFF THE UPPER GULF 
COAST REINFORCING THE EASTERLY FLOW ACROSS ARKANSAS ON SATURDAY. 
RAIN CHANCES FROM THIS SYSTEM WILL BE LIMITED TO THE SOUTHERN 
COUNTIES IN LIGHT OF DRIER AIR MOVING IN FROM THE EAST AROUND 
SURFACE HIGH IN THE SOUTHEAST. AT THE SAME TIME...A SQUEEZE PLAY 
WILL TAKE PLACE FROM THE NORTH AS THE NEXT CANADIAN HIGH BRINGS 
SMALL RAIN CHANCES SOUTH FROM MISSOURI SATURDAY. THEN THE HIGH MOVES 
FROM SOUTH CENTRAL CANADA TO THE GREAT LAKES BY MONDAY. RAIN CHANCES 
WILL END FROM SOUTHWEST TO NORTHEAST MONDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL KEEP 
CLOSE TO NORMAL..WITH HIGHS IN THE 70S AND LOWS IN THE 50S AND 60S.
&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
FIRE WEATHER STILL A CONCERN THROUGH WEDNESDAY OVER THE NORTHERN AND 
CENTRAL DISTRICTS WITH 10 HOUR FUELS ONLY IN THE SEVEN TO EIGHT 
PERCENTILE. WHILE TWENTY FOOT WINDS WILL REMAIN BELOW RED FLAG 
CRITERIA...DRIER AIR COMING IN BEHIND THE AFOREMENTIONED FRONT WILL 
PRODUCE MINIMUM RELATIVE HUMIDITY IN THE UPPER 20S TO LOWER 30S 
THROUGH WEDNESDAY. SOME AREAS ACROSS THE NORTH MAY DROP INTO THE 
UPPER 20S TUESDAY AFTERNOON. HUMIDITY RECOVERY AT NIGHT WILL 
CONTINUE TO BE EXCELLENT. THE CHANCES OF WETTING RAIN ACROSS THE 
NORTH AND CENTRAL DISTRICTS STILL LOOKS MINIMAL THROUGH THE 
REMAINDER OF THE WEEK.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    75  51  75  54 /  10  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       69  47  73  54 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    76  52  76  60 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     76  53  76  59 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  69  47  73  54 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     76  54  77  60 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         74  49  75  54 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      75  52  76  61 /  10  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   73  50  75  56 /  10  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
915 PM CDT MON OCT 4 2004

.DISCUSSION...
QUICK UPDATE TO GRIDS FOR TEMPS THIS EVENING AND OVERNIGHT. COLD 
FRONT CURRENTLY ACROSS CENTRAL ARKANSAS. DRIER AIR AND LIGHT WINDS 
WILL ALLOW TEMPS TO FALL TONIGHT...BUT CLOUD COVER FROM UPPER SYSTEM 
TO THE SOUTH WILL KEEP TEMPS FROM BOTTOMING OUT. MAIN CHANGE TO THE 
GRIDS WAS ACCOUNTING FOR LOWER MAX TEMPS IN THE SOUTHWEST TODAY DUE 
TO CLOUD COVER AND RAIN...AND THE EFFECT ON LOWS FOR TONIGHT.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&



423 
FXUS64 KLZK 041940 CCA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
239 PM CDT MON OCT  4 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
LATEST SATELLITE PICS FIND ABUNDANT CLOUD COVER OVER MUCH OF THE 
FORECAST AREA THIS AFTERNOON. SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES A COLD FRONT 
SEVERELY LACKING IN SURFACE MOISTURE OVER NORTHERN ARKANSAS...NEAR 
FORT SMITH...RUSSELLVILLE...AND SEARCY. RAIN HAS BEEN PREVALENT MOST 
OF THE DAY OVER EXTREME SOUTHERN ARKANSAS...IMMEDIATELY SOUTH OF THE 
FORECAST AREA. DOUBTFUL IF MANY RETURNS OVER OUR SOUTHERN ARKANSAS 
COUNTIES ARE HITTING THE GROUND...AS THERE CONTINUES TO BE A 
SIGNIFICANT MOISTURE BOUNDARY BETWEEN ELDORADO AND MONTICELLO WITH 
MUCH DRIER AIR IN THE LOWER LEVELS THE FURTHER NORTH YOU GO. 

THIS AREA OF SHOWERS AND ISOLATED STORMS WILL CONTINUE MOVING 
EASTWARD TONIGHT...INVOF ASSOCIATED UPPER SYSTEM MOVING ACROSS 
LOUISIANA. CONDS WILL REMAIN DRY OVER MUCH OF ARKANSAS...WITH ONLY 
SOME MID AND HIGH CLOUDS NOTED. WILL KEEP A SLIGHT CHANCE OF POPS IN 
THE EXTREME SOUTH FOR TONIGHT. FRONT WILL SLIDE SOUTH AND OUT OF THE 
STATE BY TUESDAY...BRINGING A REINFORCEMENT OF COOLER AIR.

TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY LOOK TO BE DRY AS FRONT STALLS OR WASHES OUT 
NEAR THE GULF COAST AND SURFACE RIDGE NOSES INTO NORTHERN ARKANSAS. 
SIGNIFICANT MOISTURE WILL LIE JUST TO THE WEST OF ARKANSAS DURING 
THIS TIME. POSITION OF THE RIDGE WILL ALLOW FOR PREVALENT EASTERLY 
FLOW...SHUTTING OFF AVAILABLE SOURCE OF LOW LEVEL MOISTURE. 

BY THURSDAY...UPPER RIDGE WILL BEGIN MOVING NORTHEAST UP OUT OF THE 
GULF. SURFACE RIDGE WILL HEAD EASTWARD...WITH RETURN FLOW SETTING UP 
ONCE AGAIN.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
SOME AMPLIFICATION OF THE UPPER AIR FLOW OVER NORTH AMERICA WILL 
OCCUR EARLY IN THIS PERIOD. MEDIUM RANGE MODEL SOLUTIONS DO VARY 
WITH THE FINER SCALE ELEMENTS IN THIS FLOW. AT THIS TIME WILL LEAN 
TOWARDS THE DRIER SOLUTIONS...GIVEN RECENT TRENDS. 
&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
COLD FRONTAL PASSAGE HAS BROUGHT A REINFORCING SHOT OF DRY 
AIR...ESPECIALLY TO THE NORTHERN AND CENTRAL DISTRICTS. WHILE WINDS 
OVER THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS WILL REMAIN BELOW RED FLAG CRITERIA...
HUMIDITIES WILL CONTINUE TO BE IN THE 30 TO 35 PERCENT RANGE IN MANY 
AREAS THROUGH AT LEAST WEDNESDAY. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    55  74  49  76 /  10  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       43  68  45  70 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    56  75  50  76 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     56  75  51  79 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  44  68  45  70 /   0  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     57  75  52  79 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         52  73  47  75 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      56  74  50  75 /  10  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   52  72  48  74 /  10  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 55





633 
FXUS64 KLZK 040808
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
310 AM CDT MON OCT  4 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT...
SHORT RANGE MODELS CONTINUE TO ADVERTISE AN ACTIVE SOUTHERN STREAM 
WITH NUMEROUS SHORTWAVES MOVING THROUGH THE MEAN FLOW. AS EXPECTED 
IN THIS TYPE OF PATTERN...THERE ARE DIFFERENCES IN THE TIMING AND 
STRENGTH OF THE INDIVIDUAL WAVES WITH THE GFS A BIT FASTER AND 
STRONGER. ETA SOLUTION HAS COME MORE IN LINE WITH THE CONSISTENT GFS 
BUT NOT SURE OF THE STRONGER AND FASTER SCENARIO WITH THE AMOUNT OF
SURFACE PRESSURE OVER THE EASTERN CONUS. THAT BEING SAID...FEEL A 
BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS IS IN ORDER THIS MORNING.

IT APPEARS RETURN FLOW IS STARTING TO SET UP ACROSS THE WESTERN AND 
SOUTHERN PARTS OF THE STATE. DEW POINTS HAVE CLIMBED BACK INTO THE 
LOWER 60S ACROSS THE SOUTH AND MID 50S OVER THE WEST WHILE DEW 
POINTS REMAIN IN THE 40S ACROSS THE EAST. RETURN FLOW IS WEAK AT 
BEST WITH SURFACE WINDS BEING VERY LIGHT AND FLOW ALOFT IS ZONAL. 
WEAK SURFACE BOUNDARY STILL PROGGED TO DROP DOWN FROM THE NORTH BUT 
IT LOOKS DRY UNTIL IT REACHES THE SOUTHERN PART OF THE STATE.

ACTIVE SOUTHERN STREAM MOVES A SHORTWAVE ACROSS NORTHERN LOUISIANA 
AT ABOUT ROUGHLY THE SAME TIME THE FRONT ARRIVES. WILL KEEP SLIGHT 
CHANCE TO CHANCE POPS OVER THE SOUTHWEST WITH REMAINDER OF CWA 
REMAINING DRY. GFS MORE AGGRESSIVE WITH THIS FEATURE BUT APPEARS TO 
BE SOMEWHAT OVERDONE.

MID LEVEL TROF WILL CONTINUE TO DIG OVER THE FOUR CORNERS ON TUESDAY 
WITH DOWN STREAM RIDGING IN RESPONSE OVER THE MID SOUTH. MOISTURE  
TRIES TO STREAM INTO THE AREA FROM THE WEST BUT HIGH PRESSURE OVER 
THE OHIO VALLEY WILL KEEP DEEPER MOISTURE OFF TO THE SOUTH AND WEST 
OF THE CWA. ETA SWINGS A WAVE ACROSS THE SOUTH WHILE THE GFS MAKES 
NO MENTION OF IT. WILL BE FORCED TO CARRY SLIGHT POPS MONDAY NIGHT 
AND TUESDAY TO ACCOUNT FOR THIS FEATURE. 

SURFACE HIGH SLIPS OFF TO THE EAST WEDNESDAY AS AFOREMENTIONED 
TROUGH APPROACHES WITH BETTER MOISTURE RETURN BUT AGAIN... DEEPEST 
MOISTURE REMAINS TO THE WEST AND SOUTH. SEVERAL WAVES PASS NEAR THE 
AREA BUT STAY TO THE NORTH OR WEST AND CAN ONLY JUSTIFY SLIGHT 
CHANCES POPS OVER PARTS OF THE AREA. STRONGER WAVE PASSES OVER THE 
AREA THURSDAY NIGHT FOR ADDITIONAL POPS. 

EVEN THOUGH POPS ARE IN THE FORECAST THROUGH OUT...RAINFALL AMOUNTS 
ARE EXPECTED TO BE LOW AS DEEPEST MOISTURE REMAINS TO THE WEST AND 
SOUTH. IN ADDITION...SURFACE WINDS ARE EXPECTED TO BE EAST TO 
NORTHEAST FROM THIS AFTERNOON UNTIL MIDDAY THURSDAY WHEN MORE OF A 
SOUTHERLY COMPONENT IS INTRODUCED. THIS WIND FLOW WILL TRY TO ADVECT 
IN DRIER AIR FROM THE EAST WHICH WILL INHIBIT PRECIPITATION CHANCES 
EVEN MORE. PATTERN NOT A DRY WEATHER BUSTER BY ANY MEANS.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES....FLOW IS BASICALLY ZONAL UNTIL WEDNESDAY 
WHEN WINDS ALOFT WILL BECOME MORE SOUTHWEST. WARMEST DAY WILL BE 
TODAY BEFORE A REINFORCING SHOT OF COOL AIR COMES IN BEHIND THE 
FRONT. WITH EASTERLY SURFACE COMPONENT AND INCREASED MOISTURE...WILL 
KEEP TEMPERATURES PRETTY CLOSE TO GUIDANCE DAYS TUESDAY THROUGH 
THURSDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY...
UPPER RIDGE CONTINUES ITS TREK EAST WHILE AMPLIFYING OVER THE GREAT 
PLAINS FROM CANADA INTO THE NORTHERN PART OF THE COUNTRY. AT THE 
SAME TIME...A LOW KEEPS SLIDING EAST UNDER THE RIDGE OVER THE TEXAS 
AND OKLAHOMA PAN HANDLES UNTIL 00Z SAT. THEN THE LOW FILLS AND OPENS 
AS IT GETS PUSHED NORTHEAST BY THE NEXT SHORT WAVE CROSSING THE 
NORTHERN ROCKIES SATURDAY NIGHT. A WEAK SHOT OF ENERGY WILL REMAIN 
OVER THE STATE FOR SUNDAY. AT THE SURFACE...MOISTURE MOVES ACROSS 
ARKANSAS FROM WEST TO EAST AS RIDGE DROPS FROM THE OHIO RIVER VALLEY 
TO THE MID ATLANTIC COAST. RAIN CHANCES WILL RANGE FROM 30 PERCENT 
ON FRIDAY TO 20 PERCENT BY SUNDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL BE MAINLY IN 
THE 70S FOR HIGHS AND IN THE 50S FOR LOWS.
&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
TEN HOUR FUEL MOISTURE HAS DROPPED INTO THE FIVE TO SIX PERCENTILE 
ACROSS PARTS OF THE CWA WITH BURN BANS CONTINUING ACROSS MANY PARTS 
OF THE STATE. SOME MOISTURE HAS RETURNED TO THE SOUTH AND WEST BUT 
MINIMUM HUMIDITY IS STILL EXPECTED TO BOTTOM OUT IN THE MID 30S 
ACROSS MANY PARTS OF NORTHERN ARKANSAS THIS AFTERNOON. DRIER AIR
WILL ADVECT INTO THE AREA TONIGHT WITH MINIMUM RH IN THE LOWER 30S 
EXPECTED TUESDAY AFTERNOON. EVEN THOUGH HUMIDITY IS APPROACHING RED 
FLAG CRITERIA... WILL NOT ISSUE ANY HIGHLIGHTS AS 20 FOOT WINDS WILL 
REMAIN WELL BELOW 14 MPH. WHILE RECOVERIES AT NIGHT WILL BE 
EXCELLENT AND SCATTERED PRECIPITATION IS POSSIBLE...THE CHANCES OF 
WETTING RAIN WILL BE MINIMAL THIS WEEK. HIGHER DEW POINTS
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  53  74  48 /  10  20  20  10 
HARRISON AR       78  45  68  44 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    83  53  74  48 /  10  20  20  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  55  75  49 /  10  20  20  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  78  44  67  44 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     84  56  76  51 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         81  51  72  48 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      83  53  73  48 /  10  20  20  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   81  50  72  47 /  10  20  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.


000 
FXUS64 KLZK 040808
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
310 AM CDT MON OCT  4 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT...
SHORT RANGE MODELS CONTINUE TO ADVERTISE AN ACTIVE SOUTHERN STREAM 
WITH NUMEROUS SHORTWAVES MOVING THROUGH THE MEAN FLOW. AS EXPECTED 
IN THIS TYPE OF PATTERN...THERE ARE DIFFERENCES IN THE TIMING AND 
STRENGTH OF THE INDIVIDUAL WAVES WITH THE GFS A BIT FASTER AND 
STRONGER. ETA SOLUTION HAS COME MORE IN LINE WITH THE CONSISTENT GFS 
BUT NOT SURE OF THE STRONGER AND FASTER SCENARIO WITH THE AMOUNT OF
SURFACE PRESSURE OVER THE EASTERN CONUS. THAT BEING SAID...FEEL A 
BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS IS IN ORDER THIS MORNING.

IT APPEARS RETURN FLOW IS STARTING TO SET UP ACROSS THE WESTERN AND 
SOUTHERN PARTS OF THE STATE. DEW POINTS HAVE CLIMBED BACK INTO THE 
LOWER 60S ACROSS THE SOUTH AND MID 50S OVER THE WEST WHILE DEW 
POINTS REMAIN IN THE 40S ACROSS THE EAST. RETURN FLOW IS WEAK AT 
BEST WITH SURFACE WINDS BEING VERY LIGHT AND FLOW ALOFT IS ZONAL. 
WEAK SURFACE BOUNDARY STILL PROGGED TO DROP DOWN FROM THE NORTH BUT 
IT LOOKS DRY UNTIL IT REACHES THE SOUTHERN PART OF THE STATE.

ACTIVE SOUTHERN STREAM MOVES A SHORTWAVE ACROSS NORTHERN LOUISIANA 
AT ABOUT ROUGHLY THE SAME TIME THE FRONT ARRIVES. WILL KEEP SLIGHT 
CHANCE TO CHANCE POPS OVER THE SOUTHWEST WITH REMAINDER OF CWA 
REMAINING DRY. GFS MORE AGGRESSIVE WITH THIS FEATURE BUT APPEARS TO 
BE SOMEWHAT OVERDONE.

MID LEVEL TROF WILL CONTINUE TO DIG OVER THE FOUR CORNERS ON TUESDAY 
WITH DOWN STREAM RIDGING IN RESPONSE OVER THE MID SOUTH. MOISTURE  
TRIES TO STREAM INTO THE AREA FROM THE WEST BUT HIGH PRESSURE OVER 
THE OHIO VALLEY WILL KEEP DEEPER MOISTURE OFF TO THE SOUTH AND WEST 
OF THE CWA. ETA SWINGS A WAVE ACROSS THE SOUTH WHILE THE GFS MAKES 
NO MENTION OF IT. WILL BE FORCED TO CARRY SLIGHT POPS MONDAY NIGHT 
AND TUESDAY TO ACCOUNT FOR THIS FEATURE. 

SURFACE HIGH SLIPS OFF TO THE EAST WEDNESDAY AS AFOREMENTIONED 
TROUGH APPROACHES WITH BETTER MOISTURE RETURN BUT AGAIN... DEEPEST 
MOISTURE REMAINS TO THE WEST AND SOUTH. SEVERAL WAVES PASS NEAR THE 
AREA BUT STAY TO THE NORTH OR WEST AND CAN ONLY JUSTIFY SLIGHT 
CHANCES POPS OVER PARTS OF THE AREA. STRONGER WAVE PASSES OVER THE 
AREA THURSDAY NIGHT FOR ADDITIONAL POPS. 

EVEN THOUGH POPS ARE IN THE FORECAST THROUGH OUT...RAINFALL AMOUNTS 
ARE EXPECTED TO BE LOW AS DEEPEST MOISTURE REMAINS TO THE WEST AND 
SOUTH. IN ADDITION...SURFACE WINDS ARE EXPECTED TO BE EAST TO 
NORTHEAST FROM THIS AFTERNOON UNTIL MIDDAY THURSDAY WHEN MORE OF A 
SOUTHERLY COMPONENT IS INTRODUCED. THIS WIND FLOW WILL TRY TO ADVECT 
IN DRIER AIR FROM THE EAST WHICH WILL INHIBIT PRECIPITATION CHANCES 
EVEN MORE. PATTERN NOT A DRY WEATHER BUSTER BY ANY MEANS.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES....FLOW IS BASICALLY ZONAL UNTIL WEDNESDAY 
WHEN WINDS ALOFT WILL BECOME MORE SOUTHWEST. WARMEST DAY WILL BE 
TODAY BEFORE A REINFORCING SHOT OF COOL AIR COMES IN BEHIND THE 
FRONT. WITH EASTERLY SURFACE COMPONENT AND INCREASED MOISTURE...WILL 
KEEP TEMPERATURES PRETTY CLOSE TO GUIDANCE DAYS TUESDAY THROUGH 
THURSDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY...
UPPER RIDGE CONTINUES ITS TREK EAST WHILE AMPLIFYING OVER THE GREAT 
PLAINS FROM CANADA INTO THE NORTHERN PART OF THE COUNTRY. AT THE 
SAME TIME...A LOW KEEPS SLIDING EAST UNDER THE RIDGE OVER THE TEXAS 
AND OKLAHOMA PAN HANDLES UNTIL 00Z SAT. THEN THE LOW FILLS AND OPENS

ON FRIDAY TO 20 PERCENT BY SUNDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL BE MAINLY IN 
THE 70S FOR HIGHS AND IN THE 50S FOR LOWS.
&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
TEN HOUR FUEL MOISTURE HAS DROPPED INTO THE FIVE TO SIX PERCENTILE 
ACROSS PARTS OF THE CWA WITH BURN BANS CONTINUING ACROSS MANY PARTS 
OF THE STATE. SOME MOISTURE HAS RETURNED TO THE SOUTH AND WEST BUT

FXUS64 KLZK 040323 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1015 PM CDT SUN OCT 3 2004

.DISCUSSION...
HIGH PRESSURE WILL MOVE TO THE EAST OVERNIGHT...WITH COLD FRONT 
APPROACHING FROM NORTH AND SYSTEM ALOFT LOOMING IN TEXAS PANHANDLE. 

FRONT WILL ARRIVE IN NORTHERN ARKANSAS ON MONDAY...WITH SYSTEM TO 
WEST SPREADING CLOUDS INTO SOUTHWEST HALF OF STATE. LATEST DATA 
SHOWING SYSTEM IN TEXAS INTERACTING WITH FRONT...WITH SCATTERED 
SHOWERS/A FEW THUNDERSTORMS DEVELOPING MAINLY IN SOUTHWEST PORTIONS 
OF STATE MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH EARLY TUESDAY.

GIVEN THIS...UPDATED SKY TRENDS MONDAY/TUESDAY TO ADD MORE CLOUDS. 
ALSO INTRODUCED SMALL CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION ACROSS THE SOUTHWEST 
HALF OF THE STATE.

REST OF FORECAST OK. HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD BEHIND FRONT FROM THE 
NORTH BY MIDWEEK. HOWEVER...LOTS OF MOISTURE HANGING AROUND IN 
SOUTHERN PLAINS. THIS MOISTURE WILL BE AVAILABLE IN ARKANSAS TOWARD 
THE END OF THE WEEK...WITH BEST CHANCES FOR RAIN IN SOME TIME. (46)
&& 

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

103 
FXUS64 KLZK 031917
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT SUN OCT 3 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT
SURFACE RIDGE LIES ACROSS THE AREA THIS AFTERNOON AND SHOULD PERSIST
FOR MUCH OF TONIGHT THOUGH IT MAY SLIDE ENOUGH TO THE EAST TO ALLOW 
SOME LIGHT RETURN FLOW TO KICK IN LATER TONIGHT. THIS SHOULD HELP 
KEEP MINS A LITTLE HIGHER THAN LAST NIGHT WITH MOST AREAS IN THE 
LOWER 50S. A REINFORCING COLD FRONT MOVES IN ON MONDAY BUT IT WILL 
COME THROUGH PRETTY DRY SO TEMPS SHOULD RISE WELL IN MOST AREAS ON
MONDAY WITH MOST OF CENTRAL AND SOUTH REACHING THE 80S. MOISTURE 
FROM THE WEST WILL APPROACH THE AREA OVER THE NEXT DAY OR TWO BUT
IT APPEARS THE DEEPER MOISTURE WILL STAY TO THE WEST OF THE CWA
WITH MOSTLY MIDDLE AND HIGH CLOUDS STREAMING MOSTLY INTO SOUTHERN 
SECTIONS. STILL BORDERLINE ON WHETHER TO MENTION POPS...BUT WILL
KEEP RAIN OUT OF THE FORECAST FOR NOW WITH 10 PERCENT POPS MOSTLY
IN THE SOUTH AND WEST. COOLER AND DRIER AIR RETURNS WITH A NEW 
SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM MONDAY NIGHT AND TUESDAY AND WILL GO 
WITH LOWER TEMPS CLOSE TO MAV. AN UPPER TROF APPROACHES FROM THE 
WEST AROUND MIDWEEK. MOISTURE RETURNS RATHER STRONGLY AROUND THE
SURFACE HIGH BUT MOST OF THE INITIAL MOISTURE RETURN ON WEDNESDAY
AND WEDNESDAY NIGHT WILL BE TO THE SOUTH AND WEST OF THE CWA. THE
SURFACE HIGH WILL LIKELY HOLD IN ENOUGH TO KEEP MOST OF THE AREA
DRY THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT. BACKED OFF ON POPS FOR WEDNESDAY WITH
ONLY SMALL POPS IN THE WEST MOSTLY DURING THE AFTERNOON THEN SLOWLY
BROUGHT SMALL POPS INTO THE REST OF THE AREA WEDNESDAY NIGHT. THE
BETTER CHANCES OF RAIN WILL COME IN THE EXTENDED PERIOD.  
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SUNDAY
UPPER RIDGE BEGINS MOVING EAST OF THE AREA ON THURSDAY. THIS WILL 
ALLOW RETURN FLOW TO BRING MOISTURE INTO WESTERN SECTIONS OF THE 
CWFA. MOISTURE INCREASES ACROSS THE AREA THROUGH FRIDAY. THOUGH THE 
GFS MAY BE OVERDOING THE MOISTURE...A SURFACE LOW WILL BE MOVING 
NORTHEAST OUT OF THE GULF OF MEXICO AND SHOULD HELP PULL SOME 
MOISTURE IN FROM THE GULF. WILL INCREASE POPS SLIGHTLY TO THE CHANCE 
CATEGORY FOR THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY EVENING. AN UPPER LOW 
MOVES ACROSS THE AREA ON SATURDAY SO WILL NEED TO KEEP THE SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS IN THROUGH THE WEEKEND.  

NEAR NORMAL TEMPERATURES ARE EXPECTED THROUGH THE EXTENDED PERIOD. 
LOWS IN THE 50S AND HIGHS IN THE 70S AND 80S WILL BE MOST COMMON. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    53  82  53  74 /  10  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       53  77  45  68 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    54  82  53  74 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     54  82  55  75 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  52  77  44  67 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     54  83  56  76 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         53  80  51  72 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      53  82  53  73 /  10  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   53  80  50  72 /  10  10  10  10



043 
FXUS64 KLZK 030753
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 AM CDT SUN OCT 3 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT
UPPER LEVEL FLOW HAS NOT CHANGED SIGNIFICANTLY FROM YESTERDAY. A 
STRONG VORTEX CONTINUES ROTATING OVER THE HUDSON BAY AREA...WITH 
ZONAL FLOW ACROSS ARKANSAS. A SHORT WAVE IS STILL PROGGED TO UNDER 
CUT THE RIDGE OVER THE ROCKIES. TROF WILL BE AMPLIFYING FROM 00Z TUE 
INTO 12Z TUE. AS THE SHORT WAVE GETS CLOSER TO ARKANSAS IT WILL 
BEGIN INFLUENCING OUR WEATHER AFTER 12Z WED. THE SURFACE PATTERN 
STILL SHOWS A RIDGE MOVING OFF TO THE EAST OF ARKANSAS AND ALLOWING 
MOISTURE TO PUSH NORTH ON ITS BACK SIDE. THE RIDGE MOVES EAST 
SOMEWHAT FASTER THAN THE 00Z RUN YESTERDAY. THIS WILL TRANSLATE INTO 
THAT MOISTURE ENTERING THE STATE FROM THE WEST FASTER THAN EXPECTED 
BEFORE. INTRODUCED SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR DAYTIME WEDNESDAY AND 
CONTINUED THEM INTO WEDNESDAY NIGHT. THE MOISTURE RETURN WILL RESULT 
IN MORE CLOUDS AND COOLER TEMPERATURES SO HIGHS WILL BE MAINLY IN 
THE 70S AND LOWS MAINLY IN THE 50S.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
MODELS THIS MORNING A LITTLE MORE AGGRESSIVE WITH RETURNING MOISTURE 
TO THE AREA THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE PERIOD VERSUS THE PAST SEVERAL 
NIGHTS. WITH SURFACE HIGH MOVING OFF THE EAST COAST OF THE COUNTRY 
AT THE START OF THE PERIOD...RETURN FLOW IS LIKELY BUT NOT TO THE 
EXTENT THE MODELS... ESPECIALLY THE GFS ARE SHOWING. MEX NUMBERS ARE 
OFF THE CHART WITH 70 PLUS POPS IN THE THURSDAY AND FRIDAY TIME 
FRAME AND SEEN WAY OVERDONE. THAT BEING SAID...WILL GO WITH A BLEND 
OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS THIS MORNING WITH REGARDS TO POSITION AND 
TIMING OF THE FEATURES BUT I WILL CUT BACK OF THE POPS WHICH AGAIN 
APPEAR TO BE OVERDONE.

SURFACE HIGH WILL BE JUST OFF THE EAST COAST AT THE ONSET OF THE 
PERIOD WITH RETURN FLOW SETTING UP. SEVERAL WEAK SHORTWAVES SEEM TO 
BE EMBEDDED IN THE SOUTHERN STREAM WITH THE USUAL TIMING CONCERNS TO 
DEAL WITH. ONLY SCATTERED POPS SEEM TO BE WARRANTED AS AIR MASS WILL 
TAKE SOME TIME TO GET JUICED UP ENOUGH TO SUPPORT PRECIP. COME 
FRIDAY...ALL MODELS ARE GENERATING A WEAK SURFACE WAVE IN THE 
WESTERN GULF. THERE ARE DIFFERENCES IN THE INTENSITY OF THE LOW BUT 
THE MODELS ARE FAIRLY SIMILAR IN CARRYING IT ALONG THE GULF COAST 
THROUGH DAY SEVEN. WITH PROXIMITY OF LOW WILL NEED TO INTRODUCE 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR DAYS SIX AND SEVEN BUT CONFIDENCE IS NOT 
OVERLY HIGH AT THIS POINT DEPENDING UPON WHAT THIS FEATURE ENDS UP 
DOING.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...WITH INCREASED MOISTURE AND CLOUD COVER I 
DECIDED TO CUT BACK ON THE HIGH TEMPS A FEW DEGREES TO BRING THEM 
MORE IN LINE WITH THE MEX GUIDANCE WHICH LOOKS REASONABLE. DAY TIME 
HIGHS WILL STILL AVERAGE VERY CLOSE TO SEASONABLE NORMS WHILE 
OVERNIGHT LOWS WILL AVERAGE A FEW DEGREES ABOVE NORMAL.

&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
10 HOUR FUEL MOISTURE REMAINS IN THE SEVEN TO NINE PERCENTILE ACROSS 
MOST OF CENTRAL AND NORTHERN ARKANSAS THIS MORNING WITH NUMEROUS 
COUNTIES IMPOSING BURN BANS. AFTERNOON HUMIDITIES ARE EXPECTED TO 
BOTTOM OUT IN THE LOWER 30S ACROSS THE NORTH WITH SOME UPPER 20S NOT 
OUT OF THE QUESTION. CONDITIONS ARE FAVORABLE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT 
AND SPREAD OF FIRES THROUGH WEDNESDAY WHEN MOISTURE WILL BEGIN TO 
INCREASE BUT THE CHANCE OF WETTING RAIN STILL APPEARS LOW. EXCELLENT 
RECOVERIES OF RELATIVE HUMIDITY ARE LIKELY AT NIGHT. WINDS WILL 
REMAIN WELL BELOW RED FLAG CRITERIA OTHERWISE A FIRE WEATHER WATCH 
WOULD HAVE BEEN CONSIDERED FOR A MAJORITY OF THE COUNTY WARNING 
AREA. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    77  53  80  53 /   0  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       75  53  75  45 /   0  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    77  54  80  53 /   0  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     78  54  82  55 /   0  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  75  52  74  44 /   0  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     78  54  84  56 /   0  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         76  53  78  51 /   0  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      77  53  80  53 /   0  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   76  53  79  50 /   0  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

32/56





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 030753
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 AM CDT SUN OCT 3 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT
UPPER LEVEL FLOW HAS NOT CHANGED SIGNIFICANTLY FROM YESTERDAY. A 
STRONG VORTEX CONTINUES ROTATING OVER THE HUDSON BAY AREA...WITH 
ZONAL FLOW ACROSS ARKANSAS. A SHORT WAVE IS STILL PROGGED TO UNDER 
CUT THE RIDGE OVER THE ROCKIES. TROF WILL BE AMPLIFYING FROM 00Z TUE 
INTO 12Z TUE. AS THE SHORT WAVE GETS CLOSER TO ARKANSAS IT WILL 
BEGIN INFLUENCING OUR WEATHER AFTER 12Z WED. THE SURFACE PATTERN 
STILL SHOWS A RIDGE MOVING OFF TO THE EAST OF ARKANSAS AND ALLOWING 
MOISTURE TO PUSH NORTH ON ITS BACK SIDE. THE RIDGE MOVES EAST 
SOMEWHAT FASTER THAN THE 00Z RUN YESTERDAY. THIS WILL TRANSLATE INTO 
THAT MOISTURE ENTERING THE STATE FROM THE WEST FASTER THAN EXPECTED 
BEFORE. INTRODUCED SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR DAYTIME WEDNESDAY AND 
CONTINUED THEM INTO WEDNESDAY NIGHT. THE MOISTURE RETURN WILL RESULT 
IN MORE CLOUDS AND COOLER TEMPERATURES SO HIGHS WILL BE MAINLY IN 
THE 70S AND LOWS MAINLY IN THE 50S.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
MODELS THIS MORNING A LITTLE MORE AGGRESSIVE WITH RETURNING MOISTURE 
TO THE AREA THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE PERIOD VERSUS THE PAST SEVERAL 
NIGHTS. WITH SURFACE HIGH MOVING OFF THE EAST COAST OF THE COUNTRY 
AT THE START OF THE PERIOD...RETURN FLOW IS LIKELY BUT NOT TO THE 
EXTENT THE MODELS... ESPECIALLY THE GFS ARE SHOWING. MEX NUMBERS ARE 
OFF THE CHART WITH 70 PLUS POPS IN THE THURSDAY AND FRIDAY TIME 
FRAME AND SEEN WAY OVERDONE. THAT BEING SAID...WILL GO WITH A BLEND 
OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS THIS MORNING WITH REGARDS TO POSITION AND 
TIMING OF THE FEATURES BUT I WILL CUT BACK OF THE POPS WHICH AGAIN 
APPEAR TO BE OVERDONE.

SURFACE HIGH WILL BE JUST OFF THE EAST COAST AT THE ONSET OF THE 
PERIOD WITH RETURN FLOW SETTING UP. SEVERAL WEAK SHORTWAVES SEEM TO 
BE EMBEDDED IN THE SOUTHERN STREAM WITH THE USUAL TIMING CONCERNS TO 
DEAL WITH. ONLY SCATTERED POPS SEEM TO BE WARRANTED AS AIR MASS WILL 
TAKE SOME TIME TO GET JUICED UP ENOUGH TO SUPPORT PRECIP. COME 
FRIDAY...ALL MODELS ARE GENERATING A WEAK SURFACE WAVE IN THE 
WESTERN GULF. THERE ARE DIFFERENCES IN THE INTENSITY OF THE LOW BUT 
THE MODELS ARE FAIRLY SIMILAR IN CARRYING IT ALONG THE GULF COAST 
THROUGH DAY SEVEN. WITH PROXIMITY OF LOW WILL NEED TO INTRODUCE 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR DAYS SIX AND SEVEN BUT CONFIDENCE IS NOT 
OVERLY HIGH AT THIS POINT DEPENDING UPON WHAT THIS FEATURE ENDS UP 
DOING.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...WITH INCREASED MOISTURE AND CLOUD COVER I 
DECIDED TO CUT BACK ON THE HIGH TEMPS A FEW DEGREES TO BRING THEM 
MORE IN LINE WITH THE MEX GUIDANCE WHICH LOOKS REASONABLE. DAY TIME 
HIGHS WILL STILL AVERAGE VERY CLOSE TO SEASONABLE NORMS WHILE 
OVERNIGHT LOWS WILL AVERAGE A FEW DEGREES ABOVE NORMAL.

&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
10 HOUR FUEL MOISTURE REMAINS IN THE SEVEN TO NINE PERCENTILE ACROSS 
MOST OF CENTRAL AND NORTHERN ARKANSAS THIS MORNING WITH NUMEROUS 
COUNTIES IMPOSING BURN BANS. AFTERNOON HUMIDITIES ARE EXPECTED TO 
BOTTOM OUT IN THE LOWER 30S ACROSS THE NORTH WITH SOME UPPER 20S NOT 
OUT OF THE QUESTION. CONDITIONS ARE FAVORABLE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT 
AND SPREAD OF FIRES THROUGH WEDNESDAY WHEN MOISTURE WILL BEGIN TO 
INCREASE BUT THE CHANCE OF WETTING RAIN STILL APPEARS LOW. EXCELLENT 
RECOVERIES OF RELATIVE HUMIDITY ARE LIKELY AT NIGHT. WINDS WILL 
REMAIN WELL BELOW RED FLAG CRITERIA OTHERWISE A FIRE WEATHER WATCH 
WOULD HAVE BEEN CONSIDERED FOR A MAJORITY OF THE COUNTY WARNING 
AREA. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    77  53  80  53 /   0  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       75  53  75  45 /   0  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    77  54  80  53 /   0  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     78  54  82  55 /   0  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  75  52  74  44 /   0  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     78  54  84  56 /   0  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         76  53  78  51 /   0  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      77  53  80  53 /   0  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   76  53  79  50 /   0  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

776 
FXUS64 KLZK 021925
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT SAT OCT 2 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
HIGH PRESSURE WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA TONIGHT. GUIDANCE CAME IN
WITH MILDER MINS FOR TONIGHT THAN WHAT IS FORECAST BUT WITH THE 
SURFACE RIDGE IN NORTHERN SECTIONS...LOOKS LIKE IT WILL BE A GOOD
NIGHT FOR RADIATIONAL COOLING SO KEPT MINS ABOUT WHERE THEY WERE
EXCEPT FOR MAYBE A DEGREE OR TWO INCREASE IN A FEW PLACES. MOSTLY
SUNNY SKIES AND LIGHT WINDS THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS SUPPORT GOOD 
RADIATIONAL WARMING SO DID GO A LITTLE HIGHER ON MAXES AS SUGGESTED 
BY GUIDANCE. NEXT FRONT MOVES THROUGH MONDAY INTO TUESDAY. A WEAK
SHORT WAVE MOVES NEAR THE AREA WITH A SLIGHT INCREASE IN MOISTURE
MOSTLY TO THE WEST. LOOKS MARGINAL FOR SMALL POPS MONDAY NIGHT AND 
TUESDAY...ESPECIALLY IN THE WEST. DECIDED TO LEAVE MENTION OF RAIN
OUT FOR NOW BUT WILL HAVE TO VISIT THIS AGAIN TOMORROW. 
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
RIDGE BEGINS BUILDING OVER THE AREA ON WEDNESDAY. MOISTURE WILL 
RETURN HOWEVER ON A MORE SOUTHERLY FLOW. AS THE SURFACE HIGH MOVES 
OFF TO THE EAST....SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL RETURN ON THURSDAY. A 
SHORTWAVE MOVES ACROSS THE NORTHWEST PART OF THE AREA ON FRIDAY AND 
THEREFORE WILL INCLUDE JUST A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS FRIDAY AFTERNOON. DRIER AIR MOVES IN FOR SATURDAY SO 
WILL NOT INCLUDE ANY POPS ON SATURDAY. 

A WARMING TREND WILL BE NOTED DURING THE LATTER PART OF THE WEEK AS 
HIGH PRESSURE PULLS AWAY. LOWS IN THE 50S AND HIGHS IN THE 70S AND 
80S WILL BE MOST COMMON. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    48  78  53  80 /   0   0  10  10 
HARRISON AR       38  75  52  75 /   0   0  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    48  78  54  81 /   0   0  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     50  78  53  82 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  38  75  52  74 /   0   0  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     51  79  53  84 /  10   0   0  10 
SEARCY AR         44  77  52  78 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      47  78  52  81 /   0   0  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   44  77  52  79 /   0   0  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

930 
FXUS64 KLZK 021617
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1115 AM CDT SAT OCT 2 2004

.DISCUSSION...
STRONG COLD FRONT HAS MOVED OUT OF THE STATE ALTHOUGH MAIN AREA OF 
COOLER AND DRIER AIR IS STILL SEEPING ACROSS THE STATE AS SURFACE 
ANALYSIS SHOWS A STRONGER PRESSURE GRADIENT ACROSS NORTHERN AND 
CENTRAL SECTIONS. SATELLITE SHOWS LOW CLOUDS BOTH ERODING AND SLIDING
TO THE SOUTHEAST...SO MOST ALL AREAS SHOULD SEE CLEARING OVER THE 
NEXT FEW HOURS. WITH THIS IN MIND...FIGURE TEMPS SHOULD RISE AT LEAST
A FEW DEGREES DESPITE THE COLD ADVECTION...SO DID NOT MAKE MUCH CHANGE
TO THE MAX FORECASTS FOR THIS AFTERNOON. ADJUSTED SKY FORECASTS TO 
REFLECT OBSERVED CONDITIONS AND SHOW CLEARING THROUGH THE AFTERNOON. 
ISOLATED SHOWERS CONTINUE IN THE SOUTHEAST AND KEPT MENTION OF THIS 
THROUGH AT LEAST EARLY AFTERNOON IN THOSE AREAS.    
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&



781 
FXUS64 KLZK 020738
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 AM CDT SAT OCT 2 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
CURRENT CONDITIONS SHOW THE SHORT WAVE ENERGY MOVING EAST ACROSS THE 
NORTHERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE...DRIVING ECHOES DEPICTED ON RADAR. 
SATURDAY AFTERNOON SHOULD SEE THE ENERGY TO THE EAST OF ARKANSAS 
WILL ALL ITS ACCOMPANYING PRECIPITATION HAVING BEEN PUSHED TO THE 
SOUTHEAST ALONG WITH THE COLD FRONT AT THE SURFACE. FROM SATURDAY 
NIGHT INTO TUESDAY NIGHT THE FLOW WILL BE ZONAL ACROSS THE SOUTHERN 
TIER OF STATES. RIDGE OVER THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST WILL AMPLIFY AND IT 
WILL ALLOW THE WESTERLIES TO DIP SOUTHEAST OVER THE UPPER MIDWEST 
AND BOTTOM OUT AROUND THE GREAT LAKES. BY 12Z WEDNESDAY A WEAK SHORT 
WAVE WILL BE UNDER CUTTING THE WESTERN RIDGE AND APPROACHING THE 
STATE ACROSS THE CENTRAL ROCKIES. ONCE THE SURFACE FRONT EXITS THE 
STATE ON DAY 1...COOL AND DRY AIR WILL KEEP ARKANSAS IN PLEASANT 
CONDITIONS FOR THIS TIME OF THE YEAR. ANOTHER SURFACE HIGH WILL DROP 
SOUTHEAST OUT OF THE CANADIAN ROCKIES UNDER THE NORTHWEST FLOW 
ALOFT. THIS WILL BRING A DRY...COLD FRONT INTO THE STATE MONDAY. 
MOISTURE WILL BE LIMITED WITH THIS SYSTEM AND ANY SIGNIFICANT 
PRECIPITATION WILL BE FALLING TO OUR WEST AS MOISTURE POOLS AGAINST 
THE HIGHER TERRAIN ON THE BACK SIDE OF THE RIDGE. DRY FORECAST FROM 
DAY 2 ON INTO TUESDAY NIGHT. FWC AND MAV NUMBERS SIMILAR AND 
REASONABLE.
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
MODELS IN BETTER AGREEMENT THIS MORNING VERSUS PREVIOUS ONES 
CONCERNING THE LONG TERM FORECAST. GFS HAD BEEN THE ODD MAN OUT OF 
LATE BY GENERATING A CUT OFF LOW OVER THE CENTRAL PLAINS WHILE OTHER 
MODELS WERE NOT NEARLY AS AGGRESSIVE. LATEST GFS RUN NOW IN 
AGREEMENT WITH OTHER MODELS WITH SWINGING NOTHING MORE THAN A 
SHORTWAVE ACROSS THE AREA LATE IN THE PERIOD. WILL CONTINUE TO GO 
WITH A BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS BUT CONFIDENCE IS A LITTLE BETTER 
CONCERNING THE FINAL OUTCOME THAN MORNINGS PAST.

PATTERN STARTS OFF WITH HIGH PRESSURE BOTH ALOFT AND ON THE SURFACE 
IN CONTROL WITH JUST A SLIGHT INCREASE IN MOISTURE LATE IN THE 
PERIOD AS AFOREMENTIONED WAVE APPROACHES. SOUTHERN STREAM CARRIES 
THIS FEATURE THROUGH SOUTHERN MISSOURI/NORTHEAST ARKANSAS LATE 
THURSDAY THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT. FEATURE NOT OVERLY IMPRESSIVE AND 
ACTUALLY WEAKENS WITH TIME AND NOTHING MORE THAN OCCASIONAL 
CLOUDINESS IS EXPECTED. HIGH PRESSURE RETURNS FOR FRIDAY SO WILL 
KEEP THE CURRENT THINKING OF A DRY EXTENDED PERIOD.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...SURFACE PATTERN WILL KEEP SOME TYPE OF 
EASTERLY COMPONENT TO THE WIND DURING THE ENTIRE PERIOD WITH NEAR 
NORMAL TEMPERATURES EXPECTED. LATEST MEX NUMBERS SUPPORT NEAR NORMAL 
TEMPS AND ARE GENERALLY ACCEPTED. WILL NEED TO TRIM TEMPS BACK A 
DEGREE OR TWO ON DAY SEVEN BUT OTHERWISE NO SIGNIFICANT CHANGES 
HERE. 

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    73  48  76  52 /  20   0   0  10 
HARRISON AR       62  37  72  50 /  10   0   0  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    75  48  76  52 /  20   0   0  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     75  51  77  53 /  20   0   0  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  62  37  72  50 /  10   0   0  10 
MONTICELLO AR     75  52  78  53 /  20  10   0   0 
SEARCY AR         70  46  75  52 /  20   0   0  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      75  47  76  52 /  20   0   0  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   71  44  74  51 /  10   0   0  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

931 
FXUS64 KLZK 020237 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
935 PM CDT FRI OCT 1 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS DEVELOPED IN NORTHEAST OKLAHOMA 
THIS EVENING AND PUSHED INTO NORTHWEST ARKANSAS. STORMS HAVING A 
TOUGH TIME HANGING TOGETHER...AND WILL NOT LIKELY MAKE IT INTO 
PORTIONS OF CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS OVERNIGHT. IN THESE 
AREAS...REDUCED CHANCES OF RAIN.

FRONT WILL DEPART TOWARD THE GULF COAST ON SATURDAY. ANY LINGERING 
SHOWERS WILL END DURING THE MORNING...WITH CLOUDS DECREASING. 
CANADIAN HIGH PRESSURE WILL FOLLOW WITH COOLER/DRIER AIR. 

WEEKEND WILL FINISH WITH PLENTY OF SUNSHINE AFTER COOL START SUNDAY 
MORNING. PORTIONS OF NORTHERN ARKANSAS WILL START OFF WITH 
TEMPERATURES IN THE 30S. (46)

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

980 
FXUS64 KLZK 011925
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT FRI OCT 1 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
COLD FRONT CONTINUES TO SWEEP DOWN THE PLAINS TOWARD THE CWA AND
APPEARS ON SCHEDULE FOR A MID EVENING ARRIVAL INTO THE NORTHWEST. 
UPPER TROF MOVING ACROSS THE PLAINS WILL HELP KEEP THE FRONT MOVING. 
CLOUDS WITH PATCHY LIGHT RAIN HAVE PERSISTED IN THE NORTH AND WEST 
WITH TEMPS REMAINING IN 60S WITH DEW POINTS MOSTLY IN THE 50S. THE
MOST UNSTABLE AIR HAS DEVELOPED IN THE SOUTH AND EAST WITH TEMPS 
WELL INTO THE 80S AND DEW POINTS INTO THE 60S IN SOME AREAS. 
STILL LOOKING FOR SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO DEVELOP ALONG THE 
FRONT LATER TODAY AND TONIGHT AND MOVE ACROSS MUCH OF THE AREA.
AVAILABLE INSTABILITY WILL BE QUESTIONABLE ESPECIALLY IN THE 
NORTHWEST...SO CHANCE OF SEVERE IS NOT LOOKING GOOD. BY TIME THE
FRONT REACHES AREAS WHERE THE AIR HAS BECOME THE MOST UNSTABLE...
IT WILL BE LATE TONIGHT AND THINGS SHOULD HAVE STABILIZED. WILL
KEEP POPS IN CHANCE CATEGORY FOR TONIGHT AS THE COLD FRONT MOVES
THROUGH AND WILL NOT GO TOO HIGH WITH QPF AS MOISTURE WILL STILL
NOT BE VERY DEEP AND THE BETTER FORCING WILL BE NORTH OF THE AREA. 
KEPT POPS GOING INTO EARLY SATURDAY ACROSS THE AREA BUT HAVE RAIN
OUT OF THE FORECAST BY AFTERNOON IN ALL BUT THE SOUTHEAST. SURFACE
HIGH PRESSURE SETTLES IN FOR SATURDAY NIGHT...ESPECIALLY IN THE 
NORTH AND THIS SHOULD LEAD TO NEAR RECORD COOLING IN THE NORTH 
WITH UNSEASONABLE COLD ELSEWHERE. GUIDANCE TEMPS IN FAIRLY CLOSE 
CONSENSUS AND WENT CLOSE TO THEM. WENT WITH UPPER 30S IN THE 
FAR NORTH FOR MINS SUNDAY MORNING. THE HIGH PRESSURE SLIPS TO THE
SOUTH AFTER THAT AND THE AIR MASS SHOULD MODIFY SOME. A REINFORCING 
FRONT MOVES THROUGH ON MONDAY. SOME MOISTURE MOVES INTO THE AREA.
DECIDED TO HOLD OFF MENTIONING POPS WITH THIS FRONT FOR NOW BUT WILL
NEED TO MONITOR FUTURE MODEL RUNS. WENT A LITTLE COOLER AND DRIER 
BEHIND THE FRONT MONDAY NIGHT.   

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
HIGH PRESSURE AT THE SURFACE AND ALOFT WILL DOMINATE THROUGH THE 
EXTENDED. GFS SHOWS A SHORTWAVE DEVELOPING TO THE NORTHWEST 
THURSDAY...BUT HAVE LEFT FORECAST DRY AT THIS TIME. TEMPS WILL BE 
SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL THROUGH NEXT WEEK. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    60  72  48  75 /  40  40   0   0 
HARRISON AR       48  61  38  71 /  40  20   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    60  74  47  75 /  40  40   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     61  74  50  76 /  40  40  10   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  48  61  37  71 /  40  20   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     64  74  51  77 /  40  40  10   0 
SEARCY AR         59  69  45  74 /  40  40   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      59  74  46  75 /  40  40   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   55  70  44  73 /  40  30   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT FRI OCT 1 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
COLD FRONT CONTINUES TO SWEEP DOWN THE PLAINS TOWARD THE CWA AND
APPEARS ON SCHEDULE FOR A MID EVENING ARRIVAL INTO THE NORTHWEST. 
UPPER TROF MOVING ACROSS THE PLAINS WILL HELP KEEP THE FRONT MOVING. 
CLOUDS WITH PATCHY LIGHT RAIN HAVE PERSISTED IN THE NORTH AND WEST 
WITH TEMPS REMAINING IN 60S WITH DEW POINTS MOSTLY IN THE 50S. THE
MOST UNSTABLE AIR HAS DEVELOPED IN THE SOUTH AND EAST WITH TEMPS 
WELL INTO THE 80S AND DEW POINTS INTO THE 60S IN SOME AREAS. 
STILL LOOKING FOR SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO DEVELOP ALONG THE 
FRONT LATER TODAY AND TONIGHT AND MOVE ACROSS MUCH OF THE AREA.
AVAILABLE INSTABILITY WILL BE QUESTIONABLE ESPECIALLY IN THE 
NORTHWEST...SO CHANCE OF SEVERE IS NOT LOOKING GOOD. BY TIME THE
FRONT REACHES AREAS WHERE THE AIR HAS BECOME THE MOST UNSTABLE...
IT WILL BE LATE TONIGHT AND THINGS SHOULD HAVE STABILIZED. WILL
KEEP POPS IN CHANCE CATEGORY FOR TONIGHT AS THE COLD FRONT MOVES
THROUGH AND WILL NOT GO TOO HIGH WITH QPF AS MOISTURE WILL STILL
NOT BE VERY DEEP AND THE BETTER FORCING WILL BE NORTH OF THE AREA.

OUT OF THE FORECAST BY AFTERNOON IN ALL BUT THE SOUTHEAST. SURFACE
HIGH PRESSURE SETTLES IN FOR SATURDAY NIGHT...ESPECIALLY IN THE 
NORTH AND THIS SHOULD LEAD TO NEAR RECORD COOLING IN THE NORTH 
WITH UNSEASONABLE COLD ELSEWHERE. GUIDANCE TEMPS IN FAIRLY CLOSE 
CONSENSUS AND WENT CLOSE TO THEM. WENT WITH UPPER 30S IN THE

29/58






697 
FXUS64 KLZK 011612
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1111 AM CDT FRI OCT 1 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SURFACE RIDGE CONTINUES ACROSS ARKANSAS WITH DRIER AIR REMAINING IN 
PLACE...DEW POINTS IN MID 40S TO MID 50S. BETTER MOISTURE AXIS IS
ACROSS KANSAS AND OKLAHOMA AHEAD OF AN APPROACHING COLD FRONT. 
PRESSURE RISES SUPPORT CONTINUED MOVEMENT OF THE COLD FRONT TOWARD
THE AREA AND UPPER ANALYSIS SHOWS RATHER STRONG UPPER TROF SWINGING
INTO THE CENTRAL U.S. WHICH SHOULD HELP SUPPORT THE FRONT AS IT MOVES
IN. AREA OF MOSTLY WARM ADVECTION RAINS CONTINUES IN NORTHWESTERN 
SECTIONS BUT IT IS UNABLE TO PENETRATE FAR INTO THE STATE DUE TO 
THE DRIER AIR STILL IN PLACE. SOME HIGHER DEW POINT AIR IS POISED TO
THE SOUTH AND IF THE SURFACE RIDGE CAN BREAK DOWN THIS MOISTURE COULD
MOVE INTO MUCH OF THE AREA AHEAD OF THE COLD FRONT. 

SENT OUT UPDATE MAINLY TO CLEAN UP MORNING WORDING. KEPT POPS FOR
THIS AFTERNOON ABOUT AS THEY WERE BUT DID BUMP UP A LITTLE IN THE
NORTHWEST WHERE THE RAIN IS. MAX TEMPS MAY BE A REACH IN PARTS OF
THE NORTH AND WEST DUE TO ONGOING CLOUD COVER AND RAIN BUT LEFT THEM
AS THEY WERE IN CASE THE RAIN DISSOLVES AND CLOUDS CAN BREAK FOR 
AWHILE. STILL EXPECT THE MAIN THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY TO DEVELOP
ALONG THE FRONT TO THE WEST OF THE AREA LATER THIS AFTERNOON AND
MOVE IN DURING THE NIGHT CONTINUING INTO SATURDAY. INSTABILITY
LOOKING MORE IN QUESTION ESPECIALLY IF THE SURFACE RIDGE HANGS IN
ENOUGH TO KEEP THE HIGHER DEW POINTS FROM MOVING IN. BASICALLY
KEPT FORECAST AS IS FOR TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY OTHER THAN TO
INCREASE CLOUD COVER SOME AND DO NOT SEE ANY SIGNIFICANT CHANGES
TO THE FORECAST ON THE AFTERNOON PACKAGE.   

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29 







917 
FXUS64 KLZK 010838
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
337 AM CDT FRI OCT  1 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
MOST OF THE UPPER LEVEL ENERGY WILL BE WELL TO THE NORTH OF THE 
STATE IN THE SHORT TERM. WEAK SHORT WAVE MOVING THROUGH THE 
NORTHWEST CORNER OF ARKANSAS HAS TRIGGERED ONLY MINOR ECHOES. THE 
NEXT SHORT WAVE WILL BEGIN ITS INFLUENCE ON OUR WEATHER FRIDAY NIGHT 
INTO SATURDAY MORNING BY PROVIDING THE PUSH FOR THE SURFACE COLD 
FRONT. AFTER SATURDAY MORNING...THE FLOW TAKES ON A ZONAL 
CONFIGURATION WITH NO TRIGGERS. MEANWHILE AT THE SURFACE...MOISTURE 
APPROACHES FROM THE WEST AHEAD OF THE COLD FRONT. RH VALUES LIFT TO 
THE NORTH...WITH THE HIGHER CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION EXPECTED TO 
FALL ACROSS THE NORTH AND DECREASE TOWARD THE CENTRAL SECTIONS. 
SMALL POPS WILL AFFECT THE SOUTHERN COUNTIES TODAY. NEXT...THE COLD 
FRONT WILL ENTER THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF ARKANSAS OVERNIGHT TONIGHT 
AND IT WILL BE PUSHING OUT OF THE STATE THROUGH THE SOUTHEAST CORNER 
AFTER SUNRISE SATURDAY. POPS WILL DECREASE QUICKLY FROM THE 
NORTHWEST TO THE SOUTHEAST FRIDAY NIGHT AND EARLY SATURDAY. 
TEMPERATURES WILL BE A BIT TRICKY TODAY IN LIGHT OF THE DIFFERENCE 
IN THE GUIDANCE VALUES. THE GFS HAS THE HIGHER POPS AND LOWER TEMPS 
COMPARED TO THE FWC NUMBERS. BELIEVE THAT THE LOWER POPS WILL BE 
CLOSER TO WHAT WILL HAPPEN...SO EXPECT TEMPERATURES TO RISE MORE 
THAT THE GFS SUGGESTS. ONCE THE COLD FRONT CROSSES THE STATE...MOS 
NUMBERS CONVERGE IN LIGHT OF THE COOLER AND MUCH DRIER AIR 
ACCOMPANYING THE SURFACE RIDGE.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
MODELS THIS MORNING START OFF FAIRLY CONSISTENT BUT DIVERGE TOWARDS 
THE END OF THE PERIOD. BIGGEST DIFFERENCE IN THE MODELS IS THE 
DEVELOPMENT...OR LACK OF IN SOME CASES...OF AN UPPER LOW OVER THE 
CENTRAL PLAINS BY THE END OF THE PERIOD. GFS IS THE MOST AGGRESSIVE 
WITH THIS FEATURE WHILE THE CANADIAN AND ECMWF SOLUTIONS REALLY DO 
NOT HIT IT VERY HARD. SINCE WE ARE TALKING ABOUT DAY SEVEN FEEL THE 
BEST SOLUTION WILL BE TO SPLIT THE DIFFERENCES AND GO WITH A 
COMPROMISE SOLUTION.

PATTERN OVERALL IS PROGRESSIVE AND BEGINS WITH NORTHWEST FLOW OVER 
THE AREA AND HIGH PRESSURE ON THE SURFACE. HIGH WILL DOMINATE 
THROUGH WEDNESDAY AS BROAD RIDGING BEGINS TO BUILD OVER THE NATIONS 
MID SECTION. DIFFERENCES COME INTO PLAY THURSDAY AS GFS DEVELOPS THE
UPPER LOW WHILE THE OTHER MODELS ARE DEVELOPING MORE OF A TROF AS 
OPPOSED TO A CUT OFF LOW. MODELS KEEPING A GENERALLY EASTERLY 
SURFACE FLOW THROUGH THE PERIOD. SINCE NONE OF THE MODELS BRING ANY 
DEEP MOISTURE TO THE AREA OR GENERATE PRECIPITATION THROUGH THURSDAY 
WILL CONTINUE THE DRY FORECAST BUT KEEP A WARY EYE ON WHATS GOING ON 
IN THE LATTER PERIODS. 

GUIDANCE KEEPING TEMPERATURES CLOSE TO NORMAL THROUGH THE PERIOD 
WITH MILD DAYS AND COOL NIGHTS. SOME WARMING IS LIKELY ON THURSDAY 
WITH TEMPERATURES A TAD ABOVE SEASONAL NORMS. MEX GUIDANCE LOOKS 
GOOD AND IS GENERALLY ACCEPTED.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    84  60  71  49 /  30  40  40   0 
HARRISON AR       76  51  62  39 /  40  40  20   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  60  71  48 /  30  40  40   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     86  61  72  50 /  20  40  40  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  77  51  62  40 /  40  40  20   0 
MONTICELLO AR     86  63  74  51 /  20  40  40  10 
SEARCY AR         83  59  70  47 /  30  40  40   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      83  60  71  47 /  30  40  40   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   81  58  68  44 /  40  40  30   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

889 
FXUS64 KLZK 010319 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1005 PM CDT THU SEP 30 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CLOUDS INCREASING ACROSS WESTERN ARKANSAS THIS EVENING. A FEW 
SHOWERS TRYING TO DEVELOP IN THE NORTHWEST...BUT MOISTURE STILL 
RATHER LIMITED. 

FIRST DECENT ROUND OF PRECIPITATION WILL NOT BE NOTED UNTIL FRIDAY 
MORNING...MAINLY ACROSS THE NORTHWEST HALF OF THE STATE. SCATTERED 
SHOWERS/A FEW THUNDERSTORMS EXPECTED TO POP UP AHEAD OF SYSTEM ALOFT 
ARRIVING FROM THE SOUTHERN PLAINS. PRECIPITATION SHOULD FALL APART 
BY THE EARLY AFTERNOON HOURS. 

ROUND TWO OF PRECIPITATION SHOULD DEVELOP FRIDAY NIGHT AHEAD OF 
STRONG COLD FRONT FROM THE NORTH. SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE 
TRIGGERED ACROSS THE NORTHERN/CENTRAL COUNTIES...BUT SOME DOUBT AS 
TO HOW FAR SOUTH PRECIPITATION WILL GO WITH MAIN UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT 
SHIFTING EASTWARD INTO TENNESSEE VALLEY BY SATURDAY MORNING. 

SOME LEFTOVER SHOWERS SATURDAY MORNING BEFORE FRONT DEPARTS TO THE 
SOUTH. FRONT WILL BE FOLLOWED BY CANADIAN HIGH PRESSURE AND 
COOLER/DRIER AIR TO FINISH OUT THE WEEKEND.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46








910 
FXUS64 KLZK 301955
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
255 PM CDT THU SEP 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
CLEAR SKIES CONTINUE ACROSS THE AREA THIS AFTERNOON. VERY DRY AIR IS 
STILL OVER MUCH OF THE AREA. DEW POINTS ARE MAINLY IN THE 40S. 
HOWEVER...DEW POINTS IN THE MID 50S ARE STARTING TO WORK INTO THE 
SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST PORTIONS OF THE STATE ON THE BACK SIDE OF 
DEPARTING HIGH PRESSURE. 

A SHORT WAVE WILL ROTATE THROUGH THE UPPER LEVEL TROUGH TONIGHT AND 
BRING A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO MAINLY WESTERN 
SECTIONS AFTER MIDNIGHT. WILL SPREAD PRECIPITATION EASTWARD ON 
FRIDAY. WITH THE VERY LOW DEW POINTS IN PLACE...WILL NEED TO SEE A 
CONSIDERABLE INCREASE IN MOISTURE BEFORE WE WILL GET RAIN AT THE 
SURFACE. THIS MAY DELAY THE ONSET OF THE RAIN. 

A COLD FRONT IN THE NORTHERN PLAINS WILL MOVE RAPIDLY SOUTHWARD AND 
WILL MOVE THROUGH THE AREA ON SATURDAY. MODELS ARE IN FAIR AGREEMENT 
WITH THE MOVEMENT OF THE FRONT. THE FRONT SHOULD ENTER NORTHWEST 
ARKANSAS LATE FRIDAY NIGHT. WILL EXPECT A CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS ALONG THE FRONT SATURDAY. MOST PRECIP WILL END BY 
SATURDAY EVENING AS THE FRONT WILL BE MOVING ALONG QUICKLY. COOLER 
AND DRIER AIR WILL MOVE IN BEHIND THE FRONT ASSOCIATED WITH THE 
CANADIAN HIGH PRESSURE. THIS LIKELY WILL BE THE COOLEST AIR OF THE 
SEASON WITH LOWS AROUND 40 IN THE NORTH SUNDAY MORNING. DRY 
CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED FOR SUNDAY AS HIGH PRESSURE TAKES CONTROL. 
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL DOMINATE THE AREA NEXT WEEK. A REINFORCING
COLD FRONT MOVES THROUGH MONDAY WITH SOME MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH 
IT. DECIDED TO STICK IN SMALL POPS FOR MONDAY FOR THIS WITH POPS
DECREASING FROM THE NORTH LATE IN THE DAY. ANOTHER FRONT MOVES IN
LATER IN THE WEEK. GFS CLOSES OFF AN UPPER LOW IN THE AREA TOWARD 
THE END OF NEXT WEEK. HAVE SOME QUESTION ABOUT THE VALIDITY OF
THAT AT THIS TIME BUT PRESENT INDICATIONS ARE ANY PRECIP WOULD 
BE BEYOND DAY 7. KEPT MENTION OF PRECIP OUT THROUGH THURSDAY
FOR NOW. DID LOWER TEMP FORECASTS A LITTLE THROUGH THE PERIOD
TO FIT NEW GUIDANCE. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    58  84  62  73 /  20  30  30  30 
HARRISON AR       56  76  51  67 /  30  40  40  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    59  84  65  74 /  20  30  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     57  85  62  76 /  10  20  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  55  77  51  68 /  20  40  40  20 
MONTICELLO AR     58  86  63  78 /  10  20  30  30 
SEARCY AR         57  82  61  72 /  20  30  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      60  83  64  74 /  20  40  30  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   55  81  58  71 /  20  40  40  20

51/29


000 
FXUS64 KLZK 301955
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
255 PM CDT THU SEP 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
CLEAR SKIES CONTINUE ACROSS THE AREA THIS AFTERNOON. VERY DRY AIR IS 
STILL OVER MUCH OF THE AREA. DEW POINTS ARE MAINLY IN THE 40S. 
HOWEVER...DEW POINTS IN THE MID 50S ARE STARTING TO WORK INTO THE 
SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST PORTIONS OF THE STATE ON THE BACK SIDE OF 
DEPARTING HIGH PRESSURE. 

A SHORT WAVE WILL ROTATE THROUGH THE UPPER LEVEL TROUGH TONIGHT AND 
BRING A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO MAINLY WESTERN 
SECTIONS AFTER MIDNIGHT. WILL SPREAD PRECIPITATION EASTWARD ON 
FRIDAY. WITH THE VERY LOW DEW POINTS IN PLACE...WILL NEED TO SEE A 
CONSIDERABLE INCREASE IN MOISTURE BEFORE WE WILL GET RAIN AT THE 
SURFACE. THIS MAY DELAY THE ONSET OF THE RAIN. 

A COLD FRONT IN THE NORTHERN PLAINS WILL MOVE RAPIDLY SOUTHWARD AND 
WILL MOVE THROUGH THE AREA ON SATURDAY. MODELS ARE IN FAIR AGREEMENT 
WITH THE MOVEMENT OF THE FRONT. THE FRONT SHOULD ENTER NORTHWEST 
ARKANSAS LATE FRIDAY NIGHT. WILL EXPECT A CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS ALONG THE FRONT SATURDAY. MOST PRECIP WILL END BY 
SATURDAY EVENING AS THE FRONT WILL BE MOVING ALONG QUICKLY. COOLER 
AND DRIER AIR WILL MOVE IN BEHIND THE FRONT ASSOCIATED WITH THE 
CANADIAN HIGH PRESSURE. THIS LIKELY WILL BE THE COOLEST AIR OF THE 
SEASON WITH LOWS AROUND 40 IN THE NORTH SUNDAY MORNING. DRY 
CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED FOR SUNDAY AS HIGH PRESSURE TAKES CONTROL. 
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL DOMINATE THE AREA NEXT WEEK. A REINFORCING
COLD FRONT MOVES THROUGH MONDAY WITH SOME MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH 
IT. DECIDED TO STICK IN SMALL POPS FOR MONDAY FOR THIS WITH POPS
DECREASING FROM THE NORTH LATE IN THE DAY. ANOTHER FRONT MOVES IN
LATER IN THE WEEK. GFS CLOSES OFF AN UPPER LOW IN THE AREA TOWARD 
THE END OF NEXT WEEK. HAVE SOME QUESTION ABOUT THE VALIDITY OF
THAT AT THIS TIME BUT PRESENT INDICATIONS ARE ANY PRECIP WOULD 
BE BEYOND DAY 7. KEPT MENTION OF PRECIP OUT THROUGH THURSDAY
FOR NOW. DID LOWER TEMP FORECASTS A LITTLE THROUGH THE PERIOD
TO FIT NEW GUIDANCE. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    58  84  62  73 /  20  30  30  30 
HARRISON AR       56  76  51  67 /  30  40  40  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    59  84  65  74 /  20  30  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     57  85  62  76 /  10  20  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  55  77  51  68 /  20  40  40  20 
MONTICELLO AR     58  86  63  78 /  10  20  30  30 
SEARCY AR         57  82  61  72 /  20  30  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      60  83  64  74 /  20  40  30  30

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED

1023 AM CDT THU SEP 30 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CLEAR SKIES CONTINUE ACROSS THE AREA. SATELLITE IMAGES NOTE A SWATH 
OF CLOUDS MOVING NORTHEAST ACROSS OKLAHOMA. THESE CLOUDS WILL START 
MAKING THEIR WAY INTO WESTERN ARKANSAS LATE THIS AFTERNOON AND 
SPREAD EAST. THESE CLOUDS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH THE APPROACHING SHORT 
WAVE...AND WILL INCREASE ACROSS THE AREA THIS EVENING. INCREASED 
WINDS JUST A BIT ACROSS THE AREA AS THE HIGH PRESSURE WILL BE 
PULLING OFF TO THE EAST TODAY. SOUTHEAST WINDS ARE EXPECTED ACROSS 
THE WEST TODAY WITH EAST WINDS ELSEWHERE.

51






417 
FXUS64 KLZK 300735
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
235 AM CDT THU SEP 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY
FORECAST AREA CLEAR AS A BELL THIS MORNING AS SFC HIGH PRESSURE IS 
ANCHORED INVOF SOUTHEASTERN MISSOURI. CONDITIONS QUITE PLEASANT WITH 
DEWPOINTS RANGING FROM NEAR 40 TO THE LOWER 50S OVER MUCH OF THE 
AREA. MOISTURE WILL BEGIN INCREASING LATER TODAY AS THE SURFACE HIGH 
SLIDES OFF TO THE SOUTHEAST AND WINDS GAIN A MORE SOUTHERLY 
COMPONENT. 

NO DOUBT...TEMPS WILL BE WARMER TONIGHT...AS CLOUDS INCREASE FROM 
THE WEST OUT AHEAD OF APPROACHING SHORTWAVE. THIS SYSTEM WILL BRING 
THE NEXT CHANCE FOR SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO NORTHWESTERN 
ARKANSAS TOWARD FRIDAY MORNING. NEXT ROUND WILL COME ON FRIDAY 
AFTERNOON AND NIGHT AS STRONGER COLD FRONT MOVES INTO NORTHWEST 
ARKANSAS. 

MOST SHORT RANGE SOLUTIONS ARE NOT QUITE AS AGGRESSIVE AS THE 
ETA...WHICH INDICATES A LINE OF STRONG STORMS FORMING AND MOVING 
THROUGH DURING THE NIGHT. WHILE THIS MAY BE THE CASE...GFS/UKMET/
CANADIAN SOLUTIONS SHOW MORE STRONG UPPER SUPPORT WITH THE SYSTEM TO 
THE NORTH OVER THE MID/UPR MS VALLEY...AND TO THE SOUTHWEST NEAR 
DEVELOPING SURFACE LOW. THIS HAS BEEN THE MOST CONSISTENT...SO WILL 
STICK WITH THIS SOLUTION. 

HIGHEST POPS WILL BE ACROSS THE NORTHWESTERN ZONES FRIDAY 
MORNING...THEN ACROSS THE NORTHWEST HALF OF THE FORECAST AREA FRIDAY 
NIGHT...AS FRONT AND ASSOCIATED UPPER TROUGH MAKES ITS WAY ACROSS. 
AS FAR AS THE CHANCE OF STRONG TO SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS...AT THIS 
TIME...FEEL THAT ANY WILL BE ISOLATED AT BEST...GIVEN THAT THE 
STRONGEST UPPER SUPPORT WILL BE AWAY FROM THE AREA...AND DAYTIME 
HEATING WILL BE LOST ONCE THE FRONT MOVES INTO ARKANSAS. HOWEVER...
LOOKING AT FORECAST SOUNDINGS...INSTABILITY PARAMETERS WILL 
CERTAINLY PRESENT...ALONG WITH UPR JET DYNAMICS OF 85 KNOTS OR 
GREATER. 

FELL THAT THE MORE SIGNIFICANT FEATURE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS SYSTEM 
WILL BE THE COLD AIR MOVING IN BEHIND IT. IN FACT...THE HIGH 
PRESSURE SYSTEM THAT WILL ACT TO PUSH THE FRONT TO THE SOUTH OF THE 
STATE WILL USHER IN THE COOLEST TEMPERATURES SINCE THE EARLY SPRING. 
THE FRONT SHOULD CLEAR SOUTHEASTERN ARKANSAS BY LATE AFTERNOON 
SATURDAY...WITH TEMPERATURES STEADY OR SLOWLY FALLING FOR THE 
REMAINDER OF THE DAYTIME HOURS. LOWS ON SATURDAY NIGHT ARE EXPECTED 
TO FALL INTO THE LOWER 40S NORTH TO THE LOWER 50S SOUTH. SOME OF THE 
VALLEY AREAS OF NORTHERN AND NORTHWEST ARKANSAS MAY DROP BELOW 40 
DEGREES. 

FOR SHORT TERM TEMPS...TENDED TO BLEND GUIDANCE IN THE FIRST FEW 
PERIODS...AS MOS IS IN GENERALLY GOOD AGREEMENT. NOT SURPRISINGLY...
STRONG DISAGREEMENT ARISES FOR SATURDAYS MAX TEMPERATURES. TENDED TO 
LEAN TOWARD THE WARMER GFS IN THAT TIME PERIOD. AS FAR AS POPS 
GO...LEANED MORE TOWARD THE GFS AND FWC MOS...WHICH ARE THE LEAST 
AGGRESSIVE. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
COOLER AIRMASS WILL BE IN PLACE ACRS THE FA AT THE START OF THE PD. 
MODELS STILL SHOW ANOTHER CDFNT MOVG THRU THE REGION LATE SUN NIGHT 
AND MON. SOME MID AND HIGH LVL CLOUDS WILL AFFECT THE AREA AS AN 
ASSOCD IMPULSE ALOFT SLIDES EWD THRU THE REGION. GULF WL RMN CUTOFF 
AT THIS POINT...SO HAVE LEFT FCST DRY. YET ANOTHER FNT WL APCH FROM 
THE W BY WED. WL CONT WITH A DRY FCST WITH SIG MOISTURE LIMITED AND 
UPPER SUPPORT LAGGING TO THE W. CURRENT TEMP FCST LOOKS ON TRACK AND 
NO SIG CHGS MADE.
&&  

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    80  58  84  62 /   0  20  30  30 
HARRISON AR       78  56  76  51 /   0  30  40  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    81  59  84  65 /   0  20  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     81  57  85  62 /   0  10  20  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  78  55  77  51 /   0  20  40  40 
MONTICELLO AR     81  58  86  63 /   0  10  20  30 
SEARCY AR         79  57  82  61 /   0  20  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      81  60  83  64 /   0  20  40  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   82  55  81  58 /   0  20  40  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

970 
FXUS64 KLZK 291958
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
258 PM CDT WED SEP 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
SUNNY SKIES WERE THE GENERAL RULE ACROSS THE AREA THIS AFTERNOON. AS 
HIGH PRESSURE MOVED IN AND SUBSIDENCE INCREASED...THE SCATTERED 
CLOUDS FROM THE MORNING DISSIPATED. MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES WILL CONTINUE 
TONIGHT AND THURSDAY. 

AN UPPER LOW OVER THE GREAT LAKES WILL CONTINUE TO MOVE EAST 
TONIGHT. THIS WILL ALLOW A STRONG UPPER LOW TO DROP SOUTH THROUGH 
CANADA LATE THURSDAY. MODELS SEEM TO BE IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THIS 
NEXT SYSTEM. THE COLD FRONT ASSOCIATED WITH THIS LOW WILL MOVE INTO 
THE PLAINS FRIDAY. SOUTHWEST FLOW RETURNS FOR FRIDAY BRINGING A 
SHORT WAVE ACROSS THE AREA AHEAD OF THE FRONT...AND THIS WILL BRING 
A CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. THE FRONT WILL MOVE THROUGH 
ARKANSAS ON SATURDAY AND BRING ANOTHER ROUND OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. THE FRONT SHOULD MOVE THROUGH RATHER QUICKLY AND 
PRECIPITATION SHOULD END BY SATURDAY EVENING. MUCH OF THE ENERGY AND 
MOISTURE WILL REMAIN NORTH OF ARKANSAS SO SEVERE WEATHER IS NOT 
ANTICIPATED AT THIS TIME.  

ANOTHER SHOT OF COOL DRY AIR WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA SATURDAY NIGHT. 
THE COLDEST LOWS OF THE SEASON ARE EXPECTED SATURDAY NIGHT INTO 
SUNDAY MORNING. MUCH OF THE NORTH WILL BE IN THE 40S. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
STRONG UPPER TROF WILL HAVE PASSED THROUGH THE AREA BY SUNDAY WITH
NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT COVERING THE AREA. THE COLD FRONT SHOULD BE 
WELL PAST THE AREA WITH UNSEASONABLY COOL AND DRY AIR IN PLACE. 
ANOTHER REINFORCING FRONT WILL MOVE THROUGH ON MONDAY AND A SECOND
REINFORCING FRONT WILL BE APPROACHING THE AREA ON WEDNESDAY. 
SURFACE RIDGE FROM THE NORTHEAST WILL KEEP RETURN FLOW FROM SETTING
UP AHEAD OF THE MONDAY FRONT SO WILL NOT HAVE ANY POPS WITH THAT.
SOME RETURN FLOW SETS UP NEXT WEDNESDAY AS THE SECOND FRONT 
APPROACHES BUT INDICATIONS ARE THAT MOISTURE WILL BE INSUFFICIENT
TO MENTION POPS THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT. MADE MINOR ADJUSTMENTS
TO TEMP AND DEW POINT FORECASTS BUT OVERALL LOOKS LIKE MINS WILL
BE IN THE 40S AND 50S WITH MAXES MOSTLY IN THE 70S. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    52  81  57  83 /   0   0  10  20

TEMPERATURE GRIDS TO BETTER REFLECT CURRENT CONDITIONS. A DECENT 
PRESSURE GRADIENT HAS DEVELOPED OVER THE AREA WITH HIGH PRESSURE

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
247 AM CDT WED SEP 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY
DECAYING SURFACE FRONT...OR THE REMNANTS OF IT VERY DIFFICULT TO 
FIND THIS MORNING. BASED ON PRESSURE TENDENCIES...DEWPOINTS AND WIND 
SPEEDS...APPEARS TO BE SAGGING FROM SOUTHWESTERN MISSOURI...TOWARD 
CENTRAL ARKANSAS...DOWN TOWARD THE DELTA REGION OF SOUTHEAST 
ARKANSAS. LITTLE MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH THE SYSTEM IN THE LOWER 
LEVELS...THUS ONLY ALTOCU AND CIRRUS HAVE BEEN NOTED DURING THE 
OVERNIGHT HOURS...WITH A LITTLE BIT OF STRATOCU IN THE ARKANSAS 
RIVER VALLEY...AND IN THE WHITE RIVER VALLEY OF NORTH CENTRAL 
ARKANSAS. 

REMNANTS OF THE WEAK BOUNDARY WILL SAG FURTHER SOUTHWARD TODAY. MAIN 
FEATURE ASSOCIATED WITH THE BOUNDARY WILL BE REINFORCING SHOT OF 
COOLER AND DRIER AIR. READINGS TODAY WILL BE COOLER...WITH HIGHS 
MOSTLY IN THE LOWER 70S NORTH TO LOWER 80S SOUTH. READINGS TONIGHT 
WILL BOTTOM OUT IN THE MID 40S NORTH TO THE LOWER 50S SOUTH...AS 
SURFACE RIDGE PUSHES SOUTHWARD FROM THE MID MISSISSIPPI VALLEY AND 
ALLOWS CLOUDS TO BREAK UP. WOULD NOT BE SURPRISED TO SEE READINGS 
TANK TOWARD THE 40 DEGREE MARK IN SOME OF THE VALLEYS OF NORTHWEST 
AND NORTH CENTRAL ARKANSAS. 

500 MB RIDGE BUILDING OVER WEST/SOUTH TEXAS WILL SEND REMNANTS OF 
THE OLD FRONTAL BOUNDARY BACK TO THE NORTH ON THURSDAY. RETURN FLOW 
WILL SET UP...THUS TEMPERATURES WILL BE A BIT WARMER ON THURSDAY AND 
FRIDAY. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE POSSIBLE BY FRIDAY 
MORNING...AS INITIAL WAVE OF MOISTURE AND UPPER SUPPORT HEAD 
NORTHEAST IN THE MEAN FLOW. BEST CHANCES WILL BE OVER NORTHWEST 
ARKANSAS...GENERALLY NORTH OF A WALDRON TO MOUNTAIN HOME LINE. THIS 
AREA WILL SEE THE BEST UPPER SUPPORT.

COLD FRONT WILL BE MOVING INTO ARKANSAS BY FRIDAY NIGHT. SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE POSSIBLE ON FRIDAY NIGHT AND SATURDAY AS THE 
SYSTEM MOVES ACROSS. SUCCESSIVE MODEL RUNS HAVE BEEN CONSISTENT IN 
SPEEDING UP THIS FEATURE...WITH THE SYSTEM EXITING THE FORECAST AREA 
BY LATE SATURDAY. HAVE THUS TRENDED POPS DOWNWARD DURING THE DAY. 

MOS GUIDANCE IS DANGEROUSLY REASONABLE THIS MORNING...SO A GENERAL 
BLEND WAS USED. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
LATEST MODEL SOLUTIONS CONT TO INDC THAT CDFNT WILL BE MOVG SE OF AR 
EARLY IN THE PD. IMPRESSIVE CAA NOTED WITH THE GFS AGAIN THIS MRNG 
BEHIND FROPA. HAVE TRENDED BOTH MAX AND MIN TEMPS LOWER USING A 
BLEND OF GFS MOS AND NCEP TEMP PROGS. UPPER FLOW IS FCST TO 
TRANSITION FROM NWLY TO WLY OVER THE FA EARLY NEXT WEEK. EXPECT 
TEMPS TO SLOLY MODIFY...BUT STILL RMN AT BELOW NORMAL LVLS.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    80  53  81  56 /   0   0   0  10 
HARRISON AR       71  46  75  54 /   0   0   0  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    79  52  81  57 /   0   0   0  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     80  52  81  55 /   0   0   0  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  71  46  75  53 /   0   0   0  10 
MONTICELLO AR     81  51  82  55 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         78  52  79  55 /   0   0   0  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      78  51  81  58 /   0   0   0  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   79  49  79  53 /   0   0   0  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

247 AM CDT WED SEP 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY
DECAYING SURFACE FRONT...OR THE REMNANTS OF IT VERY DIFFICULT TO 
FIND THIS MORNING. BASED ON PRESSURE TENDENCIES...DEWPOINTS AND WIND 
SPEEDS...APPEARS TO BE SAGGING FROM SOUTHWESTERN MISSOURI...TOWARD 
CENTRAL ARKANSAS...DOWN TOWARD THE DELTA REGION OF SOUTHEAST 
ARKANSAS. LITTLE MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH THE SYSTEM IN THE LOWER


933 
FXUS64 KLZK 290126
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
822 PM CDT TUE SEP 28 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS TO BE IN GOOD SHAPE AND ONLY SOME SUPERFICIAL 
CHANGES WILL BE NEEDED THIS EVENING. SURFACE BOUNDARY BECOMING VERY 
ILL DEFINED BUT APPEARS TO BE ACROSS SOUTHERN MISSOURI AT THIS TIME. 
VIRTUALLY NO MOISTURE ACCOMPANIES THIS BOUNDARY WITH ONLY MID TO 
HIGH LEVEL CLOUDINESS COMING IN FROM THE WEST TO DEAL WITH. CLOUDS 
ASSOCIATED WITH A WEAK WAVE WHICH ALSO WILL HAVE NO EFFECT ON OUR 
SENSIBLE WEATHER.

THE BOUNDARY...OR WHATS LEFT OF IT...WILL CRUISE THROUGH THE AREA 
OVERNIGHT. THE FEATURE WILL ONLY REINFORCE THE COOL AND DRY AIR 
CURRENTLY OVER THE REGION WITH HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING BACK IN BEHIND 
IT. CURRENT PACKAGE HAS NO PRECIP MENTIONED UNTIL THE FRIDAY NIGHT 
AND SATURDAY TIME FRAME AND THIS LOOKS SOLID.

ALL FORECAST PARAMETERS ON TARGET AND OVERNIGHT LOWS SHOULD BE 
OBTAINED. ONLY CHANGES WILL BE TO ADJUST/TWEAK THE GRIDS TO REFLECT 
CURRENT TRENDS AND TO CLEAN UP THE WORDING.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

015 
FXUS64 KLZK 282009
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT TUE SEP 28 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES AT THE SURFACE ACROSS THE AREA. THE WEAK 
COLD FRONT IS NOT REALLY DISTINGUISHABLE. NORTH WINDS AND LOW DEW 
POINTS CONTINUE ACROSS THE AREA. SATELLITE IMAGES SHOW PARTLY CLOUDY 
SKIES ACROSS THE AREA. 

DRY WEATHER WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THURSDAY. THE NEXT WEATHER CHANGE 
WILL COME WITH A STRONGER COLD FRONT ON FRIDAY. SOUTHWEST FLOW 
RETURNS ON THURSDAY. THIS WILL BRING MORE MOISTURE INTO THE AREA. 
WILL CONTINUE THE CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FOR FRIDAY 
AND SATURDAY. NOT A LOT OF MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH THE FRONT...BUT 
MORE THAN WAS ASSOCIATED WITH TODAYS FRONT. COOL DRY AIR IS EXPECTED 
THROUGH THE WEEK. TEMPERATURES NEAR NORMAL ARE EXPECTED. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
SINCE A NORTHWEST FLOW WILL SETUP ALOFT BY EARLY SUNDAY...IT WILL 
DRIVE A DRY AIRMASS ASSOCIATED WITH A SURFACE BASED HIGH PRESSURE 
SYSTEM FROM WESTERN KANSAS ACROSS PARTS OF OKLAHOMA INTO ARKANSAS.
A DRY SPELL WILL CONTINUE SUNDAY THROUGH AT LEAST TUESDAY. SLIGHTLY 
BELOW NORMAL TEMPERATURES ON SUNDAY AFTER THE FRONTAL PASSAGE WILL 
TREND SLOWLY UPWARDS MONDAY AND TUESDAY.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    57  80  55  80 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       51  73  51  78 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    57  81  55  81 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     59  79  56  81 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  51  73  51  77 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     60  80  56  83 /   0   0   0   0

MOUNT IDA AR      56  80  55  81 /   0   0   0   0



183 
FXUS64 KLZK 280815
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
315 AM CDT TUE SEP 28 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY
LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS INDICATES A COLD FRONT FROM NORTHERN 
MISSOURI...STRETCHING ACROSS MUCH OF CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN KANSAS. 
VERY DIFFICULT TO FIND FROM ANALYZING...BUT THIS IS THE BEST 
POSITION AS INDICATED BY INCREASING WINDS BEHIND THE SYSTEM AND THE 
50 AND 55 DEGREE ISODROSOTHERMS. FRONT WILL SLOWLY MOVE SOUTHWARD 
TODAY...REACHING THE NORTHERN FORECAST AREA LATE TONIGHT. 

FORECAST CROSS SECTIONS INDICATE A SEVERE LACK OF LOW LEVEL MOISTURE 
WITH THE SYSTEM. HENCE...ONLY NOTICEABLE CHANGE IN CONDITIONS WILL 
BE INCREASED MID AND UPPER LEVEL CLOUD COVER...AND PERHAPS A 
REINFORCING SHOT OF DRY AIR ALREADY IN PLACE. THE SYSTEM WILL WASH 
OUT INVOF CENTRAL/SRN ARKANSAS BY LATE WEDNESDAY. 

RETURN FLOW WILL SET UP LATE THURSDAY AS SFC RDG OVER EASTERN UNITED 
STATES PROGRESSES EASTWARD. FAIRLY STRONG COLD FRONT DEVELOPING IN 
THE PLAINS WILL SLIDE EASTWARD JUST IN TIME FOR THE WEEKEND. RAIN 
CHANCES RETURN TO THE FORECAST AS EARLY AS FRIDAY AFTERNOON IN THE 
NORTHWEST...AS UPPER IMPULSE WILL MOVE ACROSS NWRN AR IN THE MEAN 
FLOW. 

AS FAR AS TEMPERATURES GO...MAV/MET/FWC ARE ALL IN FAIRLY DECENT 
AGREEMENT...SO A BLEND WAS USED. SURFACE FLOW MAINLY OUT OF THE 
NORTH AND NORTHEAST WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT NEAR TO SLIGHTLY BELOW 
NORMAL TEMPERATURES. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
LONGER RANGE PDS OF THE GFS STILL SHOW A STRONG UPR TROF DROPPING 
SEWD INTO THE NRN PLAINS AND UPPER GREAT LAKES DURG THE PD. ASSOCD 
SFC CDFNT IS PROGGED TO DROP SEWD AND MOVE THRU THE FA FRI NIGHT AND 
SAT. THIS SOLUTION STILL MAY BE A BIT FAST AS COMPARED TO THE OTHER 
FCST MODELS. FOR NOW...HAVE TRENDED A BIT FASTER WITH FROPA AND 
ADJUSTED POPS ACCORDINGLY. LOWERED MAX/MIN TEMPS A FEW DEGREES FOR 
SUN AND MON...BUT NOT AS COOL AS THE LATEST GFS MOS INDCS. WOULD 
LIKE TO SEE A FEW MORE MODELS RUNS FOR MORE CONSISTENCY.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  57  80  56 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       78  51  73  52 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  56  81  56 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  59  79  57 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  78  51  73  52 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     83  60  80  57 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         81  58  78  55 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      84  56  80  56 /   0   0   0   0

SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 44





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 280815
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
315 AM CDT TUE SEP 28 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY
LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS INDICATES A COLD FRONT FROM NORTHERN 
MISSOURI...STRETCHING ACROSS MUCH OF CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN KANSAS. 
VERY DIFFICULT TO FIND FROM ANALYZING...BUT THIS IS THE BEST 
POSITION AS INDICATED BY INCREASING WINDS BEHIND THE SYSTEM AND THE 
50 AND 55 DEGREE ISODROSOTHERMS. FRONT WILL SLOWLY MOVE SOUTHWARD 
TODAY...REACHING THE NORTHERN FORECAST AREA LATE TONIGHT. 

FORECAST CROSS SECTIONS INDICATE A SEVERE LACK OF LOW LEVEL MOISTURE 
WITH THE SYSTEM. HENCE...ONLY NOTICEABLE CHANGE IN CONDITIONS WILL 
BE INCREASED MID AND UPPER LEVEL CLOUD COVER...AND PERHAPS A 
REINFORCING SHOT OF DRY AIR ALREADY IN PLACE. THE SYSTEM WILL WASH 
OUT INVOF CENTRAL/SRN ARKANSAS BY LATE WEDNESDAY. 

RETURN FLOW WILL SET UP LATE THURSDAY AS SFC RDG OVER EASTERN UNITED 
STATES PROGRESSES EASTWARD. FAIRLY STRONG COLD FRONT DEVELOPING IN 
THE PLAINS WILL SLIDE EASTWARD JUST IN TIME FOR THE WEEKEND. RAIN 
CHANCES RETURN TO THE FORECAST AS EARLY AS FRIDAY AFTERNOON IN THE 
NORTHWEST...AS UPPER IMPULSE WILL MOVE ACROSS NWRN AR IN THE MEAN 
FLOW. 

AS FAR AS TEMPERATURES GO...MAV/MET/FWC ARE ALL IN FAIRLY DECENT 
AGREEMENT...SO A BLEND WAS USED. SURFACE FLOW MAINLY OUT OF THE 
NORTH AND NORTHEAST WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT NEAR TO SLIGHTLY BELOW 
NORMAL TEMPERATURES. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
LONGER RANGE PDS OF THE GFS STILL SHOW A STRONG UPR TROF DROPPING 
SEWD INTO THE NRN PLAINS AND UPPER GREAT LAKES DURG THE PD. ASSOCD 
SFC CDFNT IS PROGGED TO DROP SEWD AND MOVE THRU THE FA FRI NIGHT AND 
SAT. THIS SOLUTION STILL MAY BE A BIT FAST AS COMPARED TO THE OTHER 
FCST MODELS. FOR NOW...HAVE TRENDED A BIT FASTER WITH FROPA AND 
ADJUSTED POPS ACCORDINGLY. LOWERED MAX/MIN TEMPS A FEW DEGREES FOR 
SUN AND MON...BUT NOT AS COOL AS THE LATEST GFS MOS INDCS. WOULD 
LIKE TO SEE A FEW MORE MODELS RUNS FOR MORE CONSISTENCY.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  57  80  56 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       78  51  73  52 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  56  81  56 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  59  79  57 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  78  51  73  52 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     83  60  80  57 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         81  58  78  55 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      84  56  80  56 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   82  53  78  52 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 44





014 
FXUS64 KLZK 280149
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
843 PM CDT MON SEP 27 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS RIGHT ON TARGET AND NO UPDATES REQUIRED THIS 
EVENING. HIGH PRESSURE TO REMAIN IN CONTROL OVERNIGHT WITH ONLY A 
LITTLE CIRRUS MOVING THROUGH ON OCCASION. CURRENT TEMPERATURE TRENDS 
SUPPORT FORECASTED LOWS.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
SURFACE ANALYSIS THIS MORNING SIMILAR TO THOSE OF THE PAST COUPLE OF 
WEEKS...EXCEPT FOR TROPICAL CYCLONE JEANNE IN SOUTHERN GEORGIA. 
SURFACE HIGH WAS TO THE NORTH WITH A NORTHEAST GRADIENT ACROSS 
ARKANSAS. OUTER CIRCULATION AROUND JEANNE RESULTED IN SLIGHTLY 
STRONGER WINDS TODAY WITH SOME GUSTS IN THE EAST. THIS SHOULD RELAX 
SOME TONIGHT AS JEANNE MOVES TO THE NORTHEAST BUT SOME WIND SHOULD 
CONTINUE. SKIES SHOULD BE MOSTLY CLEAR EXCEPT FOR SOME CIRRUS 
PASSING OVER THE AREA AHEAD OF A SHORT WAVE IN THE HIGH PLAINS. MINS 
SHOULD BE NEAR OR A LITTLE COOLER THAN THIS MORNING. THE TROF WILL 
APPROACH FROM THE WEST THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS BUT WILL WEAKEN. A 
COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH FROM THE NORTHWEST BUT THE BROAD 
CIRCULATION AROUND THE REMNANTS OF JEANNE AND WEAK SURFACE HIGH TO 
THE EAST WILL KEEP NORTHEAST WINDS IN THE AREA AND WILL RESULT IN 
LITTLE CONVERGENCE ALONG THE FRONT. THE FRONT SHOULD MOVE INTO THE 
AREA MOSTLY UNNOTICED. THIS AND THE WEAKENING UPPER TROF MAY PROVIDE 
SOME CLOUDS BUT LIMITED MOISTURE AND LACK OF CONVERGENCE WILL KEEP 
CHANCES OF RAIN TOO LOW TO MENTION IN THE FORECAST. THERE MAY BE A 
WEAK COOLING TREND TO TEMPS AROUND MIDWEEK BUT LITTLE ELSE. 

MAIN WEATHER FEATURE IN THE EXTENDED IS THE RATHER STRONG COLD FRONT
EXPECTED TO REACH THE AREA OVER THE WEEKEND. RIDGING ALOFT WILL BE 
IN THE AREA LATE THIS WEEK WHICH WILL BE UNFAVORABLE FOR A CLEAN 
FRONTAL PASSAGE IN THE AREA. HOWEVER A RATHER STRONG TROF WILL 
TRANSLATE TO THE EAST ACROSS THE COUNTRY AND THIS SHOULD BE ENOUGH 
TO DRIVE THE FRONT THROUGH THE AREA. MODELS IN DISAGREEMENT ON 
TIMING AND STRENGTH OF THIS TROF. THE NEW GFS BRINGS A STRONGER TROF 
ACROSS AND BRINGS THE FRONT THROUGH THE AREA FASTER WITH MOST 
EVERYTHING PAST THE AREA BY SATURDAY NIGHT. BUT OTHER MODELS SLOWLY 
BRING THE FRONT INTO THE AREA FRIDAY NIGHT AND HANG IT AROUND INTO 
MONDAY WITH THE UPPER TROF NOT MOVING THROUGH UNTIL THEN. AM 
INCLINED TO GO WITH THE SLOWER SOLUTION AT THIS TIME AS THAT IS MORE 
FAVORED CLIMATOLOGICALLY. THUS KEPT SOME POPS IN FROM LATE FRIDAY 
THROUGH EARLY MONDAY WITH NO SIGNIFICANT CHANGES IN TEMPS.    

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

813 
FXUS64 KLZK 270811
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
310 AM CDT MON SEP 27 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY
WEAK RDG OF HI PRES OVER AR THIS MRNG RESULTING IN CLEAR SKIES AND 
LIGHT WINDS. DRIER AIR HAS CONTD TO SLOWLY WORK INTO THE FA DURG THE 
PAST 24 HOURS...WITH MAIN EFFECTS ACRS THE NERN HALF OF THE FA.

MODELS STILL IN GOOD AGREEMENT THIS MRNG WITH OVERALL SYNOPTIC 
TRENDS THRU THE SHORT TERM. T.S. JEANNE IS FCST TO LIFT NWD AND THEN 
NEWD ACRS THE SERN AND MID-ATLANTIC STATES OVER THE NEXT 24 TO 48 
HRS. 

MEANWHILE...WEAK CDFNT STILL PROGGED TO DROP SWD INTO AR LATE TUE 
AND TUE NIGHT. TIME SECTIONS CONT TO INDC THAT MAINLY MID AND HIGH 
LVL MOISTURE WILL ACCOMPANY THE BNDRY AS IT WORKS SWD INTO THE FA. 
HAVE INDCD MORE IN THE WAY OF CLOUD COVER IN THE GRIDS AND KEPT FCST 
DRY WITH FROPA. UPPER TROF OVER WRN TX SHOULD HAVE MINMAL EFFECT ON 
OUR WX IN THE SHORT TERM OTHER THAN TO BRING SOME HIGH LVL CLOUDS 
FROM TIME TO TIME.

CONTD WITH SLIGHTLY COOLER TEMPS WED THRU THU AS CDFNT WASHES OUT 
OVER THE AREA. MOS TEMPS IN GOOD AGREEMENT ACRS THE BOARD AND DID 
NOT STRAY TO FAR FOR MAX/MIN TEMPS.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
BY THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY...PATTERN FINALLY BEGINS TO TRANSITION 
A BIT. SFC RDG OVR ERN UNITED STATES WILL PROGRESS EWD...WITH 
RETURN FLOW SETTING UP OVR AR. H5 FLOW WILL BECOME MORE ZONAL IN 
NATURE...ALLOWING FOR DVLPNG CDFNT OUT IN THE PLAINS TO MOVE EWD 
INTO MD/LWR MS VLY. CLOUDS WILL INCRS ON FRIDAY. RAIN CHCS ALSO 
RE-ENTER THE FCST...AS CDFNT MOVES INTO WRN AR...AND SFC LOW DVLPS 
ALONG BNDRY. 

H5 RDG OVR GULF COAST WILL STRENGTHEN A BIT ON SAT...WHICH MAY STALL 
BNDRY OVR CNTL AR FOR A GOOD PART OF THE WEEKEND. BY LATE SUNDAY...
UPR RDG WILL RETROGRADE TO THE SW...WHICH WILL SET UP NWLY FLOW BY 
LATE IN THE WEEKEND. THIS WILL ALLOW SFC BNDRY TO MOVE EWD...WITH 
DRIER AIR FILTERING IN.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

44/57






285 
FXUS64 KLZK 270222
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
917 PM CDT SUN SEP 26 2004

.DISCUSSION...
NO UPDATES NEEDED THIS EVENING. CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS RIGHT ON 
TARGET WITH PLENTY OF DRY AIR IN PLACE COURTESY OF HIGH PRESSURE 
BUILDING IN. CURRENT TRENDS SUPPORT FORECASTED LOWS SO NO CHANGES 
ARE REQUIRED AT THIS TIME.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES THIS AFTERNOON ACROSS THE AREA...EXCEPT FOR 
EXTREME EAST...AS LEFTOVER MOISTURE HAS POOLED ALONG AN OLD FRONTAL 
BOUNDARY. LIGHT RAIN/SPRINKLES HAVE FALLEN ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST 
TODAY...BUT WILL CONTINUE TO DISSIPATE. WINDS HAVE BEEN THE STORY 
TODAY AS MUCH OF THE AREA HAD SUSTAINED WINDS AROUND 15 MPH DURING 
THE AFTERNOON.

CLOUDS WILL DISSIPATE THIS EVENING...WITH MOSTLY CLEAR CONDITIONS 
FOR THE OVERNIGHT HOURS. WINDS WILL ALSO SUBSIDE LATE THIS 
AFTERNOON...AND TEMPS WILL BE COOLER IN MOST AREAS THAN PREVIOUS 
NIGHTS.

MONDAY AND TUESDAY WILL BE MILD AND DRY...AS HIGH PRESSURE HOLDS 
STRONG. A REINFORCING SHOT OF COOL AIR WILL MOVE INTO THE STATE 
TUESDAY NIGHT...DUE TO AN UPPER TROUGH MOVING EAST ACROSS THE GREAT 
LAKES. THE GFS IS GENERATING PRECIP WITH THIS FEATURE...BUT WITH 
NORTHEAST WINDS CONTINUING FROM NOW UNTIL THEN...HAVE NOT FIGURED 
OUT WHERE THE MODELS ARE GETTING THE MOISTURE. HAVE LEFT THE 
FORECAST DRY...AND WILL CONTINUE THE TREND OF COOLER TEMPS ON 
WEDNESDAY.

DRY WEATHER WILL CONTINUE THE EARLY PART OF THE LONG TERM. NEXT 
FRONTAL SYSTEM WILL BEGIN TO AFFECT THE FORECAST AREA FRIDAY NIGHT 
WITH CHANCE POPS IN THROUGH THE WEEKEND. TEMPERATURES WILL BE NEAR 
OR A LITTLE BELOW NORMAL THROUGH THE PERIOD.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 270222
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
917 PM CDT SUN SEP 26 2004

.DISCUSSION...
NO UPDATES NEEDED THIS EVENING. CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS RIGHT ON 
TARGET WITH PLENTY OF DRY AIR IN PLACE COURTESY OF HIGH PRESSURE 
BUILDING IN. CURRENT TRENDS SUPPORT FORECASTED LOWS SO NO CHANGES 
ARE REQUIRED AT THIS TIME.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES THIS AFTERNOON ACROSS THE AREA...EXCEPT FOR 
EXTREME EAST...AS LEFTOVER MOISTURE HAS POOLED ALONG AN OLD FRONTAL 
BOUNDARY. LIGHT RAIN/SPRINKLES HAVE FALLEN ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST 
TODAY...BUT WILL CONTINUE TO DISSIPATE. WINDS HAVE BEEN THE STORY 
TODAY AS MUCH OF THE AREA HAD SUSTAINED WINDS AROUND 15 MPH DURING 
THE AFTERNOON.

CLOUDS WILL DISSIPATE THIS EVENING...WITH MOSTLY CLEAR CONDITIONS 
FOR THE OVERNIGHT HOURS. WINDS WILL ALSO SUBSIDE LATE THIS 
AFTERNOON...AND TEMPS WILL BE COOLER IN MOST AREAS THAN PREVIOUS 
NIGHTS.

MONDAY AND TUESDAY WILL BE MILD AND DRY...AS HIGH PRESSURE HOLDS 
STRONG. A REINFORCING SHOT OF COOL AIR WILL MOVE INTO THE STATE 
TUESDAY NIGHT...DUE TO AN UPPER TROUGH MOVING EAST ACROSS THE GREAT 
LAKES. THE GFS IS GENERATING PRECIP WITH THIS FEATURE...BUT WITH 
NORTHEAST WINDS CONTINUING FROM NOW UNTIL THEN...HAVE NOT FIGURED 
OUT WHERE THE MODELS ARE GETTING THE MOISTURE. HAVE LEFT THE 
FORECAST DRY...AND WILL CONTINUE THE TREND OF COOLER TEMPS ON 
WEDNESDAY.

DRY WEATHER WILL CONTINUE THE EARLY PART OF THE LONG TERM. NEXT 
FRONTAL SYSTEM WILL BEGIN TO AFFECT THE FORECAST AREA FRIDAY NIGHT 
WITH CHANCE POPS IN THROUGH THE WEEKEND. TEMPERATURES WILL BE NEAR 
OR A LITTLE BELOW NORMAL THROUGH THE PERIOD.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$
