FXUS64 KLZK 261522 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1020 AM CDT SUN SEP 26 2004

.DISCUSSION...
PATCHY FOG HAS DISSIPATED...AND CLOUDS ARE DECREASING ACROSS EASTERN 
ARKANSAS. DRIER AIR MOVING INTO NORTHEAST ARKANSAS...BUT HAVING A 
HARD TIME GETTING THROUGH THE OZARKS IN WESTERN ARKANSAS. A FEW 
SHOWERS/SPRINKLES SHOWING UP ALONG THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER IN SOUTHERN 
ARKANSAS...BUT BEING ISOLATED IN NATURE...WILL NOT INCLUDE IN ZONE 
FORECAST. OVERALL...CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS GOOD. OTHER THAN A FEW 
TWEAKS OF TEMPS/WIND/SKY...MAIN CHANGE WAS TO REMOVE MORNING FOG.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

58





738 
FXUS64 KLZK 260817
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
315 AM CDT SUN SEP 26 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
DRIER AIR CONTS TO SLOWLY FILTER INTO AR FROM THE N EARLY THIS MRNG. 
SINCE SFC WINDS ARE RATHER LIGHT...THE DRIER AIR IS TAKING A PATH OF 
LEAST RESISTANCE AND WORKING SWD ACRS THE DELTA REGION OF NERN AR. 
FETCH OF HIGHER LVL MOISTURE CONTS TO STREAM NEWD ACRS ERN AR ATTM.

MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT THIS MRNG WITH OVERALL FCST TRENDS FOR 
THE SHORT TERM. WEAK RDG OF HIGH PRES WILL PERSIST OVER AR THE NEXT 
FEW DAYS AS REMNANTS OF JEANNE WORK N-NEWD OVER THE SERN AND 
MID-ATLANTIC STATES. PERSISTENT NELY WIND FLOW AT THE SFC WILL ALLOW 
FOR CONTD DRYING AND LTL CHC FOR RAINFALL.

MODELS STILL SHOWING A REINFORCING SHOT OF COOLER AIR WORKING SWD 
INTO AR STARTING TUE. STILL LOOKS LIKE SIG MOISTURE AND CONVERGENCE 
WILL BE LACKING FOR ANY ORGANIZED PRECIP...SO HAVE LEFT FCST DRY PER 
GOING FCST. EXPECT TEMPS TO BE A FEW DEGREES COOLER FOR HIGHS AND 
LOWS BY MID-WEEK.
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
FOR MUCH OF THE EXTENDED...PATTERN WILL REMAIN UNCHANGED. UPPER 
RIDGE WILL HOLD STEADY OVER THE GULF COAST...WHICH WILL PRECLUDE ANY 
SYSTEMS FROM MOVING DOWN FROM THE PLAINS. SURFACE FLOW WILL BE OUT 
OF THE NORTHEAST AND EAST...AND THIS WILL ACT TO KEEP TEMPERATURES 
NEAR TO SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL FOR MUCH OF THE PERIOD. 

BY THURSDAY...SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD OVER THE EASTERN 
PORTION OF THE COUNTRY. THIS WILL ALLOW FOR RETURN FLOW TO SET UP 
OVER THE FORECAST AREA. THOUGH UPPER RIDGE WILL REMAIN NEAR THE GULF 
COAST...IT WILL SINK SOUTHWARD A LITTLE. FLOW WILL BECOME MORE ZONAL 
IN NATURE...AND WILL ALLOW FOR A SURFACE FRONT TO MOVE DOWN FROM THE 
PLAINS BY LATE FRIDAY INTO SATURDAY. AT THIS POINT ITS SPLITTING 
HAIRS TO GET DETAILED ON DAY 7...BUT IF THE LONG RANGE GFS IS ANY 
INDICATION...THE FRONT COULD HANG UP OVER THE FORECAST AREA...
BRINGING THE FIRST SIGNIFICANT CHANCE OF RAIN FOR THE FALL SEASON. 

BY AND LARGE...GOING EXTENDED FORECAST LOOKS GOOD. ONLY MINOR 
ADJUSTMENTS WERE MADE TO TEMPERATURES AND POPS ON DAY 7. AT THIS 
POINT...NO MORE THAN SLIGHT CHANCE/CHANCE CATEGORY IS APPROPRIATE.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

44/57







028 
FXUS64 KLZK 260238
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
916 PM CDT SAT SEP 25 2004

.DISCUSSION...
FORECAST ALREADY UPDATED EARLIER THIS EVENING BUT A LITTLE MORE 
CLEAN UP WORK IS NEEDED. BIGGEST CHANGE WILL BE TO TIGHTEN UP THE 
WORDING...ADJUST TEMPERATURE TRENDS A LITTLE AND MAKE SOME 
ADJUSTMENTS TO SKY FORECAST. CURRENT SATELLITE IMAGES SHOW SKIES 
HAVE CLEARED OUT JUST ABOUT EVERYWHERE WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE 
SOUTHEAST. DEEP LAYERED MOISTURE CONTINUES TO BE SHUNTED SOUTHWARD 
AS DRIER AIR ADVECTS IN FROM THE NORTH. LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS 
PLACES 60 DEGREE ISODROSOTHERM ROUGHLY FROM KFYV TO KSRC TO KHKA. 
QUICK PEAK AT THE NEW MODELS SHOWS IT SLOWLY MOVING SOUTH THROUGH 
THE NIGHT. 

NEXT CONCERN WILL BE FOG FORMATION. MODELS NOT REALLY HINTING AT IT 
WITH TEMP/DEW POINT SPREADS ABOVE 3 DEGREES MOST OF THE NIGHT AND 
THE AFOREMENTIONED DRIER AIR COMING IN. WOULD NOT BE SURPRISED TO 
SEE A LITTLE FOG IN THE FAVORED AREAS INITIALLY BUT CONFIDENCE IS 
NOT HIGH ENOUGH TO INCLUDE IT IN THE GRIDS/ZONES.

OVERNIGHT LOWS APPEAR REASONABLE AND WILL BE LEFT ALONE BUT WILL 
ADJUST THE GRIDS A BIT TO REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS. WILL ALSO ADJUST 
SKY GRIDS/ZONES FOR SUNDAY AS MODELS SHOWING THE AREA UNDER 
SUBSIDENCE FROM THE LATEST HURRICANE MOVING THROUGH THE EASTERN 
CONUS AND LOTS OF DRY AIR IN PLACE. UPDATES OUT SHORTLY.  
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56






665 
FXUS64 KLZK 260021
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
717 PM CDT SAT SEP 25 2004

.DISCUSSION...
QUICK UPDATE THIS EVENING NEEDED TO REMOVE MENTION OF PRECIP AND 
CLEAN UP THE GRIDS A BIT. ALL DIURNAL SHOWER ACTIVITY HAS ENDED 
ACROSS THE AREA WITH DRIER AIR CONTINUING TO SLOWLY ADVECT IN. CLOUD 
COVER AND TEMPERATURE GRIDS WILL BE TWEAKED TO REFLECT CURRENT 
TRENDS BUT NO WHOLESALE CHANGES WILL BE MADE AT THIS TIME. 
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
ISOLATED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS OVER THE AREA...WITH MOISTURE 
STILL IN PLACE FROM THE REMNANTS OF IVAN. CLOUDS HAVE SHOWED SOME 
BREAKS THIS AFTERNOON...BUT STILL MOSTLY CLOUDY. FRONT TO THE 
SOUTHEAST OF THE STATE...WITH THE DRIER DEWPOINTS STILL ALONG THE 
MISSOURI BORDER. THE DRIER AIR WILL MOVE SOUTH TONIGHT AND 
SUNDAY...ENDING PRECIP CHANCES BEFORE MIDNIGHT. 

FORECAST REMAINS DRY THROUGH THE SHORT TERM...AS HIGH PRESSURE 
SETTLES IN. ANOTHER FRONT FROM THE PLAINS LOOKS TO MOVE IN 
TUESDAY...BUT MODELS HANDLING SITUATION DIFFERENTLY. GFS SHOWING A 
MORE PROGRESSIVE PATTERN WITH A STRONG SHORTWAVE. AM HAVING A HARD 
TIME BITING ON THE AMOUNT OF MOISTURE...GIVEN WINDS WILL BE FROM THE 
NORTHEAST AS HURRICANE JEANNE IS TO THE EAST OF THE MID SOUTH. FOR 
NOW...LEFT PRECIP OUT...BUT TRENDED TEMPS DOWN SLIGHTLY FOR TUESDAY.

SURFACE HIGH TO THE NORTH AND NORTHEAST OF THE AREA WILL KEEP LIGHT 
NORTHEAST WINDS IN THE AREA THROUGH THE MIDDLE AND LATTER PART OF 
THE WEEK. GFS SHOWS INCREASED MOISTURE TO THE WEST OF THE AREA AND 
THIS LOOKS LIKE UPSLOPE EFFECTS WHICH SHOULD STAY WEST OF THE CWA. 
THUS KEPT DRY FORECAST WITH MINS A LITTLE BELOW NORMAL AND MAXES 
CLOSE TO NORMAL. GFS BRINGS A RATHER STRONG COLD FRONT INTO THE AREA 
NEXT SATURDAY BUT THE UPPER FLOW PATTERN IS NOT FAVORABLE FOR A 
FRONTAL PASSAGE AS AN UPPER RIDGE REMAINS IN THE AREA AND FLOW ALOFT 
IS MOSTLY FROM THE SOUTHWEST. COMPROMISED THE POSSIBILITIES FOR 
NOW...PUT IN SOME POPS FOR NEXT SATURDAY WITH THE HIGHEST IN THE 
NORTH. DID GO WITH LOWER MAXES BUT THIS MAINLY FOR INCREASED CLOUDS. 
WINDS AHEAD OF THE FRONT MAY BE EAST TO SOUTHEAST...THUS CONVERGENCE 
MAY NOT BE REAL GREAT AND WENT WITH EASTERLY WINDS FOR SATURDAY.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56






BREAKS THIS AFTERNOON...BUT STILL MOSTLY CLOUDY. FRONT TO THE 
SOUTHEAST OF THE STATE...WITH THE DRIER DEWPOINTS STILL ALONG THE 
MISSOURI BORDER. THE DRIER AIR WILL MOVE SOUTH TONIGHT AND 
SUNDAY...ENDING PRECIP CHANCES BEFORE MIDNIGHT. 

FORECAST REMAINS DRY THROUGH THE SHORT TERM...AS HIGH PRESSURE 
SETTLES IN. ANOTHER FRONT FROM THE PLAINS LOOKS TO MOVE IN 
TUESDAY...BUT MODELS HANDLING SITUATION DIFFERENTLY. GFS SHOWING A 
MORE PROGRESSIVE PATTERN WITH A STRONG SHORTWAVE. AM HAVING A HARD 
TIME BITING ON THE AMOUNT OF MOISTURE...GIVEN WINDS WILL BE FROM THE 
NORTHEAST AS HURRICANE JEANNE IS TO THE EAST OF THE MID SOUTH. FOR 
NOW...LEFT PRECIP OUT...BUT TRENDED TEMPS DOWN SLIGHTLY FOR TUESDAY.
&&

.LONG TERM...
SURFACE HIGH TO THE NORTH AND NORTHEAST OF THE AREA WILL KEEP LIGHT 
NORTHEAST WINDS IN THE AREA THROUGH THE MIDDLE AND LATTER PART OF 
THE WEEK. GFS SHOWS INCREASED MOISTURE TO THE WEST OF THE AREA AND 
THIS LOOKS LIKE UPSLOPE EFFECTS WHICH SHOULD STAY WEST OF THE CWA. 
THUS KEPT DRY FORECAST WITH MINS A LITTLE BELOW NORMAL AND MAXES 
CLOSE TO NORMAL. GFS BRINGS A RATHER STRONG COLD FRONT INTO THE AREA 
NEXT SATURDAY BUT THE UPPER FLOW PATTERN IS NOT FAVORABLE FOR A 
FRONTAL PASSAGE AS AN UPPER RIDGE REMAINS IN THE AREA AND FLOW ALOFT 
IS MOSTLY FROM THE SOUTHWEST. COMPROMISED THE POSSIBILITIES FOR 
NOW...PUT IN SOME POPS FOR NEXT SATURDAY WITH THE HIGHEST IN THE 
NORTH. DID GO WITH LOWER MAXES BUT THIS MAINLY FOR INCREASED CLOUDS. 
WINDS AHEAD OF THE FRONT MAY BE EAST TO SOUTHEAST...THUS CONVERGENCE 
MAY NOT BE REAL GREAT AND WENT WITH EASTERLY WINDS FOR SATURDAY.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

58/29






239 
FXUS64 KLZK 251545 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1050 AM CDT SAT SEP 25 2004

.DISCUSSION...
ISOLATED LIGHT RAIN SHOWERS CONTINUE ACROSS MUCH OF THE STATE. THESE 
ARE IN RESPONSE TO A TROPICAL AIRMASS AND SHORTWAVE ENERGY REMAINING 
FROM IVAN. COLD FRONT PRETTY MUCH WASHED OUT ACROSS EASTERN 
ARKANSAS...WITH THE DRIER AIR STILL NORTH IN MISSOURI. PATHCY DENSE 
FOG IN NORTHWEST ARKANSAS IS NOW BEGINNING TO DISSIPATE.

FOR THE REST OF TODAY...EXPECT LIGHT RAIN SHOWERS/DRIZZLE TO 
CONTINUE. CLOUDS WILL BREAK UP SOMEWHAT IN THE EAST...WHILE PARTLY 
CLOUDY CONDITIONS WILL PREVAIL IN THE WEST. TEMPS IN THE WEST WILL 
BEGIN TO RISE QUICKLY WITH THE FOG DISSIPATION...WHILE THE CLOUDS 
WILL HOLD TEMPS DOWN IN THE EAST. MUCH OF THE STATE WILL SEE 
AFTERNOON READINGS IN THE LOWER 80S. CURRENT FORECAST HANDLES PRECIP 
TRENDS WELL...AND HAVE ALREADY UPDATED GRIDS TO TWEAK TEMPS AND 
CLOUD COVER.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

58





756 
FXUS64 KLZK 250811
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
310 AM CDT SAT SEP 25 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY
HAVE SEEN SHOWER ACTIVITY ON THE DECREASE OVR THE FA SINCE LAST 
EVENING. OLD FNTL BNDRY CONTS TO LOSE IDENTITY OVER THE REGION THIS 
MRNG. GOING BY SFC WIND FIELDS...BNDRY APPEARS TO BE IN THE VCNTY OF 
THE MS RIVER. HOWEVER...SFC DEWPOINTS ARE STILL IN THE 60S ACRS THE 
ENTIRE CWA.

MODELS STILL INDC ONE MORE DAY OF SOMEWHAT UNSETTLED WX FOR AR. 
WATER VAPOR PICS INCD THAT MAIN UPR LVL MOISTURE FETCH FROM IVAN IS 
ACRS CNTRL/ERN AR ATTM. ANOTHER WEAK SHRTWV OR TWO WILL LIFT NEWD 
ACRS THE AREA TODAY. FOR THIS REASON...HAVE KEPT POPS IN THE 20-30 
PERCENT RANGE FOR MOST AREAS TODAY. WILL MENTION PATCHY FOG FOR WRN 
AND NRN AR EARLY THIS MRNG WHERE CLOUDS HAVE CLEARED OUT.

DRIER AIR IS STILL PROGGED TO SETTLE INTO AR FROM THE N STARTING 
TNGT AND CONTG THRU THE SHORT TERM. EXPECT N-NELY WIND FLOW TO 
PERSIST ACRS AR MON AND TUE AS HURCN JEANNE TRACKS ALONG THE SERN 
AND MID-ATL COASTAL REGION. WITH DRIER AIRMASS IN PLACE...EXPECT A 
DECENT DIURNAL RANGE IN TEMPS ACRS THE FA. 
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
NOT MUCH CHANGES ARE NEEDED TO THE EXTENDED FORECAST THIS MORNING. 
IF ANY THING...ADJUSTED TEMPERATURES DOWNWARD A DEGREE OR TWO. FLOW 
ALOFT TURNS ALMOST ZONAL BY WEDNESDAY. HOWEVER...HIGH PRESSURE WILL 
TAKE HOLD OVER THE GREAT LAKES...WITH ANOTHER RIDGE BUILDING OVER 
OLD MEXICO/SOUTH TEXAS. 500 MB RIDGE WILL BE STRENGTHENING OVER THE 
SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES IN THE WAKE OF HURRICANE JEANNE. 

BOTTOM LINE IS THAT THIS PATTERN DOES NOT APPEAR TO ALLOW FOR THE 
PROGRESSION OF ANY SYSTEMS THROUGH THE FORECAST AREA THROUGH THE END 
OF THE PERIOD. ALTHOUGH DRY CONDITIONS WILL RETURN...SURFACE FLOW 
WILL MAINLY BE OUT OF THE NORTH AND NORTHEAST. THIS WILL ACT TO KEEP 
TEMPERATURES NEAR TO POSSIBLY SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL THROUGH FRIDAY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

44/57





324 
FXUS64 KLZK 250223
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
920 PM CDT FRI SEP 24 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATE WILL BE NEEDED THIS EVENING. COLD FRONT ILL DEFINED AT BEST 
THIS EVENING WITH WIND ANALYSIS PLACING IT SOMEWHERE OVER THE EAST 
BUT MOISTURE ANALYSIS WOULD PLACE IT OVER THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF 
THE STATE. PRESSURE CHANGE WOULD INDICATE THE FRONT OVER THE EAST 
WITH MOISTURE LAGGING BEHIND. REGARDLESS...FRONT WILL CONTINUE TO 
WEAKEN WITH TIME AS IT SAGS THROUGH THE STATE OVERNIGHT.

WSR-88D CONTINUES TO SHOW SCATTERED RETURNS OVER A LARGE AREA OF THE 
CWA WITH A GENERAL DRIFT TO THE NORTHEAST. MAIN BULK OF THE PRECIP 
SEEMS TO BE TIED INTO A MID LEVEL SHORTWAVE THAT WEAKENS WITH TIME. 
QUICK LOOK AT THE MODELS KEEP ABUNDANT MOISTURE AND PRECIPITATION 
IN PLACE THROUGH THE NIGHT. 00Z KLZK SOUNDING IS HINTING AT SOME 
DRYING IN THE LOW LEVELS SO PRECIP AMOUNTS WILL NOT BE VERY HIGH.

WILL NOT TOUCH THE POPS AND KEEP CURRENT TREND OF DECREASING THEM 
THROUGH THE NIGHT. CHANGE HERE WILL BE TO REMOVE ALL MENTION OF 
THUNDER WITH NO STRIKES IN THE CWA OVER THE PAST FEW HOURS.

OTHER CHANGE WILL BE TO TEMPERATURES...CURRENT TRENDS DO NOT SUPPORT 
FORECASTED LOWS. WITH ABUNDANT CLOUD COVER IN PLACE ...FAIRLY LOW 
TEMP/DEW POINT SPREADS AND CURRENT READINGS...WILL NEED TO BOOST 
LOWS ACROSS THE BOARD.

UPDATE OUT SHORTLY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56





103 
FXUS64 KLZK 241952
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
250 PM CDT FRI SEP 24 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
SCATTERED SHOWERS ACROSS THE WESTERN TWO THIRDS OF THE STATE THIS 
AFTERNOON...WITH ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS IN THE EXTREME WEST. 
MOISTURE BEING PULLED INTO THE STATE FROM THE REMNANTS OF HURRICANE 
IVAN...AND INTERACTING WITH A NEARLY STATIONARY FRONT. 
ALSO...SHORTWAVES OFF OF THE CIRCULATION OF IVAN ARE MOVING NORTH 
AND HELPING TO GENERATE SHOWERS. WITH ALL THESE FACTORS BEING IN 
CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE AREA...HAVE CONTINUED THE CHANCE POPS 
TONIGHT...ALONG WITH ISOLATED THUNDER. FOR NOW...HAVE ONLY LIGHT 
AMOUNTS IN FOR QPF...BUT IF ENOUGH MOISTURE GETS PULLED 
NORTH...SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS COULD SEE AN INCREASE IN PRECIP RATES.

FRONTAL BOUNDARY WILL MOVE SLOWLY SOUTHEAST THROUGH THE STATE 
TONIGHT AND SATURDAY. HIGHEST COVERAGE OF RAINFALL WILL BE RIGHT 
ALONG THE BOUNDARY...SO HAVE HIGHEST POPS WEST OF A LINE FROM 
TEXARKANA TO BATESVILLE. SATURDAY THE AXIS SHIFTS SOUTH...AS DRIER 
AIR MOVES IN FROM THE NORTH. HAVE RAINFALL ENDING IN THE NORTH 
SATURDAY MORNING...BUT LINGERING IN THE SOUTH UNTIL SATURDAY EVENING.

TEMPS TODAY WERE HELD IN CHECK DUE TO CLOUD COVER AND RAINFALL...BUT 
THINK SATURDAY WILL BE SLIGHTLY WARMER DUE TO LESS CLOUD COVER. BY 
SUNDAY AND MONDAY...HIGH PRESSURE AND DRIER AIR WILL MOVE INTO THE 
STATE...WITH TEMPS NEAR NORMAL.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
DRY PERIOD IN STORE FOR THE EXTENDED. SOME INCREASE IN MOISTURE OVER 
THE AREA BY WEDNESDAY...BUT NOT ENOUGH TO INCLUDE ANY POPS. 
TEMPERATURES SHOULD BE NEAR NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    64  84  61  84 /  40  30  20  10 
HARRISON AR       58  79  55  79 /  30  20  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    64  84  61  84 /  40  30  20  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     65  85  62  85 /  30  30  20  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  58  79  54  79 /  30  20  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     66  85  63  85 /  30  20  20  10 
SEARCY AR         63  83  59  83 /  40  30  20  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      63  84  59  84 /  40  30  20  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   61  82  56  82 /  40  20  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&



003 
FXUS64 KLZK 240820
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
320 AM CDT FRI SEP 24 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY
HAVE SEEN SCTD PATCHES OF MOSTLY LIGHT RAIN AFFECT THE SERN HALF OF 
THE FA OVR THE PAST FEW HOURS. RAINFALL COVERAGE HAS DECREASED 
FURTHER N WHERE THE AIRMASS IS SOMEWHAT DRIER. REMNANTS OF IVAN WERE 
CENTERED ALONG THE GULF COAST NEAR THE TX/LA BRDR. MEANWHILE...WEAK 
CDFNT WAS LOCATED ROUGHLY ALONG THE I-44 CORRIDOR JUST TO THE NW OF 
AR.

MAIN FCST CONCERN FOR THE EARLY PART OF THE FCST PD IS RAIN CHCS. 
MODELS STILL ARE IN DECENT AGREEMENT WITH LARGE SCALE FEATURES OVER 
THE NEXT FEW DAYS. WHAT IS LEFT OF IVAN IS PROGGED TO DRIFT WWD AND 
THEN SWWD INTO SERN TX. THE WEAK CDFNT IS FCST TO DRIFT SLOLY SEWD 
INTO AR INTO THE WEEKEND. 

STILL LOOKS LIKE SOME RESIDUAL MOISTURE WITH IVAN WILL INTERACT WITH 
THE FNT TO KEEP RAIN CHCS IN THE FCST THRU SAT. SEVERAL WEAK UPPER 
LVL IMPULSES ARE ALSO FCST TO LIFT NEWD ACRS AR OVER THE NEXT 24 TO 
48 HRS. THUS...HAVE GONE WITH CHC POPS FOR NOW WHICH AGREES WELL 
WITH GOING FCST.

BY SUN AND MON...THE FNTL BNDRY WILL BE ABSORBED BY THE FLOW ARND 
HURCN JEANNE AS IT TRACKS ALONG THE COAST OF THE SERN US. WEAK SFC 
RDG WILL SETTLE OVER AR...ALLOWING DRIER AIR TO WORK BACK INTO THE 
FA.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
EXTENDED RANGE SOLUTIONS ARE IN VERY GOOD AGREEMENT THIS MORNING. 
GFS...ECMWF...NOGAPS...AND GGEM ALL KEEP SOME FORM OF SFC AND UPR 
RDGNG INVOF THE FCST AREA THROUGH DAY 7. SEVERAL SYSTEMS WILL 
PASS TO THE NORTH OF ARKANSAS...MOST NOTABLY AROUND THE THURSDAY 
TIME FRAME AS UPR LOW IS PROGGED TO MOVE DOWN OUT OF THE NORTHERN 
ROCKIES AND THROUGH THE MID/UPR MS VLY. HOWEVER...WITH SFC AND 
UPR RDG IN PLACE OVER THE GULF COAST...FCST AREA WILL ONLY SEE 
INCRS IN CLOUD COVER ACROSS THE NRN AND CNTRL PTNS. TEMPS WILL BE 
NEAR TO SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL...AS FLOW WILL REMAIN OUT OF THE 
NORTHEAST AND EAST.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
320 AM CDT FRI SEP 24 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY
HAVE SEEN SCTD PATCHES OF MOSTLY LIGHT RAIN AFFECT THE SERN HALF OF 
THE FA OVR THE PAST FEW HOURS. RAINFALL COVERAGE HAS DECREASED 
FURTHER N WHERE THE AIRMASS IS SOMEWHAT DRIER. REMNANTS OF IVAN WERE 
CENTERED ALONG THE GULF COAST NEAR THE TX/LA BRDR. MEANWHILE...WEAK 
CDFNT WAS LOCATED ROUGHLY ALONG THE I-44 CORRIDOR JUST TO THE NW OF 
AR.

MAIN FCST CONCERN FOR THE EARLY PART OF THE FCST PD IS RAIN CHCS. 
MODELS STILL ARE IN DECENT AGREEMENT WITH LARGE SCALE FEATURES OVER 
THE NEXT FEW DAYS. WHAT IS LEFT OF IVAN IS PROGGED TO DRIFT WWD AND 
THEN SWWD INTO SERN TX. THE WEAK CDFNT IS FCST TO DRIFT SLOLY SEWD 
INTO AR INTO THE WEEKEND. 

STILL LOOKS LIKE SOME RESIDUAL MOISTURE WITH IVAN WILL INTERACT WITH 
THE FNT TO KEEP RAIN CHCS IN THE FCST THRU SAT. SEVERAL WEAK UPPER 
LVL IMPULSES ARE ALSO FCST TO LIFT NEWD ACRS AR OVER THE NEXT 24 TO 
48 HRS. THUS...HAVE GONE WITH CHC POPS FOR NOW WHICH AGREES WELL 
WITH GOING FCST.

BY SUN AND MON...THE FNTL BNDRY WILL BE ABSORBED BY THE FLOW ARND 
HURCN JEANNE AS IT TRACKS ALONG THE COAST OF THE SERN US. WEAK SFC 
RDG WILL SETTLE OVER AR...ALLOWING DRIER AIR TO WORK BACK INTO THE 
FA.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
EXTENDED RANGE SOLUTIONS ARE IN VERY GOOD AGREEMENT THIS MORNING. 
GFS...ECMWF...NOGAPS...AND GGEM ALL KEEP SOME FORM OF SFC AND UPR 
RDGNG INVOF THE FCST AREA THROUGH DAY 7. SEVERAL SYSTEMS WILL 
PASS TO THE NORTH OF ARKANSAS...MOST NOTABLY AROUND THE THURSDAY 
TIME FRAME AS UPR LOW IS PROGGED TO MOVE DOWN OUT OF THE NORTHERN 
ROCKIES AND THROUGH THE MID/UPR MS VLY. HOWEVER...WITH SFC AND 
UPR RDG IN PLACE OVER THE GULF COAST...FCST AREA WILL ONLY SEE 
INCRS IN CLOUD COVER ACROSS THE NRN AND CNTRL PTNS. TEMPS WILL BE 
NEAR TO SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL...AS FLOW WILL REMAIN OUT OF THE 
NORTHEAST AND EAST.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

44/57






491 
FXUS64 KLZK 240232
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
930 PM CDT THU SEP 23 2004

.DISCUSSION...
MINOR UPDATE NEEDED THIS EVENING. ONLY SLIGHT CHANCE TO SCATTERED 
POPS IN THE FORECAST TONIGHT AND BASED ON CURRENT TRENDS...APPEAR TO 
BE RIGHT ON TRACK. TROPICAL STORM IVAN ON SHORE NOW OVER SOUTHERN 
LOUISIANA AND WHAT CONVECTION THERE WAS...SEEMS TO BE RAPIDLY 
DETERIORATING. BAND OF RAIN ASSOCIATED WITH THE FEATURE OVER THE 
SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE AREA MOVING TO THE NORTHEAST. MOST OF THE 
PRECIP IS ALOFT AS SURFACE OBS ARE SHOWING MOST OF THE PRECIPITATION 
NOT MAKING IT TO THE SURFACE. BAND ACTUALLY APPEARS TO BE DECREASING 
SOMEWHAT AS IT MOVES INTO DRIER AIR.

COLD FRONT NOW ENTERING THE EXTREME NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE STATE 
BASED ON SURFACE ANALYSIS. LOCAL RADARS CURRENTLY SHOW VIRTUALLY NO 
PRECIPITATION ASSOCIATED WITH THIS FEATURE AS UPPER SUPPORT MOVES 
OFF TO THE NORTHEAST. 

QUICK PEAK AT THE LATEST MODELS SHOW ALMOST NO MEASURABLE 
PRECIPITATION OVER THE CWA TONIGHT. HOWEVER...WITH SO MUCH GOING ON 
WILL SIMPLY LEAVE POPS IN PLACE. BEST CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION MAY 
BE ALONG THE FRONT ITSELF BUT WILL LEFT MIDNIGHT CREW MADE FINAL 
DECISION. FORECASTED TEMPS AND WINDS LOOKS GOOD AND WILL ALSO BE 
LEFT IN PLACE.

ONLY CHANGES WILL BE TO CLEAN UP WORDING AND DO SOME TWEAKING TO THE 
GRIDS TO REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS. CHANGES TO THE ACTUAL FORECAST WILL 
BE NEGLIGIBLE.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
BIG QUESTION IS HOW FAR NORTHWARD ANY SIGNIFICANT MOISTURE FROM IVAN 
WILL MAKE IT. APPEARS THAT MOST OF THE HEAVIEST MOISTURE WILL REMAIN 
SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST OF THE FORECAST AREA. MAY POSSIBLY SEE UP TO 1/2 
INCH OR SO OVER THE SOUTH AND SOUTHWESTERN AREAS OVER NEXT 24 HOURS 
OR SO. REST OF THE AREA WILL SEE LIGHTER AMOUNTS. HAVE CHANCE POPS 
INCREASING NORTHWESTWARD OVERNIGHT...THEN CONTINUE CHANCE POPS OVER 
THE AREA ON FRIDAY. POPS WILL BEGIN TO DECREASE ON FRIDAY NIGHT AND 
CONTINUING DECREASING ON SATURDAY. COLD FRONT MOVING INTO 
NORTHWESTERN SECTIONS THIS EVENING...BUT WILL BE VERY SLOW IN MOVING 
ACROSS THE AREA OVER THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS. THUS...ONLY A LITTLE 
OF THE COOLER AND DRIER AIR BEHIND IT WILL MAKE IT INTO THE AREA BY 
THE EARLY PART OF THE WEEKEND.

SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL BRING A FEW DISTURBANCES THROUGH THE 
STATE...BUT WITH DRY AIR...HAVE LEFT PRECIP CHANCES OUT. TEMPS WILL 
BE NEAR NORMAL THROUGH THE EXTENDED.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



202 
FXUS64 KLZK 230826
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT THU SEP 23 2004

.DISCUSSION...
PATTERN CONTINUES WITH SURFACE RIDGE IN THE AREA FROM THE NORTHEAST
AND A STRONG UPPER HIGH IN THE EASTERN U.S. THIS WILL CHANGE OVER THE
NEXT DAY OR TWO AS A STRONG UPPER LOW LIFTS NORTHEAST ACROSS THE 
PLAINS AND WEAKENS THE RIDGE TO THE EAST WHICH WILL ALSO BE MOVING 
TO THE EAST. THIS WILL HELP BRING A COLD FRONT INTO THE AREA TONIGHT
AND FRIDAY. IN ADDITION...THE REMNANTS OF IVAN HAVE REGENERATED INTO
A WEAK TROPICAL STORM IN THE NORTHERN GULF. MOISTURE FROM THIS LOOKS
LIKE IT WILL MOVE INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS TODAY AND SPREAD ACROSS
MUCH OF THE AREA TONIGHT IN ADVANCE OF THE APPROACHING COLD FRONT. 
DUE TO THIS...HAVE KEPT SMALL POPS IN THE SOUTHEAST STARTING AROUND 
NOON THEN SLOWLY INCREASE POPS DURING THE AFTERNOON IN CENTRAL AND
SOUTHERN SECTIONS. INCREASED POPS FOR TONIGHT TO AT LEAST 30 PERCENT
IN ALL AREAS AS MOISTURE GETS PULLED NORTH AND THE COLD FRONT BEGINS
TO MOVE INTO THE AREA. RAISED POPS TO 50 PERCENT IN THE SOUTH WHERE
MORE TROPICAL MOISTURE WILL BE PRESENT. GFS INDICATES AREA OF HEAVY
RAIN IN THE SOUTH TONIGHT BUT THAT LOOKS A LITTLE SUSPECT CONSIDERING
HOW FAR IT IS FROM THE CENTER OF IVAN. DO THINK THE SOUTH WILL BE
IN FOR HEAVIER RAIN BUT THINK AMOUNTS GENERALLY WILL BE ONE HALF
INCH OR LESS. THE FRONT WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA FRIDAY BUT WILL 
BE WEAKENING CONSIDERABLY FROM THE LOSS OF UPPER SUPPORT AS THE MAIN
SHORT WAVE DRIVING IT WILL BE SCOOTING OFF TO THE NORTHEAST. HOWEVER
THE CIRCULATION AROUND THE REMNANTS OF IVAN AND THE PERSISTENT 
SURFACE RIDGE WILL LIKELY BRING A GENERAL NORTHEAST TO EAST WIND TO
THE AREA AND MAKE THE FRONT HARDER TO DEFINE WITH TIME. WILL 
CONTINUE WITH POPS RANGING FROM 30 IN THE NORTH TO 50 IN THE SOUTH.
THE MOISTURE AXIS GETS SHUNTED SLOWLY TO THE SOUTHEAST LATE FRIDAY 
THROUGH SATURDAY. THE MAIN TROF AXIS ALSO MOVES INTO SOUTHEASTERN 
ARKANSAS BY FRIDAY EVENING. WHAT IS LEFT OF IVAN MAY GET STRETCHED 
OUT ALONG THIS AXIS BUT IT SUGGESTS POPS SHOULD DECREASE FROM THE 
NORTHWEST LATE FRIDAY INTO FRIDAY NIGHT. ENOUGH MOISTURE REMAINS
TO CONTINUE A MENTION OF RAIN IN THE SOUTHEAST INTO SATURDAY. 
HIGH PRESSURE AT THE SURFACE FINALLY PUSHES INTO THE AREA ENOUGH
BY SATURDAY NIGHT TO BRING MOSTLY DRY CONDITIONS WHICH SHOULD 
CONTINUE THROUGH THE EARLY PART OF NEXT WEEK. WENT CLOSE TO
PERSISTENCE ON MAXES TODAY EXCEPT FOR THE SOUTH WHERE INCREASED 
CLOUDS AND RAIN CHANCES SHOULD HOLD TEMPS DOWN A LITTLE. WENT
LOWER WITH MAXES FRIDAY DUE TO EXPECTED MOSTLY CLOUDY SKIES. 
WENT CLOSE TO GUIDANCE ON TEMPS THROUGH THE REST OF THE PERIOD 
WITH COOL MINS MOSTLY IN THE MID 50S TO AROUND 60 AND MAXES IN
THE UPPER 70S NORTH AND LOWER TO MID 80S ELSEWHERE.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    86  65  83  64 /  20  40  40  20 
HARRISON AR       83  61  78  58 /  10  30  30  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    87  66  83  65 /  10  40  40  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     86  66  82  65 /  30  40  40  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  83  60  77  58 /  10  30  30  20 
MONTICELLO AR     85  67  80  66 /  30  50  50  30 
SEARCY AR         85  64  82  63 /  20  40  40  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      87  65  83  64 /  10  40  40  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   86  63  82  62 /  10  40  40  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29 






647 
FXUS64 KLZK 230220
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
915 PM CDT WED SEP 22 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS RIGHT ON TARGET AND NO CHANGES ARE NEEDED.  
HIGH PRESSURE WILL REMAIN PARKED OVER THE AREA TONIGHT WITH A COLD 
FRONT STRETCHING ACROSS THE CENTRAL PLAINS. TROPICAL SYSTEM SLOWLY 
ORGANIZING IN THE GULF IS ACTUALLY WHATS LEFT OF HURRICANE IVAN. 
SYSTEM TRAVERSED THE EAST COAST OF THE COUNTRY ON THE EASTERN 
PERIPHERY OF THE HIGH AND IS NOW BACK IN THE GULF. PROGS HAVE SYSTEM 
APPROACHING THE TEXAS COAST TOWARDS MORNING WITH DEEP MOISTURE 
SURGING BACK INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS.

WILL KEEP FORECAST DRY AS NO REAL TRIGGER IS SEEN FOR TONIGHT BUT 
TROPICAL MOISTURE EXPECTED TO INTERACT WITH APPROACHING FRONT FOR AT 
LEAST CHANCE POPS THURSDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH FRIDAY PER GOING 
FORECAST. WILL TWEAK THE GRIDS A LITTLE TO REFLECT CURRENT 
CONDITIONS BUT TRENDS SUPPORT FORECASTED LOWS. 
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES TO BRING DRY WEATHER TO THE REGION. THROUGH
THE 20TH...LZK HAD 3RD DRIEST SEPTEMBER ON RECORD. THAT MAY CHANGE.

HIGH WILL FLATTEN HEADING INTO WEEKEND. COLD FRONT IN THE 
PLAINS...WHICH HAS PRETTY MUCH STALLED...WILL BEGIN MOVING AGAIN. 
FRONT WILL ARRIVE IN NORTHWEST ARKANSAS LATE THURSDAY NIGHT.

UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT WITH FRONT WILL HEAD WELL TO THE NORTH...WITH 
FRONT SLOWING ONCE AGAIN. FRONT WILL LINGER IN THE STATE FRIDAY 
BEFORE DEPARTING ON SATURDAY.

ASIDE FROM FRONT...SYSTEM IN THE GULF WILL HEAD TO THE NORTHWEST
TOWARD THE REGION. MOISTURE SURROUNDING THE SYSTEM WILL SURGE INTO
THE SOUTHEAST COUNTIES BY THURSDAY AFTERNOON...WITH MOISTURE 
OVERSPREADING ARKANSAS THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY.

WITH A FRONT IN THE AREA...AND WITH SOME TROPICAL MOISTURE IN 
PLACE...WENT AHEAD AND BOOSTED CHANCES FOR RAIN A BIT IN THE 
THURSDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH FRIDAY TIME FRAME. THIS ESPECIALLY THE 
CASE IN THE SOUTHERN HALF OF THE STATE. A LITTLE HISTORY WILL PLAY 
IN THIS DECISION AS WELL. 

LOOKING BACK AT TOP 5 DRIEST SEPTEMBERS...4 OF THESE HAD RAIN DURING 
THE LAST WEEK OF THE MONTH. SOME OF THIS RAIN WAS SIGNIFICANT...WITH 
3 OF THESE YEARS PUSHED OUT OF THE TOP 10 LIST FOR DRIEST 
SEPTEMBERS. NOT THAT HISTORY WILL REPEAT ITSELF THIS YEAR...BUT 
INTERESTING ANYWAY.

ASSUMING FRONT EXITS TO START THE WEEK...WILL GO BACK TO A DRY 
WEATHER PATTERN. DRIER AIR BEHIND FRONT...WITH SLIGHTLY COOLER 
TEMPERATURES FELT MAINLY AT NIGHT. (46)          

BROAD AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE WILL BE OVER THE GULF COAST STATES FOR 
THE EARLY PORTION OF NEXT WEEK. SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL BRING A FEW WEAK 
SHORTWAVES ACROSS THE STATE...BUT MOISTURE RETURN IS RELATIVELY 
SMALL. FOR NOW...HAVE A DRY FORECAST THROUGH THE BEGINNING OF NEXT 
WEEK...WITH TEMPS NEAR NORMAL.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 230220
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
915 PM CDT WED SEP 22 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS RIGHT ON TARGET AND NO CHANGES ARE NEEDED.  
HIGH PRESSURE WILL REMAIN PARKED OVER THE AREA TONIGHT WITH A COLD 
FRONT STRETCHING ACROSS THE CENTRAL PLAINS. TROPICAL SYSTEM SLOWLY 
ORGANIZING IN THE GULF IS ACTUALLY WHATS LEFT OF HURRICANE IVAN. 
SYSTEM TRAVERSED THE EAST COAST OF THE COUNTRY ON THE EASTERN 
PERIPHERY OF THE HIGH AND IS NOW BACK IN THE GULF. PROGS HAVE SYSTEM 
APPROACHING THE TEXAS COAST TOWARDS MORNING WITH DEEP MOISTURE 
SURGING BACK INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS.

WILL KEEP FORECAST DRY AS NO REAL TRIGGER IS SEEN FOR TONIGHT BUT 
TROPICAL MOISTURE EXPECTED TO INTERACT WITH APPROACHING FRONT FOR AT 
LEAST CHANCE POPS THURSDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH FRIDAY PER GOING 
FORECAST. WILL TWEAK THE GRIDS A LITTLE TO REFLECT CURRENT 
CONDITIONS BUT TRENDS SUPPORT FORECASTED LOWS. 
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES TO BRING DRY WEATHER TO THE REGION. THROUGH
THE 20TH...LZK HAD 3RD DRIEST SEPTEMBER ON RECORD. THAT MAY CHANGE.

HIGH WILL FLATTEN HEADING INTO WEEKEND. COLD FRONT IN THE 
PLAINS...WHICH HAS PRETTY MUCH STALLED...WILL BEGIN MOVING AGAIN. 
FRONT WILL ARRIVE IN NORTHWEST ARKANSAS LATE THURSDAY NIGHT.

UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT WITH FRONT WILL HEAD WELL TO THE NORTH...WITH 
FRONT SLOWING ONCE AGAIN. FRONT WILL LINGER IN THE STATE FRIDAY 
BEFORE DEPARTING ON SATURDAY.

ASIDE FROM FRONT...SYSTEM IN THE GULF WILL HEAD TO THE NORTHWEST
TOWARD THE REGION. MOISTURE SURROUNDING THE SYSTEM WILL SURGE INTO
THE SOUTHEAST COUNTIES BY THURSDAY AFTERNOON...WITH MOISTURE 
OVERSPREADING ARKANSAS THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY.

WITH A FRONT IN THE AREA...AND WITH SOME TROPICAL MOISTURE IN 
PLACE...WENT AHEAD AND BOOSTED CHANCES FOR RAIN A BIT IN THE 
THURSDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH FRIDAY TIME FRAME. THIS ESPECIALLY THE 
CASE IN THE SOUTHERN HALF OF THE STATE. A LITTLE HISTORY WILL PLAY 
IN THIS DECISION AS WELL. 

LOOKING BACK AT TOP 5 DRIEST SEPTEMBERS...4 OF THESE HAD RAIN DURING 
THE LAST WEEK OF THE MONTH. SOME OF THIS RAIN WAS SIGNIFICANT...WITH 
3 OF THESE YEARS PUSHED OUT OF THE TOP 10 LIST FOR DRIEST 
SEPTEMBERS. NOT THAT HISTORY WILL REPEAT ITSELF THIS YEAR...BUT 
INTERESTING ANYWAY.

ASSUMING FRONT EXITS TO START THE WEEK...WILL GO BACK TO A DRY 
WEATHER PATTERN. DRIER AIR BEHIND FRONT...WITH SLIGHTLY COOLER 
TEMPERATURES FELT MAINLY AT NIGHT. (46)          

BROAD AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE WILL BE OVER THE GULF COAST STATES FOR 
THE EARLY PORTION OF NEXT WEEK. SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL BRING A FEW WEAK 
SHORTWAVES ACROSS THE STATE...BUT MOISTURE RETURN IS RELATIVELY 
SMALL. FOR NOW...HAVE A DRY FORECAST THROUGH THE BEGINNING OF NEXT 
WEEK...WITH TEMPS NEAR NORMAL.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56

FRONT WILL ARRIVE IN NORTHWEST ARKANSAS LATE THURSDAY NIGHT.

UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT WITH FRONT WILL HEAD WELL TO THE NORTH...WITH 
FRONT SLOWING ONCE AGAIN. FRONT WILL LINGER IN THE STATE FRIDAY 
BEFORE DEPARTING ON SATURDAY.

ASIDE FROM FRONT...SYSTEM IN THE GULF WILL HEAD TO THE NORTHWEST
TOWARD THE REGION. MOISTURE SURROUNDING THE SYSTEM WILL SURGE INTO
THE SOUTHEAST COUNTIES BY THURSDAY AFTERNOON...WITH MOISTURE 
OVERSPREADING ARKANSAS THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY.

WITH A FRONT IN THE AREA...AND WITH SOME TROPICAL MOISTURE IN 
PLACE...WENT AHEAD AND BOOSTED CHANCES FOR RAIN A BIT IN THE 
THURSDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH FRIDAY TIME FRAME. THIS ESPECIALLY THE 
CASE IN THE SOUTHERN HALF OF THE STATE. A LITTLE HISTORY WILL PLAY 
IN THIS DECISION AS WELL. 

LOOKING BACK AT TOP 5 DRIEST SEPTEMBERS...4 OF THESE HAD RAIN DURING 
THE LAST WEEK OF THE MONTH. SOME OF THIS RAIN WAS SIGNIFICANT...WITH 
3 OF THESE YEARS PUSHED OUT OF THE TOP 10 LIST FOR DRIEST 
SEPTEMBERS. NOT THAT HISTORY WILL REPEAT ITSELF THIS YEAR...BUT 
INTERESTING ANYWAY.

ASSUMING FRONT EXITS TO START THE WEEK...WILL GO BACK TO A DRY 
WEATHER PATTERN. DRIER AIR BEHIND FRONT...WITH SLIGHTLY COOLER 
TEMPERATURES FELT MAINLY AT NIGHT. (46)          
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
BROAD AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE WILL BE OVER THE GULF COAST STATES FOR 
THE EARLY PORTION OF NEXT WEEK. SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL BRING A FEW WEAK 
SHORTWAVES ACROSS THE STATE...BUT MOISTURE RETURN IS RELATIVELY 
SMALL. FOR NOW...HAVE A DRY FORECAST THROUGH THE BEGINNING OF NEXT 
WEEK...WITH TEMPS NEAR NORMAL.

801 
FXUS64 KLZK 221621 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1115 AM CDT WED SEP 22 2004

.DISCUSSION...
NOTE MUCH TO CHANGE IN GOING FORECAST. MOISTURE INCREASING SLOWLY 
FROM GULF...AND THIS WILL YIELD A FEW MORE CLOUDS THAN IN RECENT 
DAYS. OTHERWISE...A DRY AFTERNOON IN STORE. 

LOOKING AT THURSDAY/FRIDAY...MAY HAVE TO FURTHER ADDRESS DEVELOPING 
SYSTEM IN GULF. LATEST DATA SHOWING SYSTEM MOVING NORTHWEST...WITH 
MOISTURE FROM SYSTEM INCREASING IN ARKANSAS. THIS ALONG WITH SLOW 
MOVING FRONT FROM THE PLAINS MAY PRODUCE MORE PRECIPITATION THAN 
INDICATED IN FORECAST. AS A RESULT...MAY BUMP UP CHANCES FOR RAIN 
IN AFTERNOON FORECAST PACKAGE. (46)
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&



375 
FXUS64 KLZK 221144
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
645 AM CDT WED SEP 22 2004

.DISCUSSION...
HIGH BASED STRATOCUMULUS IN THE 5000 TO 6000 FOOT RANGE HAS DEVELOPED
IN MUCH OF CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN ARKANSAS APPARENTLY IN RESPONSE TO
A WEAK SHORT WAVE ROTATING AROUND THE UPPER HIGH IN THE OHIO VALLEY.
UPDATED ZONES TO CHANGE TO PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES FOR TODAY. FIGURE
CLOUDS SHOULD SCATTER OUT WITH MIXING LATER THIS MORNING AND SHOULD
HAVE LITTLE IF ANY EFFECT ON TEMPS. 

.PREV DISCUSSION...
SURFACE RIDGE FROM THE EAST REMAINS IN THE AREA KEEPING DRY AIR IN
PLACE. THIS BEING AIDED BY THE STRONGEST UPPER RIDGE OF THE SEASON 
ACROSS THE AREA. THIS SHOULD GENERALLY CONTINUE UNTIL A COLD FRONT 
MANAGES TO REACH THE AREA LATE THURSDAY NIGHT INTO FRIDAY. AT THE 
SAME TIME AN UPPER LOW WILL MOVE WEST ACROSS THE NORTHERN GULF OF
MEXICO AND SOME MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS COULD MAKE IT INTO 
AT LEAST SOUTHERN ARKANSAS BY LATE THURSDAY. THE APPROACHING FRONT 
WILL BE PUSHED AROUND BY AN UPPER TROF THAT WILL LIFT TO THE 
NORTHEAST INTO THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI VALLEY AND THIS TROUGH WILL 
WEAKEN THE RIDGE THAT HAS COVERED THE AREA. THE FRONT SHOULD WEAKEN
CONSIDERABLY BEFORE REACHING THE AREA HOWEVER AS THE BEST UPPER 
SUPPORT MOVES AWAY TO THE NORTHEAST AND THE UPPER RIDGE REMAINS IN
THE AREA THOUGH IN A WEAKENED STATE. LOW LEVEL FLOW REMAINS FROM THE
EAST SO THE GULF NEVER REALLY OPENS UP AND MOISTURE WILL STILL BE 
RATHER LIMITED. 

WILL GO CLOSE TO PERSISTENCE WITH THE FORECAST TODAY AND TONIGHT.
CLOUDS WILL INCREASE THURSDAY ESPECIALLY IN THE SOUTH FROM THE
UPPER LOW MOVING TO THE WEST. MAX TEMPS SHOULD STILL BE ABOUT THE
SAME AS THEY WILL BE TODAY. WILL INTRODUCE SMALL POPS THURSDAY
NIGHT AS THE FRONT APPROACHES. THE WEAKENED FRONT WILL MOVE INTO
THE STATE FRIDAY AND WILL MOVE SLOWLY ACROSS THE AREA. MOISTURE
WILL REMAIN THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT SO WILL CONTINUE THE SMALL POPS
THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT. GFS MOISTURE FIELDS SUGGEST CONTINUING
POPS INTO SATURDAY IN THE SOUTH BUT WILL HOLD OFF FOR NOW. THE
COOLER AND DRIER AIR WILL LIKELY LAG WELL BEHIND THE FRONT AND
WILL NOT MAKE ITS PRESENCE FELT TOO MUCH. KEPT MINS IN THE MID 50S
TO LOWER 60S WITH MAXES IN THE UPPER 70S TO MID 80S FOR THE 
WEEKEND. SURFACE HIGH TO THE NORTH SHOULD TAKE CONTROL OF THE 
WEATHER OVER THE WEEKEND AND CONTINUE INTO NEXT WEEK. THIS WILL
BRING A REPEAT OF THE RATHER DRY NORTHEAST SURFACE FLOW INTO 
THE AREA. KEPT THE FORECAST DRY THROUGH THE REST OF THE SEVEN DAY
PERIOD.   
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    85  61  86  65 /   0  10  10  20 
HARRISON AR       83  57  83  60 /   0  10  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    86  60  87  65 /   0  10  10  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     86  62  86  65 /   0  10  10  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  82  58  83  59 /   0  10  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     87  63  85  66 /   0  10  10  20 
SEARCY AR         85  61  85  63 /   0  10  10  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      85  60  87  64 /   0  10  10  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   84  60  86  63 /   0  10  10  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT WED SEP 22 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SURFACE RIDGE FROM THE EAST REMAINS IN THE AREA KEEPING DRY AIR IN
PLACE. THIS BEING AIDED BY THE STRONGEST UPPER RIDGE OF THE SEASON 
ACROSS THE AREA. THIS SHOULD GENERALLY CONTINUE UNTIL A COLD FRONT 
MANAGES TO REACH THE AREA LATE THURSDAY NIGHT INTO FRIDAY. AT THE 
SAME TIME AN UPPER LOW WILL MOVE WEST ACROSS THE NORTHERN GULF OF
MEXICO AND SOME MOISTURE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS COULD MAKE IT INTO 
AT LEAST SOUTHERN ARKANSAS BY LATE THURSDAY. THE APPROACHING FRONT 
WILL BE PUSHED AROUND BY AN UPPER TROF THAT WILL LIFT TO THE 
NORTHEAST INTO THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI VALLEY AND THIS TROUGH WILL 
WEAKEN THE RIDGE THAT HAS COVERED THE AREA. THE FRONT SHOULD WEAKEN
CONSIDERABLY BEFORE REACHING THE AREA HOWEVER AS THE BEST UPPER 
SUPPORT MOVES AWAY TO THE NORTHEAST AND THE UPPER RIDGE REMAINS IN
THE AREA THOUGH IN A WEAKENED STATE. LOW LEVEL FLOW REMAINS FROM THE
EAST SO THE GULF NEVER REALLY OPENS UP AND MOISTURE WILL STILL BE 
RATHER LIMITED. 

WILL GO CLOSE TO PERSISTENCE WITH THE FORECAST TODAY AND TONIGHT.
CLOUDS WILL INCREASE THURSDAY ESPECIALLY IN THE SOUTH FROM THE
UPPER LOW MOVING TO THE WEST. MAX TEMPS SHOULD STILL BE ABOUT THE
SAME AS THEY WILL BE TODAY. WILL INTRODUCE SMALL POPS THURSDAY
NIGHT AS THE FRONT APPROACHES. THE WEAKENED FRONT WILL MOVE INTO
THE STATE FRIDAY AND WILL MOVE SLOWLY ACROSS THE AREA. MOISTURE
WILL REMAIN THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT SO WILL CONTINUE THE SMALL POPS
THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT. GFS MOISTURE FIELDS SUGGEST CONTINUING
POPS INTO SATURDAY IN THE SOUTH BUT WILL HOLD OFF FOR NOW. THE
COOLER AND DRIER AIR WILL LIKELY LAG WELL BEHIND THE FRONT AND
WILL NOT MAKE ITS PRESENCE FELT TOO MUCH. KEPT MINS IN THE MID 50S
TO LOWER 60S WITH MAXES IN THE UPPER 70S TO MID 80S FOR THE 
WEEKEND. SURFACE HIGH TO THE NORTH SHOULD TAKE CONTROL OF THE 
WEATHER OVER THE WEEKEND AND CONTINUE INTO NEXT WEEK. THIS WILL
BRING A REPEAT OF THE RATHER DRY NORTHEAST SURFACE FLOW INTO 
THE AREA. KEPT THE FORECAST DRY THROUGH THE REST OF THE SEVEN DAY
PERIOD.

.DISCUSSION...

DEWPOINTS ADVECTING WWD INTO ERN AR THE LAST FEW HOURS. MEANWHILE...
DRIER AIRMASS STILL NOTED OVER WRN AND N-CNTRL AR. HAVE TWEAKED MIN 
TEMPS JUST A FEW DEGREES IN THE WRN ZNS TO REFLECT THESE TRENDS. 
REST OF FCST IN GREAT SHAPE. UPDATED GRIDS AND ZNS ALREADY OUT.

AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
258 PM CDT TUE SEP 21 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT
DRY WEATHER TO CONTINUE IN THE EARLY PART OF THE SHORT TERM. SLOW 
MOISTURE INCREASE ON WEDNESDAY WILL BRING SOME CLOUDS BY AFTERNOON. 
NEW GFS BRINGS WHAT APPEARS TO BE THE REMNANTS OF IVAN INTO ARKANSAS 
BY THURSDAY. NEWEST RUN APPEARS TO BE CONSIDERABLY OVERDONE ON 
MOISTURE. SO HAVE CONTINUED WITH SMALL POPS IN FOR THURSDAY NIGHT 
INTO FRIDAY. COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH BY FRIDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
CONTINUE THE SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FRIDAY...AS CONFIDENCE IS NOT REAL 
HIGH ON GFS MOISTURE. FRONT WILL MOVE THROUGH THE STATE...BUT 
RAINFALL WILL ALSO DEPEND ON LOW MOVING NORTH OUT OF THE GULF. AFTER 
UPPER TROUGH MOVES TO THE NORTHEAST...DRY CONDITIONS WILL AGAIN 
PREVAIL...WITH TEMPS NEAR NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    57  86  61  86 /   0   0  10  10

255 
FXUS64 KLZK 210736
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
238 AM CDT TUE SEP 21 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SINCE A FAIRLY DEEP TROUGH ACROSS THE ROCKIES AND A CORRESPONDING 
AMPLIFIED UPPER LEVEL RIDGE EXTENDS FROM MEXICO INTO THE GREAT LAKES 
REGION...EXPECT LITTLE CHANGE IN THE FAIR WEATHER PATTERN OVER 
ARKANSAS FOR THE NEXT FEW DAYS. THE ATMOSPHERE REMAINS QUITE DRY 
WITH DEWPOINTS IN THE 50S STATEWIDE. LATEST LZK SOUNDING REVEALS 
LITTLE OR NO MOISTURE ALL THE WAY UP TO BALLOON BURST. THE LATEST 
MODEL RUNS ARE NOW COMING MORE IN AGREEMENT WITH TIMING OF NEXT COLD 
FRONT WHICH WILL BE APPROACHING FROM THE NORTHWEST LATE THURSDAY. 
THE QPF AMOUNTS ARE STILL IN QUESTION...BUT AT THIS POINT WILL LEAN 
MORE TOWARDS THE LIGHT RAINFALL. WILL THEREFORE KEEP SMALL RAIN 
CHANCES WITH SMALL RAINFALL AMOUNTS LATE THURSDAY AND FRIDAY WITH 
THE COLD FRONT PASSAGE. BOTTOM LINE IS THAT A DRY SPELL WILL 
CONTINUE TODAY THROUGH AT LEAST THURSDAY WITH SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL 
AFTERNOON HIGHS AND SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL LOWS MAINLY DUE TO THE DRY 
AIRMASS.   
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    86  58  87  63 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       84  56  84  59 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    86  58  87  62 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     86  58  86  64 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  84  56  84  60 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     86  60  87  65 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         85  58  86  63 /   0   0   0   0


283 
FXUS64 KLZK 201953
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
253 PM CDT MON SEP 20 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT
HIGH PRESSURE CENTERED OVER THE NORTHEAST U.S. CONTINUES TO DOMINATE 
THE ARKANSAS WEATHER. CROSS SECTIONS SHOW VERY DRY AIR IN PLACE OVER 
THE AREA AND THIS WILL CONTINUE FOR A FEW MORE DAYS. MODELS ARE IN 
AGREEMENT WITH THE STAGNANT HIGH PRESSURE. THE ONLY CHANGE IN THE 
PATTERN WILL COME LATE THURSDAY AND INTO FRIDAY AS A COLD FRONT 
APPROACHES THE AREA. THE LATEST GFS RUN SHOWS EVEN LESS MOISTURE 
ASSOCIATED WITH THIS FRONT. HOWEVER...WILL CONTINUE THE SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS FOR SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FOR THURSDAY NIGHT INTO 
FRIDAY AT THIS TIME. NOT IMPRESSED WITH THE MOISTURE WITH THIS FRONT 
AND IF THE TREND CONTINUES MAY NEED TO ELIMINATE POPS IN FUTURE 
FORECASTS. HIGH PRESSURE THEN BUILDS IN BEHIND THE FRONT FOR ANOTHER 
SHOT OF DRY AIR. 

TEMPERATURES WILL BE SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL THROUGH THE PERIOD. A 
WARMING TREND SHOULD BEGIN LATE IN THE WEEK AHEAD OF THE COLD FRONT.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY
HIGH PRESSURE AND LOWER DEW POINTS WILL BUILD INTO THE AREA BEHIND 
THE COLD FRONT. THUS...DRY WEATHER WILL BE THE RULE. TEMPERATURES 
WILL BE A FEW DEGREES COOLER DURING THE PERIOD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    56  86  58  87 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       52  84  56  84 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    56  86  58  87 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     56  86  58  86 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  52  84  56  84 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     57  86  60  87 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         55  85  58  86 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      55  86  58  87 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   54  85  58  86 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&


990 
FXUS64 KLZK 191851
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
150 PM CDT SUN SEP 19 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT...
SHORT TERM MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH REGARDS TO THE SURFACE 
FEATURES BUT DIFFERENCES ARE NOTED IN THE UPPER PATTERN IN THE LATER 
PART OF THE PERIOD. ALL MODELS START OFF WITH THE TROF-RIDGE-TROF 
PATTERN ACROSS THE CONUS BUT DIVERGE AFTER ABOUT 48 HOURS. THE 
DIFFERENCES CONCERN THE WESTERN CONUS TROF. THE ETA SOLUTION BEGINS 
TO PINCH OFF AN UPPER LOW OVER THE GREAT BASIN WHILE THE GFS 
MAINTAINS AN OPEN TROF. WHILE BOTH MODELS ARE SLOWER WITH THE 
OVERALL SOLUTION...THE ETA IS CONSIDERABLY SLOWER. GFS LOOKS TO BE 
MORE IN LINE WITH THE OTHER MODELS AT THE END OF THE PERIOD AND IS 
THE PREFERRED SOLUTION THIS AFTERNOON.

HIGH PRESSURE ON BOTH THE SURFACE AND ALOFT WILL CONTINUE TO 
DOMINATE IN THE SHORT TERM. AIR MASS WILL BE QUITE DRY THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY WITH DEW POINTS ONLY PROGGED TO BE IN THE 50S. LITTLE 
MOISTURE IN PLACE WILL ALLOW GOOD RADIATIONAL COOLING AT NIGHT AND 
COMFORTABLY COOL MORNING LOWS. DAYTIME HIGHS WILL STILL AVERAGE A 
FEW DEGREES ABOVE NORMAL. WENT WITH A BLEND OF MAV/FWC NUMBERS THIS 
AFTERNOON. LOTS OF SUNSHINE IN STORE THROUGH WEDNESDAY AS WELL.

COME THURSDAY...THE HIGH BEGINS TO MOVE OFF TO THE EAST AND THE 
AFOREMENTIONED TROUGH BEGINS TO APPROACH. WINDS WILL SHIFT TO MORE 
OF A SOUTHERLY DIRECTION AND MOISTURE WILL BEGIN TO CREEP BACK UP 
INTO THE AREA. MEANWHILE...WAVE GETS CAUGHT UP IN THE CIRCULATION 
UNDER THE RIDGE AND TRAVELS ALONG THE GULF COAST. DEEP MOISTURE 
REMAINS JUST SOUTH OF THE AREA WITH THIS FEATURE BUT WILL GO WITH 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR THURSDAY NIGHT TO ACCOUNT FOR THE COLD FRONT 
ASSOCIATED WITH APPROACHING TROUGH. FRONT APPEARS TO MOISTURE 
STARVED AND WITH NO REAL FORCING SEEN ONLY 20 PERCENT POPS ARE 
JUSTIFIED.
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY
THE LATEST MODEL RUNS INDICATE THAT THE UPPER LEVEL RIDGE WILL BREAK 
DOWN SLOWLY BY 00Z SATURDAY...AND THUS ALLOWING A LOW OVER THE UPPER 
MID WEST TO PASS WELL TO THE NORTH. ON THE THE SURFACE...THE WEAK 
COLD FRONT WILL CROSS ARKANSAS ON FRIDAY...BRINGING A SLIGHT CHANCE 
OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FRIDAY. HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS BACK IN 
BEHIND THE FRONT. THE AIR BEHIND THE COLD FRONT WILL BE ONLY 
SLIGHTLY DRIER AND RELATIVELY COOLER. TEMPERATURES WILL TREND CLOSER 
TO NORMALS. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    55  86  56  86 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       53  85  53  84 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    55  87  56  86 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     55  86  56  86 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  52  82  52  84 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     55  87  57  86 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         53  83  55  85 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      55  87  55  86 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   54  85  54  85 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
150 PM CDT SUN SEP 19 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT...
SHORT TERM MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH REGARDS TO THE SURFACE 
FEATURES BUT DIFFERENCES ARE NOTED IN THE UPPER PATTERN IN THE LATER 
PART OF THE PERIOD. ALL MODELS START OFF WITH THE TROF-RIDGE-TROF 
PATTERN ACROSS THE CONUS BUT DIVERGE AFTER ABOUT 48 HOURS. THE 
DIFFERENCES CONCERN THE WESTERN CONUS TROF. THE ETA SOLUTION BEGINS 
TO PINCH OFF AN UPPER LOW OVER THE GREAT BASIN WHILE THE GFS 
MAINTAINS AN OPEN TROF. WHILE BOTH MODELS ARE SLOWER WITH THE 
OVERALL SOLUTION...THE ETA IS CONSIDERABLY SLOWER. GFS LOOKS TO BE 
MORE IN LINE WITH THE OTHER MODELS AT THE END OF THE PERIOD AND IS 
THE PREFERRED SOLUTION THIS AFTERNOON.

DOMINATE IN THE SHORT TERM. AIR MASS WILL BE QUITE DRY THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY WITH DEW POINTS ONLY PROGGED TO BE IN THE 50S. LITTLE 
MOISTURE IN PLACE WILL ALLOW GOOD RADIATIONAL COOLING AT NIGHT AND 
COMFORTABLY COOL MORNING LOWS. DAYTIME HIGHS WILL STILL AVERAGE A 
FEW DEGREES ABOVE NORMAL. WENT WITH A BLEND OF MAV/FWC NUMBERS THIS 
AFTERNOON. LOTS OF SUNSHINE IN STORE THROUGH WEDNESDAY AS WELL.

AFOREMENTIONED TROUGH BEGINS TO APPROACH. WINDS WILL SHIFT TO MORE 
OF A SOUTHERLY DIRECTION AND MOISTURE WILL BEGIN TO CREEP BACK UP 
INTO THE AREA. MEANWHILE...WAVE GETS CAUGHT UP IN THE CIRCULATION 
UNDER THE RIDGE AND TRAVELS ALONG THE GULF COAST. DEEP MOISTURE

492 
FXUS64 KLZK 191520
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1005 AM CDT SUN SEP 19 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATE ON THE WAY THIS MORNING. WEAK MID LEVEL DISTURBANCE THAT WAS 
OVER SOUTHERN MISSOURI LAST NIGHT NOW LOCATED IN NORTHEAST ARKANSAS. 
WITH ALL THE DRY AIR IN PLACE IT IS SURPRISING IT WAS ABLE TO 
HANG ON THROUGH THE NIGHT. REGARDLESS...ALL PROGS HAVE THIS FEATURE 
RAPIDLY DETERIORATING WITH TIME AND WILL MASSAGE THE GRIDS A BIT TO 
REMOVE ANY MENTION OF.

ONLY OTHER CHANGE WILL BE TO KNOCK OFF A FEW DEGREES OFF THE 
FORECASTED HIGHS FOR THIS AFTERNOON. DRIER AIR CONTINUES TO FILTER 
INTO THE AREA ON EAST TO NORTHEAST WINDS BUT TEMPERATURES ARE 
RUNNING A FEW DEGREES BEHIND THIS TIME YESTERDAY. IN ADDITION...12Z 
SOUNDING IS SHOWING TEMPERATURES IN THE LOW TO MID LEVELS ARE 
RUNNING ABOUT 3 DEGREES COOLER THAN YESTERDAY SO HIGHS ONLY IN THE 
MID TO UPPER 80S ARE SUPPORTED. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&



591 
FXUS64 KLZK 190850
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
350 AM CDT SUN SEP 19 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
SATELLITE IMAGERY INDICATES A SMALL SCALE MID LEVEL DISTURBANCE 
CENTERED BETWEEN WEST PLAINS AND BATESVILLE. THIS FEATURE WAS 
PROMOTED BY CONVECTION ACROSS PORTIONS OF MISSOURI ON SATURDAY.  
THIS FEATURE HAS MANAGED TO SUPPORT A SMALL...BUT PERSISTENT AREA OF 
LIGHT SHOWERS...AS HIGHLIGHTED BY 8 BIT RADAR DATA. LATEST RUNS OF 
THE RUC AND ETA HOLD ONTO THE IDENTITY OF THIS MESOSCALE FEATURE 
THROUGH 00Z/20...AS IT MOVES SOUTH-SOUTHEAST. WOULD EXPECT THE 
LIMITED AVAILABLE MOISTURE TO PREVENT ANY MORE THAN ISOLATED 
CONVECTION THROUGH 00Z.    
 
OTHERWISE DRY CONDITIONS WILL PREVAIL DURING THE REST OF THE SHORT 
TERM PERIODS. A SMALL COOLING TREND IS EXPECTED...AS THE FOCUS OF 
THE MID LEVEL RIDGE MOVES TO THE OHIO VALLEY REGION.
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
UPPER RIDGE DOES BREAK DOWN SLOWLY BY 00Z SATURDAY...ALLOWING LOW 
OVER THE UPPER MID WEST TO BEGIN PHASING WITH LOW MOVING NORTH OUT 
OF THE TROPICS OVER THE ATLANTIC. THE SURFACE PATTERN WILL SEE 
CONVERGING OVER ARKANSAS FROM THE SOUTHEAST AND THE NORTHWEST. THE 
SOUTHEAST SYSTEM WILL BE COMING AROUND THE BACK SIDE OF THE HIGH. A 
SLIM AREA OF MOISTURE WILL MOVE SOUTHEAST ACROSS THE STATE 
ACCOMPANYING A WEAK COLD FRONT THAT WILL CROSS ARKANSAS FRIDAY. THE 
AIR BEHIND THE COLD FRONT WILL BE ONLY SLIGHTLY DRIER. TEMPERATURES 
WILL BE CLOSE TO NORMALS.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    90  57  88  57 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       89  55  87  54 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    91  57  89  57 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     90  57  88  57 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  86  54  84  53 /  10   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     91  57  89  58 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         87  55  85  56 /  10  10   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      91  57  89  56 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   89  56  87  55 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

55/32






681 
FXUS64 KLZK 181904
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
201 PM CDT SAT SEP 18 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT...
ETA SOLUTION HAS COME INTO BETTER AGREEMENT WITH THE OTHER SHORT 
TERM MODELS AND NOW ALL ARE PRETTY MUCH ON THE SAME PAGE. GFS HAS 
BEEN THE MOST CONSISTENT MODEL AND SEE NOW REASON TO VEER FROM IT 
ESPECIALLY SINCE THE OTHER MODELS ARE IN AGREEMENT WITH IT. THAT 
BEING SAID...WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS THIS AFTERNOON WITH 
A LEAN TOWARDS THE GFS.

ELEVATED CONVECTION OVER SOUTHERN MISSOURI ALL BUT DONE AS MAIN 
SHORTWAVE MOVING OFF TO THE EAST. A FEW STORMS APPROACHED THE 
NORTHERN BORDER OF THE STATE BUT MOVED INTO A VERY DRY AND STABLE 
AIRMASS AND RAPIDLY FELL APART. IN FACT...SOME DEBRIS CLOUDS FROM 
THE CONVECTION WORKED INTO THE NORTH BUT DRIED UP QUICKLY AS SEEN ON 
THE SATELLITE IMAGERY. HIGH LEVEL CLOUDS ARE STILL POSSIBLE THIS 
EVENING OVER THE NORTH FROM ANY LEFT OVER CONVECTION BUT REMAINDER 
OF THE CWA WILL BE CLEAR. 

HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES TO BUILD INTO THE AREA WITH PLENTY OF DRY 
AIR ADVECTING IN ON NORTHEAST WINDS. DEW POINT TEMPERATURES ARE ONLY 
IN THE MID 40S TO MID 50S ACROSS THE CWA. DRY AND STABLE AIRMASS 
SHOULD REMAIN IN PLACE THROUGH THE MAJORITY OF THE PERIOD AS SURFACE 
RIDGE WILL DOMINATE. MAINLY CLEAR SKIES AND DRY AIR WILL ALLOW A 
DIURNAL TEMPERATURE RANGE OF NEAR 30 DEGREES. OVERNIGHT LOWS WILL BE 
COMFORTABLY COOL WITH DAYTIME HIGHS WARMING TO A FEW DEGREES ABOVE 
SEASONAL NORMS.

UPPER PATTERN HIGHLY AMPLIFIED TO BEGIN THE PERIOD. LARGE MID LEVEL 
RIDGE OVER THE NATIONS MID SECTION IN ANCHORED BY TROUGHS ON BOTH 
COASTS. REMNANTS OF IVAN GET CAUGHT UP IN THE CLOCKWISE FLOW AROUND 
THE RIDGE AND ARE USHERED OUT TO SEA. LARGE TROF OVER THE WESTERN 
CONUS TRIES TO MOVE EASTWARD BUT MAKES ONLY SLOW PROGRESS AS IT 
RUNS INTO THE STRONG RIDGE. TROUGH SHEARS OUT BY THE END OF THE DAY 
THREE WITH AN UPPER LEVEL LOW SPINNING UP OVER THE FOUR CORNERS. LOW 
LIFTS TO THE NORTHEAST AND ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT WILL ONLY MAKE IT 
INTO THE CENTRAL PLAINS BY THE END OF THE PERIOD.

MODELS NOT NEARLY AS AGGRESSIVE WITH ALMOST NO MOISTURE RETURNING TO 
THE AREA THROUGH OUT THE PERIOD. EVEN CLOUDS WILL BE AT A PREMIUM 
THE MAJORITY OF THE PERIOD. RETURN FLOW STARTS TO GET REESTABLISHED 
LATE WEDNESDAY BUT EBEN THEN MOISTURE RETURN WILL BE LIMITED AS DEW 
POINTS ONLY BEGIN TO CREEP BACK UP. 
&&

LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY...
VERY DRY AIR UNDERNEATH AN UPPER RIDGE WILL CONTINUE ACROSS ARKANSAS 
THROUGH THURSDAY. MODELS CONTINUE TO SLOW DOWN THE COLD FRONT IN THE 
PLAINS. DOES NOT LOOK LIKE THE FRONT WILL MAKE IT INTO NORTHWEST 
ARKANSAS UNTIL FRIDAY MORNING. THEREFORE...WILL REMOVE ALL POPS 
UNTIL FRIDAY MORNING. WILL KEEP POPS ACROSS THE AREA FOR FRIDAY THEN 
TAPER OFF IN THE EVENING. THE AREA OF LOW PRESSURE ASSOCIATED WITH 
THE COLD FRONT WILL MOVE NORTHEAST INTO THE GREAT LAKES. DRIER AIR 
WILL FILTER INTO THE CWFA FRIDAY NIGHT AND SATURDAY AND ELIMINATE 
RAIN CHANCES FOR SATURDAY. WILL NOT EXPECT A BIG COOL DOWN WITH THE 
PASSAGE OF THE COLD FRONT. TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN NEAR NORMAL. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    58  88  58  87 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       55  88  55  86 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    58  90  58  88 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     58  89  58  87 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  54  85  54  85 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     59  90  58  87 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         55  86  55  86 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      57  90  57  88 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   56  88  56  87 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56/51






647 
FXUS64 KLZK 181547
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1045 AM CDT SAT SEP 18 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS IN FINE SHAPE BUT SOME CHANGES WILL BE NEEDED 
TO MAKE THE GRIDS REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS. ELEVATED CONVECTION 
CONTINUES ACROSS CENTRAL MISSOURI. PRECIP UP THERE SEEMS TO BE ON 
THE WANE AS CLOUD TOPS WARM AND LOW LEVEL JET WEAKENS BUT IT IS 
STILL SLOW SINKING TOWARDS THE SOUTH. AIRMASS OVER THE CWA IS VERY 
DRY AND STABLE AND ACTIVITY WOULD HAVE A HARD TIME GETTING IN HERE. 
SOME DEBRIS CLOUDS FROM THE CONVECTION HAVE WORKED INTO THE NORTH 
BUT ARE DRYING UP AS SEEN ON THE SATELLITE IMAGERY. HIGH LEVEL 
CLOUDS OVER THE NORTH STILL POSSIBLE BUT CURRENT FORECAST/GRIDS HAVE 
THIS HANDLED. AIRMASS WILL HEAT RAPIDLY THIS MORNING AND FORECASTED 
HIGHS LOOKS GOOD.

ONLY CHANGES WILL BE TO LOWER DEW POINTS. OBSERVED CONDITIONS HAVE 
BEEN RUNNING ABOUT 5 TO 7 DEGREES BELOW WHAT IS IN THE FORECAST 
GRIDS. WITH MODELS SHOWING AIRMASS DRYING OUT MORE WITH TIME WILL 
NEED TO ADJUST. CONSEQUENT LOWERING OF DEW POINTS WILL CHANGE 
HUMIDITY...HEAT INDEX AND GRAPHICAL FORECASTS AS WELL. FIRE WEATHER 
FORECAST WILL ALSO HAVE TO ADDRESSED.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
IR SATELLITE IMAGERY AND LOCAL RADARS CONTINUE TO INDICATE THE 
DEVELOPMENT OF CONVECTION ACROSS NORTHWEST MISSOURI. HIGH CLOUDS 
ASSOCIATED WITH THIS CONVECTION WILL AFFECT NORTHERN PORTIONS OF THE 
CWA THIS MORNING. 

ANIMATED IMAGERY FROM THE WATER VAPOR CHANNEL CLEARLY REVEALS THE 
DEVELOPMENT OF AN AMPLIFIED PATTERN ACROSS NORTH AMERICA. UPPER 
RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL PLAINS WILL SPREAD NORTHEAST 
THROUGH THIS PERIOD. SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE WILL REMAIN DOMINANT OVER 
THE STATE DURING THE SHORT TERM.  OVERALL CONDITIONS WILL REMAIN 
DRY...WITH A SLIGHT COOLING TREND. 55

MODELS ARE NOT AS AGGRESSIVE WITH THE RETURN OF UPPER LOW FROM THE 
EAST AROUND THE STRONG RIDGE. THIS WILL KEEP THE DRIER/COOLER AIR 
OVER THE STATE A BIT LONGER BEFORE MOISTURE RETURNS ON THE BACK SIDE 
OF THE HIGH. THE SURFACE HIGH GAINS STRENGTH AS THE UPPER RIDGE 
AMPLIFIES. THIS WILL KEEP MOISTURE FARTHER SOUTH...ALONG THE GULF 
COAST. LOW ALOFT OVER THE INTER MOUNTAIN REGION MOVES EAST AND LIFTS 
AS IT GETS CAUGHT UP IN THE WESTERLIES. THERE SEEMS TO BE TOO MUCH 
BREAKING DOWN OF THE RIDGE OVER THE EASTERN PART OF THE COUNTRY 
SINCE THE LOW IS LIFTING. THE FORECAST WILL HOLD OFF ON THE RAIN FOR 
WEDNESDAY...WHILE KEEPING SMALL POPS FOR WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH 
FRIDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL HAVE A WIDE DIURNAL RANGE AS LONG AS THE 
DRY AIR STAYS IN PLACE. A SMALLER DIURNAL SPREAD WILL RETURN AS 
MOISTURE INCREASES AT THE LOWER LEVELS. HIGHS WILL BE IN THE 80S AND 
LOWS WILL BE MAINLY IN THE 60S...WITH A FEW 50S POSSIBLE IN THE 
NORTH. 32

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    93  60  90  60 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       90  57  90  57 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    93  60  92  60 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     92  60  91  60 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  90  56  87  56 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     92  61  92  60 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         91  57  88  57 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      93  59  92  59 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   91  58  90  58 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&


000 
FXUS64 KLZK 181547
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1045 AM CDT SAT SEP 18 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS IN FINE SHAPE BUT SOME CHANGES WILL BE NEEDED 
TO MAKE THE GRIDS REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS. ELEVATED CONVECTION 
CONTINUES ACROSS CENTRAL MISSOURI. PRECIP UP THERE SEEMS TO BE ON 
THE WANE AS CLOUD TOPS WARM AND LOW LEVEL JET WEAKENS BUT IT IS 
STILL SLOW SINKING TOWARDS THE SOUTH. AIRMASS OVER THE CWA IS VERY 
DRY AND STABLE AND ACTIVITY WOULD HAVE A HARD TIME GETTING IN HERE. 
SOME DEBRIS CLOUDS FROM THE CONVECTION HAVE WORKED INTO THE NORTH 
BUT ARE DRYING UP AS SEEN ON THE SATELLITE IMAGERY. HIGH LEVEL 
CLOUDS OVER THE NORTH STILL POSSIBLE BUT CURRENT FORECAST/GRIDS HAVE 
THIS HANDLED. AIRMASS WILL HEAT RAPIDLY THIS MORNING AND FORECASTED 
HIGHS LOOKS GOOD.

ONLY CHANGES WILL BE TO LOWER DEW POINTS. OBSERVED CONDITIONS HAVE 
BEEN RUNNING ABOUT 5 TO 7 DEGREES BELOW WHAT IS IN THE FORECAST 
GRIDS. WITH MODELS SHOWING AIRMASS DRYING OUT MORE WITH TIME WILL 
NEED TO ADJUST. CONSEQUENT LOWERING OF DEW POINTS WILL CHANGE 
HUMIDITY...HEAT INDEX AND GRAPHICAL FORECASTS AS WELL. FIRE WEATHER 
FORECAST WILL ALSO HAVE TO ADDRESSED.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
IR SATELLITE IMAGERY AND LOCAL RADARS CONTINUE TO INDICATE THE 
DEVELOPMENT OF CONVECTION ACROSS NORTHWEST MISSOURI. HIGH CLOUDS 
ASSOCIATED WITH THIS CONVECTION WILL AFFECT NORTHERN PORTIONS OF THE 
CWA THIS MORNING. 

ANIMATED IMAGERY FROM THE WATER VAPOR CHANNEL CLEARLY REVEALS THE 
DEVELOPMENT OF AN AMPLIFIED PATTERN ACROSS NORTH AMERICA. UPPER 
RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL PLAINS WILL SPREAD NORTHEAST

OF THE HIGH. THE SURFACE HIGH GAINS STRENGTH AS THE UPPER RIDGE 
AMPLIFIES. THIS WILL KEEP MOISTURE FARTHER SOUTH...ALONG THE GULF 
COAST. LOW ALOFT OVER THE INTER MOUNTAIN REGION MOVES EAST AND LIFTS 
AS IT GETS CAUGHT UP IN THE WESTERLIES. THERE SEEMS TO BE TOO MUCH 
BREAKING DOWN OF THE RIDGE OVER THE EASTERN PART OF THE COUNTRY 
SINCE THE LOW IS LIFTING. THE FORECAST WILL HOLD OFF ON THE RAIN FOR 
WEDNESDAY...WHILE KEEPING SMALL POPS FOR WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH

FXUS64 KLZK 180300 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1000 PM CDT FRI SEP 17 2004

.DISCUSSION...
HAD A FEW SHRA FORM OVER THE HIGHER TERRAIN OF W-CNTRL AR LATE IN 
THE DAY...BUT THE ACTIVITY DIED ARND SUNSET. LOOKING AT ABOUT A 20 
TO 25 DEGREE DEWPOINT SPREAD FROM NE TO SW ACRS AR THIS EVENING...
WITH NEAR 50 OVER NERN AR AND LOWER 70S SW. REWORKED HOURLY GRIDDED 
TEMPS TO REFLECT THESE TRENDS. ALSO ADJUSTED MIN TEMPS TNGT UP A FEW 
DEGREES OVER THE WRN COUNTIES.

ONGOING CONVECTION OVER NRN MO ASSOCD WITH WAA. EXPECT THIS ACTIVITY 
TO RMN N OF AR THRU TNGT. COULD SEE SOME CLOUD DEBRIS WORK SWD INTO 
NRN AR LATER TNGT.

LOOKS LIKE WE WILL SEE HIGHS ON SAT CLOSE TO TODAYS READINGS. WENT 
AHEAD AND RAISED MAXES ON SAT A FEW DEGREES ACRS THE BOARD. UPDATED 
ZNS AND GRIDS ALREADY SENT.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

44





070 
FXUS64 KLZK 171923
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
221 PM CDT FRI SEP 17 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT...
MODELS IN VERY GOOD AGREEMENT IN THE SHORT TERM WITH ONLY MINOR 
DIFFERENCES OF NOTE. LARGEST DIFFERENCE IS THE PLACEMENT OF WHATS 
LEFT OF IVAN AFTER H48. ETA SOLUTION KEEPS A CLOSED LOW OFF CAPE 
HATTERAS WHILE THE GFS IS MORE OF AN OPEN WAVE NEAR CAPE FEAR. WHILE 
BOTH MODELS HAVE MOVED THE CENTER FURTHER SOUTH VERSUS PREVIOUS 
RUNS...THE ETA HAS MOVED IT CONSIDERABLY FURTHER SOUTH VERSUS ITS 
EARLIER POSITION. THAT BEING SAID...WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF 
SOLUTIONS THROUGH H48 THEN LEAN MORE TOWARDS THE MORE CONSISTENT GFS 
AFTER THAT POINT.

LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES SURFACE BOUNDARY RIGHT ALONG THE 
LOUISIANA/ARKANSAS BORDER WITH HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING INTO THE MID 
SOUTH. REMNANTS OF IVAN STRADDLING THE VIRGINIA/NC BORDER WITH 
DRIER AIR AND WIDESPREAD SUBSIDENCE IN PLACE OVER THE MID SOUTH. 
EVEN CU ARE HAVING A HARD TIME GOING UP IN THIS ENVIRONMENT. DEW 
POINTS HAVE DROPPED INTO THE MID 50S ACROSS THE NORTH. ALL MODELS 
SGENERALLY PROGGED TO BE IN THE 50S. LITTLE MOISTURE IN PLACE WILL 
ALLOW GOOD RADIATIONAL COOLING AT NIGHT AND COMFORTABLY COOL MORNING 
LOWS. DAYTIME HIGHS WILL STILL AVERAGE A FEW DEGREES ABOVE NORMAL. 
WENT WITH A BLEND OF MAV/FWC NUMBERS THIS AFTERNOON. LOTS OF 
SUNSHINE IN STORE THROUGHTUESDAY AS WELL.

MODELS ALL ADVERTISING THE UPPER PATTERN BEING PROGRESSIVE AND 
BECOMING HIGHLY AMPLIFIED. MASSIVE HEIGHT FALLS ALONG THE WEST COAST 
RESULT IN A VERY DEEP TROUGH BEING CARVED OUT. A LARGE RIDGE PUMPS 
UP IN RESPONSE OVER THE NATIONS MID SECTION BY LATE SATURDAY WITH 
MORE TROUGHING OVER THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE COUNTRY. REMNANTS OF 
IVAN PROGGED TO GET CAUGHT UP IN THE CLOCKWISE FLOW AROUND THE RIDGE 
AND START TO MOVE SOUTHWARD ALONG THE EAST COAST. PREVIOUS RUNS TOOK 
WHATS LEFT OF THE CENTER OF CIRCULATION OVER ARKANSAS WITH LATEST 
MODELS NOW HAVING IT OFF EAST COAST OF FLORIDA BY MONDAY MORNING. 
SYSTEM WILL BE WEAKENING THROUGHOUT THIS TIME FRAME. WHERE IS ENDS 
UP HERE IS TRICKY AS SOME MODELS HAVE IT INTERACTING WITH JEANNE 
WITH OTHER ARE DRIVING A SLUG OF MOISTURE TOWARDS THE CWA TOWARDS 
THE MIDDLE PART OF NEXT WEEK.

REGARDLESS...THE SURFACE RIDGE STRENGTHENS OVER CWA DURING THE  
WEEKEND AND WILL HOLD STRONG THROUGH THE ENTIRE PERIOD. ALL MENTION 
OF PRECIPITATION HAS BEEN REMOVED THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT. MEANWHILE
THE AFOREMENTIONED TROUGH CROSSES THE INTERMOUNTAIN WEST AND SHEARS 
OUT A BIT AS IT RUNS INTO THE RIDGE WHICH HAS NOW SHIFTED TO THE 
EASTERN CONUS. ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT ONLY GETS AS FAR AS SOUTHEAST 
KANSAS BY WEDNESDAY MORNING BUT IT LOOKS LIKE RETURN FLOW DOES NOT 
GET REESTABLISHED UNTIL VERY LATE IN THE PERIOD.  
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY...
THE DEEP TROUGH OVER THE WESTERN U.S. BEGINS TO SHIFT NORTHEAST BY 
WEDNESDAY. THE LARGE UPPER RIDGE OVER THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN U.S. 
BEGINS MOVING EAST ON WEDNESDAY. GFS SEEMS TO HAVE A GOOD HANDLE ON 
THE EXTENDED. A COLD FRONT APPROACHES FROM THE NORTHWEST ON 
WEDNESDAY AND WILL STALL OVER ARKANSAS ON THURSDAY. MOISTURE WILL 
FEED BACK INTO THE MID SOUTH UNDERNEATH THE STRONG UPPER LEVEL HIGH 
PRESSURE. THEREFORE...WILL BRING IN A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON JUST AHEAD OF THE FRONT AND ON 
THURSDAY ALONG THE FRONT. WILL TAPER THE POPS DOWN ON FRIDAY AS 
ZONAL FLOW RETURNS WITH DRIER AIR AND SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS 
IN. TEMPERATURES WILL BE NEAR NORMAL THROUGH THE EXTENDED WITH 
HUMIDITY LEVELS RATHER LOW.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    59  88  60  88 /  10  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       56  84  57  85 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    59  88  60  90 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     60  89  60  89 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  57  84  56  85 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     62  89  62  90 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         58  87  59  86 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      59  88  59  90 /  10  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   57  87  58  88 /  10  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS RIGHT ON TARGET AND NO CHANGES ARE REQUIRED 
THIS MORNING. LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACE SURFACE BOUNDARY RIGHT 
ALONG THE LOUISIANA/ARKANSAS BORDER WITH HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING INTO 
THE MID SOUTH. REMNANTS OF IVAN CONTINUE TO MOVE ALONG THE SPINE OF 
THE APPALACHIANS WITH DRIER AIR AND WIDESPREAD SUBSIDENCE IN PLACE. 
DEW POINTS HAVE DROPPED INTO THE MID 50S ACROSS THE NORTH AND AIR 
MASS SHOULD CONTINUE TO DRY OUT THIS AFTERNOON. TEMPERATURES SHOULD 
HAVE NO PROBLEMS REACHING FORECASTED HIGHS. CONVECTION ACROSS 
EASTERN KANSAS MAY SPREAD SOME CIRRUS BLOW OFF OVER THE NORTH LATER 
BUT WILL TAKE A WAIT AND SEE APPROACH HERE. REMNANTS OF IVAN WILL 
COME BACK INTO PLAY NEXT BUT A VERY PLEASANT AFTERNOON IS ON TAP FOR 
THE CWA.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
INTERESTING SITUATION WITH THE UPPER LEVEL FLOW AS THE TROPICAL 
SYSTEM MOVES EAST. RIDGE BEGINS TO BUILD FROM THE SOUTHWEST TOWARD 
THE GREAT LAKES AS TROF DEEPENS IN THE NORTHWEST AND THE LOW MOVES 
TO THE MID ATLANTIC COAST BY SATURDAY AFTERNOON. THEN...THE LOW 
PLUNGES SOUTH ALONG THE EAST COAST BY 00Z MONDAY. THAT IS WHEN IT 
BEGINS TO REGRESS TOWARD ARKANSAS...KNOCKING ON OUR DOORS FROM THE 
EAST BY 00Z TUESDAY. IN THE MEANTIME...THE SURFACE DRIES OUT AS 
RIDGE BUILDS SOUTH FROM THE GREAT LAKES. THE STRENGTH OF THE RIDGE 
PUSHES TROPICAL MOISTURE BACK TOWARD ARKANSAS WHILE THE RIDGE 
ORIENTS ITSELF MORE FROM NORTHEAST TO SOUTHWEST. IN ESSENCE...THE 
FORECAST WILL BE A DRY ONE IN THE SHORT TERM...WITH THE POSSIBILITY 
OF RAIN RETURNING IN THE LONG RANGE. MAXIMUM TEMPERATURES WILL 
REMAIN IN THE UPPER 80S TO LOWER 90S IN LIGHT OF THE DRY AIR THAT 
WILL PREVAIL UNDER THE STRONG RIDGE. MIN TEMPERATURES WILL BE THE 
MAIN BENEFICIARIES OF THE RIDGE SINCE THE DRY AIR WILL RADIATE 
BETTER OVERNIGHT. LOWS WILL BE RATHER PLEASANT IN THE UPPER 50S TO 
LOWER 60S.

LATEST GFS INDICATING THAT THE REMNANTS OF IVAN WILL BEGIN TO 
RETROGRADE SOUTHWESTWARD EARLY NEXT WEEK AS HIGH PRESSURE RIDGES 
SOUTHWESTWARD FROM THE GREAT LAKES. MOISTURE IS BROUGHT BACK INTO 
ARKANSAS STARTING MONDAY NIGHT AND CONTINUING TUESDAY. HAVE 
INTRODUCED SMALL POPS LATE MONDAY NIGHT AND THROUGH THE DAY ON 
TUESDAY. MAINLY DRY CONDITIONS EXPECTED ON WEDNESDAY...BUT NEW COLD 
FRONT WILL BRING SMALL CHANCES OF RAINFALL AGAIN ON THURSDAY. 
TEMPERATURES WILL BE NEAR OR A LITTLE ABOVE NORMAL. &&
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

950 PM CDT THU SEP 16 2004

.DISCUSSION...
REMAINS OF IVAN CONT TO TRACK SLOLY INTO NERN AL THIS EVENING. PRES 
GRADIENT HAS RELAXED ACRS AR THIS EVENING. CONVECTION OVER THE FA 
THIS AFTN AND EARLY EVENING HAS DISSIPATED. FNTL BNDRY ASSOCD WITH 
ACTIVITY IS BECOMING LESS DEFINED. EXPECT BNDRY TO BE ABSORBED BY 
FLOW ARND IVAN INTO FRI.

HAVE GONE AHEAD AND PULLED POPS FOR THE REST OF TNGT. EXPECT MOSTLY 
CLR SKIES OVER MUCH OF THE AREA. TWEAKED MIN TEMPS A FEW DEGREES 
BASED ON LATEST TRENDS. HOURLY GRIDS HAVE BEEN ADJUSTED AS WELL TO 
REFLECT CURRENT CONDS. NO OTHER CHGS TO GOING FCST. UPDATED GRIDS 
AND ZNS ALREADY GONE.


405 
FXUS64 KLZK 161951
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
248 PM CDT THU SEP 16 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
A FEW SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS DEVELOPED ACROSS THE WESTERN FRINGES 
OF THE CWFA THIS AFTERNOON AS NOTED ON KLZK RADAR. SATELLITE IMAGES 
CONTINUE TO SHOW TROPICAL STORM IVAN MOVING NORTH THROUGH ALABAMA 
WITH ASSOCIATED CLOUD COVER EXTENDING INTO EASTERN ARKANSAS. THE 
COLD FRONT IS NOW LOCATED NEAR THE MISSOURI BORDER AND EXTENDS 
THROUGH EASTERN OKLAHOMA. THE FRONT HAS MOVED VERY LITTLE TODAY. 
WILL EXPECT SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS MAINLY NEAR THE FRONT THROUGH 
EARLY THIS EVENING THEN DISSIPATE. WINDS IN THE SOUTHEAST WILL 
DISSIPATE THROUGH THE EVENING AS IVAN CONTINUES TO PULL AWAY. 
THEREFORE HAVE CANCELLED THE LAKE WIND ADVISORY THAT WAS IN EFFECT 
FOR THIS EVENING. 

MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THE MOVEMENT OF AN UPPER RIDGE OF 
HIGH PRESSURE. THIS HIGH WILL BUILD INTO ARKANSAS ON FRIDAY AND 
STRENGTHEN THROUGH THE WEEKEND AND WASH OUT THE COLD FRONT. CROSS 
SECTIONS SHOW VERY DRY AIR MOVING INTO THE AREA FRIDAY MORNING. THIS 
WILL KEEP PRECIP FROM DEVELOPING THROUGH THE WEEKEND AND INTO EARLY 
NEXT WEEK. AFTER THIS EVENING...WILL KEEP A DRY FORECAST THROUGH 
MONDAY NIGHT. TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN NEAR TO SLIGHTLY ABOVE 
NORMAL. 
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
MODELS CONTINUE TO BE ON THE SAME PAGE THIS AFTERNOON WITH THE 
OVERALL EVOLUTION OF THE PATTERN. THERE ARE SOME TIMING AND STRENGTH 
DIFFERENCES IN THE MODELS BUT OVERALL THERE IS GOOD AGREEMENT AND 
CONTINUITY BETWEEN THEM. THAT BEING SAID...FEEL A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS 
IS WARRANTED. OVERALL DRY PATTERN LOOKS TO CONTINUE THROUGH THE 
PERIOD.

PERIOD BEGINS WITH A HIGHLY AMPLIFIED PATTERN OF DEEP TROUGHING OVER 
THE ROCKIES AND STRONG RIDGING OVER THE EASTERN HALF OF THE NATION. 
GFS MODEL HAS BEEN NOTORIOUS WITH KEEPING REMNANTS OF IVAN TRAPPED 
UNDER THE RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS AND NOW IT APPEARS IT 
MAY HAVE BEEN RIGHT ALL ALONG. REMNANTS JUST SORT OF WOBBLE AROUND 
THE SOUTHEAST CONUS FOR A WHILE BEFORE WHATS LEFT DISSIPATES WITH NO 
REAL IMPACT ON OUR SENSIBLE WEATHER. TROF THEN BEGINS TO SHEAR OUT 
WITH AN UPPER LEVEL LOW CUTTING OFF OVER THE FOUR CORNERS AND RACES 
OFF TO THE NORTHEAST.

RETURN FLOW WILL RETURN WITH A SUBSEQUENT INCREASE IN MOISTURE. 
LATEST RUNS SLOWING UP ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT EVEN MORE AND FEATURE 
NOW NOT EXPECTED TO APPROACH THE AREA UNTIL LATE WEDNESDAY AS IT 
RUNS INTO THE AFOREMENTIONED RIDGE AND SLOWS DOWN. MOISTURE DOES NOT 
APPEAR TO BE PLENTIFUL ENOUGH TO JUSTIFY MORE THAN SLIGHT CHANCE 
POPS AT THIS TIME BUT I WILL PUSH THEM BACK TO DAY SEVEN.

TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO RUN A FEW DEGREES ABOVE SEASONABLE 
WITH THE RIDGE DOMINATING. CURRENT MEX GUIDANCE SUPPORTS THIS 
SCENARIO AND IS GENERALLY ACCEPTED. DEW POINT TEMPS STILL PROGGED TO 
BE IN THE UPPER 50S TO LOWER 60S SO OVERALL HUMIDITY LEVELS WILL NOT 
BE TERRIBLE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    68  90  61  88 /  10   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       60  85  57  86 /  20   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    69  90  61  89 /  10   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     69  90  62  89 /  10   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  56  85  58  86 /  10   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     70  90  64  90 /  10   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         67  88  60  88 /  10   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      69  89  61  89 /  20   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   66  88  59  88 /  20   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

1034 AM CDT THU SEP 16 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SATELLITE IMAGES SHOW HURRICANE IVAN CONTINUING TO MOVE NORTH 
THROUGH THE SOUTHEAST U.S. AND THUNDERSTRMS DEVELOPING ACROSS 
NORTHEAST OKLAHOMA. CENTRAL ARKANSAS IS EXPERIENCING SUBSIDENCE ON 
THE BACK SIDE OF IVAN AND THIS IS KEEPING SKIES MOSTLY CLEAR IN THE 
CENTRAL ARKANSAS AREA. THE COLD FRONT STRETCHES FROM SOUTHERN 
MISSOURI THROUGH OKLAHOMA. WILL KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS IN FOR THE CWFA THIS AFTERNOON. WITH IVAN MOVING NORTH 
WILL ALSO KEEP THE LAKE WIND ADVISORY FOR THE EASTERN PORTIONS OF 
THE CWFA THROUGH MIDNIGHT. NORTHEAST WINDS WILL INCREASE THIS 
AFTERNOON.

MIDNIGHT PARTS OF EAST ARZ047...ARZ056>057...ARZ063>065... 
ARZ068>069.



840 
FXUS64 KLZK 160856
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT THU SEP 16 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY
HURRICANE IVAN MADE LANDFALL IN THE VICINITY OF GULF SHORES AL ABOUT
0645Z BY SATELLITE IMAGES AND IS MOVING INLAND. MAIN INFLUENCE IS 
STAYING TO THE EAST OF THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BUT THE OVERALL CIRCULATION
AROUND IVAN SHOULD COVER ARKANSAS TODAY AND PRODUCE NORTHEAST WINDS.
A COLD FRONT IS MOVING TOWARD THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF ARKANSAS THIS
MORNING AND IT WILL LIKELY BE ABSORBED INTO THE BROAD CIRCULATION 
AROUND IVAN AS THE DAY PROGRESSES. THERE IS NOT A LOT OF COOLING OR
DRYING WITH THIS FRONT ANYMORE SO THERE LIKELY WILL NOT BE MUCH 
EFFECT ON TEMPS AND DEW POINTS. SOME THUNDERSTORMS HAVE CONTINUED ALONG
AND BEHIND THE FRONT DURING THE NIGHT AND THIS BAND OF MOISTURE IS 
PROGEED TO MOVE INTO ARKANSAS THIS MORNING. WILL KEEP A SLIGHT 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS GOING ACROSS THE AREA TODAY 
DUE TO THESE THUNDERSTORMS. THE INTERACTION OF THIS WITH THE 
CIRCULATION AND SUBSIDENCE AROUND IVAN WILL LIKELY SUPRESS THIS
THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY LATER TODAY. WILL LOWER POPS IN THE NORTHWEST
LATER TODAY AND DROP MENTION OF RAIN AFTER THE TODAY PERIOD. THE WINDS
AROUND IVAN ALONG WITH THE HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN FROM THE PLAINS
WILL RESULT IN GUSTY NORTHEAST WINDS WITH THE HIGHEST WINDS IN THE 
SOUTHEAST. THE TIGHTEST GRADIENT LOOKS LIKE IT WILL STAY TO THE EAST
OF THE AREA...BUT COULD SEE WINDS REACH LAKE WIND CRITERIA IN PARTS
OF THE EAST AND SOUTHEAST. ALSO LOOKS LIKE WINDS WILL DIMINISH WITH
LOSS OF HEATING AND DAYLIGHT...SO LAKE WIND ADVISORY CONDITIONS WILL
LIKELY END BY EARLY TONIGHT. CUT DOWN LAKE WIND ADVISORY TO INCLUDE
SEVERAL EASTERN AND SOUTHEASTERN COUNTIES AND ENDED ADVISORY AT 
MIDNIGHT...WHICH MAY STILL BE TOO LONG. AFTER ALL THIS...UPPER RIDGING
WILL BUILD INTO THE AREA WITH A SURFACE RIDGE EXTENDING INTO 
ARKANSAS FROM THE NORTHEAST. THIS SHOULD RESULT IN MOSTLY CLEAR TO
PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES WITH LIGHT NORTHEAST WINDS FROM FRIDAY THROUGH 
SUNDAY. FIGURE ON CLOUDS...WINDS AND THE DECAYING FRONTAL SYSTEM 
WILL TAKE A COUPLE OF DEGREES OFF MAXES TODAY COMPARED TO YESTERDAY. 
AFTER THAT...PATTERN SHOULD FAVOR MINS CLOSE TO NORMAL AND MAXES A 
LITTLE ABOVE NORMAL.   
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
THE UPPER LEVEL PATTERN SHOWS ALMOST NO FEATURES AFFECTING THE STATE 
FROM SUNDAY NIGHT UNTIL TUESDAY MORNING WHEN A WEAK LOW...POSSIBLY THE
OLD REMNANTS OF IVAN...APPROACHES ARKANSAS FROM THE EAST. THE LOW 
LINGERS IN PLACE AND THEN FILLS GRADUALLY. THE SURFACE PATTERN SHOWS 
DRY AIR OVER THE STATE SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING. 
THEN...SOME MOISTURE RETURNS TO THE STATE FROM THE EAST. DRY THROUGH 
TUESDAY MORNING...WITH MOISTURE INCREASING...BUT NOT ENOUGH TO 
INCLUDE ANY PRECIPITATION DURING ANY PART OF THE LONG TERM. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    90  68  90  62 /  20  10   0   0 
HARRISON AR       85  59  85  58 /  20  10   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    90  66  90  62 /  20  10   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     90  69  91  63 /  20  20   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  85  59  85  59 /  20  10   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     88  70  90  65 /  20  20   0   0 
SEARCY AR         88  64  88  61 /  20  10   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      89  65  89  62 /  20  10   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   88  64  88  60 /  20  10   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...LAKE WIND ADVISORY FROM MID MORNING
UNTIL MIDNIGHT ARZ047...ARZ056>057...ARZ063>065...ARZ068>069.

29/32






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 160856
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT THU SEP 16 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY
HURRICANE IVAN MADE LANDFALL IN THE VICINITY OF GULF SHORES AL ABOUT
0645Z BY SATELLITE IMAGES AND IS MOVING INLAND. MAIN INFLUENCE IS 
STAYING TO THE EAST OF THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BUT THE OVERALL CIRCULATION
AROUND IVAN SHOULD COVER ARKANSAS TODAY AND PRODUCE NORTHEAST WINDS.
A COLD FRONT IS MOVING TOWARD THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF ARKANSAS THIS
MORNING AND IT WILL LIKELY BE ABSORBED INTO THE BROAD CIRCULATION 
AROUND IVAN AS THE DAY PROGRESSES. THERE IS NOT A LOT OF COOLING OR
DRYING WITH THIS FRONT ANYMORE SO THERE LIKELY WILL NOT BE MUCH 
EFFECT ON TEMPS AND DEW POINTS. SOME THUNDERSTORMS HAVE CONTINUED ALONG
AND BEHIND THE FRONT DURING THE NIGHT AND THIS BAND OF MOISTURE IS 
PROGEED TO MOVE INTO ARKANSAS THIS MORNING. WILL KEEP A SLIGHT 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS GOING ACROSS THE AREA TODAY 
DUE TO THESE THUNDERSTORMS. THE INTERACTION OF THIS WITH THE 
CIRCULATION AND SUBSIDENCE AROUND IVAN WILL LIKELY SUPRESS THIS
THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY LATER TODAY. WILL LOWER POPS IN THE NORTHWEST
LATER TODAY AND DROP MENTION OF RAIN AFTER THE TODAY PERIOD. THE WINDS
AROUND IVAN ALONG WITH THE HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN FROM THE PLAINS
WILL RESULT IN GUSTY NORTHEAST WINDS WITH THE HIGHEST WINDS IN THE 
SOUTHEAST. THE TIGHTEST GRADIENT LOOKS LIKE IT WILL STAY TO THE EAST
OF THE AREA...BUT COULD SEE WINDS REACH LAKE WIND CRITERIA IN PARTS
OF THE EAST AND SOUTHEAST. ALSO LOOKS LIKE WINDS WILL DIMINISH WITH
LOSS OF HEATING AND DAYLIGHT...SO LAKE WIND ADVISORY CONDITIONS WILL
LIKELY END BY EARLY TONIGHT. CUT DOWN LAKE WIND ADVISORY TO INCLUDE
SEVERAL EASTERN AND SOUTHEASTERN COUNTIES AND ENDED ADVISORY AT 
MIDNIGHT...WHICH MAY STILL BE TOO LONG. AFTER ALL THIS...UPPER RIDGING
WILL BUILD INTO THE AREA WITH A SURFACE RIDGE EXTENDING INTO 
ARKANSAS FROM THE NORTHEAST. THIS SHOULD RESULT IN MOSTLY CLEAR TO
PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES WITH LIGHT NORTHEAST WINDS FROM FRIDAY THROUGH 
SUNDAY. FIGURE ON CLOUDS...WINDS AND THE DECAYING FRONTAL SYSTEM 
WILL TAKE A COUPLE OF DEGREES OFF MAXES TODAY COMPARED TO YESTERDAY. 
AFTER THAT...PATTERN SHOULD FAVOR MINS CLOSE TO NORMAL AND MAXES A 
LITTLE ABOVE NORMAL.   
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
THE UPPER LEVEL PATTERN SHOWS ALMOST NO FEATURES AFFECTING THE STATE 
FROM SUNDAY NIGHT UNTIL TUESDAY MORNING WHEN A WEAK LOW...POSSIBLY THE
OLD REMNANTS OF IVAN...APPROACHES ARKANSAS FROM THE EAST. THE LOW 
LINGERS IN PLACE AND THEN FILLS GRADUALLY. THE SURFACE PATTERN SHOWS 
DRY AIR OVER THE STATE SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING. 
THEN...SOME MOISTURE RETURNS TO THE STATE FROM THE EAST. DRY THROUGH 
TUESDAY MORNING...WITH MOISTURE INCREASING...BUT NOT ENOUGH TO 
INCLUDE ANY PRECIPITATION DURING ANY PART OF THE LONG TERM. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    90  68  90  62 /  20  10   0   0 
HARRISON AR       85  59  85  58 /  20  10   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    90  66  90  62 /  20  10   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     90  69  91  63 /  20  20   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  85  59  85  59 /  20  10   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     88  70  90  65 /  20  20   0   0 
SEARCY AR         88  64  88  61 /  20  10   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      89  65  89  62 /  20  10   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   88  64  88  60 /  20  10   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...LAKE WIND ADVISORY FROM MID MORNING
UNTIL MIDNIGHT ARZ047...ARZ056>057...ARZ063>065...ARZ068>069.
&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
950 PM CDT WED SEP 15 2004

.DISCUSSION...
HURRICANE IVAN CONTS MOVG NWD TOWARD THE AL/FL GULF COAST REGION. 
STILL LOOKS LIKE LANDFALL WILL TAKE PLACE EARLY THU MRNG IN THE 
VCNTY OF MOBILE BAY. 

BACK IN THE NATURAL STATE...WDLY SCTD CONVECTION DISSIPATED SHORTLY 
AFT SUNSET OVER WRN AND NRN AR. CDFNT LINED UP ROUGHLY ALONG THE 
I-44 CORRIDOR ATTM. EXPECT THE BNDRY TO MOVE SLOLY SEWD LATER TNGT 
AND HAVE LEFT 20 POPS FOR THE NWRN ZNS TNGT. DID LOWER MIN TEMPS A 
FEW DEGREES OVER NRN AR WHERE A LTL DRIER AIR HAS MANAGED TO WORK 
IN. REWORKED HOURLY GRIDS TO REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS. UPDATED ZNS AND 
GRIDS ALREADY OUT.
&&

CDT THURSDAY UNTIL 600 AM CDT FRIDAY FOR ZONES ARZ007...ARZ016... 
ARZ>025...ARZ032>034...ARZ043>047...ARZ053>057.. .ARZ062>069.
