44





861 
FXUS64 KLZK 151958
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
257 PM CDT WED SEP 15 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
SHOWERS CONTINUE TO BE ISOLATED ACROSS THE WEST SECTIONS OF THE CWFA 
AS SEEN ON THE KLZK RADAR. SATELLITE IMAGES CONTINUE TO SHOW 
ABUNDANT CUMULUS ACROSS THE AREA. BETTER LIFT IS BEING NOTED IN 
NORTHWEST ARKANSAS AS THE COLD FRONT APPROACHES FROM THE PLAINS. THE 
COLD FRONT CONTINUES TO STRETCH FROM IOWA INTO OKLAHOMA AND ARKANSAS 
IS SQUEEZED BETWEEN THE FRONT AND APPROACHING HURRICANE IVAN.  

THE COLD FRONT IS EXPECTED TO MOVE INTO NORTHWEST ARKANSAS THURSDAY 
MORNING. ISOLATED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE 
ALONG AND AHEAD OF THE FRONT. HURRICANE IVAN WILL MAKE LANDFALL NEAR 
MOBILE BAY THURSDAY MORNING. GFS IS CONSISTENT WITH THE NORTHEAST 
TRACK OF IVAN AFTER MAKING LANDFALL. AS IVAN MOVES NORTH THE 
PRESSURE GRADIENT WILL TIGHTEN AND WINDS WILL INCREASE ESPECIALLY 
ACROSS EASTERN ARKANSAS. WILL ISSUE A LAKE WIND ADVISORY FOR SOUTH 
AND EAST SECTIONS OF THE CWFA. WINDY CONDITIONS WILL CONTINUE 
THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT AS IVAN SLOWLY MOVES NORTHEAST. WILL CONTINUE 
WITH A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN THE EAST 
THROUGH THURSDAY EVENING. IVAN WILL PULL AWAY FROM ARKANSAS ON 
FRIDAY...THE PRESSURE GRADIENT WILL RELAX AND WINDS WILL DECREASE. 

DRY AIR MOVES IN FOR FRIDAY AND THROUGH THE WEEKEND. TEMPERATURES 
WILL REMAIN ABOVE NORMAL. 

&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY...
MODELS REMAIN IN GOOD AGREEMENT OVERALL WITH THE PATTERN REMAINING 
BECOMING HIGHLY AMPLIFIED THROUGH THE END OF THE PERIOD. THERE ARE 
SOME TIMING AND STRENGTH DIFFERENCES BUT OVERALL THERE IS GOOD 
CONTINUITY. THAT BEING SAID...FEEL A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS IS WARRANTED 
WITH A LEAN TOWARDS THE SLIGHTLY MORE CONSISTENT ECMWF.

PERIOD BEGINS WITH A HIGHLY AMPLIFIED PATTERN OF DEEP TROUGHING OVER 
THE ROCKIES AND STRONG RIDGING OVER THE EASTERN HALF OF THE NATION. 
GFS MODEL HAS BEEN NOTORIOUS WITH KEEPING REMNANTS OF IVAN TRAPPED 
UNDER THE RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS. PREFER THE OTHER 
MODELS HERE THAT WHISK THE REMNANTS OFF TO THE WEST. UPPER RIDGING 
WILL DOMINATE OVER THE AREA WITH THE TROF WEAKENING AS IT HEADS EAST 
WITH A CUT OFF LOW BEING PINCHED OFF IN ITS BASE. RETURN FLOW WILL
RETURN THROUGH TUESDAY WITH AN INCREASE IN MOISTURE. ASSOCIATED COLD 
FRONT APPROACHES THE AREA TUESDAY NIGHT BUT LIKELY WILL NOT IMPACT 
THE AREA UNTIL WEDNESDAY AS IT RUNS INTO THE AFOREMENTIONED RIDGE 
AND SLOWS DOWN. MOISTURE DOES NOT APPEAR TO BE PLENTIFUL ENOUGH TO 
JUSTIFY MORE THAN SLIGHT CHANCE POPS AT THIS TIME.

TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO RUN A FEW DEGREES ABOVE SEASONABLE 
WITH THE RIDGE DOMINATING. CURRENT MEX GUIDANCE SUPPORTS THIS 
SCENARIO AND IS GENERALLY ACCEPTED. DEW POINT TEMPS STILL PROGGED TO 
BE IN THE UPPER 50S TO LOWER 60S SO OVERALL HUMIDITY LEVELS WILL 
NOT BE TERRIBLE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    70  90  68  89 /  20  20  10   0 
HARRISON AR       70  88  60  86 /  20  20  10   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    71  90  68  90 /  20  20  10   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     70  90  67  88 /  20  20  20   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  69  87  61  86 /  20  20  10   0 
MONTICELLO AR     70  89  67  89 /  20  20  20   0 
SEARCY AR         69  89  67  88 /  20  20  10   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      71  90  68  90 /  20  20  10   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   70  90  65  88 /  20  20  10   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...LAKE WIND ADVISORY FROM 900 AM 
CDT THURSDAY UNTIL 600 AM CDT FRIDAY FOR ZONES ARZ007...ARZ016... 
ARZ>025...ARZ032>034...ARZ043>047...ARZ053>057.. .ARZ062>069.
&&

613 
FXUS64 KLZK 151541
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1041 AM CDT WED SEP 15 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATE TO FORECAST WILL BE OUT SHORTLY. SATELLITE IMAGES INDICATE A 
BAND OF CLOUDS ACROSS MAINLY CENTRAL AND WESTERN ARKANSAS. INCREASED 
CLOUD COVER IN THESE AREAS IN THE LATE MORNING AND EARLY AFTERNOON 
GRIDS. KLZK RADAR SHOWS ISOLATED SHOWERS ACROSS THE PARTS OF THE 
NORTH. WILL CONTINUE SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
THROUGH THIS AFTERNOON. WILL DECREASE POPS FOR TONIGHT TO SLIGHT 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. MOISTURE IS STILL NOT THAT 
IMPRESSIVE ACROSS THE AREA. HOWEVER A COLD FRONT NOW LOCATED FROM 
IOWA THROUGH EASTERN KANSAS TO OKLAHOMA WILL MOVE TO THE NORTHWEST 
CORNER OF ARKANSAS BY THURSDAY MORNING. ALSO INCREASED HIGH 
TEMPERATURES A COUPLE OF DEGREES FOR TODAY...AS WE TEND TO WARM UP 
ONCE THE CLOUDS DISSIPATE SOME IN THE AFTERNOON.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

51






687 
FXUS64 KLZK 150805
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
305 AM CDT WED SEP 15 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY
UPPER TROUGH OVER NORTH TEXAS AND EASTERN OKLAHOMA CONTINUES TO 
GENERATE AREA OF SHOWERS WITH ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS. THESE HAVE 
TRIED TO MOVE EAST INTO WESTERN ARKANSAS...BUT HAVENT MADE IT VERY 
FAR BEFORE DISSIPATING...THANKS TO MID LEVEL DRYING TAKING PLACE. 

THIS DRYING WILL BE SHORT LIVED...HOWEVER...AS SOUTHERLY FLOW WILL 
DRAW MORE MOISTURE INTO THE REGION TODAY. UPPER SYSTEM AND 
ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH WESTERN ARKANSAS TODAY...AS 
HURRICANE IVAN CONTINUES TO TRACK NORTHWARD TOWARD THE CENTRAL GULF 
COAST. ISOLATED/WIDELY SCATTERED SHOWERS WILL BE POSSIBLE TODAY AND 
TONIGHT...AS SEVERAL WAVES MOVE THROUGH THE APPROACHING TROUGH...AND 
COLD FRONT MOVES INTO NWRN ARKANSAS. 

WITH THE SURFACE SYSTEMS BOTH APPROACHING THE SOUTHERN UNITED 
STATES...BREEZY OR WINDY CONDITIONS WILL BE NOTED TOWARD THURSDAY 
MORNING...ON INTO FRIDAY AS GRADIENT TIGHTENS. MODELS CONTINUE TO 
TAKE IVAN ONTO THE CENTRAL GULF COAST...BUT THEN THEY SLOW THE 
SYSTEM DOWN SIGNIFICANTLY. ETA BRING THE SYSTEM SLOWLY UP INTO 
CENTRAL MISSISSIPPI BY THE END OF 60 HRS...WHEREAS THE GFS CURVES 
THE SYSTEM INTO NORTHERN ALABAMA...THEN STALLS IT OUT OVER THE 
SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS FOR SEVERAL DAYS...AND THEN EVEN HAS A SLIGHT 
RETROGRESSION BY MONDAY CANADIAN IS MORE IN LINE WITH THE GFS...
ALTHOUGH A BIT FASTER...AND ECMWF MORE RESEMBLES THE ETA. 

WITH ALL THE UNCERTAINTIES INVOLVED IN THIS FORECAST...WILL TREND 
THE FORECAST WITH THE OFFICIAL NHC TRACK IN MIND...WHICH CARRIES THE 
SYSTEM INTO WESTERN ALABAMA AND THEN INTO EASTERN TENNESSEE BY 
MONDAY. ON THIS TRACK...THE PRIMARY EFFECT IVAN WILL HAVE ON THE 
FORECAST AREA WILL BE HEAVIER CLOUD COVER IN THE EAST AND INCREASED 
WINDS. 

BY FRIDAY...COLD FRONT...OR RATHER THE REMNANTS OF IT WILL LIKELY 
GET ABSORBED IN THE CIRCULATION OF IVAN. UPPER RIDGE BUILDING 
NORTHEAST OUT OF TEXAS SHOULD GIVE THE SYSTEMS A PUSH FURTHER AWAY 
FROM THE LOWER MISSISSIPPI VALLEY/MID SOUTH AREA. THUS...CLOUDS WILL 
DECREASE AND DRIER AIR WILL FILTER IN. 

AS ALWAYS...FOR INFORMATION CONCERNING HURRICANE IVAN...PLEASE REFER 
TO PRODUCTS ISSUED BY THE NATIONAL HURRICANE CENTER. 
&&

LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
UPPER RIDGING FROM THE SOUTHWEST AND SURFACE RIDGING FROM THE 
NORTHEAST WILL DOMINATE THE AREA AT THE BEGINNING OF THE MEDIUM
RANGE. THIS WILL CONTINUE INTO EARLY NEXT WEEK BUT WILL BEGIN
TO CHANGE AS UPPER TROFFING INCREASES IN THE WESTERN U.S. THE 
TROFFING WILL INDUCE RETURN FLOW MONDAY INTO TUESDAY AND SOME
INCREASE IN MOISTURE. A COLD FRONT MOVES INTO THE AREA LATE TUESDAY
OR TUESDAY NIGHT. NEW GFS INDICATES THE FRONT WILL BE SLOWER MOVING 
IN BUT DID NOT ADJUST THE FORECAST FOR THAT AT THIS TIME. BASICALLY
KEPT A DRY FORECAST WITH MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES FOR SATURDAY NIGHT INTO 
MONDAY THEN WARMED TEMPS A LITTLE WITH PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES AS THE 
RETURN FLOW MOVES IN. WAS INCLINED TO PUT SOME POPS IN FOR TUESDAY
NIGHT...BUT LEFT THEM OUT FOR NOW.
&& 

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    89  69  89  68 /  20  30  30  10 
HARRISON AR       84  65  86  60 /  30  30  20  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    90  69  92  68 /  30  30  20  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     89  70  86  67 /  20  30  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  84  65  86  61 /  30  30  20  10 
MONTICELLO AR     90  70  86  67 /  20  30  30  20 
SEARCY AR         87  69  88  67 /  20  30  30  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      90  69  91  68 /  30  30  20  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   87  68  89  65 /  30  30  20  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$
 
SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 29





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 150805
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
305 AM CDT WED SEP 15 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY
UPPER TROUGH OVER NORTH TEXAS AND EASTERN OKLAHOMA CONTINUES TO

CENTRAL MISSISSIPPI BY THE END OF 60 HRS...WHEREAS THE GFS CURVES 
THE SYSTEM INTO NORTHERN ALABAMA...THEN STALLS IT OUT OVER THE 
SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS FOR SEVERAL DAYS...AND THEN EVEN HAS A SLIGHT 
RETROGRESSION BY MONDAY CANADIAN IS MORE IN LINE WITH THE GFS...
ALTHOUGH A BIT FASTER...AND ECMWF MORE RESEMBLES THE ETA. 

WITH ALL THE UNCERTAINTIES INVOLVED IN THIS FORECAST...WILL TREND 
THE FORECAST WITH THE OFFICIAL NHC TRACK IN MIND...WHICH CARRIES THE 
SYSTEM INTO WESTERN ALABAMA AND THEN INTO EASTERN TENNESSEE BY 
MONDAY. ON THIS TRACK...THE PRIMARY EFFECT IVAN WILL HAVE ON THE 
FORECAST AREA WILL BE HEAVIER CLOUD COVER IN THE EAST AND INCREASED 
WINDS. 

BY FRIDAY...COLD FRONT...OR RATHER THE REMNANTS OF IT WILL LIKELY 
GET ABSORBED IN THE CIRCULATION OF IVAN. UPPER RIDGE BUILDING 
NORTHEAST OUT OF TEXAS SHOULD GIVE THE SYSTEMS A PUSH FURTHER AWAY 
FROM THE LOWER MISSISSIPPI VALLEY/MID SOUTH AREA. THUS...CLOUDS WILL 
DECREASE AND DRIER AIR WILL FILTER IN. 

AS ALWAYS...FOR INFORMATION CONCERNING HURRICANE IVAN...PLEASE REFER 
TO PRODUCTS ISSUED BY THE NATIONAL HURRICANE CENTER. 
&&

LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
UPPER RIDGING FROM THE SOUTHWEST AND SURFACE RIDGING FROM THE 
NORTHEAST WILL DOMINATE THE AREA AT THE BEGINNING OF THE MEDIUM
RANGE. THIS WILL CONTINUE INTO EARLY NEXT WEEK BUT WILL BEGIN
TO CHANGE AS UPPER TROFFING INCREASES IN THE WESTERN U.S. THE 
TROFFING WILL INDUCE RETURN FLOW MONDAY INTO TUESDAY AND SOME
INCREASE IN MOISTURE. A COLD FRONT MOVES INTO THE AREA LATE TUESDAY
OR TUESDAY NIGHT. NEW GFS INDICATES THE FRONT WILL BE SLOWER MOVING 
IN BUT DID NOT ADJUST THE FORECAST FOR THAT AT THIS TIME. BASICALLY
KEPT A DRY FORECAST WITH MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES FOR SATURDAY NIGHT INTO 
MONDAY THEN WARMED TEMPS A LITTLE WITH PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES AS THE 
RETURN FLOW MOVES IN. WAS INCLINED TO PUT SOME POPS IN FOR TUESDAY
NIGHT...BUT LEFT THEM OUT FOR NOW.
&& 

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    89  69  89  68 /  20  30  30  10 
HARRISON AR       84  65  86  60 /  30  30  20  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    90  69  92  68 /  30  30  20  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     89  70  86  67 /  20  30  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  84  65  86  61 /  30  30  20  10 
MONTICELLO AR     90  70  86  67 /  20  30  30  20 
SEARCY AR         87  69  88  67 /  20  30  30  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      90  69  91  68 /  30  30  20  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   87  68  89  65 /  30  30  20  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$
 
SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 29





407 
FXUS64 KLZK 150236
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
930 PM CDT TUE SEP 14 2004

A SHORT WAVE HAS BEEN TRIGGERING SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS OVER 
NEIGHBORING PARTS OF OKLAHOMA AND TEXAS. ALTHOUGH ECHOES HAVE BEEN 
DECREASING...THERE WILL BE A FEW SHOWERS SURVIVING INTO THE EXTREME 
WESTERN AND SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE...SO A 20 PERCENT CHANCE 
OF SHOWERS SHOULD SUFFICE AFTER MIDNIGHT UNTIL SUNRISE. 32

PREVIOUS DISCUSSION FOLLOWS...

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
ISOLATED SHOWERS WERE MAINLY ACROSS THE NORTH AND WEST THIS 
AFTERNOON. ALL SHOWERS HAVE DISSIPATED AT THIS TIME. SATELLITE 
IMAGES INDICATE QUITE A FEW CUMULUS ACROSS THE AREA. MOST CLOUDS 
WILL DISSIPATE AT SUNSET. 

BROAD TROUGH ACROSS THE CENTRAL U.S. WILL FLATTEN OUT AS HURRICANE 
IVAN APPROACHES THE GULF COAST. GFS SEEMS TO HAVE A GOOD HANDLE ON 
THE SITUATION AT THIS TIME. A COLD FRONT IN THE CENTRAL PLAINS WILL 
MOVE SOUTH AND WILL ENTER NORTHWEST ARKANSAS THURSDAY MORNING. WILL 
KEEP THE SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS GOING FOR 
WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. WILL EXPECT WINDY CONDITIONS TO DEVELOP 
THURSDAY AND FRIDAY AS IVAN MOVES EAST OF ARKANSAS. DRY AIR WILL 
MOVE INTO THE AREA FRIDAY AS AN UPPER RIDGE BUILDS IN FROM THE 
SOUTHWEST. 

TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN ABOVE NORMAL THROUGH SATURDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY...
MODELS ARE IN GENERAL AGREEMENT THIS AFTERNOON CONCERNING THE 
SYNOPTIC SCALE FEATURES WITH DIFFERENCES NOTED IN THE FINER DETAILS. 
WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS THIS AFTERNOON WITH A 
LEAN TOWARDS THE MORE CONSISTENT ECMWF SOLUTION. GFS SEEMS A LITTLE 
OVERDONE WITH HOLDING ON TO WHATS LEFT OF IVAN OVER THE SOUTHEAST 
CONUS THROUGH THE ENTIRE PERIOD. 

PERIOD STARTS OFF WITH REMNANTS OF IVAN OVER THE CENTRAL APPALACHIAN 
MOUNTAINS AND A LARGE TROUGH STARTING TO DIG OVER THE WESTERN CONUS. 
TROUGH SHOULD WHISK IVAN OFF TO THE NORTHEAST. DIGGING TROUGH WILL 
RESULT IN RIDGING THAT IS ALREADY IN CONTROL WHEN THE PERIOD STARTS 
AND WILL BE REMAIN SO THROUGH OUT. AFOREMENTIONED TROUGH SWINGS INTO 
THE CENTRAL PLAINS LATE IN THE PERIOD WITH AN ACCOMPANYING COLD 
FRONT THAT EXTENDS FROM THE PARENT SURFACE LOW IN THE NORTHERN 
PLAINS TO NORTHERN NEW MEXICO. A SPRAWLING AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE  
CONTINUES TO PUSH BEHIND THE FRONT WITH MODELS CONTINUING TO WEAKEN 
THE BOUNDARY...MOVING THE BEST DYNAMICS OFF TO THE NORTHEAST. FRONT 
MAY BEGIN TO IMPACT THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE STATE LATE ON DAY 
SEVEN BUT WILL LEAVE THE CWA DRY FOR NOW.

RETURN FLOW WILL CONTINUE TO STRENGTHEN THROUGH THE PERIOD FOR MORE 
OF A GRADUAL INCREASE IN MOISTURE AND CONSEQUENTLY CLOUD COVER AND 
HUMIDITY. MEX NUMBERS CONTINUING TO ADVERTISE TEMPERATURES NEAR 
NORMAL MINIMUMS AT NIGHT AND THREE TO FIVE DEGREES ABOVE AVERAGE 
DURING THE DAY. THIS LOOKS REASONABLE AND IS EXCEPTED.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    68  89  71  88 /  10  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       66  86  65  85 /  10  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    70  90  71  88 /  10  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     69  90  72  89 /  10  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  66  85  65  85 /  10  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     69  91  72  89 /  10  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         67  87  71  87 /  10  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      69  89  70  88 /  10  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   67  88  68  87 /  10  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1023 AM CDT TUE SEP 14 2004

.DISCUSSION...
THE ISOLATED SHOWERS THAT HAVE MOVED ACROSS PARTS OF THE CWFA THIS 
MORNING HAVE DISSIPATED FOR THE MOST PART. WILL CONTINUE THE SLIGHT 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS THROUGH THIS AFTERNOON. 
INCREASED CLOUD COVER TO BLEND MORE WITH THE CURRENT OBSERVATIONS. 
SATELLITE IMAGES SHOW ABUNDANT CLOUD COVER ACROSS THE AREA...THIS 
SHOULD KEEP TEMPERATURES A LITTLE COOLER THAN YESTERDAY IN MANY 
AREAS.

51






714 
FXUS64 KLZK 140802
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
302 AM CDT TUE SEP 14 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY
SATELLITE PIC CURRENTLY INDICATES DEVELOPING STRATOCU OVER PORTIONS 
OF THE FORECAST AREA. AIRMASS IS PRETTY WARM AT THE SURFACE...WITH 
DEWPOINTS IN THE MID 60S TO LOWER 70S AND TEMPS IN THE LOWER TO MID 
70S. ANOTHER WARM DAY IS IN STORE FOR THE FORECAST AREA...WITH HIGHS 
IN THE MID 80S TO LOWER 90S. H5 FLOW WILL CONTINUE TO BE OUT OF THE 
SOUTHWEST...AND THIS WILL ALLOW FOR SEVERAL IMPULSES TO MOVE UP IN 
THE MEAN FLOW. THUS...COULD BE SOME ISOLATED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS THIS AFTERNOON AND THIS EVENING. 

COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH FROM THE PLAINS TONIGHT. MOISTURE WILL 
INCREASE OUT AHEAD OF THE SYSTEM. THE FRONT WILL ALLOW FOR A SLIGHT 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. 

BY WEDNESDAY NIGHT...IVAN COMES INTO PLAY. LATEST MODEL RUNS HAVE 
CONVERGED ON A LANDFALL NEAR THE MISSISSIPPI/ALABAMA COAST. THE 
TENDENCY HAS BEEN TO SHIFT THIS SLIGHTLY WESTWARD OVER THE LAST 
SEVERAL DAYS. AT THIS TIME...IT APPEARS THAT THE PRIMARY EFFECT IVAN 
WILL HAVE ON ARKANSAS WILL BE INCREASED CLOUD COVER IN THE EASTERN 
HALF ALONG WITH BREEZY CONDITIONS ON THURSDAY. OF COURSE...IF THE 
TRACK OF THE STORM SHIFTS FURTHER WESTWARD...THERE WOULD BE MORE OF 
AN EFFECT...AND IF THE TRACK SHIFTS BACK TO THE EAST...THERE WILL BE 
LESS OF AN EFFECT ON OUR SENSIBLE WEATHER. INTERESTINGLY ENOUGH...
THE PREDICTED PATH OF IVAN TOWARD THE GULF COAST IS EERILY CLOSE TO 
THE ONE CAMILLE TOOK BACK IN AUGUST 1969. 

BASED ON THE LATEST INFORMATION AVAIALABLE...WILL TREND CONDITIONS 
SLIGHTLY UPWARD FROM THE GOING FORECAST. HAVE INCREASED POPS TO 20 
AND 30 PERCENT...HOWEVER THE SOURCE FOR ANY RAINFALL OBSERVED WILL 
BE PRIMARILY FROM THE APPROACHING COLD FRONT. WITH THE FORECAST AREA 
ON THE WEST SIDE OF IVAN...THE STORM WILL BE DRAWING IN DRIER 
CONTINENTAL AIR...LESSENING THE POTENTIAL FOR RAINFALL. ALSO...HAVE 
UPPED WINDS AND SKY COVER IN THE EASTERN PORTIONS OF THE AREA. 

COLD FRONT WILL GET CAUGHT UP IN IVANS CIRCULATION...AND BY THURSDAY 
AFTERNOON...BOTH SYSTEMS WILL MOVE TOWARD THE APPALACHIANS AS AN H5 
RIDGE BUILDS NORTHEASTWARD OUT OF TEXAS. HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD 
INTO ARKANSAS ON FRIDAY...WITH DRIER AIR FILTERING IN. 

FOR MORE INFORMATION ON THE POTENTIAL PATH OF HURRICANE IVAN...
PLEASE REFER TO PRODUCTS ISSUED BY THE NATIONAL HURRICANE 
CENTER. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
FORECAST WAS PREDICATED ON IVAN AND ITS REMNANTS MOVING NORTH AND 
NORTHEASTWARD AWAY FROM THE AREA AS PROGGED BY THE GFS AND BY THE 
TPC FORECAST THROUGH 120 HOURS. BASED ON THAT...RIDGE OF HIGH 
PRESSURE AT THE SURFACE SHOULD POKE ITS WAY INTO THE AREA BY FRIDAY 
NIGHT AND CONTINUE INTO THE WEEKEND AND RIDGING ALOFT SHOULD 
OVERTAKE THE AREA. THAT SHOULD BRING MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES AND DRY 
WEATHER WITH MAXES A LITTLE ABOVE NORMAL AND MINS CLOSE TO NORMAL. 
UPPER RIDGING CONTINUES THROUGH MONDAY BUT A STRONG UPPER TROF 
DEVELOPS TO THE WEST WHICH RESULTS IN A RATHER STRONG FRONTAL SYSTEM 
DEVELOPING IN THE HIGH PLAINS. THIS WILL BRING INCREASING RETURN 
FLOW INTO THE AREA ABOUT SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY WITH AN INCREASE IN 
MOISTURE WHICH SHOULD MEAN AN INCREASE IN CLOUDS AND DEW POINTS. 
THIS IN TURN SHOULD RESULT IN HIGHER MINS.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  68  88  71 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       86  66  85  65 /  20  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    89  70  89  71 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     88  69  89  72 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  85  66  85  65 /  20  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     89  69  89  72 /  20  20  30  20 
SEARCY AR         87  67  87  71 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      89  69  89  70 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   88  67  88  68 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 29





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 140802
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
302 AM CDT TUE SEP 14 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY
SATELLITE PIC CURRENTLY INDICATES DEVELOPING STRATOCU OVER PORTIONS 
OF THE FORECAST AREA. AIRMASS IS PRETTY WARM AT THE SURFACE...WITH 
DEWPOINTS IN THE MID 60S TO LOWER 70S AND TEMPS IN THE LOWER TO MID 
70S. ANOTHER WARM DAY IS IN STORE FOR THE FORECAST AREA...WITH HIGHS 
IN THE MID 80S TO LOWER 90S. H5 FLOW WILL CONTINUE TO BE OUT OF THE 
SOUTHWEST...AND THIS WILL ALLOW FOR SEVERAL IMPULSES TO MOVE UP IN 
THE MEAN FLOW. THUS...COULD BE SOME ISOLATED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS THIS AFTERNOON AND THIS EVENING. 

COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH FROM THE PLAINS TONIGHT. MOISTURE WILL 
INCREASE OUT AHEAD OF THE SYSTEM. THE FRONT WILL ALLOW FOR A SLIGHT 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. 

BY WEDNESDAY NIGHT...IVAN COMES INTO PLAY. LATEST MODEL RUNS HAVE 
CONVERGED ON A LANDFALL NEAR THE MISSISSIPPI/ALABAMA COAST. THE 
TENDENCY HAS BEEN TO SHIFT THIS SLIGHTLY WESTWARD OVER THE LAST 
SEVERAL DAYS. AT THIS TIME...IT APPEARS THAT THE PRIMARY EFFECT IVAN 
WILL HAVE ON ARKANSAS WILL BE INCREASED CLOUD COVER IN THE EASTERN 
HALF ALONG WITH BREEZY CONDITIONS ON THURSDAY. OF COURSE...IF THE 
TRACK OF THE STORM SHIFTS FURTHER WESTWARD...THERE WOULD BE MORE OF 
AN EFFECT...AND IF THE TRACK SHIFTS BACK TO THE EAST...THERE WILL BE 
LESS OF AN EFFECT ON OUR SENSIBLE WEATHER. INTERESTINGLY ENOUGH...
THE PREDICTED PATH OF IVAN TOWARD THE GULF COAST IS EERILY CLOSE TO 
THE ONE CAMILLE TOOK BACK IN AUGUST 1969. 

BASED ON THE LATEST INFORMATION AVAIALABLE...WILL TREND CONDITIONS 
SLIGHTLY UPWARD FROM THE GOING FORECAST. HAVE INCREASED POPS TO 20 
AND 30 PERCENT...HOWEVER THE SOURCE FOR ANY RAINFALL OBSERVED WILL 
BE PRIMARILY FROM THE APPROACHING COLD FRONT. WITH THE FORECAST AREA 
ON THE WEST SIDE OF IVAN...THE STORM WILL BE DRAWING IN DRIER 
CONTINENTAL AIR...LESSENING THE POTENTIAL FOR RAINFALL. ALSO...HAVE 
UPPED WINDS AND SKY COVER IN THE EASTERN PORTIONS OF THE AREA. 

COLD FRONT WILL GET CAUGHT UP IN IVANS CIRCULATION...AND BY THURSDAY 
AFTERNOON...BOTH SYSTEMS WILL MOVE TOWARD THE APPALACHIANS AS AN H5 
RIDGE BUILDS NORTHEASTWARD OUT OF TEXAS. HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD 
INTO ARKANSAS ON FRIDAY...WITH DRIER AIR FILTERING IN. 

FOR MORE INFORMATION ON THE POTENTIAL PATH OF HURRICANE IVAN...
PLEASE REFER TO PRODUCTS ISSUED BY THE NATIONAL HURRICANE 
CENTER. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
FORECAST WAS PREDICATED ON IVAN AND ITS REMNANTS MOVING NORTH AND 
NORTHEASTWARD AWAY FROM THE AREA AS PROGGED BY THE GFS AND BY THE 
TPC FORECAST THROUGH 120 HOURS. BASED ON THAT...RIDGE OF HIGH 
PRESSURE AT THE SURFACE SHOULD POKE ITS WAY INTO THE AREA BY FRIDAY 
NIGHT AND CONTINUE INTO THE WEEKEND AND RIDGING ALOFT SHOULD 
OVERTAKE THE AREA. THAT SHOULD BRING MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES AND DRY 
WEATHER WITH MAXES A LITTLE ABOVE NORMAL AND MINS CLOSE TO NORMAL. 
UPPER RIDGING CONTINUES THROUGH MONDAY BUT A STRONG UPPER TROF 
DEVELOPS TO THE WEST WHICH RESULTS IN A RATHER STRONG FRONTAL SYSTEM 
DEVELOPING IN THE HIGH PLAINS. THIS WILL BRING INCREASING RETURN 
FLOW INTO THE AREA ABOUT SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY WITH AN INCREASE IN 
MOISTURE WHICH SHOULD MEAN AN INCREASE IN CLOUDS AND DEW POINTS. 
THIS IN TURN SHOULD RESULT IN HIGHER MINS.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  68  88  71 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       86  66  85  65 /  20  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    89  70  89  71 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     88  69  89  72 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  85  66  85  65 /  20  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     89  69  89  72 /  20  20  30  20 
SEARCY AR         87  67  87  71 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      89  69  89  70 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   88  67  88  68 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

SHORT TERM 57 / LONG TERM 29





541 
FXUS64 KLZK 131943
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
240 PM CDT MON SEP 13 2004

.DISCUSSION...
FEW SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS POPPED UP FROM CENTRAL INTO EASTERN 
ARKANSAS THIS AFTERNOON. PRECIPITATION SURROUNDING SYSTEM ALOFT IN 
WESTERN TENNESSEE. WILL KEEP ISOLATED PRECIPITATION IN FORECAST THIS 
EVENING...FOLLOWED BY CLEAR/PARTLY CLOUDY SKY. 

SYSTEM IN TENNESSEE WILL MOVE NORTHEAST ON TUESDAY...LEAVING 
ARKANSAS IN DRY WEATHER PATTERN ONCE AGAIN. LOW LEVEL MOISTURE STILL 
FAIRLY HIGH...WITH HUMID CONDITIONS NOTED IN MAINLY THE SOUTHEAST 
HALF OF THE STATE. COULD BE SOME PATCHY LOW CLOUDS ONCE AGAIN TO 
START THE DAY.

HURRICANE IVAN WILL MAKE LANDFALL SOMETIME LATE WEDNESDAY ALONG 
CENTRAL GULF COAST. MEANWHILE...COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH FROM THE 
NORTHWEST. REMNANTS OF IVAN WILL MOSTLY STAY EAST OF THE REGION... 
WITH PLENTY OF SUBSIDENCE IN ARKANSAS. THIS WILL KEEP RAIN CHANCES 
LOW AS FRONT PUSHES INTO THE STATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT/THURSDAY. BREEZY 
CONDITIONS MAY DEVELOP IN EASTERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE AS IVAN GOES 
BY ON THURSDAY.

AS IVAN DEPARTS AND FRONT EXITS TO THE EAST...WILL BE FOLLOWED BY 
ANOTHER SHOT OF DRY AIR LATE IN THE WEEK. THIS WILL LEAD TO COOLER 
NIGHTS AND LOWER AFTERNOON HUMIDITY LEVELS. 

TEMPERATURES...OVERALL...PRETTY CLOSE TO NORMAL THE NEXT 7 DAYS. 
NOTHING TO INDICATE THAT CURRENT DRY SPELL WILL END ANYTIME 
SOON. (46)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    68  89  68  89 /  20  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       65  86  65  86 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    67  90  67  91 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     68  90  68  90 /  20  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  65  86  65  85 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     68  90  68  90 /  20  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         66  88  66  88 /  20  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      66  90  66  91 /  10  10  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   65  90  65  90 /  10  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED

1050 AM CDT MON SEP 13 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LOTS OF LOW CLOUDS FROM CENTRAL INTO NORTHEAST ARKANSAS THIS 
MORNING. UPDATED FORECAST TO ADD MORE CLOUDS LATE THIS MORNING/EARLY 
THIS AFTERNOON IN AFOREMENTIONED AREAS. 

ALSO...A STRAY SHOWER POPPED UP BRIEFLY IN LONOKE COUNTY THIS 
MORNING. WITH SYSTEM ALOFT CLOSE TO AREA...MAY BE A PRECURSOR FOR 
MORE ISOLATED SHOWERS/STORMS THIS AFTERNOON. WENT AHEAD AND 
MENTIONED SLIGHT CHANCE FOR PRECIPITATION IN EASTERN HALF OF 
STATE. 

OTHERWISE...FORECAST ON TRACK AND NO ADDITIONAL CHANGES MADE. (46)



483 
FXUS64 KLZK 130803
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT MON SEP 13 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY
SHORT WAVE ALONG EASTERN EDGES OF CWA SET OFF SOME THUNDERSTORMS
IN EXTREME EASTERN PARTS OF THE CWA DURING THE NIGHT BUT THEY 
DISSIPATED SHORTLY AFTER MIDNIGHT. SHORT WAVE WILL MOVE SLOWLY TO
THE EAST WHICH SUGGESTS CONVECTION WITH IT SHOULD STAY TO THE 
EAST OF THE AREA. SOME MOISTURE LINGERS IN THE EAST SO WILL 
HAVE POPS JUST BELOW THRESHOLD TO MENTION IN FORECAST IN THE 
EAST FOR MUCH OF THE DAY WITH POPS DECREASING TO THE WEST. 
OTHERWISE WINDS WILL BECOME MORE FROM THE SOUTH AS THE SURFACE RIDGE 
TO THE NORTHEAST WEAKENS. THIS SHOULD RESULT IN MAXES AT LEAST AS
HIGH AS SUNDAY AND MAYBE A DEGREE OR TWO HIGHER IN SOME PLACES. 
DRY AND WARM WEATHER SHOULD PREVAIL TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
WITH TEMPS NEAR PERSISTENCE. A COLD FRONT APPROACHES THE AREA
WEDNESDAY DRIVEN BY AN UPPER TROF MOVING ACROSS THE UPPER MIDWEST. 
AT THE SAME TIME...HURRICANE IVAN MAY BE APPROACHING THE GULF 
COAST...PROVIDED HE EVER MAKES THE TURN TO THE NORTH THAT HAS BEEN
FORECAST FOR SEVERAL DAYS. MOISTURE MAY INCREASE ACROSS THE AREA
DUE TO THIS SO WILL GO WITH MORE CLOUDS STARTING WEDNESDAY NIGHT.
MAXES WEDNESDAY SHOULD AGAIN BE IN THE UPPER 80S TO LOWER 90S. 
THE FRONT SHOULD REACH INTO NORTHWESTERN ARKANSAS WEDNESDAY NIGHT 
BUT WILL LIKELY BE WEAKENING AS UPPER SUPPORT IS PULLING AWAY FROM
THE AREA. HOWEVER THE BROAD CIRCULATION AROUND IVAN MAY BRING NORTHEAST
WINDS TO THE CWA AND THE FRONTAL SYSTEM MAY GET ABSORBED INTO THE
SYSTEM AS WELL. WILL PUT IN A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS IN THE NORTHWEST WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND ACROSS THE ENTIRE 
AREA THURSDAY DUE TO THIS. WILL INCREASE CLOUDS SOMEWHAT AND THIS
SHOULD ALSO MODERATE HIGH TEMPS WITH MAXES THURSDAY A LITTLE LOWER. 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
EXTENDED RANGE MODELS ARE NOW TRENDING THINGS SLOWER AND FURTHER 
WEST WITH HURRICANE IVAN. LOOKS AS THOUGH THERE COULD BE SOME 
INFLUENCE IN THE FORECAST AREA...MAINLY IN THE FORM OF INCREASED 
CLOUD COVER IN THE EASTERN HALF ON THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY. OF 
COURSE...WHERE IVAN COMES ASHORE WILL MAKE A GREAT DEAL OF 
DIFFERENCE. IF IT MAKES LANDFALL FURTHER WEST...THERE WILL BE A 
GREATER EFFECT FOR OUR AREA. FOR NOW...FEEL THAT ONLY INCREASED 
CLOUDS WILL BE NOTED...AS WEST SIDE OF IVANS CIRCULATION DRAWS IN 
DRIER AIR AT THE LOWER LEVELS. 

BY LATE FRIDAY...RIDGE WILL BUILD NORTHEAST OUT OF TEXAS...PUSHING 
IVAN TOWARD APPALACHIA AND THE EAST COAST. NORTHWESTERLY FLOW ALOFT 
WILL SET UP OVER ARKANSAS FOR THE WEEKEND. SEVERAL IMPULSES MAY MOVE 
DOWN IN THE MEAN FLOW...BUT AT THIS POINT MOISTURE AND UPPER SUPPORT 
SEEMS TOO MARGINAL TO ADD RAIN CHANCES. HAVE THUS LEFT THE EXTENDED 
DRY FOR NOW. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    91  68  91  68 /  10   0  10  10 
HARRISON AR       87  65  88  65 /   0   0  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    91  68  92  68 /  10   0  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     91  68  92  68 /  10   0  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  87  65  87  65 /   0   0  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     92  68  92  68 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         90  65  90  65 /  10   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      91  65  92  65 /   0   0  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   90  65  91  65 /   0   0  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

961 
FXUS64 KLZK 130153
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
853 PM CDT SUN SEP 12 2004

THE FORECAST REQUIRES MINOR ADJUSTMENTS IN WORDING...SO AN UPDATE 
WILL BE OUT SHORTLY. THE PREVIOUS DISCUSSION FOLLOWS. (32)

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT
UPPER LVL SYS LOCATED ALONG THE MS RVR THIS AFTN WITH INVERTED TROF 
NOTED AT THE SFC. ISOLD SHRA/TSRA NOTED OVR THE DELTA REGION OF ERN 
AR. WL WATCH RADAR TRENDS PRIOR TO ZN ISSUANCE...BUT CURRENT 
THINKING IS TO KEEP FCST DRY THIS EVENING.

MODELS STILL IN GOOD AGREEMENT IN THE SHORT TERM WITH OVERALL FCST
TRENDS. UPPER FEATURE WILL CONT TO SHIFT E OF THE FA THRU MON. WEAK 
RDG ALOFT THEN BLDS INTO THE REGION INTO MIDWEEK AS MAIN STORM TRACK 
RMNS WELL N OF AR.

BY THE END OF THE PD...FOCUS WILL SHIFT TO THE EVENTUAL TRACK OF 
IVAN. MODELS CONT TO INDC A MORE WWD SHIFT IN THE FCST PATH. ETA 
SOLUTION IS FURTHER W THAN THE GFS BY LATE WED. STILL LOOKS LIKE 
MAIN EFFECT ON OUR WX ATTM WILL BE FOR INCRSG NELY FLOW AS SYS APCHS 
THE NRN GULF.

HAVE GONE WITH PERSISTENCE WITH TEMPS. MOS READINGS FAIRLY CLOSE 
WITH THIS THINKING IN REGARDS TO MAX TEMPS. GUIDANCE STILL LOOKS A 
BIT WARM ON MINS...ESP IN THE VALLEY AREAS THE NEXT FEW NIGHTS.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
HIGH PRESSURE WILL ONCE AGAIN DOMINATE THE EXTENDED PORTION OF THE 
FORECAST. OF COURSE...THIS ALL DEPENDS ON THE TRACK OF HURRICANE 
IVAN. RIGHT NOW...IVAN LOOKS TO STAY TO THE EAST OF ARKANSAS. HAVE 
INCREASED CLOUDS...BUT LEFT PRECIP OUT OF THE EXTENDED. TEMPS WILL 
REMAIN NEAR TO SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

MODELS STILL IN GOOD AGREEMENT IN THE SHORT TERM WITH OVERALL FCST
TRENDS. UPPER FEATURE WILL CONT TO SHIFT E OF THE FA THRU MON. WEAK 
RDG ALOFT THEN BLDS INTO THE REGION INTO MIDWEEK AS MAIN STORM TRACK 
RMNS WELL N OF AR.

BY THE END OF THE PD...FOCUS WILL SHIFT TO THE EVENTUAL TRACK OF 
IVAN. MODELS CONT TO INDC A MORE WWD SHIFT IN THE FCST PATH. ETA 
SOLUTION IS FURTHER W THAN THE GFS BY LATE WED. STILL LOOKS LIKE 
MAIN EFFECT ON OUR WX ATTM WILL BE FOR INCRSG NELY FLOW AS SYS APCHS 
THE NRN GULF.

HAVE GONE WITH PERSISTENCE WITH TEMPS. MOS READINGS FAIRLY CLOSE 
WITH THIS THINKING IN REGARDS TO MAX TEMPS. GUIDANCE STILL LOOKS A 
BIT WARM ON MINS...ESP IN THE VALLEY AREAS THE NEXT FEW NIGHTS.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
HIGH PRESSURE WILL ONCE AGAIN DOMINATE THE EXTENDED PORTION OF THE 
FORECAST. OF COURSE...THIS ALL DEPENDS ON THE TRACK OF HURRICANE 
IVAN. RIGHT NOW...IVAN LOOKS TO STAY TO THE EAST OF ARKANSAS. HAVE 
INCREASED CLOUDS...BUT LEFT PRECIP OUT OF THE EXTENDED. TEMPS WILL 
REMAIN NEAR TO SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

44/58

44





938 
FXUS64 KLZK 120721
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT SUN SEP 12 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY TRHOUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT
PATTERN CONTINUES TO SHOW LITTLE CHANGE OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS. IVAN
SHOWS NO SIGN OF TURNING TO THE NORTH YET AND CHANCES ARE INCREASING 
THAT IT MIGHT TAKE A WIDER TURN AND COME FAR ENOUGH TO THE WEST TO
HAVE SOME EFFECT ON ARKANSAS BUT FOR NOW WILL NOT BRING THAT INTO 
PLAY. TIMING WOULD PUT ANY EFFECTS FROM IVAN PAST THE SHORT TERM 
PERIOD ANYWAY. SHORT WAVE MOVING ACROSS THE AREA TONIGHT LOOKS LIKE
IT WILL MOVE TO NEAR THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER THIS MORNING THEN STALL 
THERE OR MOVE VERY SLOWLY TO THE EAST. OVERALL MOISTURE STILL LIMITED
SO MAIN EFFECTS SHOULD BE SOME HIGH BASED STRATOCUMULUS OR LOW BASED
ALTOCUMULUS WITH CHANCES OF RAIN TOO LOW TO MENTION IN FORECAST. DID
GO WITH 10 PERCENT POPS IN THE AFTERNOON IN THE EAST CLOSEST TO THE 
TROF AXIS WITH LOWER POPS TO THE WEST. TEMPS SHOULD BE CLOSE TO
PERSISTENCE BUT THERE COULD BE A SLIGHT WARMING TREND OVER THE 
NEXT THREE DAYS. WINDS WILL GENERALLY REMAIN LIGHT OUT OF THE EAST
AROUND A SURFACE RIDGE FROM THE NORTHEAST AND THIS WILL KEEP SIGNIFICANT
MOISTURE OUT OF THE AREA.  
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
ONCE AGAIN...THE EXTENDED PERIODS FIND ME SOUNDING LIKE A BROKEN 
RECORD. MOST OF THE PERIOD WILL FIND 500 MB RIDGING DOMINATING THE 
MIDSOUTH AND SOUTHERN PLAINS. BY THE BEGINNING OF THE 
EXTENDED...SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES WILL BE IN THE MIDST OF 
DEALING WITH IVAN. BUILDING RIDGE OVER WEST TEXAS WILL WORK ITS WAY 
EASTWARD TOWARD ARKANSAS...SHUTTING OFF ANY MID AND UPPER LEVEL 
MOISTURE COMING FROM IVAN. SURFACE FLOW WILL BE OUT OF THE 
NORTHEAST AND EAST...THUS NO MAJOR INFLUX OF LOW LEVEL MOISTURE IS 
IMMINENT. TEMPERATURES WILL BE NEAR TO SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL. 

BY DAY 7 /SATURDAY/...MODELS START TO BRING A COLD FRONT DOWN OUT OF 
THE PLAINS...BUT PROGRESSION OF THIS FEATURE INTO THE LOWER 
MISSISSIPPI VALLEY IS NOT LIKELY...GIVEN POSITION OF UPPER RIDGING 
OVER THE WESTERN GULF COAST STATES. THUS...HAVE CONTINUED A DRY 
FORECAST.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    89  64  90  65 /  10  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       87  62  87  61 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    89  63  90  65 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     90  66  90  66 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  86  62  87  61 /  10  10   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     91  67  91  66 /  10  10  10  10 
SEARCY AR         89  64  89  64 /  10  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      89  62  90  65 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   89  60  89  63 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29/57






556 
FXUS64 KLZK 120152
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
850 PM CDT SAT SEP 11 2004

WINDS HAVE BECOME LIGHT OR CALM. UPDATE HAS BEEN SENT OUT ALREADY TO 
CLEAN UP THE REFERENCES TO THE WINDS BECOMING CALM. PREVIOUS 
DISCUSSION FOLLOWS. 32

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
WEAK SFC HIGH PERSISTS ACRS AR THIS AFTN. DEWPOINTS HAVE MADE A BIT 
OF RECOVERY OVER THE PAST 24 HOURS...WITH MID 50S TO MID 60S COMMON. 
AFTN CU FIELD OVER MUCH OF THE AREA WILL DISSIPATE SOON AFTER SUNSET 
THIS EVENING.

MODEL SOLUTIONS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT FOR THE SHORT TERM. WEAK UPPER 
LVL SYS OVER ERN KS IS PROGGED TO DROP SLOWLY SEWD THRU SUN. SYS IS 
FCST TO EVENTUALLY MEANDER IN THE VCNTY OF THE MS RVR REGION INTO 
MON BEFORE LIFTING OUT OF THE AREA. WITH SIG MOISTURE STILL 
LIMITED...WL NOT MENTION ANY POPS FOR ERN ZNS ATTM. UPPER SYS LIFTS 
OUT OF THE REGION MON NIGHT AND TUE ALLOWING WEAK UPPER RDG TO BUILD 
IN ALONG WITH CONTD DRY WX.

EXPECT HIGH TEMPS TO RMN AT NEAR NORMAL LVLS THE NEXT FEW DAYS. 
OVERNIGHT LOWS WILL SLOLY MODERATE AS SFC WINDS BECOME MORE SELY 
DURG THE PD. HAVE GENERALLY GONE WITH A BLEND OF THE VARIOUS MOS 
NUMBERS FOR TEMPS.
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
A WEAK COLD FRONT WILL STAY JUST TO THE NORTH IN MISSOURI ON 
WEDNESDAY. HOWEVER...NOT MUCH MOISTURE TO WORK WITH...SO WILL ONLY 
SEE AN INCREASE IN CLOUD COVER. HIGH PRESSURE ONCE AGAIN WILL 
STRENGTHEN OVER THE STATE...WITH THE REMNANTS OF HURRICANE IVAN 
STAYING TO THE EAST. ANOTHER WEAK FRONT WILL APPROACH THE STATE 
SATURDAY AFTERNOON...BUT AGAIN WILL ONLY SEE AN INCREASE IN CLOUDS. 
TEMPERATURES WILL BE SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



111 
FXUS64 KLZK 110706
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT SAT SEP 11 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY
RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE AT THE SURFACE FROM THE NORTHEAST WILL CONTINUE
IN THE AREA IN SOME WAY SHAPE OR FORM OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS KEEPING
LIGHT EAST OR NORTHEAST WINDS AT LOW LEVELS AND KEEPING MOISTURE
LEVELS LOW. A WEAK SHORT WAVE ALOFT MOVES THROUGH TODAY AND TONIGHT
AND SLIDES PAST THE AREA ON SUNDAY. ETA KEEPS THIS SHORT WAVE IN THE
EASTERN PART OF THE AREA AND TRIES TO DRAW IVAN TO THE WEST TOWARDS 
THIS...BUT DISCOUNTED THAT SOLUTION. WEATHER SHOULD CHANGE LITTLE
THROUGH TUESDAY WITH MAYBE A SLIGHT WARMING TREND. COULD BE SOME 
INCREASED CLOUDINESS TO THE EAST SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY DUE TO THE 
SHORT WAVE TOWARD THAT AREA. PATCH OF LOW TO MID CLOUDS HAS 
DEVELOPED IN SOUTHWESTERN ARKANSAS EARLY THIS MORNING AND INCREASED 
CLOUD COVER FOR THE SOUTH FOR THIS MORNING BUT FIGURE THESE SHOULD 
MIX OUT BY THIS AFTERNOON.  
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
ONCE AGAIN...EXTENDED LOOKS TO BE UNEVENTFUL. PERSISTENT 500MB RIDGE 
OVER THE MID MISSISSIPPI VALLEY WILL CUT OFF ANY SYSTEMS MOVING 
EASTWARD FROM THE PLAINS THROUGH THE EXTENDED PERIODS. SURFACE FLOW 
WILL MAINLY BE OUT OF THE EAST...THUS NO MAJOR INFLUX OF WARM AIR OR 
MOISTURE IS EXPECTED. POSITION OF THE RIDGE SHOULD NEGATE ANY 
POTENTIAL INFLUENCE FROM HURRICANE IVAN. 

BOTTOM LINE IS THAT DRY WEATHER WILL CONTINUE...WITH NEAR TO 
SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES EXPECTED. (57).
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  63  90  64 /  10   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       85  58  86  60 /  10   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    88  63  90  64 /  10   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     89  64  90  65 /  10   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  86  58  86  61 /  10   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     90  65  91  67 /  10   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         87  63  89  63 /  10   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      88  63  90  64 /  10   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   87  62  89  63 /  10   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

OVER THE MID MISSISSIPPI VALLEY WILL CUT OFF ANY SYSTEMS MOVING 
EASTWARD FROM THE PLAINS THROUGH THE EXTENDED PERIODS. SURFACE FLOW 
WILL MAINLY BE OUT OF THE EAST...THUS NO MAJOR INFLUX OF WARM AIR OR 
MOISTURE IS EXPECTED. POSITION OF THE RIDGE SHOULD NEGATE ANY 
POTENTIAL INFLUENCE FROM HURRICANE IVAN. 

BOTTOM LINE IS THAT DRY WEATHER WILL CONTINUE...WITH NEAR TO 
SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES EXPECTED. (57).
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  63  90  64 /  10   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       85  58  86  60 /  10   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    88  63  90  64 /  10   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     89  64  90  65 /  10   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  86  58  86  61 /  10   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     90  65  91  67 /  10   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         87  63  89  63 /  10   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      88  63  90  64 /  10   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   87  62  89  63 /  10   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

FXUS64 KLZK 101926
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
225 PM CDT FRI SEP 10 2004

.DISCUSSION...
STRONG HIGH PRESSURE REMAINS IN CONTROL. CUMULUS FIELD HAS DEVELOPED 
IN THE SOUTH AND EAST THIS AFTERNOON...WITH SCATTERED CLOUDS OVER 
THE STATE DURING THE AFTERNOON FOR MUCH OF THE UPCOMING WEEK. A WEAK 
SHORTWAVE WILL MOVE OVER THE STATE SATURDAY INTO EARLY SUNDAY...BUT 
WILL ONLY BRING AN INCREASE IN CLOUDS. REGION WILL REMAIN PRECIP 
FREE THROUGH THE UPCOMING WEEK. IVAN LOOKS TO STAY TO THE EAST OF 
THE AREA. MAY SEE AN INCREASE IN WIND SPEEDS IF PRESSURE GRADIENT 
GETS CLOSE TO THE AREA. DEWPOINTS WILL SLOWLY BEGIN TO CLIMB OVER 
THE WEEKEND. TEMPERATURES WILL SHOW A VERY SLOW WARMING 
TREND....WITH READINGS NEAR TO SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    62  89  63  90 /   0  10   0   0



242 
FXUS64 KLZK 100728
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT FRI SEP 10 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY
SURFACE RIDGE EXTENDS INTO THE AREA FROM THE NORTHEAST AND THIS 
PATTERN IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE FOR THE SHORT TERM AND BEYOND. 
THIS WILL KEEP LIMITED MOISTURE IN THE AREA AS THE GULF STAYS 
CUT OFF. A WEAK SHORT WAVE OR TWO ALOFT MOVES THROUGH THE AREA
THROUGH SATURDAY BEFORE SETTLING INTO THE SOUTHEASTERN U.S. BUT
IT SHOULD DO LITTLE MORE THAN CAUSE A FEW CLOUDS. TEMPS WILL 
PROBABLY SHOW A SLOW WARMING TREND AND BE CLOSE TO OR A LITTLE ABOVE
NORMAL ON MAXES AND CLOSE TO OR A LITTLE BELOW NORMAL ON MINS.  
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
NO MAJOR CHANGES HAVE BEEN MADE TO THE EXTENDED FORECAST. EXTENDED 
RANGE MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT THIS MORNING...KEEPING DRY AIR 
OVER THE FORECAST AREA FOR THE DURATION. LARGE H5 RIDGE EAST OF THE 
MISSISSIPPI RIVER WILL PRECLUDE ANY FORWARD MOVEMENT OF SYSTEMS IN 
FROM THE PLAINS. SURFACE FLOW WILL MOSTLY BE EASTERLY...SO NO 
SIGNIFICANT INFLUX OF MOISTURE WILL BE NOTED. JUST NEAR NORMAL 
TEMPERATURES...AND LITTLE IN THE WAY OF RAINFALL. (57).
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  62  90  63 /   0   0  10  10 
HARRISON AR       85  59  87  61 /   0   0  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    88  62  90  63 /   0   0  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     88  62  90  64 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  85  59  87  61 /   0   0  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     88  62  91  65 /   0   0  10  10 
SEARCY AR         88  61  89  63 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      88  61  90  63 /   0   0  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   88  60  89  63 /   0   0  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

TEMPERATURES WILL SHOW A VERY SLOW WARMING TREND. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
HIGH PRESSURE WILL MOVE EAST AS A LONG WAVE TROUGH MOVES INTO THE 
INTERMOUNTAIN WEST. A FEW WEAK DISTURBANCES WILL MOVE THROUGH IN THE 
FLOW NEXT WEEK...BUT ONLY INCREASE THE CLOUD COVER. DRY CONDITIONS 
WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE EXTENDED FORECAST.


309 
FXUS64 KLZK 090828
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
325 AM CDT THU SEP 9 2004

.DISCUSSION...
FIRST PART OF FORECAST WILL FEATURE BELOW NORMAL TEMPERATURES...AT 
LEAST TODAY/TONIGHT. SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE PROVIDING LOW 
DEWPOINTS...LEADING TO COOL NIGHTS/LOW AFTERNOON HUMIDITY LEVELS. 

FAIRLY PROGRESSIVE PATTERN/NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT TO START 
FORECAST...WITH HIGH PRESSURE EXITING FRIDAY/SATURDAY. 
TEMPERATURES/DEWPOINTS WILL BEGIN A SLOW CLIMB TO MORE NORMAL 
LEVELS. 

A FEW WEAK SYSTEMS ALOFT WILL RIDE FLOW OVER STATE THE NEXT FEW 
DAYS. OVERALL...THE SYSTEMS WILL NOT DO MUCH...BUT WILL PROVIDE SOME 
CLOUDS HEADING INTO THE WEEKEND GIVEN SLIGHTLY HIGHER DEWPOINTS/A 
LITTLE MORE MOISTURE TO WORK WITH. WHILE THERE MAY BE A FEW MORE 
CLOUDS...NO PRECIPITATION IS EXPECTED. 

A DRY FORECAST WILL CONTINUE INTO NEXT WEEK. LATE IN THE 
WEEKEND/EARLY NEXT WEEK...A COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH FROM THE NORTH. 
HOWEVER...IT APPEARS THAT IT WILL BE A GLANCING BLOW...WITH MAIN 
EFFECTS INTO OHIO VALLEY. AFTER FRONT...STORM SYSTEM WILL GET 
ORGANIZED IN THE ROCKIES TOWARD MIDWEEK WITH A RIDGE OF HIGH 
PRESSURE STRENGTHENING IN THE CENTRAL UNITED STATES. THUS...WILL 
KEEP IT WARM WITH LITTLE IF ANY RAIN. (46)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    85  59  89  63 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       83  55  85  60 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    85  59  89  63 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     85  59  89  63 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  82  55  84  60 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     85  58  89  63 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         84  58  87  62 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      85  58  90  62 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   84  57  89  61 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

721 
FXUS64 KLZK 081916
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
215 PM CDT WED SEP  8 2004

.SHORT TERM...
HIGH PRESSURE OVER THE REGION FOR THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS. THUS THE 
MAIN ISSUE WITH THIS FORECAST IS TEMPERATURES. COOL READINGS THIS 
MORNING...ESPECIALLY IN THE WEST...AND BELIEVE THIS WILL HOLD TRUE 
FOR TONIGHT. WENT A DEGREE OR TWO BELOW GUIDANCE FOR LOWS THURSDAY 
MORNING.

HIGH PRESSURE ALOFT OVER THE SOUTHWEST WILL GRADUALLY MOVE EAST 
THROUGH THE END OF THE WEEK. TEMPS WILL GRADUALLY WARM THROUGH 
SATURDAY...REACHING ABOVE NORMAL READINGS. DUE TO THE STRONG HIGH 
PRESSURE...AREA WILL REMAIN PRECIP AND ALMOST CLOUD FREE.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
MODEL SOLUTIONS STILL SHOWING A MORE AMPLIFIED UPPER FLOW PATTERN 
ACRS THE COUNTRY...WITH TROF DVLPG OVER THE WRN STATES AND UPPER 
HGTS INCRSG IN THE E. THIS WILL ALLOW TEMPS TO GRADUALLY RETURN TO 
MORE NORMAL LVLS DURG THE PD AND CURRENT FCST TEMPS LOOK GOOD. STILL 
LOOKS LIKE THE EFFECTS OF IVAN WILL STAY TO THE E OF THE FA.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    57  85  59  89 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       51  83  55  87 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    57  85  59  89 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     58  85  59  89 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  51  82  55  86 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     58  85  58  89 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         56  84  58  88 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      57  85  58  90 /   0   0   0   0

ACRS THE COUNTRY...WITH TROF DVLPG OVER THE WRN STATES AND UPPER 
HGTS INCRSG IN THE E. THIS WILL ALLOW TEMPS TO GRADUALLY RETURN TO 
MORE NORMAL LVLS DURG THE PD AND CURRENT FCST TEMPS LOOK GOOD. STILL 
LOOKS LIKE THE EFFECTS OF IVAN WILL STAY TO THE E OF THE FA.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    57  85  59  89 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       51  83  55  87 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    57  85  59  89 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     58  85  59  89 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  51  82  55  86 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     58  85  58  89 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         56  84  58  88 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      57  85  58  90 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   55  84  57  89 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

611 
FXUS64 KLZK 080858
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
350 AM CDT WED SEP 8 2004

.DISCUSSION...
NOT A LOT GOING ON THIS GO AROUND. REMNANTS OF FRANCES MOVING INTO 
OHIO VALLEY...WITH FRONT HEADING EAST OF THE REGION. HIGH PRESSURE 
WILL BUILD INTO THE PLAINS...WITH COOL NIGHTS/LOW AFTERNOON HUMIDITY 
LEVELS AND BELOW NORMAL TEMPERATURES THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS. 

UNTIL HIGH ARRIVES...STILL A LITTLE BREEZY TODAY...BUT NOT AS MUCH 
AS ON TUESDAY WHEN FRANCES WAS A LITTLE CLOSER. 

LOOKING AHEAD...OVERALL PATTERN WILL CHANGE A BIT HEADING INTO THE 
WEEKEND. TROUGH OF LOW PRESSURE WILL DIG IN THE WESTERN UNITED 
STATES. THIS WILL CAUSE RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE TO BUILD FARTHER 
EAST. TEMPERATURES WILL SLOWLY CLIMB UNDER THE RIDGE...WITH READINGS 
PRETTY CLOSE TO NORMAL BY THIS WEEKEND. HUMIDITY LEVELS WILL ALSO GO 
UP A LITTLE...WITH A FEW MORE CLOUDS POPPING UP DURING THE HEAT OF 
THE DAY. HOWEVER...NOTHING TO SUGGEST ANY PRECIPITATION...AND NONE 
ADDED TO THE FORECAST AT THIS TIME. (46)                
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  58  84  61 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       79  51  82  56 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    83  58  85  60 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  59  85  59 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  79  50  82  55 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     83  58  85  57 /   0   0   0   0

669 
FXUS64 KLZK 080157 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
857 PM CDT TUE SEP 7 2004

.DISCUSSION...
RATHER NICE EVENING ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA TONIGHT. RIDGE HAS 
TAKEN HOLD OVER MUCH OF THE WESTERN HALF OF THE COUNTRY...AND AS A 
RESULT...NORTHERLY TO NORTHEASTERLY FLOW CONTINUES TO BRING DRY AIR 
INTO THE AREA. JUST LOOK AT THOSE BEAUTIFUL 40 TO 50 DEGREE 
DEWPOINTS ACROSS NORTHERN AND CENTRAL ARKANSAS. 

ONLY UPDATE TO TEXT FORECASTS THIS EVENING WAS TO CLEAN UP SOME 
TEMPORAL WORDING. OTHERWISE...WITH DRY AIR MAKING ITS WAY IN...AND 
CLEAR SKY OVER THE AREA...FORECASTED MINS IN THE LOWER 50S NORTH TO 
LOWER 60S SOUTH ARE CERTAINLY REASONABLE. 

HAVE ALSO ADJUSTED OTHER PARAMETERS...I.E. DEWPOINTS AND 
HUMIDITIES...TO BETTER ACCOUNT FOR ONGOING WEATHER TRENDS. UPDATE TO 
TEXT FORECASTS IS ALREADY OUT. UPDATED GRIDDED DATA AND GRAPHICAL 
FORECASTS WILL BE OUT VERY SHORTLY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



938 
FXUS64 KLZK 071934
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
233 PM CDT TUE SEP 7 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES TO TRY TO MOVE INTO ARKANSAS FROM THE 
NORTHWEST. HOWEVER TROPICAL DEPRESSION FRANCES WILL HINDER THE 
PROGRESSION OF THE HIGH PRESSURE. CYCLONIC FLOW AROUND FRANCES 
CONTINUES TO BRING CLOUDS SOUTHWARD ACROSS EAST ARKANSAS AND ALONG 
THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER. ALTHOUGH THE CLOUDS IN THE EAST HAVE 
DISSIPATED SOME...AS SEEN ON VISIBLE SATELLITE IMAGERY...PARTLY 
CLOUDY CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED IN THE SOUTHEAST TONIGHT. BREEZY 
CONDITIONS WILL DECREASE A BIT TONIGHT AND WINDS SHOULD NOT BE AS 
STRONG ON WEDNESDAY AS THE GRADIENT SLACKENS AS FRANCES EXITS THE 
AREA. 

AS FRANCES MOVES FURTHER NORTH ON WEDNESDAY...HIGH PRESSURE WILL BE 
ALLOWED TO MOVE INTO ARKANSAS. THE ETA HAS DONE WELL WITH HOLDING 
THE CLOUDS AND MOISTURE IN LONGER OVER THE EASTERN SECTIONS. THE 
MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT LATER IN THE PERIOD. THE HIGH PRESSURE 
AND MUCH DRIER AIR WILL BE THE RULE FOR THE REST OF THE 
WEEK...ELIMINATING THE CHANCES OF RAIN. THEREFORE THE FORECAST WILL 
BE DRY THROUGH SATURDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL BEGIN WARMING LATE IN THE 
WEEK AND TO BEGIN THE WEEKEND.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY...
MODELS CONTINUE TO BE IN GOOD AGREEMENT THIS AFTERNOON WITH THE 
OVERALL PROGRESSIVE FLOW. WILL SIMPLY GO WITH A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS 
THIS AFTERNOON WITH A LEAN TOWARDS THE MORE CONSISTENT AND SLIGHTLY 
FASTER GFS. PATTERN BEGINS WITH RATHER SIGNIFICANT H5 TROUGH 
APPROACHING THE WESTERN UNITED STATES WITH RIDGING OVER THE NATIONS 
MID SECTION. TROF MOVES EASTWARD WHICH IN TURNS PUMPS UP THE RIDGE 
OVER THE MOST OF THE EASTERN HALF OF THE NATION. TROUGH LOOKS LIKE 
IT WILL BE FORCED UP AND OVER THE RIDGE WITH THE WESTERLIES 
REMAINING WELL NORTH OF THE CWA.

ON THE SURFACE...HIGH PRESSURE WILL DOMINATE THE MAJORITY OF THE 
TIME WITH LITTLE IF ANY MOISTURE MOVING THROUGH. WITH ALL THE MODELS 
SHOWING NO SIGNIFICANT SHORTWAVES...WILL CONTINUE THE DRY FORECAST 
THROUGH THE PERIOD. FLOW ALOFT LOOKS WEAK AND GULF APPEARS TO BE CUT 
OFF. WITH DRY AIR IN PLACE...WARM DAYS WITH TEMPERATURES AT OR 
SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL WILL PREVAIL WITH NIGHT TIME TEMPERATURES 
COMFORTABLY COOL. OVERALL HUMIDITY LEVELS WILL BE IN THE NON 
OPPRESSIVE CATEGORY.

WILD CARD IN ALL THIS WILL BE YET ANOTHER STRONG HURRICANE MOVING 
THROUGH THE WESTERN CARIBBEAN. THERE IS SOME DIFFERENCES IN EXACTLY 
WHERE IVAN WILL END UP WITH THE GFS CARRYING IT UP THE EAST COAST 
BUT OTHER MODELS SWING IT INTO THE EASTERN GULF BY EARLY NEXT WEEK. 
IMPACT ON THE CWA LOOKS MINIMAL RIGHT NOW BUT OF COURSE IVAN WILL 
BEAR WATCHING.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    60  83  60  86 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       51  79  52  82 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    59  83  59  86 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     61  83  59  85 /  10   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  52  79  52  82 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     62  83  57  85 /  10   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         58  81  56  83 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      58  84  59  86 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   57  83  56  85 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

.DISCUSSION...

WILL MAINLY UPDATE FOR THE MORNING WORDING. WILL NOT EXPECT ANY MORE 
RAIN ACROSS THE AREA THIS AFTERNOON. CLOUDS WILL HANG AROUND IN THE 
EAST AND SOUTHERN SECTIONS FOR A FEW HOURS...THEN BEGIN TO DECREASE. 
TEMPERATURES SEEM TO BE ON TRACK WITH COLD AIR ADVECTION CONTINUING 
THROUGHOUT THE DAY. DEW POINTS ARE FROM 50 DEGREES IN THE NORTH TO 
THE MID 60S IN THE SOUTHEAST AND WILL CONTINUE TO DECREASE THIS 
AFTERNOON.

645 
FXUS64 KLZK 070845
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
340 AM CDT TUE SEP 7 2004

.DISCUSSION...
COLD FRONT HAS PUSHED ACROSS MUCH OF ARKANSAS THIS MORNING...AND 
SITTING PRETTY MUCH ALONG THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER. APPEARS THAT FRONT 
WILL SLOW DOWN AND WILL ACTUALLY STALL JUST EAST OF THE STATE 
TODAY/TONIGHT. FRONT WILL WAIT FOR REMNANTS OF HURRICANE FRANCES TO 
MOVE THROUGH THE SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES.

BEHIND THE FRONT...QUITE A FEW CLOUDS THIS MORNING IN CENTRAL AND 
EASTERN ARKANSAS. UNDER THE CLOUDS...SOME PATCHY RAIN NOTED EARLY 
THIS MORNING...WITH MEASURABLE RAIN AROUND 08Z IN NORTH LITTLE 
ROCK.

GIVEN THIS...WILL KEEP CLOUDS AND A SLIGHT CHANCE OF RAIN IN 
CENTRAL/EASTERN ARKANSAS THIS MORNING. CLOUDS SHOULD ERODE THIS 
AFTERNOON WITH NO RAIN EXPECTED. 

HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD BEHIND THE FRONT TODAY. BETWEEN THE HIGH 
AND THE REMNANTS OF FRANCES...A BREEZY NORTH/NORTHEAST WIND WILL BE 
GENERATED AND THIS COVERED IN THE FORECAST.

LOOKING AHEAD...THE HIGH WILL PROVIDE DRY AIR/LOW DEWPOINTS...WITH 
COOL TEMPERATURES WEDNESDAY/THURSDAY MORNINGS. LOW HUMIDITY LEVELS 
WILL BE NOTED DURING THE AFTERNOON...WITH BELOW NORMAL 
TEMPERATURES. 

HEADING INTO THE UPCOMING WEEKEND...DRY WEATHER WILL CONTINUE. 
HOWEVER...TEMPERATURES WILL BEGIN TO MODIFY...WITH READINGS CLOSER 
TO NORMAL. DEWPOINTS NOT QUITE SO LOW EITHER. (46)             
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  60  81  57 /  20   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       80  51  79  54 /  10   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  59  83  58 /  10   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  61  82  58 /  20  10   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  80  52  79  54 /  10   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     84  62  83  58 /  20  10   0   0 
SEARCY AR         82  58  81  57 /  20   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      84  58  84  58 /  10   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   83  57  83  57 /  10   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

311 
FXUS64 KLZK 070212 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
912 PM CDT MON SEP 6 2004

.DISCUSSION...
COLD FRONT CURRENTLY INDICATED FROM NEAR THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER IN 
NORTHEAST ARKANSAS...TO NORTH CENTRAL LOUISIANA...AND PROGRESSING 
AHEAD. DRIER AIR CONTINUES TO FILTER IN BEHIND THE SYSTEM...AS 
EVIDENCED BY 60 DEGREE ISODROSOTHERM FROM EAST OF BATESVILLE TO NEAR 
HOT SPRINGS. 

DRIER AIR WILL CONTINUE MOVING IN FOR THE REMAINDER OF TONIGHT. 
PRECIP HAS ENDED FOR THE EVENING...AND AS SUCH...WILL REMOVE IT FROM 
THE FORECAST. CLOUDS SHOULD CONTINUE TO BREAK UP BEHIND THE 
FRONT...WITH THE WEST BECOMING MOSTLY CLEAR BY MORNING. TEMPS COULD 
VERY WILL DIP DOWN INTO THE MID 50S IN NORTHWEST ARKANSAS.

UPDATE WILL BE FORTHCOMING...TO REMOVE PRECIP...CLEAN UP SOME 
TEMPORAL WORDING...AND TO ADJUST OTHER WEATHER PARAMETERS TO BETTER 
ACCOUNT FOR ONGOING TRENDS. FORECASTED MIN TEMPERATURES APPEAR TO BE 
ATTAINABLE. AMENDED PACKAGE OUT BY 930 PM. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

000 
FXUS64 KLZK 070212 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
912 PM CDT MON SEP 6 2004

.DISCUSSION...
COLD FRONT CURRENTLY INDICATED FROM NEAR THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER IN 
NORTHEAST ARKANSAS...TO NORTH CENTRAL LOUISIANA...AND PROGRESSING 
AHEAD. DRIER AIR CONTINUES TO FILTER IN BEHIND THE SYSTEM...AS 
EVIDENCED BY 60 DEGREE ISODROSOTHERM FROM EAST OF BATESVILLE TO NEAR 
HOT SPRINGS. 

DRIER AIR WILL CONTINUE MOVING IN FOR THE REMAINDER OF TONIGHT. 
PRECIP HAS ENDED FOR THE EVENING...AND AS SUCH...WILL REMOVE IT FROM 
THE FORECAST. CLOUDS SHOULD CONTINUE TO BREAK UP BEHIND THE 
FRONT...WITH THE WEST BECOMING MOSTLY CLEAR BY MORNING. TEMPS COULD 
VERY WILL DIP DOWN INTO THE MID 50S IN NORTHWEST ARKANSAS.

UPDATE WILL BE FORTHCOMING...TO REMOVE PRECIP...CLEAN UP SOME 
TEMPORAL WORDING...AND TO ADJUST OTHER WEATHER PARAMETERS TO BETTER 
ACCOUNT FOR ONGOING TRENDS. FORECASTED MIN TEMPERATURES APPEAR TO BE 
ATTAINABLE. AMENDED PACKAGE OUT BY 930 PM. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

57





427 
FXUS64 KLZK 061841
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
139 PM CDT MON SEP  6 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT...
MODELS IN GOOD AGREEMENT THROUGH THE PERIOD WITH NO REAL DIFFERENCES 
SEEN. MODELS ARE CONSISTENT WITH CARRYING WHATS LEFT OF FRANCES OFF 
TO THE NORTHEAST AND SWEEPING A COLD FRONT THROUGH THE STATE EARLY. 
THAT BEING SAID...WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS THIS 
AFTERNOON. 

LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES THE COLD FRONT ROUGHLY ALONG A SALEM 
TO CABOT TO MAGNOLIA LINE AND CRAWLING EASTWARD. LARGE AREA OF 
SHOWERS THAT WAS MOVING ACROSS WESTERN ARKANSAS THIS MORNING HAS 
DISIPATED INTO MORE OF THE HIT AND MISS VARIETY AS THE FRONT RUNS 
INTO DRIER AIR AND LARGE SCALE SUBSIDENCE ON THE BACK SIDE OF WHATS 
LEFT OF HURRICANE FRANCES. MODELS ARE SLOW TO MOVE THE FRONT THROUGH 
OVERNIGHT. WITH SOME DECENT MOISTURE AND FORCING WILL KEEP SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS IN THIS EVENING OVER CENTRAL SECTIONS AND THROUGH EARLY 
MORNING OVER THE SOUTHEAST UNTIL THE FRONT FINALLY DOES CLEAR THE 
STATE.

GRADIENT TIGHTENS UP FOR TUESDAY AS STRONG HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS INTO 
ARKANSAS FROM THE NORTH AND THE REMNANTS OF THE HURRICANE CONTINUE 
OVER THE SOUTHEAST CONUS. NORTHEAST WINDS OF 10 TO 20 MPH WILL BE 
COMMONPLACE. COOLER AND DRIER AIR WILL BE SWEPT BACK INTO THE STATE 
AS NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT DEVELOPS. BROAD TROFFING OVER THE EASTERN 
CONUS AND UPPER LEVEL HIGH OVER THE FOUR CORNERS WILL PERSIST 
THROUGH THE PERIOD AND MAINTAIN THE NORTHWEST FLOW. WESTERLIES WILL 
BE CONFINED TO THE NORTHERN TIER OF THE NATION AND WITH NO 
APPRECIABLE SHORTWAVES SEEN...WILL GO WITH A DRY FORECAST FROM 
TUESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH THE END OF THE PERIOD.

MODELS BRINGING IN DEW POINTS IN THE LOWER 50S MID WEEK. FEEL THIS 
WILL BE TOO COOL BUT MUCH DRIER AIR WILL BE RETURNING TO THE AREA. 
TEMPERATURES WILL AVERAGE A FEW DEGREES BELOW NORMAL THROUGH THE END 
OF THE PERIOD. WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF MAV/FWC NUMBERS.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY...
MID LEVEL RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHWEST U.S. WILL BUILD EASTWARD NEXT 
WEEKEND. GFS KEEPS DRY AIR IN PLACE...WHICH LOOKS REASONABLE...AND 
NO PRECIPITATION IS EXPECTED DURING THE EXTENDED PERIOD. JET STREAM 
STAYS NORTH OF THE AREA AND KEEPS SYSTEMS MOVING ACROSS THE NORTHERN 
U.S. TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN NEAR TO SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL WITH 
MOSTLY CLEAR TO PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES. 

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    65  83  60  84 /  20  10   0   0 
HARRISON AR       56  81  51  79 /  10  10   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    64  84  59  84 /  20  10   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     66  84  61  85 /  20  10  10   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  56  80  52  79 /  20  10   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     67  85  62  85 /  20  10  10   0 
SEARCY AR         64  83  58  83 /  20  10   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      62  84  58  84 /  20  10   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   60  83  57  83 /  20  10   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



194 
FXUS64 KLZK 061510
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
954 AM CDT MON SEP  6 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS TO BE IN OUTSTANDING SHAPE AND NO CHANGES ARE 
NEEDED THIS MORNING. LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS HAS COLD FRONT ROUGHLY 
BISECTING THE STATE FROM NORTHEAST TO SOUTHWEST. FRONT WILL MOVE 
EASTWARD WITH TIME REST OF THE DAY BUT IT WILL BE SLOW GOING AS IT 
RUNS INTO THE UPPER LEVEL RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHEAST CONUS.

AREA OF SHOWERS AND ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS CONTINUES TO CRAWL TO THE 
EAST AND IS ACTUALLY DISSIPATING WITH TIME AND NOT MUCH PRECIP 
EXPECTED TO MAKE IT OVER TO THE SOUTHEAST PART OF THE STATE. CURRENT 
FORECAST HAS THIS PEGGED AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF POPS LOOKS 
RIGHT ON TARGET. CURRENT TEMPS AND WINDS ONLY NEED MINOR TWEAKING 
WHICH WILL HAVE NO CHANGES ON THE SENSIBLE FORECAST.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
COLD FRONT APPROACHING ARKANSAS FROM THE NORTHWEST EARLY THIS 
MORNING. LARGE AREA OF SHOWERS/A FEW THUNDERSTORMS AHEAD OF THE 
FRONT...AND INTO NORTHWEST SECTIONS OF THE STATE AS OF 3 AM. FRONT 
WILL PROGRESS THROUGH WESTERN/CENTRAL ARKANSAS THROUGH THIS 
EVENING...AND WILL EXIT THE STATE TO THE EAST LATE TONIGHT/TUESDAY 
MORNING. 

SCATTERED/NUMEROUS SHOWERS AND ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS IN THE 
FORECAST TODAY...ESPECIALLY IN THE WESTERN HALF OF THE STATE. 
APPEARS THAT PRECIPITATION WILL BECOME MORE SCATTERED AS IT MOVES 
EAST...WITH LITTLE IF ANY PRECIPITATION TOWARD THE MISSISSIPPI 
RIVER. 

BY THIS EVENING...ONLY SLIGHT CHANCES FOR SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS 
MENTIONED FOR CENTRAL/EASTERN ARKANSAS...WITH DRY AIR FOUND BEHIND 
THE FRONT FARTHER WEST. 

ON TUESDAY...OTHER THAN MAYBE A LINGERING SHOWER OR TWO IN THE 
EAST...WILL BE A BREEZY DAY WITH SLIGHTLY COOLER TEMPERATURES. 
REMNANTS OF FRANCES WILL BE HEADING THROUGH SOUTHEAST UNITED 
STATES...WITH FAIRLY STRONG HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING INTO ARKANSAS 
FROM THE PLAINS. BETWEEN THE TWO SYSTEMS...A BREEZY NORTH/NORTHEAST 
WIND WILL BE GENERATED.

LOOKING AHEAD...DRY AIR WILL LEAD TO COOL MORNINGS/SLIGHTLY BELOW 
NORMAL TEMPERATURES DURING THE AFTERNOON WEDNESDAY/THURSDAY. MERCURY 
LEVELS WILL BEGIN MODIFYING A BIT LATER IN THE WEEK...WITH DRY 
CONDITIONS HOLDING THROUGH NEXT WEEKEND. (46)            

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

527 
FXUS64 KLZK 060202 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
902 PM CDT SUN SEP 5 2004

ISOLATED CONVECTION CURRENTLY MOVING NORTHEASTWARD OVER EASTERN 
OKLAHOMA...BUT NOT MUCH IS MATERIALIZING THANKS TO LOSS OF DAYTIME 
HEATING...AND A VERY WEAK CAP STILL IN PLACE OVER THE FORECAST AREA. 
ALTOCU CONTINUES INCREASING FROM THE SOUTH AND SOUTHWEST OUT AHEAD 
OF APPROACHING FRONTAL BOUNDARY. AND SPEAKING OF THE FRONTAL 
BOUNDARY...LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS IT FROM ERN KANSAS INTO 
WESTERN OKLAHOMA AND TEXAS. LINE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS HAS 
ORGANIZED ALONG THE BOUNDARY...BUT THESE HAVE NOT BEEN SIGNIFICANT 
AT ALL. MOST IMPRESSIVE CONVECTION HAS BEEN AND WILL CONTINUE TO BE 
IN THE UPPER MIDWEST...NEAR THE BETTER UPPER SUPPORT AND SURFACE 
LOW. 

WILL BE ISSUING AN UPDATE THIS EVENING...WITH SEVERAL ISSUES IN 
MIND. FIRST...WILL CLEAN UP SOME TEMPORAL WORDING IN THE FORECAST. 
HAVE ALSO READJUSTED POPS A BIT. STILL KEEPING HIGHER RAIN CHANCES 
OVER THE WESTERN FORECAST AREA...BUT HAVE TRIMMED BACK THE POPS 
UNTIL AFTER MIDNIGHT. ALSO...DEWPOINTS ARE FAIRLY HIGH...WITH MID 
60S TO LOWER AND MID 70S NOTED. WINDS HAVE SUBSIDED QUITE A BIT OVER 
MOST OF THE FORECAST AREA...BUT WILL LIKELY PICK UP IN THE WEST 
TOWARD MORNING AS THE BOUNDARY APPROACHES. CANNOT RULE OUT PATCHY 
FOG...BUT ANY FOG THAT DEVELOPS WILL NOT BE WIDESPREAD...AND WOULD 
BE MOST LIKELY IN RIVER BOTTOMS AND OTHER OUTLYING AREAS.

UPDATE WILL BE OUT BY 930 PM. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

153 
FXUS64 KLZK 051947
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
245 PM CDT SUN SEP  5 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
A FEW SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS DEVELOPED OVER MAINLY THE WESTERN 
HALF OF THE FORECAST AREA LATE THIS MORNING AND CONTINUE THIS 
AFTERNOON. COLD FRONT OVER THE CENTRAL PLAINS THIS AFTERNOON WILL 
CONTINUE TO MOVE TOWARD ARKANSAS TONIGHT. WILL INCREASE POPS SLOWLY 
FROM WEST TO EAST DURING THE NIGHT. FRONT SHOULD MOVE INTO THE STATE 
ON LABOR DAY AND MOVE SLOWLY THROUGH. HAVE SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS FORECAST FOR LABOR DAY WITH POPS IN THE 30-40 PCT 
RANGE. BEST CHANCES WILL BE OVER THE NORTHERN AND WESTERN SECTIONS 
WHERE MOISTURE WILL BE A LITTLE BETTER. LEFT SMALL LINGERING POPS IN 
FOR MONDAY NIGHT. DRIER AIR WILL MOVE IN BEHIND FRONT...PLUS 
SUBSIDENCE TO THE WEST OF FRANCES WILL MAKE FOR DRY CONDITIONS THE 
REMAINDER OF THE SHORT TERM. 
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
AN UPPER LEVEL RIDGE WILL BUILD GRADUALLY DURING THE EXTENDED 
PERIOD. THERE WILL BE DRY WEATHER AND A SURFACE HIGH TO ACCOMPANY 
THE UPPER RIDGE. TEMPERATURES WILL BE TYPICAL AND DEW POINTS WILL BE 
LOWER.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    89  71  89  67 /  20  20  30  20 
HARRISON AR       87  68  83  60 /  20  30  40  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    90  71  88  66 /  20  30  30  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     89  71  89  68 /  20  20  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  87  68  83  60 /  20  30  30  20 
MONTICELLO AR     89  71  90  69 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         89  71  88  66 /  20  20  30  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      90  71  87  66 /  20  30  40  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   89  70  86  64 /  20  30  40  20 
&&

000 
FXUS64 KLZK 051947
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
245 PM CDT SUN SEP  5 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
A FEW SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS DEVELOPED OVER MAINLY THE WESTERN 
HALF OF THE FORECAST AREA LATE THIS MORNING AND CONTINUE THIS 
AFTERNOON. COLD FRONT OVER THE CENTRAL PLAINS THIS AFTERNOON WILL 
CONTINUE TO MOVE TOWARD ARKANSAS TONIGHT. WILL INCREASE POPS SLOWLY 
FROM WEST TO EAST DURING THE NIGHT. FRONT SHOULD MOVE INTO THE STATE 
ON LABOR DAY AND MOVE SLOWLY THROUGH. HAVE SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS FORECAST FOR LABOR DAY WITH POPS IN THE 30-40 PCT 
RANGE. BEST CHANCES WILL BE OVER THE NORTHERN AND WESTERN SECTIONS 
WHERE MOISTURE WILL BE A LITTLE BETTER. LEFT SMALL LINGERING POPS IN 
FOR MONDAY NIGHT. DRIER AIR WILL MOVE IN BEHIND FRONT...PLUS 
SUBSIDENCE TO THE WEST OF FRANCES WILL MAKE FOR DRY CONDITIONS THE 
REMAINDER OF THE SHORT TERM. 
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
AN UPPER LEVEL RIDGE WILL BUILD GRADUALLY DURING THE EXTENDED 
PERIOD. THERE WILL BE DRY WEATHER AND A SURFACE HIGH TO ACCOMPANY 
THE UPPER RIDGE. TEMPERATURES WILL BE TYPICAL AND DEW POINTS WILL BE 
LOWER.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    89  71  89  67 /  20  20  30  20 
HARRISON AR       87  68  83  60 /  20  30  40  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    90  71  88  66 /  20  30  30  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     89  71  89  68 /  20  20  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  87  68  83  60 /  20  30  30  20 
MONTICELLO AR     89  71  90  69 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         89  71  88  66 /  20  20  30  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      90  71  87  66 /  20  30  40  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   89  70  86  64 /  20  30  40  20

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.



562 
FXUS64 KLZK 050857
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
345 AM CDT SUN SEP 5 2004

.DISCUSSION...
STILL PLENTY OF LOW LEVEL MOISTURE ACROSS THE REGION THIS MORNING.
WILL BE SOME LOW CLOUDS/PATCHY DENSE FOG AS A RESULT DURING THE
MORNING HOURS. BY LATE MORNING/EARLY AFTERNOON...DAYTIME HEATING 
WILL TRIGGER ISOLATED TO SCATTERED SHOWERS AND PERHAPS A FEW 
THUNDERSTORMS...MAINLY OVER THE SOUTHWEST HALF OF ARKANSAS. 

COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH FROM THE WEST TONIGHT/MONDAY. ISOLATED 
SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS IN THE FORECAST AHEAD OF THE FRONT 
OVERNIGHT IN THE WEST...WITH SCATTERED PRECIPITATION IN MOST AREAS 
ON MONDAY.

FRONT WILL BE HELD UP SOMEWHAT BY REMNANTS OF FRANCES...WHICH WILL 
HEAD INTO THE SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES BY TUESDAY OR SO. FAIRLY 
STRONG HIGH PRESSURE BEHIND FRONT ALONG WITH CIRCULATION AROUND 
FRANCES WILL CREATE BREEZY NORTH/NORTHEAST WIND ACROSS ARKANSAS. 

SINCE ARKANSAS WILL BE EXPERIENCING QUITE A BIT OF SUBSIDENCE TO THE 
WEST OF FRANCES ON TUESDAY...ANY PRECIPITATION ALONG/NEAR FRONT WILL 
PRETTY MUCH DISSIPATE...WITH CHANCES FOR RAIN DROPPING. ALSO...AIR 
BEHIND THE FRONT QUITE DRY...AND WILL BE FILTERING INTO REGION. 

BY MIDWEEK...DRY AIR IN PLACE...WHICH WILL YIELD LOWER AFTERNOON 
HUMIDITY LEVELS AND SLIGHTLY COOLER NIGHTS. DAYTIME TEMPERATURES 
WILL REMAIN RATHER WARM...BUT PRETTY CLOSE TO NORMAL.

APPEARS THAT DRY WEATHER/CLOSE TO NORMAL TEMPERATURES WILL HOLD INTO 
NEXT WEEKEND. (46)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    89  71  90  70 /  20  20  30  20 
HARRISON AR       87  68  84  63 /  20  30  30  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    90  71  89  70 /  20  30  30  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     89  71  90  70 /  20  20  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  87  68  84  63 /  20  30  30  20 
MONTICELLO AR     89  71  91  70 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         89  71  89  69 /  20  20  30  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      90  71  88  69 /  20  30  30  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   89  70  87  67 /  20  30  30  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



038 
FXUS64 KLZK 042017
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT SAT SEP  4 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY
FEW SHOWERS OVER CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN ARKANSAS THIS AFTERNOON ARE 
EXPECTED TO CONTINUE INTO EARLY EVENING. HAVE PUT PATCHY FOG IN ALL 
AREAS AFTER MIDNIGHT AS CONDITIONS WILL BE SIMILAR TO THOSE THAT 
OCCURRED THIS MORNING. SUNDAY SHOULD BE PRETTY MUCH OF A CARBON COPY 
OF TODAY AS A FEW SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE POSSIBLE DURING 
THE AFTERNOON HOURS. WILL CONTINUE SMALL CHANCES SUNDAY NIGHT AS 
NEXT COLD FRONT WILL BEGIN TO APPROACH THE AREA FROM THE NORTHWEST. 
FRONT IS EXPECTED TO MOVE INTO THE STATE ON MONDAY...BUT WILL BE 
VERY SLOW. BIGGEST QUESTION IS WHETHER FRONT WILL MOVE COMPLETELY 
THROUGH THE AREA. THINK THAT HURRICANE FRANCES WILL HOLD UP THINGS 
SOMEWHAT AND FRONT MAY BE SLOWER THAN PROGGED. 
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
THE LONG TERM UPPER LEVEL PATTERN WILL BE MARKED BY THE LOW OVER THE 
SOUTHEAST PART OF THE COUNTRY ASSOCIATED WITH TROPICAL SYSTEM. IT 
APPEARS THAT THIS SYSTEM WILL NOT MAKE IT FAR ENOUGH WEST TO AFFECT 
THE STATE DIRECTLY. THERE WILL BE BRIEF AND WEAK SHORT WAVES COMING 
ALONG IN THE NORTHWEST FLOW BUT NOT ENOUGH TO TRIGGER ANY 
CONVECTION. THE RIDGE WILL BUILD ACROSS THE SOUTHERN UNITED STATES 
BY 00Z SATURDAY AND IT WILL HOLD FOR 24 HOURS AT LEAST. AT THE 
SURFACE...WE WILL SEE AVERAGE HUMIDITY LEVELS LOWER AS THE REMNANTS 
OF THE TROPICAL SYSTEM MOVE AWAY FROM THE STATE. DRY NORTHERLY WINDS 
WILL PREVAIL THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON...THEN WINDS WILL VEER 
SLOWLY THROUGH SATURDAY. BEYOND THE LONG TERM...MOISTURE WILL BE 
POISED TO RETURN TO THE STATE FROM THE SOUTHEAST SUNDAY INTO THE 
EARLY PART OF THE FOLLOWING WEEK.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    69  89  71  90 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       67  87  68  84 /   0  20  30  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    70  90  71  90 /  20  20  20  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     70  89  71  90 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  67  87  68  84 /   0  20  20  30 
MONTICELLO AR     70  89  71  91 /  30  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         69  89  71  89 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      70  90  71  89 /  20  20  20  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   69  89  70  86 /   0  20  20  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



245 
FXUS64 KLZK 040913
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
355 AM CDT SAT SEP  4 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
BIGGEST WEATHER MAKER IN THE SHORT TERM WILL BE HURRICANE FRANCES IN 
THE SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES. FRANCES WILL HAVE SOME IMPACT IN 
ARKANSAS...BUT THIS WILL BE MINOR. 

FAIR AMOUNT OF MOISTURE OVER THE STATE TODAY...ESPECIALLY ACROSS 
CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. THIS WILL LEND ITSELF TO SOME CLOUDS AND 
ISOLATED/SCATTERED SHOWERS AND PERHAPS A FEW THUNDERSTORMS. DRY 
WEATHER IN THE FORECAST FARTHER NORTH. 

AS DAYTIME HEATING SUBSIDES THIS EVENING...SO WILL ANY 
PRECIPITATION. 

ON SUNDAY...COLD FRONT/WEAKENING TROUGH ALOFT WILL APPROACH FROM THE 
WEST. WENT AHEAD AND ADDED SLIGHT CHANCES FOR SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS 
IN WESTERN ARKANSAS...WITH SOME RIDGING/DRY AND WARM WEATHER FARTHER 
EAST. 

REMNANTS OF FRANCES WILL MOVE INTO THE SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES 
MONDAY/TUESDAY. IT APPEARS THAT FRANCES WILL REMAIN FAR ENOUGH TO 
THE EAST TO KEEP MOST RAIN OUT OF THE FORECAST. HOWEVER... 
CIRCULATION AROUND REMNANTS WILL PRODUCE A BREEZY NORTH/NORTHEAST 
WIND. 

AS FAR AS THE FRONT TO THE WEST...IT MAY HEAD INTO STATE TO END THE 
SHORT TERM...BUT WILL LIKELY WASH OUT. PRECIPITATION WITH THE FRONT 
WILL BE HARD TO COME BY SINCE ARKANSAS WILL BE IN THE SUBSIDENCE 
AREA WEST OF FRANCES. 

OVERALL...TEMPERATURES PRETTY CLOSE TO NORMAL IN THE SHORT TERM. 
AFTERNOON READINGS WILL BE IN THE MID 80S/LOWER 90S...WITH 60S/LOWER 
70S AT NIGHT. (46)                  
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
MEDIUM RANGE MODELS CONTINUE TO BE IN GOOD AGREEMENT THIS MORNING 
WITH REGARDS TO HURRICANE FRANCES BUT MODELS HAVE DONE A BIT ON AN 
ABOUT FACE REGARDING THE NEXT SYSTEM PROGGED TO COME IN LATE NEXT 
WEEK. PREVIOUS RUNS WERE ADVERTISING A COLD FRONT LATE IN THE 
PERIOD AND HAVE NOW BACKED OFF ON IT. BASED ON THE UPPER FLOW... 
FRONT WOULD HAVE A VERY TOUGH TIME GETTING IN HERE AT ALL. WITH SUCH 
A RATHER LARGE CHANGE...FEEL A BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS IS IN 
ORDER.

PERIOD STARTS OFF WITH SLOWLY MOVING FRANCES OVER THE SOUTHEAST 
CONUS. WEAKENING SYSTEM SHOULD HAVE VIRTUALLY NO EFFECT ON THE CWA 
OTHER THAN SOME NORTHEAST BREEZES AS THE AREA WILL CONTINUE TO BE IN 
WIDESPREAD SUBSIDENCE. REMNANTS OF STORM ROCKET OFF TO THE NORTHEAST 
WHILE STRONG SHORT WAVE ENERGY DROPS INTO THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST. 
WAVE CARVES OUT A TROUGH ALONG THE INTERNATIONAL BORDER AND IS TAKEN
INTO SOUTHERN ONTARIO BY THE END OF THE PERIOD. LAST NIGHTS MODELS 
WERE CONSIDERABLY STRONGER WITH THIS FEATURE AND DRAGGED A COLD 
FRONT ACROSS THE REGION FRIDAY BUT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT LOOKING 
FEASIBLE AT THIS TIME. 

MODELS NOW ADVERTISING BROAD RIDING FROM THE DESERT SOUTHWEST TO 
THE NEW ENGLAND STATES WITH THE GULF BASICALLY CLOSED FOR BUSINESS. 
PATTERN WOULD SUGGEST DRY CONDITIONS FOR DAYS FIVE THROUGH SEVEN AND 
AT THIS POINT...I SEE NO REASON TO ARGUE. TEMPERATURES SHOULD REMAIN 
IN THE MID 80S TO LOWER 90S ACROSS THE CWA THROUGH THE PERIOD WHICH 
IS A FEW DEGREES ABOVE NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  69  89  71 /  20  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       87  67  87  68 /  10  10  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    89  70  90  71 /  20  10  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     88  70  89  71 /  30  20  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  87  67  87  68 /  10  10  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     88  70  89  71 /  30  20  10  10 
SEARCY AR         88  69  89  71 /  20  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      90  70  90  71 /  20  10  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   89  69  89  70 /  10  10  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46/56

MEDIUM RANGE MODELS CONTINUE TO BE IN GOOD AGREEMENT THIS MORNING 
WITH REGARDS TO HURRICANE FRANCES BUT MODELS HAVE DONE A BIT ON AN 
ABOUT FACE REGARDING THE NEXT SYSTEM PROGGED TO COME IN LATE NEXT 
WEEK. PREVIOUS RUNS WERE ADVERTISING A COLD FRONT LATE IN THE 
PERIOD AND HAVE NOW BACKED OFF ON IT. BASED ON THE UPPER FLOW... 
FRONT WOULD HAVE A VERY TOUGH TIME GETTING IN HERE AT ALL. WITH SUCH 
A RATHER LARGE CHANGE...FEEL A BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS IS IN 
ORDER.

PERIOD STARTS OFF WITH SLOWLY MOVING FRANCES OVER THE SOUTHEAST 
CONUS. WEAKENING SYSTEM SHOULD HAVE VIRTUALLY NO EFFECT ON THE CWA 
OTHER THAN SOME NORTHEAST BREEZES AS THE AREA WILL CONTINUE TO BE IN 
WIDESPREAD SUBSIDENCE. REMNANTS OF STORM ROCKET OFF TO THE NORTHEAST 
WHILE STRONG SHORT WAVE ENERGY DROPS INTO THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST. 
WAVE CARVES OUT A TROUGH ALONG THE INTERNATIONAL BORDER AND IS TAKEN
INTO SOUTHERN ONTARIO BY THE END OF THE PERIOD. LAST NIGHTS MODELS 
WERE CONSIDERABLY STRONGER WITH THIS FEATURE AND DRAGGED A COLD 
FRONT ACROSS THE REGION FRIDAY BUT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT LOOKING 
FEASIBLE AT THIS TIME. 

MODELS NOW ADVERTISING BROAD RIDING FROM THE DESERT SOUTHWEST TO 
THE NEW ENGLAND STATES WITH THE GULF BASICALLY CLOSED FOR BUSINESS. 
PATTERN WOULD SUGGEST DRY CONDITIONS FOR DAYS FIVE THROUGH SEVEN AND 
AT THIS POINT...I SEE NO REASON TO ARGUE. TEMPERATURES SHOULD REMAIN 
IN THE MID 80S TO LOWER 90S ACROSS THE CWA THROUGH THE PERIOD WHICH 
IS A FEW DEGREES ABOVE NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  69  89  71 /  20  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       87  67  87  68 /  10  10  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    89  70  90  71 /  20  10  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     88  70  89  71 /  30  20  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  87  67  87  68 /  10  10  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     88  70  89  71 /  30  20  10  10 
SEARCY AR         88  69  89  71 /  20  10  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      90  70  90  71 /  20  10  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   89  69  89  70 /  10  10  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46/56


000 
FXUS64 KLZK 040238 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
935 PM CDT FRI SEP 3 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST PRETTY MUCH ON TRACK. MOST OF THE SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS IN THE FORECAST AREA HAS ENDED THIS EVENING. 
BUT...WITH FAIR MOISTURE TO THE SOUTH OF THE STATE...PLUS SOME 
LINGERING RAINFALL OVER NORTHERN LOUISIANA ON RADAR...WILL KEEP 
SMALL CHANCES OVER CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN ARKANSAS OVERNIGHT. TWEAKED 
TEMPERATURES AND WINDS SLIGHTLY. GRID AND TEXT UPDATES ALL OUT.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

22






442 
FXUS64 KLZK 031953
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
245 PM CDT FRI SEP 3 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
UPPER LEVEL PATTERN KEEPS A WEAK SHORT WAVE OVER ARKANSAS TONIGHT 
MAINLY OVER THE SOUTHEAST HALF AND INTO SATURDAY. RIDGE BUILDS 
BRIEFLY OVER THE STATE FOR SUNDAY...BUT THE NEXT SHORT WAVE IN THE 
WESTERLIES IS NOT TOO FAR BEHIND. IT WILL AFFECT MAINLY THE 
NORTHWEST SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY OVER ALL SECTIONS. DRY MONDAY 
NIGHT. THERE WILL NOT BE A REALLY NOTICEABLE FRONTAL PASSAGE SINCE 
THE TROPICAL SYSTEM THE WILL APPROACH FROM THE SOUTHEAST WILL TURN 
OUR WINDS OUT OF THE NORTHEAST AND NORTH. FOLLOWED GFS TEMPERATURES.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
LOOKS MORE LIKE FRANCES WILL STAY FAR ENOUGH EAST OF THE AREA TO HAVE
NO DIRECT EFFECTS ON THE WEATHER. A WEAK SHORT WAVE MOVES ACROSS THE
AREA IN NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT TUESDAY WITH SOME MOISTURE INDICATED SO
PUT IN SMALL POPS FOR TUESDAY MOSTLY IN THE EAST. THIS MAY ALSO BE 
THE REMNANTS OF THE FRONTAL SYSTEM THAT MOVES INTO THE AREA LATER IN 
THE WEEKEND. LOOKS LIKE FRONT MAY BE ABSORBED INTO THE BROAD 
CIRCULATION AROUND FRANCES OR ITS REMNANTS BY LATE MONDAY OR 
TUESDAY. THERE LIKELY WILL BE LITTLE EFFECT ON TEMPERATURES AND
MINS MAY ACTUALLY GET HELD UP A LITTLE DUE TO HIGHER DEW POINTS
BEING THRUST INTO THE AREA FROM THE NORTHEAST OR EAST. GFS WANTS
TO BRING A RATHER STRONG COLD FRONT ACROSS THE AREA BY NEXT FRIDAY.
UPPER PATTERN DOES NOT BECOME TOO FAVORABLE FOR A FRONTAL PASSAGE
IN ARKANSAS UNTIL FRIDAY NIGHT AND SATURDAY SO THINK GFS IS A 
LITTLE FAST WITH THE FRONT. DID PUT IN CHANCE POPS ACROSS THE 
AREA FOR FRIDAY WITH A SLIGHT CHANCE ON FRIDAY NIGHT. MADE
LITTLE CHANGE TO TEMPERATURES ON FRIDAY BUT DID BRING IN COOLER
AND DRIER AIR FRIDAY NIGHT.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    67  88  70  90 /  20  20  10  10 
HARRISON AR       64  86  66  87 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    68  88  69  91 /  20  20  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     68  87  69  91 /  20  30  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  64  86  66  87 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     68  87  69  92 /  30  30  10  10 
SEARCY AR         66  88  69  89 /  20  20  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      68  89  69  91 /  10  20  10  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   67  89  69  88 /  10  10  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&
