32





074 
FXUS64 KLZK 030902
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
355 AM CDT FRI SEP 3 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
DEEP TROUGH IN THE ROCKIES...WITH RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE OVER 
CENTRAL/EASTERN UNITED STATES TO START THE SHORT TERM. IN THE COMING 
DAYS...TROUGH WILL WEAKEN AS IT HEADS EAST...WITH RIDGE FLATTENING 
OUT. THIS WILL LEAVE PRETTY MUCH ZONAL FLOW ACROSS MUCH OF THE 
COUNTRY LATE IN THE WEEKEND/EARLY NEXT WEEK...WITH NO SIGNIFICANT 
SYSTEMS TO MENTION. OF COURSE...THERE IS HURRICANE FRANCES...WHICH 
WILL BE MENTIONED LATER.

ANYWAY...AT THE SURFACE...HIGH PRESSURE WILL BE HEADING TO THE 
EAST...WITH A MORE SOUTHERLY WIND FLOW. MOISTURE WILL TEND TO 
INCREASE...AND ALREADY SEEING MORE CLOUDS OVER SOUTHEAST HALF OF 
STATE THIS MORNING. HOWEVER...WITH NOT MUCH TO TAP INTO THE 
MOISTURE...ONLY A FEW SPRINKLES/ISOLATED SHOWERS OCCURRING. 

NOT EXPECTING MUCH CHANGE THROUGH THE WEEKEND...WITH FAIR AMOUNT OF 
MOISTURE/CLOUDS...BUT LITTLE IN THE WAY OF TRIGGERING MECHANISMS. AT 
BEST...SLIGHT CHANCES OF SHOWERS/MAYBE A FEW THUNDERSTORMS IN 
FORECAST.

ONLY SIGNIFICANT WEATHER FEATURE WILL BE HURRICANE FRANCES...WITH
THE SYSTEM CLOSING IN ON FLORIDA THIS WEEKEND. SYSTEM PROGGED TO 
MOVE INTO SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES BY EARLY NEXT WEEK...WITH ARKANSAS 
IN SUBSIDENCE AREA TO WEST OF SYSTEM. THIS WILL FURTHER LEND TO A 
MOSTLY DRY PATTERN IN THE COMING DAYS. 

WILL BE A WEAK COLD FRONT CLOSING IN FROM THE NORTHWEST EARLY NEXT 
WEEK...BUT WILL NOT LIKELY AMOUNT TO MUCH AND WILL PROBABLY WASH OUT 
TO END THE SHORT TERM.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
MEDIUM RANGE MODELS COMING INTO BETTER AGREEMENT THIS MORNING 
REGARDING THE EVOLUTION AND TRACK OF HURRICANE FRANCIS. GFS SOLUTION 
LAST NIGHT WAS CARRYING THE SYSTEM UP THE COAST BUT HAS SHIFTED ITS 
THINKING AND NOW BRINGS IT ACROSS THE FLORIDA PENINSULA AND INTO THE
SOUTHEAST CONUS. GFS NOW IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH ALL OTHER MODELS 
SANS THE ECMWF WHICH CARRIES WHATS LEFT OF IT MUCH FURTHER WEST. 
THAT BEING SAID...WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS THIS 
MORNING.

PERIOD STARTS OFF WITH FRANCES OVER THE SOUTHEAST CONUS AND SHOULD 
HAVE VIRTUALLY NO EFFECT ON THE CWA OTHER THAN SOME NORTHEAST 
BREEZES AS THE AREA WILL CONTINUE TO BE IN WIDESPREAD SUBSIDENCE. 
OTHERWISE THE WESTERLIES ARE CONFINED TO THE NORTHERN TIER STATES IN 
A NEARLY ZONAL FLOW. THE REMNANTS OF THE HURRICANE WILL MOVE ALONG 
THE SPINE OF THE APPALACHIANS WHILE STRONG SHORT WAVE ENERGY DROPS 
IN THE THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST. WAVE CARVES OUT AN UPPER LOW AND 
RATHER DEEP TROUGH OVER THE INTERMOUNTAIN WEST WHICH THEN MOVES OFF 
TO THE NORTHEAST AND INTO THE NORTHERN PLAINS BY THE END OF THE 
PERIOD. RESULT WILL BE A RETURN OF A RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHEAST CONUS. 
PATTERN WOULD SUGGEST DRY CONDITIONS FOR DAYS FIVE THROUGH SEVEN AND 
AT THIS POINT...I SEE NO REASON TO ARGUE. TEMPERATURES SHOULD REMAIN 
IN THE MID 80S TO LOWER 90S ACROSS THE CWA THROUGH THE PERIOD WHICH 
IS A FEW DEGREES ABOVE NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  68  89  71 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       85  65  87  67 /  10  10  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    88  69  89  71 /  10  10  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     88  69  88  70 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  85  65  87  67 /  10  10  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     88  69  88  70 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         88  67  89  70 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      88  69  90  70 /  10  10  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   88  68  90  70 /  10  10  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

46/56






785 
FXUS64 KLZK 021938
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 PM CDT THU SEP 2 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
THE UPPER LEVEL PATTERN WILL BE FLATTENING THE RIDGE OVER ARKANSAS 
GRADUALLY THROUGH 00Z MONDAY AS A SHORT WAVE MOVES EAST ACROSS THE 
NORTHERN TIER OF STATE IN THE WESTERLIES. AT THE SAME TIME...THE GFS 
SHOWS THE TROPICAL SYSTEM APPROACHING FROM THE SOUTHEAST...AIDING IN 
THE BREAKING DOWN OF THE RIDGE. OUR WEATHER WILL BE RESPONDING 
MAINLY TO THE SYSTEM APPROACHING FROM THE WEST. THE SURFACE FRONT 
WILL BE GETTING ITS ENERGY FROM THE SHORT WAVE MOVING ACROSS THE 
NORTHERN PART OF THE COUNTRY. THE FRONT WILL BE POISED TO ENTER THE 
STATE SUNDAY AFTERNOON AND IT WILL CONTINUE TO CROSS SLOWLY BEYOND 
THE SHORT RANGE. LOWER LEVEL HUMIDITY WILL BE INCREASING BEFORE THE 
COLD FRONT ARRIVES...SO THAT CHANCES OF RAIN WILL BE ENTERING THE 
FORECAST AS EARLY AS SATURDAY AFTERNOON...ESPECIALLY FROM THE 
SOUTHEAST. SMALL CHANCES OF RAIN WILL CONTINUE THROUGH MOST OF THE 
DAY SUNDAY...AND THEN THEY WILL BE DECREASING OVERNIGHT INTO MONDAY 
MORNING.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
STILL UNCERTAINTIES ABOUT TRACK OF HURRICANE FRANCES IN EXTENDED BUT 
INDICATIONS ARE IT WILL STAY FAR ENOUGH EAST TO HAVE LITTLE IMPACT ON
THE AREA. THUS PRETTY MUCH IGNORED FRANCES IN MAKING THE EXTENDED 
FORECAST. THE MAIN EFFECT THAT COULD HAPPEN WOULD BE COLD FRONT 
HOLDING UP IN THE AREA ON LABOR DAY AND CONTINUING CHANCES OF RAIN. 
KEPT FORECAST DRY FOR NOW BUT SET POPS AT 14 PERCENT. OTHER THAN 
THAT HIGH PRESSURE TO THE NORTH SHOULD COVER THE AREA WITH DRY 
WEATHER. MADE SOME MINOR ADJUSTMENTS DOWN ON MIN FORECASTS TO BETTER 
FIT GUIDANCE AND SURROUNDING STATIONS. RIDGE SLIPS PAST THE AREA BY 
THURSDAY WHICH WILL ALLOW SOME RETURN FLOW AND MODERATED TEMPS A 
LITTLE. RATHER STRONG SHORT WAVE MOVES BY TO THE NORTH BUT PRESENT 
INDICATIONS ARE IT WILL STAY TO THE NORTH OF THE AREA AS UPPER 
RIDGING DEVELOPS ACROSS THE SOUTH. KEPT FORECAST DRY THROUGH DAY 7 
PERIOD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    65  92  68  91 /   0  10  10  20 
HARRISON AR       62  89  65  87 /   0   0  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    65  93  69  92 /   0  10  10  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     66  92  69  92 /   0  10  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  62  89  65  87 /   0   0  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     66  93  69  92 /   0  10  20  20 
SEARCY AR         64  92  67  89 /   0  10  10  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      65  93  69  92 /   0  10  10  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   64  92  68  89 /   0   0  10  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

RUSSELLVILLE AR   64  92  68  89 /   0   0  10  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

32/29





338 
FXUS64 KLZK 020811
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
309 AM CDT THU SEP  2 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT...
MODELS IN BETTER AGREEMENT THIS MORNING VERSUS LAST NIGHT AND ALL 
ARE IN ON THE SAME PAGE REGARDING THE EVOLUTION OF THE WESTERN 
CONUS SYSTEM. MODELS ARE ALSO CONSISTENT IN SLOWING DOWN THE 
APPROACHING SYSTEM SOMEWHAT WHICH WHEN LOOKING AT THE SOUTHEAST 
CONUS RIDGE...MAKES SENSE. WITH NO CLEAR CUT MODEL OF CHOICE.. I 
WILL CONTINUE TO GO WITH A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS.

SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE STILL IN CONTROL THIS MORNING BUT ITS 
INFLUENCE WILL BE STARTING TO WANE A BIT AS IT MOVES OFF TO THE 
EAST. UPPER FLOW STILL SHOWING A WEAKNESS OVER THE NATIONS MID 
SECTION. THIS DEFORMATION ZONE SHOWS SEVERAL WEAK WAVES EMBEDDED IN 
IT WHICH WILL MOVE THROUGH THE REGION OVER THE NEXT TWO DAYS. 
HOWEVER...WITH VIRTUALLY NO MOISTURE TO WORK WITH...ONLY SCATTERED 
AFTERNOON CU ARE EXPECTED AS MODEL SOUNDINGS ARE SHOWING SOME 
MOISTURE TRAPPED UNDER THE SURFACE RIDGE.

MEANWHILE...INTENSE UPPER LOW NOW LOCATED OVER EASTERN BRITISH 
COLUMBIA WILL CONTINUE TO MOVE EASTWARD CARVING OUT A DEEP TROUGH AS 
IT DOES. STRONG SHORTWAVE DIVING DOWN THE BACK SIDE OF THE LOW IS 
AIDED BY A STRONG JET MAX AND SPINS UP A NEW UPPER LOW OVER THE 
CENTRAL PLAINS WHILE THE INITIAL TROUGH SHEARS OUT. AS THE SYSTEM 
EVOLVES...SUB TROPICAL RIDGES STRENGTHENS OVER THE SOUTHEAST UNITED 
STATES BY SATURDAY MORNING. INCREASED RIDGING IN TURN SLOWS UP THE 
FORWARD SPEED OF HURRICANE FRANCES WHICH SHOULD BE JUST OFF THE 
CENTRAL FLORIDA COAST BUT ALSO INTRODUCES MORE MOISTURE TO THE MID 
SOUTH AS FLOW ALOFT BECOMES MORE SOUTHWESTERLY.

SURFACE LOW DEVELOPS OVER NORTHEAST COLORADO SATURDAY MORNING AND 
RACES OFF TO THE NORTHEAST DURING THE DAY...REACHING NORTHERN 
MINNESOTA BY EARLY SUNDAY. ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT STRETCHES ACROSS 
THE CENTRAL PLAINS INTO NORTHEAST TEXAS BY SUNDAY MORNING BUT WILL 
START TO BOG DOWN AS IT RUNS INTO THE AFOREMENTIONED SOUTHEAST CONUS 
RIDGE. CURRENT FORECAST IS CARRYING SLIGHT CHANCE POPS SATURDAY 
AFTERNOON AND THIS APPEARS REASONABLE AS NO REAL FORCING OR 
SHORTWAVES ARE SEEN BUT SOME LIFT IS EVIDENT. MOISTURE WILL BE ON 
THE INCREASE SATURDAY NIGHT...ESPECIALLY OVER THE SOUTHEAST. FRONT 
DOES APPEAR TO WEAKEN SOMEWHAT AS IT RUNS INTO THE RIDGE WITH WHAT 
DYNAMICS THAT ARE PRESENT...APPEARING TO BE PRE FRONTAL. FROPA 
ITSELF SHOULD BE SOMETIME MID TO LATE DAY SUNDAY OVER THE METRO AREA 
BUT ENOUGH MOISTURE LINGERS FOR A CONTINUATION OF SLIGHT CHANCE POPS 
THROUGH THE EARLY EVENING.

WITH HURRICANE FRANCES CRAWLING UP THE EAST COAST...AREA OF 
SUBSIDENCE BEGINS TO MOVE IN FROM THE NORTHWEST SUNDAY NIGHT. 
MOISTURE SHUNTED OFF TO THE SOUTHEAST DURING THE NIGHT BUT WILL 
LEAVE SOME SLIGHT CHANCES POPS IN EARLY SUNDAY NIGHT AND TAPER THEM 
OFF BY MONDAY MORNING.

TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO RUN AT OR SLIGHTLY ABOVE SEASONABLE 
OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS. DEW POINT TEMPERATURES SLOWLY CREEP UP 
THROUGH THE PERIOD FOR INCREASED HUMIDITY BUT WITH DEW POINT 
TEMPERATURES ONLY PROGGED TO PEG OUT IN THE LOWER 70S...CONDITIONS  
WILL NOT BE OVERLY OPPRESSIVE. DRIER AIR STARTS TO COME BACK IN 
AFTER FROPA. WENT WITH A BLEND OF FWC/MAV NUMBERS THIS MORNING.

ENTIRE FORECAST FOR THE WEEKEND BASED ON PROJECTED PATH OF FRANCES 
AND A MAJOR SHIFT IN HER PATH WOULD OF COURSE ALTER WHAT WOULD 
HAPPEN OVER THE MID SOUTH. WILL CONTINUE TO MONITOR FRANCES 
CAREFULLY OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY... 
COLD FRONT SHOULD BE OUT OF THE AREA BY MONDAY MORNING. HIGH 
PRESSURE MOVES INTO THE AREA MONDAY ALLOWING MUCH DRIER AIR AND 
NORTHWEST FLOW TO RETURN. GFS IS SLOWER WITH THE FRONT THAN 24 HRS 
AGO. HOWEVER...HIGH PRESSURE RESIDES OVER THE AREA THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY. UPPER NORTHWEST FLOW WILL CONTINUE AS HURRICANE FRANCES 
WORKS UP THE EAST COAST. WILL KEEP PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES THROUGH THE 
PERIOD. TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO BE NEAR NORMAL THROUGH THE 
EXTENDED PERIOD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  65  92  67 /   0   0   0  10 
HARRISON AR       86  62  89  64 /   0   0   0  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    87  65  92  68 /   0   0   0  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     88  66  92  68 /   0   0   0  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  85  62  89  64 /   0   0   0  10 
MONTICELLO AR     89  66  92  68 /   0   0   0  10 
SEARCY AR         86  64  92  66 /   0   0   0  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      88  65  92  68 /   0   0   0  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   87  64  91  67 /   0   0   0  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



692 
FXUS64 KLZK 011938
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
238 PM CDT WED SEP  1 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CU DEVELOPED ACROSS THE REGION AGAIN THIS AFTERNOON. DEW POINTS 
REMAIN FAIRLY COMFORTABLE ACROSS THE STATE...WITH MEASUREMENTS A FEW 
DEGREES EITHER SIDE OF 60. SFC HIGH PRESSURE SYSTEM REMAINS CENTERED 
OVER EAST CENTRAL MO. EASTERLY WINDS WILL KEEP DEW POINTS DOWN FOR 
THE NEXT FEW DAYS. EXPECT CU TO SUBSIDE AFTER 6 PM. WILL BE CLEAR 
TONIGHT WITH THE EXCEPTION OF A FEW HIGH CLOUDS ACROSS WESTERN AR.

IN THE SHORT TERM...INHERITED GRIDS LOOKED PRETTY GOOD. ONLY 
NOTICEABLE ADJUSTMENT WAS TO SLIGHTLY RAISE MAX TEMPS ON FRIDAY. 
FEEL THAT WITH HURRICANE FRANCES APPROACHING THE SE US COAST...WILL 
SEE SOME LARGE SCALE SUBSIDENCE OVER THE MID SOUTH. THIS...ALONG 
WITH THE RIDGE ALREADY IN PLACE...WILL ALLOW TEMPERATURES FRIDAY TO 
GET JUST A BIT HIGHER THEN PREVIOUSLY FORECASTED.

BIGGEST CHANGES WERE MADE TO THE SATURDAY/SUNDAY TIME FRAME IN THE 
LONG RANGE. ALL MODELS ADVERTISING A STRONG H5 SHORTWAVE TO DROP OUT 
OF THE PACIFIC NW. LATEST GFS MODEL CARRIES THE LOW FURTHER 
NORTH...AND IS A BIT FASTER WITH IT. SFC LOW DEVELOPS AHEAD OF THE 
H5 LOW AND MOVES NE. A COLD FRONT GETS DRAGGED THROUGH AR...WITH 
FROPA APPEARING TO OCCUR SUNDAY AFTERNOON.

MOISTURE MAY BE AN ISSUE THOUGH. FEEL THAT WHILE SOUTHERLY FLOW WILL 
RETURN TO MUCH OF THE STATE...FURTHER SOUTH WINDS WILL NOT BE AS 
STRONG OUT OF THE GULF DUE TO WIND FIELDS BEING PERTURBED BY 
HURRICANE FRANCES. TIMING WILL ALSO BE TRICKY...AS H5 LOW MAY BE 
FASTER/SLOWER AND TREND EVEN FURTHER NORTH. WENT AHEAD AN INTRODUCED 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH MOST OF SUNDAY.

UPPER LEVEL WINDS BECOME WESTERLY IN THE LATER PERIODS...BRINGING 
DRY AIR AGAIN TO THE REGION. LOOKS LIKE WE COULD BE IN STORE FOR 
ANOTHER PROLONGED PERIOD OF DRY WEATHER FOR NEXT WEEK...WITH 
TEMPERATURE REMAINING NEAR NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    64  89  66  92 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       61  87  63  89 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    64  88  66  92 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     65  89  67  92 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  60  86  63  89 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     65  90  67  92 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         64  87  65  92 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      64  89  66  92 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   64  88  65  91 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

934 
FXUS64 KLZK 011605 CCA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...CORRECTED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1055 AM CDT WED SEP  1 2004

.DISCUSSION...
NOT MUCH TO CHANGE LATE THIS MORNING. ADJUSTED MAX TEMPS ACROSS 
NORTHEAST ARKANSAS FOR TODAY...TEMPERATURE TRENDS ARE FASTER THEN 
FORECASTED...AND FEEL THAT LACK OF CLOUD COVER THIS MORNING WILL 
ALLOW THAT AREA TO EASILY HIT THE UPPER 80S. OTHERWISE...A FEW CU 
EXPECTED TO DEVELOP TODAY...SLIGHTLY MORE THEN YESTERDAY...BUT STILL 
MOSTLY SUNNY. REST OF GRIDS APPEAR TO BE ON TRACK.

QUICK GLANCE AT REST OF FORECAST...TROUGH FORECASTED TO DEVELOP OVER 
NW CONUS AND AMPLIFY AS IT HEADS EAST. MOISTURE INCREASES AS UPPER 
LEVEL FLOW BECOMES MORE SWLY. ALSO WILL HAVE TO KEEP AN EYE ON 
FRANCES TO DETERMINE IF IT WILL HAVE ANY EFFECT ON OUR 
WEATHER...CURRENT THINKING IS LIKELY NOT AS STRONG MID LEVEL TROUGH 
PUSHED TROPICAL SYSTEM AWAY FROM ARKANSAS.

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

220






440 
FXUS64 KLZK 010808
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
303 AM CDT WED SEP  1 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT...
THE MODELS...WHICH HAD BEEN QUITE CONSISTENT OF LATE...HAVE DONE AN 
ABOUT FACE THIS MORNING REGARDING THE EVOLUTION OF THE SIGNIFICANT 
WESTERN CONUS TROF. MODELS NOW ADVERTISING A MUCH STRONGER WAVE 
DROPPING ALONG THE BACKSIDE OF THE DEVELOPING TROF WITH A WEAKER 
SURFACE REFLECTION VERSUS PREVIOUS RUNS.

MODELS ALSO TRENDING SLOWER WITH MOVING THE TROF THROUGH THE WESTERN 
UNITED STATES AND EVENTUALLY THE MID SOUTH. THIS SLOWER MOVEMENT 
ACTUALLY SEEMS REASONABLE BASED ON THE STRENGTH OF THE DOWNSTREAM 
RIDGE. REGARDLESS...FAITH IN ANY ONE MODEL IS LACKING AND A FEEL A 
COMPROMISE OF SOLUTIONS THIS MORNING IS WARRANTED. THERE ARE ALSO 
NOTICEABLE DIFFERENCES IN THE HANDLING OF A WEAKNESS UNDER THE BROAD
RIDGE OVER THE MID SOUTH BUT THE EFFECT ON OUR SENSIBLE WEATHER 
WILL BE MINIMAL.

PERIOD STARTS OF TRANQUIL WITH SURFACE RIDGE REMAINING IN CONTROL 
AND BROAD RIDGING OVER THE MAJORITY OF THE NATION SANS THE PACIFIC 
NORTHWEST. MODELS STILL SHOWING A WEAKNESS UNDERNEATH THE RIDGE OVER 
THE MID SOUTH BUT WITH LIMITED MOISTURE WILL CONTINUE DRY FORECAST. 
ONLY REAL IMPACT WILL BE AN INCREASE IN CLOUD COVER FOR BOTH 
WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. AFOREMENTIONED TROF REALLY STARTS TO DIG ON 
FRIDAY AS STRONG PIECE OF ENERGY SWINGS THROUGH ITS BASE. THIS IN 
TURN PUMPS UP THE RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES. MODELS NOW 
HAVE THE WAVE CLOSING OFF INTO AN UPPER LOW ON SATURDAY WITH TROF 
SHEARING OUT WHICH IS A NEW SOLUTION BEING OFFERED BY THE MODELS. 

SURFACE LOW AND ASSOCIATED FRONT NOW CONSIDERABLY WEAKER THAN 
PREVIOUS RUNS AND ALSO SLOWER. STRENGTHENING OF THE SOUTHEAST CONUS 
RIDGE WILL DELAY THE FRONTAL ARRIVAL UNTIL SUNDAY BUT MODELS ALSO 
INDICATING SYSTEM MAY WASH OUT BEFORE GETTING HERE AND JUST BE AN 
INVERTED TROF ONCE IT DOES. THERE IS A SUBSTANTIAL INCREASE IN 
MOISTURE FROM PREVIOUS RUNS BUT NOT SURE WHERE ALL THIS MOISTURE IS 
COMING FROM AS AREA WILL BE IN WEAK FLOW AND WEAK SUBSIDENCE WITH 
HURRICANE FRANCES APPROACHING THE EAST COAST OF FLORIDA.

FOR NOW...WILL PULL PRECIP OUT UNTIL SATURDAY NIGHT AND THEN ONLY GO 
WITH SLIGHT CHANCES POPS. ENTIRE FORECAST SUBJECT TO CHANGE 
DEPENDING UPON WHAT FRANCES DOES AND THE OVERALL EVOLUTION OF THE 
CUT OFF WESTERN LOW. TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO BE VERY CLOSE TO 
SEASONAL NORMALS THROUGH THE PERIOD. DEW POINT TEMPERATURES HAVE 
TRENDED UP A FEW DEGREES VERSUS PREVIOUS RUNS AS FLOW IS MORE 
SOUTHWEST ALOFT. HUMIDITY LEVELS SHOULD STILL REMAIN BELOW 
OPPRESSIVE BUT DEW POINTS WILL BE CREEPING UP TO 70 DEGREES AS THE 
WEEKEND NEARS. WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF FWC/MAV NUMBERS THIS MORNING.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY ...
COLD FRONT MOVES THROUGH THE STATE AND WILL BE IN THE SOUTHEAST 
CORNER OF ARKANSAS SUNDAY MORNING. MODELS SHOW ABUNDANT MOISTURE 
WITH THE SYSTEM BUT QUESTION THE ACCURACY OF THIS SCENARIO. IF 
HURRICANE FRANCIS MOVES INTO THE SOUTHEAST U.S. A NORTHEAST FLOW 
WILL DEVELOP ACROSS THE AREA. SOME MOISTURE MAY MAKE IT INTO THE MID 
SOUTH BUT THIS SHOULD BE LIMITED GIVEN THE DISTANCE TO THE 
HURRICANE. THEREFORE...WILL KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THROUGH 
SUNDAY MORNING. HIGH PRESSURE WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA MONDAY AND 
BRING DRY CONDITIONS THROUGH TUESDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO 
BE NEAR NORMAL FOR THIS TIME OF YEAR. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  64  89  66 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       84  61  87  63 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    88  64  88  66 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     88  65  89  67 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  84  60  86  63 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     88  65  90  67 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         87  64  87  65 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      88  64  89  66 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   87  64  88  65 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

56/51






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 010808
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
303 AM CDT WED SEP  1 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT...
THE MODELS...WHICH HAD BEEN QUITE CONSISTENT OF LATE...HAVE DONE AN 
ABOUT FACE THIS MORNING REGARDING THE EVOLUTION OF THE SIGNIFICANT 
WESTERN CONUS TROF. MODELS NOW ADVERTISING A MUCH STRONGER WAVE 
DROPPING ALONG THE BACKSIDE OF THE DEVELOPING TROF WITH A WEAKER 
SURFACE REFLECTION VERSUS PREVIOUS RUNS.

MODELS ALSO TRENDING SLOWER WITH MOVING THE TROF THROUGH THE WESTERN 
UNITED STATES AND EVENTUALLY THE MID SOUTH. THIS SLOWER MOVEMENT 
ACTUALLY SEEMS REASONABLE BASED ON THE STRENGTH OF THE DOWNSTREAM 
RIDGE. REGARDLESS...FAITH IN ANY ONE MODEL IS LACKING AND A FEEL A 
COMPROMISE OF SOLUTIONS THIS MORNING IS WARRANTED. THERE ARE ALSO 
NOTICEABLE DIFFERENCES IN THE HANDLING OF A WEAKNESS UNDER THE BROAD
RIDGE OVER THE MID SOUTH BUT THE EFFECT ON OUR SENSIBLE WEATHER 
WILL BE MINIMAL.

PERIOD STARTS OF TRANQUIL WITH SURFACE RIDGE REMAINING IN CONTROL 
AND BROAD RIDGING OVER THE MAJORITY OF THE NATION SANS THE PACIFIC 
NORTHWEST. MODELS STILL SHOWING A WEAKNESS UNDERNEATH THE RIDGE OVER 
THE MID SOUTH BUT WITH LIMITED MOISTURE WILL CONTINUE DRY FORECAST. 
ONLY REAL IMPACT WILL BE AN INCREASE IN CLOUD COVER FOR BOTH 
WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. AFOREMENTIONED TROF REALLY STARTS TO DIG ON 
FRIDAY AS STRONG PIECE OF ENERGY SWINGS THROUGH ITS BASE. THIS IN 
TURN PUMPS UP THE RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES. MODELS NOW 
HAVE THE WAVE CLOSING OFF INTO AN UPPER LOW ON SATURDAY WITH TROF 
SHEARING OUT WHICH IS A NEW SOLUTION BEING OFFERED BY THE MODELS. 

SURFACE LOW AND ASSOCIATED FRONT NOW CONSIDERABLY WEAKER THAN 
PREVIOUS RUNS AND ALSO SLOWER. STRENGTHENING OF THE SOUTHEAST CONUS 
RIDGE WILL DELAY THE FRONTAL ARRIVAL UNTIL SUNDAY BUT MODELS ALSO 
INDICATING SYSTEM MAY WASH OUT BEFORE GETTING HERE AND JUST BE AN 
INVERTED TROF ONCE IT DOES. THERE IS A SUBSTANTIAL INCREASE IN 
MOISTURE FROM PREVIOUS RUNS BUT NOT SURE WHERE ALL THIS MOISTURE IS 
COMING FROM AS AREA WILL BE IN WEAK FLOW AND WEAK SUBSIDENCE WITH 
HURRICANE FRANCES APPROACHING THE EAST COAST OF FLORIDA.

FOR NOW...WILL PULL PRECIP OUT UNTIL SATURDAY NIGHT AND THEN ONLY GO 
WITH SLIGHT CHANCES POPS. ENTIRE FORECAST SUBJECT TO CHANGE 
DEPENDING UPON WHAT FRANCES DOES AND THE OVERALL EVOLUTION OF THE 
CUT OFF WESTERN LOW. TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO BE VERY CLOSE TO 
SEASONAL NORMALS THROUGH THE PERIOD. DEW POINT TEMPERATURES HAVE 
TRENDED UP A FEW DEGREES VERSUS PREVIOUS RUNS AS FLOW IS MORE 
SOUTHWEST ALOFT. HUMIDITY LEVELS SHOULD STILL REMAIN BELOW 
OPPRESSIVE BUT DEW POINTS WILL BE CREEPING UP TO 70 DEGREES AS THE 
WEEKEND NEARS. WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF FWC/MAV NUMBERS THIS MORNING.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY ...
COLD FRONT MOVES THROUGH THE STATE AND WILL BE IN THE SOUTHEAST 
CORNER OF ARKANSAS SUNDAY MORNING. MODELS SHOW ABUNDANT MOISTURE 
WITH THE SYSTEM BUT QUESTION THE ACCURACY OF THIS SCENARIO. IF 
HURRICANE FRANCIS MOVES INTO THE SOUTHEAST U.S. A NORTHEAST FLOW 
WILL DEVELOP ACROSS THE AREA. SOME MOISTURE MAY MAKE IT INTO THE MID 
SOUTH BUT THIS SHOULD BE LIMITED GIVEN THE DISTANCE TO THE 
HURRICANE. THEREFORE...WILL KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THROUGH 
SUNDAY MORNING. HIGH PRESSURE WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA MONDAY AND 
BRING DRY CONDITIONS THROUGH TUESDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO 
BE NEAR NORMAL FOR THIS TIME OF YEAR. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    88  64  89  66 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       84  61  87  63 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    88  64  88  66 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     88  65  89  67 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  84  60  86  63 /   0   0   0   0

408 
FXUS64 KLZK 311958
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
245 PM CDT TUE AUG 31 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
STRONG SYSTEM MOVING INTO THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST WILL HOLD THE UPPER 
RIDGE OVER THE NORTH CENTRAL SECTION OF THE COUNTRY. THERE WILL BE A 
BIT OF A WEAKNESS IN THE RIDGE JUST TO OUR WEST IN THE SHORT TERM. 
THERE WILL NOT BE ENOUGH ENERGY TO TRIGGER ANY PRECIPITATION UNTIL 
SATURDAY AFTERNOON...MAINLY OVER THE EASTERN SECTIONS OF ARKANSAS 
SINCE MOISTURE WILL BE INCREASING FROM THE SOUTHEAST RIDING ALONG 
THE BACK SIDE OF THE SURFACE RIDGE THAT WILL ANCHOR OVER THE EASTERN 
THIRD OF THE COUNTRY. SURFACE WINDS WILL KEEP AN EASTERLY COMPONENT 
OF THEY WILL BE VERY LIGHT...SO THAT TEMPERATURES WILL BE SLOW TO 
CLIMB BACK TO NORMALS. RELATIVE HUMIDITY WILL CONTINUE AT 
COMFORTABLE LEVELS.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
FRONTAL SYSTEM WILL SLOWLY MAKE ITS WAY ACROSS THE AREA SATURDAY 
NIGHT INTO SUNDAY. WILL KEEP SMALL CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS IN FOR SATURDAY NIGHT AND SUNDAY...THEN DRY INTO THE 
EARLY PART OF NEXT WEEK. TEMPERATURES NEAR OR JUST SLIGHTLY BELOW 
NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    62  89  65  88 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       60  85  62  86 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    62  87  65  87 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     63  87  66  88 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  59  84  61  85 /   0   0   0   0

32/22





307 
FXUS64 KLZK 310745
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
241 AM CDT TUE AUG 31 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT...
MODELS IN VERY GOOD AGREEMENT THIS MORNING THROUGH 60 HOURS WITH NO 
MAJOR DIFFERENCES NOTED. MODELS START TO DIVERGE A BIT AFTER THAT 
WITH GFS A BIT FASTER AND STRONGER WITH THE APPROACHING H5 TROUGH 
AND THE ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT. FASTER SPEED SEEMS MORE REASONABLE 
BASED ON OVERALL PROGRESSIVE NATURE TO THE PATTERN. WILL GO WITH A 
BLEND OF SOLUTIONS THROUGH 60 HOURS AND THEN LEAN TOWARDS THE GFS 
THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD. 

BENIGN CONDITIONS IN PLACE TO ROUND OUT THE MONTH WILL NO REAL 
CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION THROUGH THE PERIOD. THUNDERSTORMS TO THE 
WEST SPREADING SOME CIRRUS OVER THE AREA AT THIS TIME BUT NO REAL 
EFFECT ON THE SENSIBLE WEATHER EXPECTED.

SURFACE RIDGE EXTENDS FROM TEXAS ALL THE WAY INTO SOUTHERN QUEBEC 
AND REMAINS NEARLY STATIONARY THROUGH EARLY THURSDAY. MOISTURE 
REMAINS LIMITED THROUGH THAT TIME WITH THE GULF EFFECTIVELY CUT OFF. 
UPPER PATTERN IS CHARACTERIZED BY BROAD RIDGING ALOFT THAT IS 
EVENTUALLY SHUNTED EASTWARD LATE IN THE PERIOD BY A TROF DIGGING 
ACROSS THE NATIONS MID SECTION. ONLY POSSIBLE FLY IN THE OINTMENT IS 
A WEAKNESS IN THE FLOW THAT DEVELOPS OVER THE SOUTHERN PLAINS 
THURSDAY MORNING. SHORTWAVE MOVES THROUGH THE STATE BUT WITH 
MOISTURE STILL SERIOUSLY LACKING WILL MAINTAIN THE DRY FORECAST.

LATER PART OF THE PERIOD STARTS TO GET INTERESTING WITH STRONG 
HURRICANE FRANCES APPROACHING THE EAST COAST OF FLORIDA AND STRONG 
SHORTWAVE MOVING ACROSS THE PRAIRIE PROVINCES OF CANADA. LARGE TROF 
BEING CARVED OUT OVER THE CENTRAL PLAINS BY SATURDAY MORNING WITH 
THE ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT EXTENDING FROM THE OKLAHOMA PANHANDLE TO 
EASTERN KANSAS. 

TEMPERATURES WILL BE CLOSE TO SEASONAL NORMALS AND WENT WITH A BLEND 
OF MAV/FWC NUMBERS THIS MORNING. MODELS CONTINUING THE TREND OF 
KEEPING RELATIVELY DRY AIR OVER THE AREA THROUGH THE PERIOD. WHILE 
TEMPERATURES WILL BE WARM...HUMIDITY LEVELS WILL BE HELD SOMEWHAT IN 
CHECK BY DEW POINT TEMPERATURES PROGGED TO REMAIN IN THE LOW TO MID 
60S.  
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY...
A TROUGH ACROSS THE NATIONS MID SECTION IS APPARENT ON THE LATEST 
GFS RUN. A SURFACE COLD FRONT MOVES TO EASTERN KANSAS AND WESTERN 
OKLAHOMA BY SATURDAY MORNING. WITH THE APPROACHING FRONT AND 
SOUTHWEST SURFACE FLOW FEEDING MOISTURE BACK INTO THE AREA...WILL 
INCLUDE SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR SATURDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH SATURDAY 
NIGHT. THE FRONT AND ASSOCIATED TROUGH WILL MOVE EAST OF THE AREA 
SUNDAY. APPEARS AT THIS TIME THAT THE TROPICAL SYSTEM WILL BE PICKED 
UP BY THE UPPER TROUGH AND MOVE ALONG THE EAST COAST. 

HIGH PRESSURE AND DRIER AIR MOVES INTO THE ARKANSAS AREA ALONG WITH 
NORTHWEST FLOW SUNDAY. WILL NOT EXPECT PRECIP AT THIS TIME FOR 
SUNDAY AND MONDAY. WILL STAY CLOSE TO THE GFS TEMPERATURES AND 
SLIGHTLY COOLER FOR SUNDAY AND MONDAY. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    87  63  89  66 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       84  59  86  62 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    87  63  87  66 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     87  63  87  67 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  84  59  84  62 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     87  63  88  67 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         86  60  85  65 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      87  61  87  66 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   86  60  86  64 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

FXUS64 KLZK 310158
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
905 PM CDT MON AUG 30 2004

CLOUDS CONTINUE TO DECREASE OVER THE REGION.
&&

PREVIOUS DISCUSSION...
407 PM CDT MON AUG 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT...
PRECIPITATION IS EXPECTED TO BE SCARCE ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA 
DURING THE SHORT TERM PERIODS. THE LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS INDICATES 
A RIDGE AXIS FROM SOUTHWEST OKLAHOMA THROUGH CENTRAL ILLINOIS.  A 
NEARLY STATIONARY BOUNDARY IS LOCATED WELL TO THE SOUTH ACROSS 
SOUTHERN LOUISIANA...INTO SOUTH CENTRAL TEXAS.

THE LOW LEVEL RIDGE IS FORECAST TO REMAIN NEARLY STATIONARY THROUGH 
THE SHORT TERM PERIODS...WILL CONTINUE TO PROMOTE A RELATIVELY DRY 
AIR MASS ACROSS THE REGION. 

&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH LABOR DAY...
ONLY A FEW CHANGES MADE TO THE LONG TERM GRIDS. FOLLOWED PREVIOUS 
FORECAST AND KEPT FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY DRY. A WEAK COLD FRONT LOOKS 
TO MOVE THROUGH THE AREA SATURDAY...BUT NOT MUCH MOISTURE ASSOCIATED 
WITH IT. A BROAD TROUGH SETS UP OVER THE MIDWEST THIS WEEKEND...AND 
COULD AFFECT PLACEMENT OF HURRICANE FRANCIS. FOR NOW...ADDED SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS FOR LABOR DAY AS A DISTURBANCE MOVES INTO THE BASE OF 
THE TROUGH...BUT CONFIDENCE IS NOT HIGH.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    62  88  64  90 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       56  85  60  87 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    63  88  64  88 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     64  88  64  88 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  56  85  60  85 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     65  88  64  89 /   0   0   0  10 
SEARCY AR         60  87  61  86 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      63  88  62  88 /   0   0   0   0

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

55/58/38


280 
FXUS64 KLZK 302110
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
407 PM CDT MON AUG 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT...
PRECIPITATION IS EXPECTED TO BE SCARCE ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA 
DURING THE SHORT TERM PERIODS. THE LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS INDICATES 
A RIDGE AXIS FROM SOUTHWEST OKLAHOMA THROUGH CENTRAL ILLINOIS.  A 
NEARLY STATIONARY BOUNDARY IS LOCATED WELL TO THE SOUTH ACROSS 
SOUTHERN LOUISIANA...INTO SOUTH CENTRAL TEXAS.

THE LOW LEVEL RIDGE IS FORECAST TO REMAIN NEARLY STATIONARY THROUGH 
THE SHORT TERM PERIODS...WILL CONTINUE TO PROMOTE A RELATIVELY DRY 
AIR MASS ACROSS THE REGION. 

&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH LABOR DAY...
ONLY A FEW CHANGES MADE TO THE LONG TERM GRIDS. FOLLOWED PREVIOUS 
FORECAST AND KEPT FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY DRY. A WEAK COLD FRONT LOOKS 
TO MOVE THROUGH THE AREA SATURDAY...BUT NOT MUCH MOISTURE ASSOCIATED 
WITH IT. A BROAD TROUGH SETS UP OVER THE MIDWEST THIS WEEKEND...AND 
COULD AFFECT PLACEMENT OF HURRICANE FRANCIS. FOR NOW...ADDED SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS FOR LABOR DAY AS A DISTURBANCE MOVES INTO THE BASE OF 
THE TROUGH...BUT CONFIDENCE IS NOT HIGH.
&&

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

51






255 
FXUS64 KLZK 300843
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
342 AM CDT MON AUG 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...
THE SKY WAS CLEAR ACROSS MUCH OF ARKANSAS THIS MORNING WITH HIGH 
PRESSURE BUILDING OVER THE AREA. SATELLITE IMAGES INDICATE ISOLATED 
LOW STRATUS CLOUDS MOVING WEST ACROSS SOME AREAS. THESE CLOUDS WILL 
DISSIPATE THIS MORNING. HIGH CLOUDS CONTINUE TO MOVE NORTHEAST 
ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE CWFA. THESE CLOUDS WILL CONTINUE 
TO SLOWLY MOVE EAST. 

UPPER TROUGH ACROSS THE EASTERN U.S. WILL CONTINUE MOVING EAST. A 
LARGE RIDGE OVER THE WESTERN U.S. WILL SPREAD EASTWARD AND CONTINUE 
THE SUBSIDENCE OVER THE AREA. MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH 
KEEPING DRY AIR OVER THE AREA. MUCH DRIER AIR IS ASSOCIATED WITH 
THE HIGH PRESSURE AREA OVER THE MID SOUTH NOW...AS SEEN WITH THE 
CURRENT DEW POINTS IN THE 50S AND 60S ACROSS THE AREA. DRY AIR WILL 
REMAIN IN PLACE THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT. WILL NOT INCLUDE ANY POPS 
THROUGH THE SHORT TERM. 

WILL GO NEAR THE GFS TEMPERATURES. COOLER THAN NORMAL TEMPERATURES 
ARE EXPECTED TODAY BUT A WARMING TREND WILL BE NOTED THROUGH THE 
WEEK. 
 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY...
GFS MODEL HAS CHANGED ITS THINKING IN REGARDS TO TROPICAL SYSTEM 
THAT WILL BE APPROACHING THE EAST COAST OF THE CONUS LATE IN THE 
PERIOD. WILL GO WITH MORE OF A BLEND OF MODEL SOLUTIONS AS OPPOSED 
TO MORNINGS PAST BUT OVERALL...THE MODELS ARE STILL MAINTAINING A 
DRY FORECAST THROUGH THE PERIOD.

PERIOD STARTS OFF WITH DRY AIR IN PLACE OVER THE FORECAST AREA WITH 
A WEAK TROF OVER THE CENTRAL PLAINS. MEANWHILE...MORE SIGNIFICANT 
TROF STARTS TO DIG OVER THE NORTHERN PLAINS. ENSUING SOUTHWEST FLOW 
IS WEAK AND BEST MOISTURE RETURN REMAINS TO THE SOUTHEAST OF THE 
AREA. MODELS ARE SHOWING SOME WEAK IMPULSES MOVING THROUGH THE FLOW 
BUT WITH LACK OF DYNAMICS...WE WOULD BE HARD PRESSED TO GET ANY 
PRECIP FROM THESE WAVES. FLOW DOES SHARPEN UP CONSIDERABLY ON 
SATURDAY AS AFOREMENTIONED TROF REALLY STARTS TO DIG INTO THE 
NATIONS MID SECTION. MODELS NOW PICKING UP ON A COLD FRONT THAT 
SWINGS THROUGH LATE SATURDAY. FRONT DOES HAVE SOME MOISTURE BUT NOT 
MUCH MORE SO ONLY CLOUDS ARE EXPECTED WITH ITS PASSAGE.

MODELS HAVE REALLY CHANGED THEIR THINKING OF TROPICAL SYSTEM THAT 
WILL BE OFF THE EAST COAST OF FLORIDA BY SATURDAY NIGHT. PREVIOUS 
RUNS WERE CARRYING SYSTEM INTO THE GULF COAST AFTER CROSSING THE 
FLORIDA PENINSULA. CURRENT RUN HAS THE SYSTEM BEING PICKED UP BY THE 
TROF IN THE NATIONS MID SECTION AND CARRYING IT UP THE EASTERN 
SEABOARD. PLACEMENT OF SYSTEM WOULD PRECLUDE ANY MENTION OF PRECIP 
ON SUNDAY AS WELL.

MEX NUMBERS LOOK RIGHT ON TRACK AND WILL BE FOLLOWED FAIRLY CLOSELY. 
DEW POINTS ADVERTISED TO STAY IN THE 60S THROUGH OUT THE PERIOD FOR 
NON OPPRESSIVE CONDITIONS. OF COURSE...ALL IS SUBJECT TO CHANGE IF 
TROPICAL SYSTEM DECIDES TO DO ITS OWN THING. A WARY EYE WILL REMAIN 
ON THE TROPICS FOR THE NEXT WEEK.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    85  64  88  64 /   0   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       82  59  85  60 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    87  63  89  64 /   0   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     85  63  90  64 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  82  59  85  60 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     86  62  90  63 /   0   0   0   0 
SEARCY AR         84  60  87  61 /   0   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      86  62  88  62 /   0   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   85  60  87  61 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

51/56






947 
FXUS64 KLZK 300207
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
856 PM CDT SUN AUG 29 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CLOUDS CONTINUE TO DECREASE AS HIGHER PRESSURE BUILDS INTO OUR 
REGION. DEWPOINTS IN THE 50S ACROSS THE NORTH WILL CONTINUE TO
SPREAD SOUTHWARD.
&&

38
&&

PREVIOUS DISCUSSION...
300 PM CDT SUN AUG 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT
COOLER AND DRIER AIR OVERTAKING THE AREA AND SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE 
CENTERED TO THE NORTH SHOULD COVER THE AREA THROUGH THE MIDDLE
OF THE WEEK. THIS SHOULD KEEP LIGHT NORTHEAST TO EAST FLOW AT LOW 
LEVELS AND LIMIT MOISTURE. UPPER TROF SLOWLY MOVES PAST THE AREA BY
MONDAY THEN NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT CONTINUES. THERE STILL MAY BE A WEAK
SHORT WAVE IN THE FLOW MONDAY NIGHT INTO TUESDAY BUT PRESENT
INDICATIONS ARE IT SHOULD NOT SET OFF ANY PRECIPITATION. MOS MINS
RANGING FROM MID TO UPPER 50S IN THE NORTH TO LOWER 60S MOST OTHER
AREAS TONIGHT LOOK GOOD AND GENERALLY WENT WITH IT. ALSO WENT A
LITTLE COOLER AND WITH MOS FOR MAXES ON MONDAY. A SLOW MODERATION
SHOULD FOLLOW BUT SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE SHOULD BE IN THE AREA 
ENOUGH TO ALLOW FOR GOOD COOLING AGAIN MONDAY NIGHT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SUNDAY
TEMPERATURES WILL BEGIN WARMING BY THURSDAY...AS SURFACE HIGH 
PRESSURE MOVES EASTWARD...AND RETURN FLOW SETS UP. H5 TROUGH LOOKS 
TO TAKE A FAIR AMOUNT OF TIME MOVING ACROSS THE MID SOUTH FROM THE 
TEXAS PLAINS...WITH SEVERAL UPPER IMPULSES MOVING UP AROUND THE 
TROUGH IN THE SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW. WHILE A SURFACE FOCUS WILL BE 
LACKING...CANNOT RULE OUT ISOLATED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FOR 
THURSDAY AND FRIDAY INTO SATURDAY...AS THE SYSTEMS TRAVERSE THE 
FORECAST AREA AND AIR MASS WARMS UP. STRONG UPPER RIDGING WILL 
PRECLUDE ANY PROGRESSION OF SURFACE SYSTEMS...HOLDING A COLD FRONT 
AND SURFACE LOW OUT IN THE PLAINS FOR SEVERAL DAYS. 

FOR LATE DAY 6 AND DAY 7...PICTURE GETS MUCH LESS CLEAR. THE 
PRINCIPAL REASON FOR THIS WILL BE WHETHER OR NOT FRANCES HAS ANY 
INFLUENCE ON WEATHER OVER THE SOUTHERN UNITED STATES. NOT 
SURPRISINGLY...LONG RANGE SOLUTIONS ARE NOT IN THE BEST AGREEMENT 
WITH REGARDS TO POSITION OF THE STORM BY SUNDAY. GFS HAS BEEN 
CONSISTENT THE LAST FEW DAYS BRINGING THE SYSTEM INTO THE GULF...
WITH EVENTUAL LANDFALL BETWEEN SRN MS AND WRN FLORIDA...WITH THE 
OTHER MODELS BRINGING THE SYSTEM ACROSS THE BAHAMAS. REGARDLESS...
WITH THE SYSTEM APPROACHING...FLOW ALOFT AND AT THE SURFACE WILL 
TURN MORE EASTERNLY AND NORTHEASTERLY...THEREFORE SHUTTING OFF 
AVAILABLE MOISTURE FROM THE GULF. THUS HAVE GONE WITH A DRY FORECAST 
FOR SUNDAY...WITH HIGHEST CLOUD COVER IN THE SOUTH AND EAST. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    63  85  64  88 /   0   0   0  10 
HARRISON AR       56  82  59  85 /   0   0  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    63  87  64  89 /   0   0   0  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     64  86  64  90 /  10   0   0  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  56  82  59  85 /   0   0  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     63  87  62  90 /  10   0   0  10 
SEARCY AR         60  84  60  87 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      63  86  62  88 /   0   0   0  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   59  85  60  87 /   0   0  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

LITTLE COOLER AND WITH MOS FOR MAXES ON MONDAY. A SLOW MODERATION
SHOULD FOLLOW BUT SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE SHOULD BE IN THE AREA 
ENOUGH TO ALLOW FOR GOOD COOLING AGAIN MONDAY NIGHT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SUNDAY
TEMPERATURES WILL BEGIN WARMING BY THURSDAY...AS SURFACE HIGH 
PRESSURE MOVES EASTWARD...AND RETURN FLOW SETS UP. H5 TROUGH LOOKS 
TO TAKE A FAIR AMOUNT OF TIME MOVING ACROSS THE MID SOUTH FROM THE 
TEXAS PLAINS...WITH SEVERAL UPPER IMPULSES MOVING UP AROUND THE 
TROUGH IN THE SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW. WHILE A SURFACE FOCUS WILL BE 
LACKING...CANNOT RULE OUT ISOLATED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FOR 
THURSDAY AND FRIDAY INTO SATURDAY...AS THE SYSTEMS TRAVERSE THE 
FORECAST AREA AND AIR MASS WARMS UP. STRONG UPPER RIDGING WILL 
PRECLUDE ANY PROGRESSION OF SURFACE SYSTEMS...HOLDING A COLD FRONT 
AND SURFACE LOW OUT IN THE PLAINS FOR SEVERAL DAYS. 

FOR LATE DAY 6 AND DAY 7...PICTURE GETS MUCH LESS CLEAR. THE 
PRINCIPAL REASON FOR THIS WILL BE WHETHER OR NOT FRANCES HAS ANY 
INFLUENCE ON WEATHER OVER THE SOUTHERN UNITED STATES. NOT 
SURPRISINGLY...LONG RANGE SOLUTIONS ARE NOT IN THE BEST AGREEMENT 
WITH REGARDS TO POSITION OF THE STORM BY SUNDAY. GFS HAS BEEN 
CONSISTENT THE LAST FEW DAYS BRINGING THE SYSTEM INTO THE GULF...
WITH EVENTUAL LANDFALL BETWEEN SRN MS AND WRN FLORIDA...WITH THE 
OTHER MODELS BRINGING THE SYSTEM ACROSS THE BAHAMAS. REGARDLESS...
WITH THE SYSTEM APPROACHING...FLOW ALOFT AND AT THE SURFACE WILL 
TURN MORE EASTERNLY AND NORTHEASTERLY...THEREFORE SHUTTING OFF 
AVAILABLE MOISTURE FROM THE GULF. THUS HAVE GONE WITH A DRY FORECAST 
FOR SUNDAY...WITH HIGHEST CLOUD COVER IN THE SOUTH AND EAST. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    63  85  64  88 /   0   0   0  10 
HARRISON AR       56  82  59  85 /   0   0  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    63  87  64  89 /   0   0   0  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     64  86  64  90 /  10   0   0  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  56  82  59  85 /   0   0  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     63  87  62  90 /  10   0   0  10 
SEARCY AR         60  84  60  87 /   0   0  10  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      63  86  62  88 /   0   0   0  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   59  85  60  87 /   0   0  10  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29/57








070 
FXUS64 KLZK 291911
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT SUN AUG 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT
COOLER AND DRIER AIR OVERTAKING THE AREA AND SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE 
CENTERED TO THE NORTH SHOULD COVER THE AREA THROUGH THE MIDDLE
OF THE WEEK. THIS SHOULD KEEP LIGHT NORTHEAST TO EAST FLOW AT LOW 
LEVELS AND LIMIT MOISTURE. UPPER TROF SLOWLY MOVES PAST THE AREA BY
MONDAY THEN NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT CONTINUES. THERE STILL MAY BE A WEAK
SHORT WAVE IN THE FLOW MONDAY NIGHT INTO TUESDAY BUT PRESENT
INDICATIONS ARE IT SHOULD NOT SET OFF ANY PRECIPITATION. MOS MINS
RANGING FROM MID TO UPPER 50S IN THE NORTH TO LOWER 60S MOST OTHER
AREAS TONIGHT LOOK GOOD AND GENERALLY WENT WITH IT. ALSO WENT A
LITTLE COOLER AND WITH MOS FOR MAXES ON MONDAY. A SLOW MODERATION
SHOULD FOLLOW BUT SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE SHOULD BE IN THE AREA 
ENOUGH TO ALLOW FOR GOOD COOLING AGAIN MONDAY NIGHT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SUNDAY
TEMPERATURES WILL BEGIN WARMING BY THURSDAY...AS SURFACE HIGH 
PRESSURE MOVES EASTWARD...AND RETURN FLOW SETS UP. H5 TROUGH LOOKS 
TO TAKE A FAIR AMOUNT OF TIME MOVING ACROSS THE MID SOUTH FROM THE 
TEXAS PLAINS...WITH SEVERAL UPPER IMPULSES MOVING UP AROUND THE

.DISCUSSION...
SENT OUT UPDATE MAINLY TO CLEAN UP MORNING WORDING IN SOUTH. LEFT
SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND ISOLATED THUNDER IN EXTREME SOUTHEAST
AS FRONT IS STILL IN THAT AREA. CLOUDS IN EAST SHOULD BREAK UP AND
MOVE OUT DURING THE AFTERNOON. SOME AREAS WILL HAVE TO HUSTLE TO
REACH FORECAST MAXES BUT LEFT THEN AS THEY WERE. DO NOT SEE SIGNIFICANT
CHANGES TO SHORT TERM FORECAST...MAINLY TO BLEND IN WITH NEW 
GUIDANCE AND WHAT SURROUNDING OFFICES ARE FORECASTING.

29








454 
FXUS64 KLZK 290839
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
339 AM CDT SUN AUG 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT
COLD FRONT IS TRAVERSING THE STATE THIS MORNING. EARLIER SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS OVER NORTH CENTRAL ARKANSAS HAVE NOW DISSIPATED. THE 
CURRENT LOCATION OF THE FRONT IS FROM NEAR JBR...TO LIT...TO HOT. 
SOUTHEAST MOVEMENT WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE THE DAY KEEPING CHANCES 
OF PRECIPITATION IN THE SOUTH. WILL ONLY KEEP SLIGHT CHANCES IN THE 
SOUTHEAST CORNER THROUGH EARLY AFTERNOON. THE FRONT SHOULD BE OUT OF 
THE AREA BY THEN AND ANY PRECIPITATION WILL BE EAST OF THE CWFA. 

UPPER TROUGH ACROSS THE U.S. WILL MOVE TO THE EAST COAST MONDAY. 
HIGH PRESSURE ACROSS THE WESTERN U.S. WILL BUILD EASTWARD EARLY THIS 
WEEK AND KEEP DRY WEATHER ACROSS THE AREA THROUGH MID WEEK. LOWER 
DEW POINTS AND SLIGHTLY COOLER TEMPERATURES WILL BE NOTED 
MONDAY...THEN A SLOW WARMING TREND WILL BEGIN...WITH LOWER HUMIDITY. 
CROSS SECTIONS SHOW ABUNDANT DRY AIR MOVING IN TODAY AT ALL LEVELS. 

STAYED CLOSE TO THE GFS TEMPERATURES. HIGHS TODAY WILL BE IN THE 80S 
AND IN THE MID 80S TO AROUND 90 FOR MONDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY...
MODELS SHOWING SOME DIFFERENCES THIS MORNING AS OPPOSED TO THE PAST 
FEW WHEN THERE WERE IN EXCELLENT AGREEMENT. BIGGEST DIFFERENCES IS 
IN THE EVOLUTION OF THE UPPER FLOW. GFS HAS BEEN ADVERTISING A SHIFT 
FROM NEAR ZONAL TO ONE THAT IS CONSIDERABLY MORE AMPLIFIED AND 
PROGRESSIVE OVER THE PAST FEW RUNS WHILE THE OTHER MODELS WERE MORE 
SLUGGISH. WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MEAN WESTERN CONUS TROF AND 
EASTERN CONUS RIDGING ...THE OVERALL PATTERN WOULD SEEM TO FAVOR A 
GFS SOLUTION AND WILL LEAN IN ITS DIRECTION THIS MORNING. 

PERIOD STARTS OFF WITH LARGE TROFFING OVER THE WESTERN CONUS WITH  
MUCH WEAKER TROFFING OVER THE NATIONS MID SECTION. STRONG SURFACE 
HIGH WILL MOVE OFF TO THE NEW ENGLAND STATES WITH TROF MOVING 
THROUGH ON FRIDAY. SEVERAL VORT MAXES ARE PROGGED TO MOVE THROUGH 
MEAN FLOW. HOWEVER...DYNAMICS ARE NON EXISTENT AND MOISTURE IS 
LIMITED SO ONLY CLOUDS ARE EXPECTED DURING THIS TIME. FORECAST GETS 
A LITTLE TRICKIER FOR DAY SEVEN AS RETURN FLOW GETS REESTABLISHED 
WITH A CORRESPONDING INCREASE IN MOISTURE. AS SUCH...WILL CONTINUE 
THE SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR CENTRAL AND SOUTH DAY SEVEN. CONFIDENCE 
IN THE FORECAST LESSENS WITH TIME AS TROPICS LOOK TO BECOME ACTIVE 
WITH SYSTEM POSSIBLY APPROACHING SOUTHERN FLORIDA BY THE END OF THE 
PERIOD.

MEX GUIDANCE SHOWS TEMPERATURES SHOULD BE CLOSE TO NORMAL FOR THE 
PERIOD AND CURRENT FORECAST HAS IT PEGGED SO NO CHANGES WILL BE MADE 
HERE. MODELS ALSO SHOWING KEEPING RELATIVELY DRY AIR IN PLACE 
THROUGH THE PERIOD WITH DEW POINT TEMPS PROGGED TO STAY IN THE MID 
60S. IT APPEARS HUMIDITY LEVELS WILL BE TOLERABLE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    85  65  87  65 /  10   0   0   0 
HARRISON AR       80  57  84  60 /   0   0   0   0 
HOT SPRINGS AR    85  64  88  65 /  10   0   0   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     86  65  88  66 /  20  10   0   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  80  57  84  60 /   0   0   0   0 
MONTICELLO AR     87  66  89  66 /  20  10   0   0 
SEARCY AR         84  64  87  63 /  10   0   0   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      85  63  88  65 /  10   0   0   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   83  60  86  63 /   0   0   0   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

FXUS64 KLZK 290248 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
940 PM CDT SAT AUG 28 2004

.DISCUSSION...
GOING FORECAST PRETTY MUCH ON TARGET...WITH COLD FRONT IN CENTRAL 
ARKANSAS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE HEADING TOWARD THE GULF COAST 
OVERNIGHT AND SUNDAY. STILL SOME SCATTERED SHOWERS/ISOLATED 
THUNDERSTORMS TO CONTEND WITH...WITH A FEW SHOWERS LINGERING IN 
SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE SUNDAY MORNING.

OTHERWISE...ADDED SOME FOG OVERNIGHT...WITH FOG MOST PREVALENT IN 
AREAS WHERE IT RAINED RECENTLY AND THE GROUND IS SATURATED. SOME 
CLEARING IN THE NORTH/WEST WILL HELP FOG DEVELOP AS WELL. 

HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD INTO THE REGION BEHIND THE FRONT TO START 
THE NEW WEEK. SLIGHTLY COOLER/DRIER AIR WITH HIGH. NEXT CHANCE OF 
RAIN LATE IN THE WEEK AS A NEW FRONT APPROACHES FROM THE WEST. (46) 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.



122 
FXUS64 KLZK 281931
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT SAT AUG 28 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
LINE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS HAS ABOUT WORKED ITS WAY THROUGH
THE CWA. IT HAS WORKED OVER THE AIR MASS TAKING OUT MUCH OF THE
INSTABILITY. ONLY PATCHY RAIN REMAINS BEHIND THE AREA. THE MAIN 
COLD FRONT IS HARD TO FIND BUT IS LIKELY IN WESTERN SECTIONS.
STILL MAY BE SOME DEVELOPMENT OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ALONG
THE FRONT LATER TODAY INTO TONIGHT BUT CHANCES DO NOT LOOK AS GOOD
AS THEY DID EARLIER. LOWERED POPS SOME FOR TONIGHT BUT KEPT 50 TO60 
POPS GOING IN THE SOUTHEAST WHERE THE MOST INSTABILITY REMAINS. 
POPS LOWER LATER TONIGHT AND ONLY KEPT SMALL POPS FOR THE SOUTH 
ON SUNDAY AS HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN FROM THE NORTH. THIS HIGH 
PRESSURE DOMINATES THE AREA INTO EARLY IN THE WEEK AND SHOULD KEEP 
THE AREA DRY. STILL NEED TO WATCH FOR A WEAK SHORT WAVE IN NORTHWEST 
FLOW MONDAY NIGHT INTO TUESDAY BUT IT LOOKS WEAKER ON TODAYS PROGS.
GOING TEMP FORECASTS LOOK GOOD AND NO CHANGES WERE MADE.  
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
HATE TO KEEP SOUNDING LIKE A BROKEN RECORD...BUT GOING FORECAST 
CONTINUES TO LOOK FAIRLY DECENT. SURFACE RIDGING WILL BE DOMINANT 
OVER THE MIDSOUTH AT THE BEGINNING OF THE EXTENDED. H5 FLOW WILL 
VARY FROM NORTHWESTERLY TO ZONAL. A COUPLE OF IMPULSES MAY MOVE 
ACROSS IN THE MEAN FLOW...HOWEVER DUE TO LACK OF A FOCUS...AND CAP 
IN PLACE...SHOULD ONLY SEE SOME CLOUDS AND NOTHING MORE. 

BY FRIDAY...SURFACE RIDGE WILL SLIDE ON TO THE EAST...WITH RETURN 
FLOW SETTING UP OVER THE AREA. FLOW ALOFT WILL BECOME MORE 
SOUTHWESTERLY...WITH WEAK SHORTWAVE MOVING INTO THE FORECAST AREA. 
THUS...HAVE CONTINUED SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR FRIDAY...AND INTO THE 
WEEKEND. 

BOTTOM LINE IS THAT ASIDE FROM A FEW MINOR ADJUSTMENTS TO SENSIBLE 
WEATHER PARAMETERS...NO MAJOR CHANGES WERE MADE TO THE EXTENDED.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    69  86  65  88 /  50  20  10   0 
HARRISON AR       61  81  57  85 /  30  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    69  86  64  89 /  50  20  10   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     70  87  65  89 /  60  20  10   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  61  81  57  85 /  30  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     71  88  66  90 /  60  30  10   0 
SEARCY AR         68  85  64  88 /  50  10  10   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      68  86  63  89 /  50  10  10   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   66  84  60  87 /  40  10  10   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT SAT AUG 28 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
LINE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS HAS ABOUT WORKED ITS WAY THROUGH
THE CWA. IT HAS WORKED OVER THE AIR MASS TAKING OUT MUCH OF THE
INSTABILITY. ONLY PATCHY RAIN REMAINS BEHIND THE AREA. THE MAIN 
COLD FRONT IS HARD TO FIND BUT IS LIKELY IN WESTERN SECTIONS.
STILL MAY BE SOME DEVELOPMENT OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ALONG
THE FRONT LATER TODAY INTO TONIGHT BUT CHANCES DO NOT LOOK AS GOOD
AS THEY DID EARLIER. LOWERED POPS SOME FOR TONIGHT BUT KEPT 50 TO60 
POPS GOING IN THE SOUTHEAST WHERE THE MOST INSTABILITY REMAINS. 
POPS LOWER LATER TONIGHT AND ONLY KEPT SMALL POPS FOR THE SOUTH 
ON SUNDAY AS HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN FROM THE NORTH. THIS HIGH 
PRESSURE DOMINATES THE AREA INTO EARLY IN THE WEEK AND SHOULD KEEP 
THE AREA DRY. STILL NEED TO WATCH FOR A WEAK SHORT WAVE IN NORTHWEST 
FLOW MONDAY NIGHT INTO TUESDAY BUT IT LOOKS WEAKER ON TODAYS PROGS.
GOING TEMP FORECASTS LOOK GOOD AND NO CHANGES WERE MADE.  
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
HATE TO KEEP SOUNDING LIKE A BROKEN RECORD...BUT GOING FORECAST 
CONTINUES TO LOOK FAIRLY DECENT. SURFACE RIDGING WILL BE DOMINANT 
OVER THE MIDSOUTH AT THE BEGINNING OF THE EXTENDED. H5 FLOW WILL 
VARY FROM NORTHWESTERLY TO ZONAL. A COUPLE OF IMPULSES MAY MOVE 
ACROSS IN THE MEAN FLOW...HOWEVER DUE TO LACK OF A FOCUS...AND CAP 
IN PLACE...SHOULD ONLY SEE SOME CLOUDS AND NOTHING MORE. 

BY FRIDAY...SURFACE RIDGE WILL SLIDE ON TO THE EAST...WITH RETURN 
FLOW SETTING UP OVER THE AREA. FLOW ALOFT WILL BECOME MORE 
SOUTHWESTERLY...WITH WEAK SHORTWAVE MOVING INTO THE FORECAST AREA. 
THUS...HAVE CONTINUED SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR FRIDAY...AND INTO THE 
WEEKEND. 

BOTTOM LINE IS THAT ASIDE FROM A FEW MINOR ADJUSTMENTS TO SENSIBLE 
WEATHER PARAMETERS...NO MAJOR CHANGES WERE MADE TO THE EXTENDED.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    69  86  65  88 /  50  20  10   0 
HARRISON AR       61  81  57  85 /  30  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    69  86  64  89 /  50  20  10   0 
PINE BLUFF AR     70  87  65  89 /  60  20  10   0 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  61  81  57  85 /  30  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     71  88  66  90 /  60  30  10   0 
SEARCY AR         68  85  64  88 /  50  10  10   0 
MOUNT IDA AR      68  86  63  89 /  50  10  10   0 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   66  84  60  87 /  40  10  10   0 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29/57






851 
FXUS64 KLZK 281625
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1125 AM CDT SAT AUG 28 2004

.DISCUSSION... 
AREA OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS SLOWLY PROGRESSING TO THE EAST ACROSS
THE AREA AHEAD OF A COLD FRONT. TEMPS WARMING RAPIDLY AHEAD OF THE AREA
OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. THIS INSTABILITY WILL INCREASE CHANCE
OF SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS AND MICROBURSTS IN CENTRAL AND EASTERN SECTIONS
DURING THE AFTERNOON. LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN WITH 2 INCHES OR MORE POSSIBLE
BASED ON PRECIP WATER OF 2 INCHES OR MORE...BUT STILL LOOKS LIKE GENERAL
RAINFALL WILL BE 1/4 TO 1/2 INCH OR SO. KEPT LIKELY POPS THROUGH THE
AFTERNOON AND ADJUSTED TEMP...DEW POINT AND WIND FORECASTS BASED ON
OBSERVED DATA AT LATE MORNING AND CONTINUED SLOW EASTWARD PROGRESSION
OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. TEMPS SHOULD REACH LOWER TO MID 90S
IN CENTRAL AND EAST BEFORE RAIN ARRIVES BUT INDICATED DROP INTO 70S
AND 80S. TEMPS MAY RECOVER SOME IN THE WEST THIS AFTERNOON AND PUT
MAXES MOSTLY IN LOWER TO MID 80S THERE. PUT IN MENTION OF LOCALLY 
HEAVY RAIN MOSTLY FOR THIS AFTERNOON. REST OF FORECAST KEPT AS IS 
FOR NOW.     
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29



517 
FXUS64 KLZK 280831
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
331 AM CDT SAT AUG 28 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
CLOUDS HAVE BEEN INCREASING ACROSS MUCH OF ARKANSAS THIS MORNING PER 
SURFACE OBSERVATIONS AND SATELLITE IMAGES. SHOWERS HAVE DEVELOPED 
ACROSS THE NORTHWEST HALF OF THE CWFA ALONG THE PREFRONTAL TROUGH. 
WILL EXPECT THESE SHOWERS TO SPREAD ACROSS THE AREA LATER THIS 
MORNING. 

THE LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS THE APPROACHING COLD FRONT FROM 
CENTRAL MISSOURI...TO SOUTHEAST KANSAS...TO CENTRAL OKLAHOMA WITH 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ALONG THE FRONT. THE FRONT WILL CONTINUE 
TO MOVE SOUTHEAST TODAY WITH HELP FROM THE UPPER TROUGH OVER THE MID 
SECTION OF THE U.S. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL DEVELOP ALONG THE 
FRONT. MODELS CONTINUE TO BE IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THIS SYSTEM. THE 
FRONT SHOULD EXIT SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS ON SUNDAY AND WILL TAPER POPS 
DOWN FROM NORTHWEST TO SOUTHEAST FOR SUNDAY. HIGH PRESSURE MOVES IN 
FOR MONDAY AND DRY CONDITIONS WILL CONTINUE THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT. 

CROSS SECTIONS SHOW ABUNDANT MOISTURE ACROSS THE AREA THROUGH SUNDAY 
MORNING. MUCH DRIER AIR ADVECTS IN SUNDAY. ARKANSAS WILL BE BACK IN 
THE NORTHWEST FLOW BY MONDAY. 

TEMPERATURES WILL BE A BIT COOLER TODAY WITH EXCESSIVE CLOUD COVER 
AND PRECIPITATION. DRIER AIR WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA TONIGHT AND 
SUNDAY...RIDDING THE AIR OF MUCH OF THE HUMIDITY.
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY...
AS HAS BEEN THE CASE OVER THE PAST FEW NIGHTS...THE MEDIUM RANGE 
MODELS CONTINUE TO BE EXCELLENT AGREEMENT AND JUST A BLEND OF 
SOLUTIONS WITH A SLIGHT JOG TOWARDS THE MORE CONSISTENT GFS IS 
REQUIRED. REGARDLESS...IT LOOKS A RATHER BENIGN PATTERN WILL 
PREDOMINATE THIS PERIOD WITH TEMPERATURES HOVERING RIGHT AROUND 
SEASONAL NORMS. MODELS ARE ALSO CONSISTENT WITH KEEPING CONSIDERABLY 
DRIER AIR OVER THE REGION AS SPRAWLING AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE WILL 
PREDOMINATE MOST OF THE PERIOD. 

PERIOD STARTS OFF WITH HIGH PRESSURE WELL IN CONTROL ON THE SURFACE 
WITH A PATTERN ALOFT THAT IS NON EVENTFUL AT BEST. DAYS FOUR AND 
FIVE AND CHARACTERIZED BY MOISTURE TRYING TO MOVE INTO THE AREA ON 
THE WESTERN PERIPHERY OF THE HIGH CENTERED IN THE OHIO VALLEY. WITH 
NO SIGNIFICANT SHORTWAVES NOTED AND EVEN LESS DYNAMICS...WILL 
CONTINUE THE CURRENT DRY FORECAST. SURFACE HIGH HAS MOVED OFF TO THE 
EAST BY FRIDAY MORNING WITH A CORRESPONDING INCREASE IN BOTH 
TEMPERATURE AND HUMIDITY. MODELS KEEPING DEW POINT TEMPERATURES IN 
THE 60S EVEN OUT THROUGH DAY SEVEN SO OVERALL CONDITIONS WILL NOT BE 
OPPRESSIVE. CURRENT FORECAST HAS SLIGHT CHANCE POPS OVER THE 
SOUTHERN TWO THIRDS OF THE CWA ON DAY SEVEN AND THIS LOOKS 
REASONABLE WITH RETURN FLOW SETTING BACK UP AND MODELS HINTING AT A 
WEAK SHORTWAVE APPROACHING FROM THE SOUTHWEST.

OVERALL FORECAST LOOKS TO BE IN OUTSTANDING SHAPE AND ONLY A FEW 
SUPERFICIAL CHANGES ARE NEEDED AT THIS TIME.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    89  69  86  65 /  60  60  20  10 
HARRISON AR       82  61  81  57 /  60  50  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    89  69  86  64 /  60  60  20  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     91  70  87  65 /  60  60  30  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  83  61  81  57 /  60  50  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     91  71  88  66 /  60  60  30  10 
SEARCY AR         88  68  85  64 /  60  60  20  10 
MOUNT IDA AR      88  68  86  63 /  60  60  20  10 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   86  66  84  60 /  60  60  20  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

719 
FXUS64 KLZK 280310 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1000 PM CDT FRI AUG 27 2004

.DISCUSSION...
FRONT FROM NORTHERN ILLINOIS TO NORTHWEST MISSOURI...SOUTHEAST 
KANSAS...WESTERN OKLAHOMA MAKING VERY SLOW PROGRESS TO THE 
SOUTHEAST. UNTIL FRONT ARRIVES...ATMOSPHERE FAIRLY WELL CAPPED...AND 
LOOKS DRY/MUGGY MUCH OF CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS OVERNIGHT. IN 
NORTHERN AND WESTERN SECTIONS...KEPT CHANCES OF THUNDER IN AFTER 
MIDNIGHT AS FRONT NEARS. 

BETTER CHANCES FOR THUNDER/MORE CLOUDS ON SATURDAY AS FRONT FINALLY 
PUSHES INTO THE STATE. GOOD CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION MENTIONED 
THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT...BUT WITH LITTLE IN THE WAY OF SEVERE 
WEATHER. 

FRONT WILL EXIT TO THE SOUTH ON SUNDAY WITH CLOUDS DECREASING. 
SLIGHTLY COOLER/DRIER AIR TO FOLLOW FRONT...WITH SLIGHTLY BELOW 
NORMAL TEMPERATURES. (46)
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED

46







468 
FXUS64 KLZK 271927
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT FRI AUG 27 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
COLD FRONT SLOWLY MAKING ITS WAY DOWN THE PLAINS TOWARD THE AREA WHILE
RIDGING ALOFT CONTINUES FOR THE SHORT TERM. THIS IS KEEPING THE AREA 
CAPPED WITH NO MORE THAN ISOLATED CONVECTION. THIS SHOULD CONTINUE
THROUGH EARLY EVENING. FRONT LOOKS LIKE IT WILL BE A LITTLE SLOWER
MOVING IN...NOT REACHING THE CWA UNTIL EARLY SATURDAY MORNING. 
CONVECTION ASSOCIATED WITH THE FRONT WILL LIKELY BE DELAYED BUT 
MODELS DO INCREASE MOISTURE IN THE AREA OVER NIGHT SO COULD SEE
SOME DEVELOPMENT AHEAD OF THE FRONT LATE TONIGHT ALTHOUGH IT SHOULD
STILL BE RATHER ISOLATED AND LIGHT. CUT BACK ON POPS A LITTLE FOR
LATER TONIGHT AND LEFT UNCERTAINTY WORDING IN THE NORTHWEST
BUT ISOLATED WORDING ELSEWHERE. COLD FRONT LIKELY WILL BE SLOW TO
MOVE ACROSS HILLY AREAS OF NORTHWEST SATURDAY AND THIS MAY ALLOW 
CENTRAL AND SOUTH TO HEAT UP SOMEWHAT...REACHING NEAR OR A LITTLE 
ABOVE 90 AGAIN. HEAT INDEX SHOULD STAY BELOW ADVISORY LEVELS BUT MAY 
EXCEED 100 IN PARTS OF THE SOUTHEAST. WILL INCREASE POPS ACROSS
THE AREA TO 50 PERCENT BY AFTERNOON AND WILL PUT IN LIKELY POPS 
ACROSS THE NORTH CLOSER TO THE BETTER DYNAMICS. MAIN UPPER SHORT 
WAVE SHOULD PASS TO THE NORTH OF THE AREA SO SHEAR AND DYNAMICS 
SHOULD NOT BE SUFFICIENT FOR SIGNIFICANT SEVERE WEATHER BUT 
ISOLATED SEVERE CANNOT BE RULED OUT WITH THE INSTABILITY IN PLACE.
ALSO 2 PLUS INCHES OF PRECIPITABLE WATER RAISES HEAVY RAIN 
CONCERNS BUT FEEL LIKE GENERAL RAINFALL WILL NOT BE TOO EXCESSIVE
BUT LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN WILL BE LIKELY. WILL CONTINUE 40 TO 50
POPS INTO SATURDAY NIGHT THEN TAPER OFF POPS FROM THE NORTH LATE. 
STILL SOME LACK OF CONFIDENCE WHETHER THE DRIER AIR WILL MOVE
IN THAT FAST AND WENT A LITTLE SLOWER THAN THE MODELS. STILL SHOULD
SEE COOLER AIR MOVE INTO MOST OF THE AREA WITH MOST MINS IN THE 60S
AND THE NORTH NEAR 60. KEPT SOME POPS IN SUNDAY EXCEPT IN THE NORTH
BUT END ALL CHANCE OF RAIN BY THE END OF THE DAY. SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE
TO THE NORTH SHOULD BRING DRY AND MILD WEATHER IN THROUGH MONDAY 
NIGHT. HAVE CONCERN FOR SHORT WAVE IN NORTHWEST FLOW MONDAY NIGHT
BUT WILL IGNORE FOR NOW. WILL NEED TO WATCH THIS OVER THE NEXT FEW
MODEL RUNS.   
&& 

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
NOT MUCH CHANGES HAVE BEEN MADE TO GOING FORECAST. SURFACE HIGH 
PRESSURE WILL BE THE DOMINANT FEATURE FOR MUCH OF THE EXTENDED. H5 
FLOW WILL VARY FROM NORTHWESTERLY TO NEAR ZONAL...WITH SEVERAL AREAS 
OF MOISTURE MOVING ACROSS IN THE MEAN FLOW. HOWEVER...LACK OF A 
FORCING MECHANISM...ALONG WITH CAPPING THAT WILL LIKELY TO BE OVER 
THE AREA PRECLUDES THE MENTION OF RAIN CHANCES FOR DAYS 4 THROUGH 6 
AT THIS TIME.

BY LATE WEDNESDAY...HIGH PRESSURE WILL MOVE EASTWARD TOWARD THE 
APPALACHIANS...WITH RETURN FLOW SETTING UP OVER THE AREA. THUS...
TEMPERATURES WILL MODERATE TOWARD MORE SEASONAL LEVELS. A SLIGHT 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL RETURN TO THE FORECAST FOR 
ABOUT THE SOUTHERN TWO THIRDS OF THE AREA ON FRIDAY...AS A WEAK 
SHORTWAVE APPROACHES. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    76  90  68  86 /  20  50  50  20 
HARRISON AR       71  82  60  81 /  30  60  50  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    76  89  68  86 /  20  50  50  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     77  91  69  87 /  20  50  50  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  71  83  60  81 /  30  60  50  10 
MONTICELLO AR     76  91  70  88 /  20  50  50  40 
SEARCY AR         75  89  67  85 /  20  50  50  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      75  88  67  86 /  20  50  50  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   74  86  65  84 /  30  50  50  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

HARRISON AR       71  82  60  81 /  30  60  50  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    76  89  68  86 /  20  50  50  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     77  91  69  87 /  20  50  50  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  71  83  60  81 /  30  60  50  10 
MONTICELLO AR     76  91  70  88 /  20  50  50  40 
SEARCY AR         75  89  67  85 /  20  50  50  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      75  88  67  86 /  20  50  50  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   74  86  65  84 /  30  50  50  10 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

29/57






704 
FXUS64 KLZK 271545
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1045 AM CDT FRI AUG 27 2004

.DISCUSSION...
RIDGING ALOFT REMAINS OVER THE AREA WITH A CAP OR TWO PRESENT. AIR REMAINS
MOIST AT LOW LEVELS AND QUITE UNSTABLE. COLD FRONT TO THE NORTHWEST
WILL MAKE SLOW PROGRESS TODAY BUT SHOULD STAY WELL NORTHWEST OF THE
AREA AND WILL NOT INCREASE SPEED UNTIL UPPER TROF TO THE WEST SWINGS
CLOSER. LOOKS LIKE ANY SHOWER OR THUNDERSTORM DEVELOPMENT THIS 
AFTERNOON AND EVENING SHOULD STAY ISOLATED LIKE IT WAS THE PAST TWO 
DAYS AND WENT BACK TO ISOLATED WORDING FOR THIS AFTERNOON ACROSS
THE ENTIRE AREA AND FOR THE CENTRAL AND SOUTH THIS EVENING. TEMP
FORECASTS LOOK GOOD BUT DID MAKE MINOR ADJUSTMENTS TO DEW POINTS
BASED ON OBSERVED DEW POINTS AT ISSUE TIME. INCREASED WINDS SLIGHTLY
ALSO BASED ON OBSERVED DATA. REST OF FORECAST KEPT THE SAME. CHANCES
OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS SHOULD INCREASE FROM THE NORTHWEST 
TONIGHT AS THE FRONT APPROACHES AND LEFT UNCERTAINTY WORDING IN 
THE NORTHWEST FOR ALL NIGHT AND FOR OTHER AREAS LATER TONIGHT. 
HEAT INDICES WILL MEET ADVISORY LEVELS FOR AWHILE THIS AFTERNOON
IN PARTS OF CENTRAL AND SOUTH BUT WILL NOT BE MET SATURDAY.   
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29








702 
FXUS64 KLZK 270840
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
338 AM CDT FRI AUG 27 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
HIGH PRESSURE AT THE SURFACE CONTINUED TO BE LOCATED OVER THE 
SOUTHEAST U.S. AND LOW PRESSURE WAS LOCATED ACROSS MISSOURI AND 
KANSAS ON THE LATEST ANALYSIS. A COLD FRONT STRETCHED FROM NORTHWEST 
MISSOURI THROUGH CENTRAL KANSAS. IN THE UPPER LEVELS OF THE 
ATMOSPHERE A BROAD TROUGH WAS LOCATED OVER THE CENTRAL U.S. AND HIGH 
PRESSURE REMAINED OVER THE SOUTHEAST PART OF THE COUNTRY. 

MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THE MOVEMENT OF THE NEXT SYSTEM. 
WILL EXPECT ISOLATED DIURNAL SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WITH THE 
AFTERNOON HEATING TODAY. AS THE TROUGH PUSHES THE COLD FRONT THROUGH 
THE AREA...THE BEST CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE 
DURING THE WEEKEND. THE COLD FRONT WILL ENTER NORTHWEST ARKANSAS 
SATURDAY MORNING AND SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE ALONG AND 
AHEAD OF THE FRONT. WILL TAPER PRECIPITATION CHANCES FROM NORTH TO 
SOUTH ON SUNDAY. HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS INTO THE AREA SUNDAY NIGHT AND 
INTO MONDAY. COOLER AND DRIER AIR IS EXPECTED TO RETURN ALONG WITH 
NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT. THEREFORE...WILL NOT INCLUDE ANY CHANCES OF 
RAIN FOR MONDAY AND MONDAY NIGHT. 

TEMPERATURES WILL BE COOLER ON SATURDAY AND SUNDAY WITH ABUNDANT 
CLOUD COVER AND PRECIPITATION. WARMER TEMPERATURES ARE EXPECTED ON 
MONDAY WITH INCREASED SUNSHINE.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY...
MEDIUM RANGE MODELS CONTINUE TO BE IN EXCELLENT AGREEMENT THIS 
MORNING AND WILL SIMPLY FOLLOW A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS WITH A SLIGHT 
LEAN TOWARDS THE MORE CONSISTENT GFS. REGARDLESS...IT LOOKS LIKE  
DRY WEATHER WILL DOMINATE THIS PERIOD WITH TEMPERATURES HOVERING 
RIGHT AROUND SEASONAL NORMS. BIGGEST IMPACT ON SENSIBLE WEATHER 
WOULD BE DRIER AIR COMING IN WITH MODELS FORECASTING AS MUCH AS 12 
TO 15 DEGREE DROP IN DEW POINTS. 

PERIOD STARTS OFF WITH HIGH PRESSURE WELL IN CONTROL ON THE SURFACE 
AND PLENTY OF DRY AIR IN PLACE. BROAD RIDGING OVER THE NATIONS MID 
SECTION WILL KEEP WEAK NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT IN PLACE. SURFACE HIGH 
BEGINS TO SLIP OFF TO THE EAST BY WEDNESDAY MORNING AND FLOW BUCKLES 
AS A SIGNIFICANT TROF COMES ON SHORE OVER THE PAC NW. AS A RESULT... 
RETURN FLOW GETS REESTABLISHED FOR AN INCREASE IN CLOUD COVER LATE 
WEDNESDAY BUT NOT MUCH MORE. NOT SEEING MUCH IN THE WAY OF RAIN 
CHANCES NEXT THURSDAY SO WILL DROP POPS DOWN TO SILENT 10 PERCENT 
AND GO DRY THROUGH THE PERIOD. MEX NUMBERS LOOK RIGHT ON TARGET AND 
WILL BE FOLLOWED FAIRLY CLOSELY.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    95  75  88  67 /  20  20  50  50 
HARRISON AR       92  70  82  61 /  20  40  50  50 
HOT SPRINGS AR    95  75  87  67 /  20  20  50  50 
PINE BLUFF AR     95  75  89  69 /  20  20  40  50 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  92  71  83  62 /  20  40  50  50 
MONTICELLO AR     95  75  91  70 /  20  20  40  50 
SEARCY AR         94  75  87  67 /  20  20  50  50 
MOUNT IDA AR      95  74  87  67 /  20  20  50  50 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   95  73  86  66 /  20  30  50  50 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

759 
FXUS64 KLZK 270246 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
940 PM CDT THU AUG 26 2004

.DISCUSSION...
WENT AHEAD AND REMOVED CHANCES FOR RAIN OVERNIGHT. LATEST LZK 
SOUNDING SHOWING -4C AT H5 AND +12C AT H7...WITH CAPPING LEADING TO 
FORMATION OF LOW CLOUDS TOWARD MORNING. THIS ALREADY COVERED IN 
GOING FORECAST. 

CAP STILL IN PLACE ON FRIDAY...WITH HIGH PRESSURE OVER SOUTH 
CENTRAL/SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES. AGAIN...ANY PRECIPITATION WILL BE 
ISOLATED...WITH ANOTHER HOT AFTERNOON IN STORE.

HIGH WILL BREAK DOWN TO BEGIN THE WEEKEND. THIS WILL ALLOW A COLD 
FRONT TO PUSH INTO ARKANSAS FROM THE NORTHWEST FRIDAY 
NIGHT/SATURDAY. CLOUDS WILL INCREASE...WITH BETTER CHANCES FOR 
SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS. 

SLIGHTLY COOLER/DRIER AIR WILL FOLLOW THE FRONT ON SUNDAY. (46)
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

46






104 
FXUS64 KLZK 261916
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT THU AUG 26 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
UPPER RIDGE SHOULD DOMINATE THE AREA THROUGH FRIDAY BEFORE 
UNUSUALLY STRONG UPPER TROF FOR THIS TIME OF YEAR SWINGS ACROSS 
THE PLAINS AND SHOULD GIVE THE COLD FRONT IN THE PLAINS ENOUGH
OF A PUSH TO MOVE THROUGH THE AREA. AN UPPER SHEAR AXIS REMAINS
OVER SOUTHERN SECTIUONS THROUGH FRIDAY WITH HIGH LOW LEVEL 
MOISTURE PRESENT. HOWEVER UPPER RIDGE SHOULD KEEP ENOUGH OF A CAP
ON THE AREA TO PREVENT MUCH CONVECTION FROM FORMING THROUGH EARLY
FRIDAY NIGHT. CANNOT COMPLETELY RULE OUT SOME DIURNALLY DRIVEN 
CONVECTION DUE TO THE MOISTURE INSTABILITY AND SHEAR AXIS...SO WILL
KEEP SMALL POPS GOING IN THE AFTERNOON AND EVENING WITH ISOLATED 
WORDING IN THE ZONES. COLD FRONT BEARING DOWN ON THE AREA FRIDAY
MAY LEAD TO A LITTLE ADDITIONAL WARMING AND WILL GO WITH MAXES NEAR 
95 IN MOST OF CENTRAL AND SOUTH AND ABOUT A CATEGORY COOLER IN THE 
NORTH. HEAT INDEX REACHES ADVISORY LEVELS FOR AN HOUR OR TWO IN 
CENTRAL AND SOUTH ON FRIDAY BUT THIS IS NOT EXPECTED TO CONTINUE 
SATURDAY SO ADVISORY CRITERIA WILL NOT BE MET. HIGH HEAT INDICES 
FOR FRIDAY CAN BE HANDLED BY ZONE TEXT AND HWO. MODELS BRING THE 
COLD FRONT THROUGH FASTER NOW AND THIS LOOKS REASONABLE AS THE UPPER 
TROF SWINGS ACROSS THE MIDDLE OF THE COUNTRY. LOOKS LIKE FRONT
WILL REACH THE NORTHWEST LATE FRIDAY NIGHT AND WILL VERY SLOWLY GET 
THROUGH THE HILLS IN THE NORTHWEST INTO SATURDAY BEFORE MOVING 
MORE RAPIDLY THROUGH THE REST OF THE AREA SATURDAY NIGHT. WILL 
INCREASE POPS IN THE NORTHWEST LATE FRIDAY NIGHT AND ELSEWHERE BY 
SATURDAY MORNING. FOR NOW WILL MAX POPS OUT AT 50 PERCENT SATURDAY
AFTERNOON ACROSS THE ENTIRE AREA AND CONTINUE WITH 40 PERCENT POPS
SATURDAY NIGHT. EVOLUTION OF SYSTEM SUGGESTS CHANCES OF RAIN WILL
END IN MOST AREAS BY SUNDAY MORNING BUT WILL CONTINUE SOME POPS
THROUGH THE DAY SUNDAY IN CASE THE FRONT HANGS UP. CONTINUED SMALL
POPS IN THE SOUTHEAST INTO EARLY SUNDAY NIGHT FOR THE SAME 
REASONING. FASTER FRONTAL PROGRESS LED TO LOWERING TEMP FORECASTS
A LITTLE FOR SATURDAY AND SATURDAY NIGHT.   
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
NORTHWESTERLY FLOW WILL SET UP OVER THE AREA FOR THE BEGINNING OF 
THE WEEK. HOWEVER...WITH SURFACE HIGH MOVING DOWN FROM THE CENTRAL 
PLAINS...ANY CONVECTIVE ACTIVITY WILL BE SUPPRESSED. RIDGE OVER THE 
AREA AND NORTHWESTERLY FLOW WILL ALLOW FOR NEAR TO SLIGHTLY BELOW 
NORMAL TEMPERATURES THROUGH MUCH OF THE PERIOD. SURFACE RIDGE WILL 
BEGIN MOVING OFF TO THE EAST BY LATE WEDNESDAY...WITH RETURN FLOW 
SETTING UP. CLOUDS WILL INCREASE...AND RAIN CHANCES RETURN TO THE 
FORECAST BY THURSDAY...AS A SHORTWAVE WILL APPROACH FROM WEST 
TEXAS. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    77  95  75  87 /  20  20  20  50 
HARRISON AR       73  92  70  83 /  20  20  30  50 
HOT SPRINGS AR    79  95  75  87 /  20  20  20  50 
PINE BLUFF AR     77  95  75  89 /  20  20  20  50 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  73  92  71  83 /  20  20  30  50 
MONTICELLO AR     77  95  75  91 /  20  20  20  50 
SEARCY AR         76  95  75  87 /  20  20  20  50 
MOUNT IDA AR      78  95  74  87 /  20  20  20  50 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   76  95  73  86 /  20  20  20  50 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$


575 
FXUS64 KLZK 261556
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1055 AM CDT THU AUG 26 2004

.DISCUSSION... 
UPPER RIDGE OVER THE AREA AND RAOB SHOWS SEVERAL CAPS PRESENT. AIR
MASS IS VERY MOIST AND UNSTABLE WITH THE MAIN MOISTURE AT LOW LEVELS.
CAPS SHOULD KEEP SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FROM DEVELOPING FOR THE 
MOST PART BUT CANNOT RULE OUT ISOLATED DEVELOPMENT. ANYTHING THAT 
IS ABLE TO DEVELOP COULD PULSE TO SEVERE LEVELS LIKE WHAT HAPPENED
LAST EVENING. KEPT 20 PERCENT POPS IN ZONE PRODUCTS AND LOWERED POPS
TO 16 PERCENT IN GRIDS...WHICH LOOKS TOO HIGH...BUT DECIDED TO KEEP
MENTION IN THE FORECAST FOR ISOLATED DEVELOPMENT. CHANGED WORDING
FOR THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING TO ISOLATED WHICH SHOULD BETTER FIT
SCENARIO. MADE SOME MINOR TWEAKS TO TEMPS AND DEW POINTS BASED ON
CURRENT TRENDS BUT THIS MADE LITTLE CHANGE TO OVERALL FORECAST. 
HEAT INDEX VALUES MAY BRIEFLY REACH 105 AT ISOLATED LOCATIONS 
IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH THIS AFTERNOON AND FRIDAY BUT LOOKS LIKE IT WILL
NOT BE ENOUGH TO NEED A HEAT ADVISORY. THIS IS COVERED IN THE HWO.
REST OF FORECAST LEFT AS IS FOR NOW. WILL PROBABLY CHANGE WORDING 
TO ISOLATED FOR SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FRIDAY ON THE AFTERNOON
PACKAGE.   
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29







.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT
HIGH CLOUDS OVER THE SOUTHEAST HALF OF ARKANSAS THIS MORNING...AS 
THE CONVECTION UNDER WAY IN ST. LOUIS. THESE HIGH CLOUDS WILL 
CONTINUE TO MOVE SOUTHEAST...WITH MUCH OF THE STATE MOSTLY CLEAR BY 
SUNRISE.

WARM AND HUMID CONDITIONS WILL CONTINUE TODAY AND FRIDAY...AS SOUTH 
WINDS CONTINUE TO BRING MOISTURE/HIGH DEWPOINTS TO THE AREA. HIGHS 
WILL BE IN THE LOWER TO MID 90S. HOWEVER...HEAT INDEX VALUES WILL BE 
IN THE 100 TO 105 DEGREE RANGE...JUST BELOW HEAT ADVISORY CRITERIA. 
IF VALUES APPROACH 105 DEGREES...IT WILL BE ONLY FOR AN HOUR OR TWO.

HUMID CONDITIONS WILL LEAD TO ISOLATED CONVECTION THIS AFTERNOON AND 
EVENING...AND AGAIN FRIDAY. SHORTWAVES IN SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT AHEAD 
OF TROUGH IN THE ROCKIES WILL HELP IN THIS SITUATION.

COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH ARKANSAS FRIDAY NIGHT/SATURDAY. MODELS 
DIFFERING ON TIMING...WITH GFS BRINGING FRONT THROUGH SUNDAY 
MORNING. HAVE A HARD TIME BELIEVING THE FRONT WILL MOVE THAT 
QUICKLY...AS UPPER TROUGH DOES NOT MOVE THROUGH UNTIL SUNDAY 
AFTERNOON/EVENING. THUS...SLOWED FRONTAL TIMING AND HELD POPS IN FOR 
SUNDAY. TIMING WILL HAVE TO ADJUSTED AS FUTURE MODEL RUNS COME IN.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
STILL SOME TIMING ISSUES EARLY IN THE PD IN REGARDS TO FNTL 
POSITION. APPEARS THAT THE BNDRY WILL BE S OF AR EARLY ON MON. LEFT 
SLGT CHC POPS FOR SERN AR EARLY MON WITH DRY WX TO FOLLOW. LOOKS 
LIKE SFC HIGH WL PERSIST OVER THE FA INTO MID WEEK. CURRENT FCST 
TEMPS LOOK IN LINE WITH NEW MOS NUMBERS...SO NO SIG CHGS MADE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    94  75  93  73 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       91  73  90  72 /  20  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    94  76  94  74 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     94  75  94  73 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  90  72  90  71 /  20  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     95  74  94  72 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         92  73  92  72 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      94  76  94  74 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   93  75  93  73 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

968 
FXUS64 KLZK 260255 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
950 PM CDT WED AUG 25 2004

.DISCUSSION...
MOST PRECIPITATION HAS COME TO AN END THIS EVENING...WITH DRY/MUGGY 
CONDITIONS EXPECTED OVERNIGHT. 

COUPLE OF DAYS OF TYPICAL SUMMERTIME WEATHER ON THE WAY...WITH HIGH 
PRESSURE BUILDING OVER SOUTH CENTRAL/SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES. ONLY 
ISOLATED THUNDER IN THE FORECAST THURSDAY AND FRIDAY AFTERNOONS. 

HIGH WILL WEAKEN A BIT THIS WEEKEND. THIS WILL ALLOW A COLD FRONT TO 
APPROACH FROM THE NORTHWEST...WITH MORE CLOUDS/BETTER CHANCES FOR 
PRECIPITATION. SLIGHTLY COOLER AIR WILL FOLLOW THE FRONT LATE IN THE 
WEEKEND/EARLY NEXT WEEK. (46)
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46






329 
FXUS64 KLZK 251957
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT WED AUG 25 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
MOST OF THE ENERGY ALOFT IS MOVING EAST QUICKLY ALONG THE NORTHERN 
BORDER AND SHEARING OFF FROM THE SLOWER SHORT WAVE OVER THE ROCKIES. 
THIS FITS WELL WITH A LACK OF FRONTAL PASSAGE AT THE SURFACE THROUGH 
MOST OF THE SHORT TERM...UNTIL SATURDAY NIGHT. PASSAGE OF THE FRONT 
WILL BE RATHER SLOW AND LACK-LUSTER ON ACCOUNT OF THE WEAK DYNAMICS 
DRIVING IT. THE CURRENT SHORT TERM FORECAST REFLECTS THE SITUATION 
WELL AND SEE NO REASON TO MAKE MAJOR CHANGES. POPS AND TEMPS ARE 
ADEQUATE.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
STILL SOME TIMING QUESTIONS ON COLD FRONT OVER THE WEEKEND. LOOKS 
LIKE MAIN FRONTAL PASSAGE WILL BE ON SUNDAY WITH THE BEST CHANCES OF 
RAIN ALONG AND BEHIND IT. MADE LITTLE CHANGE TO POPS AND TEMPS FOR 
SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY EXCEPT TO EXTEND SMALL POPS INTO MONDAY 
MORNING IN THE SOUTHEAST. STILL LOOKS LIKE HIGH PRESSURE TO THE 
NORTH WILL TAKE CONTROL OF THE AREA FROM MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY 
WITH DRY CONDITIONS AND COOLER NIGHTS WITH MOST MINS IN THE 60S AND 
MAXES IN THE MID 80S TO AROUND 90...A LITTLE BELOW NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    75  94  74  94 /  30  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       73  91  72  92 /  30  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    76  95  75  95 /  30  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     75  95  74  95 /  30  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  72  90  71  91 /  30  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     74  95  74  95 /  30  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         73  93  72  94 /  30  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      76  95  75  95 /  30  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   75  94  74  94 /  30  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

32/22





423 
FXUS64 KLZK 251454
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
955 AM CDT WED AUG 25 2004

AREA OF SHOWERS AND STORMS MOVING ACROSS EASTERN OKLAHOMA IS 
WEAKENING AS IT MOVES INTO HIGHER PRESSURE AND AWAY FROM THE UPPER 
SUPPORT. FORECAST ALREADY INCLUDES 30 POPS...AND THIS WILL SUFFICE. 
WILL TAKE OUT REFERENCE TO MORNING...OTHERWISE NO OTHER CHANGES NOW. 
UPDATE WILL BE OUT SHORTLY.

PREVIOUS DISCUSSION FOLLOWS...32.

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
LOW CLOUDS/STRATUS BEGINNING TO FORM OVER THE AREA...WITH SOUTH 
WINDS BRINGING MOISTURE INTO THE AREA. THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY OVER 
NORTHERN MISSOURI/SOUTHERN IOWA THIS MORNING...AND MOVING EAST.

SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL CONTINUE BRINGING UPPER LEVEL ENERGY INTO 
THE STATE...AS HAS BEEN THE LAST SEVERAL DAYS. MODELS ARE DIFFERING 
ON STRENGTH AND SPEED...WITH THE ETA BEING THE STRONGEST. HAVE USED 
A BLEND OF MODELS...AND CONTINUED SCATTERED POPS WITH SOME TWEAKS IN 
THE TIMING.

AFTER SYSTEM TODAY MOVES EAST THIS EVENING...MOISTURE RETURN IS 
RATHER WEAK. HOWEVER...WILL NOT RULE OUT DIURNAL CONVECTION THURSDAY 
AFTERNOON...WITH SLIGHT CHANCE POPS. SAME SITUATION AS WELL ON 
FRIDAY...AHEAD OF THE NEXT COLD FRONT IN THE PLAINS.

COLD FRONT WILL MOVE INTO THE STATE DURING THE DAY SATURDAY... 
SIMILAR TO TIMING FROM MODEL RUNS TUESDAY. SCATTERED POPS ACROSS THE 
STATE DUE TO THIS FEATURE SATURDAY AND SATURDAY NIGHT.

CURRENT TEMPERATURE FORECASTS LOOK GOOD. READINGS WILL BE NEAR TO 
SLIGHTLY ABOVE NORMAL TODAY...AND INCREASE A COUPLE OF DEGREES 
THURSDAY AND FRIDAY. TEMPS WILL BE SLIGHTLY LOWER SATURDAY DUE TO 
APPROACHING COLD FRONT AND CLOUDS. OVERALL...A BLEND OF GUIDANCE WAS 
USED. HEAT INDEX READINGS WILL BE IN THE 100 TO 105 DEGREE RANGE IN 
CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN ARKANSAS DURING THE AFTERNOONS TODAY THROUGH 
FRIDAY...AND WILL HAVE TO BE MONITORED IF TEMPS WARM.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
MODELS STILL IN GOOD AGREEMENT TAKING NEXT CDFNT THRU THE AREA EARLY 
IN THE PD. TIMING ACRS AR STILL LOOKS TO BE ON SUNDAY. STILL SOME 
CONCERN OF HOW FAR WILL FNT WORK S OF THE AREA. HAVE KEPT PRECIP 
TRENDS OF CURRENT FCST IN TACT. LATEST GFS MOS DATA GIVING LIKELY 
POPS WITH FROPA ON SUN. HAVE STUCK WITH HIGH CHC POPS FOR NOW. TEMPS 
LOOK GOOD AND NO SIG CHGS MADE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    92  73  93  73 /  30  30  20  20 
HARRISON AR       89  72  91  72 /  30  30  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    93  74  94  74 /  30  30  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     93  73  94  73 /  30  30  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  88  71  90  71 /  30  30  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     93  72  94  73 /  30  30  20  20 
SEARCY AR         91  72  93  72 /  30  30  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      93  74  94  74 /  30  30  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   91  73  93  73 /  30  30  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

MOUNT IDA AR      93  74  94  74 /  30  30  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   91  73  93  73 /  30  30  20  20

930 PM CDT TUE AUG 24 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CONVECTION ALL BUT DONE ACROSS THE CWA WITH LARGE AREA OF CLEARING 
NOW OVER MOST OF THE CWA. CIRRUS ALREADY STREAMING IN FROM THE WEST 
IN ADVANCE OF NEXT WAVE PROGGED TO COME IN SOMETIME LATE WEDNESDAY 
MORNING. WITH NO APPRECIABLE SHORTWAVES SEEN FOR TONIGHT...PRECIP 
PULLED FROM THE CURRENT PACKAGE. ADJUSTED CLOUD COVER AS WELL BASED 
ON CURRENT CONDITIONS AND EXPECTED TRENDS.

OTHER FORECAST PARAMETERS LOOK RIGHT ON TARGET AND WILL NOT BE 
MAKING ANY WHOLESALE CHANGES HERE. GRIDS WILL BE TWEAKED TO REFLECT 
CURRENT TRENDS/CONDITIONS BUT NO APPRECIABLE CHANGE IN THE FORECAST 
WILL RESULT.
