
265 
FXUS64 KLZK 160827
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
325 AM CDT FRI JUL 16 2004

.DISCUSSION...
QUASI-STATIONARY FNTL BNDRY STILL NOTED ACRS THE FA THIS MRNG. SFC 
DEWPOINT ANALYSIS DEPICTS BNDRY QUITE WELL...RUNNING W-E ACRS CNTRL 
AR ATTM. HAVE SEEN SOME CONVECTION DVLP THE LAST FEW HOURS OVER SERN 
AR. MORE IMPRESSIVE ACTIVITY NOTED OVER NWRN MO...WHICH COULD AFFECT 
NRN AR LATER THIS MRNG.

MODELS ARE IN DECENT AGREEMENT THIS MRNG WITH LARGE SCALE FEATURES. 
NWLY FLOW ALOFT IS PROGGED TO CONT ACRS THE MID-SOUTH WITH RIDGE 
OVER THE WRN STATES AND UPPER TROF IN THE EAST. THE SFC BNDRY 
CURRENTLY OVER AR AND OTHER MESOSCALE BNDRYS WILL FOCUS ADDITIONAL 
SHRA/TSRA FORMATION OVER THE FA DURING THE NEXT 24 TO 36 HOURS.

HAVE PLACED HIGHEST POPS TODAY OVER NRN AR AS ACTIVITY FM MO WORKS 
SWD LATER THIS MRNG. WENT WITH CHC POPS ELSEWHERE TODAY. MODELS CONT 
TO INDC THAT ANOTHER TSTM COMPLEX WILL FIRE TO OUR NW THIS AFTN AND 
AFFECT MUCH OF AR TNGT AND EARLY SAT. DAY SHIFT WILL HAVE TO MONITOR 
FOR THE POTENTIAL OF HEAVY RAINFALL LATER TODAY AND TONIGHT. GFS QPF 
OUTPUT SEEMS A BIT OVERDONE WITH POSSIBLE CONVECTIVE FEEDBACK 
PROBLEMS.

HAVE USED A BLEND OF THE GFS AND ETA MOS TEMP OUTPUT FOR THE SHORT 
TERM. SOME LOCATIONS OVER SRN AR MAY FLIRT WITH 105 HEAT INDEX 
READINGS THIS AFTN...BUT CONDS NOT EXPECTED TO BE PROLONGED AND 
WIDESPREAD FOR AN ADVY.

DRIER AND COOLER WEATHER STILL APPEARS ON TRACK FOR SUN INTO EARLY 
NEXT WEEK.

NO SIG CHGS MADE TO THE EXTENDED PDS. LATEST GFS SHOWING A LESS 
AMPLIFIED UPPER FLOW PATTERN LATER NEXT WEEK. EXPECT A GRADUAL 
RETURN OF HEAT AND HUMIDITY TO THE AREA WITH TYPICAL DIURNAL AFTN 
AND EVENING CONVECTION. THESE TRENDS HANDLED WELL BY GOING FCST. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

44

936 
FXUS64 KLZK 160137
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
835 PM CDT THU JUL 15 2004

.DISCUSSION...
FORECAST IN GENERALLY GOOD SHAPE THIS EVENING BUT A QUICK UPDATE IS 
NEEDED TO REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS. SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS FIRED UP 
ALONG A STALLED OUT BOUNDARY WHICH BASICALLY BISECTS THE STATE FROM 
NORTHWEST TO SOUTHEAST. FIRST SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WATCH HAS EXPIRED 
BUT SECOND ONE STILL HAS A FEW HOURS TO GO.

NUMEROUS REPORTS OF LARGE HAIL RECEIVED FROM NORTH CENTRAL SECTIONS 
OF THE STATE. CONVECTION CONTINUES TO SHOW A SLOW WEAKENING TREND 
WITH THE LOSS OF DAYTIME HEATING BUT A FEW MORE STORMS MAY STILL 
APPROACH SEVERE LEVELS DURING THE DURATION OF THE WATCH BUT THE 
LARGEST CONCERNS APPEARS TO BE OVER.

LATEST SATELLITE CONTINUES TO SHOW CONVECTION FIRING UP OVER THE 
CENTRAL PLAINS WHICH MAY BE THE BEGINNING OF AN MCS. FORECAST MOTION 
VECTORS FOR ANY COMPLEX THAT FORMS INDICATE THAT NORTHERN PORTIONS 
OF THE FORECAST AREA WOULD BE MOST LIKELY AFFECTED BY ANY ORGANIZED 
STORM COMPLEX THAT FORMS. BASED ON CURRENT RADAR RETURNS AND THE 
MCS POSSIBLY GETTING STARTED...HAVE BOOSTED POPS AND QPF ACROSS THE 
BOARD FOR TONIGHT. BIGGEST CHANGES WILL BE ACROSS THE NORTH. ALL 
OTHER FORECAST PARAMETERS LOOK FINE AND WILL BE LEFT IN PLACE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    74  93  74  90 /  40  40  40  30 
HARRISON AR       70  88  67  87 /  50  50  30  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    74  93  74  90 /  40  40  40  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     75  93  74  90 /  30  40  40  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  70  87  67  87 /  50  50  30  20 
MONTICELLO AR     75  95  74  90 /  30  40  40  30

RUSSELLVILLE AR   73  93  72  89 /  40  50  40  20

AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
835 PM CDT THU JUL 15 2004

.DISCUSSION...
FORECAST IN GENERALLY GOOD SHAPE THIS EVENING BUT A QUICK UPDATE IS 
NEEDED TO REFLECT CURRENT TRENDS. SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS FIRED UP 
ALONG A STALLED OUT BOUNDARY WHICH BASICALLY BISECTS THE STATE FROM 
NORTHWEST TO SOUTHEAST. FIRST SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WATCH HAS EXPIRED 
BUT SECOND ONE STILL HAS A FEW HOURS TO GO.

NUMEROUS REPORTS OF LARGE HAIL RECEIVED FROM NORTH CENTRAL SECTIONS 
OF THE STATE. CONVECTION CONTINUES TO SHOW A SLOW WEAKENING TREND 
WITH THE LOSS OF DAYTIME HEATING BUT A FEW MORE STORMS MAY STILL 
APPROACH SEVERE LEVELS DURING THE DURATION OF THE WATCH BUT THE 
LARGEST CONCERNS APPEARS TO BE OVER.

LATEST SATELLITE CONTINUES TO SHOW CONVECTION FIRING UP OVER THE 
CENTRAL PLAINS WHICH MAY BE THE BEGINNING OF AN MCS. FORECAST MOTION 
VECTORS FOR ANY COMPLEX THAT FORMS INDICATE THAT NORTHERN PORTIONS 
OF THE FORECAST AREA WOULD BE MOST LIKELY AFFECTED BY ANY ORGANIZED 
STORM COMPLEX THAT FORMS. BASED ON CURRENT RADAR RETURNS AND THE 
MCS POSSIBLY GETTING STARTED...HAVE BOOSTED POPS AND QPF ACROSS THE 
BOARD FOR TONIGHT. BIGGEST CHANGES WILL BE ACROSS THE NORTH. ALL 
OTHER FORECAST PARAMETERS LOOK FINE AND WILL BE LEFT IN PLACE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

660 
FXUS64 KLZK 152026
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
327 PM CDT THU JUL 15 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY...
THE LATEST MESOSCALE SURFACE ANALYSIS INDICATES A STATIONARY 
BOUNDARY...FROM NEAR MONTICELLO...TO CLARKSVILLE. LOCAL RADARS 
INDICATES WIDELY SCATTERED RETURNS ALONG THIS BOUNDARY. MOST 
UNSTABLE CONDITIONS APPEAR TO BE ALONG THE BOUNDARY...ACROSS EXTREME 
SOUTHEAST PORTIONS OF THE CWA. IF THE CAP CAN BE BROKEN...CONVECTIVE 
DEVELOPMENT WOULD BE EXPLOSIVE...AND DAMAGING WIND GUSTS WOULD BE 
LIKELY. 

OVERNIGHT...ORGANIZED CONVECTIVE DEVELOPMENT APPEARS TO BE A GOOD 
POSSIBILITY ACROSS PORTIONS OF THE CENTRAL PLAINS. FORECAST MOTION 
VECTORS FOR ANY COMPLEX THAT FORMS INDICATE THAT NORTHERN PORTIONS 
OF THE FORECAST AREA WOULD BE MOST LIKELY AFFECTED BY ANY ORGANIZED 
STORM COMPLEX THAT FORMS.

RESIDUAL BOUNDARIES WILL BE A FOCUS FOR CONVECTION ON FRIDAY. IN 
ADDITION...A COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH LATE ON FRIDAY. EXPECT 
SCATTERED CONVECTION FRIDAY TO EARLY SATURDAY. DRIER AND COOLER 
CONDITIONS WILL PREVAIL SUNDAY AND MONDAY. 

&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY 
DRY PATTERN TO CONTINUE THROUGH MOST OF THE LONG TERM AS HIGH 
PRESSURE CONTINUES OVER THE AREA. FRONTAL SYSTEM BEGINS TO APPROACH 
THE AREA ON THURSDAY AND THEN MOVES IN ON FRIDAY. WITH MOISTURE 
INCREASING ON THURSDAY AHEAD OF SYSTEM...HAVE PUT SLIGHT CHANCE POPS 
IN FOR THEN. 

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    74  93  74  90 /  30  40  40  30 
HARRISON AR       70  88  67  87 /  40  50  30  20


839 
FXUS64 KLZK 150842
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT THU JUL 15 2004

.DISCUSSION...
WEAK COLD FRONT SLOWLY MOVING SOUTH ACROSS THE AREA THIS MORNING. 
APPEARS STRONG CAP IS HOLDING ACROSS THE AREA AS THUNDERSTORMS STAYED
TO THE EAST OF THE AREA OVERNIGHT. MODELS AND GUIDANCE KEEP THE AREA
DRY TODAY SUGGESTING THE ATMOSPHERE WILL REMAIN CAPPED. HOWEVER WITH
THE FRONTAL BOUNDARY IN THE AREA AND POSSIBLY AN OUTFLOW BOUNDARY 
FROM THE MCS IN NORTHERN MISSISSIPPI...AM RELUCTANT TO NOT HAVE A
MENTION OF RAIN IN THE FORECAST. WILL GO WITH 20 PERCEBT POPS ACROSS
THE AREA MOSTLY FOR THIS AFTERNOON AND GO WITH ISOLATED WORDING. IF
FORCING ALONG THE BOUNDARIES CAN OVERCOME THE CAP THEN SIGNIFICANT
DEVELOPMENT WOULD TAKE PLACE. THINGS MAY STAY CAPPED EARLY TONIGHT 
BUT A SHORT WAVE IN NORTHWEST FLOW MAY SET OFF THUNDERSTORMS IN 
THE PLAINS LATE TODAY OR EARLY TONIGHT WHICH MAY DEVELOP INTO AN
MCS WHICH COULD ROLL INTO THE AREA LATER TONIGHT INTO EARLY FRIDAY.
THE SPC DAY ONE OUTLOOK SEEMS TO REFLECT THIS AND WILL GO WITH 
CHANCE POPS IN THE NORTH FOR LATER TONIGHT FOR THIS POSSIBILITY. 
FOR FRIDAY...THERE MAY BE SOME ONGOING SHOWERS OR THUNDERSTORMS
IN THE MORNING FROM MCS ACTIVITY TONIGHT WHICH SHOULD CONTINUE
OUT OF THE AREA DURING THE DAY. A STRONGER SHORT WAVE APPROACHES 
THE AREA WHICH COULD SET OFF ANOTHER MCS IN THE PLAINS WHICH MAY 
REACH THE AREA FRIDAY NIGHT. A COLD FRONT SHOULD MOVE ACROSS THE
CWA FRIDAY NIGHT AND MOVE TO THE SOUTH SATURDAY. DUE TO ALL 
THIS...WENT WITH 30 PERCENT POPS ACROSS THE AREA FOR MOST OF FRIDAY 
AND 40 PERCENT POPS FOR FRIDAY NIGHT. DECREASED POPS FROM THE NORTH
ON SATURDAY AS THE COLD FRONT MOVES TO THE SOUTH. LOOKS RATHER DRY 
AFTER THAT BUT WITH NORTHWEST FLOW IN PLACE...CANNOT TRUST THAT 
COMPLETELY. DID TAKE ALL RAIN OUT FOR SATURDAY NIGHT AND KEPT 
SMALL POPS IN FOR SUNDAY AFTERNOON. KEPT DRY FORECAST IN AFTER
THAT...BUT CONFIDENCE IS NOT REAL HIGH. EFFECTS OF THE FRONT 
TODAY SHOULD LOWER TEMPS A LITTLE AND TAKE THE EDGE OFF THE HEAT. 
FORECAST TEMPS AND DEW POINTS YIELD HEAT INDICES OF 100 TO 105 
THIS AFTERNOON IN MOST OF CENTRAL AND SOUTH. BASED ON THIS WILL
NOT NEED TO EXTEND THE HEAT ADVISORY BUT MAY STILL MENTION THE
HIGH HEAT INDICES IN THE HWO AND WEATHER SUMMARY. APPEARS THE
FRONT FRIDAY NIGHT AND SATURDAY WILL BE STRONG ENOUGH TO MODERATE
TEMPS A LITTLE MORE...BUT THEY SHOULD STILL RUN CLOSE TO 
NORMAL.       
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    95  74  92  72 /  20  20  30  40 
HARRISON AR       89  70  87  67 /  20  30  30  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    95  74  93  72 /  20  20  30  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     95  74  93  73 /  20  20  30  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  88  69  87  67 /  20  30  30  40 
MONTICELLO AR     95  75  94  74 /  20  20  30  40 
SEARCY AR         93  72  92  71 /  20  30  30  40 
MOUNT IDA AR      94  74  93  72 /  20  20  30  40 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   93  71  92  70 /  20  30  30  40 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
912 PM CDT WED JUL 14 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATES ON THE WAY THIS EVENING TO INCREASE POPS ACROSS THE NORTH. 
AN INTENSE AREA OF CONVECTION CONTINUES OVER NORTHEAST MISSISSIPPI 
AND IS BACK BUILDING TO THE WEST NORTHWEST ALONG A SLOW MOVING 
FRONT. LATEST ANALYSIS PLACES THE FRONT FROM ROUGHLY SOUTH OF 
MEMPHIS TO CAVE CITY TO SOUTH OF BRANSON MISSOURI. WIDELY SCATTERED 
ACTIVITY FIRING UP ALONG SAID BOUNDARY ACROSS THE NORTHEAST AND 
NORTHERN PARTS OF THE CWA. WHILE BEST DYNAMICS REMAIN TO THE 
NORTHEAST OF THE CWA...WILL NEED TO UPDATE POPS BASED ON CURRENT 
TRENDS. ALL OVER FORECAST PARAMETERS LOOK FINE AND WILL BE LEFT 
ALONE.

647 
FXUS64 KLZK 141835
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
135 PM CDT WED JUL 14 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPPER AIR PATTERN WILL HAVE A NORTHWEST FLOW OVER THE STATE DURING 
THE NEXT 7 DAYS. A SHORT WAVE WILL DROP TO THE SOUTHEAST ACROSS OUR 
NORTHEAST CORNER TONIGHT. THIS WILL GIVE A PUSH TO THE SURFACE FRONT 
JUST OUTSIDE OUR NORTHERN BORDER. SMALL POPS WILL ACCOMPANY THIS 
FRONT OVERNIGHT. THE FLOW WILL DROP THE NEXT SHORT WAVE OVERNIGHT 
FRIDAY...HELPING TO PUSH THE SURFACE FRONT TO THE SOUTHWEST AS THE 
TROF GETS DEEPENED ALOFT. HIGHER RAIN CHANCES WILL BE IN STORE FOR 
SATURDAY...DECREASING DURING THE DAY SUNDAY. THERE WILL BE A BRIEF 
DRY SPELL FOR MONDAY AND TUESDAY...THEN RETURN FLOW AT THE SURFACE 
WILL BEGIN FROM THE WEST ON WEDNESDAY BUT IT SHOULD STILL BE A DRY 
WEDNESDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL BE KEPT TO SEASONAL LEVELS FOR HIGHS 
AND LOWS...WITHOUT THE NEED FOR HEAT ADVISORIES.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    96  75  95  73 /  10  20  20  30 
HARRISON AR       93  69  89  68 /  10  20  20  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    97  75  95  73 /  10  20  20  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     97  75  95  73 /  10  20  20  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  92  70  88  67 /  10  30  20  30 
MONTICELLO AR     97  75  95  74 /  10  20  30  30 
SEARCY AR         96  74  93  71 /  10  30  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      97  74  94  73 /  10  20  20  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   95  72  93  70 /  10  20  20  30

463 
FXUS64 KLZK 141721 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1201 PM CDT WED JUL 14 2004

NO UPDATE PLANNED NOW. HEAT INDICES HAVE BEEN SLOW TO GET GOING 
TODAY IN LIGHT OF THIN...HIGH CLOUDS MOVING DOWM FROM MCS REMANANTS 
TO OUR NORTH. 32

.DISCUSSION...
UPPER RIDGE HAS STRENGTHEND BUT IS RETROGRADING TO THE WEST AS A 
TROF DIGS INTO THE EASTERN U.S. THIS WILL DEVELOP NORTHWEST FLOW
ALOFT OVER THE AREA AND ALLOW A COLD FRONT TO REACH THE AREA LATE 
TODAY AND TONIGHT. THE FRONT WILL WEAKEN AND STALL IN THE AREA 
THEN THE REMAINING BOUNDARY WILL LIKELY OSCILLATE AROUND THE AREA
FOR A FEW DAYS. ANOTHER WEAK COLD FRONT MAY JOIN FORCES WITH THE
FIRST BOUNDARY OVER THE WEEKEND. THE AREA WILL BE VULNERABLE TO 
MCS ACTION FROM THE PLAINS ESPECIALLY FROM THURSDAY THROUGH 
SUNDAY. OF COURSE TIMING AND IDENTIFICATION OF THESE IS NOT
GOOD AT THIS POINT. THE WARM HUMID AND CAPPED ATMOSPHERE WILL
CARRY THROUGH MOST OF THE DAY AND WILL NOT MENTION ANY POPS
DURING THE DAYTIME PERIOD. BY EARLY TONIGHT...THE FRONT MAY REACH 
NORTHEASTERN SECTIONS AND THIS SHOULD WEAKEN OR BREAK THE CAP
IN THAT AREA. CONVERGENGE AROUND THE FRONT WILL BE WEAK AS WIND 
SPEEDS ARE NOT STRONG AND DIRECTIONAL CHANGE IN THE WIND IS NOT
MUCH EITHER. WILL GO WITH SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THE NORTHEAST FOR
TONIGHT. IF ANYTHING DOES GET STARTED IN THAT AREA OR MOVES IN FROM
THE NORTH...IT WILL HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO BE STRONG TO SEVERE DUE
TO THE STRONG INSTABILITY THAT WILL BE AVAILABLE. CONTINUED SMALL 
POPS IN THE NORTHEAST INTO THURSDAY THEN SPREAD THEM ACROSS THE 
REST OF THE AREA BY AFTERNOON AS THE FRONT SHOULD MOVE ACROSS
MOST OF THE AREA OR IF NOT...OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES MAY BE PRESENT 
FROM CONVECTION TONIGHT. AFTER THAT...THE CHANCE IS THERE THAT AN
MCS COULD MOVE ACROSS PART OF THE AREA SO WILL KEEP 20 PERCENT 
POPS GOING INTO THE WEEKEND. ENHANCED THE POPS SATURDAY AFTERNOON
AND SUNDAY MORNING TO ACCOUNT FOR THE NEXT FRONT. NEW GFS BRINGS DRY 
AIR INTO THE AREA MONDAY AND TUESDAY. LEFT FORECAST DRY FOR MONDAY
NIGHT AND TUESDAY FOR NOW. MAXES TODAY SHOULD BE WELL INTO THE 90S
AGAIN WITH HEAT INDICES IN THE CENTRAL AND SOUTH OVER 105. THINGS
SHOULD BACK OFF THURSDAY DUE TO THE PRESENCE OF THE FRONT OR ANY
OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES AND THE RESULTING INCREASE IN CLOUDS WILL LOWER
MAXES A LITTLE AND DEW POINTS MAY DROP A LITTLE AS WELL. WILL
CONTINUE THE HEAT ADVISORY FOR TODAY.      
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    96  75  94  74 /  10  10  20  20 
HARRISON AR       93  69  89  69 /  10  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    97  75  95  74 /  10  10  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     97  75  95  74 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  92  70  88  68 /  10  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     97  76  95  75 /  10  10  20  20 
SEARCY AR         96  74  92  72 /  10  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      97  74  93  74 /  10  10  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   95  72  92  71 /  10  10  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...HEAT ADVISORY TODAY 
FOR ZONES ARZ016...ARZ021>025...ARZ030>034...ARZ037>039... 
ARZ040>047...ARZ052>057...ARZ062>069.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1201 PM CDT WED JUL 14 2004

NO UPDATE PLANNED NOW. HEAT INDICES HAVE BEEN SLOW TO GET GOING 
TODAY IN LIGHT OF THIN...HIGH CLOUDS MOVING DOWM FROM MCS REMANANTS 
TO OUR NORTH. 32

.DISCUSSION...
UPPER RIDGE HAS STRENGTHEND BUT IS RETROGRADING TO THE WEST AS A 
TROF DIGS INTO THE EASTERN U.S. THIS WILL DEVELOP NORTHWEST FLOW
ALOFT OVER THE AREA AND ALLOW A COLD FRONT TO REACH THE AREA LATE 
TODAY AND TONIGHT. THE FRONT WILL WEAKEN AND STALL IN THE AREA 
THEN THE REMAINING BOUNDARY WILL LIKELY OSCILLATE AROUND THE AREA
FOR A FEW DAYS. ANOTHER WEAK COLD FRONT MAY JOIN FORCES WITH THE
FIRST BOUNDARY OVER THE WEEKEND. THE AREA WILL BE VULNERABLE TO 
MCS ACTION FROM THE PLAINS ESPECIALLY FROM THURSDAY THROUGH 
SUNDAY. OF COURSE TIMING AND IDENTIFICATION OF THESE IS NOT
GOOD AT THIS POINT. THE WARM HUMID AND CAPPED ATMOSPHERE WILL
CARRY THROUGH MOST OF THE DAY AND WILL NOT MENTION ANY POPS
DURING THE DAYTIME PERIOD. BY EARLY TONIGHT...THE FRONT MAY REACH 
NORTHEASTERN SECTIONS AND THIS SHOULD WEAKEN OR BREAK THE CAP
IN THAT AREA. CONVERGENGE AROUND THE FRONT WILL BE WEAK AS WIND 
SPEEDS ARE NOT STRONG AND DIRECTIONAL CHANGE IN THE WIND IS NOT
MUCH EITHER. WILL GO WITH SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THE NORTHEAST FOR
TONIGHT. IF ANYTHING DOES GET STARTED IN THAT AREA OR MOVES IN FROM
THE NORTH...IT WILL HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO BE STRONG TO SEVERE DUE
TO THE STRONG INSTABILITY THAT WILL BE AVAILABLE. CONTINUED SMALL 
POPS IN THE NORTHEAST INTO THURSDAY THEN SPREAD THEM ACROSS THE 
REST OF THE AREA BY AFTERNOON AS THE FRONT SHOULD MOVE ACROSS
MOST OF THE AREA OR IF NOT...OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES MAY BE PRESENT 
FROM CONVECTION TONIGHT. AFTER THAT...THE CHANCE IS THERE THAT AN
MCS COULD MOVE ACROSS PART OF THE AREA SO WILL KEEP 20 PERCENT

AND SUNDAY MORNING TO ACCOUNT FOR THE NEXT FRONT. NEW GFS BRINGS DRY 
AIR INTO THE AREA MONDAY AND TUESDAY. LEFT FORECAST DRY FOR MONDAY

AGAIN WITH HEAT INDICES IN THE CENTRAL AND SOUTH OVER 105. THINGS
SHOULD BACK OFF THURSDAY DUE TO THE PRESENCE OF THE FRONT OR ANY
OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES AND THE RESULTING INCREASE IN CLOUDS WILL LOWER
MAXES A LITTLE AND DEW POINTS MAY DROP A LITTLE AS WELL. WILL
CONTINUE THE HEAT ADVISORY FOR TODAY.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 PM CDT TUE JUL 13 2004

HUMIDITY AND HEAT WILL CONTINUE TO PRODUCE UNHEALTHY INDEX VALUES 
THROUGH WEDNESDAY...SO KEPT THE ADVISORY GOING. WEDNESDAY NIGHT WILL 
SEE THE NEXT WEAK FRONT MOVE INTO THE NORTHEAST PART OF THE STATE 
AND IT WILL SLIDE SOUTH-SOUTHWEST THROUGH 12Z THURSDAY. THE FRONT 
WILL DISSIPATE SLOWLY ACROSS THE CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE STATE FROM 
NORTHWEST TO SOUTHEAST. MOISTURE AND BOUNDARIES WILL KEEP THAT 
ORIENTATION SATURDAY THROUGH EARLY SUNDAY...THEN MOISTURE WILL SLIDE 
MORE TO THE SOUTHERN SECTIONS. INSTABILITY WILL CONTINUE THROUGHOUT 
THE FORECAST PERIOD IN TYPICAL DIURNAL FASHION. PLACED ONLY 20 
PERCENT POPS FOR THE MOST PART DURING THE AFTERNOONS AND EARLY 
EVENINGS. MADE FEW CHANGES TO TEMPERATURES OUT ALREADY. MOS NUMBERS 
WERE SHOWING A FEW TRIPLE DIGITS FOR SOME LOCATIONS IN 
ARKANSAS...BUT CHOSE TO KEEP HIGHS IN THE 90S.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...


972 
FXUS64 KLZK 131606 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1000 AM CDT TUE JUL 13 2004

MADE SMALL ADJUSTMENTS TO THE GRIDS IN THE FIRST PERIOD ON ACCOUNT 
OF FEWER CLOUDS AROUND THAN WE HAD FORECAST. UPDATE OUT ALREADY. 32

.DISCUSSION...
UPPER RIDGE CENTERED TO THE WEST OF THE AREA WILL COVER THE AREA 
ENOUGH TODAY TO KEEP THE ATMOSPHERE CAPPED AND BRING STRONG HEATING 
COMBINED WITH THE HIGH HUMIDITY THAT HAS BEEN IN PACE FROM THE 
RECENT RAINY WEATHER. 850 TEMPS PROGGED TO REACH 20 TO 22C WHICH 
TRANLATES TO SURFACE TEMPS IN THE UPPER 90S BUT THESE WILL BE 
TEMPERED A LITTLE FROM THE STILL MOIST SOIL. IT WILL STILL LIKELY BE 
THE HOTTEST DAY OF THE SUMMER SO FAR FOR MOST AREAS. AFTERNOON HEAT 
INDICES IN MOST OF CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN ARKANSAS WILL REACH OR 
EXCEED 105. THE SAME IS LIKELY ON WEDNESDAY ALTHOUGH THE PATTERN 
WILL BEGIN TO CHANGE. NIGHTTIME TEMPS WILL STAY AT OR ABOVE 80 MUCH 
OF THE NIGHT IN MOST OF THOSE AREAS SO WILL CONTINUE WITH THE HEAT 
ADVISORY FOR TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY FOR ALL BUT NORTHERN AREAS. 
UPPER TROF DIGS INTO THE NORTHEAST WEDNESDAY WHICH SLIPS THE UPPER 
RIDGE TO THE WEST AND PUTS THIS AREA INTO NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT. THIS 
WILL ENABLE A WEAK COLD FRONT TO MOVE THROUGH LATE WEDNESDAY INTO 
THURSDAY. THE RIDGE ALOFT WILL HAVE ENOUGH OF AN EFFECT TO KEEP 
SIGNIFICANT COOLING FROM OCCURRING BUT THE FRONT WILL LIKELY TAKE A 
FEW DEGREES OFF DEW POINTS AND EASE THE HEAT ADVISORY CONDITIONS. 
THE RIDGE MAY ALSO KEEP ENOUGH OF A CAP GOING TO KEEP MUCH 
CONVECTION FROM DEVELOPING. CONVERGENCE AROUND THE FRONT WILL BE 
WEAK AS THE DIRECTIONAL WIND SHIFT WILL BE SMALL AND SPEEDS WILL BE 
LIGHT. THIS WILL LIMIT CHANCES OF RAIN. THE CAP SHOULD BE STRONG 
ENOUGH TO KEEP MENTION OF RAIN OUT OF THE FORECAST TODAY THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY MORNING THEN WILL ONLY HAVE 20 PERCENT POPS WEDNESDAY 
AFTERNOON AND NIGHT FOR THE FRONT. THE FRONT BECOMES VERY WEAK AND 
HANGS AROUND THE AREA. SEVERAL SHORT WAVES MOVE THROUGH IN NORTHWEST 
FLOW AND THERE WILL BE THE RISK OF AN MCS OR TWO OR MORE AFFECTING 
THE AREA LATER IN THE WEEK. GENERALLY KEPT TEMPS CLOSE TO NORMAL AND 
LEFT IN BROAD BRUSH 20 PERCENT POPS THROUGH THE EXTENDED AS IT IS NOT
POSSIBLE TO TIME EFFECTS OF ANY MCS THAT AFFECTS THE AREA.  &&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    97  76  98  74 /  10  10  20  20 
HARRISON AR       93  72  93  68 /  10  10  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    97  76  98  74 /  10  10  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     97  76  98  74 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  93  72  93  69 /  10  10  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     97  76  98  75 /  10  10  20  20 
SEARCY AR         96  73  97  74 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      97  76  98  73 /  10  10  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   96  73  97  71 /  10  10  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...HEAT ADVISORY FOR TODAY THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY FOR ZONES 
ARZ016...ARZ021>025...ARZ030>034...ARZ037>039...ARZ040>047...
ARZ052>057...ARZ062>069.
 
&&

$$

THURSDAY. THE RIDGE ALOFT WILL HAVE ENOUGH OF AN EFFECT TO KEEP 
SIGNIFICANT COOLING FROM OCCURRING BUT THE FRONT WILL LIKELY TAKE A 
FEW DEGREES OFF DEW POINTS AND EASE THE HEAT ADVISORY CONDITIONS. 
THE RIDGE MAY ALSO KEEP ENOUGH OF A CAP GOING TO KEEP MUCH 
CONVECTION FROM DEVELOPING. CONVERGENCE AROUND THE FRONT WILL BE 
WEAK AS THE DIRECTIONAL WIND SHIFT WILL BE SMALL AND SPEEDS WILL BE 
LIGHT. THIS WILL LIMIT CHANCES OF RAIN. THE CAP SHOULD BE STRONG 
ENOUGH TO KEEP MENTION OF RAIN OUT OF THE FORECAST TODAY THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY MORNING THEN WILL ONLY HAVE 20 PERCENT POPS WEDNESDAY 
AFTERNOON AND NIGHT FOR THE FRONT. THE FRONT BECOMES VERY WEAK AND 
HANGS AROUND THE AREA. SEVERAL SHORT WAVES MOVE THROUGH IN NORTHWEST 
FLOW AND THERE WILL BE THE RISK OF AN MCS OR TWO OR MORE AFFECTING 
THE AREA LATER IN THE WEEK. GENERALLY KEPT TEMPS CLOSE TO NORMAL AND 
LEFT IN BROAD BRUSH 20 PERCENT POPS THROUGH THE EXTENDED AS IT IS NOT
POSSIBLE TO TIME EFFECTS OF ANY MCS THAT AFFECTS THE AREA.  &&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    97  76  98  74 /  10  10  20  20 
HARRISON AR       93  72  93  68 /  10  10  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    97  76  98  74 /  10  10  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     97  76  98  74 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  93  72  93  69 /  10  10  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     97  76  98  75 /  10  10  20  20 
SEARCY AR         96  73  97  74 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      97  76  98  73 /  10  10  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   96  73  97  71 /  10  10  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...HEAT ADVISORY FOR TODAY THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY FOR ZONES 
ARZ016...ARZ021>025...ARZ030>034...ARZ037>039...ARZ040>047...
ARZ052>057...ARZ062>069.
 
&&


372 
FXUS64 KLZK 130830
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT TUE JUL 13 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPPER RIDGE CENTERED TO THE WEST OF THE AREA WILL COVER THE AREA ENOUGH
TODAY TO KEEP THE ATMOSPHERE CAPPED AND BRING STRONG HEATING COMBINED
WITH THE HIGH HUMIDITY THAT HAS BEEN IN PACE FROM THE RECENT RAINY
WEATHER. 850 TEMPS PROGGED TO REACH 20 TO 22C WHICH TRANLATES TO
SURFACE TEMPS IN THE UPPER 90S BUT THESE WILL BE TEMPERED A LITTLE
FROM THE STILL MOIST SOIL. IT WILL STILL LIKELY BE THE HOTTEST DAY
OF THE SUMMER SO FAR FOR MOST AREAS. AFTERNOON HEAT INDICES IN MOST
OF CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN ARKANSAS WILL REACH OR EXCEED 105. THE SAME
IS LIKELY ON WEDNESDAY ALTHOUGH THE PATTERN WILL BEGIN TO CHANGE. 
NIGHTTIME TEMPS WILL STAY AT OR ABOVE 80 MUCH OF THE NIGHT IN MOST
OF THOSE AREAS SO WILL CONTINUE WITH THE HEAT ADVISORY FOR TODAY
THROUGH WEDNESDAY FOR ALL BUT NORTHERN AREAS. UPPER TROF DIGS INTO
THE NORTHEAST WEDNESDAY WHICH SLIPS THE UPPER RIDGE TO THE WEST 
AND PUTS THIS AREA INTO NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT. THIS WILL ENABLE A 
WEAK COLD FRONT TO MOVE THROUGH LATE WEDNESDAY INTO THURSDAY. 
THE RIDGE ALOFT WILL HAVE ENOUGH OF AN EFFECT TO KEEP SIGNIFICANT
COOLING FROM OCCURRING BUT THE FRONT WILL LIKELY TAKE A FEW DEGREES
OFF DEW POINTS AND EASE THE HEAT ADVISORY CONDITIONS. THE RIDGE MAY
ALSO KEEP ENOUGH OF A CAP GOING TO KEEP MUCH CONVECTION FROM 
DEVELOPING. CONVERGENCE AROUND THE FRONT WILL BE WEAK AS THE 
DIRECTIONAL WIND SHIFT WILL BE SMALL AND SPEEDS WILL BE LIGHT. 
THIS WILL LIMIT CHANCES OF RAIN. THE CAP SHOULD BE STRONG ENOUGH
TO KEEP MENTION OF RAIN OUT OF THE FORECAST TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
MORNING THEN WILL ONLY HAVE 20 PERCENT POPS WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON AND
NIGHT FOR THE FRONT. THE FRONT BECOMES VERY WEAK AND HANGS AROUND
THE AREA. SEVERAL SHORT WAVES MOVE THROUGH IN NORTHWEST FLOW AND 
THERE WILL BE THE RISK OF AN MCS OR TWO OR MORE AFFECTING THE AREA
LATER IN THE WEEK. GENERALLY KEPT TEMPS CLOSE TO NORMAL AND LEFT
IN BROAD BRUSH 20 PERCENT POPS THROUGH THE EXTENDED AS IT IS NOT
POSSIBLE TO TIME EFFECTS OF ANY MCS THAT AFFECTS THE AREA.  
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    97  76  98  74 /  10  10  20  20 
HARRISON AR       93  72  93  68 /  10  10  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    97  76  98  74 /  10  10  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     97  76  98  74 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  93  72  93  69 /  10  10  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     97  76  98  75 /  10  10  20  20 
SEARCY AR         96  73  97  74 /  10  10  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      97  76  98  73 /  10  10  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   96  73  97  71 /  10  10  20  20

293 
FXUS64 KLZK 122038
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
335 PM CDT MON JUL 12 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
HIGH PRESSURE WILL CONTINUE OVER THE AREA INTO WEDNESDAY. WITH 
DEWPOINTS IN THE 70S AND TEMPERATURES IN THE 90S...HEAT INDEX VALUES 
WILL RISE TO OR ABOVE THE CRITICAL 105 DEGREE VALUE IN CENTRAL AND 
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS BOTH TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. HAVE ISSUED A HEAT 
ADVISORY FOR THOSE AREAS FOR BOTH TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. COLD FRONT 
SHOULD MOVE INTO THE STATE WEDNESDAY AND MOVE SLOWLY SOUTHWARD. 
HOWEVER...MOISTURE LEVELS REMAIN LOW...SO HAVE ONLY SLIGHT CHANCE 
POPS AS FRONT MOVES THROUGH. DRIER AND SLIGHTLY COOLER AIR WILL MOVE 
IN ON THURSDAY DIMINISHING HEAT INDEX PROBLEMS.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
WITH DEEP TROUGH OVER THE EASTERN SECTION OF THE COUNTRY...THE 
NATURAL STATE WILL BE IN NORTHWEST FLOW. TAIL END OF FRONT WILL OVER 
ARKANSAS THURSDAY NIGHT. FRONT MOVES JUST TO THE SOUTHWEST OF THE 
STATE FRIDAY...BEFORE MOVING NORTH SATURDAY AS A WARM FRONT. 
UNSETTLED WEATHER WILL CONTINUE THROUGH MONDAY...AS ANOTHER FRONT 
MOVES INTO THE MID SOUTH.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    74  97  75  97 /  10  10  10  20 
HARRISON AR       71  94  71  93 /  10  10  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    74  97  76  97 /  10  10  10  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     74  97  76  97 /  10  10  10  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  71  94  70  93 /  10  10  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     74  97  77  97 /  10  10  10  20 
SEARCY AR         73  96  75  96 /  10  10  10  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      74  97  75  97 /  10  10  10  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   73  96  74  96 /  10  10  10  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...HEAT ADVISORY FOR TUESDAY THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY FOR ZONES ARZ016...ARZ021>025...ARZ030>034...ARZ037>039.

HEAT ADVISORY FOR TUESDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY FOR ZONES ARZ040>047...

936 
FXUS64 KLZK 120833
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
332 AM CDT MON JUL 12 2004

.DISCUSSION...
THE SKY REMAINED MOSTLY CLEAR DURING THE OVERNIGHT HOURS. IR 
SATELLITE IMAGES SHOW JUST A FEW HIGH CLOUDS ACROSS THE NORTH 
SECTIONS OF THE AREA. HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES OVER THE AREA AT THE 
SURFACE AND ALOFT. MID LEVEL RIDGE WILL CONTINUE TO RETROGRADE 
WESTWARD AND WILL TAKE UP RESIDENCE OVER COLORADO AND NEW MEXICO BY 
WEDNESDAY. MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THIS. VERY DRY AIR 
ALOFT MOVES INTO THE AREA BY TUESDAY. HOT AND HUMID CONDITIONS CAN 
BE EXPECTED OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS. MAY NEED A HEAT ADVISORY FOR 
TUESDAY AS HEAT INDICES COULD REACH 105 TO 110 DEGREES FOR A GOOD 
PORTION OF THE DAY. WILL NOT ISSUE ADVISORY AT THIS TIME. WILL DEFER 
IT TO THE DAY SHIFT TODAY OR MID CREW TOMORROW. 

ISOLATED AFTERNOON AND EVENING SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ARE 
EXPECTED THROUGH TUESDAY. A COLD FRONT APPROACHES LATE WEDNESDAY OR 
THURSDAY. TEMPERATURES WILL STILL BE HOT SOUTH OF THE FRONT BUT 
SLIGHTLY COOLER TEMPERATURES WILL BE USHERED IN BEHIND THE FRONT. 
THE FRONT WILL ALSO BRING A BETTER CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. BY LATE THURSDAY THE FRONT WILL STALL SOUTHWEST OF 
THE STATE AND THIS WILL PUT ARKANSAS BACK IN THE NORTHWEST FLOW 
PATTERN. SHORT WAVES WILL TRAVERSE THE AREA AND THE POTENTIAL FOR 
NIGHTTIME MCS ACTIVITY WILL RETURN...THROUGH NEXT WEEKEND.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    95  74  97  74 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       90  69  94  70 /  20  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    95  74  97  74 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     95  74  97  74 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  90  69  94  70 /  20  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     95  74  97  74 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         95  71  96  73 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      94  73  97  73 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   94  71  96  72 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

623 
FXUS64 KLZK 111848
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
143 PM CDT SUN JUL 11 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY...
MODELS ONCE AGAIN IN VERY GOOD AGREEMENT AND ONCE AGAIN ARE SHOWING 
VERY GOOD RUN TO RUN CONSISTENCY. AS PER THE PAST FEW DAYS...WILL 
SIMPLY GO WITH A BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS.

CONVECTION ALREADY FIRING UP ON WHATS LEFT OF SHEER AXIS THAT IS 
STRETCHED OUT FROM THE RED RIVER ACROSS NORTHERN ARKANSAS TO THE 
MISSISSIPPI RIVER. AS PER THE PAST FEW DAYS...CONVECTION IS DIURNAL 
IN NATURE AND SHOULD DISSIPATE AFTER SUNSET. BIGGEST CONCERN WILL BE 
LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN WITH PWATS AT OR ABOVE 2 INCHES AND A VIRTUALLY 
NON EXISTENT FLOW. AXIS REMAINS OVER THE AREA FOR THE NEXT SEVERAL 
DAYS WITH COPIOUS AMOUNTS OF MOISTURE AND CONDITIONALLY UNSTABLE 
AIR. WILL CONTINUE TO KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THE FORECAST FOR 
THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS BUT ACTIVITY ONCE AGAIN WILL BE DIURNAL IN 
NATURE. 

UPPER LEVEL RIDGE IS CENTERED OVER SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPI WITH A 
RATHER COMPACT UPPER LOW JUST NORTH OF CALGARY IN SOUTHERN ALBERTA 
PROVENCE. RIDGE FORECAST TO SLOWLY RETROGRADE THROUGH THE DAY MONDAY 
BEFORE CENTER BECOMES QUASI STATIONARY OVER CENTRAL COLORADO. UPPER 
LOW WILL TRAVEL ALONG THE TOP OF THE EXPANDING RIDGE BEFORE DIVING
SOUTHEAST AND INTO THE NORTHERN GREAT LAKES REGION LATE TUESDAY.
WAVE WILL CONTINUE TO SWING EASTWARD WEDNESDAY CARVING OUT A RATHER 
PRONOUNCED EASTERN CONUS TROUGH BY MID JULY STANDARDS. DANGEROUS 
NORTHWEST FLOW WILL PREVAIL OVER THE REGION BY THE END OF THE 
PERIOD. PRECIP CHANCES WILL INCREASE LATE WEDNESDAY AND MCS ACTIVITY 
CAN BE RULED OUT WEDNESDAY NIGHT AS CONVECTIVE VORT MAX MOVES DOWN 
FROM THE CENTRAL PLAINS. QPF FIELDS NOT REALLY PICKING UP ON IT YET 
SO WILL JUST CARRY SCATTERED POPS FOR NOW BUT PATTERN DOES LOOK 
FAVORABLE FOR MCS DEVELOPMENT AT THAT TIME.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...MODELS CONTINUE THEIR TREND OF RAISING 
HEIGHTS FOR THE NEXT FEW DAYS. GOOD SURFACE BASED SOUTH TO SOUTHWEST 
FLOW DEVELOPS MONDAY AND TUESDAY THANKS TO SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE 
SITTING IN THE GULF. TUESDAY APPEARS TO BE THE HOTTEST DAY OF THE 
WEEK WITH MID TO UPPER 90S COMMON. WITH DEW POINTS IN THE MID 70S...
HEAT INDICES MAY EXCEED ADVISORY CRITERIA. WOULD NOT BE SURPRISED TO 
SEE HEADLINES ON THIS DAY. SLIGHTLY COOLER WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY AS 
SURFACE FLOW TAKES ON MORE OF A NORTHERLY COMPONENT.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY...
EXTENDED RANGE MODELS CONTINUE TO BE IN REASONABLY ENOUGH AGREEMENT 
AND SUPPORT THE SAME TRENDS AS THE GOING FORECAST. NORTHWESTERLY 
FLOW REGIME WILL CONTINUE BEYOND SUNDAY. 

STALLED FRONTAL BOUNDARY WILL BE PRESSED UP AGAINST SOUTHWESTERN 
RIDGE...WITH H5 NORTHWESTERLY FLOW OVER THE FORECAST AREA AT THE 
BEGINNING OF THE EXTENDED PERIODS. THIS WILL BE THE SET UP FOR A 
SERIES OF MESOSCALE COMPLEXES TO SWING DOWN IN THE FLOW ACROSS 
ARKANSAS. THIS SCENARIO WILL BE MOST LIKELY THURSDAY NIGHT...AND 
AGAIN ON FRIDAY NIGHT.

FRONT WILL NOT MAKE MUCH OF A PROGRESSION THROUGH THE EARLY PART OF 
THE WEEKEND...AND MAY EVENTUALLY WASH OUT TO THE SOUTH OF ARKANSAS. 
INDICATIONS ARE THAT UPPER RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHWEST MAY FLATTEN OUT 
ENOUGH TO PUSH ANOTHER COLD FRONT TOWARD THE AREA BY SUNDAY.

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    73  95  72  97 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       70  91  69  94 /  20  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    73  95  72  97 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     72  95  72  97 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  70  91  69  94 /  20  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     72  95  72  97 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         72  95  71  96 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      73  94  72  97 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   72  94  71  96 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&


000 
FXUS64 KLZK 111848
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
143 PM CDT SUN JUL 11 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY...
MODELS ONCE AGAIN IN VERY GOOD AGREEMENT AND ONCE AGAIN ARE SHOWING 
VERY GOOD RUN TO RUN CONSISTENCY. AS PER THE PAST FEW DAYS...WILL 
SIMPLY GO WITH A BLEND OF FORECAST SOLUTIONS.

CONVECTION ALREADY FIRING UP ON WHATS LEFT OF SHEER AXIS THAT IS 
STRETCHED OUT FROM THE RED RIVER ACROSS NORTHERN ARKANSAS TO THE 
MISSISSIPPI RIVER. AS PER THE PAST FEW DAYS...CONVECTION IS DIURNAL 
IN NATURE AND SHOULD DISSIPATE AFTER SUNSET. BIGGEST CONCERN WILL BE 
LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN WITH PWATS AT OR ABOVE 2 INCHES AND A VIRTUALLY 
NON EXISTENT FLOW. AXIS REMAINS OVER THE AREA FOR THE NEXT SEVERAL 
DAYS WITH COPIOUS AMOUNTS OF MOISTURE AND CONDITIONALLY UNSTABLE 
AIR. WILL CONTINUE TO KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THE FORECAST FOR 
THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS BUT ACTIVITY ONCE AGAIN WILL BE DIURNAL IN 
NATURE. 

UPPER LEVEL RIDGE IS CENTERED OVER SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPI WITH A 
RATHER COMPACT UPPER LOW JUST NORTH OF CALGARY IN SOUTHERN ALBERTA 
PROVENCE. RIDGE FORECAST TO SLOWLY RETROGRADE THROUGH THE DAY MONDAY 
BEFORE CENTER BECOMES QUASI STATIONARY OVER CENTRAL COLORADO. UPPER 
LOW WILL TRAVEL ALONG THE TOP OF THE EXPANDING RIDGE BEFORE DIVING
SOUTHEAST AND INTO THE NORTHERN GREAT LAKES REGION LATE TUESDAY.
WAVE WILL CONTINUE TO SWING EASTWARD WEDNESDAY CARVING OUT A RATHER 
PRONOUNCED EASTERN CONUS TROUGH BY MID JULY STANDARDS. DANGEROUS 
NORTHWEST FLOW WILL PREVAIL OVER THE REGION BY THE END OF THE 
PERIOD. PRECIP CHANCES WILL INCREASE LATE WEDNESDAY AND MCS ACTIVITY 
CAN BE RULED OUT WEDNESDAY NIGHT AS CONVECTIVE VORT MAX MOVES DOWN 
FROM THE CENTRAL PLAINS. QPF FIELDS NOT REALLY PICKING UP ON IT YET 
SO WILL JUST CARRY SCATTERED POPS FOR NOW BUT PATTERN DOES LOOK 
FAVORABLE FOR MCS DEVELOPMENT AT THAT TIME.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...MODELS CONTINUE THEIR TREND OF RAISING 
HEIGHTS FOR THE NEXT FEW DAYS. GOOD SURFACE BASED SOUTH TO SOUTHWEST 
FLOW DEVELOPS MONDAY AND TUESDAY THANKS TO SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE 
SITTING IN THE GULF. TUESDAY APPEARS TO BE THE HOTTEST DAY OF THE 
WEEK WITH MID TO UPPER 90S COMMON. WITH DEW POINTS IN THE MID 70S...
HEAT INDICES MAY EXCEED ADVISORY CRITERIA. WOULD NOT BE SURPRISED TO 
SEE HEADLINES ON THIS DAY. SLIGHTLY COOLER WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY AS 
SURFACE FLOW TAKES ON MORE OF A NORTHERLY COMPONENT.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY...
EXTENDED RANGE MODELS CONTINUE TO BE IN REASONABLY ENOUGH AGREEMENT 
AND SUPPORT THE SAME TRENDS AS THE GOING FORECAST. NORTHWESTERLY 
FLOW REGIME WILL CONTINUE BEYOND SUNDAY. 

STALLED FRONTAL BOUNDARY WILL BE PRESSED UP AGAINST SOUTHWESTERN 
RIDGE...WITH H5 NORTHWESTERLY FLOW OVER THE FORECAST AREA AT THE 
BEGINNING OF THE EXTENDED PERIODS. THIS WILL BE THE SET UP FOR A 
SERIES OF MESOSCALE COMPLEXES TO SWING DOWN IN THE FLOW ACROSS 
ARKANSAS. THIS SCENARIO WILL BE MOST LIKELY THURSDAY NIGHT...AND 
AGAIN ON FRIDAY NIGHT.

FRONT WILL NOT MAKE MUCH OF A PROGRESSION THROUGH THE EARLY PART OF 
THE WEEKEND...AND MAY EVENTUALLY WASH OUT TO THE SOUTH OF ARKANSAS. 
INDICATIONS ARE THAT UPPER RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHWEST MAY FLATTEN OUT 
ENOUGH TO PUSH ANOTHER COLD FRONT TOWARD THE AREA BY SUNDAY.

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    73  95  72  97 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       70  91  69  94 /  20  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    73  95  72  97 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     72  95  72  97 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  70  91  69  94 /  20  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     72  95  72  97 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         72  95  71  96 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      73  94  72  97 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   72  94  71  96 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

823 
FXUS64 KLZK 111536
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1027 AM CDT SUN JUL 11 2004

.DISCUSSION...
NO CHANGES TO THE ONGOING FORECAST THIS AFTERNOON. UPPER LEVEL RIDGE 
OVER THE SOUTHEAST CONUS PRETTY MUCH LOCKED IN AND FORECAST TO DRIFT 
SLOWLY TO THE WEST OVER THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS. LZK SOUNDING FROM 
THIS MORNING NOT SHOWING MUCH OF A CAP AND ONLY A WEAK INVERSION 
WHICH HAS LIKELY BEEN BROKEN. STILL EXPECTING CU FORMATION THIS 
AFTERNOON BUT PRECIPITATION WILL BE LIMITED AS RIDGE STARTS TO SLIDE 
OVER THE CWA AND MID LEVEL TEMPS RISE. WITH MODELS STILL SHOWING 
SEVERAL WEAK SHORTWAVES LURKING ABOUT...PRECIPITATION CAN NOT BE 
RULED OUT BUT ONLY SLIGHT CHANCE POPS LOOK GOOD. TEMPERATURES ALSO 
LOOK GOOD.  
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
JUST A FEW CLOUDS ARE INDICATED ON THE IR SATELLITE IMAGES THIS 
MORNING ACROSS NORTHWEST AND SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS. STRONG SURFACE HIGH 
PRESSURE CENTERED OVER ALABAMA HAS KEPT THE WEATHER QUIET OVERNIGHT. 
THIS HIGH PRESSURE WILL ALSO KEEP THUNDERSTORM CHANCES LIMITED TO 
AFTERNOON AND EVENING TIMEFRAMES INTO THE EARLY PART OF THIS WEEK. 
THIS MID LEVEL RIDGE FORMS QUITE A GRIP ON THE MIDDLE PART OF THE 
COUNTRY THIS WEEK. WARMER TEMPERATURES ARE EXPECTED FOR MONDAY AND 
TUESDAY AS THE RIDGE MOVES WEST...MANY AREAS WILL EXPERIENCE 
TEMPERATURES IN THE MID 90S. BY TUESDAY THE AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE 
BECOMES CENTERED OVER COLORADO. THE MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT 
THROUGH THE UPCOMING WEEK. 

AN AREA OF LOW PRESSURE WILL SLIDE INTO THE GREAT LAKES AREA HOWEVER 
ON WEDNESDAY AND THIS WILL BRING A COLD FRONT TOWARD 
ARKANSAS...INCREASING CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. THE 
FRONT MAY GET HUNG UP IN ARKANSAS...GIVEN THE STRENGTH OF THE RIDGE 
TO THE WEST. NORTHWEST FLOW RETURNS TO ARKANSAS LATE WEDNESDAY AND 
THIS WILL ALLOW SHORT WAVES TO TRAVERSE THE AREA AS WELL AS MCS 
ACTIVITY. NORTHWEST FLOW CONTINUES INTO SATURDAY. 

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    92  73  95  73 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       90  70  91  70 /  20  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    92  73  95  73 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     92  72  95  73 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  90  70  91  70 /  20  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     94  72  95  73 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         92  72  95  72 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      92  73  94  73 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   91  72  94  72 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&


976 
FXUS64 KLZK 101814
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
111 PM CDT SAT JUL 10 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY...
ALL SHORT RANGE MODELS IN GOOD AGREEMENT THIS AFTERNOON WITH REGARDS 
TO BOTH CONSISTENCY AND TIMING OF THE PRIMARY PLAYERS. WITH ONLY 
DISCRETE DIFFERENCES NOTED...FEEL A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS IS WARRANTED.

MODELS HAVE BEEN ADVERTISING A MAJOR PATTERN CHANGE LATELY AND ALL 
INDICATIONS ARE IT IS WELL UNDERWAY. WEAK ZONAL FLOW THAT PERSISTED 
MOST OF LAST WEEK IS BECOMING HIGHLY AMPLIFIED FOR MID JULY. WEAK 
SHEER AXIS THAT WAS LOCATED ALONG THE TEXAS/ARKANSAS BORDER ALL BUT 
DISSIPATED AT THIS TIME. DIURNAL CONVECTION ALREADY UNDERWAY IN THE 
MOIST AND CONDITIONALLY UNSTABLE AIR MASS. DYNAMICS ARE SORELY 
LACKING ACROSS THE AREA AND WHILE A FEW STORMS MAY PULSE UP AND 
BECOME BRIEFLY STRONG...NO WIDESPREAD SEVER WEATHER IS EXPECTED. 
BIGGEST CONCERN WILL BE LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN AS THESE STORMS WILL BE 
SLOW MOVERS WITH PWATS HOVERING AROUND 2 INCHES. PRECIPITATION WILL 
BE DIURNAL IN NATURE AND DRY UP AFTER SUNSET.

UPPER RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHERN CONUS WILL STRENGTHEN AND BECOME THE 
DOMINANT WEATHER FEATURE THROUGH MID WEEK. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
WILL CONTINUE IN THE TROPICAL AIRMASS BUT WILL BE DIURNAL IN NATURE 
AS NO SIGNIFICANT SHORTWAVES ARE SEEN. RIDGE AXIS ACTUALLY 
RETROGRADES WESTWARD THROUGH THE WEEK. RIDGE AXIS POKES UP INTO THE 
CANADIAN PRAIRIE PROVINCES ON SUNDAY WHILE AN UPPER LEVEL LOW SWINGS 
IN TO THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST. 

UPPER LOW FORECAST TO MOVE UP AND OVER THE RIDGE...FLATTENING IT 
ONLY BRIEFLY AS IT PASSES THROUGH SOUTH CENTRAL CANADA. ONCE THE 
WAVES CLEARS THE RIDGE...IT DIVES SOUTHEAST AND CARVES OUT AN 
EASTERN CONUS TROF BY THE END OF THE PERIOD AND A RETURN TO THE 
DANGEROUS NORTHWEST FLOW. STRONGER LOOKING SHORTWAVE COMES DOWN IN 
SAID NORTHWEST FLOW LATE WEDNESDAY TO BRING A BETTER CHANCE OF 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...MID LEVEL TEMPS SUPPORT HIGHS IN THE MID 
90S AND LOWS IN THE LOWER 70S THIS PERIOD. MAV/FWC NUMBERS ALSO 
FOLLOW THIS SCENARIO AND ARE GENERALLY ACCEPTED. DEW POINTS WILL 
BORDER ON THE OPPRESSIVE SIDE WITH HIGH HEAT INDICES. IN OTHER 
WORDS...ITS SUMMER.
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY...
EXTENDED RANGE MODELS IN FAIRLY GOOD AGREEMENT THIS AFTERNOON. ALL 
POINT TO RETROGRESSION OF LARGE H5 RIDGE CURRENTLY OVER THE SOUTHERN 
PLAINS BY MID WEEK.

LOOKS AS THOUGH WEAK COLD FRONT WILL MOVE THROUGH THE AREA SOME TIME 
WEDNESDAY NIGHT/EARLY THURSDAY MORNING...BEFORE STALLING OUT TO THE 
SOUTH AND WEST OF ARKANSAS. FRONT COULD REMAIN INVOF EASTERN 
OKLAHOMA DOWN THROUGH SOUTHERN ARKANSAS/NORTHERN LOUISIANA FOR 
SEVERAL DAYS. WITH RIDGE CENTERED MORE TOWARD NEW MEXICO/WEST 
TEXAS...H5 FLOW WILL BE NORTHWESTERLY...WHICH WILL ALLOW SEVERAL 
SHORTWAVES MOVING DOWN THROUGH THE AREA. THIS WOULD BE MORE OF A 
RETURN TO THE NIGHTLY MCS PATTERN THAT WE HAVE GROWN SO USED TO THIS 
SUMMER. 

ONE BENEFIT OF THIS PATTERN WOULD BE NORTHEASTERLY COMPONENT TO 
SURFACE WINDS...WHICH WILL HELP TO BRING TEMPERATURES DOWNWARD FOR 
THE MID TO LATE WEEK TIME FRAME. DONT GET ME WRONG...ITS STILL 
SUMMER...AND TEMPERATURES WILL BE HOT...JUST NOT AS HOT AS THEY WILL 
BE IN THE SHORT TERM.

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    73  93  73  95 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       69  90  70  91 /  20  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    72  93  73  95 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     73  94  72  95 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  69  90  70  91 /  20  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     73  94  72  95 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         72  92  72  95 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      72  94  73  94 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   71  92  72  94 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1018 AM CDT SAT JUL 10 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS RIGHT ON TARGET AND NO CHANGES ARE NEEDED. 
HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES TO BUILD IN THE MID LEVELS AND WEAK SHEER 
AXIS OVER WESTERN ARKANSAS BECOMING MORE ILL DEFINED WITH TIME. 
THIS MORNINGS SOUNDING SHOWS CAPPING AROUND 600 MB AS MID LEVEL 
TEMPS CONTINUE TO WARM. AIRMASS REMAINS CONDITIONALLY UNSTABLE WITH 
PWAT VALUES IN THE VICINITY OF 2 INCHES SO ISOLATED DIURNAL 
ACTIVITY STILL LOOKS GOOD. OVERALL PATTERN SHOWS VERY LITTLE CHANGES 
THROUGH THE MIDDLE OF THE WEEK FOR A CONTINUATION OF HOT AND HUMID 
CONDITIONS.
&&

56

.PREV DISCUSSION...
.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
KLZK RADAR IS QUIET THIS MORNING. HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES TO BUILD 
OVER THE AREA. SATELLITE IMAGES SHOW CLOUDS INCREASING ACROSS 
WESTERN ARKANSAS AND EASTERN OKLAHOMA NEAR A SHEAR AXIS. GFS AND ETA 
ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT THIS MORNING. HIGH PRESSURE AND SOUTHERLY FLOW 
WILL CONTINUE INTO EARLY NEXT WEEK. MAINLY AFTERNOON AND EVENING 
ISOLATED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE EXPECTED. DECENT MOISTURE 
AND AFTERNOON HEATING WILL LEAD TO THUNDERSTORM DEVELOPMENT. 
OTHERWISE PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES AND RATHER WARM AND MUGGY CONDITIONS 
WILL CONTINUE THROUGH TUESDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
AS A LARGE MID LEVEL RIDGE BUILDS WEST OVER THE ROCKIES MID 
WEEK...NORTHWEST FLOW WILL RETURN TO ARKANSAS. THIS MAY LEAD TO MORE 
MCS ACTIVITY BY THURSDAY. WILL STICK WITH LOW POPS AT THIS TIME 
THROUGH THE EXTENDED PERIOD.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

51

.DISCUSSION...
A FEW SHRA/TSRA CONFINED TO SRN AR ATTM. HAVE LOWERED POPS TO ISOLD 
FOR THE SRN COUNTIES AND REMOVED RAIN CHCS ELSEWHERE FOR REST OF 
TNGT. REWORKED HOURLY TEMP GRIDS TO BETTER REFLECT CURRENT CONDS. 
REST OF FCST IN GOOD SHAPE AND NO OTHER CHGS MADE. UPDATED GRIDS AND 
ZONES ALREADY OUT.

44





207 
FXUS64 KLZK 091857
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
154 PM CDT FRI JUL  9 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY...
MODELS ARE IN VERY GOOD AGREEMENT THIS AFTERNOON AND ALL ARE 
ADVERTISING A RETURN TO A MORE SUMMER LIKE PATTERN FOR THE PERIOD. 
ONLY DISCERNIBLE DIFFERENCE IS THE MODELS ARE SLIGHTLY FASTER WITH 
THE FEATURES VERSUS PREVIOUS RUNS BUT SINCE ALL MODELS ARE PICKING 
UP ON THIS TREND...WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF ETA/GFS SOLUTIONS THIS 
AFTERNOON.

LAST NIGHTS MCS DEVELOPED PRETTY MUCH ON SCHEDULE OVER CENTRAL 
NEBRASKA BEFORE SPLITTING IN HALF. PIECES OF THE COMPLEX MOVED DUE 
EAST AND SOUTHWEST...BASICALLY MISSING THE ENTIRE CWA. COMPLEX DID 
LAY DOWN A NICE OUTFLOW BOUNDARY ACROSS THE NORTH TO GO ALONG WITH 
THE NUMEROUS BOUNDARIES LURKING ABOUT FROM YESTERDAYS CONVECTION. 
APPEARS THE AIR MASS HAS RECOVERED WITH SCATTERED SHOWERS STILL 
POPPING UP ACROSS THE NORTH. WITH SEVERAL VORTICITY MAXIMA FORECAST 
TO MOVE SLOWLY THROUGH THE WEAK FLOW...WILL NEED TO KEEP SCATTERED 
POPS IN THE FORECAST THIS EVENING. 

UPPER LEVEL WEAKNESS ALONG THE EASTERN TEXAS BORDER...DEPICTED QUITE 
WELL ON THE MODELS...WILL HELP ENHANCE PRECIP CHANCES TONIGHT. 
FEATURE WASHES OUT EARLY SATURDAY WITH MID LEVEL HEIGHTS STARTING TO 
BUILD. TROPICAL RIDGE BEGINS TO BUILD IN EARNEST OVER THE SOUTHERN 
AND CENTRAL CONUS AS EXTENSION OF THE BERMUDA HIGH MOVES IN ACROSS 
THE SOUTHEAST CONUS. RIDGE WILL REMAIN LOCKED IN OVER THE WEEKEND 
WITH CHANNELED VORTICITY STRETCHED OUT FROM CENTRAL TEXAS... ACROSS 
NORTHWEST ARKANSAS AND INTO THE OHIO VALLEY. WITH PLENTY OF DEEP
SUBTROPICAL MOISTURE TRAPPED BENEATH THE RIDGE...DIURNAL SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS WILL CONTINUE BUT ONLY SLIGHT CHANCE POPS CAN BE 
JUSTIFIED OVER THE WEEKEND.

UPPER LEVEL LOW MOVES ONSHORE OVER THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST SATURDAY 
AND MOVES EASTWARD...UP AND OVER THE EXPANDING SUB TROPICAL RIDGE. 
LOW THEN DROPS INTO SOUTHERN ONTARIO AND CARVES OUT A WEAK TROF OVER 
THE OHIO VALLEY. TROF EFFECTIVELY PUSHES THE CENTER OF THE RIDGE TO 
THE WEST AND ALLOWS IMPULSES TO SLIDE DOWN THE EASTERN PERIPHERY ON 
WEAK NORTHWEST FLOW. DIURNAL PRECIPITATION WILL ONCE AGAIN HAVE TO 
BE ACCOUNTED FOR.

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...BOTH FWC AND MAV NUMBERS SHOW A GRADUAL 
WARMING TREND WITH THE BUILDING SUBTROPICAL RIDGE. SEE NO REASON TO 
ARGUE HERE AND WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF GUIDANCE THIS AFTERNOON. 
BOTTOM LINE WILL BE A STRETCH OF HOT AND HUMID CONDITIONS WITH ONLY 
DIURNAL PRECIPITATION TO COOL THINGS DOWN.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY...
THIS NORTHWEST FLOW WILL CONTINUE THROUGH ALL OF THE LONG RANGE... 
SETTING UP THE POSSIBILITY OF BRIEF BOUTS OF CONVECTION FIRING UP 
EACH TIME A SHORT WAVE SLIDES DOWN THE EDGE OF THE RIDGE. A SURFACE 
RIDGE WILL BE GAINING STRENGTH GRADUALLY...PUSHING A WEAK FRONT INTO 
NORTHERN ARKANSAS THURSDAY AFTERNOON INTO FRIDAY MORNING. HIGH WILL 
STRETCH FROM THE UPPER MID-WEST THROUGH THE PLAINS FOR THE WEEK 
END...WITH ANOTHER FRONT ABOUT TO ENTER THE STATE SUNDAY AFTERNOON. 
SURFACE RIDGE WILL KNOCK BACK HUMIDITIES TO BRING SOME RELIEF FROM 
THE MUGGY CONDITIONS. ALSO...A NORTHEASTERLY COMPONENT TO THE WIND 
WILL HELP TO HOLD TEMPERATURES IN THE NEAR NORMAL RANGE...RATHER 
THAN GETTING OPPRESSIVELY ABOVE NORMAL. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    72  91  73  93 /  30  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       69  88  70  91 /  30  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    73  91  72  93 /  30  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     73  92  73  94 /  30  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  69  88  69  91 /  30  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     72  92  73  94 /  30  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         72  90  72  92 /  30  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      73  92  72  94 /  30  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   72  90  71  92 /  30  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56/32






952 
FXUS64 KLZK 091556
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1055 AM CDT FRI JUL  9 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SOME SUPERFICIAL UPDATES ARE NEEDED THIS MORNING WITH ONLY MINIMAL 
EFFECTS ON THE FORECAST ITSELF. LAST NIGHTS MCS DEVELOPED PRETTY 
MUCH ON SCHEDULE OVER CENTRAL NEBRASKA BEFORE SPLITTING IN HALF. 
PIECES OF THE COMPLEX MOVED DUE EAST AND SOUTHWEST...BASICALLY 
MISSING THE ENTIRE CWA. SATELLITE CONTINUES TO SHOW CLOUD TOPS 
WARMING AND SYSTEMS DISSIPATING. STORMS CONTINUE TO FIRE UP ON THE 
OUTFLOW OVER SOUTHERN MISSOURI AND ARE DRIFTING TO THE SOUTH. 

OTHER SHOWERS ARE POPPING UP OVER PARTS OF THE CWA AS DAYTIME 
HEATING COMMENCES. OVERALL PATTERN IS A BIT COMPLEX WITH MODELS 
PICKING UP A WEAKNESS IN THE OVERALL FLOW OVER CENTRAL ARKANSAS
AND SEVERAL WEAK SHORTWAVES THAT STILL HAVE TO MOVE THROUGH. LAST 
NIGHTS CONVECTION OVER ARKANSAS LAID DOWN NUMEROUS BOUNDARIES AND 
WITH ALL OTHER FACTORS COMING INTO PLAY...DECIDED TO BOOST POPS FOR 
THIS AFTERNOON CWA WIDE. OTHER CHANGES INCLUDE INCREASING QPF AND 
LOWERING MAX TEMPS AS THICK CLOUD COVER HAS INHIBITED TEMPERATURES 
JUST A BIT.

UPDATE WILL BE OUT SHORTLY.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    90  73  91  72 /  40  30  20  20 
HARRISON AR       86  70  88  69 /  40  30  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    90  74  91  71 /  40  30  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     90  74  92  72 /  40  30  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  86  70  88  68 /  40  30  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     90  73  92  72 /  40  30  30  30 
SEARCY AR         88  73  90  71 /  40  30  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      90  74  92  71 /  40  30  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   88  73  90  70 /  40  30  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

MOUNT IDA AR      90  74  92  71 /  40  30  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   88  73  90  70 /  40  30  20  20

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

672 
FXUS64 KLZK 090859
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
358 AM CDT FRI JUL 9 2004

.DISCUSSION...
KLZK RADAR SHOWS PRECIPITATION DIMINISHING ACROSS THE AREA. 
SATELLITE IMAGES SHOW DISSIPATING MCS OVER ARKANSAS AND ANOTHER MCS 
OVER NEBRASKA AND KANSAS AND HEADED SOUTHEAST. WILL EXPECT THIS MCS 
TO AFFECT NORTHWEST ARKANSAS AROUND 15Z. FEEL THE MCS WILL WEAKEN 
SOMEWHAT ONCE IT GETS INTO ARKANSAS AS MORE STABLE AIR IS LOCATED IN 
NORTHWEST ARKANSAS. 

A MID LEVEL TROUGH OVER ARKANSAS WILL CONTINUE OVER THE AREA THROUGH 
SATURDAY. HIGH PRESSURE WILL BREAK THIS TROUGH DOWN BY SUNDAY 
AFTERNOON AND THE PATTERN WILL GET BACK TO MORE OF THE ISOLATED 
AFTERNOON AND EVENING THUNDERSTORMS. ABUNDANT MOISTURE CONTINUES 
OVER THE AREA THROUGH SATURDAY AS WELL. INCREASED POPS ESPECIALLY 
ACROSS THE NORTH TODAY. EXPECT SOME ACTIVITY TO DEVELOP WITH THE 
APPROACHING MCS. 

MID LEVEL HIGH PRESSURE WILL BECOME MORE OF A PLAYER ON SUNDAY. THIS 
WILL LIMIT THE THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY TO THE AFTERNOON AND EVENING 
TYPES. THIS PATTERN WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE MIDDLE OF NEXT WEEK. 
WARM AND HUMID CONDITIONS WILL ALSO CONTINUE.  
&&


.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    93  73  91  72 /  30  30  20  20 
HARRISON AR       89  70  88  69 /  40  30  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    93  74  91  71 /  30  30  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     93  74  92  72 /  30  30  30  30

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATED FORECAST TO PUT HIGHER CHANCES FOR RAIN IN MOST 
AREAS...ESPECIALLY IN THE NORTHWEST HALF OF THE STATE. UPPED 
RAINFALL AMOUNTS AS WELL. 

MCS CONTINUES TO HEAD TOWARD CENTRAL ARKANSAS THIS EVENING FROM THE 
NORTHWEST. NOTICE THAT OUTFLOW STARTING TO OUTRUN LINE OF 
STORMS...SO WOULD EXPECT SOME WEAKENING TO OCCUR. THIS ALONG WITH 
WEAK WINDS ALOFT WOULD SUPPORT ONLY ISOLATED SEVERE WEATHER.

PRECIPITATION SHOULD PRETTY MUCH FALL APART AFTER MIDNIGHT. CLOUDS 
WILL ALSO THIN OUT...WITH PATCHY FOG FORMING. 

THANKS TO SPC FOR COORDINATION. (46)


909 
FXUS64 KLZK 081941
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
240 PM CDT THU JUL  8 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY...
MCS FROM SOUTHEAST KANSAS MOVING INTO SOUTHWEST MISSOURI AND
WILL EVENTUALLY HEAD INTO NORTHWEST ARKANSAS BY THIS EVENING.
MEANWHILE...SCATTERED SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS WORKING NORTHWARD
FROM LOUISIANA. WILL KEEP CHANCE FOR PRECIPITATION THIS
EVENING IN NORTHERN COUNTIES AND ALSO IN SOUTH. ONLY
ISOLATED PRECIPITATION IN CENTRAL SECTIONS OF STATE. ALL
PRECIPITATION PRETTY MUCH GONE BY MIDNIGHT.

WEAK AREA OF LOW PRESSURE/SHEAR AXIS WILL CONTINUE FROM
TEXAS INTO NORTHERN/WESTERN ARKANSAS THROUGH FRIDAY...WITH
RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE TO WEST. WITH HIGH NOT QUITE TAKING
OVER YET...WILL KEEP SCATTERED SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS IN THE
FORECAST FRIDAY AFTERNOON/EVENING.

OVER THE WEEKEND...SHEAR AXIS GONE WITH HIGH PRESSURE FIRMLY IN
CONTROL OF WEATHER PATTERN. ONLY ISOLATED AFTERNOON AND EVENING
THUNDER EXPECTED...WITH DRY/HOT CONDITIONS. (46)
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
SEE NO REASON TO MAKE ANY MAJOR CHANGES TO THE EXTENDED FORECAST
TODAY. MAIN REASON...H5 RIDGE WILL BE PREDOMINANT THROUGHOUT MUCH OF
THE PERIOD. SOUTHWESTERLY/SOUTHERLY FLOW WILL BE NOTED AT THE
SURFACE...KEEPING TEMPERATURES WARM. SEVERAL WEAKNESSES IN THE UPPER
FLOW WILL MOVE THROUGH...BUT WITH MOISTURE BEING MARGINAL...AND LACK
OF A LARGE SCALE FOCUSING MECHANISM...ANY CONVECTION WILL BE
ISOLATED AND DIURNAL IN NATURE.

BY WEDNESDAY...UPPER RIDGE WILL SINK SOUTHWARD AND MAY EVEN SHOW A
LITTLE RETROGRESSION. NORTHWESTERLY FLOW WILL SET UP ACROSS
NORTHERN ARKANSAS. THIS WILL ALLOW SEVERAL IMPULSES TO MOVE DOWN IN
THE MEAN FLOW...KEEPING A CONTINUED CHANCE OF AFTERNOON AND EVENING
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN THE FORECAST.

BY THURSDAY...NORTHWESTERLY FLOW AT THE UPPER LEVELS MAY ALLOW A
SURFACE FRONT TO PUSH INTO THE AREA. HOWEVER...SOLUTIONS ARE ALWAYS
A BIT IFFY THIS FAR OUT. WITH PERSISTENT SUMMERTIME PATTERN FOR MUCH
OF THE PERIOD...WILL CONTINUE CURRENT POP AND SENSIBLE WEATHER
TRENDS OF DIURNAL ACTIVITY. MADE VERY LITTLE CHANGES TO
TEMPERATURES. (57)
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    73  92  73  91 /  20  30  20  20
HARRISON AR       70  89  70  88 /  30  30  20  20
HOT SPRINGS AR    74  93  74  91 /  30  30  20  20
PINE BLUFF AR     74  92  74  92 /  30  30  20  20
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  70  89  70  88 /  30  30  20  20
MONTICELLO AR     73  92  73  92 /  30  30  20  20
SEARCY AR         73  91  73  90 /  20  30  20  20
MOUNT IDA AR      74  93  74  92 /  30  30  20  20
RUSSELLVILLE AR   73  91  73  90 /  30  30  20  20
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

205 
FXUS64 KLZK 081609 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1105 AM CDT THU JUL 8 2004

.DISCUSSION...
MCS DEVELOPING OVER SOUTHEAST KANSAS THIS MORNING. VISIBLE SATELLITE 
PICKING UP SOME INDICATION OF GRAVITY WAVE...WHICH WOULD INFER THAT 
SYSTEM IS ELEVATED AT THE MOMENT. SCATTERED CONVECTION AHEAD OF THE 
SYSTEM ALIGNED TO THE SOUTH/SOUTHEAST INTO NORTHEAST 
OKLAHOMA/NORTHWEST ARKANSAS...SO WOULD EXPECT SYSTEM TO TRACK IN 
THIS DIRECTION INTO THIS AFTERNOON. 

FOR NOW...UPPED CHANCES OF RAIN A BIT IN NORTHERN/WESTERN ARKANSAS 
THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING. CAPES QUITE HIGH IN THESE AREAS...AS 
WELL AS THE REST OF THE STATE...AND COULD HAVE SOME SEVERE WEATHER. 
LOOKING FOR MAINLY STRONG/DAMAGING WINDS.

WILL BE INTERESTING TO SEE WHAT HAPPENS AS SYSTEM MOVES FARTHER 
SOUTH/SOUTHEAST. FOR NOW...A FAIRLY CAPPED ENVIRONMENT NOTED...BUT 
SYSTEM WILL BECOME MORE SURFACE BASED AS CAP WEAKENS. WILL WATCH 
THIS CLOSELY THIS AFTERNOON. (46)
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$


507 
FXUS64 KLZK 080832
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
330 AM CDT THU JUL 8 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY
BROAD RIDGE OVER THE SOUTHERN UNITED STATES THIS MORNING...WITH MAIN 
AREA OF ACTIVITY JUST TO THE NORTH OF THE STATE. A WARM FRONT IS 
CURRENTLY IN SOUTHERN MISSOURI...AND WILL NOT MOVE MUCH TODAY. 
OVERNIGHT...TWO SMALL THUNDERSTORM COMPLEXES DEVELOPED IN EASTERN 
KANSAS AND WEST CENTRAL MISSOURI...AND WILL CONTINUE THEIR TREK 
SOUTHEAST. 

MODELS IN GOOD AGREEMENT CONCERNING TODAY...BEFORE DIFFERING IN THE 
FORECAST FOR FRIDAY. BOTH THE ETA AND GFS SHOW THUNDERSTORM 
COMPLEXES MOVING SOUTHEAST AND JUST REACHING NORTHERN ARKANSAS 
TODAY. SCATTERED THUNDERSTORMS WILL DEVELOP IN THE NORTH TODAY DUE 
TO THE COMPLEXES MOVING SOUTHEAST...AND THE ASSOCIATED OUTFLOWS 
INITIATING CONVECTION THIS AFTERNOON. WARM AND UNSTABLE AIR REMAINS 
OVER THE ENTIRE STATE...SO CAN NOT RULE OUT ISOLATED CONVECTION OVER 
THE CENTRAL AND SOUTH AS WELL.

UPPER RIDGE TRIES TO MOVE OVER THE MID SOUTH TONIGHT AND 
FRIDAY...BUT CIRCULATION OVER THE GULF OF MEXICO WILL MOVE TO THE 
NORTHWEST OVER TEXAS. ALSO...NEW ETA RUN TRYING TO DEVELOP ANOTHER 
MCS OVER THE PLAINS AND MOVES IT TO THE SOUTHEAST. DUE TO 
UNCERTAINTY IN MODEL SOLUTIONS...HAVE KEPT SLIGHT CHANCE GOING 
THROUGH TONIGHT AND FRIDAY...WITH SLIGHTLY HIGHER POPS IN THE NORTH 
TONIGHT.

THE WEAKNESS IN THE UPPER RIDGE CONTINUES INTO THE WEEKEND...WITH 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS CONTINUING. HOWEVER...MUCH OF THE ACTIVITY LOOKS 
TO BE DIURNAL IN NATURE.

AS FAR AS TEMPERATURES GO...MOST READINGS WILL REMAIN NEAR NORMAL. 
LOWERED TEMPS A COUPLE OF DEGREES TODAY IN THE NORTH DUE TO CLOUD 
COVER AND RAINFALL...BUT OVERALL GUIDANCE NUMBERS LOOK GOOD.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
UPPER RIDGE WILL DOMINATE THE AREA WITH FAIRLY TYPICAL SUMMER
WEATHER. KEPT MENTION OF ISOLATED AFTERNOON SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. NEW GFS SHOWS RIDGE RETROGRADING TO THE WEST AND
DANGEROUS NORTHWEST FLOW DEVELOPING OVER THE AREA AROUND MIDWEEK
WITH A WEAK FRONT MOVING THROUGH. DID NOT MAKE ANY CHANGES TO 
ACCOUNT FOR THIS TODAY SINCE IT WILL MAINLY BE ON DAY 7 AND
BEYOND AND PROGGED PATTERN LIKELY WILL CHANGE A FEW TIMES BEFORE IT 
GETS HERE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    91  73  92  74 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       88  70  89  71 /  30  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    92  73  92  73 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     92  74  93  74 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  88  70  89  70 /  30  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     93  74  93  74 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         90  72  91  73 /  30  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      92  73  93  73 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   90  72  91  72 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

877 
FXUS64 KLZK 080258 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
955 PM CDT WED JUL 7 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LAST OF THE CONVECTION HAS PUSHED SE OF THE FA ATTM. OTHER STORMS 
NOTED OVER NERN TX BUT MOVG VERY LITTLE. MEANWHILE...LARGE COMPLEX 
CONTS TO DROP SWD ACRS KS. EXPECT ADDITIONAL SHRA/TSRA TO FORM NW OF 
AR LATER TNGT AND COULD AFFECT THE NRN PARTS OF THE STATE AFTER 
SUNRISE THU MRNG. CURRENT FCST HAS THIS TREND WELL HANDLED. ONLY 
CHGS TO THE GOING FCST WAS TO ADJUST TEMP GRIDS TO BETTER REFLECT 
CURRENT TRENDS. UPDATED ZONES AND GRIDS ALREADY OUT.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

.DISCUSSION...
LAST OF THE CONVECTION HAS PUSHED SE OF THE FA ATTM. OTHER STORMS

AR LATER TNGT AND COULD AFFECT THE NRN PARTS OF THE STATE AFTER 
SUNRISE THU MRNG. CURRENT FCST HAS THIS TREND WELL HANDLED. ONLY

44





469 
FXUS64 KLZK 071920
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
220 PM CDT WED JUL  7 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY...
LOOKS LIKE THE ETA HAS A BETTER HANDLE ON THE CURRENT SITUATION 
VERSUS THE OTHER SHORT RANGE MODELS. ETA ALSO HAS BEEN MORE 
CONSISTENT THAN THE OTHER MODELS OF LATE AND IS IN BETTER AGREEMENT 
WITH THE CANADIAN VERSUS THE GFS. THERE ARE SOME SUBTLE DIFFERENCES 
IN THE STRENGTH AND TIMING OF SHORTWAVES LATE IN THE PERIOD BUT ALL 
BEING SAID...WILL LEAN TOWARDS A ETA SOLUTION THIS AFTERNOON. 

UNSETTLED WEATHER TO CONTINUE THROUGH THE EVENING HOURS TONIGHT. 
LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES FRONTAL BOUNDARY RIGHT ALONG THE 
ARKANSAS/MISSOURI BORDER. FRONT DIFFICULT TO PICK UP WITH NUMEROUS 
OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES FROM ONGOING CONVECTION. CLOUD TEMPERATURES WITH 
THE MCS THAT MOVED INTO EASTERN OKLAHOMA/SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS CONTINUE 
TO WARM AND FEATURE CONTINUES TO RAPIDLY DISSIPATE AND IS BARELY 
DISCERNIBLE. OTHER STORMS CONTINUE TO FIRE UP ON THE AFOREMENTIONED 
OUTFLOW OR IN THE IN THE WARM AND UNSTABLE AIR MASS SOUTH OF THE 
FRONT. WOULD EXPECT MOST OF THIS PRECIPITATION TO DISSIPATE AFTER 
SUNSET AND WILL TREND POPS DOWNWARD THIS EVENING.

OVERALL SYNOPTIC PATTERN CHARACTERIZED BY ACTIVE NORTHERN BRANCH 
OF THE WESTERLIES AND SEVERAL STRONG UPPER LOWS TRAVERSING THE 
UNITED STATES/CANADIAN BORDER. STRONG UPPER LEVEL RIDGING WILL 
REMAIN OVER THE SOUTHERN UNITED STATES WITH THE OCCASIONAL WEAKNESS 
IN THE FLOW TRYING TO INITIATE PRECIPITATION. ETA CONTINUES TO HINT 
AT ANOTHER MCS FOR TONIGHT WITH STRONGEST PART OF THE FEATURE 
STAYING ACROSS MISSOURI. SOUTHERN EXTENT OF THE MCS WOULD BRUSH THE 
NORTHERN COUNTIES. WILL GO HIGH SCATTERED HERE AND LOW SCATTERED OR 
SLIGHT CHANCE ELSEWHERE AS TOO MUCH MOISTURE AND TWO MANY BOUNDARIES 
REMAIN TO COMPLETELY REMOVE IT.

FRONT MOVES BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT THURSDAY AND UPPER 
LEVEL RIDGING WILL DOMINATE. ENOUGH MOISTURE WILL REMAIN TRAPPED 
BENEATH THE RIDGE THAT DIURNAL SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE 
POSSIBLE. MODELS GENERATE AN UPPER LEVEL DISTURBANCE OVER THE TEXAS 
GULF COAST LATE THURSDAY AND SLIDE THE FEATURE SOUTHWARD FRIDAY. 
FEATURE MAY INCREASE PRECIP CHANCES ACROSS THE SOUTH BUT WILL TAKE A 
WAIT AND SEE APPROACH AT THIS POINT AS GFS IS NOT AS AGGRESSIVE WITH 
THIS SYSTEM AS THE ETA.

FWC/MAV TEMPS BOTH IN GOOD AGREEMENT AND WILL GENERALLY GO WITH  
BLEND OF NUMBERS. TEMPERATURES WILL AVERAGE PRETTY CLOSE TO SEASONAL 
NORMS THROUGH OUT THE PERIOD.  
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY...
UPPER RIDGE WILL PREDOMINATE WITH SEVERAL WEAKNESSES IN THE OVERALL 
FLOW. SUMMER LIKE CONDITIONS WILL CONTINUE WITH DIURNAL SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. TEMPERATURES WILL AVERAGE NEAR NORMAL. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    71  91  74  92 /  30  30  20  20 
HARRISON AR       67  88  70  89 /  40  40  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    71  92  73  92 /  30  30  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     72  92  74  93 /  30  30  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  67  88  71  89 /  40  40  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     72  92  74  93 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         71  90  73  91 /  40  40  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      71  92  73  92 /  30  30  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   70  90  73  91 /  40  40  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$


582 
FXUS64 KLZK 071527
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1025 AM CDT WED JUL  7 2004

.DISCUSSION...
FRONT THAT WAS LYING ACROSS NORTHERN ARKANSAS THIS MORNING HAS MADE 
SOME SOUTHWARD PROGRESS AND NOW EXTENDS FROM KJBR TO KBVX TO JUST 
SOUTH OF KFYV. NOT EXPECTING THIS FEATURE TO MAKE MUCH MORE OF A 
SOUTHERN PUSH BEFORE STARTING TO RETREAT BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM 
FRONT. FRONT WILL STILL ACT AS A FOCUS POINT FOR AFTERNOON 
CONVECTION.

MCS STILL CONTINUING OVER EASTERN OKLAHOMA AND SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS. 
CLOUD TOPS HAVE BEEN WARMING AND COMPLEX DECREASING IN SIZE AND 
INTENSITY BUT WILL STILL NEED TO UPDATE TO REFLECT CURRENT 
TRENDS...ESPECIALLY OVER THE SOUTH. OTHERWISE SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS ARE FORMING IN THE WARM AND UNSTABLE AIR TO THE SOUTH 
OF THE FRONT AND ALONG OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES FROM THE AFOREMENTIONED 
MCS. WILL NEED TO BOOST POPS ACROSS THE BOARD AS SCATTERED DIURNAL 
CONVECTION SEEMS LIKE A PRETTY GOOD BET...ESPECIALLY WITH ANY BREAKS 
IN THE CLOUD COVER. 

TEMPERATURES LOOK REASONABLE AND WILL BE LEFT ALONE BUT WILL 
CONTINUE TO MONITOR AND MAY NEED TO LOWER THEM LATER IF AIRMASS CAN 
NOT RECOVER FROM PRECIPITATION AND CLOUDS DO NOT BREAK UP.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$



427 
FXUS64 KLZK 070833
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
330 AM CDT WED JUL 7 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY
FRONT IN RIGHT ALONG MISSOURI/ARKANSAS BORDER AND INTO CENTRAL 
OKLAHOMA...WITH LOWER DEWPOINTS AND LIGHT NORTH WINDS NORTH OF THE 
FRONT. SOUPY AIR SOUTH OF THE FRONT...WITH DEWPOINTS ACROSS MUCH OF 
ARKANSAS IN THE UPPER 60S TO THE MID 70S. THUNDERSTORMS ALREADY 
UNDER WAY ALONG THE FRONT IN CENTRAL OKLAHOMA.

FRONT WILL NOT MAKE MUCH MORE OF A PUSH INTO ARKANSAS AS UPPER 
TROUGH AXIS HAS MOVED EAST OF THE AREA. HOWEVER...WITH THE WARM 
UNSTABLE AIR ACROSS THE STATE...THE FRONT WILL HELP INITIATE 
SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TODAY.

THE FRONT WILL BECOME NEARLY STATIONARY THIS AFTERNOON INTO EARLY 
EVENING...AND THEN BEGIN TO MOVE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT THURSDAY. 
MODELS INDICATING ANOTHER MCS WILL DEVELOP IN THE PLAINS TONIGHT 
...AND MOVE SOUTHEAST TO NEAR THE ARKANSAS MISSOURI BORDER. WHILE 
MOST OF THE STRONGER STORMS WILL BE TO THE NORTHWEST OF 
ARKANSAS...COULD SEE A LARGE HAIL/STRONG WIND EVENT ACROSS THE 
NORTH. RIGHT NOW...BELIEVE THAT THIS WILL BE MORE OF A HEAVY RAIN 
EVENT...DUE TO THE LARGE AMOUNTS OF MOISTURE. HAVE RAISED AVERAGE 
QPF AMOUNTS FOR TONIGHT/THURSDAY MORNING. COULD SEE SOME ISOLATED 
AMOUNTS OF UP TO 2 INCHES IN THE NORTH IF THE MCS TRACKS FAR ENOUGH 
TO THE SOUTH.

SOUTHERLY FLOW WILL KEEP MOISTURE ACROSS THE STATE FOR THE END OF 
THE WEEK. IN THE TYPICAL SUMMERTIME PATTERN...DIURNAL CONVECTION 
WILL KEEP SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN THE FORECAST FOR THE 
AFTERNOON AND EVENINGS THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY.

TEMPERATURES WILL SIMILAR TO TUESDAY...WITH MOST LOCATIONS SLIGHTLY 
BELOW NORMAL. AS RIDGE GETS ESTABLISHED OVER AREA...TEMPERATURES 
WILL CLIMB INTO THE LOWER TO MID 90S IN MOST AREAS BY SATURDAY.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
UPPER RIDGE TAKES HOLD OVER THE AREA DURING THE PERIOD BUT THERE ARE 
INDICATIONS OF A WEAK SHORT WAVE IN THE AREA ESPECIALLY SATURDAY 
NIGHT INTO SUNDAY. WITH THIS IN MIND AND THE LIKELIHOOD MOISTURE 
WILL STILL BE PLENTIFUL FROM THE RECENT RAINY WEATHER...WENT WITH 
ISOLATED AFTERNOON SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS EACH DAY. TEMPS SHOULD 
BE AROUND NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    87  72  90  73 /  30  30  30  20 
HARRISON AR       85  68  87  69 /  20  30  30  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    87  72  91  72 /  30  30  30  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     87  73  91  73 /  30  30  30  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  85  68  87  70 /  20  30  30  20 
MONTICELLO AR     88  73  91  73 /  40  30  30  20 
SEARCY AR         87  72  89  72 /  30  30  30  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      87  72  91  72 /  30  30  30  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   87  71  89  72 /  30  30  30  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

.DISCUSSION...
KLZK RADAR INDICATES A FEW THUNDERSTORMS CONTINUING IN SOUTHEAST 
PART OF CWFA. UPDATED FORECASTS TO DECREASE POPS OVERNIGHT. ALSO PUT 
THE HIGHEST POPS IN THE SOUTH...SINCE THE APPROACHING COLD FRONT 
WILL BE INTO NORTH ARKANSAS SOON. EXPECT PARTLY CLOUDY CONDITIONS 
ACROSS THE AREA...AT LEAST UNTIL ANY THUNDERSTORMS DEVELOP. THE 
FRONT IN SOUTHERN MISSOURI WILL CONTINUE MOVING SOUTHEAST OVERNIGHT. 
THE BEST CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE ALONG AND 
AHEAD OF THE FRONT.



368 
FXUS64 KLZK 061918
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
220 PM CDT TUE JUL 6 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT
CURRENT CONVECTION WILL CONTINUE TO TREK EAST ACROSS ARKANSAS 
TONIGHT...PUSHED ALONG BY A SHORT WAVE. THERE WILL BE ENOUGH 
MOISTURE LEFT AROUND FOR THE NEXT SHORT WAVE TO MOVE ACROSS SOUTH 
MISSOURI AND NORTHERN ARKANSAS TONIGHT INTO MID DAY WEDNESDAY. THERE 
WILL BE A BRIEF LULL IN THE CONVECTION WEDNESDAY NIGHT...WITH MORE 
OF IT RETURNING FOR THURSDAY. THE GFS SEEMS TO HAVE CONVECTIVE 
FEEDBACK SHOWING UP FOR THURSDAY AFTERNOON INTO FRIDAY AFTERNOON. 
DID NOT FEEL CONFIDENT TO KEEP POPS AS HIGH AS THE GFS MOS SUGGESTED 
BUT KEPT SOME NONETHELESS ON ACCOUNT OF SLUG OF MOISTURE RETURNING 
NORTH AROUND BACK SIDE OF SURFACE RIDGE. AT THE SURFACE...A WEAK 
FRONT WILL BEGIN MOVING INTO THE STATE FROM THE NORTHWEST OVERNIGHT. 
THE FRONT WILL STALL IN THE CENTRAL SECTIONS WEDNESDAY. THIS FRONT 
WILL BE THE FOCUS OF MORE CONVECTION AIDED BY DAYTIME HEATING...SO 
KEPT POPS GOING THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT IN THE CHANCE CATEGORY. 
AFTER WEDNESDAY...WILL KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE POPS MAINLY FOR AFTERNOON 
AND EARLY EVENING CONVECTION. HIGH TEMPERATURES WILL BE SLIGHTLY 
BELOW MOS ON ACCOUNT OF CLOUDS AND PRECIPITATION. WENT ABOVE MOS 
LOWS SINCE WARM DEW POINTS WILL TEND TO KEEP LOWS UP DURING THE 
NIGHT.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
LOOKS LIKE RIDGE WILL BUILD ALOFT...WITH A TYPICAL SUMMERTIME 
PATTERN EXPECTED. ENOUGH MOISTURE FOR SOME WIDELY SCATTERED 
AFTERNOON AND EVENING THUNDER. TEMPERATURES WILL WARM UP...WITH 
LOWER/MID 90S DURING DAYTIME AND 70S AT NIGHT.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    72  87  71  88 /  40  40  40  20 
HARRISON AR       66  84  67  86 /  50  50  30  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    72  87  71  90 /  40  40  40  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     73  88  72  90 /  30  40  40  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  66  83  67  86 /  50  50  30  20 
MONTICELLO AR     73  89  72  91 /  30  40  40  30 
SEARCY AR         71  85  71  88 /  40  40  40  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      71  87  71  90 /  40  40  40  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   70  85  70  88 /  40  40  40  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

THE FRONT WILL STALL IN THE CENTRAL SECTIONS WEDNESDAY. THIS FRONT 
WILL BE THE FOCUS OF MORE CONVECTION AIDED BY DAYTIME HEATING...SO 
KEPT POPS GOING THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT IN THE CHANCE CATEGORY. 
AFTER WEDNESDAY...WILL KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE POPS MAINLY FOR AFTERNOON 
AND EARLY EVENING CONVECTION. HIGH TEMPERATURES WILL BE SLIGHTLY 
BELOW MOS ON ACCOUNT OF CLOUDS AND PRECIPITATION. WENT ABOVE MOS 
LOWS SINCE WARM DEW POINTS WILL TEND TO KEEP LOWS UP DURING THE 
NIGHT.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
LOOKS LIKE RIDGE WILL BUILD ALOFT...WITH A TYPICAL SUMMERTIME 
PATTERN EXPECTED. ENOUGH MOISTURE FOR SOME WIDELY SCATTERED 
AFTERNOON AND EVENING THUNDER. TEMPERATURES WILL WARM UP...WITH 
LOWER/MID 90S DURING DAYTIME AND 70S AT NIGHT.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    72  87  71  88 /  40  40  40  20 
HARRISON AR       66  84  67  86 /  50  50  30  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    72  87  71  90 /  40  40  40  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     73  88  72  90 /  30  40  40  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  66  83  67  86 /  50  50  30  20 
MONTICELLO AR     73  89  72  91 /  30  40  40  30 
SEARCY AR         71  85  71  88 /  40  40  40  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      71  87  71  90 /  40  40  40  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   70  85  70  88 /  40  40  40  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

32/46





170 
FXUS64 KLZK 060837
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
335 AM CDT TUE JUL 6 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY
MCS IN KANSAS AND NORTHERN OKLAHOMA THIS MORNING...WITH COLD FRONT 
OVER NORTHERN MISSOURI. MCS WILL CONTINUE TO MOVE SOUTHEAST 
...REACHING ARKANSAS BY MID TO LATE MORNING. LOOKS LIKE STRONG TO 
SEVERE DAMAGING WINDS WILL BE THE MAIN STORY AS IT MOVES SOUTHEAST. 
COULD SEE SOME BRIEF HEAVY RAIN AS WELL...BUT WITH FAST MOVEMENT NOT 
AS CONCERNED ABOUT FLOODING.

COLD FRONT CURRENTLY IN NORTHERN MISSOURI. THIS WILL MOVE SOUTH 
TODAY AS THE UPPER TROUGH MOVES EAST TOWARDS THE GREAT LAKES. 
OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES FROM THE MCS THIS MORNING WILL AID IN DEVELOPMENT 
OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS...ALONG WITH THE COLD FRONT. MAIN 
CONCERN IS HOW FAR SOUTH THE FRONT MAKES IT. CURRENT THINKING IS 
THAT THE FRONT WILL MEANDER AROUND NORTHERN AND CENTRAL ARKANSAS 
TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY. THERE IS A POTENTIAL FOR HEAVY RAIN IN 
WESTERN AND NORTHERN ARKANSAS TONIGHT/EARLY WEDNESDAY...AS MODELS 
HINTING AT ANOTHER MCS DEVELOPING. FOR NOW...HAVE GONE WITH UP TO AN 
INCH...BUT COULD SEE UP TO TWO INCHES. WILL HOLD OFF ON A FLOOD 
WATCH FOR NOW...AS WILL WAIT TO SEE WHERE BOUNDARIES END UP TODAY.

DECREASED POPS DURING THE DAY WEDNESDAY...BUT ENOUGH MOISTURE AROUND 
TO KEEP IN SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. MOISTURE STAYS IN 
THE MID SOUTH THROUGH FRIDAY...AS RETURN FLOW AROUND BERMUDA HIGH 
DEVELOPS. CONTINUED ISOLATED DIURNAL CONVECTION FOR THIS TIME FRAME. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
NO SIGNIFICANT CHANGES MADE TO EXTENDED...MAINLY TWEAKS TO COORDINATE
ELEMENTS WITH SURROUNDING OFFICES. WEAK UPPER TROF IN THE AREA OVER
THE WEEKEND AND WEAK RIDGING AFTER THAT BUT MOISTURE LOOKS LIKE IT
WILL BE ENOUGH TO MAINTAIN SMALL POPS THROUGH THE PERIOD. THERE ARE
INDICATIONS A FRONT MAY MOVE THROUGH MONDAY BUT UPPER FLOW PATTERN 
A LITTLE IFFY TO SUPPORT IT. LEFT WIND FORECASTS FOR THEN THE SAME 
WHICH IMPLIES FRONTAL PASSAGE. TEMPS GENERALLY CLOSE TO NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    91  71  88  71 /  40  40  30  30 
HARRISON AR       85  65  85  67 /  50  50  30  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    91  71  88  71 /  30  40  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     91  72  89  72 /  30  30  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  85  65  84  67 /  50  50  30  20 
MONTICELLO AR     92  72  90  72 /  30  30  30  30 
SEARCY AR         89  70  86  70 /  40  40  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      90  70  88  71 /  40  40  30  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   88  69  86  70 /  40  40  30  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

929 PM CDT MON JUL 5 2004

.DISCUSSION...
WILL SEND AN UPDATE TO THE FORECASTS TO FOCUS ON THE OVERNIGHT TIME 
FRAME. A FEW SHOWERS WERE CLOSE TO MAKING THEIR WAY INTO BRADLEY 
COUNTY THIS EVENING...BUT DISSIPATED BEFORE THEY REACHED THE COUNTY 
LINE. PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES CAN BE EXPECTED ACROSS THE AREA OVERNIGHT. 
CURRENT OBSERVATIONS SUGGEST REST OF FORECAST IS ON TRACK.

51






556 
FXUS64 KLZK 051919
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
205 PM CDT MON JUL  5 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT
THE MOST SIGNIFICANT SHOTS OF ENERGY WILL CONTINUE MOVING ACROSS THE 
COUNTRY NORTH OF ARKANSAS...WITH ONLY MINOR SHORT WAVES AFFECTING 
OUR STATE. WEAK FEATURES ALOFT WILL CONTINUE PUSHING A FRONT SLOWLY 
TO THE SOUTHEAST ON TUESDAY. THE FRONT WILL LOSE ITS OOMPH TUESDAY 
NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY MORNING. LIGHT SOUTHEASTERLY WINDS WILL COME 
AROUND THE BACK SIDE OF SURFACE HIGH TO OUR EAST THROUGH FRIDAY 
NIGHT. THIS WILL TEND TO KEEP MOISTURE AVAILABLE FOR DIURNAL 
CONVECTION AFTER THE FRONT STALLS WEDNESDAY. LOWS WILL CONTINUE TO 
BE WARMER THAN MOS NUMBERS ON ACCOUNT OF THE HIGHER DEWPOINTS WE 
HAVE BEEN HAVING. HIGHS WILL KEEP IN THE NEAR 90 TO LOWER 90S RANGE 
AS HEATING WILL CREATE CUMULUS FIELDS EACH AFTERNOON...TENDING TO 
HOLD DOWN THE AFTERNOON MAXES ALONG WITH THE SCATTERED OR WIDELY 
SCATTERED CONVECTION.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY MORNING THROUGH MONDAY...
MEDIUM RANGE MODELS ALL IN GOOD AGREEMENT THIS AFTERNOON WITH THE 
OVERALL SYNOPTIC PATTERN AND A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS WILL BE USED.
MODELS CONTINUE THEIR TREND OF RETURNING TO A MORE SUMMER LIKE 
PATTERN FOR THE MID SOUTH. NORTHERN BRANCH OF THE WESTERLYS REMAINS 
ACROSS THE NORTHERN TIER STATES THROUGHOUT THE PERIOD AS THE BERMUDA 
HIGH BUILDS WESTWARD FROM THE SOUTHEAST CONUS. STRONG UPPER LEVEL 
RIDGING DEVELOPS IN RESPONSE WITH ABUNDANT TROPICAL MOISTURE TRAPPED 
UNDERNEATH IT. WITH NO SHORTWAVES OF SIGNIFICANCE SEEN AND MID LEVEL 
TEMPERATURES ON THE WARM SIDE...ANY PRECIPITATION WOULD HAVE TO BE 
DIURNAL IN NATURE. SLIGHT CHANCE POPS ARE JUSTIFIED WITH 
TEMPERATURES VERY CLOSE TO SEASONAL NORMS. MEX NUMBERS SUPPORT THIS 
AND ARE GENERALLY ACCEPTED.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    73  91  71  88 /  10  20  30  30 
HARRISON AR       70  86  65  84 /  10  30  30  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    73  91  71  88 /  10  20  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     73  91  72  88 /  10  20  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  70  86  65  84 /  10  30  30  30 
MONTICELLO AR     74  92  72  89 /  10  20  20  30 
SEARCY AR         72  90  70  86 /  10  20  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      73  90  70  88 /  10  20  30  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   72  89  69  86 /  10  30  30  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

32/56





419 
FXUS64 KLZK 051515 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1000 AM CDT MON JUL 5 2004

UPDATE IS OUT ALREADY TO TAKE CARE OF THE HOUSEKEEPING WITH THE 
WATCHES. ALSO...REMOVED THE SMALL POPS ACROSS THE NORTH IN LIGHT OF
LITTLE RADAR ACTIVITY OVER THAT PART OF THE STATE. 

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY
UPPER RIDGE HAS BUILT INTO THE AREA TEMPORARILY WHICH HAS BROUGHT 
WARM AIR ALOFT AND A CAP. THIS SHOULD INHIBIT CONVECTIVE DEVELOPMENT 
OVER THE AREA TODAY BUT THERE IS STILL CONCERN ABOUT EFFECTS OF 
THUNDERSTORMS IN SOUTHERN KANSAS AND NORTHERN OKLAHOMA THIS MORNING. 
THE UPPER FLOW SHOULD KEEP THIS TO THE NORTH OF THE AREA BUT WILL 
KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THE NORTH THIS MORNING JUST IN CASE. WILL 
LEAVE THE REST OF THE AREA DRY TODAY FOR NOW. SOUTHWEST SURFACE FLOW 
SHOULD ALLOW MOST OF THE AREA TO WARM INTO THE 90S BUT MAY STAY A 
LITTLE BELOW GUIDANCE DUE TO WET SOIL FROM RECENT RAINS. THE HIGH 
HUMIDITY LEFT OVER WILL BRING HEAT INDEX VALUES CLOSE TO 105 IN 
PARTS OF THE CENTRAL AND SOUTH AGAIN THIS AFTERNOON AND WILL MENTION 
THAT IN THOSE ZONES. WILL KEEP THINGS DRY TONIGHT BUT TROFFING ALOFT 
DEVELOPS TO THE WEST BY TUESDAY MORNING AND A SHORT WAVE WILL 
APPROACH. THIS COULD GENERATE SOME SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO THE 
WEST MONDAY NIGHT WHICH COULD REACH THE CWA EARLY TUESDAY...SO HAVE 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS STARTING IN THE MORNING THEN INCREASED POPS IN 
THE NORTH DURING THE AFTERNOON AS A COLD FRONT SHOULD BE NEARING 
THAT AREA. KEPT CHANCE POPS GOING TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY AS THE 
UPPER FLOW LOOKS LIKE IT WILL BUCKLE ENOUGH TO ALLOW THE FRONT TO 
MOVE INTO THE AREA. THE FRONT MAY RETREAT NORTH BY THURSDAY AS THE 
SURFACE HIGH SHIFTS OFF TO THE EAST AND UPPER RIDGING BEGINS TO 
BUILD BACK IN. MOISTURE REMAINS IN THE AREA SO WENT WITH CHANCE POPS 
FOR THURSDAY AFTERNOON. MAXES WILL BE LOWER TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY 
DUE TO INCREASED CLOUDS AND THE PRESENCE OF THE FRONT. WARMER MINS 
MOSTLY IN THE LOWER 70S SHOULD CONTINUE AS DEW POINTS REMAIN HIGH.   
 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
BERMUDA HIGH SETS UP IN THE EXTENDED...WHICH WILL BRING A TYPICAL 
SUMMERTIME PATTERN TO ARKANSAS. MOISTURE WILL BE ABUNDANT...WITH 
DIURNAL CONVECTION EXPECTED. TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN NEAR NORMAL 
READINGS...WITH HIGHS IN THE UPPER 80S TO MID 90S.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    93  74  91  71 /  10  10  20  30 
HARRISON AR       90  71  86  65 /  20  10  30  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    93  74  91  71 /  10  10  20  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     93  75  92  72 /  10  10  20  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  90  71  86  65 /  20  10  30  30 
MONTICELLO AR     94  75  92  72 /  10  10  20  30 
SEARCY AR         92  73  90  70 /  10  10  20  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      93  74  90  70 /  10  10  20  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   93  73  89  69 /  10  10  20  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$
