AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT MON JUL 5 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY
UPPER RIDGE HAS BUILT INTO THE AREA TEMPORARILY WHICH HAS BROUGHT WARM
AIR ALOFT AND A CAP. THIS SHOULD INHIBIT CONVECTIVE DEVELOPMENT OVER
THE AREA TODAY BUT THERE IS STILL CONCERN ABOUT EFFECTS OF 
THUNDERSTORMS IN SOUTHERN KANSAS AND NORTHERN OKLAHOMA THIS MORNING.
THE UPPER FLOW SHOULD KEEP THIS TO THE NORTH OF THE AREA BUT WILL KEEP
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THE NORTH THIS MORNING JUST IN CASE. WILL LEAVE
THE REST OF THE AREA DRY TODAY FOR NOW. SOUTHWEST SURFACE FLOW SHOULD
ALLOW MOST OF THE AREA TO WARM INTO THE 90S BUT MAY STAY A LITTLE
BELOW GUIDANCE DUE TO WET SOIL FROM RECENT RAINS. THE HIGH HUMIDITY 
LEFT OVER WILL BRING HEAT INDEX VALUES CLOSE TO 105 IN PARTS OF THE
CENTRAL AND SOUTH AGAIN THIS AFTERNOON AND WILL MENTION THAT IN THOSE
ZONES. WILL KEEP THINGS DRY TONIGHT BUT TROFFING ALOFT DEVELOPS TO
THE WEST BY TUESDAY MORNING AND A SHORT WAVE WILL APPROACH. THIS COULD
GENERATE SOME SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO THE WEST MONDAY NIGHT 
WHICH COULD REACH THE CWA EARLY TUESDAY...SO HAVE SLIGHT CHANCE POPS
STARTING IN THE MORNING THEN INCREASED POPS IN THE NORTH DURING THE
AFTERNOON AS A COLD FRONT SHOULD BE NEARING THAT AREA. KEPT CHANCE
POPS GOING TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY AS THE UPPER FLOW LOOKS LIKE 
IT WILL BUCKLE ENOUGH TO ALLOW THE FRONT TO MOVE INTO THE AREA. THE
FRONT MAY RETREAT NORTH BY THURSDAY AS THE SURFACE HIGH SHIFTS OFF 
TO THE EAST AND UPPER RIDGING BEGINS TO BUILD BACK IN. MOISTURE
REMAINS IN THE AREA SO WENT WITH CHANCE POPS FOR THURSDAY AFTERNOON. 
MAXES WILL BE LOWER TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY DUE TO INCREASED CLOUDS
AND THE PRESENCE OF THE FRONT. WARMER MINS MOSTLY IN THE LOWER 70S
SHOULD CONTINUE AS DEW POINTS REMAIN HIGH.   
 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
BERMUDA HIGH SETS UP IN THE EXTENDED...WHICH WILL BRING A TYPICAL 
SUMMERTIME PATTERN TO ARKANSAS. MOISTURE WILL BE ABUNDANT...WITH 
DIURNAL CONVECTION EXPECTED. TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN NEAR NORMAL 
READINGS...WITH HIGHS IN THE UPPER 80S TO MID 90S.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    93  74  91  71 /  10  10  20  30 
HARRISON AR       90  71  86  65 /  20  10  30  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    93  74  91  71 /  10  10  20  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     93  75  92  72 /  10  10  20  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  90  71  86  65 /  20  10  30  30 
MONTICELLO AR     94  75  92  72 /  10  10  20  30 
SEARCY AR         92  73  90  70 /  10  10  20  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      93  74  90  70 /  10  10  20  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   93  73  89  69 /  10  10  20  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

29/58






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 050755
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT MON JUL 5 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY
UPPER RIDGE HAS BUILT INTO THE AREA TEMPORARILY WHICH HAS BROUGHT WARM
AIR ALOFT AND A CAP. THIS SHOULD INHIBIT CONVECTIVE DEVELOPMENT OVER
THE AREA TODAY BUT THERE IS STILL CONCERN ABOUT EFFECTS OF 
THUNDERSTORMS IN SOUTHERN KANSAS AND NORTHERN OKLAHOMA THIS MORNING.
THE UPPER FLOW SHOULD KEEP THIS TO THE NORTH OF THE AREA BUT WILL KEEP
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THE NORTH THIS MORNING JUST IN CASE. WILL LEAVE
THE REST OF THE AREA DRY TODAY FOR NOW. SOUTHWEST SURFACE FLOW SHOULD
ALLOW MOST OF THE AREA TO WARM INTO THE 90S BUT MAY STAY A LITTLE
BELOW GUIDANCE DUE TO WET SOIL FROM RECENT RAINS. THE HIGH HUMIDITY 
LEFT OVER WILL BRING HEAT INDEX VALUES CLOSE TO 105 IN PARTS OF THE
CENTRAL AND SOUTH AGAIN THIS AFTERNOON AND WILL MENTION THAT IN THOSE
ZONES. WILL KEEP THINGS DRY TONIGHT BUT TROFFING ALOFT DEVELOPS TO
THE WEST BY TUESDAY MORNING AND A SHORT WAVE WILL APPROACH. THIS COULD
GENERATE SOME SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO THE WEST MONDAY NIGHT 
WHICH COULD REACH THE CWA EARLY TUESDAY...SO HAVE SLIGHT CHANCE POPS
STARTING IN THE MORNING THEN INCREASED POPS IN THE NORTH DURING THE
AFTERNOON AS A COLD FRONT SHOULD BE NEARING THAT AREA. KEPT CHANCE
POPS GOING TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY AS THE UPPER FLOW LOOKS LIKE 
IT WILL BUCKLE ENOUGH TO ALLOW THE FRONT TO MOVE INTO THE AREA. THE
FRONT MAY RETREAT NORTH BY THURSDAY AS THE SURFACE HIGH SHIFTS OFF 
TO THE EAST AND UPPER RIDGING BEGINS TO BUILD BACK IN. MOISTURE
REMAINS IN THE AREA SO WENT WITH CHANCE POPS FOR THURSDAY AFTERNOON. 
MAXES WILL BE LOWER TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY DUE TO INCREASED CLOUDS
AND THE PRESENCE OF THE FRONT. WARMER MINS MOSTLY IN THE LOWER 70S
SHOULD CONTINUE AS DEW POINTS REMAIN HIGH.   
 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
BERMUDA HIGH SETS UP IN THE EXTENDED...WHICH WILL BRING A TYPICAL 
SUMMERTIME PATTERN TO ARKANSAS. MOISTURE WILL BE ABUNDANT...WITH 
DIURNAL CONVECTION EXPECTED. TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN NEAR NORMAL 
READINGS...WITH HIGHS IN THE UPPER 80S TO MID 90S.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    93  74  91  71 /  10  10  20  30 
HARRISON AR       90  71  86  65 /  20  10  30  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    93  74  91  71 /  10  10  20  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     93  75  92  72 /  10  10  20  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  90  71  86  65 /  20  10  30  30 
MONTICELLO AR     94  75  92  72 /  10  10  20  30 
SEARCY AR         92  73  90  70 /  10  10  20  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      93  74  90  70 /  10  10  20  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   93  73  89  69 /  10  10  20  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

921 PM CDT SUN JUL  4 2004

.DISCUSSION...
PREVIOUS FORECAST ON TRACK. HAVE UPDATED GRIDS TO TWEAK OVERNIGHT 
WINDS A LITTLE...AND HAVE UPDATED TEXT PRODUCTS TO CLEAN UP WORDING 
FOR OVERNIGHT. MCS IN THE CENTRAL PLAINS THIS EVENING WILL LIKELY 
AFFECT THE STATE BY MONDAY MORNING. MAY END FOLLOWING CLOSELY THE 
TRACK OF MCS THAT PASSED THROUGH NORTHERN ARKANSAS ON INDEPENDENCE 
DAY.

238 PM CDT SUN JUL  4 2004

.DISCUSSION...
AN MCS WHICH MOVED ACROSS MOST OF ARKANSAS EARLIER TODAY HAS LEFT 
BEHIND BOUNDARIES WHERE REDEVELOPMENT CAN BE EXPECTED. NEAR NORMAL 
TEMPERATURES WILL PREVAIL THROUGHOUT THE SHORT AND LONG TERM 
PERIODS. A COLD FRONT TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY WILL BRING ABOUT 
AN INCREASE IN POPS.

1245 PM CDT SUN JUL 4 2004

.DISCUSSION...
MCS THAT TRACKED ACRS NRN HALF OF AR THIS MRNG IS NOW PUSHING E OF 
THE STATE. HAVE SEEN A NUMBER OF TREES AND POWER LINES DOWN ASSOCD 
WITH THE SYS. OUTFLOW BNDRY EVIDENT S OF LIT RIGHT NOW. SEEING SOME 
SCTD CONVECTION DVLPG OVER SERN AR IN MORE UNSTABLE AIRMASS. HAVE 
REWORKED GRIDS TO ACCOUNT FOR CURRENT PRECIP AND TEMP TRENDS. 
CLEARED REMAINDER OF SVR TSTM WATCH 547. UPDATES ALREADY OUT.

44





088 
FXUS64 KLZK 041151
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
650 AM CDT SUN JUL 4 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LOOKS LIKE MCS IS HOLDING TOGETHER AS IT APPROACHES THE CWA. DUE TO
THE INCREASED CONFIDENCE IT WILL MAKE IT IN...INCREASED POPS TO 40
PERCENT IN THE NORTH FOR MID TO LATE MORNING. CONFIDENCE DECREASES 
AFTER THAT SO PUT IN 30 POPS IN NORTHERN THIRD AT NOON WITH 20
PERCENT ELSEWHERE THEN GRADUALLY WENT TO BROAD BRUSH 20 PERCENT 
FROM MID AFTERNOON ON. INCREASED CLOUD COVER A LITTLE AS WELL. 
DID NOT CHANGE TEMP FORECASTS ALTHOUGH IT IS LOOKING MORE LIKELY
TEMPS WILL BE IMPACTED AT LEAST IN THE NORTHWEST. 

.PREV DISCUSSION...
.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
SUMMER TO RETURN TO THE AREA TODAY FOR THE MOST PART. MAIN FLY IN
THE OINTMENT WILL BE WHAT EFFECTS THE ONGOING MCS IN KANSAS MAY HAVE
ON THE AREA LATER TODAY. MODELS HAVE DIFFERENT SOLUTIONS AND NONE SEEM
TO HAVE A GOOD HANDLE ON IT. WENT WITH COMPROMISE OF POSSIBILITIES.
STARTED SLIGHT CHANCE POPS IN THE NORTH AT MID MORNING AND SLOWLY
EXPANDED THEM ACROSS NORTHERN SECTIONS. WAS NOT GOING TO FORECAST
A CHANCE OF RAIN IN THE SOUTHERN HALF...BUT DUE TO POSSIBILITY OF
OUTFLOW FROM MCS MOVING INTO THOSE AREAS...DECIDED TO PUT IN SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS FOR MID TO LATE AFTERNOON. UPPER RIDGING IN THE AREA 
MAY SERVE TO CAP THE SOUTH BUT WITH IT BEING A HOLIDAY DECIDED TO 
KEEP A MENTION IN JUST IN CASE. LEFT SMALL POPS IN THE NORTHERN THIRD
OR SO THROUGH TONIGHT IN THE EVENT ANOTHER MCS GETS GOING IN THE PLAINS
AND MANAGES TO MAKE IT IN THE AREA. CONFIDENCE IS NOT HIGH FOR THIS
SO ONLY WENT 20 PERCENT. THIS POSSIBILITY ALSO LED TO HAVING SLIGHT
CHANCE POPS IN ALL AREAS FOR MONDAY. MORE POTENTIAL MCS DEVELOPMENT
IN PLAINS TRANSLATING INTO THE AREA LED TO CONTINUED SMALL POPS 
THROUGH TUESDAY. A COLD FRONT WILL APPROACH THE AREA TUESDAY NIGHT 
AND THE UPPER FLOW LOOKS LIKE IT WILL BUCKLE ENOUGH TO ALLOW IT TO
MOVE INTO THE AREA SO KEPT 30 PERCENT POPS GOING FOR THAT TIME 
FRAME. MAX TEMPS TODAY WOULD BE ADVERSELY AFFECTED IF THE KANSAS 
MCS WERE TO MOVE INTO THE AREA STILL GOING STRONG...BUT THAT DOES
NOT LOOK LIKELY AT THIS TIME. THUS FIGURE ON MOST AREAS SEEING GOOD
HEATING AND WITH SOUTHWEST SURFACE FLOW...MAXES INTO THE LOWER 90S
IN MOST AREAS LOOKS GOOD WITH THE OZARKS ABOUT A CATEGORY COOLER. 
FOLLOWED THE SAME PATTERN FOR MONDAY AND TUESDAY. MINS SHOULD STAY 
IN THE LOWER TO MID 70S WITH VERY HUMID AIR IN PLACE FROM THE RECENT 
RAINY WEATHER. AFTERNOON HEAT INDEX TODAY WILL BE 100 TO 105 IN MOST
OF CENTRAL AND SOUTH AND WILL HIGHLIGHT THAT IN ZONES.  
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
ZONAL FLOW JUST TO THE NORTH OF THE STATE WILL KEEP THE STORM TRACK 
TO THE NORTH...AS HIGH PRESSURE MOVES INTO THE MID SOUTH. HOWEVER... 
PLENTY OF MOISTURE AROUND...AND TYPICAL SUMMERTIME DIURNAL 
CONVECTION IS WORTHY OF SLIGHT CHANCE POPS THROUGH MOST OF THE 
EXTENDED. TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN NEAR NORMAL READINGS...WITH HIGHS 
IN THE UPPER 80S TO MID 90S. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    93  75  93  74 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       89  71  90  70 /  20  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    94  75  93  74 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     94  75  93  75 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  89  71  90  70 /  20  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     94  75  94  75 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         92  74  92  73 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      94  75  93  74 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   93  73  93  73 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

EXTENDED. TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN NEAR NORMAL READINGS...WITH HIGHS 
IN THE UPPER 80S TO MID 90S. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    93  75  93  74 /  20  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       89  71  90  70 /  20  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    94  75  93  74 /  20  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     94  75  93  75 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  89  71  90  70 /  20  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     94  75  94  75 /  20  20  20  20 
SEARCY AR         92  74  92  73 /  20  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      94  75  93  74 /  20  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   93  73  93  73 /  20  20  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
225 PM CDT SAT JUL  3 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY 
THE UPPER LEVEL TROUGH WHICH BROUGHT A WET SPELL THESE LAST THREE 
DAYS IS FINALLY MOVING OUT OF THE AREA AND WITH IT WILL GO MOST OF 
THE MOISTURE. WILL KEEP SMALL PROBABILITIES OF PRECIPITION MAINLY 
DUE TO WEAK SURFACE FEATURES AND WEAK INSTABILITY BUT OVERALL WILL 
GO WITH A SOMEWHAT DRIER WEATHER PATTERN THE NEXT FEW DAYS. 
TEMPERATURES WILL LIKELY BE CLIMBING BACK TO A MORE NORMAL EARLY 
JULY PATTERN THROUGHOUT THE SHORT TERM PERIOD.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
WE FINALLY RETURN TO A MORE TYPICAL SUMMERTIME PATTERN THRU THE PD. 
MAIN STORM TRACK SHIFTS N OF AR WITH WEAK RDG SETTLE INTO THE 
REGION. A CDFNT IS PROGGED TO APCH NRN AR WED WITH A CHC OF 
CONVECTION. ABUNDANT LOW LVL RH AND A WEAKNESS IN THE UPPER RDG OVER 
THE MID SOUTH WILL PRODUCE MAINLY DIURNAL CONVECTION FOR THE REST OF 
THE PD. CURRENT FCST TEMPS LOOK GOOD WITH READINGS NEAR NORMAL.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    72  93  74  92 /  20  20  20  20

.DISCUSSION...
HAVE ALLOWED FF WATCH TO EXPIRE ON TIME AT 8 AM THIS MRNG. REMNANTS 
OF MCS NOW AFFECTING MAINLY THE SRN HALF OF AR ATTM. OVERALL 
INTENSITY OF PRECIP HAS CONTD TO DECREASE THE LAST HOUR OR TWO. 
REWORKED PRECIP GRIDS BASED ON LATEST TRENDS. KEPT LIKELY POPS OVER 
SRN AR FOR THIS MRNG AND LOWERED POPS ELSEWHERE. STILL COULD SEE 
SOME CONVECTION REFIRE THIS AFTN ALONG RESIDUAL BNDRYS. FOR THAT 
REASON...LEFT CHC POPS GOING FOR THE FA PER GOING FCST. NO CHGS MADE 
TO HIGH TEMPS THIS AFTN...BUT THAT WILL BE LOOKED AT AGAIN LATER 
THIS MRNG AS NEW MODEL DATA ARRIVES. UPDATED GRIDS AND ZONES ALREADY 
OUT.

879 
FXUS64 KLZK 030851
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT SAT JUL 3 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY
UPPER LOW MOVING ACROSS NORTHERN MISSOURI THIS MORNING WITH MCS IN
THE NORTHWESTERN PART OF THE CWA AT ISSUANCE TIME. THE MCS WILL LIKELY
SPREAD SOUTHEAST DURING THE MORNING. STORMS HAVE SHOWN A WEAKENING 
TREND WHICH SHOULD CONTINUE THIS MORNING. BUT LOOK FOR NEW DEVELOPMENT
OF THUNDERSTORMS ALONG OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES AROUND MIDDAY. ACTUAL 
LOCATION OF THIS STILL IN QUESTION AND IT MAY END UP BEING SOUTH
OF THE CWA. APPEARS NOW THAT NORTHERN SECTIONS MAY HAVE STEADY LIGHT
RAIN FOR AWHILE THIS MORNING WITH THE HEAVIER RAINS MOVED OFF TO THE
SOUTH. AS A RESULT WILL LEAVE FLASH FLOOD WATCH AS IT IS FOR NORTHERN
SECTIONS...EXPIRING AT 8 AM. IF IT LOOKS LIKE HEAVY RAINS WILL 
CONTINUE IN SOME AREAS AFTER THAT...MAY EXTEND LATER THIS MORNING. 
THUNDERSTORMS THAT DEVELOP ON THE OUTFLOWS LATER TODAY WILL HAVE 
THE CHANCE OF BEING SEVERE BUT WILL NOT PLAY UP IN THE ZONES ESPECIALLY
SINCE THERE IS A CHANCE THAT COULD END UP HAPPENING OUTSIDE THE CWA. 
LOWERED POPS IN THE WEST THIS AFTERNOON AND BY THIS EVENING HAVE
20 PERCENT POPS ACROSS THE AREA WITH 30 PERCENT IN THE SOUTHEAST. 
WENT WITH DRY FORECAST LATER TONIGHT INTO EARLY SUNDAY. STUCK IN 
20 PERCENT FOR SUNDAY AFTERNOON IN THE EVENT SOME BOUNDARIES ARE
AROUND FOR THUNDERSTORMS TO DEVELOP IN THE HOT HUMID UNSTABLE AIR. 
BEYOND THAT...LEFT SMALL POPS IN JUST IN CASE SHORT WAVES IN 
NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT SHOULD COME CLOSE TO THE AREA OR MCS ACTIVITY
IN THE PLAINS MANAGES TO REACH INTO THE AREA. SURFACE PATTERN SETS 
UP WITH SOUTHWEST FLOW WHICH SHOULD BRING QUITE WARM CONDITIONS TO 
THE AREA. HOWEVER THE RECENT RAINS SHOULD KEEP DEW POINTS OPPRESSIVE
AND SHOULD HOLD MAXES IN CHECK. WENT CLOSER TO FWC NUMBERS.     
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
EXTENDED KEPT ABOUT THE SAME. FRONTAL SYSTEM WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA
ABOUT WEDNESDAY WITH AN ENHANCED CHANCE OF RAIN AT THAT TIME. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    87  72  92  73 /  60  20  20  20 
HARRISON AR       86  69  88  69 /  70  20  20  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    88  72  93  73 /  60  20  20  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     88  72  93  73 /  50  20  20  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  85  69  88  69 /  70  20  20  20 
MONTICELLO AR     89  73  93  74 /  50  30  20  20 
SEARCY AR         86  71  91  72 /  60  20  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      89  72  93  73 /  60  20  20  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   87  71  92  71 /  60  20  20  20 
&&

ARZ003>007...ARZ012>016...ARZ021>025...ARZ030>034...ARZ037>047.

000 
FXUS64 KLZK 021958
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
255 PM CDT FRI JUL 2 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT
REMNANTS OF MCS CONTS WORKING ACRS CNTRL AR ATTM. LOCALLY HEAVY 
RAINS CONTS TO AFFECT PARTS OF THE FA AS WELL. LOOKS LIKE BULK OF 
ACTIVITY SHOULD BE OVER ERN AR BY EARLY THIS EVENING AND WILL MAKE 
FINAL DECISION ON EVENING POPS JUST BEFORE ZONE ISSUANCE.

UPPER SYSTEM CENTERED OVER ERN KS THIS AFTN IS PROGGED TO SHIFT EWD 
OVER THE NEXT 24 HOURS. MEANWHILE...ANOTHER COMPLEX OF STORMS IS 
FCST FORM TO OUR NW LATER THIS EVENING AS MORE ENERGY ROTATES AROUND 
THE UPPER LOW. ACTIVITY IS PROGGED TO WORK SEWD LATE TONIGHT AND SAT 
MRNG...AFFECTING MUCH OF NRN AND CNTRL AR. HAVE STUCK WITH THE 
MESOETA SOLUTION FOR MUCH OF THE SHORT TERM.

AS FOR THE HEAVY RAIN POTENTIAL...APPEARS THAT NRN AND CNTRL 
SECTIONS WILL SEE THE GREATEST THREAT WITH THE NEXT COMPLEX LATER 
TNGT. THUS...PLAN TO EXTEND FF WATCH THRU TNGT FOR NRN AND CNTRL 
SECTIONS AND ALLOW WATCH FOR SRN AR TO EXPIRE AT 00Z.

UPPER SYSTEM MOVES FURTHER AWAY FROM THE FA LATER SAT AND SUN TO 
ALLOW FOR DECREASING POPS. MESOETA STILL SHOWING POSSIBLE REMNANTS 
OF ANOTHER MCS DROPPING SEWD INTO AR BY SUN MNRG. HAVE STUCK WITH 
GOING FCST AND KEPT SLGT CHC POPS TO CLOSE OUT THE WEEKEND.

MOS MIN TEMPS THRU THE PERIOD LOOK GOOD AND PRETTY MUCH FOLLOW 
PERSISTENCE. HAVE GONE BELOW MOS MAX TEMPS FOR SAT WITH EXPECTED 
CLOUD COVER AND RAIN CHCS. SWLY SFC FLOW ON SUN WL ALLOW FOR A 
WARMING TREND. MOS OUTPUT INDCG HIGHS IN THE LOW TO MID 90S FOR 
SUN. THESE READINGS SEEM A LITTLE TOO WARM WITH SOIL MOISTURE QUITE 
HIGH AND HAVE GONE ABOUT A CAT LOWER SUN AND MON. 
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY
A COLD FRONT WILL ENTER THE NORTHWESTERN SECTIONS OF ARKANSAS EARLY 
WEDNESDAY AND THEN MOVE SLOWLY TOWARDS THE SOUTHEAST. AND BY THURSDAY
MORNING THE COLD FRONT IS EXPECTED TO BE NEAR THE SOUTHERN ARKANSAS 
BORDER. THIS WILL BRING ABOUT SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
WEDNESDAY THROUGH EARLY THURSDAY. COOLER AND DRIER AIR WILL MOVE INTO
THE NORTHERN SECTIONS AFTER THE FRONTAL PASSAGE. BY FRIDAY THE FRONT 
WILL BE QUASI-STATIONARY ACROSS THE SOUTHERN ARKANSAS BORDER. THIS 
WILL LIKELY KEEP A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ACROSS 
MOST OF THE CWA. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
FLOOD WATCH UNTIL 700 PM CDT FRIDAY FOR ZONES ARZ052>057... 
ARZ062>069.

FLOOD WATCH UNTIL 800 AM CDT SATURDAY FOR ZONES ARZ003>007... 
ARZ012>016...ARZ021>025...ARZ030>034...ARZ037>047.
&&



442 
FXUS64 KLZK 020844
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT FRI JUL 2 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY
UPPER TROF MOVING ACROSS THE PLAINS WILL BE MAIN FACTOR FOR THE
WEATHER IN THE CWA OVER THE NEXT TWO DAYS. FEATURE TAKES ON A
NEGATIVE TILT AND SPREADS DIFFLUENCE ALOFT OVER THE AREA WITH
THE STRONGER DIFFLUENCE IN THE NORTH. WITH THE MAIN CENTER PASSING
FARTHER NORTH THAN THOUGHT EARLIER IN THE WEEK...THIS WOULD PUT
NORTHERN SECTIONS AT THE BETTER RISK FOR HEAVY RAINS AND FLASH
FLOODING. MCS IN NORTHERN OKLAHOMA WILL MOVE CLOSER TO THE AREA
AND WILL LIKELY LEAVE AN OUTFLOW BOUNDARY FOR NEW DEVELOPMENT
LATER TODAY. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FROM THE MCS MAY REACH 
NORTHWESTERN AREAS EARLY THIS MORNING...SO WILL GO WITH LIKELY
POPS ALL DAY IN THAT AREA. WILL START SOUTHERN SECTIONS WITH CHANCE 
POPS THEN INCREASE TO LIKELY BY LATE MORNING. THE BEST COVERAGE
SHOULD COME THIS AFTERNOON BOTH AS NEW DEVELOPMENT OCCURS ALONG
BOUNDARIES AND EFFECTS OF HEATING ALSO TAKE HOLD. LOOKS LIKE 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE LIKELY INTO TONIGHT AS THE TROF
AXIS STARTS TO MOVE THROUGH AND ACTIVITY WILL BE FEEDING ON 
A NUMBER OF BOUNDARIES...SO KEPT LIKELY POPS GOING. COULD END UP
HAVING AN MCS MOVING ACROSS AT LEAST PART OF THE AREA. LOOKS
LIKE BEST CHANCE OF FLASH FLOODS MAY BE IN NORTH LATE TODAY INTO 
TONIGHT. ALREADY HAVE FLOOD WATCH IN SOUTH FOR TODAY. WILL EXPAND
FLOOD WATCH FOR TODAY TO COVER ENTIRE CWA. DAY SHIFT CAN LOOK AT
NEW MODELS AND WATCH HOW THINGS UNFOLD AND ADJUST WATCH FOR LATER
TODAY AND POSSIBLE EXTENSIONS INTO TONIGHT. DECREASED POPS FROM THE
WEST LATE TONIGHT INTO SATURDAY AS THE TROF AXIS PASSES. CONTINUED
CHANCE POPS IN MOST AREAS THROUGH SATURDAY AS SOME OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES
MAY REMAIN AND DECREASING CLOUDS AND SOUTHWEST LOW LEVEL FLOW SHOULD
LEAD TO STRONG HEATING WHICH WILL RESULT IN SCATTERED THUNDERSTORMS
SATURDAY AFTERNOON. KEPT DRY FORECAST FOR MOST OF SATURDAY NIGHT BUT
STUCK IN SMALL POPS FOR THE NORTH SUNDAY MORNING IN THE EVENT THE
SHORT WAVE DEPICTED BY THE ETA MODEL MATERIALIZES. UNLESS THIS SHORT
WAVE CAUSES AN MCS TO COVER THE AREA SUNDAY MORNING...THERE SHOULD
BE GOOD HEATING SUNDAY WITH MOST AREAS SOUTH OF THE OZARKS REACHING
THE 90S. CONTINUED WITH SMALL POPS THROUGH MONDAY WITH WARM HUMID
UNSTABLE AIR REMAINING IN PLACE. NO SIGNIFICANT FRONTS OR SHORT
WAVES ARE INDICATED BUT SOME WEAK BOUNDARIES MAY STILL BE PRESENT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL ALLOW MOISTURE RETURN TO THE STATE...WITH 
DIURNAL SLIGHT CHANCE POPS MONDAY NIGHT AND TUESDAY. COLD FRONT 
APPROACHES TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY. NEW GFS RUN SLOWING FEATURE 
DOWN SOMEWHAT...BUT WILL HAVE TO SEE WHAT FUTURE RUNS DEPICT. HAVE 
INCLUDED LOW CHANCE POPS AS THE FRONT MOVES INTO THE STATE...AS 
MOISTURE WILL STILL BE PRESENT DUE TO RETURN FLOW. DUE TO THE 
UNCERTAINTY OF SOLUTIONS...CONTINUED DRY FORECAST FOR THURSDAY.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    85  72  88  72 /  60  60  50  20 
HARRISON AR       80  68  84  69 /  70  70  40  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    85  72  89  72 /  60  60  40  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     85  73  88  72 /  60  60  50  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  80  68  84  69 /  70  70  40  20 
MONTICELLO AR     86  73  89  73 /  60  60  50  20 
SEARCY AR         84  71  87  71 /  70  70  50  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      84  72  89  72 /  60  60  40  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   83  71  88  71 /  70  70  40  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...FLOOD WATCH TODAY FOR ZONES 
ARZ003>007...ARZ012>016...ARZ021>025...ARZ030>034...ARZ037>047...
ARZ052>057...ARZ062>069.

POPS ALL DAY IN THAT AREA. WILL START SOUTHERN SECTIONS WITH CHANCE 
POPS THEN INCREASE TO LIKELY BY LATE MORNING. THE BEST COVERAGE
SHOULD COME THIS AFTERNOON BOTH AS NEW DEVELOPMENT OCCURS ALONG
BOUNDARIES AND EFFECTS OF HEATING ALSO TAKE HOLD. LOOKS LIKE 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE LIKELY INTO TONIGHT AS THE TROF
AXIS STARTS TO MOVE THROUGH AND ACTIVITY WILL BE FEEDING ON 
A NUMBER OF BOUNDARIES...SO KEPT LIKELY POPS GOING. COULD END UP
HAVING AN MCS MOVING ACROSS AT LEAST PART OF THE AREA. LOOKS
LIKE BEST CHANCE OF FLASH FLOODS MAY BE IN NORTH LATE TODAY INTO 
TONIGHT. ALREADY HAVE FLOOD WATCH IN SOUTH FOR TODAY. WILL EXPAND
FLOOD WATCH FOR TODAY TO COVER ENTIRE CWA. DAY SHIFT CAN LOOK AT
NEW MODELS AND WATCH HOW THINGS UNFOLD AND ADJUST WATCH FOR LATER
TODAY AND POSSIBLE EXTENSIONS INTO TONIGHT. DECREASED POPS FROM THE
WEST LATE TONIGHT INTO SATURDAY AS THE TROF AXIS PASSES. CONTINUED
CHANCE POPS IN MOST AREAS THROUGH SATURDAY AS SOME OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES
MAY REMAIN AND DECREASING CLOUDS AND SOUTHWEST LOW LEVEL FLOW SHOULD
LEAD TO STRONG HEATING WHICH WILL RESULT IN SCATTERED THUNDERSTORMS
SATURDAY AFTERNOON. KEPT DRY FORECAST FOR MOST OF SATURDAY NIGHT BUT
STUCK IN SMALL POPS FOR THE NORTH SUNDAY MORNING IN THE EVENT THE
SHORT WAVE DEPICTED BY THE ETA MODEL MATERIALIZES. UNLESS THIS SHORT
WAVE CAUSES AN MCS TO COVER THE AREA SUNDAY MORNING...THERE SHOULD
BE GOOD HEATING SUNDAY WITH MOST AREAS SOUTH OF THE OZARKS REACHING
THE 90S. CONTINUED WITH SMALL POPS THROUGH MONDAY WITH WARM HUMID
UNSTABLE AIR REMAINING IN PLACE. NO SIGNIFICANT FRONTS OR SHORT
WAVES ARE INDICATED BUT SOME WEAK BOUNDARIES MAY STILL BE PRESENT. 
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL ALLOW MOISTURE RETURN TO THE STATE...WITH 
DIURNAL SLIGHT CHANCE POPS MONDAY NIGHT AND TUESDAY. COLD FRONT 
APPROACHES TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY. NEW GFS RUN SLOWING FEATURE 
DOWN SOMEWHAT...BUT WILL HAVE TO SEE WHAT FUTURE RUNS DEPICT. HAVE 
INCLUDED LOW CHANCE POPS AS THE FRONT MOVES INTO THE STATE...AS 
MOISTURE WILL STILL BE PRESENT DUE TO RETURN FLOW. DUE TO THE 
UNCERTAINTY OF SOLUTIONS...CONTINUED DRY FORECAST FOR THURSDAY.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    85  72  88  72 /  60  60  50  20 
HARRISON AR       80  68  84  69 /  70  70  40  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    85  72  89  72 /  60  60  40  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     85  73  88  72 /  60  60  50  20 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  80  68  84  69 /  70  70  40  20 
MONTICELLO AR     86  73  89  73 /  60  60  50  20 
SEARCY AR         84  71  87  71 /  70  70  50  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      84  72  89  72 /  60  60  40  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   83  71  88  71 /  70  70  40  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...FLOOD WATCH TODAY FOR ZONES 
ARZ003>007...ARZ012>016...ARZ021>025...ARZ030>034...ARZ037>047...
ARZ052>057...ARZ062>069.
&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
945 PM CDT THU JUL  1 2004

.DISCUSSION...
MOST SHOWER AND THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY HAD ENDED OVER THE FORECAST 
AREA AT MID EVENING...EXCEPT FOR SOME SCATTERED SHOWERS AND STORMS 
OVER CENTRAL AND NORTH CENTRAL SECTIONS. HAVE LOWERED POPS FOR 
OVERNIGHT A LITTLE IN ALL AREAS...BUT LEFT HIGHEST CHANCES WHERE 
ACTIVITY IS NOW AND SHOULD MOVE THROUGH THE NIGHT. REST OF PREVIOUS 
PACKAGE OKAY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...FLASH FLOOD WATCH FROM 400 AM CDT 
FRIDAY UNTIL 400 PM CDT FRIDAY FOR ZONES ARZ052>057...ARZ062>069..

22






802 
FXUS64 KLZK 011906
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
205 PM CDT THU JUL  1 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT...
MODELS THIS AFTERNOON ARE IN DECENT AGREEMENT IN THE SYNOPTIC SCALE 
WITH JUST SUBTLE DIFFERENCES IN THE FINER DETAILS. WITH MODELS 
GENERALLY ON THE SAME PAGE...WILL GO WITH A BLEND OF SOLUTIONS THIS 
AFTERNOON. MODELS ALSO CONSISTENT WITH MOVING THE UPPER TROF/UPPER 
LOW ACROSS THE AREA FASTER THAN PREVIOUS RUNS.

OVERALL WET PATTERN TO CONTINUE FOR THE NEXT 36 TO 48 HOURS AS 
STUBBORN UPPER LOW WILL BE SLOW TO CLEAR THE AREA. FEATURE IS 
CURRENTLY OVER CENTRAL KANSAS WITH NEARLY FULL LATITUDE...NEGATIVELY 
TILTED UPPER TROUGH. WINDS ALOFT REMAIN WEAK IN THE LOW TO MID 
LEVELS SO SYSTEM WILL ONLY CRAWL EASTWARD. AIRMASS CONTINUES TO BE 
TROPICAL IN NATURE AND CONDITIONALLY UNSTABLE WITH PWAT VALUES 
HOVERING NEAR TWO INCHES.

MANY AREAS OVER MAINLY SOUTHERN ARKANSAS HAVE SEEN SEVERAL INCHES OF 
RAIN OVER THE PAST FEW DAYS. ANY ADDITIONAL HEAVY RAINFALL COULD 
LEAD TO ADDITIONAL FLOODING. SLOW MOVING SHORTWAVE TRACKED ACROSS 
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS THIS MORNING LEADING TO WIDESPREAD LIGHT RAIN. 
WAVE CURRENTLY OVER SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS WITH LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN. 
FLASH FLOODING WAS REPORTED EARLIER TODAY IN BRADLEY COUNTY.

MODELS CONTINUE TO SHOW A BREAK IN THE ACTION TONIGHT AFTER ANY 
DIURNAL SHOWERS DISSIPATE. WILL ONLY CARRY CHANCE OR SLIGHT CHANCE 
POPS AS SOMETHING COULD KICK UP ON AN OLD BOUNDARY OR IN ASSOCIATION 
WITH SEVERAL WEAK IMPULSES MOVING THROUGH THE AREA. NEXT PIECE OF 
ENERGY DROPS DOWN FROM OKLAHOMA LATE TONIGHT AND SWINGS ACROSS THE 
STATE FRIDAY. WITH NATURE OF THE AIRMASS AND STRENGTH OF THE WAVE... 
WILL HAVE TO GO HIGH LIKELY OR CATEGORICAL POPS. MESO-ETA DROPS 
ANOTHER PIECE OF ENERGY DOWN FRIDAY NIGHT SO MORE RAIN IS LIKELY. 
WITH SATURATED GROUND AND FLOODING ALREADY EXPERIENCED...WILL HOIST 
A FLOOD WATCH FOR FRIDAY ACROSS THE SOUTH.

DRIER AIR MOVES INTO THE WEST EARLY SATURDAY AS TROF AXIS/COLD FRONT 
SWEEPS DEEP MOISTURE TO THE EAST. WILL TAPER OFF POPS FROM WEST TO 
EAST SATURDAY MORNING AS SYSTEM PULLS OUT. WILL NOT ENTIRELY REMOVE 
PRECIPITATION AS DIURNAL SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL STILL BE 
POSSIBLE THROUGH THE HOLIDAY WEEKEND WITH NUMEROUS BOUNDARIES 
FLOATING AROUND. DAYTIME TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN BELOW NORMAL 
THROUGH SATURDAY...BUT WILL WARM UP SUNDAY AS MOISTURE LEVELS 
DROP/CLOUDS BECOME LESS OF A FACTOR. WHILE MOISTURE BECOMES MORE 
SHALLOW...SOUTHERLY FLOW WILL KEEP LOW LEVEL MOISTURE IN PLACE. THIS 
WILL LEAD TO MUGGY NIGHTS WITH NIGHTTIME READINGS CLOSE TO NORMAL 
OVERALL.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY
BY EARLY TUESDAY...A WEAK COLD FRONT WILL BE APPROACHING FROM THE 
NORTHWEST. SOUTHERLY WINDS IN ADVANCE OF THIS APPROACHING SYSTEM 
WILL LIKELY BRING ABOUT A NOTICEABLE WARM-UP. ENOUGH MOISTURE WILL 
ADVECT INTO THE AREA FOR A SLIGHT CHANCE OF AFTERNOON SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS. THESE SHOWERS AND AN INCREASE IN CLOUDS OVER MOST 
AREAS WILL KEEP AFTERNOON TEMPERATURES FROM GETTING TOO FAR OUT OF 
HAND. THEN BY EARLY WEDNESDAY...THE COLD FRONT IS EXPECTED TO BE 
NEAR AN IMAGINARY LINE EXTENDING FROM NEAR BATESVILLE TO NEAR MENA. 
COOLER AND RELATIVELY DRIER AIR WILL LIE TO THE NORTH OF THIS 
EAST-WEST FRONTAL BOUNDARY. TO THE SOUTH OF THE FRONT HOWEVER WARMER 
AND HUMID AIR WILL PERSIST. SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS CAN 
BE EXPECTED IN THE SOUTHERN SECTIONS WHERE THE PRECIPITABLE WATER 
VALUES WILL BE MUCH HIGHER. THE FRONT WILL STALL THEN BECOME A WARM 
FRONT BEFORE MOVING BACK ACROSS THE NORTHERN SECTIONS LATE 
WEDNESDAY. THE WARM FRONT WILL BE WELL NORTH OF OUR CWA BY THURSDAY 
WITH ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES LIKELY ACROSS MOST OF ARKANSAS BY 
THURSDAY AFTERNOON.   
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    70  84  70  87 /  30  50  50  40 
HARRISON AR       68  82  68  86 /  40  60  50  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    70  85  70  88 /  30  50  50  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     71  85  72  87 /  30  50  50  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  68  81  68  85 /  40  60  50  40 
MONTICELLO AR     72  85  72  88 /  30  40  50  40 
SEARCY AR         69  83  70  87 /  30  50  50  40 
MOUNT IDA AR      68  85  70  88 /  30  50  50  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   68  83  69  87 /  30  60  50  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
AR...FLASH FLOOD WATCH FROM 400 AM CDT FRIDAY UNTIL 400 PM CDT FRIDAY
FOR ZONES ARZ052>057...ARZ062>069.
&&

$$

000 
FXUS64 KLZK 011528
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1025 AM CDT THU JUL  1 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATE ON THE WAY THIS MORNING TO LOWER POPS AND QPF FOR THE 
REMAINDER OF THE DAY. CURRENT RADAR CONTINUES TO SHOW A DECREASING 
TREND WITH THE PRECIPITATION AS DRIER AIR TRIES TO PUNCH IN FROM THE 
SOUTHWEST. LATEST WATER VAPOR IMAGERY SHOWS DRY SLOT ENTERING THE 
EXTREME SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE STATE BUT NOT CONFIDENT HOW FAR IT 
WILL PROGRESS AS LARGE AREA OF CONVECTION IN OKLAHOMA TRIES TO MOVE 
EASTWARD.

NEW MODELS SHUNT ALL THE PRECIPITATION OFF TO THE EAST FOR THIS 
AFTERNOON. STILL SOME SHOWERS POSSIBLE CENTRAL AND NORTH THROUGH THE 
REMAINDER OF THE DAY IN TROPICAL AIRMASS. WITH NO REAL FORCING SEEN 
WILL LOWER POPS ACROSS ALL AREAS WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE SOUTH 
WHERE MODELS CONTINUE TO SWING A SHORTWAVE THROUGH. 

WILL ALSO NEED TO LOWER TEMPS A DEGREE OR TWO BASED ON CURRENT 
TRENDS AND RAIN COOLED AIR. MODELS CONTINUE TO SWING THE UPPER 
TROUGH THROUGH THE AREA LATE TONIGHT AND FRIDAY SO ONLY A RESPITE 
FROM THE WET WEATHER EXPECTED. MODELS ALSO SPEEDING THE SYSTEM UP 
VERSUS THIS TIME YESTERDAY BUT WILL WAIT FOR ALL THE DATA TO COME IN 
BEFORE MAKING WHOLESALE CHANGES.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56






317 
FXUS64 KLZK 010834
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
325 AM CDT THU JUL  1 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY
WET PATTERN/LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN WILL CONTINUE AT LEAST THROUGH
FRIDAY...WITH LOW PRESSURE ALOFT STILL WOBBLING TOWARD ARKANSAS
FROM THE SOUTHERN PLAINS.

WAVE OF ENERGY AHEAD OF SYSTEM WILL PUSH THROUGH ARKANSAS THIS
MORNING...WITH LULL TO FOLLOW INTO AFTERNOON HOURS. GIVEN THIS...
TODAY MAY NOT BE AS ACTIVE AS IN PREVIOUS DAYS...WITH PRECIPITATION
NOT AS WIDESPREAD.

SCATTERED PRECIPITATION THAT DEVELOPS THIS AFTERNOON DUE TO DAYTIME
HEATING WILL MOSTLY DISSIPATE AFTER SUNSET. MAY ACTUALLY HAVE
MOSTLY QUIET WEATHER DURING THE OVERNIGHT HOURS. HOWEVER...TOWARD
MORNING...NEXT WAVE OF ENERGY FROM OKLAHOMA WILL ARRIVE IN WESTERN
COUNTIES.

WAVE WILL SPREAD AREA OF SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS ACROSS THE REGION ON
FRIDAY...WITH LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN.

MAIN SYSTEM ALOFT WILL FINALLY GET HERE FRIDAY NIGHT/SATURDAY...WITH
CONTINUED GOOD CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION. AT THE SURFACE...COLD
FRONT WILL PUSH INTO ARKANSAS...WITH ABUNDANT MOISTURE SHUNTED TO THE
EAST.

AS WEEKEND COMES TO A CLOSE...FRONT WILL STALL IN ARKANSAS...BUT
THERE WILL NOT BE AS MUCH MOISTURE. AS A RESULT...ONLY ISOLATED TO
SCATTERED THUNDER WILL POP UP...MAINLY DURING THE AFTERNOON/EVENING
ON SUNDAY.

DAYTIME TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN BELOW NORMAL THROUGH SATURDAY...
BUT WILL WARM UP SUNDAY AS MOISTURE LEVELS DROP/CLOUDS BECOME LESS
OF A FACTOR. WHILE MOISTURE BECOMES MORE SHALLOW...SOUTHERLY
FLOW WILL KEEP LOW LEVEL MOISTURE IN PLACE. THIS WILL
LEAD TO MUGGY NIGHTS WITH NIGHTTIME READINGS CLOSE TO NORMAL
OVERALL.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
THE UPPER LEVEL FLOW WILL RETURN TO A MORE NORMAL PATTERN. THERE
WILL BE WEAK SHORT WAVES MOVING OVER THE STATE ON THE NORTHERN EDGE
OF THE SUBTROPICAL RIDGE. THIS SHOULD TRANSLATE INTO THE TYPICAL 20
OR 30 PERCENT CHANCES EACH AFTERNOON. ALSO...AFTERNOON HIGHS WILL
RETURN TO THEIR SEASONAL LEVELS. LOWS WILL CONTINUE RATHER MUGGY
WITH PERSISTENT MOISTURE-LADEN FLOW FROM THE SOUTH.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  70  84  70 /  50  30  50  50
HARRISON AR       80  68  82  68 /  50  40  60  50
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  70  85  70 /  50  30  50  50
PINE BLUFF AR     84  71  85  72 /  40  30  50  50
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  80  68  81  68 /  50  40  60  50
MONTICELLO AR     85  72  85  72 /  40  30  40  50
SEARCY AR         82  69  83  70 /  50  40  50  50
MOUNT IDA AR      84  68  85  70 /  50  30  50  50
RUSSELLVILLE AR   83  68  83  69 /  50  30  60  50
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
325 AM CDT THU JUL  1 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  70  84  70 /  50  30  50  50
HARRISON AR       80  68  82  68 /  50  40  60  50
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  70  85  70 /  50  30  50  50
PINE BLUFF AR     84  71  85  72 /  40  30  50  50
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  80  68  81  68 /  50  40  60  50
MONTICELLO AR     85  72  85  72 /  40  30  40  50
SEARCY AR         82  69  83  70 /  50  40  50  50
MOUNT IDA AR      84  68  85  70 /  50  30  50  50
RUSSELLVILLE AR   83  68  83  69 /  50  30  60  50
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

22






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 301933
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 PM CDT WED JUN 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT
ANOTHER WET DAY ACRS THE FA TODAY WITH SCTD TO NUMEROUS SHRA/TSRA 
NOTED. HAVE SEEN A BREAK IN THE RAINFALL OVER CNTRL AND SERN AR...
BUT THE LEADING EDGE OF ANOTHER BATCH OF PRECIP IS SLOLY APCHG FROM 
SWRN AR ATTM.

LOOKS LIKE LITTLE CHANGE IN THE OVERALL PATTERN IS EXPECTED OVER AR 
FOR MUCH OF THE SHORT TERM. UPPER LVL TROF TO THE W OF THE REGION 
WILL CONT TO SEND WEAK IMPULSES NEWD ACRS AR IN THE COMING DAYS. 
THESE FEATURES...COMBINED WITH ABUNDANT MOISTURE AND LINGERING SFC 
BNDRY...WILL RESULT IN LIKELY RAIN CHCS FOR MOST AREAS. EXPECT TO 
SEE PERIODS OF RAIN...LOCALLY HEAVY AT TIMES...AFFECT AR WITH TIMING 
OF EACH EPISODE THE BIG FCST CHALLENGE. CONT TO FOLLOW CURRENT FCST 
TRENDS OF HI CHC/LIKELY POPS FOR MOST PDS THRU FRI. STILL NEED TO 
MONITOR RAINFALL RATES CLOSELY...BUT FOR NOW FEEL THAT FF POTENTIAL 
WILL STAY ISOLD WITH NO WATCH ANTICIPATED IN THE NEAR TERM.

UPPER TROF FINALLY SHOWING SIGNS OF WORKING FURTHER EWD LATE FRI 
INTO THE WEEKEND. LATEST GFS SHOWS A CLOSED UPPER LOW BY LATE SAT 
WORKING ACRS SRN MO. MEANWHILE...SFC CDFNT STILL PROGGED TO MOVE 
THRU MOST OF AR BY LATE SAT NIGHT WITH SOME DRIER AIR EXPECTED TO 
MAKE AN APPEARANCE.

AS FAR AS TEMPS GO...CONTD TO TREND COOLER ON DAYTIME HIGHS WITH 
EXPECTED CLOUDS AND RAINFALL. ACTUALLY PREFER THE TRENDS OF THE GFS 
MOS HIGHS FOR THE NEXT FEW DAYS. STUCK WITH PERSISTENCE ON LOW TEMPS 
THRU THE PD.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
A WEAK COLD FRONT WILL BECOME QUASI-STATIONARY AND EXTEND EAST TO 
WEST ACROSS NORTHERN ARKANSAS SUNDAY. THE FRONT WILL THEN MOVE BACK 
NORTH AS A WARM FRONT AND OUT OF THE CWA MONDAY. THE FRONT WILL 
REMAIN NORTH OF OUR CWA TUESDAY. THIS WILL BRING PERIODS OF SHOWERS 
AND THUNDERSTORMS TO MOST OF THE CWA THROUGH THE FIRST PART OF THE 
LONG TERM PERIOD. BY WEDNESDAY HOWEVER...HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD 
FROM THE SOUTHEAST AND THIS WILL KEEP SHOWERS TO A MINIMUM. 
TEMPERATURES WILL TREND UPWARD TO NEAR NORMAL LEVELS SUNDAY THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

FXUS64 KLZK 301626 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1125 AM CDT WED JUN 30 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LARGE AREA OF RAIN AND SCTD TSRA CONTS OVER MUCH OF AR ATTM. 
ACTIVITY ASSOCD WITH UPPER LVL SYSTEM TO OUT W AND PERSISTENT SFC 
BNDRY MEANDERING OVER AR. WENT AHEAD AND RAISED POPS INTO LIKELY AND 
CAT RANGE FOR THIS AFTN. KEPT LOCALLY HEAVY RAINFALL IN THE FCST 
WITH PW VALUE AROUND 2 INCHES NOTED ON OUR 12Z SOUNDING THIS MRNG. 
ALSO LOWERED HIGH TEMPS A FEW DEGREES MOST AREAS DUE TO CLOUDS AND 
RAINFALL COVERAGE. REST OF FCST IN GOOD SHAPE. UPDATED GRIDS AND 
ZONES ALREADY POSTED.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

44





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 300753
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
250 AM CDT WED JUN 30 2004

.SHORT TERM...WEDNESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY
FRONT REMAINS NEARLY STATIONARY ACROSS NORTHERN ARKANSAS THIS
MORNING. LOW PRESSURE ALOFT WILL WOBBLE TOWARD THE REGION
FROM THE SOUTHERN PLAINS...AND WILL INTERACT WITH THE FRONT.
AS A RESULT...SCATTERED TO NUMEROUS SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS
WILL DEVELOP.

PRECIPITATION ALREADY ON RADAR THIS MORNING...MAINLY IN SOUTHEAST
ARKANSAS. SLOW MOVEMENT AND A PRECIPITABLE WATER VALUE BETWEEN
1.5 AND 2.0 INCHES HAS LED TO SOME HEAVY RAINFALL TOTALS. AS
CELLS BECOME MORE NUMEROUS TODAY...WOULD FULLY EXPECT SIMILAR
RESULTS...AND HAVE MENTIONED LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN IN THE FORECAST.

LOW PRESSURE IN THE PLAINS NOT MAKING MUCH HEADWAY ON THURSDAY...
SO WILL CONTINUE WITH LIKELY CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION/LOCALLY
HEAVY RAIN.

APPEARS THAT NEW SURFACE FRONT WILL SLOWLY PUSH INTO ARKANSAS
FROM THE NORTHWEST ON FRIDAY...WITH SOME OF THIS ABUNDANT
MOISTURE SHUNTED TO THE EAST. HOWEVER...FRONT WILL LIKELY STALL
ACROSS THE REGION OVER THE WEEKEND.

WITH A FRONT IN THE STATE...WILL CONTINUE WITH SMALL CHANCES
FOR THUNDER ON SATURDAY. WITH LESS MOISTURE/CLOUDS...WILL
LIKELY BE WARMER.

OVERALL...DAYTIME TEMPERATURES IN THE SHORT TERM WILL REMAIN BELOW
NORMAL WITH GOOD CHANCES FOR RAIN/LOTS OF CLOUDS. MUGGINESS AT
NIGHT/BLANKET OF CLOUDS WILL HOLD OVERNIGHT READINGS UP...AND
PRETTY CLOSE TO NORMAL.

TENDED TO GO BELOW MODEL RAIN CHANCES. THIS TIME OF YEAR...SUCH
HIGH POPS SEEM A BIT LOFTY. HOWEVER...POPS MENTIONED IN FORECAST
STILL WELL ABOVE THE NORM...WITH WAY MORE THAN THE TYPICAL POPCORN
THUNDER EXPECTED.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
UPPER TROF WILL BE MOVING OFF TO THE EAST SATURDAY NIGHT. THEN THERE
WILL BE A SUCCESSION OF SHORT WAVES ACROSS ARKANSAS AT H5 THAT WILL
TRACK MAINLY OVER MISSOURI. THIS SHOULD TRANSLATE INTO AN END TO ALL
THE ABOVE NORMAL PRECIPITATION THAT HAS BEEN PERSISTING OVER
ARKANSAS. RAIN CHANCES WILL TAPER TO MORE SEASONAL 20 OR 30 PERCENT
POPS DUE TO AFTERNOON HEATING.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  70  84  71 /  60  50  60  40
HARRISON AR       80  66  81  66 /  40  50  60  50
HOT SPRINGS AR    83  70  84  69 /  60  50  60  40
PINE BLUFF AR     84  71  85  72 /  60  50  60  40
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  79  66  80  67 /  40  50  60  50
MONTICELLO AR     85  71  85  72 /  60  50  60  40
SEARCY AR         82  69  83  71 /  50  50  60  50
MOUNT IDA AR      83  68  84  68 /  60  50  60  40
RUSSELLVILLE AR   82  68  83  68 /  60  50  60  50
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

46/32





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 300213
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
915 PM CDT TUE JUN 29 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPDATE ON THE WAY THIS EVENING. LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES 
STATIONARY FRONT BISECTING THE STATE FROM EAST TO WEST. WATER VAPOR 
IMAGERY CONTINUES TO SHOW A TROPICAL CONNECTION WITH A CONTINUOUS 
FEED OF MOISTURE INTO THE MID SOUTH WITH PWAT VALUES CLOSE TO 2 
INCHES. SOUNDING FROM EARLIER THIS EVENING SHOWS AIRMASS ALMOST 
SATURATED UP TO ABOUT 9K FEET AND STORM MOTION LESS THAN 8 KTS WITH 
VERY LIGHT WINDS THROUGH THE FIRST 6 THOUSAND FEET. AS SUCH... 
PRECIPITATION WILL CONTINUE TO MOVE VERY SLOWLY WITH POTENTIAL FOR 
HEAVY RAIN REMAINING A CONCERN.

SEVERAL WEAK UPPER LEVEL IMPULSES STILL PROGGED TO TRAVEL ACROSS THE 
AREA AND WILL PROVIDE ADDED LIFT TO KEEP THE PRECIPITATION GOING. 
AREA RADARS CONTINUE TO SHOW A DECREASING TREND IN INTENSITY OF THE 
RAIN...LIKELY FROM THE AIR MASS STABILIZING FROM LOSS OF DAYTIME 
HEATING. HOWEVER...COVERAGE IS THE SAME OR HAS ACTUALLY INCREASED. 
WITH THESE WAVES STILL PROGGED TO COME THOROUGH AND BASED ON CURRENT 
TRENDS...WILL BOOST POPS TO LIKELY ACROSS THE BOARD FOR THE REST OF 
THE NIGHT. WILL ALSO NEED TO TWEAK OTHER GRIDS/ZONES BASED ON OTHER
CURRENT TRENDS AND OBSERVATIONS.

LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56








000 
FXUS64 KLZK 291941
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
240 PM CDT TUE JUN 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT
SFC FNTL BNDRY STILL STALLED OUT ACRS CNTRL AR THIS AFTN. SCTD 
CONVECTION HAS FIRED VCNTY OF THE BNDRY WITH LOCALLY HEAVY RAINS 
ACCOMPANYING SOME OF THE CELLS OVER CNTRL AR ATTM. EXPECT ACTIVITY 
TO PERSIST INTO THE EARLY EVENING HOURS BEFORE WEAKENING WITH THE 
LOSS OF DAYTIME HEATING.

UNSETTLED WEATHER PATTERN TO CONT THRU MUCH OF THE SHORT TERM AS THE 
FNT IS PROGGED TO PERSIST OVR THE FA. MEANWHILE...SEVERAL UPPER LVL 
IMPULSES WILL PASS ACRS THE MID-SOUTH TO PROVIDE ADDED LIFT FOR 
CONVECTIVE FORMATION. LOCALLY HEAVY RAINFALL WILL STILL BE POSSIBLE 
THE NEXT FEW DAYS WITH LIGHT WIND FLOW ALOFT. HAVE HELD OFF ON A FF 
WATCH FOR NOW DUE TO EXPECTED ISOLD NATURE OF FF POTENTIAL. LATER 
SHIFTS WILL NEED TO KEEP AN EYE ON TRENDS.

GFS STILL APPEARS TO BE SUFFERING FROM SOME CONVECTIVE FEEDBACK 
ISSUES AND IS REFLECTED BY THE HIGH MOS POPS. PREFER THE LOWER POPS 
INDCD BY THE NGM AND ETA MOS KEEPING VALUES IN THE SCTD TO LIKELY 
CAT THE NEXT 2 DAYS.

MODELS STILL INDCD NEXT CDFNT APCHG WRN AR LATE IN THE SHORT TERM. 
HAVE KEPT POPS IN CHC CAT FOR NOW AND SEE HOW TIMING PLAYS OUT WITH 
THE MODELS IN THE COMING DAYS.

TEMPS WILL BE A TOUGH CALL THE NEXT FEW DAYS DUE TO CLOUDS AND RAIN 
CHCS. HAVE TRENDED A FEW DEGREES LOWER THAN MOS FOR HIGHS MOST AREAS 
AND ACCEPTED MOS MINS THRU THE PD. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH TUESDAY
A WEAK COLD FRONT WILL BE MOVING SLOWLY SOUTHEAST ACROSS THE 
NORTHWESTERN SECTIONS OF THE CWA SATURDAY. THIS FRONT WILL BECOME 
STATIONARY ACROSS THE STATE BY SUNDAY THEN MOVE BACK NORTH AND OUT 
OF THE CWA MONDAY. THE FRONT WILL REMAIN NORTH OF OUR CWA TUESDAY. 
THIS WILL BRING PERIODS OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO MOST OF THE 
CWA THROUGHOUT THE LONG TERM PERIOD.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1125 AM CDT TUE JUN 29 2004

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT FCST ON TRACK FOR THIS AFTN. DID TWEAK HOURLY TEMP AND 
PRECIP GRIDS TO BETTER REFLECT CURRENT CONDITIONS. STATIONARY BNDRY 
STILL SITUATED OVER CNTRL AR THIS MRNG AND WILL CONT TO BE THE FOCUS 
OF ADDITIONAL CONVECTION INTO THIS EVENING. LOCALLY HEAVY RAINS WILL 
STILL BE THE MAIN CONCERN FOR CNTRL AND SRN AR AS WINDS ALOFT RMN 
WEAK. UPDATED GRIDS AND ZONES ALREADY OUT.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

1125 AM CDT TUE JUN 29 2004

.DISCUSSION...

STILL SITUATED OVER CNTRL AR THIS MRNG AND WILL CONT TO BE THE FOCUS 
OF ADDITIONAL CONVECTION INTO THIS EVENING. LOCALLY HEAVY RAINS WILL 
STILL BE THE MAIN CONCERN FOR CNTRL AND SRN AR AS WINDS ALOFT RMN 
WEAK. UPDATED GRIDS AND ZONES ALREADY OUT.
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

44





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 290746
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
240 AM CDT TUE JUN 29 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH FRIDAY
LOOKS LIKE A WET WEATHER PATTERN TO BEGIN THE SHORT TERM. FRONT THAT
MOVED INTO ARKANSAS ON MONDAY HAS PRETTY MUCH STALLED IN CENTRAL
SECTIONS OF THE STATE. WEAK ENERGY FROM THE SOUTHERN PLAINS WILL
INTERACT WITH THE FRONT...WITH SCATTERED TO NUMEROUS SHOWERS AND
THUNDERSTORMS POPPING UP THIS AFTERNOON/EVENING.

REPEAT PERFORMANCE ON WEDNESDAY...WITH STRONGER SYSTEM ARRIVING
FROM OKLAHOMA HELPING TO TRIGGER PRECIPITATION.

LZK 00Z SOUNDING NOT SHOWING MUCH OF A STORM MOTION...AND
PRECIPITABLE WATER VALUES WILL LIKELY BE BETWEEN 1.5 AND 2.0
INCHES. GIVEN THIS...STORMS THAT DEVELOP WILL HAVE A TRNDENCY TO
PRODUCE LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN. WILL ADDRESS THIS IN BODY OF FORECAST.

MODEL PRECIPITATION PROBABILITIES A LITTLE HIGH FOR THE MOST PART
THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS...BUT DEFINITELY GET YOUR ATTENTION.
BOTTOM LINE IS THAT RAIN CHANCES WILL BE INFLATED FOR THIS TIME OF
YEAR...WITH MORE ISOLATED PRECIPITATION THE NORM.

TOWARD THE END OF THE SHORT TERM...NEW COLD FRONT WILL HEAD INTO
ARKANSAS FROM THE NORTHWEST. WHILE IT APPEARS THAT THE FRONT WILL NOT
BE FOLLOWED BY A BIG COOLDOWN...IT WILL SHUNT ABUNDANT MOISTURE TO
THE EAST WITH PRECIPITATION A LITTLE MORE ISOLATED THIS WEEKEND.

AS FAR AS TEMPERATURES IN THE SHORT TERM...CLOUDS/PRECIPITATION WILL
KEEP DAYTIME READINGS BELOW NORMAL. MUGGY AIR/FAIRLY HIGH DEWPOINTS
WILL KEEP READINGS NEAR NORMAL AT NIGHT.
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
UPPER FLOW WILL HAVE A CLOSED LOW OVER THE MISSOURI BOOTHEEL FRIDAY
NIGHT INTO SATURDAY MORNING...WITH THE LOW OPENING AND GETTING
CAUGHT UP IN THE FLOW AROUND THE LOW OVER HUDSON BAY. THIS WILL
LEAVE A SHEAR AXIS THAT WILL SPLIT THE SUBTROPICAL RIDGE OVER THE
LOWER MISS RIVER VALLEY. EVEN WITH WEAK FEATURES AT H5 THERE WILL BE
ENOUGH INSTABILITY TO KEEP SCATTERED PRECIPITATION OVER AR IN THE
LIGHT NORTHWESTERLY FLOW ALOFT. TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE MAINLY IN
THE 80S FOR HIGHS...WHICH IS SOMEWHAT BELOW NORMAL WHILE THE LOWS
WILL BE PROPPED BY THE RATHER MUGGY DEW POINTS.
&&


.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    84  70  84  70 /  50  40  50  40
HARRISON AR       80  65  80  65 /  30  30  50  40
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  70  84  70 /  50  40  50  40
PINE BLUFF AR     84  71  84  71 /  50  30  50  40
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  79  65  79  65 /  30  30  50  40
MONTICELLO AR     85  71  85  71 /  50  30  50  40
SEARCY AR         83  69  83  69 /  40  40  50  40
MOUNT IDA AR      84  70  84  70 /  50  40  50  40
RUSSELLVILLE AR   83  68  83  68 /  40  40  50  40
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

46/32

000 
FXUS64 KLZK 290308
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1005 PM CDT MON JUN 28 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SHOWERS HAVE DECREASED IN MANY AREAS BUT A FEW CLUSTERS REMAIN IN THE
NORTH AND A RATHER SIGNIFICANT AREA REMAINS IN THE SOUTHWEST WHICH HAS
ACTUALLY INCREASED IN THE PAST HOUR. LITTLE MOVEMENT BEING SEEN IN ANY
OF THE ACTIVITY. UPPER AIR ANALYSIS SHOWS HEIGHTS INCREASING AND 
HIGH PRESSURE ALOFT INCREASING OVER THE AREA. THIS MAY SERVE TO LESSEN
STEERING WINDS AND RESULT IN LITTLE MOVEMENT TO ANY PRECIPITATION THAT
OCCURS. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN SOUTH CENTRAL SECTIONS LIKELY
ALONG A BOUNDARY SO THEY HAVE A BETTER CHANCE OF HOLDING TOGETHER. 
KEPT 40 PERCENT POPS IN THE SOUTH WITH DECREASE TO 30 PERCENT IN 
THE GRIDS AFTER MIDNIGHT. LOWERED POPS TO 20 PERCENT IN OTHER AREAS
FOR THE REST OF THE NIGHT. MENTIONED LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN IN SOUTHERN
ZONES FOR REST OF THE NIGHT. ADJUSTED TEMP AND DEW POINT GRIDS TO
FIT OBSERVED DATA BUT MIN FORECASTS STILL LOOK GOOD SO ADJUSTED VALUES
FOR NEXT FEW HOURS THEN INTERPOLATED TO 12Z VALUES. MADE MINOR
ADJUSTMENT TO WIND GRIDS FOR NEXT FEW HOURS ALSO TO FIT CURRENT 
TRENDS.     
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

29








000 
FXUS64 KLZK 281903
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
201 PM CDT MON JUN 28 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY...
MODELS CONTINUE TO BE IN VERY GOOD AGREEMENT IN THE SYNOPTIC SCALE 
BUT DIFFERENCES ARISE IN THE FINER DETAILS. MODELS CONTINUE TO 
ADVERTISE BROAD TROFFING OVER THE NORTHEAST QUAD OF THE NATION WITH 
RIDGING OVER THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS AND ANOTHER TROF OFF THE WEST 
COAST. PATTERN SHOWS ONLY SUBTLE CHANGES THROUGH THE END OF THE 
PERIOD. BIGGEST DIFFERENCES LAY IN THE STRENGTH OF THE SHORTWAVES
WITH GFS ONCE AGAIN STRONGER THAN THE ETA COUNTERPART. WILL LEAN 
TOWARDS THE WEAKER ETA THIS AFTERNOON AS OVERALL FLOW LOOKS WEAK AND 
GFS APPEARS TO BE OVERDONE SOMEWHAT.

LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES WEAK BOUNDARY OVER THE SOUTH BUT 
FEATURE IS BECOMING HARDER AND HARDER TO FIND AND SHOULD BE ALMOST 
COMPLETELY WASHED OUT BY PRESS TIME. MODELS CONTINUE TO PICK UP A 
NEW WAVE THAT WILL TRAVEL ALONG WHATS LEFT OF THE BOUNDARY THIS 
EVENING. CONVECTION ALREADY FIRING UP IN CENTRAL TEXAS WITH THIS 
FEATURE AND DRIFTING SLOWLY EAST. MEANWHILE...SCATTERED SHOWERS 
CONTINUE TO BREAK OUT IN THE INCREASING MOIST AND UNSTABLE AIRMASS 
OVER THE CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE STATE. 

ONLY AREA WHERE PRECIPITATION IS NOT BREAKING OUT IS THE NORTHEAST. 
DEW POINT TEMPERATURES HERE ARE IN THE LOWER 60S VERSUS UPPER 60S OR 
HIGHER ELSEWHERE. COLD FRONT HAS BACK DOORED THIS PART OF THE STATE 
AND WOULD EXPECT FEATURE TO CONTINUE TO SLOWLY MOVE SOUTHWARD INTO 
AN ENVIRONMENT THAT IS MORE MOIST AND UNSTABLE. WOULD EXPECT SHOWERS 
AND THUNDERSTORMS TO FIRE UP NEAR AND ALONG THE VICINITY OF THE 
FRONT. PRECIPITATION CHANCES WILL BE GREATER TO THE SOUTH IN THE 
VICINITY OF THE OLD BOUNDARY.

FRONT LOOKS LIKE IT WILL HANG UP OVER THE CENTRAL PART OF THE STATE
FOR TUESDAY. AIRMASS WILL REMAIN MOIST AND MODERATELY UNSTABLE. 
DAYTIME HEATING WILL HELP FIRE UP MORE AFTERNOON SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS WITH THE BEST CHANCES ONCE AGAIN OVER THE SOUTH. 
FRONT WILL BE MOVING BACK TO THE NORTH ON WEDNESDAY BUT AFTERNOON 
ACTIVITY POSSIBLE ONCE AGAIN. MODELS DEVELOP A NEW WAVE IN THE 
OKLAHOMA PANHANDLE WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON AND MOVE IT NORTHEAST. WAVE 
WOULD CLIP NORTHERN ARKANSAS WEDNESDAY NIGHT WITH MORE SHORTWAVE 
ENERGY PROGGED TO COME THROUGH ON THURSDAY. BOTTOM LINE IS A VERY 
UNSETTLED FORECAST WITH AFTERNOON SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS POSSIBLE 
EACH DAY.

BIGGEST CONCERN WILL BE POTENTIAL FOR HEAVY RAIN AS UPPER FLOW IS 
VERY WEAK AT THIS TIME AND ANY STORMS COULD PRODUCE LOCALLY HEAVY 
RAIN. WILL JUST HAVE TO TAKE A WATCH AND SEE APPROACH AS TIMING OF 
THE INDIVIDUAL WAVES WILL BE DIFFICULT AT BEST. AS FAR AS 
TEMPERATURES ARE CONCERNED...NGM NUMBERS SEEM A LITTLE TOO WARM WITH 
WITH EXPECTED CLOUD COVER AND CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION. WILL LEAN 
MORE TOWARDS THE MAV GUIDANCE. TEMPERATURES WILL WARM ON WEDNESDAY 
AND THURSDAY AS FRONT RETREATS TO THE NORTH AND WARMER AIR RETURNS.
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY...
UNSETTLED WEATHER PATTERN LOOKS TO CONTINUE THROUGHOUT THE EXTENDED. 
SHORTWAVE WILL BE MOVING THROUGH ON THURSDAY NIGHT...ALLOWING FOR A 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. AREA WILL BE DRY SLOTTED ON 
FRIDAY NIGHT/EARLY SATURDAY BEFORE ANOTHER SURFACE BOUNDARY PUSHES 
INTO NORTHERN ARKANSAS. MODELS HINT AT POSSIBLE MCS DEVELOPMENT OVER 
NORTHEAST OKLAHOMA DURING THIS TIME. THE REMNANTS WOULD MOVE INTO 
ARKANSAS BY SATURDAY AFTERNOON...POSSIBLY TOUCHING OFF AN ADDITIONAL 
ROUND OF CONVECTION. 

BY THE END OF THE WEEKEND...YOU PROBABLY CAN GUESS WHAT HAPPENS. 
YUP...YOU GUESSED IT...THIS FRONT WILL STALL OUT INVOF SOUTHERN 
ARKANSAS...THEN BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT. LOOKS TO BE MORE 
MCS DEVELOPMENT SATURDAY NIGHT AND EARLY SUNDAY...WITH THE REMNANTS 
AFFECTING THE WESTERN HALF OF THE FORECAST AREA BY SUNDAY AFTERNOON 
AND EVENING. ACCOMPANYING SHORTWAVE WILL MOVE THROUGH SUNDAY 
NIGHT...WITH AN UPPER LEVEL IMPULSE AFFECTING NORTHERN ARKANSAS BY 
MONDAY AFTERNOON.

BOTTOM LINE...VERY LITTLE CHANGES MADE TO THE EXTENDED FORECAST. 
THERE WILL BE A CONTINUED CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. 
ALSO...VARIABLE CLOUD COVER...AND ZONAL TO NORTHWESTERLY H5 FLOW 
WILL KEEP TEMPERATURES BELOW NORMAL. 57/219.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    70  84  68  85 /  40  40  30  40 
HARRISON AR       65  80  64  82 /  30  20  30  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    69  84  68  85 /  40  40  30  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     70  84  69  85 /  40  50  30  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  64  79  65  82 /  30  20  30  40 
MONTICELLO AR     71  85  69  86 /  40  50  30  40 
SEARCY AR         69  83  68  85 /  30  40  30  40 
MOUNT IDA AR      69  84  67  85 /  40  40  30  40 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   68  83  67  84 /  30  30  30  40 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

56/58/219






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 281542
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1027 AM CDT MON JUN 28 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SHOWERS AND OCCASIONAL THUNDERSTORMS CONTINUE TO DEVELOP ON 
WEAKENING BOUNDARY OVER THE SOUTH. BOUNDARY SEEMS TO HAVE DRIFTED A 
LITTLE TO THE NORTH SINCE THIS MORNING WITH PERSISTENT LIGHT BAND OF 
PRECIPITATION ACROSS THE CENTRAL PART OF THE STATE. WEAK SHORTWAVE 
RESPONSIBLE FOR HEAVIER RAIN TO THE SOUTH NOW EAST OF THE AREA BUT 
WEAKER SECONDARY WAVE PROGGED TO COME IN THIS AFTERNOON. 

NUMEROUS BREAKS IN THE CLOUDS NOTED AND AIRMASS DOES DESTABILIZE 
THIS AFTERNOON. WILL CONTINUE CHANCE TO SIGHT CHANCES POPS ACROSS 
THE REGION WITH HIGHEST POPS OVER THE SOUTH. GRIDS/ZONES WILL NEED 
TO BE TWEAKED BUT OVER CHANGE IN SENSIBLE WEATHER WILL BE MINIMAL. 
ALL OTHER FIELDS LOOK GOOD AND WILL BE LEFT IN PLACE.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS FAIRLY WIDESPREAD ACROSS SOUTHERN ARKANSAS
DURING THE PREDAWN HOURS...BUT WILL BECOME MORE SCATTERED TOWARD
MORNING. PRECIPITATION THE RESULT OF WEAKENING SHORTWAVE FROM
TEXAS INTERACTING WITH OLD FRONTAL BOUNDARY.

THE BOUNDARY MANAGED TO LIFT NORTH A BIT IN THE LAST 24 HOURS...
WITH DEWPOINTS IN THE UPPER 60S/LOWER 70S IN ABOUT THE SOUTHERN
TWO THIRDS OF THE STATE. CLOSER TO THE MISSOURI BORDER...
DEWPOINTS STILL IN THE UPPER 50S/LOWER 60S. THIS DRY AIR
GREATLY INHIBITED SHOWER DEVELOPMENT ON SUNDAY...WITH ALL
PRECIPITATION IN THE SOUTHERN COUNTIES. PRECIPITATION WILL BE
MOST CONCENTRATED OVER CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS TODAY.

OLD BOUNDARY TO THE SOUTH WILL BECOME MORE DIFFUSE TODAY...WITH
NEW COLD FRONT ARRIVING FROM THE NORTHWEST. NEW FRONT WILL BE IN
CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE STATE BY EVENING...AND WILL LIKELY
TRIGGER SCATTERED SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS. HAVE SMALL CHANCES
OF RAIN IN THE NORTH...WITH PROGRESSIVELY GREATER CHANCES
TOWARD THE LOUISIANA BORDER.

KEPT SMALL CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION TONIGHT...AGAIN MAINLY IN
CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. FRONT LOOKS LIKE IT WILL HANG UP
ACROSS THE CENTRAL COUNTIES DURING THE OVERNIGHT HOURS.

ON TUESDAY...WITH A STALLED FRONT IN PLACE AND WITH SOME HEATING...
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL REFIRE. ISOLATED TO SCATTERED
PRECIPITATION MENTIONED IN THE NORTH...WITH SCATTERED TO NUMEROUS
CELLS CENTRAL/SOUTH.

FRONT WILL LIFT TO THE NORTH WEDNESDAY/THURSDAY. RAIN CHANCES WILL
GO DOWN A BIT...ALLOWING FOR WARMER DAYS.

TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN BELOW NORMAL THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS
WITH CLOUDS/SOME PRECIPITATION. READINGS CLOSER TO NORMAL TOWARD
MIDWEEK WITH LESS CLOUDS/PRECIPITATION MORE ISOLATED.

AS A WARM FRONT DEPARTS TO THE NORTH...ANOTHER COLD FRONT WILL
ARRIVE THURSDAY NIGHT/FRIDAY FROM THE NORTHWEST. CLOUDS WILL
INCREASE ONCE AGAIN...WITH BETTER CHANCES FOR SHOWERS AND
THUNDERSTORMS.

APPEARS THAT FRONT WILL MOVE JUST TO THE SOUTH OF ARKANSAS
TO BEGIN THE WEEKEND...BUT WILL STALL VERY NEAR THE STATE.
IN MOST OF THE REGION...DRY WEATHER WILL RETURN BEHIND THE
FRONT...BUT IT WILL REMAIN WARM. COULD HAVE ISOLATED THUNDER
IN THE SOUTH NEAR THE FRONT TO CLOSE OUT THE WEEKEND.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  69  83  69 /  50  40  40  20 
HARRISON AR       79  64  79  65 /  20  30  20  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    83  68  83  69 /  50  40  40  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  69  83  70 /  50  40  50  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  78  63  78  66 /  20  30  20  10 
MONTICELLO AR     84  70  84  70 /  60  40  50  30 
SEARCY AR         82  68  82  69 /  30  30  40  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      83  68  83  68 /  50  40  40  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   82  67  82  68 /  30  30  30  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

56






199 
FXUS64 KLZK 281542
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1027 AM CDT MON JUN 28 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SHOWERS AND OCCASIONAL THUNDERSTORMS CONTINUE TO DEVELOP ON 
WEAKENING BOUNDARY OVER THE SOUTH. BOUNDARY SEEMS TO HAVE DRIFTED A 
LITTLE TO THE NORTH SINCE THIS MORNING WITH PERSISTENT LIGHT BAND OF 
PRECIPITATION ACROSS THE CENTRAL PART OF THE STATE. WEAK SHORTWAVE 
RESPONSIBLE FOR HEAVIER RAIN TO THE SOUTH NOW EAST OF THE AREA BUT 
WEAKER SECONDARY WAVE PROGGED TO COME IN THIS AFTERNOON. 

NUMEROUS BREAKS IN THE CLOUDS NOTED AND AIRMASS DOES DESTABILIZE 
THIS AFTERNOON. WILL CONTINUE CHANCE TO SIGHT CHANCES POPS ACROSS 
THE REGION WITH HIGHEST POPS OVER THE SOUTH. GRIDS/ZONES WILL NEED 
TO BE TWEAKED BUT OVER CHANGE IN SENSIBLE WEATHER WILL BE MINIMAL. 
ALL OTHER FIELDS LOOK GOOD AND WILL BE LEFT IN PLACE.
&&

.PREV DISCUSSION...
SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS FAIRLY WIDESPREAD ACROSS SOUTHERN ARKANSAS
DURING THE PREDAWN HOURS...BUT WILL BECOME MORE SCATTERED TOWARD
MORNING. PRECIPITATION THE RESULT OF WEAKENING SHORTWAVE FROM
TEXAS INTERACTING WITH OLD FRONTAL BOUNDARY.

THE BOUNDARY MANAGED TO LIFT NORTH A BIT IN THE LAST 24 HOURS...
WITH DEWPOINTS IN THE UPPER 60S/LOWER 70S IN ABOUT THE SOUTHERN
TWO THIRDS OF THE STATE. CLOSER TO THE MISSOURI BORDER...
DEWPOINTS STILL IN THE UPPER 50S/LOWER 60S. THIS DRY AIR
GREATLY INHIBITED SHOWER DEVELOPMENT ON SUNDAY...WITH ALL
PRECIPITATION IN THE SOUTHERN COUNTIES. PRECIPITATION WILL BE
MOST CONCENTRATED OVER CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS TODAY.

OLD BOUNDARY TO THE SOUTH WILL BECOME MORE DIFFUSE TODAY...WITH
NEW COLD FRONT ARRIVING FROM THE NORTHWEST. NEW FRONT WILL BE IN
CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE STATE BY EVENING...AND WILL LIKELY
TRIGGER SCATTERED SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS. HAVE SMALL CHANCES
OF RAIN IN THE NORTH...WITH PROGRESSIVELY GREATER CHANCES
TOWARD THE LOUISIANA BORDER.

KEPT SMALL CHANCES OF PRECIPITATION TONIGHT...AGAIN MAINLY IN
CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. FRONT LOOKS LIKE IT WILL HANG UP
ACROSS THE CENTRAL COUNTIES DURING THE OVERNIGHT HOURS.

ON TUESDAY...WITH A STALLED FRONT IN PLACE AND WITH SOME HEATING...
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL REFIRE. ISOLATED TO SCATTERED
PRECIPITATION MENTIONED IN THE NORTH...WITH SCATTERED TO NUMEROUS
CELLS CENTRAL/SOUTH.

FRONT WILL LIFT TO THE NORTH WEDNESDAY/THURSDAY. RAIN CHANCES WILL
GO DOWN A BIT...ALLOWING FOR WARMER DAYS.

TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN BELOW NORMAL THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS
WITH CLOUDS/SOME PRECIPITATION. READINGS CLOSER TO NORMAL TOWARD
MIDWEEK WITH LESS CLOUDS/PRECIPITATION MORE ISOLATED.

AS A WARM FRONT DEPARTS TO THE NORTH...ANOTHER COLD FRONT WILL
ARRIVE THURSDAY NIGHT/FRIDAY FROM THE NORTHWEST. CLOUDS WILL
INCREASE ONCE AGAIN...WITH BETTER CHANCES FOR SHOWERS AND
THUNDERSTORMS.

APPEARS THAT FRONT WILL MOVE JUST TO THE SOUTH OF ARKANSAS
TO BEGIN THE WEEKEND...BUT WILL STALL VERY NEAR THE STATE.
IN MOST OF THE REGION...DRY WEATHER WILL RETURN BEHIND THE
FRONT...BUT IT WILL REMAIN WARM. COULD HAVE ISOLATED THUNDER
IN THE SOUTH NEAR THE FRONT TO CLOSE OUT THE WEEKEND.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    83  69  83  69 /  50  40  40  20 
HARRISON AR       79  64  79  65 /  20  30  20  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    83  68  83  69 /  50  40  40  20 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  69  83  70 /  50  40  50  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  78  63  78  66 /  20  30  20  10 
MONTICELLO AR     84  70  84  70 /  60  40  50  30 
SEARCY AR         82  68  82  69 /  30  30  40  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      83  68  83  68 /  50  40  40  20 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   82  67  82  68 /  30  30  30  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

000 
FXUS64 KLZK 280304
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION 
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1005 PM CDT SUN JUN 27 2004

.DISCUSSION...
RAIN HAS DECREASED MARKEDLY ACROSS THE AREA WITH THE LOSS OF 
HEATING. HOWEVER SHORT WAVE IS MOVING INTO SOUTHWESTERN ARKANSAS
AND AN AREA OF RAIN AND THUNDERSTORMS IS SPREADING ACROSS THE SOUTH
IN ASSOCIATION WITH THIS. STILL SOME CHANCE OF HEAVY RAINS NEAR THE
TRACK OF THE SHORT WAVE OVERNIGHT SO LEFT FLOOD WATCH INTACT EVEN 
THOUGH CONFIDENCE IS NOT THAT HIGH. DOES LOOK LIKE CHANCE OF FLOOD
PRODUCING RAIN WILL END BY 12Z AS SHORT WAVE MOVES PAST THE AREA. 
LEFT 30 PERCENT POPS IN OTHER AREAS TO ACCOUNT FOR ONGOING ACTIVITY
IN CENTRAL SECTIONS WHILE POPS IN THE NORTH WILL BE IN CASE 
CONVECTION MOVING INTO NORTHEASTERN OKLAHOMA MAKES IT INTO THAT
AREA LATER TONIGHT. MADE SLIGHT DOWNWARD ADJUSTMENT TO POPS FOR
MONDAY BUT STILL LOOKS LIKE 40 PERCENT WILL BE JUSTIFIED TO ACCOUNT
FOR COLD FRONT MOVING ACROSS MOST OF THE CWA DURING THE DAY. TEMP
AND WIND FORECASTS LOOK GOOD AND NO CHANGE WAS MADE THERE.  
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...FLASH FLOOD WATCH TONIGHT FOR 
ZONES ARZ062>069.
&&

$$

000 
FXUS64 KLZK 272028 CCA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...CORRECTED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
325 PM CDT SUN JUN 27 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH WEDENSDAY
UPPER LEVEL SHORT WAVE OVER NORTHEASTERN TEXAS AT MID AFTERNOON WILL 
MOVE ACROSS SOUTHERN ARKANSAS TONIGHT. WAVE WILL INTERACT WITH 
STATIONARY FRONT ALONG THE ARKANSAS-LOUISIANA BORDER TO PRODUCE 
SCATTERED TO NUMEROUS SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TONIGHT...ESPECIALLY 
OVER THE SOUTH. WITH FLASH FLOOD GUIDANCE VALUES VERY LOW OVER THE 
SOUTH...DECIDED TO CONTINUE FLASH FLOOD WATCH FOR 8 SOUTHERN 
COUNTIES FOR TONIGHT. LOW WILL BEGIN TO MOVE AWAY FROM THE AREA ON 
MONDAY...AND RAINFALL WILL DIMINISH. WITH CONTINUING SERIES OF WEAK 
SHORT WAVES...RAINFALL CHANCES WILL BE KEPT IN MOST AREAS THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY. MAXIMUM TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN A LITTLE BELOW NORMAL 
DUE TO CLOUD COVER AND PRECIPITATION. 
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
PLENTY OF MOISTURE WILL BE IN PLACE ACROSS THE AREA WEDNESDAY NIGHT 
THROUGH FRIDAY. SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL BRING ABUNDANT GULF MOISTURE 
INTO THE AREA. WILL CONTINUE WITH CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS ALL AREAS WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY. WILL 
DECREASE POPS FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY. HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS OVER 
THE SOUTHWEST U.S. OVER THE WEEKEND. WILL KEEP SUNDAY DRY AT THIS 
TIME AS NORTHWEST FLOW SETS UP AND WILL HAVE LESS MOISTURE TO WORK 
WITH. TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO BE A LITTLE BELOW NORMAL. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    67  83  67  85 /  50  50  20  30 
HARRISON AR       63  79  64  82 /  40  40  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    67  83  67  85 /  50  50  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     67  83  68  86 /  60  60  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  64  78  63  82 /  40  40  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     68  84  68  87 /  70  60  30  30 
SEARCY AR         67  82  66  84 /  50  50  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      67  83  67  85 /  50  50  30  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   65  82  66  83 /  40  40  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...FLASH FLOOD WATCH TONIGHT FOR 
ZONES ARZ062>069.
&&

$$

DUE TO CLOUD COVER AND PRECIPITATION. 
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
PLENTY OF MOISTURE WILL BE IN PLACE ACROSS THE AREA WEDNESDAY NIGHT 
THROUGH FRIDAY. SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL BRING ABUNDANT GULF MOISTURE 
INTO THE AREA. WILL CONTINUE WITH CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS ALL AREAS WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY. WILL 
DECREASE POPS FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY. HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS OVER 
THE SOUTHWEST U.S. OVER THE WEEKEND. WILL KEEP SUNDAY DRY AT THIS 
TIME AS NORTHWEST FLOW SETS UP AND WILL HAVE LESS MOISTURE TO WORK 
WITH. TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE TO BE A LITTLE BELOW NORMAL. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    67  83  67  85 /  50  50  20  30 
HARRISON AR       63  79  64  82 /  40  40  10  20 
HOT SPRINGS AR    67  83  67  85 /  50  50  30  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     67  83  68  86 /  60  60  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  64  78  63  82 /  40  40  10  20 
MONTICELLO AR     68  84  68  87 /  70  60  30  30 
SEARCY AR         67  82  66  84 /  50  50  20  20 
MOUNT IDA AR      67  83  67  85 /  50  50  30  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   65  82  66  83 /  40  40  20  20 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...FLASH FLOOD WATCH TONIGHT FOR 
ZONES ARZ062>069.
&&

22






000 
FXUS64 KLZK 270932
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT SUN JUN 27 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY
DRIER AIR HAS WORKED INTO CENTRAL ARKANSAS THIS MORNING FROM THE
NORTH. IN GENERAL...FROM LITTLE ROCK NORTHWARD...DEWPOINTS IN MID
50S/LOWER 60S. FARTHER SOUTH...SCATTERD TO NUMEROUS SHOWERS
AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE ONGOING...BUT WILL HAVE A
DIFFICULT TIME PUSHING NORTH INTO DRY AIR.

IN FORECAST...HAVE NO RAIN AT ALL MENTIONED TOWARD MISSOURI
BORDER. ISOLATED TO SCATTERED SHOWERS AND MAYBE A THUNDERSTORM
WILL OCCUR CLOSER TO LITTLE ROCK...WITH WIDESPREAD
PRECIPITATION IN THE SOUTHERN COUNTIES.

PRECIPITATION TRIGGERED BY SYSTEM ALOFT ARRIVING FROM TEXAS...WITH
THE SYSTEM INTERACTING WITH A NEARLY STATIONARY FRONT IN SOUTHERN
ARKANSAS. NEAR THE FRONT...SOME AREAS COULD RECEIVE 1 TO 2 INCHES
OF RAIN TODAY...WITH A FLASH FLOOD WATCH POSTED.

PATTERN WILL CHANGE VERY LITTLE THROUGH TONIGHT...WITH HIGH CHANCES
OF RAIN IN THE SOUTH...AND LITTLE TO NO CHANCE OF RAIN THE FARTHER
NORTH YOU GO.

ON MONDAY...SYSTEM IN TEXAS WILL FLATTEN WITH PRECIPITATION IN THE
SOUTH BECOMING MORE SCATTERED. APPEARS THAT MCS MAY ARRIVE IN
WEST CENTRAL ARKANSAS IN THE MORNING...AND BUILDING SOUTHEAST AS
IT WEAKENS. SO...CHANCE OF SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS WILL REMAIN IN
CENTRAL/SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE...WITH ONLY ISOLATED
THUNDER IN THE NORTH.

HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD INTO THE REGION FROM THE NORTH
TUESDAY/WEDNESDAY...AND THIS WILL KEEP THE FRONT ACROSS SOUTHERN
ARKANSAS. SEEMS LIKE A BROKEN RECORD...BUT WILL KEEP MENTIONING
SCATTERED PRECIPITATION NEAR THE FRONT...WITH CONTINUED DRY
WEATHER IN THE NORTH.

TEMPERATURES THROUGH THE PERIOD WILL REMAIN AT/BELOW NORMAL.
&&

.LONG TERM...WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
AN UPPER LOW WILL TAKE SHAPE OVER THE CENTRAL ROCKIES BY THE MIDDLE
OF THE WEEK. IT WILL SLIDE SLOWLY TO THE EAST ATTEMPTING TO KNOCK
DOWN THE RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE OVER THE SOUTHERN TIER OF STATES. THE
RIDGE GIVES UP SOME GROUND WHILE AT THE SAME TIME WEAKENING THE LOW.
TROF WILL BEGIN AFFECTING THE MID SOUTH FRIDAY MORNING AND IT WILL BE
EAST OF ARKANSAS BY 00Z SUNDAY. ONLY A WEAK SHEAR AXIS WILL REMAIN
OVER THE MISS RIVER VALLEY THROUGH 240 HOURS. THE SURFACE PATTERN
WILL BE MARKED BY WEAK FEATURES AS WELL. PLENTY OF MOISTURE AND
ABUNDANT DAYTIME HEATING WILL BE IN PLACE WHEN MINOR RIPPLES MOVE
OVER THE STATE IN ADVANCE OF UPPER TROF...SO WET PATTERN WILL
CONTINUE...ALONG WITH BELOW NORMAL HIGHS AND MUGGY LOWS.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    79  67  82  67 /  50  50  50  30
HARRISON AR       79  63  79  64 /  10  10  20  20
HOT SPRINGS AR    79  67  84  67 /  50  50  30  30
PINE BLUFF AR     78  67  84  68 /  60  60  50  30
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  78  64  79  63 /  10  10  20  20
MONTICELLO AR     78  68  84  68 /  70  70  60  30
SEARCY AR         79  67  82  66 /  40  40  40  20
MOUNT IDA AR      80  67  83  67 /  50  50  30  30
RUSSELLVILLE AR   80  65  82  66 /  30  30  30  30
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...FLOOD WATCH FOR FLASH
FLOODING IN SOUTHERN ARKANSAS TODAY FOR ZONES ARZ062>069.
&&

$$

46/32





000 
FXUS64 KLZK 270257
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
955 PM CDT SAT JUN 26 2004

.DISCUSSION...
RAIN HAS DECREASED MARKEDLY ACROSS THE SOUTH AND HAS MOSTLY DISSIPATED
ELSEWHERE. SURFACE RIDGE FROM THE NORTH COVERS THE AREA AND THERE IS
A WEAK 850 MB HIGH IN THE AREA CONTROLLING MOSTLY NORTHERN AND CENTRAL
SECTIONS OF ARKANSAS. HOWEVER THE UPPER LOW OVER TEXAS STILL SHOWS UP
WELL AND HEAVY MOISTURE IS STILL PRESENT ESPECIALLY IN THE SOUTH. 
DO NOT THINK THERE WILL BE MUCH RAIN IN THE CWA THE NEXT FEW HOURS
BUT AS THE UPPER LOW MOVES CLOSER LATER TONIGHT THINK RAIN COULD 
INCREASE AGAIN IN THE SOUTH OR MOVE IN FROM TEXAS AND LOUISIANA. 
ALSO THINK A GOOD CHANCE OF RAIN REMAINS EARLY SUNDAY AS THE UPPER 
LOW MOVES CLOSER AND BEGINS TO SHEAR ACROSS THE AREA. TO ACCOUNT FOR
THIS...LOWERED POPS FOR THE NEXT FEW HOURS ACROSS THE AREA...KEEPING
10 PERCENT IN THE NORTH AND 20 PERCENT ACROSS CENTRAL 
SECTIONS...WHICH WAS MAINTAINED FOR THE REST OF THE NIGHT. WENT DOWN
TO 30 PERCENT IN SOUTH CENTRAL AND 50 PERCENT IN FAR SOUTH BUT INCREASED
POPS TO 50 PERCENT IN SOUTH CENTRAL AND 70 PERCENT IN FAR SOUTH AFTER
09Z. KEPT POPS AS THEY WERE AFTER 11Z AND THROUGH SUNDAY. LEFT FLOOD
WATCH AS IS EVEN THOUGH THERE SHOULD NOT BE MUCH GOING ON THROUGH MUCH
OF THE NIGHT. DO THINK HEAVY RAIN THREAT WILL RETURN BY MORNING AND
CONTINUE INTO SUNDAY.  

&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
AR...FLOOD WATCH FOR FLASH FLOODING UNTIL 400 PM CDT SUNDAY FOR 
ZONES ARZ052>057...ARZ062>069.
&&

$$

29








000 
FXUS64 KLZK 262013
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT SAT JUN 26 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
EXCESSIVE RAINFALL POTENTIAL HIGHLIGHTS THE FIRST PART OF THE SHORT 
TERM. FRONTAL BOUNDARY OVER SOUTHERN ARKANSAS HAS ALL BUT STALLED 
OUT IN THE VICINITY OF THE LOUISIANA BORDER. CONVECTION HAS 
DEVELOPED NEAR AND TO THE SOUTH OF THE BOUNDARY. THIS TREND WILL 
CONTINUE TONIGHT...WITH ACTIVITY SPREADING NORTHWARD LATE TONIGHT AS 
UPPER LOW OVER TEXAS MOVES NORTHEAST...AND FRONTAL BOUNDARY WOBBLES 
BACK TO THE NORTH SLIGHTLY. 

BY SUNDAY...H5 SYSTEM BECOMES MORE OF AN OPEN WAVE IN THE VICINITY 
OF THE ARKLATEX...WITH SURFACE LOW DEVELOPING ALONG QUASI STATIONARY 
BOUNDARY. AT THIS TIME...LOOKS AS THOUGH THE FOCUS OF HEAVIEST 
PRECIP WILL BE OVER SOUTHERN ARKANSAS INITIALLY...SHIFTING NORTHWARD 
LATE TONIGHT...THEN EASTWARD AS THE SURFACE AND UPPER SYSTEMS LINE 
UP MORE WITH EACH OTHER AND UPPER DIVERGENCE INTENSIFIES.  

GIVEN THIS...THE AMOUNT OF MOISTURE IN PLACE...SLOW STORM 
MOTION...AND THE AMOUNT OF RAINFALL OVER SOUTHERN ARKANSAS IN THE 
PAST FEW WEEKS...WILL GO AHEAD AND ISSUE A FLASH FLOOD WATCH FOR MY 
SOUTHERN COUNTIES...ROUGHLY SOUTH OF A GLENWOOD...TO MALVERN...TO 
STUTTGART LINE THROUGH TOMORROW. AS FAR AS RAINFALL AMOUNTS...WOULD 
EXPECT TO SEE AVERAGE TOTALS OF ONE TO TWO INCHES...WITH LOCALLY 
HIGHER AMOUNTS. 

BY SUNDAY NIGHT...THE FORECAST AREA MAY GET A LITTLE BREAK...AS 
SURFACE LOW AND H5 SYSTEM MOVE INTO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY. HOWEVER...
BOUNDARY WILL STILL BE IN PLACE OVER SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. MODELS ALSO
HINTING AT MCS FORMATION OVER SOUTHERN KANSAS DURING THE NIGHT...OF 
WHICH THE REMAINS WOULD AFFECT NORTHERN ARKANSAS ON MONDAY 
AFTERNOON. MCS FORMATION MAY ALSO OCCUR ON MONDAY NIGHT OVER 
SOUTHERN MISSOURI/NORTHERN ARKANSAS AS SHORTWAVE MOVES ACROSS. 

BOTTOM LINE...UNSETTLED WEATHER WILL CONTINUE INTO MONDAY AND 
TUESDAY...AS PATTERN SHOWS LITTLE SIGN OF BUDGING. CONDITIONS WILL 
BE PARTLY TO MOSTLY CLOUDY THROUGH THE PERIOD...AND TEMPERATURES 
LOOK TO REMAIN WELL BELOW NORMAL FOR THIS TIME OF YEAR. 
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
AN UNSETTLED WEATHER PATTERN WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE WEEK. A 
SERIES OF UPPER LEVEL SHORT WAVES WILL AFFECT THE AREA. TIMING WILL 
BE A PROBLEM...SO HAVE PRETTY MUCH INCLUDED CHANCE POPS IN FOR MOST 
AREAS THROUGH THE WEEK. HIGH TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN A LITTLE BELOW 
NORMAL THROUGH THE WEEK WITH HIGHS IN THE 80S...AND LOWS IN THE 60S 
AND LOWER 70S. 
&&

.COORDINATION/COLLABORATION...
THANKS TO WFO MEMPHIS...SHREVEPORT...AND JACKSON FOR GREAT 
COORDINATION AND COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS THIS AFTERNOON. 
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    65  80  68  84 /  40  60  40  30 
HARRISON AR       60  78  62  79 /  10  30  30  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    64  79  63  85 /  60  60  40  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     67  80  67  83 /  70  80  50  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  59  77  63  79 /  10  30  30  30 
MONTICELLO AR     67  77  68  83 /  70  80  50  30 
SEARCY AR         64  78  67  84 /  30  60  40  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      64  80  62  85 /  50  50  40  30 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   62  81  64  84 /  20  50  30  30 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
AR...FLASH FLOOD WATCH FROM 400 PM CDT SATURDAY UNTIL 400 PM CDT
SUNDAY FOR ZONES ARZ052>057...ARZ062>069.
&&

SHORT TERM 57/LONG TERM 22







000 
FXUS64 KLZK 260905
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
355 AM CDT SAT JUN 26 2004

.SHORT TERM...
FRONT DROPPING SLOWLY SOUTHWARD THROUGH ARKANSAS THIS MORNING...
AND WILL EVENTUALLY SETUP IN SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE.
SLIGHTLY COOLER/DRIER AIR NORTH OF FRONT...WITH MUGGY
CONDITIONS/LOTS OF LOW LEVEL MOISTURE FARTHER SOUTH. AREAS
OF FOG FORMING IN CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS DURING THE PREDAWN
HOURS...AND WILL MENTION EARLY IN THE FORECAST.

AROUND FRONT...ISOLATED TO SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS
WILL POP UP TODAY. THIS WILL MAINLY BE NOTED IN THE SOUTHERN
COUNTIES. LITTLE TO NO PRECIPITATION MENTIONED NORTH OF
LITTLE ROCK.

FORECAST FAIRLY STRAIGHT FORWARD IN THE FIRST TWELVE HOURS...
THEN IT BECOMES RATHER COMPLEX. FRONT WILL BEGIN SLOWLY
HEADING BACK TO THE NORTH TONIGHT/SUNDAY. DEEP TROUGH OF
LOW PRESSURE IN TEXAS WILL MEANDER TO THE NORTHEAST. MEANWHILE...
ARKANSAS WILL BE CLOSE TO THE EXIT REGION OF A JET TO THE NORTH.
IT ALL ADDS UP TO A LOT OF LIFTING MECHANISMS...AND HEFTY CHANCES
OF RAIN.

FOR TONIGHT...HAVE SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS LIKELY SOUTH OF LITTLE
ROCK. LIKELY CHANCES SHIFT NORTH/EAST SUNDAY MORNING...WITH ROUGHLY
SOUTHEAST HALF OF THE STATE AFFECTED. GFS INSISTS ON WIDESPREAD 2
INCH PLUS RAINFALL AMOUNTS TONIGHT/SUNDAY. WHILE THIS IS LIKELY
OVERDONE...DID MENTION POSSIBILITY OF HEAVY RAIN CENTRAL/SOUTH
DURING THIS TIME FRAME. WILL LET DAY CREW EVALUATE SITUATION...
WITH FLASH FLOOD WATCH NOT OUT OF THE QUESTION.

TROUGH OF LOW PRESSURE WILL FLATTEN/HEAD EAST SUNDAY NIGHT...WITH
PRECIPITATION MORE SCATTERED. AGAIN...HIGHEST CHANCES OF RAIN
IN SOUTHEAST HALF OF STATE. LATE SUNDAY NIGHT...IS SOME INDICATION
THAT MCS WILL GET GOING IN THE SOUTHERN PLAINS...AND MAY APPROACH
WESTERN ARKANSAS TOWARD MONDAY MORNING.

ON MONDAY...WHATEVER IS LEFT OF THE MCS WILL SLIDE FROM WESTERN
INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. IN NORTHERN/EASTERN SECTIONS...MOSTLY
DRY WEATHER EXPECTED WITH HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN FROM THE
NORTH. FRONT IN THE STATE ON SUNDAY WILL SAG BACK TO THE SOUTH
IN RESPONSE TO THE HIGH.

SMALL CHANCES OF SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS MENTIONED ON TUESDAY IN
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS NEAR THE FRONT. MOSTLY DRY WEATHER WILL CONTINUE
NORTHERN/CENTRAL SECTIONS.

TEMPERATURES FAIRLY TRICKY...BUT WITH LOTS OF CLOUDS/CHANCES
FOR PRECIPITATION IN MUCH OF THE SHORT TERM...PRETTY GOOD BET THAT
READINGS WILL REMAIN BELOW NORMAL...ESPECIALLY DURING THE DAYTIME.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
LATEST GFS SOLUTION TAKES SFC BOUNDARY S OF AR BY MIDWEEK AS CENTER
OF HIGH PRES PASSES N OF THE STATE. HAVE FOLLOWED TRENDS OF GOING
FCST AND LEFT SMALL POPS IN FOR THAT TIMEFRAME WITH BNDRY STILL IN
CLOSE PROXIMITY TO AR. MOISTURE IS FCST TO RETURN IN EARNEST LATE IN
THE WEEK AS SFC HIGH SHIFTS EWD AND ANOTHER UPPER SYSTEM IS PROGGED
TO AFFECT THE FA. LEFT POPS IN CHC CAT FOR NOW AND WAIT TO SEE MORE
CONSISTENCY IN LATER MODEL RUNS. NO SIG CHGS MADE TO TEMPS THRU THE
PD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    82  66  78  66 /  20  40  60  40
HARRISON AR       77  61  77  61 /  10  10  30  20
HOT SPRINGS AR    82  66  78  65 /  30  40  60  40
PINE BLUFF AR     83  67  79  66 /  30  60  70  40
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  77  60  77  62 /  10  10  30  30
MONTICELLO AR     83  67  80  67 /  40  70  70  40
SEARCY AR         81  65  78  65 /  20  30  60  40
MOUNT IDA AR      82  66  79  65 /  20  40  60  30
RUSSELLVILLE AR   82  64  78  64 /  20  30  50  30
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.

964 
FXUS64 KLZK 260905
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
355 AM CDT SAT JUN 26 2004

.SHORT TERM...
FRONT DROPPING SLOWLY SOUTHWARD THROUGH ARKANSAS THIS MORNING...
AND WILL EVENTUALLY SETUP IN SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF THE STATE.
SLIGHTLY COOLER/DRIER AIR NORTH OF FRONT...WITH MUGGY
CONDITIONS/LOTS OF LOW LEVEL MOISTURE FARTHER SOUTH. AREAS
OF FOG FORMING IN CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS DURING THE PREDAWN
HOURS...AND WILL MENTION EARLY IN THE FORECAST.

AROUND FRONT...ISOLATED TO SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS
WILL POP UP TODAY. THIS WILL MAINLY BE NOTED IN THE SOUTHERN
COUNTIES. LITTLE TO NO PRECIPITATION MENTIONED NORTH OF
LITTLE ROCK.

FORECAST FAIRLY STRAIGHT FORWARD IN THE FIRST TWELVE HOURS...
THEN IT BECOMES RATHER COMPLEX. FRONT WILL BEGIN SLOWLY
HEADING BACK TO THE NORTH TONIGHT/SUNDAY. DEEP TROUGH OF
LOW PRESSURE IN TEXAS WILL MEANDER TO THE NORTHEAST. MEANWHILE...
ARKANSAS WILL BE CLOSE TO THE EXIT REGION OF A JET TO THE NORTH.
IT ALL ADDS UP TO A LOT OF LIFTING MECHANISMS...AND HEFTY CHANCES
OF RAIN.

FOR TONIGHT...HAVE SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS LIKELY SOUTH OF LITTLE
ROCK. LIKELY CHANCES SHIFT NORTH/EAST SUNDAY MORNING...WITH ROUGHLY
SOUTHEAST HALF OF THE STATE AFFECTED. GFS INSISTS ON WIDESPREAD 2
INCH PLUS RAINFALL AMOUNTS TONIGHT/SUNDAY. WHILE THIS IS LIKELY
OVERDONE...DID MENTION POSSIBILITY OF HEAVY RAIN CENTRAL/SOUTH
DURING THIS TIME FRAME. WILL LET DAY CREW EVALUATE SITUATION...
WITH FLASH FLOOD WATCH NOT OUT OF THE QUESTION.

TROUGH OF LOW PRESSURE WILL FLATTEN/HEAD EAST SUNDAY NIGHT...WITH
PRECIPITATION MORE SCATTERED. AGAIN...HIGHEST CHANCES OF RAIN
IN SOUTHEAST HALF OF STATE. LATE SUNDAY NIGHT...IS SOME INDICATION
THAT MCS WILL GET GOING IN THE SOUTHERN PLAINS...AND MAY APPROACH
WESTERN ARKANSAS TOWARD MONDAY MORNING.

ON MONDAY...WHATEVER IS LEFT OF THE MCS WILL SLIDE FROM WESTERN
INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. IN NORTHERN/EASTERN SECTIONS...MOSTLY
DRY WEATHER EXPECTED WITH HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN FROM THE
NORTH. FRONT IN THE STATE ON SUNDAY WILL SAG BACK TO THE SOUTH
IN RESPONSE TO THE HIGH.

SMALL CHANCES OF SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS MENTIONED ON TUESDAY IN
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS NEAR THE FRONT. MOSTLY DRY WEATHER WILL CONTINUE
NORTHERN/CENTRAL SECTIONS.

TEMPERATURES FAIRLY TRICKY...BUT WITH LOTS OF CLOUDS/CHANCES
FOR PRECIPITATION IN MUCH OF THE SHORT TERM...PRETTY GOOD BET THAT
READINGS WILL REMAIN BELOW NORMAL...ESPECIALLY DURING THE DAYTIME.
&&

.LONG TERM...TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
950 PM CDT FRI JUN 25 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS HAVE ALL DISSIPATED FROM LOSS OF HEATING. 
FRONTAL SYSTEM STILL SOMEWHERE IN THE CENTRAL PART OF THE STATE BUT
IT IS DIFFUSE AND BOUNDARIES FROM SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS HAVE
MADE LOCATION OF FRONT VERY TOUGH TO LOCATE. DOES NOT LOOK LIKE
THERE WILL BE MUCH IN THE WAY OF PRECIPITATION THE REST OF THE
NIGHT BUT WITH THE FRONT AROUND AND WARM HUMID AIR...KEPT MENTION 
OF A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FOR THE REST OF
THE NIGHT IN CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN SECTIONS. NORTH SHOULD STAY DRY
AS AIR IN THAT AREA IS A LITTLE DRIER. MIN FORECASTS KEPT ABOUT
THE SAME ALTHOUGH THERE ARE SIGNS THE SOUTH MAY NOT COOL OFF AS MUCH 
AS EXPECTED.

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
