29













000 
FXUS64 KLZK 251926
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
230 PM CDT FRI JUN 25 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
SOME CHALLENGES AHEAD FOR THE SHORT TERM...AS MONOTONOUS PATTERN 
CONTINUES. COLD FRONT SLOWLY PUSHING SOUTHWARD FROM NORTHERN 
ARKANSAS...NOT FAR FROM ITS POSITION AT 10 AM THIS MORNING. SYSTEM 
WILL CONTINUE TO SLOWLY SAG SOUTHWARD TONIGHT. INTERACTION WITH 
DAYTIME HEATING...AND SHORTWAVE OVER EASTERN ARKANSAS WILL ALLOW 
CHANCE FOR PRECIP FOR NORTHERN/CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS BEFORE 
MIDNIGHT...AND CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS AFTER MIDNIGHT. SHOWERS 
WILL BE POSSIBLE...AND TO A LESSER DEGREE THUNDERSTORMS. HAVE THUS 
GONE WITH ISOLATED THUNDER WORDING ALONG WITH COVERAGE OF SHOWERS. 

DUE TO HIGH BOUNDARY LAYER MOISTURE...AND LIGHT WINDS...COULD VERY 
WELL SEE SOME STRATUS AND FOG SETTING UP TONIGHT...INVOF AND TO THE 
SOUTH OF SURFACE BOUNDARY. THIS SHOULD DISPERSE BY MID MORNING 
SATURDAY. WILL CONTINUE ISOLATED/SCATTERED POPS FOR SATURDAY AND 
SATURDAY NIGHT...AS SURFACE BOUNDARY WILL SLOW DOWN/STALL OUT AND 
UPPER LOW WILL MOVE UP FROM TEXAS. 

BY SUNDAY...UPPER LOW WILL SWING ACROSS SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. GFS IS 
GENERATING ABOUT ONE TO TWO INCHES OF RAINFALL OVER SOUTHERN/EASTERN 
ARKANSAS AS THE LOW MOVES ACROSS. MODELS SEEM TO BE A BIT OVERDONE 
LATELY WITH REGARDS TO QPF...SO HAVE NOT QUITE GONE AS HIGH FOR 
RAINFALL AMOUNTS. WILL MONITOR THIS CLOSELY THOUGH...BECAUSE SLOW 
STORM MOTION AND 1-2 INCH PRECIPITABLE WATER COULD PRODUCE HEAVY 
RAINFALL IN SOME AREAS. 

BRIEF RESPITE MAY OCCUR MONDAY MORNING...AS UPPER SYSTEM HEADS INTO 
THE TENNESSEE VALLEY...AND AREA GETS DRY SLOTTED FROM THE SOUTHWEST. 
HOWEVER...BY MONDAY AFTERNOON...RAIN CHANCES WILL INCREASE AS 
ANOTHER SHORTWAVE MOVES DOWN OUT OF THE PLAINS.  

BOTTOM LINE IS THAT THIS IS GOING TO BE A LOW CONFIDENCE TEMPERATURE 
FORECAST IN THE SHORT TERM. WHILE GUIDANCE IS IN REASONABLE 
AGREEMENT...CLOUD COVER WILL WREAK HAVOC ESPECIALLY WITH THE MAXIMUM 
TEMPERATURE FORECAST. ALSO...AS FAR AS POPS GO...ETA SEEMS TO BE A 
BIT OVERDONE. HAVE GRAVITATED MORE TOWARD A BLEND OF THE MAV/FWC. 
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
INHERITED FORECAST LOOKED PRETTY GOOD TODAY. RAIN CHANCES THROUGH 
THE WEEK WITH STATIONARY FRONT MEANDERING THROUGH THE CWA. WITH THE 
UNCERTAINTY OF WHERE THE FRONT WILL BE...SLIGHT CHANCES ACROSS THE 
FORECAST AREA THROUGH THURSDAY ARE JUSTIFIED. HPC 5 DAY PRECIP SHOWS 
A THREE INCH BULLSEYE OVER THE ARKLATEX AREA. WITH THE TROPICAL 
AIRMASS NOT FAR TO THE SOUTH AND THE STATIONARY FRONT CLOSE 
BY...WILL NEED TO KEEP AN EYE ON RAINFALL AMOUNTS INTO THE MIDDLE OF 
NEXT WEEK.

LATE THURSDAY/EARLY FRIDAY GFS MOVES THE NEXT SHORTWAVE INTO THE 
MIDSOUTH. LOW PRESSURE DEVELOPS AHEAD OF IT...AND TRANSLATES ACROSS 
ARKANSAS THROUGH LATE WEEK. WENT AHEAD AND PUT SMALL RAIN CHANCES IN 
THE STATE THROUGH THE WEEK...AND WILL SEE HOW THE FORECAST PANS OUT 
AS TIME PROGRESSES.

TEMPERATURES LOOKED GOOD OVERALL. GFS WAS ON A WARMING TREND INTO 
THE END OF NEXT WEEK. FEEL THAT THIS IS JUSTIFIED...AS THE LOW 
PRESSURE SYSTEM TOWARDS THE ENDS OF NEXT WEEK WILL BRING A WARM 
FRONT NORTH OF THE STATE...ALLOWING NEAR NORMAL TEMPERATURES TO 
RETURN BY THURSDAY/FRIDAY.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    68  82  66  82 /  30  30  30  40 
HARRISON AR       58  77  59  79 /  10  20  20  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    66  82  65  82 /  30  40  40  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     69  83  68  83 /  30  40  40  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  58  77  59  79 /  10  10  20  30 
MONTICELLO AR     69  83  67  80 /  30  40  40  40 
SEARCY AR         65  81  64  81 /  20  20  30  40 
MOUNT IDA AR      66  82  64  82 /  20  40  40  40 
RUSSELLVILLE AR   65  82  63  81 /  20  20  30  40 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

000 
FXUS64 KLZK 251557 AAA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1057 AM CDT FRI JUN 25 2004

.DISCUSSION...
SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES COLD FRONT OVER NORTHERN ARKANSAS...ROUGHLY 
FROM KARG...TO NEAR KFSM. NOT MUCH ACTIVITY NOTED...EXCEPT OVER 
EASTERN ARKANSAS WHERE SHORTWAVE AND SURFACE BOUNDARY ARE 
INTERACTING. THIS AREA OF SHOWERS/ISOLD THUNDER WILL CONTINUE MOVING 
SOUTH/SOUTHEAST...AND MORE DEVELOPMENT IS EXPECTED TO OCCUR OVER 
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS THIS AFTERNOON. ABUNDANT LOW CLOUD COVER HAS BEEN 
NOTED...THOUGH SOME BREAKS HAVE BEEN OCCURRING IN THE LAST HOUR OR 
SO. 

HAVE SENT OUT AN UPDATE...FOR SEVERAL REASONS. FIRST AND 
FOREMOST...HAVE REMOVED MENTION OF PATCHY FOG...AS WELL AS OTHER 
TEMPORAL WORDING. SECOND...HAVE REALIGNED POPS A BIT...MAINLY TO 
REMOVE MENTION IN THE NORTHWESTERN GROUP OF ZONES. HAVE BASICALLY 
KEPT 20S AND 30S CENTRAL...AND 30S/40S SOUTH AND EAST. 
FINALLY...HAVE READJUSTED FORECAST MAXIMUM TEMPERATURES IN SOME 
LOCATIONS FOR THIS AFTERNOON. CLOUD COVER WILL PLAY HAVOC WITH THE 
TEMPERATURE FORECAST...NO DOUBT ABOUT IT. HAVE BASICALLY UPPED 
READINGS A DEGREE OR TWO IN THE NORTHEAST...WHERE LOW CLOUDS HAVE 
THINNED OUT...AND LOWERED READINGS A DEGREE OR TWO IN THE 
SOUTHEAST...WHERE LOW CLOUD DECK REMAINS BROKEN/OVERCAST AND RAIN 
CHANCES WILL BE GREATEST. 

HAVE ALSO UPDATED GRIDS TO BETTER ACCOUNT FOR ONGOING TRENDS. 
UPDATED GRIDS...TEXT...AND GRAPHICS HAVE BEEN SENT. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

$$

000 
FXUS64 KLZK 250909
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
400 AM CDT FRI JUN 25 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH MONDAY
SAME OLD TREND WILL HOLD TRUE THROUGH THE NEXT FEW DAYS. AS
OF LATE...FRONTS HAVE MOVED THROUGH THE REGION FROM THE NORTH
AND HAVE STALLED...WITH ONGOING CHANCES FOR RAIN. SO IT IS NO
SURPRISE TO HAVE YET ANOTHER FRONT PUSH INTO ARKANSAS TODAY FROM
MISSOURI.

MOISTURE AHEAD OF THE FRONT PRETTY MUCH CONFINED TO SOUTHERN
SECTIONS OF THE STATE...WITH CHANCE OF SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS
MENTIONED THERE TODAY. FARTHER NORTH...A SLIGHT CHANCE OF
THUNDER AT BEST WITH LIMITED MOISTURE IN PLACE.

FRONT APPEARS TO DIVE INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS OR NORTHERN
LOUISIANA BEFORE COMING TO A HALT. GIVEN THIS...KEPT SMALL
CHANCES FOR SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS THROUGH SATURDAY IN THE
SOUTHERN COUNTIES. IN NORTHERN/CENTRAL SECTIONS...LOOKS LIKE
SLIGHTLY COOLER/DRIER AIR WILL FILTER IN ON A NORTH/NORTHEAST
WIND. AT THIS TIME...FIRST PART OF WEEKEND LOOKS PLEASANT.

FRONT WILL BEGIN TO HEAD BACK TO THE NORTH ON SUNDAY. CLOUDS
WILL INCREASE...WITH BETTER CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION
STATEWIDE TO END THE WEEKEND/EARLY NEXT WEEK. WITH CLOUDS
AND PRECIPITATION...DAYTIME READINGS WILL BE HELD BELOW
NORMAL.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
APPEARS THE FA WL RMN UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF SFC FNTL BNDRY THRU
MOST OF THE PD. STILL NOT HAVING HIGH CONFIDENCE WITH THE GFS RUN
THIS MRNG AS MODEL SEEMS TO HAVING CONVECTIVE FEEDBACK ISSUES...
ESPECIALLY IN THE EARLY PART OF THE FCST PD. WITH FNTL SYSTEM
EXPECTED TO LINGER OVR AR...HAVE LEFT CHC POPS THRU MOST OF THE TIME
PD. NO SIG CHANGES MADE TO GOING TEMP FCST.
&&


.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

SAME OLD TREND WILL HOLD TRUE THROUGH THE NEXT FEW DAYS. AS
OF LATE...FRONTS HAVE MOVED THROUGH THE REGION FROM THE NORTH
AND HAVE STALLED...WITH ONGOING CHANCES FOR RAIN. SO IT IS NO
SURPRISE TO HAVE YET ANOTHER FRONT PUSH INTO ARKANSAS TODAY FROM
MISSOURI.

MOISTURE AHEAD OF THE FRONT PRETTY MUCH CONFINED TO SOUTHERN
SECTIONS OF THE STATE...WITH CHANCE OF SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS
MENTIONED THERE TODAY. FARTHER NORTH...A SLIGHT CHANCE OF
THUNDER AT BEST WITH LIMITED MOISTURE IN PLACE.

FRONT APPEARS TO DIVE INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS OR NORTHERN
LOUISIANA BEFORE COMING TO A HALT. GIVEN THIS...KEPT SMALL
CHANCES FOR SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS THROUGH SATURDAY IN THE
SOUTHERN COUNTIES. IN NORTHERN/CENTRAL SECTIONS...LOOKS LIKE
SLIGHTLY COOLER/DRIER AIR WILL FILTER IN ON A NORTH/NORTHEAST
WIND. AT THIS TIME...FIRST PART OF WEEKEND LOOKS PLEASANT.

FRONT WILL BEGIN TO HEAD BACK TO THE NORTH ON SUNDAY. CLOUDS
WILL INCREASE...WITH BETTER CHANCES FOR PRECIPITATION
STATEWIDE TO END THE WEEKEND/EARLY NEXT WEEK. WITH CLOUDS
AND PRECIPITATION...DAYTIME READINGS WILL BE HELD BELOW
NORMAL.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
APPEARS THE FA WL RMN UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF SFC FNTL BNDRY THRU
MOST OF THE PD. STILL NOT HAVING HIGH CONFIDENCE WITH THE GFS RUN
THIS MRNG AS MODEL SEEMS TO HAVING CONVECTIVE FEEDBACK ISSUES...
ESPECIALLY IN THE EARLY PART OF THE FCST PD. WITH FNTL SYSTEM
EXPECTED TO LINGER OVR AR...HAVE LEFT CHC POPS THRU MOST OF THE TIME
PD. NO SIG CHANGES MADE TO GOING TEMP FCST.
&&


.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

REACH NORTHERN SECTIONS BY MORNING. WITH THIS IN MIND...LOWERED POPS
TO 20 PERCENT ACROSS NORTHERN AND CENTRAL SECTIONS FOR THE REST OF

40 PERCENT IN THE SOUTH. MIN FORECASTS LOOK LIKE THEY COULD BE A LITTLE
LOW IN CENTRAL SECTIONS BASED ON DEW POINTS BUT LEFT THEM AS THEY 
ARE. DID ADJUST DEW POINTS UP A LITTLE AND HAVE MOST AREAS SATURATED
BY MORNING. MADE MINOR ADJUSTMENT TO WIND FORECASTS BASED ON

TO MOVE BACK AND FORTH ACROSS THE STATE SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY. THE CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL CONTINUE 
THROUGH THE EXTENDED PERIOD. A RATHER PROGRESSIVE PATTERN CAN BE 
EXPECTED TO BEGIN SUNDAY NIGHT. ZONAL FLOW WILL ALLOW SHORT WAVES TO 
MOVE ALONG THE FRONT AND TRIGGER THUNDERSTORMS AS THEY MOVE THROUGH. 
INCREASED POPS SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY...OTHERWISE ONLY MINOR 
ADJUSTMENTS WERE MADE. WITH ABUNDANT CLOUDS AND PRECIPITATION... 
TEMPERATURES WILL BE SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL. DEPENDING ON HOW THE 
FRONT MOVES (OR DOES NOT MOVE) CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN ARKANSAS COULD 
EXPERIENCE SOME SIGNIFICANT RAINFALL ACCUMULATIONS.

186 
FXUS64 KLZK 240747
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
241 AM CDT THU JUN 24 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT...
ONCE AGAIN...IT APPEARS THE ETA SOLUTION HAS A BETTER HANDLE ON THE 
OVERALL SITUATION. ETA SEEMS TO HAVE INITIALIZED BETTER OVER THE 
SOUTH THAN THE GFS BASED OFF SATELLITE AND RADAR SIGNATURES. ONCE 
AGAIN NUMEROUS CONVECTIVE FEEDBACK PROBLEMS ARE SEEN ON THE GFS. GFS 
DEVELOPS A SERIES OF CONVECTIVE BOMBS ALONG THE STALLED OUT BOUNDARY 
AND SEEMS COMPLETELY OVERDONE. IN ADDITION...GFS HAS HAD A POOR 
TRACK RECORD OF LATE AND ONCE AGAIN WILL BE TOSSED IN FAVOR OF THE 
ETA SOLUTION.

CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS FRONTAL BOUNDARY HAS CREEPED 
NORTHWARD OVER THE PAST SEVERAL HOURS AND IS NOW LYING ACROSS THE 
SOUTHERN SECTION OF THE STATE. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS CONTINUE 
OVER SOUTHERN ARKANSAS...JUST TO THE SOUTH OF THE CWA. MODELS 
SHOWING MORE OF A NORTHERN PUSH TO THIS FEATURE THAN PREVIOUS RUNS. 
WAVE DEVELOPS ON THE FRONT THIS AFTERNOON OVER EASTERN TEXAS AND 
MOVES IT NORTHEAST INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS TONIGHT AND EVENTUALLY 
INTO NORTHERN MISSISSIPPI. WILL NEED TO REWORK POPS SOMEWHAT OVER 
THE SOUTH AND INTRODUCE SLIGHT CHANCES POPS THIS AFTERNOON TO THE 
CENTRAL PART OF THE STATE. WILL HOLD ONTO PATCHY FOG THIS MORNING 
BASED ON CURRENT OBS.

MOVEMENT OF THE WAVE WILL BE SLOW IN OVERALL WEAK FLOW ALOFT. WITH 
TROPICAL MOISTURE IN PLACE...POPS WILL NEED TO BE RAISED OVER THE 
SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST TONIGHT. BIGGEST QUESTION IS HOW FAR NORTH TO 
CARRY POPS. LOW LEVEL JET IN A FAVORABLE POSITION TONIGHT AND EVEN 
THOUGH BEST LIFT IS TO THE SOUTH...WOULD BE REMISS IF SCATTERED POPS 
WERE NOT INTRODUCED AS FAR NORTH AS THE METRO.
 
OVERALL SYNOPTIC PATTERN TO CONTINUE THROUGH THE PERIOD WITH HIGH 
AMPLITUDE BLOCKING PATTERN FORECASTED BY ALL MODELS. UPPER LEVEL 
RIDGING WILL REMAIN OVER THE WESTERN CONUS WITH UNUSUALLY DEEP EARLY 
SUMMER POLAR VORTEX OVER SOUTH CENTRAL CANADA. VORTEX WILL SLOWLY 
SHIFT EAST WITH TIME BUT SHORTWAVE ENERGY EJECTING OUT WILL HELP 
PUSH ANOTHER COLD FRONT TOWARDS THE REGION TONIGHT AND FRIDAY. 
SCATTERED SHOWERS WILL ACCOMPANY THE FEATURE BUT OVERALL DYNAMICS 
AND WEAK AND ONLY LOW SCATTERED POPS ARE WARRANTED. BOUNDARY PRESSES 
THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT AND STALLS OVER SOUTHERN ARKANSAS/NORTHERN 
LOUISIANA.

FRONTAL BOUNDARY APPEARS TO JUST WOBBLE AROUND FOR THE WEEKEND AS H5 
RIDGING OVER THE EASTERN GULF COAST PRECLUDES ANY MOVEMENT OF THE 
BOUNDARY. PLENTY OF TROPICAL MOISTURE IN PLACE AND FLOW ALOFT WILL
BRING SEVERAL IMPULSES ACROSS THE AREA FOR A CONTINUED CHANCE OF 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. MODELS BRING A PARTICULARLY STRONG WAVE 
ACROSS THE BOUNDARY SATURDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH MID DAY SUNDAY AND 
PRODUCES SOME IMPRESSIVE QPF. BASED ON THE HIGH QPF FORECASTS FROM 
THE MODELS OF LATE...WILL TAKE A WAIT AND SEE APPROACH BUT POTENTIAL 
FOR HEAVY RAIN WILL EXIST IN THIS TIME FRAME.

TEMPERATURES WILL REMAIN BELOW SEASONABLE OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS 
WITH CLOUDS AND PRECIPITATION ABOUT. MAV/FWC/ETA NUMBERS ALL WITHIN 
A DEGREE OR TWO OR THREE OF EACH OTHER AND SEEM REASONABLE. A BLEND 
OF THE GUIDANCE WILL BE USED. TEMPERATURES MIGHT NOT GET OUT OF THE 
70S SUNDAY IF PRECIPITATION BEING ADVERTISED BY MODELS COMES TO 
FRUITION.
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY...
STRONG HIGH PRESSURE WILL REMAIN OFF THE ATLANTIC COAST DURING EARLY 
NEXT WEEK...WITH PLENTY OF MOISTURE IN PLACE. THE COLD FRONT WILL 
HAVE A HARD TIME MAKING MUCH PROGRESS IN ANY DIRECTION DUE TO THE 
STRONG RIDGE. AT THIS TIME...THE FRONT SHOULD STAY ACROSS SOUTHERN 
ARKANSAS OR EVEN SLIGHTLY FURTHER SOUTH. SEVERAL UPPER LEVEL 
DISTURBANCES WILL MOVE ALONG THE FRONT FOR CONTINUING CHANCES OF 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN WILL REMAIN A CONCERN. 
OVERALL...ONLY MINOR CHANGES MADE TO THE EXTENDED FORECAST...WITH 
TEMPERATURES REMAINING SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL DUE TO THE UNSETTLED 
WEATHER.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
255 PM CDT WED JUN 23 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
STATIONARY FRONT REMAINS NEAR AR/LA BORDER THIS AFTERNOON...WITH 
HIGH PRESSURE TRYING TO PUSH INTO THE STATE. HIGH CLOUDS COVER THE 
SE HALF OF THE STATE...WITH A CU FIELD UNDERNEATH ACROSS MOST OF THE 
STATE. EXPECT FRONT TO SAG SOUTH A BIT...OUT OF THE FORECAST 
AREA...WHICH WILL END RAIN CHANCES ACROSS THE SOUTH THIS EVENING. 

ONCE THE SUN SETS...EXPECT SKIES TO CLEAR OUT ACROSS NORTHERN 
ARKANSAS...WHILE HIGH CLOUDS REMAIN OVER THE SOUTH. EXPECT STRATUS 
DECK IN THE SOUTH AND SCATTERED STRATUS CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE 
STATE EARLY THURSDAY.

MODELS DEVELOP A LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM ALONG THE FRONT EARLY 
THURSDAY...AND CARRY IT THROUGH NORTHERN MS AND INTO TN. TRACK LOOKS 
GOOD WITH ETA/NGM/GFS IN AGREEMENT. THREW SLIGHT CHANCES FOR PRECIP 
IN THE SOUTHEAST THROUGH THURSDAY AND THURSDAY NIGHT WITH THE 
SYSTEM...AND KEPT MOSTLY CLOUDY SKIES CONFINED TO THAT AREA.

ANOTHER COLD FRONT DROPS OUT OF THE PLAINS FRIDAY. ETA LOOKS TO HAVE 
A BETTER HANDLE ON THE SITUATION. EXPECT SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
TO DEVELOP AHEAD OF IT...BEGINNING LATE MORNING/EARLY AFTERNOON IN 
THE NORTH. HOW FAR THE FRONT WILL MAKE IT INTO THE STATE IS 
DEFINETLY A QUESTION AT THIS TIME...AND WILL CAUSE MORE UNCERTAINTY 
IN SATURDAYS FORECAST. PUT BEST CHANCES FOR RAIN FRIDAY 
EVENING/EARLY NIGHT ACROSS CENTRAL AR...AND CONTINUED CHANCES ON 
SATURDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
THINGS LOOKING AWFULLY SIMILAR TO YESTERDAYS MODEL SOLUTIONS IN THE 
EXTENDED RANGE. FRONTAL BOUNDARY APPEARS TO WOBBLE AROUND FOR 
SEVERAL DAYS...AS H5 RIDGING OVER THE EASTERN GULF COAST PRECLUDES 
ANY FORWARD PROGRESSION OF THE SYSTEM. WITH THE GULF OPEN 
UP...PLENTY OF MOISTURE WILL BE IN PLACE. FLOW ALOFT WILL BE 
SOUTHWESTERLY...AND WILL BRING SEVERAL IMPULSES ACROSS THE FORECAST 
AREA. ALL THIS WILL INTERACT WITH DAYTIME HEATING AND ANY OUTFLOW 
BOUNDARIES LEFT OVER...ALLOWING FOR A CONTINUED CHANCE OF SHOWERS 
AND THUNDERSTORMS. 

BOTTOM LINE...UNSETTLED WEATHER WILL DOMINATE IN DAYS 4 THROUGH 7. 
IF THE AFOREMENTIONED SCENARIO PANS OUT...CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN 
ARKANSAS MAY SEE SOME SIGNIFICANT RAINFALL ACCUMULATIONS. THIS FAR 
OUT...IT IS STILL A BIT EARLY TO SAY FOR SURE...GIVEN THE TIMING 
UNCERTAINTY. THE SITUATION WILL BE MONITORED CLOSELY. 
&&


294 
FXUS64 KLZK 230844 CCA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...CORRECTED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
341 AM CDT WED JUN 23 2004

.SHORT TERM...TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT...
SOME RATHER LARGE DIFFERENCES IN THE MODELS ARE NOTED THIS MORNING 
ACROSS THE REGION. WHILE THE SHORT TERM MODELS ALL DEPICT THE SAME 
OVERALL FLOW AND THE PLACEMENT OF THE SURFACE BOUNDARY...THERE ARE 
SOME SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCES IN THE LOCATION AND STRENGTH OF A 
SURFACE LOW AND THE ASSOCIATED QPF. GFS DEPICTING A LOW OVER 
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS THAT MOVES NORTHEAST THROUGH MORNING WITH HIGH 
QPF. ETA ONLY HINTS AT A SURFACE LOW AND HAS IT FURTHER NORTHEAST 
AND CONSIDERABLY WEAKER WITH SIGNIFICANTLY LESS QPF.

CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES WEAK LOW PRESSURE ALONG THE 
MISSISSIPPI RIVER. AREA RADARS CONTINUE TO SHOW ONLY ISOLATED TO 
SCATTERED SHOWERS OVER THE SOUTH. GFS SOLUTION WILL BE DISCARDED AS 
THE ETA SOLUTION SEEMS MUCH MORE REALISTIC.

IN ADDITION TO THE AFOREMENTIONED SURFACE LOW...LATEST ANALYSIS 
PLACES A COLD FRONT ROUGHLY FROM A WEST MEMPHIS TO BRINKLEY TO 
FORDYCE TO MAGNOLIA LINE. SKIES HAVE CLEARED OUT RAPIDLY AFTER FROPA 
ACROSS THE NORTH AND WEST WITH FOG/STRATUS NOW PREDOMINATING. WILL 
NEED TO ADD FOG TO THE ZONES/GRIDS THIS MORNING BUT IT DOES NOT 
APPEAR TO BE DENSE ENOUGH TO WARRANT ANY HIGHLIGHTS. MODELS DO SHOW 
THE FRONT SLOWING DOWN SO SOME MORNING POPS ARE NEEDED OVER THE 
SOUTH. FRONT SHOULD CLEAR THE STATE BY MIDDAY...WITH DRY CONDITIONS 
AREA WIDE THIS AFTERNOON DUE TO HIGH PRESSURE AND DRIER AIR BUILDING 
DOWN FROM THE NORTH.

FRONT REMAINS STALLED OUT ACROSS CENTRAL LOUISIANA THROUGH THURSDAY 
WITH SOME DEEPER MOISTURE CREEPING BACK INTO THE EXTREME SOUTHEAST 
AS A SHORT WAVE MOVES ALONG IT. WILL NEED TO CARRY AT LEAST SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS HERE THURSDAY AS RETURNS FLOW STARTS TO GET 
REESTABLISHED. WILL LEAVE THE REMAINDER OF THE AREA DRY FOR NOW.

OVERALL PATTERN REALLY DOES NOT CHANGE MUCH THROUGH THE PERIOD WITH 
DEEP LOW PRESSURE IN THE EASTERN PACIFIC...A BLOCKING RIDGE ALONG 
THE WEST COAST AND AN RATHER IMPRESSIVE...BY JUNE STANDARDS...POLAR 
VORTEX ACROSS MANITOBA AND ONTARIO PROVINCES. NEXT POLAR FRONT DROPS 
DOWN THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY. FRONT DOES NOT APPEAR TO BE OVERLY 
DYNAMIC AT THIS POINT WITH LITTLE SURFACE CONVERGENCE AND LIFT 
NOTED. ONLY SCATTERED POPS SEEM WARRANTED AT THIS POINT AND CURRENT 
FORECAST HAS IT COVERED. FRONT PASSES THROUGH THE STATE FRIDAY BUT 
STALLS OUT ACROSS NORTHERN LOUISIANA. FRONT JUST SORT OF WAFFLES 
AROUND FOR SATURDAY WITH SHORT WAVE RIPPLING ALONG IT FOR A 
CONTINUING CHANCE POPS. MODELS NOW PICKING UP IN A NEW WAVE WHICH 
SWINGS INTO NORTHEAST OKLAHOMA BY LATE SATURDAY. WILL NEED TO KEEP 
POPS IN THE REMAINDER OF THE AREA TO ACCOUNT FOR THIS FEATURE.

FWC NUMBERS SEEM TOO WARM...ESPECIALLY WITH MORNING FOG/STRATUS... 
WHILE MAV GUIDANCE IS A LITTLE TOO COOL. WILL SPLIT THE DIFFERENCE 
TODAY AND THROUGH OUT THE PERIOD. TEMPERATURES WILL AVERAGE BELOW 
NORMAL OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS WITH WEAK NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT. 
SOUTHERLY FLOW GETS REESTABLISHED FRIDAY FOR WARMER CONDITIONS 
BEFORE NEXT FRONT DROPS TEMPS A FEW DEGREES FOR SATURDAY.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY...
UNSETTLED WEATHER WILL CONTINUE FOR THE BEGINNING OF NEXT 
WEEK...WITH THE AFOREMENTIONED FRONT REMAINING NEAR THE SOUTHERN 
SECTIONS. SEVERAL DISTURBANCES WILL MOVE ALONG THE FRONT...AND 
CURRENT FORECAST OF CHANCE POPS LOOKS GOOD. TEMPERATURES WILL BE 
SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL DUE TO CLOUD COVER AND PRECIPITATION. 
OVERALL...ONLY MINOR CHANGES MADE TO EXTENDED GRIDS.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    84  64  84  67 /  20  10  10  10 
HARRISON AR       82  60  83  64 /  10  10  10  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  64  84  67 /  10  10  10  10 
PINE BLUFF AR     84  65  84  68 /  30  10  10  10 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  82  60  83  64 /  10  10  10  10 
MONTICELLO AR     85  66  84  68 /  40  20  10  10

SOUTHERN ARKANSAS THAT MOVES NORTHEAST THROUGH MORNING WITH HIGH 
QPF. ETA ONLY HINTS AT A SURFACE LOW AND HAS IT FURTHER NORTHEAST 
AND CONSIDERABLY WEAKER WITH SIGNIFICANTLY LESS QPF.

CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES WEAK LOW PRESSURE ALONG THE 
MISSISSIPPI RIVER. AREA RADARS CONTINUE TO SHOW ONLY ISOLATED TO 
SCATTERED SHOWERS OVER THE SOUTH. GFS SOLUTION WILL BE DISCARDED AS 
THE ETA SOLUTION SEEMS MUCH MORE REALISTIC.

IN ADDITION TO THE AFOREMENTIONED SURFACE LOW...LATEST ANALYSIS 
PLACES A COLD FRONT ROUGHLY FROM A WEST MEMPHIS TO BRINKLEY TO 
FORDYCE TO MAGNOLIA LINE. SKIES HAVE CLEARED OUT RAPIDLY AFTER FROPA 
ACROSS THE NORTH AND WEST WITH FOG/STRATUS NOW PREDOMINATING. WILL 
NEED TO ADD FOG TO THE ZONES/GRIDS THIS MORNING BUT IT DOES NOT 
APPEAR TO BE DENSE ENOUGH TO WARRANT ANY HIGHLIGHTS. MODELS DO SHOW 
THE FRONT SLOWING DOWN SO SOME MORNING POPS ARE NEEDED OVER THE 
SOUTH. FRONT SHOULD CLEAR THE STATE BY MIDDAY...WITH DRY CONDITIONS 
AREA WIDE THIS AFTERNOON DUE TO HIGH PRESSURE AND DRIER AIR BUILDING 
DOWN FROM THE NORTH.

FRONT REMAINS STALLED OUT ACROSS CENTRAL LOUISIANA THROUGH THURSDAY 
WITH SOME DEEPER MOISTURE CREEPING BACK INTO THE EXTREME SOUTHEAST 
AS A SHORT WAVE MOVES ALONG IT. WILL NEED TO CARRY AT LEAST SLIGHT 
CHANCE POPS HERE THURSDAY AS RETURNS FLOW STARTS TO GET 
REESTABLISHED. WILL LEAVE THE REMAINDER OF THE AREA DRY FOR NOW.

OVERALL PATTERN REALLY DOES NOT CHANGE MUCH THROUGH THE PERIOD WITH 
DEEP LOW PRESSURE IN THE EASTERN PACIFIC...A BLOCKING RIDGE ALONG 
THE WEST COAST AND AN RATHER IMPRESSIVE...BY JUNE STANDARDS...POLAR 
VORTEX ACROSS MANITOBA AND ONTARIO PROVINCES. NEXT POLAR FRONT DROPS 
DOWN THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY. FRONT DOES NOT APPEAR TO BE OVERLY 
DYNAMIC AT THIS POINT WITH LITTLE SURFACE CONVERGENCE AND LIFT 
NOTED. ONLY SCATTERED POPS SEEM WARRANTED AT THIS POINT AND CURRENT 
FORECAST HAS IT COVERED. FRONT PASSES THROUGH THE STATE FRIDAY BUT 
STALLS OUT ACROSS NORTHERN LOUISIANA. FRONT JUST SORT OF WAFFLES 
AROUND FOR SATURDAY WITH SHORT WAVE RIPPLING ALONG IT FOR A 
CONTINUING CHANCE POPS. MODELS NOW PICKING UP IN A NEW WAVE WHICH 
SWINGS INTO NORTHEAST OKLAHOMA BY LATE SATURDAY. WILL NEED TO KEEP 
POPS IN THE REMAINDER OF THE AREA TO ACCOUNT FOR THIS FEATURE.

FWC NUMBERS SEEM TOO WARM...ESPECIALLY WITH MORNING FOG/STRATUS... 
WHILE MAV GUIDANCE IS A LITTLE TOO COOL. WILL SPLIT THE DIFFERENCE 
TODAY AND THROUGH OUT THE PERIOD. TEMPERATURES WILL AVERAGE BELOW 
NORMAL OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS WITH WEAK NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT. 
SOUTHERLY FLOW GETS REESTABLISHED FRIDAY FOR WARMER CONDITIONS 
BEFORE NEXT FRONT DROPS TEMPS A FEW DEGREES FOR SATURDAY.
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY...
UNSETTLED WEATHER WILL CONTINUE FOR THE BEGINNING OF NEXT 
WEEK...WITH THE AFOREMENTIONED FRONT REMAINING NEAR THE SOUTHERN 
SECTIONS. SEVERAL DISTURBANCES WILL MOVE ALONG THE FRONT...AND 
CURRENT FORECAST OF CHANCE POPS LOOKS GOOD. TEMPERATURES WILL BE 
SLIGHTLY BELOW NORMAL DUE TO CLOUD COVER AND PRECIPITATION. 
OVERALL...ONLY MINOR CHANGES MADE TO EXTENDED GRIDS.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    84  64  84  67 /  20  10  20  40 
HARRISON AR       82  60  83  64 /  10  10  10  40 
HOT SPRINGS AR    84  64  84  67 /  10  10  10  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     84  65  84  68 /  30  10  30  40

.DISCUSSION...
SCATTERED SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS DEVELOPED OVER CENTRAL/SOUTHERN 
ARKANSAS...WITH HEAVY RAIN IN SOME AREAS. NORTH LITTLE ROCK RECEIVED
1.66 INCHES...WITH A DAILY TOTAL/RECORD OF 2.29 INCHES. SEVERAL 
LANDSPOUTS SEEN BY OBSERVERS TUESDAY EVENING...WITH NUMEROUS PHONE 
CALLS. HANDLED SITUATION WITH SPECIAL WEATHER STATEMENT TO EXPLAIN 
WHAT WAS GOING ON. 
   
PRECIPITATION APPEARS TO BE WANING LATE THIS EVENING...AND IS 
CONFINED MAINLY TO AREAS SOUTH AND EAST OF LITTLE ROCK.

A COLD FRONT WILL PUSH FROM CENTRAL INTO SOUTHERN ARKANSAS 
OVERNIGHT. STILL A CHANCE OF SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS THROUGH WEDNESDAY 
MORNING ALONG/AHEAD OF FRONT. 

FRONT WILL PUSH SOUTH OF THE REGION WEDNESDAY NIGHT...WITH A BRIEF 
PERIOD OF TRANQUIL WEATHER.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT TUE JUN 22 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
FRONTAL SYSTEM OVER NORTHERN ARKANSAS WILL CONTINUE TO MOVE SLOWLY 
SOUTHEASTWARD TONIGHT. SURFACE LOW WILL DEVELOP AND MOVE ALONG THE 
FRONT OVERNIGHT. HAVE LOWERED POPS TO SLIGHT CHANCE FOR NORTHWESTERN 
SECTIONS FOR TONIGHT WITH HIGHER CHANCES AS YOU PROGRESS 
SOUTHEASTWARD. POPS WILL CONTINUE TO DECREASE ON WEDNESDAY AS FRONT 
MOVES SOUTHEASTWARD OUT OF THE STATE. HOWEVER...FRONT WILL STALL 
JUST SOUTH OF ARKANSAS BY WEDNESDAY NIGHT. WITH CLOSENESS OF FRONT 
TO EXTREME SOUTHERN ARKANSAS...HAVE LEFT SMALL CHANCES IN THOSE 
AREAS THROUGH THURSDAY. MOISTURE SHOULD BEGIN TO RETURN BY THURSDAY 
NIGHT AS NEXT FRONT APPROACHES FROM THE NORTHWEST. WILL INCREASE 
POPS AGAIN BEGINNING THURSDAY NIGHT AND CONTINUING INTO FRIDAY. 
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
MODELS NOT PAINTING A BRIGHT PICTURE FOR THE EXTENDED PERIODS. 
LATEST RUNS INDICATE FRONTAL BOUNDARY WOBBLING AROUND IN THE 
VICINITY OF SOUTHERN ARKANSAS THROUGHOUT MUCH OF THE EXTENDED 
PERIOD. WITH RIDGING OVER THE SOUTHEAST THAT DOESNT SEEM TO WANT TO 
BUDGE...THIS SEEMS REASONABLE. 

UPPER FLOW BEHIND THE FRONT WILL BE NORTHWESTERLY...AND SEVERAL 
SYSTEMS WILL MOVE DOWN IN THE MEAN FLOW...INTERACTING WITH THE 
FRONT. THUS...THERE WILL BE A CONTINUED CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS FOR THE ENTIRE PERIOD...WITH THE BEST CHANCES OVER 
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS...CLOSEST TO SURFACE BOUNDARY. BY DAY 7...
BOUNDARY LOOKS TO MOVE BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT...AS 
UPPER FLOW BECOMES SOUTHWESTERLY. 
&&

.DISCUSSION...

OTHERWISE LEFT POPS PRETTY MUCH THE SAME FOR THIS AFTERNOON. NEW ETA 
AND NGM MOVING FRONT SOUTHEASTWARD FASTER AND DRYING THINGS OUT A 
LITTLE FASTER TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY. HAVE TAPERED POPS DOWN SOMEWHAT 
FOR TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY TO TAKE THIS INTO ACCOUNT. AFTER REVIEW OF 
NEW GFS...MAY LOWER THEM MORE ON WEDNESDAY. A FEW STORMS COULD BE 
SEVERE OVER THE SOUTH THIS AFTERNOON AS THAT AREA HEATS UP...SO


287 
FXUS64 KLZK 220744
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
245 AM CDT TUE JUN 22 2004

.SHORT TERM...TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT...
MODELS ARE IN DECENT AGREEMENT IN THE SHORT TERM AS FAR AS THE 
SYNOPTIC SCALE FEATURES GO. DIFFERENCES CONTINUE TO EXIST IN THE 
DETAILS...ESPECIALLY WITH THE STRENGTH OF THE APPROACHING WAVE FOR 
THE TUESDAY NIGHT/WEDNESDAY TIME FRAME. WHILE BOTH THE GFS AND ETA 
DEVELOP LOW PRESSURE ALONG A COLD FRONT...GFS CONTINUES TO 
EXPERIENCE SIGNIFICANT FEEDBACK PROBLEMS AND GENERATES WAY TOO MUCH 
QPF. GFS SOLUTION WILL NEED TO BE DISCARDED THIS MORNING IN FAVOR OF 
AN ETA/MESO-ETA COMPROMISE.

MODELS CONTINUE TO ADVERTISE A VERY UNUSUAL LOOKING PATTERN FOR MID 
JUNE WITH STRONG RIDGING OVER THE WEST COAST AND AN INTENSE POLAR 
VORTEX OVER CENTRAL CANADA. OVERALL PATTERN DOES NOT REALLY CHANGE 
TOO MUCH OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS WITH THE RIDGE REMAINING IN PLACE 
BUT THE POLAR VORTEX ONLY MOVES FROM CENTRAL MANITOBA TO HUDSON BAY. 
MAIN PLAYER FOR THE AREA WILL BE A SURFACE LOW MOVING ACROSS THE 
EASTERN GREAT LAKES. WHILE LOW WILL RACE OFF TO THE NORTHEAST...THE 
ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT WILL MOVE SLOWLY THROUGH THE STATE AND LIKELY 
STALL OUT FOR A TIME OVER THE CENTRAL PART OF THE STATE. LATEST 
SURFACE ANALYSIS PLACES FRONT OVER THE EXTREME NORTHWEST CORNER OF 
THE STATE. FRONT FORECAST TO SLOWLY SINK SOUTHEAST AND BISECT THE 
STATE FROM NORTHEAST TO SOUTHWEST BY THE END OF THE DAY. 

TRIO OF CONVECTIVE COMPLEXES THIS MORNING LINE UP FROM CENTRAL 
OKLAHOMA TO SOUTHERN TEXAS. AM EXPECTING THESE TO DECAY AS THEY 
TRACK EAST BUT SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS STILL LIKELY AS REMAINS OF 
THESE COMPLEXES SWING THROUGH. ATTENTION WILL THEN TURN TO THE 
AFOREMENTIONED COLD FRONT. EXPECTING SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO 
REDEVELOP IN ITS VICINITY OVER THE WEST DURING THE AFTERNOON AND 
TRANSLATE EASTWARD. EXTENSIVE CLOUD COVER MAY KEEP TEMPS IN CHECK 
BUT AIRMASS REMAINS TROPICAL IN NATURE AND MODERATELY UNSTABLE. 
WOULD NOT BE SURPRISED TO SEE A FEW SEVERE STORMS WITH LARGE HAIL 
THE PRIMARY THREAT. LOW PRESSURE DEVELOPS ON THE FRONT OVERNIGHT FOR 
ADDITIONAL LIFT AND ADDITIONAL SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS.

PRIMARY CONCERN TONIGHT WILL BE HEAVY RAIN WITH PWAT VALUES BETWEEN 
1.5 AND 2.0 INCHES. MODELS ALSO HINTING AT POSSIBLE MCS DEVELOPMENT 
OVER SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. FLASH FLOOD GUIDANCE NOT TERRIBLY OMINOUS 
BUT LOCALIZED FLOODING IS STILL A POSSIBILITY. NO HIGHLIGHTS NEEDED 
NOW BUT IF APPROACHING COMPLEXES DROP CONSIDERABLE RAIN TODAY... 
SITUATION MAY NEED TO BE REEVALUATED. 

LOW WILL TRACK TO THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BY WEDNESDAY MORNING WITH 
MODELS CONTINUING TO SHOW SIGNIFICANT QPF OUTPUTS. WILL NEED TO 
TOTALLY REVAMP POPS AND QPF FOR TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY AS 
SYSTEM SLOWLY SINKS TO THE SOUTH ON WEDNESDAY. MAY HAVE TO KEEP 
LIKELY POPS THROUGH MOST OF TUESDAY NIGHT AND SLOWLY TAPER OFF FROM 
THE NORTHWEST WEDNESDAY AS DRIER AIR TRIES TO ADVECT IN. AREA DRIES 
OUT THURSDAY AS WEAK HIGH PRESSURE WILL BE IN CONTROL. RESPITE FROM 
THE PRECIPITATION WILL BE BRIEF AS NEW FRONT BEGINS TO DROP DOWN 
FROM THE NORTH ON FRIDAY.

TEMPERATURES SHOULD REMAIN BELOW NORMAL THROUGH THE PERIOD WITH 
EXTENSIVE CLOUD COVER AND PRECIPITATION. MAV NUMBERS GENERALLY 
COOLER THAN THE FWC AND LOOK REASONABLE.
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY...
VERY FEW CHANGES MADE TO LONG TERM GRIDS. FRONTAL SYSTEM WILL 
CONTINUE TO BE FEATURE IN WEATHER SATURDAY...BUT LOWERED POPS SOME 
DUE TO FASTER MOVEMENT NOW SHOWN BY THE LATEST RUN. LATEST GFS IS 
SHOWING DRY PERIOD FROM SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY...BUT DUE TO 
UNCERTAINTY...WILL KEEP LOW CHANCE POPS IN FORECAST. FRONT LOOKS TO 
MOVE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT...SO HAVE ADDED SLIGHT CHANCES TO THE 
FORECAST. DID NOT GO WITH A DRASTIC CHANGE AS THE SOLUTION WILL 
CHANGE MANY TIMES BETWEEN NOW AND THEN.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    82  61  86  67 /  70  80  80  30 
HARRISON AR       75  56  80  62 /  70  80  70  10 
HOT SPRINGS AR    82  61  86  67 /  70  80  80  30 
PINE BLUFF AR     83  62  87  68 /  70  80  80  40 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  76  58  80  62 /  70  80  70  10

FXUS64 KLZK 212026
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
325 PM CDT MON JUN 21 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT DEVELOPING ANOTHER MCS OVERNIGHT 
TONIGHT ACROSS OKLAHOMA. SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS CAN BE EXPECTED 
ACROSS MUCH OF NORTH AND CENTRAL ARKANSAS. ALSO A COLD FRONT WILL 
MOVE OUT OF THE PLAINS TONIGHT. THE MCS WILL TRAVEL ALONG THE COLD 
FRONT AND PRODUCE HEAVY RAINS. LATEST PW VALUE AT LZK IS 1.60 
INCHES. EXPECT 2 TO 3 INCH RAINFALL AMOUNTS IN SOME AREAS OF NORTH 
AND CENTRAL ARKANSAS DURING THE EARLY MORNING HOURS. HAVE ISSUED A 
FLASH FLOOD WATCH FOR MIDNIGHT TO 7 AM FOR THE NORTHERN TWO THIRDS 
OF THE CWFA. 

CHANCES OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL TAPER OFF FROM NORTHWEST 
TO SOUTHEAST TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY MORNING. THE FRONT WILL 
MOVE INTO SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS WEDNESDAY MORNING. COOLER AND DRIER AIR 
IS EXPECTED TO MOVE IN BEHIND THE FRONT. THURSDAY WILL BE DRY WITH 
HIGH PRESSURE OVER THE AREA. 
&&

.LONG TERM...THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
SURFACE MOISTURE WILL BE RETURNING TO THE STATE ON THE BACK SIDE OF 
RIDGE AS LOW GATHERS STRENGTH IN OKLAHOMA. A COLD FRONT WILL PUSH 
SOUTHEAST AT THE SAME TIME WITH BOTH FEATURES MEETING IN THE MIDDLE 
OF THE STATE FRIDAY AFTERNOON. WEAK...COLD FRONT WILL PUSH THE STATE 
AS LOW MOVES NORTHEAST QUICKLY. HIGH HUMIDITY AND RAIN CHANCES WILL 
LINGER OVER THE SOUTHEAST HALF OF ARKANSAS SUNDAY THROUGH MONDAY 
MORNING. DRY AFTERWARDS.

238 AM CDT MON JUN 21 2004

.SHORT TERM...MONDAY THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT...
ALL SHORT RANGE MODELS IN DECENT AGREEMENT THIS MORNING REGARDING 
THE TIMING OF THE FEATURES OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS. DIFFERENCES..IN 
SOME CASES SIGNIFICANT ONES...EXIST IN THE INTENSITY OF THESE SAME 
FEATURES. MESO-ETA AND GFS ARE THE STRONGEST SOLUTIONS WHILE THE ETA 
IS THE WEAKEST. ETA HOWEVER HAS BEEN TRENDING SLIGHTLY STRONGER OVER 
THE LAST RUN OR TWO SO IT MAY BE STARTING TO BUY INTO THE STRONGER 
SOLUTION. THAT BEING SAID...WILL GO WITH A MESO-ETA/GFS SOLUTION 
THIS MORNING. 

ATYPICAL PATTERN FOR SUMMER WILL CONTINUE FOR THE SHORT TERM WITH 
UPPER LEVEL RIDGING OVER THE WEST COAST AND AN UNUSUALLY DEEP VORTEX 
FOR MID JUNE OVER THE PRAIRIE PROVINCES OF CENTRAL CANADA. VORTEX 
FORECAST TO SLIDE SOUTH AND DEEPEN. SURFACE LOW MOVING ACROSS 
SOUTHERN CANADA EVENTUALLY DRIVES A COLD FRONT INTO THE CWA 
SOMEWHERE IN THE MONDAY NIGHT TO TUESDAY TIME FRAME. 

LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS A DECAYING FRONT OVER THE SOUTHERN 
PORTION OF THE STATE. EXPECTING THIS FEATURE TO CONTINUE WASHING OUT 
AND WILL BE A NON FACTOR. ANOTHER INTENSE MCS FORECASTED BY THE 
MODELS TO DEVELOP LAST NIGHT PRETTY MUCH ON SCHEDULE ACROSS KANSAS 
AND NORTHERN OKLAHOMA AT THIS TIME. COMPLEX STILL EXPECTED TO WEAKEN 
AS IT APPROACHES BUT MODELS CONSISTENT WITH OUTFLOW BOUNDARY MOVING 
INTO NORTHERN ARKANSAS AROUND MID DAY. AM EXPECTING AFTERNOON 
HEATING TO TRIGGER SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ACROSS THE 
NORTHERN AND CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE CWA.

AFOREMENTIONED COLD FRONT BEGINS TO APPROACH THE STATE MONDAY NIGHT.
SHORTWAVE ALREADY SEEN ON WATER VAPOR VAPOR OVER SOUTHERN IDAHO 
FORECAST TO DROP INTO THE CENTRAL PLANS AND RAPIDLY INTENSIFY AS IT 
MOVES INTO CENTRAL OKLAHOMA. 

SCENARIO COULD LEAD TO MCS DEVELOPMENT WITH COMPLEX THEN TRAVELING 
ALONG THE BOUNDARY ACROSS CENTRAL OKLAHOMA AND ARKANSAS. MODELS SEEM 
TO BE KEYING IN ON WESTERN AND NORTHWEST ARKANSAS BEFORE WEAKENING 
THE SYSTEM JUST A BIT BEFORE IT ARRIVES IN THE CENTRAL PORTIONS OF 
THE STATE. WHILE THE GFS IS HAVING FEEDBACK PROBLEMS ONCE AGAIN AND 
IS OVERDOING QPF...POTENTIAL DOES EXIST FOR AN INCH OR TWO OF RAIN 
GIVEN THE TROPICAL NATURE OF THE AIR MASS AND PWAT VALUES CLOSE TO 
TWO INCHES THROUGH OUT THE EVENT. WILL BE RAISING POPS ACROSS THE 
BOARD TO LIKELY OR CATEGORICAL FOR MONDAY NIGHT AND TUESDAY MORNING 
ACROSS NORTHERN AND CENTRAL SECTIONS IN AN AREA OF ENHANCED LIFT. 
WILL LEAVE CHANCE POPS ACROSS THE SOUTH. MODELS CONTINUE TO SHOW 
FRONT SLOWING DOWN ONCE IT REACHES THE CENTRAL SECTIONS OF THE 
STATE. FRONT WILL EVENTUALLY BE SHUNTED TO THE SOUTH AS HIGH 
PRESSURE BUILDS INTO THE NATIONS MIDSECTION. POPS WILL BE TAPERED 
DOWN FROM NORTH TO SOUTH TUESDAY AFTERNOON WITH FRONT CLEARING THE 
STATE TUESDAY EVENING. HIGH PRESSURE WILL DOMINATE WEDNESDAY AND 
THURSDAY FOR DRY CONDITIONS. 

CONCERNING TEMPERATURES...FWC NUMBERS SEEM A LITTLE OVER DONE... 
ESPECIALLY FOR TODAY...AND WILL GO MORE IN LINE WITH THE MAV 
GUIDANCE. TODAY WILL BE THE WARMEST DAY IN THIS PERIOD AS CLOUDS AND 
PRECIP WILL KEEP TEMPS IN CHECK TUESDAY. COOLER AIR COMES IN FOR 
WEDNESDAY BEHIND THE FRONT WITH WARMER READINGS FOR THURSDAY AS 
RETURN FLOW GETS REESTABLISHED. LOW TEMPERATURES WILL NEED TO BE 
TWEAKED...MORE SO ON TUESDAY WITH RAIN EXPECTED ACROSS MOST AREAS.
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY...
WET PATTERN TO CONTINUE IN EXTENDED...WITH TIMING AND PLACEMENT OF 
SYSTEMS HARD TO PINPOINT. DUE TO THIS...HAVE DECIDED TO SHOW TRENDS 
INSTEAD OF PINPOINTING EXACT CONDITIONS. SYSTEM WILL MOVE INTO 
ARKANSAS FROM THE WEST FOR FRIDAY AND SATURDAY...WITH CHANCE POPS 
CONTINUING FROM PREVIOUS FORECAST. SHOWED DRYING TREND FOR SATURDAY 
AND SUNDAY...AS AFOREMENTIONED SYSTEM MOVES EAST. OVERALL...NOT TOO 
MANY CHANGES TO THE EXTENDED PORTION OF THE FORECAST...WITH 
TEMPERATURES REMAINING A LITTLE COOLER THAN NORMAL DUE TO CLOUD 
COVER.

BEING THE FEATURE OF CONCERN IN ARKANSAS. HAVE GONE WITH A BLEND OF 
MODELS IN REGARD TO TIMING OF PRECIPITATION...BEGINNING AFTER 
MIDNIGHT TONIGHT AND INCREASING TOWARD THE AFTERNOON HOURS MONDAY. 
AREA IS IN SLIGHT RISK MONDAY...WITH THE CONCERNS BEING DAMAGING 
WIND AND LARGE HAIL IN THE AFTERNOON AS BOUNDARY INTERACTS WITH 
HEATING OF THE DAY.

OKLAHOMA...AND MOVE ALONG/NEAR THE FRONTAL BOUNDARY IN ARKANSAS.

STILL MAY BE TOO CONSERVATIVE. WOULD LIKE TO SEE DEVELOPMENT OF MCS 
TONIGHT AND ASSOCIATED BOUNDARY PLACEMENT BEFORE NUMEROUS SHOWERS 
ARE INTRODUCED.

CONCERN WITH THESE SYSTEM THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS WILL BE WITH 
FLOODING. AS IS THE CASE WITH A FRONTAL BOUNDARY INTERACTING WITH 
NUMEROUS SHORTWAVES...RAINFALL AMOUNTS COULD BE QUITE HIGH. SOME 
AREAS OF THE WEST RECEIVED OVER 2 INCHES OF RAIN SATURDAY EVENING. 
WILL HIGHLIGHT POTENTIAL FOR SLOW MOVING THUNDERSTORMS/FLOODING IN 
THE HWO.

DRIER/COOLER AIR WILL MOVE INTO THE STATE WEDNESDAY. HAVE LEFT 
ISOLATED POPS IN THE FORECAST DUE TO TIMING ISSUES...BUT WILL SEE A 
DIFFERENCE IN DEW POINTS. HOWEVER...THIS WILL BE SHORT LIVED...AS 
ANOTHER SYSTEM DEVELOPS IN THE PANHANDLE REGION AND MOVES EAST 
THURSDAY INTO FRIDAY.

REGION OF TEXAS AND OKLAHOMA. MCS IS MOVING EAST...AND THE REMNANTS 
WILL INTERACT WITH THE FRONT OVER ARKANSAS. ADD IN HEATING OF THE 
DAY...AND SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL DEVELOP IN THE 
SOUTH.

FRONT WILL STAY IN SOUTHERN ARKANSAS TONIGHT AND SUNDAY. SEVERAL 
UPPER LEVEL SHORTWAVES WILL MOVE INTO THE STATE...FOR A CONTINUED 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS.

MODEL DIFFERENCES COME INTO PLAY SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY WITH FRONT 
MOVING SOUTH FROM THE PLAINS. PLACEMENT OF THE BOUNDARY WILL COME 
INTO PLAY AS SEVERAL UPPER LEVEL SYSTEM MOVE ACROSS THE REGION. RAIN 
CHANCES WILL CONTINUE MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY...ESPECIALLY IN THE 
NORTH...AS THE FRONT AND THE AFOREMENTIONED SYSTEMS INTERACT. DUE TO 
UNCERTAINTY IN PLACEMENT...LEFT CHANCE POPS GOING...BUT THESE MAY 
NEED TO BE ADJUSTED HIGHER IN THE NORTH WITH FUTURE MODEL RUNS.

VERY FEW CHANGES TO THE EXTENDED PORTION OF THE FORECAST. UNSETTLED 
WEATHER WILL CONTINUE...WITH RAIN CHANCES THROUGH THE UPCOMING WEEK.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

STATE ON SATURDAY. DATA INDICATING DRIER/COOLER AIR BEHIND FRONT...
WITH CHANCES FOR SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS CONFINED TO THE SOUTHWEST 
HALF OF THE STATE. HAVE INDICATED THIS IN LATEST FORECAST.

END...LATEST COOLDOWN WILL BE SHORT-LIVED WITH WARM/HUMID WEATHER 
RETURNING EARLY NEXT WEEK. WILL GET BACK TO POPCORN THUNDERSTORMS

555 
FXUS64 KLZK 181855
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
155 PM CDT FRI JUN 18 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY
UNSETTLED WEATHER PATTERN SETTING UP FOR THE SHORT TERM. 
CURRENTLY...SEVERAL OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES THAT WERE LEFT OVER FROM 
CONVECTION LAST NIGHT AND EARLY THIS MORNING ACTING TO PRODUCE 
WIDELY SCATTERED/SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS...MOSTLY OVER 
THE WESTERN HALF OF ARKANSAS. APPROACHING COLD FRONT STRETCHING FROM 
SOUTHERN MISSOURI TO CENTRAL OKLAHOMA WILL ALSO AIDE IN DEVELOPMENT 
OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS THROUGH TONIGHT. 

FRONT WILL MAKE ITS WAY INTO CENTRAL ARKANSAS TONIGHT...AND TOWARD 
SOUTHERN ARKANSAS EARLY SATURDAY MORNING. SHORT RANGE MODELS HAVE 
BEEN KEYING IN ON MCS DEVELOPING INVOF THE PANHANDLES AREA TONIGHT...
AND MOVING THE SYSTEM THROUGH CENTRAL OKLAHOMA BEFORE DYING OUT 
SATURDAY MORNING. LOOKS AS THOUGH REMNANTS OF THE SYSTEM WILL MAKE 
IT INTO SOUTHWESTERN ARKANSAS BY LATE SATURDAY MORNING AND INTO 
SATURDAY AFTERNOON. INTERACTING WITH THE HEATING OF THE DAY...THIS 
WILL ACT TO TOUCH OFF ANOTHER ROUND OF CONVECTION.

 FRONT IS EXPECTED TO WOBBLE AROUND CENTRAL/SOUTHERN ARKANSAS FOR 
MUCH OF THE SHORT TERM. SEVERAL UPPER LEVEL SYSTEMS WILL MOVE 
ACROSS...ALLOWING FOR A CONTINUED CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS THROUGH THE PERIOD. THUNDERSTORM DEVELOPMENT WILL BE 
ENHANCED BY INTERACTION WITH DAYTIME HEATING. WOULD NOT BE SURPRISED 
TO SEE A FEW ISOLATED STRONG STORMS DURING THE AFTERNOON AND EVENING 
HOURS. ALSO...WITH SHORTWAVE MOVING ACROSS OKLAHOMA ON SATURDAY 
NIGHT AND INTERACTING WITH SURFACE BOUNDARY...POTENTIAL MCS COULD 
OCCUR AND SCRAPE SOUTHERN ARKANSAS SUNDAY MORNING. 

WITH PRECIPITABLE WATERS IN THE 1.5 TO 2 INCH RANGE...AND WITH MCS 
POTENTIAL OVER THE SOUTHWEST...SOME STORMS MAY PRODUCE LOCALLY HEAVY 
RAINFALL. WILL CONTINUE TO HIGHLIGHT THIS IN HAZARDOUS WEATHER 
OUTLOOK. 

LOOKS AS THOUGH SURFACE BOUNDARY WILL ATTEMPT TO MOVE BACK TO THE 
NORTH ON MONDAY...BUT WITH MORE UPPER SYSTEMS APPROACHING...RAIN 
CHANCES WILL CONTINUE. 

ONE FINAL CONCERN...AND THIS DEALS WITH POTENTIAL HEAT INDEX 
PROBLEMS. ALTHOUGH HEAT ADVISORY CRITERIA IS NOWHERE NEAR BEING 
MET...DEWPOINTS IN THE 60S AND LOWER 70S...AND AFTERNOON 
TEMPERATURES IN THE 80S TO NEAR 90...COULD PUSH HEAT INDEX VALUES TO 
NEAR OR SLIGHTLY ABOVE  100 DEGREES. THE AREA MOST LIKELY AFFECTED 
WOULD BE SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. SUCCEEDING SHIFTS WILL NEED TO MONITOR 
AND PERHAPS HIGHLIGHT THIS IN THE FORECAST IF THE SITUATION 
WARRANTS.  
&&

.LONG TERM...MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
UNUSUALLY ACTIVE EARLY SUMMER PATTERN TO CONTINUE MOST OF NEXT WEEK 
AS THE SUBTROPICAL RIDGE REMAINS WEAK AND 500 MB HEIGHTS IN THE AREA 
REMAIN IN THE MID 580S OR SO. APPEARS FRONTAL SYSTEM WILL BE STALLED 
ACROSS NORTHERN ARKANSAS MONDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY AND GFS HINTS 
AT A COUPLE OF MCS MOVING ACROSS THE AREA. ENHANCED POPS TO 40 
PERCENT IN THE NORTH TO REFLECT THIS ALTHOUGH TIMING AND LOCATION 
WILL BE HIGHLY SUBJECT TO CHANGE BY THEN. GENERALLY WENT WITH 30 
PERCENT POPS ELSEWHERE. FROM WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY 
NIGHT...AREA MAY BE IN LULL BUT IT LOOKS LIKE THE TROPICAL AIR MASS 
WILL STILL BE IN PLACE SO LEFT 20 POPS GOING. THEN ANOTHER COLD 
FRONT MOVES CLOSE TO THE AREA FRIDAY SO PUT IN 30 PERCENT POPS FOR 
THAT. I WAS SO CONFIDENT THAT THERE WILL BE SOME RAIN GOING ON IN 
EACH PERIOD TO USE COVERAGE WORDING IN THE EXTENDED. KEPT MIN TEMP 
FORECASTS AS THEY WERE BUT SHADED MAXES DOWN A CATEGORY OR SO IN 
NORTHERN AND CENTRAL SECTIONS TO FIT MEX AND EXTENDED GUIDANCE.   
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
LITTLE ROCK AR    74  87  67  86 /  50  40  30  30 
HARRISON AR       64  78  60  80 /  50  30  30  30 
HOT SPRINGS AR    73  88  68  87 /  50  40  30  40 
PINE BLUFF AR     74  88  68  87 /  50  40  30  30 
MOUNTAIN HOME AR  65  79  61  81 /  50  30  30  30 
MONTICELLO AR     74  89  69  87 /  40  40  30  40 
SEARCY AR         72  86  66  85 /  50  30  30  30 
MOUNT IDA AR      72  87  68  87 /  50  40  30  40

FXUS64 KLZK 181553 CCA
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...CORRECTED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1050 AM CDT FRI JUN 18 2004

.DISCUSSION...
LATEST SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS SEVERAL OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES LEFT OVER 
FROM CONVECTION LAST NIGHT/EARLY THIS MORNING. THESE...ALONG WITH 
APPROACHING FRONTAL BOUNDARY AND SHORTWAVE WILL ACT TO PRODUCE 
SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT. 
ALREADY...ISOLATED SHOWERS POPPING UP ACROSS WESTERN ARKANSAS...
AND COVERAGE WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE AS HEATING OF THE DAY KICKS 
IN. 

TAKING A LOOK AT AREA SOUNDINGS...INSTABILITY PARAMETERS DO INDICATE 
POSSIBILITY OF ISOLATED STRONG TO SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS...WITH HAIL 
AND WIND THE GREATEST THREAT. WILL CONTINUE TO HIGHLIGHT THIS IN 
THE HAZARDOUS WEATHER OUTLOOK AND IN THE SHORT TERM FORECASTS WHEN 
NECESSARY. 

AS FAR AS UPDATES TO THE FORECASTS...HAVE MAINLY UPDATED TO REMOVE 
TEMPORAL WORDING FOR THE AFTERNOON PERIOD. KEPT POPS IN THE HIGH TO 
MID RANGE CHANCE CATEGORY...HIGHEST OVER THE WEST AND NORTH. HAVE 
ALSO UPDATED OTHER WEATHER PARAMETERS TO BETTER ACCOUNT FOR ONGOING 
TRENDS. AT THIS TIME...FORECASTED MAXES APPEAR REASONABLE...SO WILL 
LEAVE THOSE ALONE FOR NOW. 

UPDATED TEXT FORECAST HAVE BEEN SENT. GRAPHICAL FORECASTS ARE 
POSTING...AND GRIDDED FORECASTS WILL BE SENT SHORTLY. 
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
&&

447 
FXUS64 KLZK 180854
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
350 AM CDT FRI JUN 18 2004

.DISCUSSION...
BROAD RIDGE...ALMOST ZONAL FLOW...IS ACROSS THE SOUTHERN UNITED 
STATES TODAY. LOTS OF GULF MOISTURE STREAMING UP...WITH DEWPOINTS IN 
THE MID 70S IN SOUTHERN ARKANSAS. NEARLY STATIONARY FRONT JUST TO 
THE NORTH OF THE STATE...AND THIS WILL COME INTO PLAY TODAY AND 
TONIGHT. LARGE MCS ACROSS KANSAS AND NORTHEAST OKLAHOMA THIS MORNING 
MOVING NORTHEAST...WITH SOUTHERN EXTENT SHOWING A DECREASING TREND. 
HOWEVER...OUTFLOW BOUNDARY MOVING SOUTHEAST FROM MAIN AREA OF 
ACTIVITY. THIS WILL COMBINE WITH THE UNSTABLE AIR OVER ARKANSAS AND 
AFOREMENTIONED FRONT TO PRODUCE SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. SEVERE 
WEATHER WILL BE POSSIBLE THIS AFTERNOON GIVEN THE AMOUNT OF 
INSTABILITY...WITH LARGE HAIL AND DAMAGING WINDS THE PRIMARY 
CONCERNS.

MODEL DIFFERENCES COME INTO PLAY TONIGHT AND SATURDAY...WITH ANOTHER 
MCS DEVELOPING IN THE TEXAS AND OKLAHOMA PANHANDLES. POSITION OF THE 
COLD FRONT IS THE CONCERN...AS THE GFS HAS THE FRONT STAYING IN 
NORTH ARKANSAS...WHILE THE ETA MOVES IT INTO THE CENTRAL SECTION OF 
THE STATE. THIS WILL AFFECT THE MCS POSITION AND THUS THE HIGHER 
QPFS. FOR NOW...WENT MORE WITH THE ETA SOLUTION...BUT THINK THE 
FRONT WILL STALL SOMEWHERE IN CENTRAL ARKANSAS. THUS...HIGHEST POPS 
AND QPF WILL BE IN CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN AREAS SATURDAY.

FRONT WILL MOVE BACK TO THE NORTH AS A WARM FRONT SUNDAY. WITH 
LEFTOVER BOUNDARIES AND PLENTY OF MOISTURE...LEFT SLIGHT CHANCE POPS 
IN THE FORECAST. FRONT LOOKS TO STALL ALONG THE ARKANSAS MISSOURI 
BORDER SUNDAY NIGHT...AND WILL BE THE FOCUS FOR RAINFALL ONCE AGAIN. 
HAVE LEFT CHANCE POPS IN THE FORECAST FOR MONDAY...AS MOISTURE WILL 
BE PLENTIFUL. THE REST OF THE FORECAST LOOK ON TRACK AND ONLY MINOR 
CHANGES WERE MADE.

TEMPERATURES WILL HOVER AROUND 90 DEGREES IN CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN 
SECTIONS FOR THE ENTIRE FORECAST. NORTHERN ARKANSAS WILL SEE 
READINGS IN THE LOWER 80S SATURDAY AFTER THE FRONT MOVES 
THROUGH...BUT WILL CLIMB AGAIN INTO THE MID TO UPPER 80S FOR THE 
UPCOMING WEEK.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

UNCLEAR AS TO WHAT FRONT WILL DO...BUT WOULD THINK THAT IF FRONT 
DOES MAKE IT INTO ARKANSAS...IT SHOULD STALL. MEANWHILE...MCS
DEVELOPMENT WILL OCCUR IN PLAINS TONIGHT AND AGAIN FRIDAY NIGHT. 
BOUNDARIES FROM DECAYING STORMS WILL LIKELY INTERACT WITH FRONT...
WITH CHANCES FOR SHOWERS/STORMS ACROSS REGION INTO THE WEEKEND. 

WOULD THINK GREATEST CHANCES FOR STORMS WOULD BE ACROSS NORTHERN 
HALF OF ARKANSAS NEAR STALLED FRONT. THIS WOULD BE MAINLY DURING 
AFTERNOON/EVENING HOURS. A FEW STORMS WILL LIKELY BECOME 
SEVERE...WITH LARGE HAIL/DAMAGING WINDS POSSIBLE.

068 
FXUS64 KLZK 171950
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
300 PM CDT THU JUN 17 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY
TROPICAL UPPER SYSTEM MOVING OUT OF THE AREA WITH UPPER HEIGHTS 
BUILDING ACROSS THE AREA AS RIDGE BUILDS OVER THE SOUTHEAST. THIS
LOOKS LIKE IT WILL BE SHORT LIVED AS RIDGE WEAKENS A LITTLE BY 
SATURDAY. FRONTAL SYSTEM WILL BE HANGING JUST TO THE NORTH. 
COMBINATION OF UPPER HIGH TO THE SOUTHEAST AND FRONTAL ZONE TO 
THE NORTHWEST AND RESULTING MCS ACTIVITY ALONG IT WILL LEAD TO 
COMPLICATED SCENARIO FOR THE CWA IN THE SHORT TERM. THE RIDGE 
LOOKS LIKE IT WILL BE STRONG ENOUGH TO HOLD THE FRONT NORTH OF
THE AREA UNTIL AT LEAST SATURDAY NIGHT THEN THE UPPER FLOW BUCKLES 
ENOUGH TO ALLOW THE FRONT TO PENETRATE THE AREA. HOWEVER...THERE 
ARE STRONG SIGNALS OF AN MCS ACROSS KANSAS INTO MISSOURI TONIGHT
INTO EARLY FRIDAY. THIS SHOULD WEAKEN FRIDAY MORNING AND MAY LAY
OUT AN OUTFLOW BOUNDARY ON WHICH NEW CONVECTION CAN FORM FRIDAY
AFTERNOON. THERE IS A RISK THIS COULD WANDER INTO NORTHERN 
ARKANSAS LATER FRIDAY INTO FRIDAY NIGHT. ANOTHER MCS IS POSSIBLE
FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY AND ALL THESE EFFECTS COULD PUSH THE 
EFFECTIVE BOUNDARY INTO ARKANSAS AND RESULT IN A SCENARIO CLOSE TO 
WHAT THE GFS IS DEPICTING. INDICATIONS ARE RETURN FLOW SHOULD SET
UP BY SUNDAY AS THE SURFACE HIGH MOVES TO THE EAST AND THE FRONT
RE-ESTABLISHES ITSELF TO THE NORTH. DUE TO THE MANY MESOSCALE
VARAIBLES AND UNCERTAINTY WENT WITH A COMPROMISE FORECAST. 
FOR TONIGHT...WENT WITH SMALL POPS ACROSS THE NORTH EARLY DUE TO 
THUNDERSTORMS AHEAD OF AN MCV MOVING ACROSS THAT AREA AND IN THE 
EAST FROM REMAINING EFFECTS FROM THE TROPICAL SHORT WAVE. WENT
CLOSE TO PERSISTENCE ON MINS. FOR FRIDAY...INCREASED POPS TO 
30 PERCENT ACROSS THE NORTH FOR THE POSSIBILITY OF THUNDERSTORMS 
MOVING INTO THE AREA FROM AN OUTFLOW BOUNDARY THEN CONTINUED POPS
INTO FRIDAY NIGHT AND KEPT SMALL POPS IN CENTRAL SECTIONS. 
OTHERWISE HAVE SMALL POPS FOR FRIDAY FOR ISOLATED DEVELOPMENT IN 
WARM HUMID TROPICAL AIR MASS. BROAD BRUSHED 30 PERCENT POPS ACROSS
THE ENTIRE AREA FOR SATURDAY FOR NOW AND BACKED OFF TO 20 PERCENT
FOR SATURDAY NIGHT THEN CONTINUED SMALL POPS FOR ALL DAY SUNDAY. 
WENT WITH MAXES IN THE LOWER 90S IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH FOR FRIDAY
AS CONFIDENCE HIGH THOSE AREAS WILL HEAT UP. WENT LOWER ON MAXES
FOR SATURDAY DUE TO POSSIBLE EFFECTS OF CLOUDS AND MCS ACTIVITY.    
&&

.LONG TERM...SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY
ZONAL FLOW WILL BE PREDOMINANT IN THE UPPER LEVELS DURING THE 
EXTENDED PERIODS. CONSEQUENTLY...ANY SURFACE SYSTEMS THAT ATTEMPT TO 
COME DOWN FROM THE NORTH WILL BE SLOW TO DO SO. WHICH BRINGS TO 
ATTENTION APPROACHING COLD FRONT COMING DOWN FROM MISSOURI. EXTENDED 
RANGE MODELS NOW BRING THE FRONT DOWN TOWARD NORTHERN ARKANSAS BY 
TUESDAY. SYSTEM APPEARS TO WOBBLE AROUND THE AREA FOR SEVERAL DAYS.

DURING THIS TIME...SEVERAL UPPER LEVEL SYSTEMS WILL MOVE ACROSS...
AND SOUTHEASTERN RIDGE WILL KEEP THE GULF OPEN FOR BUSINESS. THUS...
THERE WILL BE A CONTINUED CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
THROUGHOUT THE EXTENDED PERIOD WITH WARM AND MOIST AIRMASS AND UPPER 
SUPPORT MOVING ACROSS. 

BY THURSDAY...FLOW ALOFT WILL BECOME MORE SOUTHWESTERLY AS H5 TROUGH 
WILL BUILD OVER WEST TEXAS. THIS WILL PUSH THE DRIFTING BACK TO THE 
NORTH...AND MAY ALLOW A COLD FRONTAL PASSAGE JUST BEYOND THE END OF 
THE EXTENDED PERIODS.
&&

UPDATED ZONES TO CLEAR UP MORNING WORDING AND MADE MINOR CHANGES TO

CUT DOWN 30 PERCENT POPS TO THOSE AREAS AND LEFT 20 PERCENT POPS 
ELSEWHERE. MAX FORECASTS LOOKING GOOD BASED ON LATE MORNING TEMPS...
MADE ONE DEGREE INCREASE IN MAXES IN THE NORTH WHICH DID NOT AFFECT
WORDING IN TEXT PRODUCTS. SURFACE RIDGE IN THE AREA HAS RESULTED
IN LIGHT WINDS THIS MORNING SO DECREASED WIND SPEEDS FOR EARLY 
AFTERNOON. UPPER AIR ANALYSIS SHOWED HEIGHTS BUILDING OVER THE 
SOUTHEASTERN U.S. PRETTY MUCH AS PROGGED SO THE RIDGING SHOULD
RESULT IN MORE TYPICAL SUMMER WEATHER FOR THE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS. 
WILL SPEND NEXT COUPLE OF HOURS LOOKING AT NEW MODEL RUNS AND 
DECIDING WHAT THE FRONT MIGHT DO TO THIS AREA OVER THE WEEKEND.
STILL NOT CONVINCED THE FRONT WILL MOVE ACROSS THE AREA AS SOME
OF THE MODELS ARE SHOWING. MAIN DETERMINING FACTOR MAY BE THE
BEHAVIOR OF THE BUILDING UPPER RIDGE IN THE SOUTHEAST.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION

300 PM CDT WED JUN 16 2004

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY
TROPICAL SHORT WAVE WILL MOVE INTO WESTERN SECTIONS AND SHEAR OUT THEN
SLOWLY TRANSLATE ACROSS THE AREA TONIGHT AND THURSDAY. COVERAGE OF 
PRECIP HAS NOT BEEN AS MUCH AS ANTICIPATED AND WILL LOWER POPS A
LITTLE FOR EARLY TONIGHT...GOING WITH 40 PERCENT AT FIRST THEN LOWERING
TO 30 PERCENT IN MOST AREAS. THIS MAY STILL BE TOO HIGH BASED ON 
COVERAGE LAST NIGHT...BUT WITH TROF AXIS MOVING ACROSS MOIST AIR
MASS HIGHER THAN USUAL POPS LOOK NECESSARY. WENT CLOSE TO 
PERSISTENCE ON MINS AND KEPT ALL AREAS AT OR ABOVE 70. TROF AXIS
IS PROGGED TO BE SLOWER MOVING OUT AND FAIRLY GOOD AMOUNT OF MOISTURE
REMAINS IN THE EASTERN PART OF THE AREA. EXPANDED 30 PERCENT POP AREA
INTO CENTRAL AND SOUTHWESTERN SECTIONS TO ACCOUNT FOR THIS. FRONTAL
SYSTEM LOOKS LIKE IT WILL HANG FARTEHR TO THE NORTH AS HEIGHTS RISE 
ACROSS ARKANSAS AND A FAIRLY STRONG UPPER RIDGE BUILDS INTO THE AREA
BY FRIDAY. THUS CUT DOWN THE HIGHER POPS FOR THE NORTH. MODELS...
ESPECIALLY THE ETA...INDICATE AN MCS WILL DEVELOP IN THE PLAINS 
THURSDAY NIGHT AND ROLL EAST INTO MISSOURI. IF THIS UNFOLDS WILL
HAVE TO WATCH OUT FOR OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES SNEAKING INTO NORTHERN
SECTIONS ON FRIDAY BUT FOR NOW WILL JUST GO WITH ISOLATED AFTERNOON
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ACROSS THE AREA AND CONTINUE THIS FOR
SATURDAY. MAX TEMPS SHOULD WARM UP WITH MOST AREAS INTO THE LOWER
90S FOR FRIDAY AND SATURDAY. GFS SHOWS RIDGE WEAKENING A LITTLE
OVER THE WEEKEND AND A COLD FRONT MOVING IN BY LATE SATURDAY BUT 
WILL DISCOUNT THIS FOR NOW AT LEAST THROUGH THE DAY SATURDAY.      
&&

.LONG TERM...SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY
EXTENDED RANGE SOLUTIONS NOW PUSHING STALLED FRONTAL BOUNDARY 
FURTHER NORTHWARD BY THE BEGINNING OF THE PERIOD. LOOKS LIKE THE 
AREA WILL BE IN THE WARM SECTOR FOR MUCH OF THE EXTENDED PERIOD. 
WITH ZONAL FLOW IN THE UPPER LEVELS FOR MUCH OF THE PERIOD...FRONT 
WILL WOBBLE AROUND IN THE VICINITY OF SOUTHERN MISSOURI. SEVERAL 
UPPER SYSTEMS WILL MOVE ACROSS...BUT ANY CONVECTION SHOULD BE MOSTLY 
DIURNAL IN NATURE...AS HIGH PRESSURE WILL BE DOMINANT FOR MUCH OF 
THE PERIOD. STILL HIGHLY DOUBTFUL IF THE FRONT WILL EVEN PASS 
THROUGH THE FORECAST AREA BEFORE THE END OF THE PERIOD. WILL AT 
LEAST KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE DIURNAL POPS IN THE FORECAST.

AFTERNOON WITH MORE COVERAGE THAN USUAL FOR SUMMER SITUATIONS BUT 
LIKELY POPS LOOK LIKE OVERKILL RIGHT NOW. ACTIVITY SHOULD DECREASE
WITH LOSS OF HEATING BUT WILL LIKELY STAY WITH MORE COVERAGE THAN 
USUAL AS THE TROF AXIS MOVES ACROSS THE AREA. STARTED WITH 50 PERCENT
POPS THEN SLOWLY LOWERED TO 30 PERCENT IN MOST AREAS DURING THE NIGHT
WITH LOWER POPS IN THE WEST TOWARD THURSDAY MORNING. FROM THE LOOKS

.SHORT TERM...TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY
TROPICAL LOWS TO THE SOUTH WILL BE THE MAIN PLAYER FOR THE AREA OVER
THE NEXT TWO DAYS. UPPER LOW OVER EASTERN TEXAS WILL SHEAR OUT AND
MOVE EAST ACROSS THE AREA THROUGH EARLY THURSDAY WHILE SURFACE LOW
IN MISSISSIPPI IS PROGGED TO WEAKEN AND BECOME A NON-ENTITY. OVERALL
SYSTEM WILL BE WEAKENING BUT VERY MOIST AIR MASS WITH DEW POINTS IN
THE LOWER 70S AND PWS UP TO 2 INCHES WILL COVER THE AREA. LOOKS LIKE
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE DIURNALLY DRIVEN WITH THE MOST
NUMEROUS ACTIVITY DURING THE DAY AND LESS AT NIGHT. BASED ON THAT
WILL HAVE CHANCE POPS DURING THE NIGHT WITH 30 TO 40 PERCENT FOR THE
MOST PART AND BROAD BRUSH 60 PERCENT POPS DURING THE DAY ON WEDNESDAY
AS THE TROF AXIS MOVES UP INTO THE AREA. WILL DECREASE POPS FROM THE
WEST LATER WEDNESDAY NIGHT AS THE TROF AXIS MOVES ACROSS THE AREA. 
FOR THURSDAY...WILL KEEP 30 PERCENT POPS IN THE EAST EARLY AS THE 
SHEAR AXIS AND MOISTURE CONTINUE IN THAT AREA. BY LATE IN THE DAY
THINK MOST OF THE AREA WILL BE DRY BUT WILL KEEP 20 PERCENT POPS IN 
AS RESIDUAL MOISTURE REMAINS AND A BOUNDARY OR TWO MAY BE LYING 
AROUND TO FOCUS SOME ACTIVITY. A COLD FRONT WILL MOVE NEAR THE 
NORTHERN BORDER OF THE STATE BUT HEIGHT RISES SHOULD HOLD THE FRONT 
JUST TO THE NORTH OF THE AREA. WILL GO A LITTLE HIGHER ON POPS ACROSS
THE NORTH THURSDAY THROUGH FRIDAY DUE TO THE NEARNESS OF THE FRONT. 
MAX TEMPS LIKELY WILL BE HELD DOWN BY CLOUDS WEDNESDAY BUT MOST AREAS
SHOULD BREAK OUT THURSDAY WITH MAXES REACHING THE UPPER 80S IN MANY 
AREAS. FRIDAY SHOULD BE WARMER WITH MOST AREAS SOUTH OF THE OZARKS 
REACHING THE LOWER 90S. THE HIGH DEW POINTS SHOULD KEEP MOST MINS IN 
THE 70S WITH ONLY THE NORTH DIPPING INTO THE 60S.     
&&

.LONG TERM...FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY
EXTENDED RANGE MODELS NOW PROJECT FRONTAL BOUNDARY TO STALL NEAR 
NORTHERN ARKANSAS/SOUTHERN MISSOURI BY THE LATE WEEK. SHORTWAVE WILL 
MOVE ACROSS ON FRIDAY NIGHT...INTERACTING WITH THE SYSTEM AND GIVING 
A CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS MAINLY FOR NORTHERN ARKANSAS. 

UPPER RIDGE BUILDING UP FROM THE GULF WILL KEEP THE FRONT FROM 
MAKING SIGNFICANT FORWARD PROGRESSION ON SATURDAY...AND THE SYSTEM 
LOOKS TO WOBBLE BACK AND FORTH FOR A COUPLE OF DAYS. MOST OF THE 
AREA WILL BE IN THE WARM SECTOR...WITH SEVERAL UPPER LEVEL SYSTEMS 
MOVING ACROSS IN THE MEAN FLOW. THUS...THERE WILL BE A CONTINUED 
SLIGHT CHANCE/LOW CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS THROUGH AT 
LEAST MONDAY NIGHT...WHEN RIDGE BUILDS OVER THE SOUTHWEST...AND FLOW 
ALOFT BECOMES NORTHWESTERLY...ALLOWING THE FRONT TO MOVE THROUGH.
&&

FXUS64 KLZK 151635
AFDLZK

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE LITTLE ROCK AR
1050 AM CDT TUE JUN 15 2004

.DISCUSSION...
UPPER LOW ANALYZED OVER EASTERN TEXAS THIS MORNING WITH SURFACE LOW
NEAR KJAN. AREAS OF RAIN MOVING MOSTLY EAST TO WEST ACROSS THE AREA
WITH THE BIGGEST CONCENTRATION IN THE SOUTH. BASED ON RADAR TRENDS
THIS MORNING UPPED POPS TO LIKELY CATEGORY IN CENTRAL AND EAST FOR
THIS AFTERNOON AND WENT TO 70 PERCENT IN THE SOUTH. UPPED POPS TO
30 PERCENT IN THE NORTHWEST. NORMALLY...OUTFLOW BOUNDARY AND EFFECTS
OF KANSAS MCS OVERNIGHT WOULD BE A CONCERN FOR NORTHWESTERN ARKANSAS
BUT SATELLITE THIS MORNING SHOWED EFFECTS OF TROPICAL LOWS IN THIS 
AREA AND CIRCULATION AROUND IT DISRUPTING THE SOUTHEASTERN EDGES OF
THE DECAYING MCS...SO ANY OUTFLOWS FROM THIS WILL LIKELY WASH OUT
AND NOT BE MUCH OF A FACTOR. SLIGHT CHANGES MADE TO INCREASE CLOUDS
FOR THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT. TEMP AND WIND FORECASTS LOOK GOOD
FOR NOW AND ONLY OTHER UPDATES WERE TO TAKE OUT MORNING WORDING.    
FIRST IMPRESSIONS ARE THAT LITTLE SIGNIFICANT CHANGE WILL BE MADE TO
THE SHORT TERM FORECAST THROUGH FRIDAY ON THE AFTERNOON PACKAGE.  
&&

.LZK WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...NONE.
